column2: The church is a living body, a living organism, and Christians are members of that body, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said in his sermon yesterday at a service marking the 130th anniversary of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Mrs. Jarmilla Vokral of the Salle Herrmann of Philadelphia won the first individual senior women's fencing competition of the season yesterday at the Salle Santelli as she vanquished both Miss Dorothy Locke of the Aldo Nadi Studio, a former national champion, and Miss Barbara Cochrane of the Salle Santelli in a fence-off for the first place medal.

The United States continued to be the chief source of origin of imports into Liberia during the first eight months of 1938, according to a report from Monrovia received today by the Department of Commerce.
President Lazaro Cardenas, at his country residence, Los Pinos, on the outskirts of Mexico City, reiterated yesterday that his administration was not communistic.

The present numerical air superiority of Germany is challenged by Major George Fielding Eliot, writer on military affairs, in the Dec. 15 issue of the Foreign Policy Association's Reports, made public today.
No perceptible economic influence has been felt in Germany from the new Franco-Italian dispute, the Italian demands not being taken seriously here.

A score of radio, musical comedy and night club entertainers gave a vaudeville show for 1,800 Sing Sing prisoners this afternoon. Because of the limited seating capacity of the prison auditorium 900 other prisoners were unable to attend.
A number of anglers, planning to take Winter cruises, seem to be interested in the fishing possibilities on their stop-overs, and the West Indies, Cuba and Bermuda seem to be the favored points.
A better feeling in Wall Street has had its effect in improving the disposition of the Bourse. The impression in financial circles continues favorable concerning the position in the United States.

The amount of obligations incurred for public relief in thirty-four States and the District of Columbia in November increased by 4 per cent as compared with October, the Social Security Board reported today. An increase of 1 per cent in the number of relief cases was reported.

Loans financing many properties in scattered sections have been announced by brokers. A building loan of $205,000 for the erection of a six-story apartment house on the east side of Lexington Avenue, twenty-four feet south of East Twenty-seventh Street, was obtained by the Carjac Realty Corporation through Louis M. Rogovin, broker.
The Misses Fay E. Henld and Frances Rogers are co-chairmen of a tea dance to be held on Dec. 29 in the Silver Room of the Ambassador for the benefit of Greenwich House.
State Senator Walter J. Mahoney announced tonight that he would ask the Legislature next month to investigate the New York State Liquor Authority and the entire beverage control set-up.

Warren Lee Pierson, president of the ExportImport Bank of Washington, arrived in Havana this morning from Miami by plane to investigate the possibilities of extending credits for the construction of various public works projects in Cuba.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange last week, also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks.

A congregation of 1,000 persons paid tribute yesterday morning to the memory of Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, noted radio preacher who died in 1936, at the Brooklyn church where he served continuously as pastor for thirty-five years.

Perry G. Noe, a former Harlan County deputy sheriff who was one of the defendants in the anti-labor conspiracy trial at London earlier this year, was slain today near the Highsplint coal mine, where he was employed as a watchman.
Rain held the field to seventeen winners at the Travers Island traps the New York A. C. yesterday. he best work was done by A. L. ornwell, who broke 97 out of 100 win the high over-all scratch up.
The Yuletide season opened in Berkshire today with a snowfall, and there are high hopes of skiing and other Winter sports for the holidays.

Herbert G. Street, with 81-14-67, and Edward P. O'Reilly, returning 93--26-67, tied for the low net in the third qualifying round of the thirtieth annual Snobird gold tournament for Siwanoy members today. Forty players participated, with thirty posting scores.

A federation of the British West e Indies with dominion status is expected to be one of the outcomes when the West Indies Royal Commission, now studying conditions in these colonies, reports through the Colonial Office to Parliament, probably next Summer.

A crowd of 15,000 puzzled but enthusiastic Frenchmen and sailors from United States ships in the harbor saw Jimmy Crowley's all-star American football team beat a selected eleven of French rugby players and former United States stars, 32-20, today.
Led by Ogden Phipps and William Fand, the national champions, Long Island won the Payne Whitney Memorial intercity court tennis doubles tournament today for the first time.

Recognizing the difficulty of enforcing uniform legislation to curb proselyting and scholarships, the South's major athletic conferences have taken off the wraps with the idea of allowing each school to handle its own affairs.
Bill Campbell's Chip and Allan Clark's Penguin, each of which won three races in its class, were the leading boats today in the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association's weekly regatta.
It cannot be denied that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's London visit aroused great interest and much speculation concerning its objects and outcome.

The doubling of the price of labels used on garments manufactured by members of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, decided upon recently as a means of raising $275,000 for refugee relief, will go into effect today, it was announced last night by John Frumkes, chairman of the board of trustees that will administer the fund.

The Crescent A. C. hockey team strengthened its hold on second place in the New York Amateur Hockey Association with a 7-to-4 triumph over the New York Sporting Club at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Mrs. Estelle Powers Egbert, wife of the Rev. Dr. George Drew Egbert, pastor of the First Congregational in Flushing, died there yesterday at their residence, 38-20 Bowne Street, of heart disease after an illness of eight months. Her husband is president of the New York Society for the Prevention of Crime.

Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, addressing members of the American Foreign Service in a holiday 'program, said that "the past year has tested the American Foreign Service as it has never been tested before and, therefore, in simple justice, my first words to the members of the service-officers, clerks and employees of all groups-must be of warmest congratulation.

The Winter concert series at the Greenwich Library, sponsored each season by Mrs. James Goldmark, chairman of the committee; Mrs. James H. Perkins, treasurer, and other prominent residents, opened this afternoon.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Alexander Linen Jr. of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Tuthill Linen, to John Collett Goodbody, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice F. Goodbody of Ridgewood, N. J.

Whittlesey House has received the manuscript of a new book by Charles E. Merriam, chairman of the Department of Political Science at the University of Chicago. It will be published in the Spring under the title "The New Democracy and the New Depotism."

American foreign policy is seemingly undergoing a radical change, in the view of Diplomatische Korrespondenz, German Foreign Office organ, which, referring to "United States antagonism" against Germany and other totalitarian states as reflected in statements by responsible Americans, says:
The sixth concert of the Federal Music Project's Beethoven symphonic series drew a capacity house last night at the Federal Music Theatre.
Nelson H. Demorest, last surviving Civil War veteran in Yates County, died last night at the home of his son, John, in Kenmore, Erie County, at the age of 92.
Only three schools for practical nurses have received tentative approval from the State Education Department, it was announced today. Several others, however, are under consideration.

Ten days have passed since a Rebel offensive was supposedly scheduled to begin and, instead of improving, the weather has become worse. Under present circumstances, the Loyalists believe, the drive is improbable if not impossible, since the Insurgents' case is different from that of the government at Teruel a year ago.

Marguerite St. Clair, in 16 W 64th St; Louis W. Black, Ben V. Schwartz. Mrs. Mary C. Nichols, in 260 West End Ave; Simon Kosofsky, Zysman Szuchman, in 305 W 72d St; Thomas J. Shea, Albert E. Kay, in 22 Riverside Dr; Alfred L. Cross, In 229 W 78th St: Mrs. Edith Freudenthal,

Six American colleges in the Near East affiliated with the Near last College Association will benefit by the matinee on Dec. 28 of "Siegfried" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The event represents the twelfth annual opera benefit sponsored by the association.

The proposal of the Westchester County Water Commission to spend more than $32,000,000 for a new water system is meeting with many protests from Westchester taxpayers' associations and from other counties whose officials object to their watersheds being seized, it was learned today.

Joseph L. Sheeketski, backfield coach at Holy Cross the last six seasons, tonight was named head football coach. He succeeds Dr. Eddie Anderson, who resigned three weeks ago to accept a position at the University of Iowa.

The price of lard'futures on the Board of Trade is holding around the lowest level of the season. Hedging pressure increased last week and there was scattered liquidation by holders of the deferred deliveries incident to the prospects of a steady increase in local stocks.

Expressing alarm at the increase in the number of surgical operations performed throughout the country, Dr. J. J. Golub, director of the Hospital for Joint Diseases, suggests the establishment in New York of "regional consultation'" boards to consider the cases of persons who have been advised to submit to surgical operations.

Several foreign shipping companies are reported to be considering a schedle of speical curises from foreign ports to New York in connection with the World's Fair next year. In view of the city's regulations against the use of steamship for restaurant or hotel purpose.
The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday:

With the basketball season in the metropolitan district well under way, six of the leading colleges still boast undefeated records. They are St. John's, Fordham, Manhattan, N. Y. U., L. I. U. and Columbia. St. Francis, C. C. N. Y. and Brooklyn College are the only ones that have been beaten and St. Francis and C. C. N. Y. came along strongly during the week.

A purchase for cash near Madison Square Garden has been made by an investor, who has acquired from the Kesgel Corporation the four-story business building at 830 Eighth Avenue, northeast corner of Fiftieth Street.

Police Captain Edwin C. McGrath, in command of the Wadsworth Avenue station, 182d Street and Wadsworth Avenue, died yesterday in Fitch's Sanitarium, 184th Street and Loring Place, the Bronx, of a heart ailment. He was 50 years old and lived at 2,685 University Avenue, the Bronx.
Miss Caroline Matilda Caswell, social worker and founder and honorary president of the Frances E. Willard Settlement in Boston, died today in her home here. She was 74 years old.

C. Walter Hill, a newspaper compositor for more than forty years, died suddenly late Saturday night at his home, 319 West Forty-second Street, at the age of 67. He had fallen earlier in the evening while in a motion-picture theatre, suffering injuries which may have contributed to his death.
After negotiations lasting nine months a new trade agreement between the United States and Turkey has been initialed at Angora.

Stars of the stage and leading figures of literature, the arts and sciences have joined to sponsor a New Year's Eve ball to be held at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street, for the benefit of political refugees from Germany.
New records in attendance and pari-mutuel betting appeared likely tonight for the Florida racing season, opening tomorrow at Tropical Park.

A 20-year-old private in Company K of the Eighteenth Infantry at Fort Wadsworth, Staten Island, was killed early this morning by a truck on Bayonne ,Bridge after he had been in at least one and probably two previous accidents.
Secretary Ickes recommended legislation today to enable the government to check overproduction and waste of mineral resources -vital to the national defense.
Many persons were feared today to have perished in a series of violent earth shocks over a period of twenty-three hours in the Kirshehir area of Central Anatolia.
George Shako Jr., a junior of Westhampton Beach, L. I. has been elected captain of the Rensselaer Poly football squad for next year.

Lieutenant Matthew J. Crawley of Fire Rescue Company No. 4, Woodhaven, Queens, died yesterday after an illness of eight weeks at the home of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Mary Ibert, 43 Lee Avenue, Valley Stream, L. I. He was 48 years old.
The Social Security Advisory Council was appointed jointly by a Senate special committee on social security and the Social Security Board in May, 1937.

Prices of cotton moved in a narrow range last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange active future deliveries showed net changes of 6 points decline to 1 point advance. At the present level cotton is about midway between the high and low points of this season.

The Board of Education wisely announces public hearings on Colonel Carlin's resolution that the use of school buildings be denied for meetings dealing with subjects "of a controversial nature liable to arouse ill-feeling, jealousy or dissension."

Markets and industrial reports last week presented the more or less contradictory picture which is usual with an approaching year-end. In particular, the Stock Exchange reflected its frequent change of view regarding the immediate future. Whereas, a week before,

Year-end monetary pressure has not yet developed, but discount loan rates are becoming firmer. Last year ended without any pressure but, although official policy and action are keeping money cheap, there is no doubt that there has been a substantial contraction in credit supplies because of the heavy flow of capital to the United States and the withdrawal of French funds.
Last Monday brought a sudden reversal of the stock market tendency, with all securities, both French and foreign, falling sharply.

The Health Department announced yesterday that the Board of Health had adopted a regulation requiring concerns engaged in chemically treating water supply systems in buildings to obtain permits from the department.

ARENDT-At Freeport, L. I., on Sunday. Dec. 18, 1938, Mary Adelaide, beloved wife of Herman 0. Arendt and daughter of John J. Nolan, in her forty-eighth year. Funeral from her residence, 11 May Court, Freeport, Wednesday, Dec. 21, at 9:30 A. M.; thence to the Church of Our Holy Redeemer, South Ocean Ave., Freeport, where Mass will be offered at 10 A. M. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Brooklyn. Please omit flowers.
The French wholesale price index on Dec. 10 was 654, compared with 655 and 658, one and two weeks previously.

The harum-scarum actions of a hundred or so members of the younger social set, bicycling recklessly through Central Park and on Fifth Avenue, were responsible yesterday for widespread frightening of taxi drivers and double-decker omnibus chauffeurs.
Farmer rejection of New Deal marketing controls for next year's burley and dark type tobacco crops led many members of Congress to predict today that the present farm law would be changed.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,563,599,850. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.
Dinner, Ohio Society, Hotel Pennsylvania, 6:35 P. M. "Current Problems in tanking," Professor Major B. Foster.

The Anti-Saloon League of America named as its president tonight Bishop Ralph Cushman of the Denver area of the Methodist Episcopal Church and reaffirmed its stand against liquor at its thirtieth annual national convention.

The United Hebrew Trades, central organization of Jewish trade unions in this city, with a total membership of 250,000, yesterday marked the fiftieth anniversary of its founding with a message to President William Green of the American Federation of Labor assuring him of the organization's undivided loyalty to the A. F. of L.

William P. Lawson, former Police. Commissioner, and three business associates were convicted tonight of conspiracy to defraud customers of a brokerage firm formerly headed by Lawson. The others found guilty were' Frank Mueller, Frederick A. Mueller and Vincent L. Clisham.
A third period bombardment which saw them shoot three perfect shots enabled the New Ycrk Americans to defeat the fast-skating Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night.

More M. Beck, a lawyer, who was advisory counsel to the Home Owners Loan Corporation in Newark in 1936-37, died here this morning of heart disease and pneumonia at his home, 1,902 Hudson Boulevard, in his thirty-eighth Year.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Dunlap of Columbia, Mo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Dunlap of Newburgh, N. Y., to Dr. Edward Rochie Hardy Jr. of this city, son of Mr. Hardy of 235 East Twenty-second Street and the late Mrs. Sarah Belcher Hardy.

Boris Kostelanetz, an assistant United States attorney on the staff of Lamar Hardy, and Miss Ethel Cory of this city were married here yesterday afternoon in the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street, by the Rev. Dr. David de Sola Pool.

The Advisory Council on Social Security made public today recommendations for enlarging the scope of benefits of the Social Security Act's old age insurance program, for expanding the system to cover a Iarger proportion of the population and for an improved method of financing the program and handling the necessary funds.

The second match between the Brookhattan F. C. and the Prague Football Club, necessary to break the tie between them in the second round of the National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Football Association, was played at Steinway Oval yesterday and Brookhattan won. 2 to 0.
The next time some one rents an airplane at Murchio's Airport here the attendants will take careful note of his name and address, and probably require a deposit to assure return of the craft.

With only six working days left the eighth Pan-American Conference was confronted today with the task of taking action on nearly 150 projects 'during the coming week in addition to working out a compromise between the divergent viewpoints of Argentina and the-United States on the keynote problem of continental solidarity.

The money market here remained liquid last week as a result of preparations which had to be made for quarterly taxation payments on Dec. 10, preChristmas payments of wages and salaries and the first installment of the Jewish fine.

A row of apartment houses on the upper West Side, near Central Park West, passed to new control in a deal announced over the weekend, when the four five-story buildings at 13 to 19 West 106th Street were sold by the Union Dime Savings Bank.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor arrived in Cannes this morning to spend Christmas at their leased home at Cap d'Antibes. It is expected they will have a number of friends visiting them.
The decline of more than [Pound]87,000,000 in Great Britain's imports since April must be associated with two factors, one being lessened trade activity and the other the fall in prices.

Reports on the Reich's financial situation show that the floating debt at the end of October had increased from 4,753,000,000 to 4,890,000,000 marks, the rise being due principally to maturity of the first batch of "delivery bonds" on Oct. 20.

The Rev. Norman B. Nash, Professor of Christian Social Ethics at the Episcopal Theological School, Cambridge, Mass., today was named rector of St. Paul's school here. He succeeds the late Dr. Samuel S. Drury.

Owing to the late pelting season in Norway and Sweden this year, the offering of 5,382 silver fox skins at the first 1938-1939 season sale recently held by the Hudson's Bay Company was considerably less in quantity than at the corresponding auction last year, according to a report from London, made public by the Department of Commerce.

John H. O'Day, Assistant United States Attorney during the World War and for a number of years prominent in political, legal and civic life of Buffalo, died this morning at his home in Snyder of coronary thrombosis. His age was 59 years.

The six-story apartment house at 2,109 Gleason Avenue, the Bronx, on a plot 53 by 95 feet, has been sold by the Lorillard Construction Company, Inc., to George J. Feinstein and Melvin Kaufman, for cash above a first mortgage of $62,600.
German savings bank deposits in November rose 183,000,000 marks, 80,000,000 more than a year ago, and amounted to 573.700.000 marks.

Dr. William Cabell Rives, noted physician and philanthropist, died here yesterday at the age of 89. Funeral services will be held Wednesday in the Washington Cathedral, of which he was a trustee and benefactor, and burial will be at Newport, R. I.

Colonel Grigori Vulturescu, chief of staff of the Second Army Corps, shot and killed himself this morning after an all-night party. Colonel Vulturescu attended the party accompanied by several other high officers and social notables.

Calling for intensification of the anti-Nazi boycott, the joint boycott council of the American Jewish Congress and Jewish Labor Committee met yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor when more than 500 men and women approved of a definite stand rejecting the Nazi "ransom plan."

Designation of the Rutgers varsity football team as a champion eleven was made today by Geroge E. Little, director of physical education, when the winners of varsity awards and class insignia in Fall sports were announced.
Earle C. Gordon, assistant treasurer of Dartmouth College, died of a heart attack this afternoon while conversing with a friend on the main street of Hanover. He was 51 years old last Monday.
Are we to live like Mendicant the Moon that borrows light of the sun? the moon's self light is gone, the early glow is done and still she takes the sky at night in trappings of the sun's light.

A resolution expressing sympathy for the oppressed minorities of Germany and urging President Roosevelt to sever diplomatic relations with the Nazi Government on the ground that its representatives in this country were plotting against our national security was adopted this afternoon at the first convention of the North Jersey branch of the German-American League for Culture.
The National Boxing Association in its quarterly ratings today ranked Tony Galento next to Champion Joe Louis among the world's heavyweight fighters.

The Brooklyn - Hispanos of the American Soccer League defeated the Danish eleven of the National League, 1 to 0, in the second round of the National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Football Association at Celtic Park yesterday.
Edward W. Cahill, United States Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization here, died last night following a heart attack. His age was 58.
By an overwhelming standing vote today, the California Medical Association approved a plan of socialized medicine to cost residents of the State about $2.50 a month.

The outworld need not believe that the United States will permit any foreign government to gain a foothold in this hemisphere, whether a Democrat or a Republican occupies the White House, Alfred M. Landon, former Presidential candidate, said tonight in a radio address carried by the National Broadcasting Company.

A sudden spell of cold following a period of unusual midlness placed the whole of Britain in the grip of frost today. Sub-freezing temperatures were registered in some parts, accompanied by strong, icy winds that reached gale force in some places, notably Scotland.

DOUGLAS CORRIGAN has made as successful a flight with his pen as with his plane. He took no co-pilot when he risked the perils of the sea, and he has taken no ghost writer to help him across the uncertainties of autobiography, but he has reached his goal of self-expression successfully in "That's My Story."*

Living costs in the United States declined two-tenths of 1 per cent from October to November, according to the statistical division of the National Industrial, Conference Board in its monthly survey issued yesterday. Decreases in food prices and rent more than offset a seasonal rise in the cost of coal.

The Passacaglia in A minor, by Charles Haubiel, which shared the honors of the Philharmonic-Sym- Liszt phony's American Composers' Con- in E test of last season, was introduced under the baton of the composer were yesterday afternoon at the orchestra's concert in Carnegie Hall.
A three-alarm fire, with leaping flames visible to thousands of persons in surrounding areas, put the navy yard In Brooklyn temporarily on an emergency footing at 8 o'clock last night.

Turnover on the Boerse here remained small last week, but a confident note prevailed, because a feasible solution of the Jewish liquidation problem seemed in sight and developments on the labor market were favorable. Several dividend increases, too, were announced.

Dr. U. Conrad Vincent, one of the leading colored surgeons of the city, who was the first member of his race to serve as an interne in Bellevue Hospital, died yesterday at his residence, 251 West 138th Street, at the age of 45. Although suffering from a liver ailment since June, he had continued at his work until Saturday night.

A national conference of the Order of the Sons of Zion, which had purchased a tract of land in Palestine for an American colony, voted yesterday at the Hotel Astor to allocate the property for the settlement of German-Jewish refugees.

On the first day of Christmas week the Neediest Cases Fund for 1938 lags more than $30,000 behind its standing on the corresponding day of the 1937 appeal. Gifts of $2,713.21-with one exception, the smallest acount received in any day since the present appeal opened on Dec. 4-reached the Fund yesterday.
Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Winchester, Mass., won the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament today with a seventy-two hole score of 275, 5 under par and one stroke in front of Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa.

Sir Leslie Probyn, Governor of Jamaica, 19181924, died yesterday at Folkstone at the age of 76. Sir Leslie, who received his knighthood in 1909, was a lawyer and in the Nineties served as Attorney General of British Honduras and Grenada.

The agreement just reached by the Reich with Italy foreshadows an increase of German exports to Italy from 311,000,000 marks in 1937 to 350,000,000 in 1939, the increase being largely due to contributions to be made by Austria and the Sudetenland.

The strike of platform men and checkers employed at long-distance truck-freight terminals was terminated officially yesterday when the terms of the agreement between the Motor Bus and Terminal Checkers, Platform. and Office Workers, Local 21,510, A. F. L. affiliate, and the Highway Transport Association.

A fashion show and tea will be held on Jan. 18 under the auspices or the Rector's Guild of St. James Church in the church auditorium, 31 East Seventy-first Street. Proceeds will provide furnishings for the new parish house. The Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan is rector of St. James.

After fighting the fire for several hours, members of Paulsboro's two fire companies abandoned tonight efforts to save the burning plant and storage buildings of the J. Howard Coombs Lumber Company, and directed their efforts to protecting near-by residences.

The Rev. Charles Howard Cadigan announced today his resignation as rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Amherst, and as director of reli- "H gious activities at Amherst College, a dual position which he has held Chi for nearly nine years.

Mr. and Mrs. Willis T. Williamson of this city have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Barbara Thielen, to Fred Maidment Huntington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Huntington of Sea Cliff, L. I.

Recalling that Christmastide is a reminder of peace and good-will, "the peace which still has the power to save the world if the world would only accept it," President Roosevelt sent a message read yesterday afternoon at the annual Clement Clarke Moore Memorial Service at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 344 West Twentieth Street.

Against a Victorian background in which the old-fashioned waltz will predominate over the newer dance fads, the 148 juniors of the College of New Rochelle will hold their annual promenade in the Sports Building on the campus here Wednesday evening, Miss Virginia Cronan of the Bronx, chairman, announced today.

The Congress of Industrial Organization's fight against the 'Oregon' initiative petition controlling labor unions, which sharply limits the definition of a labor dispute, will start tomorrow with the opening of hearings before the Social Security Board on the effect of the new Oregon law, approved at the recent State election, on the State Unemployment Compensation Law, Lee Pressman, C. I. 0. attorney, said today.
Pope Pius braved cold and rainy weather today to go to the Pontifical Academy of Science in the Vatican gardens to preside at the opening of the third academic year.

With mill margins touching record lows on many fabrics, the total textile investment failed to earn its keep in 1938 despite exceptional price stability, according to the annual review of the textile markets prepared by Scheuer Co., textile consultants and brokers, issued for publication today.

The ashes of Valery Chkaloff, pilot of the first transpolar flight to America who was killed in an aviation accident last Thursday, were sealed in the Kremlin wall today with all the pomp and circumstance with which the Soviet honors its, greatest dead.

A suggestion that a "substantial increase" be provided in the budget of the State Civil Service Commission "in order to vitalize the administration of the State civil service" has been forwarded to Governor Lehman in a letter,

Final organization of the projected United States Trotting Association, nationwide parent body of harness horse activities, will be perfected here Jan. 7 and 8, committeemen said today, after representatives of three organizations to be merged into the larger group had completed four days of negotiations on the consolidation program.

Rush orders for fill-ins on holiday merchandise arrived in large numhers in the New York wholesale markets last week. Although gift items were most in demand, the apparel divisions, nevertheless, were unusually busy.
Frankie Brimsek, young goalie of the Boston Bruins, ran his string of shutouts to five in the last six games as the leaders of the National Hockey League race beat the Red Wings, 2 to 0, tonight.
According to Colonel C. S. Ridley, Governor of the Panama Canal Zone, 5,387 commercial vessels carrying 28,058,109 tons passed through the locks in the fiscal year 1938.

Two residents of New York City, one a graduate of City College and the other of Williams College, a Washingtonian and a Philadelphian, seniors at Cornell University and the University of Pennsylvania, respectively, comprise the group elected as Rhodes scholars yesterday from the Middle Atlantic District.
An announcement today by Joseph Buerckel, Commissioner for Austria, regarding Herr Gerhold, a wealthy "Aryan" retired moneylender, surprised and puzzled Viennese.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have prepared, with the cooperation of Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin. some facts which a member of the New York State Liquor Authority in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Dec. 4, 1938, failed to give. We also desire to call attention to other results of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. P

Curling, that ancient ice sport, invented by the Dutch some six centuries ago, but adopted and perfected by the Scots since the seventeenth century, again held the spotlight in the golden jubilee celebration at the St. Andrews Golf Club today and tonight. To the comparatively few "experts" the results of the finals were merely secondary.

The Rev. Dr. Marcus Acheson Brownson, pastor emeritus of the Tenth Presbyterian Church of Philadelphia, died today at Southern Pines, N. C., where he had made his Winter home since his retirement in 1924. He was 79 years old.

A booing, shouting crowd of 2,000 persons picketed radio station WMCA at 1,657 Broadway for more than two hours yesterday afternoon in protest against the station's refusal three weeks ago to give Father Charles E. Coughlin time on the air when he failed to submit a copy of his scheduled broadcast.

The initial meeting of a students' organization to coordinate the extracurricular activities of colleges in the metropolitan area was held last night at the West Side Y. M. C. A., 5 West Sixty-third Street.

A 3.5 per cent decrease in New York's construction employment in November wbas attributed today by the State Department of Labor to "the usual seasonal reduction" and observance of Armistice and election days.

The Chesapeake Corporation, holding company of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, transferred today 1,079,432 shares of its holdings of common stock in the C. to 3,241 stockholders in the corporation. The current value of the stock exceeded $39,000,000.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 79.8, which compared with 79.8 the week before, 80.4 two weeks before, 80.5 three weeks before and 80.4 four weeks before.

Shepard Rareshide, retired vice president and former member of the board of directors of the Borden Company, died Saturday afternoon after a long illness at the Presbyterian Hospital, it was announced here yesterday by members of his family. Mr. Rareshide, who was 58 years old, had resided for the last fifteen years at 85 Laurel Hill Road, Mountain Lakes. N. J.

When the influence of Christian- te ity is overcome, as it is today in Nazi Germany, the "worst chaos of paganism" is the result, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise said yesterday in his sermon during special Hanukkah a services in the Free Synagogue at Carnegie Hall.

On information supplied by the police, of Kingston, Pa., the New York police sent out an eight-State alarm last night for Miss Margaret Martin, 20 years old, of Kingston, who is believed by the police to have been kidnapped.
Following a custom of years' standing 'an annual Christmas carol concert was given this afternoon at the county, center by. 3,000 adults and children from all sec-. tions of Westchester County.

Price movements in United States wheat markets last week were limited, and routine news had little or no effect. Sentiment, however, remains generally bearish, because of the statistical position, but operators are afraid to sell futures freely, fearing that the amount of grain that will go 'into the government loan and be taken to cover recent export sales to Great Britain will be sufficient to prevent any decline of consequence in prices.

Clarita Martin, who has not appeared here since her debut recital in 1934, gave a recital of Spanish dances last night at the Guild Theatre. Assisting her were Antonio del Val, baritone, and Owen Haynes, pianist.
The final report of the Advisory Council on Social Security, appointed by the Senate Special Committee, was made public today. The text of the report follows:

Joseph S. Lesser, John McPherson and J. M. Ligon are in the retail sales division of Seligman, Lubetkin Co., Inc. The New York Stock Exchange firm of Bull Eldredge has moved to 1 Wall Street at Mitchell, Hutchins Co.
Several Latin-American delegations . are preparing to wage a bitter battle against the United States delegation on its proposal to abolish the Inter-American Commission of Women as it now exists.
Christmas currency demands were solely responsible for a further rise last week of [Pound]7,600,000 in the circulation of the Bank of England.

Adults were urged to accept their religion with the faith and imagination that children accept Christmas in a sermon yesterday by Professor Frederic C. Grant of the faculty of Union Theological Seminary at the James Memorial Chapel, Broadway and 120th Street.

Amendment of the Wagner National Labor Relations Act to "restore youth's opportunity for employment" was urged yesterday in a letter to President Roosevelt, signed by Alfred M. Lilienthal, president, and members of the board of directors of the First Voters League.

Plans for a $100,000 self-liquidating New York City Information Center. to be built under the vehicular viaduct in Pershing Square directly opposite the Grand Central Terminal were outlined in a report submitted to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Stanley M. IsaacE, President of the Borough of Manhattan.

The following dispatch, the first of. a series, was sent by a staff correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES after a tour of provincial Germany. It was written in Paris and so not subject to German censorship.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Roy Allen of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Patricia Allen, to Francis Newton Carpenter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carpenter of 108 East Eighty-first Street, New York.
Year after year we recall, especially at this season, the degrees of charity as defined by.Maimonides, one of the great religious leaders of all times, who was born in Spain eight hundred years ago.

Davis Ave (18-5599), w s, 200 ft s of Miles Ave. 50x100: Peter Aarts to Anne Lorusso. 37-05 64th St, Woodslde, L. I. Barnes Ave, 4,184 (17-4846): Eastchester Savings Bank to Minnie Tulumello, 918 E 216th St. Tiffany St, 1,062 (10-2717) Verner Santangelo to Carl Marggraf, 1,062 Tiffany St.

The Holland-America Line received a wireless message yesterday from Captain Johannes J. Bijl, master of the liner Nieuw Amsterdam, which sailed Saturday for Rio de Janeiro, reporting that a toy airplane, equipped with a tiny gasoline engine, had crashed into the foremast of the ship Saturday afternoon while she was several miles off Sandy Hook.
A molasses avalanche resulted today when a cold wave caused the metal of a huge tank of molasses to contract, allowing more than 4,000 tons of molasses to break loose.

Premier Benito Mussolini today dedicated this new, model coalmining community in Southern Sardinia where, he recalled, only twelve months ago there had been neither men, nor roads nor wateronly solitude and malaria.
R. H. Macy Co., Inc., have negotiated a reduction of the interest rates on $5,000,000 of serial notes from an average of 3.51 per cent to 2.63 per cent, it was announced yesterday.
Twenty-two Eastern football stars, picked by Coaches Bernie Bierman and Andy Kerr, will meet here tomorrow to begin practice for their annual game against the West in San Francisco on Jan. 2.

The Associated Press moved early yesterday morning into its new seventeen-story home in Rockefeller Center from its old quarters at 383 Madison Avenue. It accomplished the shift without the slightest in,terruption in its twenty-four-hour collection and distribution of worldwide news for 1,350 member newspapers of the cooperative, nonprofit organization.

The Board of Estimate, which on Dec. 6 approved the sale of the Sixth Avenue elevated structure for $80,000 to George T. Weissbaum, West Coast scrap metal dealer, will hold a special session at 10:30 A. M. today to act upon Mr. Weissbaum's failure to pay the purchase price and post a performance bond of $45,000 by midnight last Saturday.

Judge Charles B. Faris of the United States Circuit Court, who retired from service in November, 1935, after a quarter of a century on the bench, died today at his home here after an illness of eighteen months. He was 74 years old and never fully recovered from a stroke he suffered in October, 1937.

Miss Katharine Imogene Nicolson, a member of the English Department staff of Adelphi Academy, Brooklyn, died Saturday night of a heart attack at Lake Ronkonkoma, L. I., at the age of 47. Born in Devonshire, England, she was graduated from Radcliffe College, Oxford University, with the degree of Master of Education.

G. W. Pope, A young landscape architect who has been yawning every two minutes or so during his waking hours since Tuesday, presented a problem to his physician today. Apparently healthy and cheerful, he is possessed with an uncontrollable desire to yawn, yet he does not feel sleepy and suffers no pain.

What appears to be a reaction against religion on the part of mod- 700 ern youth is merely a revolt against sentimentalism and improper concepts of religion, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the faculty of the Catholic University of America at Washing- -At ton said in a sermon yesterday at noon the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street, east of Broadway.

The Deborah Jewish Tuberculosis Society, which maintains a free non-sectarian sanatorium at Browns Mills, N. J., last night held its fifteenth anniversary dinner at the Hotel Astor. The 1,000 persons present contributed $23,000, which will be used to pay for additions recently made to the sanatorium.
Five persons were killed and a sixth was injured today when a fast passenger train struck an automobile on a grade crossing at nearby Rocky Ridge.

Negotiations between Czech and British financial experts over the promised British loan of ??10,000,000 to the truncated republic have broken down and the Czech delegation has returned to Prague, The Daily Telegraph says this morning.
This is no place for Cordell Hull. That arch-foe of bilateralism in trade between nations is much better off just now at Lima, with the breadth of a whole continent between him and Uruguay.

Distribution of "Consumer's Protection Labels" by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board yesterday totaled 54,000 in the New York area, the highest for any Dec. 19 since the board was formed.

With a $3,000 grant from the General Education Board of New York City, Princeton University's radio project is embarking on a study of the effects of the recent Orson Welles broadcast of an "invasion" from Mars, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

Adhering to his policy of secrecy, Police Commissioner Valentine refused yesterday to make known the names of the new deputy chief inspector, two inspectors and two deputy inspectors in advance of the graduation ceremony tonight for 177 probationary patrolmen at the 165th Regiment Armory, 68 Lexington Avenue.

" We should not commit future generations to a burden larger than we would want to bear ourselves." This may well prove to be the most important single sentence in the whole report of the Advisory Council on Social Security.

The movement of gold to this country from abroad came to a stop yesterday for the first time in more than three weeks. The metal in London was quoted at the equivalent of $34.779 an ounce, about 21/2 cents above the shipping level, and no engagements of the metal for shipments here ere reported.

Three high school students, one of them a girl, were called as State witnesses yesterday in the General Sessions trial of two alleged leaders of the Ukrainian Hall gang for the kidnapping-of Arthur Fried, 32 years old, a Bronx business man, from the entrance to his White Plains home Dec. 4, 1937.

F. Donald Coster, president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., made his wife, Carol Coster of Fairfield, chief legatee of his estate, it was learned tonight as Samuel Reich, counsel for Coster, prepared to file the will for probate in Fairfield, probably tomorrow. No estimate of the estate was available.

Thomas F. Lynch, counsel for the Isthmian Steamship Company, notified the Maritime Commission today that his client was withdrawing its application for an operatingdifferential subsidy for its 'roundthe-world service.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:
Leo Levine's shot in the final thirty seconds enabled the De Witt Clinton High basketball team to beat Stuyvesant by 29-28 for its fifth victory in a row yesterday.
The Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments next month on a major test of the power of the National Bituminous Coal Commission, one of the many administrative agencies set up under the New Deal.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Drury Jennison of Montclair, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Jennison, to Henry G. Riter 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Riter 3d of Montclair.

Five days before Christmas the 1938 Neediest Cases Fund stands at $150,350.35 as the result of 527 gifts totaling $10,163.92 which reached it yesterday. On the corresponding day of the appeal a year ago the Fund's total was $179,778.28-almost $30,000 more than the sum now available for this work of mercy.
Commissioner Marion M. Caskie of the Interstate Commerce Commission will become chairman of the commission, succeeding Commissioner Walter M. W. Splawn on Jan. 1, was announced today.

The official press censorship of Czecho-Slovakia was tightened up tonight when fifty government officials were established as censors, one of whom will be on duty in the future in every newspaper office and will pass in advance on every line intended for publication.
Mrs. Jane Scales Leslie obtained a divorce today from Warren Leslie Jr., a New York lawyer. They were married in Richmond, Va., in 1926 and have two children.
Kid Chocolate, former world featherweight champion, has retired from all ring activity, his managers, Pincho Gutierrez and Jess Losado, announced today.

Despite the defeat of its State ticket, the Republican party emerged from the recent elections as the leading political party in the State, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey declared last night in his first public address since his campaign.
Seven men were placed in nomination yesterday for the nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange, which will be elected Jan. 9.
The failure of crops other than sugar cane to produce a living had caused increasing pressure by farmers to share in the inelastic sugar quota. share in the inelastic sugar quota.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday reversed the convictions of the Fur Dressers Union, Local 2, and the Fur Workers Union, Local 3, which were prosecuted by John Harlan Amen when he was special assistant to the Attorney General of the United States, for alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

A drive against autograph collectors who regularly annoy prominent theatregoers has been started by the League of New York Theatres, James F. Reilly, executive secretary, announced yesterday afterdiscussing the matter with Lieutenant Hugh McGarvey of the Police Department's Juvenile Aid Bureau.

Magistrate Dreyer in Tombs Court discharged yesterday Nunzio Signorello, 44 years old, of 876 Hendrix Street, Brooklyn, on a disorderly conduct charge lodged against him last Thursday night after a fracas in the office of Commissioner of Investigations Herlands at 2 Lafayette Street.

The Legislature recessed early today until Jan. 10, after adopting a bill providing for a special election June 20, on race track betting, appropriating $75,000 for New Jersey's participation in the New York World's Fair and receiving an offer by railroads to pay $10,100,000, instead of the previously proposed $7,524,000, in settlement of $34,000,000 back taxes.
Hundreds of members of the Miami Winter. colony-attended the opening this afternoon of the racing season at Tropical Park. Today's was the largest opening day throng at the horseracing plant.

Postmaster Albert Goldman called attention yesterday to the fact that there will be no delivery of regular mail on Christmas Day, or on Monday, Dec. 26. He pointed out, however, that delivery of mail may be assured on those days by special delivery service.
The Reich Gazette announces the confiscation of property belonging to some dissolved Catholic organizations.

Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., testified in Supreme Court yesterday that he was obliged to borrow money in 1937 and 1938 to pay his income taxes, although he received upward of $400,000 from the film company in each of these years.

Mayor LaGuardia promised additional public improvements for Queens yesterday when he formally reopened the upper deck of the Queensboro Bridge that had been closed for seventy-six days for resurfacing by the WPA with a nonskid corrugated pavement.

A. Stein Co. will substantially increase their advertising appropriation for, 1939, according to an announcement yesterday. Campaigns in newspapers and roto sections in selected cities will be used together with general magazine advertising in ten magazines and two women's groups, and trade papers.

Babe Ruth's next direct association with baseball probably will be as a radio broadcaster at one of New York's three major league parks if plans for general broadcasting of local ball games materialize.

Plans for the first family's celebration of Christmas were announced today by Mrs. Roosevelt. Christmas parties for the poor will as usual have a large share in Mrs. Roosevelt's program. Annually she assists in the distribution of toys and food baskets and in discussing this activity today she declared that she regarded herself

During the big league baseball convention last week Pie Traynor sighed and said: "Nobody knows what starts a thing like that, and after it starts there's not a thing in the world you can do about it except just sit and suffer."

An assertion that the coming year would be the most properous year for both producers and retailers since 1936 was made by Kenneth Collins of Gimbel Brothers last night at the annual meeting of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, Inc., in the Hotel Governor Clinton.

The four-story apartment house for twelve families at 760 East 232d Street, on the southwest corner of Barnes Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Cotteret Realty Corporation to an investing client of Louis P. Colombo, attorney, for cash above mortgages totaling $27,500.

A plan by which the Gulf, Mobile Northern. Railroad, which is controlled by the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, would acquire the Mobile Ohio Railroad, a subsidiary of the Southern Railway, now in receivership, was announced here yesterday.

The. Mamaroneck Village Board restored Raymond J. Whitney tonight to' the position of Village Manager, from which he was ousted last April after a disagreement with the trustees on the type of incinerator to be built by the village.
Spanish Insurgents reported today the discovery of a "grave spy plot" in which a British Vice Consul had unwittingly played a part.

Mme. Sacha Guitry, whose stage name is Mlle. Jacqueline Delubac, today sued her actor husband for divorce-but the couple will go on being sweethearts in the play "Un Monde Fou," in which they are appearing at the Madeleine and which is one of the theatrical season's outstanding successes.
Negotiations for a new agreement were begun yesterday by the Penn Zone and Midtown Realty Owners Associations with Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union.

Thirty passengers were reported dead and many missing today when a ferryboat sank after a collision with a dredger on the River Tagus. The ferry sank within three minutes at a point 500 yards from the shore when rammed by the dredger.

A lawsuit which may vitally affect the whole question of valuing utility properties for rate-making purposes will be argued before the Supreme Court on Feb. 6, under an order handed down by the court today.

A banking group headed by Eastman, Dillon Co. will offer to the public today about 33,000 shares of prior-preference stock of the Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation. The offering price is $50 a share, plus accrued dividends from Dec.

Representative Bruce Barton, chairman of the advertising agency, Batten, Barton, Durstine Os- b born, Inc., will be the principal speaker before the annual mid- C Winter dinner of the New York State Bankers Association, which will bring to a conclusion the association's usual Winter conference, on Jan. 23.

SERIOUS readers, who can take their international politics straight, without a beautiful spy slinking through every chapter and a kiss kindling the last page, will relish A. Whitney Griswold's "The Far Eastern Policy of the United States."*
Protestant, Catholic and Jewish support of the recently organized American Jewish Federation to Combat Communism, Fascism and Nazism was urged last night in a broadcast over Station WMCA.

Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Gillen of Glendale, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Gillen, to Dr. Charles L. Liberali, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Liberali of Richmond Hill, Queens.
New York reports that the contraband munitions traffic that F. Donald Coster is believed to have carried on may have been centered in Montreal are doubted here.

Young Herschel Grynszpan calmly related today the full story of his shooting of the German Legation third secretary, Ernst vom Rath, whose death in November touched off Germany's latest and widest anti-Jewish campaign.
Forty-nine additional PWA projects, having an estimated total construction cost of $7,009,527, of which loans will provide $732,000 and grants $3,154,285, have been approved by President Roosevelt..

The growing anti-German feeling in Great Britain is likely to benefit certain American exports, according to reports in British commercial circles here. Aside from an increasing disinclination here to buy from a country which permits anti-Jewish excesses, merchants are fearful of more consumer resistance to the purchase of German goods.

Representative Stephen Warfield Gambrill, Democrat, of Maryland, died this afternoon in the office of Dr. George Calver, Capitol physician, following two violent heart attacks suffered within the course of a few minutes. His age was 65.

Speaking the same firm language as that emplayed last week before the Foreign Affairs Commission of the Chamber of Deputies, Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet today declared in the full house that France 'would never yield an inch of territory to Italy and that any attempt to force her to do so could have no other outcome than war.

Carmine Maglioro, 30 years old, of 105-30 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, who was shot in the back while fleeing from a policeman on Oct. 19 and was arrested on a charge of attempted grand larceny, was acquitted of the charge yesterday by a jury before County Judge Thomas Downs in Long Island City.

Five hundred restaurants in the metropolitan area will contribute 5 per cent of tomorrow's receipts to the joint appeal of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and the Brooklyn Jewish Charities, it was announced yesterday.
William J. Lee, former executive clerk of the City Council, died after a long illness at his home, 1,825 Riverside Drive, early yesterday morning at the age of 66.

Aaron Roder, 36 years old, who was convicted last week of violating the policy laws while he was out on bail for a similar offense, was sentenced yesterday by Justice Nathan D. Perlman in Special Sessions in the Bronx to an indeterminate term.

The Federal Government has no intention at this time of releasing Alphonse Capone, now in Alcatraz Prison, Distorict Attorney William J. Campbell said today, because the onetime gang leader has become "a dangerous man" as a result of suffering from paresis and is irrational about a week out of every month.

An interesting experiment in community planning and cooperative building is being carried out on a thirty-acre tract overlooking Fairfield, Conn. Tanaka Park is the name which has been given to this residential colony.
The bodies of Charles S. Rye, 37 years old, and his 6-year-old daughter, Dorothy, were sent back to Chicago tonight as the tragic end of a vacation begun three weeks ago.

The touring Marylebone Cricket Club forced a draw in its match against Southern Transvaal today, but the Springboks were in a dominating position when the time limit was reached in the three-day contest.

Buenos Aires is the hub of opposition to the. United States on this continent. Prejudice-which seldom becomes actual hostility individually but often develops into suspicion of "North" Americans collectively-is to be found, in some form or other, all over Latin America, even in essentially proAmerican Brazil.

Chinese picketing to prevent the shipment of materials to Japan spread tonight to a second ship and was scheduled to extend tomorrow to the offices of Almon Roth, president of the San Francisco Waterfront Employers Association, in protest against what spokesmen asserted was his threat to tie up the port.
Grosset Dunlap, Inc., book publishers, have rented about 10,000 square feet of space on the eleventh floor of 1,107 Broadway, to which the firm's New York offices will be moved.
Methods of planning for better financial control will be discussed at a finance. conference to be held by the American Management Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Jan. 25 and 26.
Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff was hostess this evening at a dinner in Casa Marcheta for Emerson Buckley, new director of the Romanies.

In a complaint against Herman Schwinn, leader of the Western GermanAmerican Bund, filed today by Federal District Attorney Benjamin Harrison, cancellation of his citizenship is asked on the grounds of fraud.

An agreement, extending for two years the undertaking of the Japanese textile industry to limit its shipments of cotton textiles to the United States within fixed quotas, was signed last night at the Nippon Club, 161 West Ninety-third Street.
Warners tory announced the purchase of "Invisible Stripes," a prison story by Lewis E. Lawes and Jonathan Finn, to be used as a vehicle for James Cagney and John Garfield.

A supplemental summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal shareholders in October made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed, among other sales, one of 15,200 shares of the $5-par value common stock of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation by Charles W. Nash, a director.
Mr. and Mrs. John J. Geiger of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Geiger, to Daniel A. Young Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Young of Glen Ridge.
The Eastern All-Stars went through their first workout today in Northwestern's Dyche Stadium in preparation for their post-season game with the Western All-Stars at San Francisco Jan. 2.
Prince Ulrich Kinsky died this morning in the offices of the racing association here of a heart attack at the age of 44.

Fourteen costumed Kriss Kringles, mostly unemployed, gathered yesterday on a balcony overlooking an. ice rink in West Fiftysecond Street to see what could be done about reviving an interest in Santa Claus and elevating the "standards of the profession."

German authorities today issued a communique confirming that during his three-day conferences in London, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, had "developed certain ideas on how the emigration of Jews could be facilitated with German co-aid."

Westchester County departmental and special district budgets for 1939, totaling almost $5,000,000 less than county officials had requested, were completed today by the budget appropriations committee of the Board of Supervisors and submitted to the board for adoption Dec. 29.
Warren T. McCray, former Republican Governor of Indiana, died of a heart attack at dinner tonight at his home near here. He was 73 years old.

Two empty ten-car trains of the Long Island Railroad were in collision at 5:27 P. M. yesterday just west of the passenger platforms in Pennsylvania Station, partly tying up traffic out of the station for more than an hour and delayed several thousand homeward-bound commuters.
President Roosevelt has expressed his approval of the movement at Harvard University and other institutions of higher education to assist refugee students from Germany, it was disclosed here today.
Ave A, 210-12; 4-story tenement and stores, 51.9x95; Bank of New York and Trust Co, trustee, against Julius Goodby, Inc; due, $39,119; taxes, etc, $1,617; to plaintiff for $30,667.

Release of Wild Bill Hallahan, veteran southpaw pitcher for the Phillies, was announced today by President Gerry Nugent. Hallahan, rated as one of the wealthiest players in baseball, said he might forsake the game for a year to take a cruise around the world.
President Roosevelt approved today a report of a Marine Corps selection board recommending the promotion of twenty-four captains to majors, and twventy-seven first lieutenants to captains.

Bryant McQuillen and Samuel Gottlieb of Boston failed today to get a Supreme Court review in their effort to force Dillon, Read Co. of New York to surrender certain stock of the National Cash Register Company.

After a meeting in which 200 representatives of religious organizations spoke in favor of the step, the Board of Education. tonight rescinded a nine-year-old ban on the singing of some of the best known Christmas carols in Mount Vernon public schools.
The international stock market indices for Dec. 17, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
Raymond Hervey de Montmorency, one- of the best amateur golfers of his day, and noted for his accuracy and untiring powers of concentration, died today at the age of 67.

Robert Ridgway, New York civil engineer' and a member of Secretary Ickes's Chicago Subway Commission, died tonight in a hospital here. His age was 76. Physicians said death was caused by coronary thrombosis.

Importers' hopes for modification of the government decree imposing German marking requirements and "blacklist" duties on merchandise from the Sudeten area were shattered yesterday with word from the State Department to the National Council of American Importers that no change is possible in the original ruling of Nov. 9.

Sixto Escobar, world bantamweight w boxing champion, failed to win a round tonight, and Al Mancini, Providence, R. I., fighter, easily captured a ten-round decision. Esco- m bar weighed 1211/4, while Mancini weighed 1241/4. Escobar's title was B not at stake.
The police here sought today to determine how Marguerite Johnstone, 35 years old, a concert pianist, suffered severe bruises and a brain concussion.

Securities and Exchange Commission investigators turned last night from the criminal aspects of the McKesson . Robbins case to a study-of the accounting procedure which had allowed the Musica brothers to siphon "between $4,500,000 and $5,000,000" out of the company "by payments for goods and services never received," in the period from 1932 to date.

The New York Women's Bar Association forwarded a resolution to Governor Lehman yesterday, urging him to appoint a woman to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court bench caused by the resignation of Charles Poletti, Lieutenant Governor-elect.
The Agriculture Department, in its final crop report of the year, said today that on a per capital basis the level of farm production during 1988 was not high.

Purdue used fifteen players to subdue Connecticut State in a basketball game tonight, 51 to 30. The Boilermakers led at the half, 21 to 16. Before the game tribute was paid to Don White, Connecticut coach and one of the greatest players in Purdae history. White led the Big Ten in scoring in 1921.

When the World's Fair crowds flock to New York next year they will come brimming over with questions. Where, what, when or how will be on the tip of every visitor's tongue. Where can. I stay? What shows can I see? When is the Metropolitan, Museum open? How do I get to the Fair grounds?

Gross revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad 'in the first ten months of this year decreased 24.9 per cent from the same period in 1397, M. W. Clement, president, said yesterday in a statement accompanying checks issued in payment of the current dividend of the company.
Man, as the saying goes, is the animal that laughs. The statement is not, of course, quite accurate. The hyena laughs, as do certain birds, and the horse cannot always keep a straight face.

Speaking here today at a luncheon of the Economic Club, Senator Pat Harrison of Mississippi, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, declared that it would be much wiser for the Federal Government to devise plans that would encourage private industry to give employment than for it to continue its present relief program.

The annual report of the Cudahy Packing Company and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 29, released today by E. A. Cudahy Jr., president, shows a net loss of $2,953,895 after expenses, depreciation, interest and provision for taxes. In the preceding year,
Mrs. William Maxwell Evarts gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 119 East Sixty-fifth Street, to introduce her debutante niece, Miss Cynthia Landon, to older friends of the family.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Powers of Glen Cove, L. I., gave a tea. dance yesterday in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce their daughter, Miss Marie Elise Powers. Silvered eucalyptus trees and white pompon chrysanthemums were used in the decorations.

Wendell P. Blagden, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 160 East Forty-eighth Street. He was 56 years old, a son of the late Samuel P. Blagden.

The inauguration of a one-party system in Rumania and the consequent outlawing of old political groups was signalized today by the closing of the newspaper Viitorul for forty years the organ of the once omnipotent Liberal party.

Katharine Cornell is not only going to be the star of "No Time for Comedy," the S. N. Behrman play, but she is to receive equal billing with the Playwrights Company as co-producer. The billing is to read:

DER ROSENKAVALIER, opera in three acts in German. Book by Hugo von Hofmannsthal: music by Richard Strauss. At the Metropolitan Opera House. Conductor, Artur Bodanzky; chorus master, Konrad Neuger; stage director, Leopold Sachse.

A contract for the sale of 2,000,000 army rifles was produced by surprise in the State investigation of the mysterious operations of the crude drug department of McKesson Robbins, Inc., and was immediately turned over to the battery of Federal investigating agencies which assembled here in conference yesterday.

Trading was fair to slow in local markets yesterday. The lamb market was lower and other classes of traefer meats little changed in price. The luggers' and cutters' strike in houses dispensing western dressed meats appears to be settled, but pickets are still curtailing kosher business in one large slaughter house.

The United States Government has been informed that the rights of American citizens will be fully observed in the Italian anti-Semitic program, Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary iti of State, said today.
Stark Young's translation of "The Sea Gull" by Anton Chekhov, as produced by Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne and presented by the Theatre Guild, will be published in book form by Scribner on Jan. 16.
New Jai Alai Player HerePedro Constantine, who hails om Havana, has been added to ??e list of jai alai players at the New York Hippodrome, according an announcement yesterday.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 51.7 per cent of capacity, compared with 57.6 per cent last week, a decline of 5.9 points, or 10.2 per cent, according to the American Iron'and Steel Institute. A month ago operations were at 61.9 per cent of capacity.
It looks as though the distinction of shooting the finest deer taken in Northern New Jersey will go to Miss Helen Odell of Macopin, in Passaic County.
For the second time in three nights, Butler University's basketball team defeated a Big Ten quintet, taking a 24-to-21 decision tonight from the University of Wisconsin before 3,500 fans.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 19, unless specified: At San Diego: Sonoma, Sandpiper, Dec. 18; Arctic, Bobolink Shaw. At Manila, Dec. 18: J. D. Ford, Pope. Erie, Galapagos to Cocos Island, Dec. 18. Guam, Hankow to Shanghal. Kanawha, San Pedro to San Diego. Nitro, Guantanamo to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk.

Cash over a purchase money first mortgage of $240,000 has been paid by an investor for the six-story elevator apartment house at 5,000 Fifteenth Avenue, Brooklyn. The building, which is on a plot 160 by 150 feet, accommodates eighty-seven families and was sold by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn.
Milton L. L'Ecluse, senior member of the Manhattan real estate firm of L'Ecluse, Washburn. Co., of 15 East 41st Street, died today at his home here after a brief illness at the age of 67.

Townsend B. Martin's Galapas, a 3-year-old bay colt who scored az decisive victory over Lawrin, the 1938 Kentucky Derby winner, at Hialeah last Winter, sprinted to a handy two-length victory in the Inaugural Handicap at Tropical Park today as the long Florida turf season, growing in importance and interest each year, got under way.

The plan of reorganization for the Erie Railroad announced by the management yesterday went beyond expectations by providing that the Chesapeake Ohio Railway's control of the bankrupt line should be preserved intact.
A plea for aid from a stranded trawler in the South Indian Ocean passed through Naval Communications here today en route almost all the way around the world.
Al Delaney, Oshawa, Ont., heavyweight, tonight knocked out Pancho Villar of Spain in the seventh round of a ten-round bout at Earlscourt.

7th St, 202 E. 25x90.10; 202 E 7th St Corp to Irving Schlesinger, 342 E 8th St; pr mtg, $18,000, 2 yrs, int per bond. $2,300. Manhattan Ave. 471 16.8x82: Wm. A. Johnson to Empire City Savings Bank; p m mtg, due, etc, as bond, $6,200.

Dulce, 6-month-old German shepherd pup, waked Ernest Steinbeck, his wife and his sister and brotherin-law, Mr. and Mrs. John Muller, in their home at 145-33 119th Avenue, South Ozone Park, Queens, at 2 A. M. yesterday. The house was on fire. Dulce was still barking as the four ran from the house in their night clothes.

An issue of $281,000 town of Norwich, Conn., 2 per cent bonds is being offered today by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and the R. F. Griggs Company at prices to yield 0.35 to 2.00 per cent, according to maturity. The bonds, issued for public improvement and funding purposes, are due Jan. 2, 1940 to 1959.
A group of young girls of debutante age, calling themselves The ForgetMe-Nots, will give a subscription dance at the Montclair Golf Club Wednesday night.
Mr. and Mrs. Arnall Hodges gave a dinner last night at the Madison for Mr. and Mrs. Peyton Randolph Harris, Mr. and Mrs. John M. Montgomery and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ingersoll Brown.

Temporarily shelving differences between them, the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, through their attorneys, Today appealed to the Social Security Board to refrain from certifying the Oregon Unemployment Compensation Act on the ground that the recently enacted anti-labor initiative in that State had deprived it of the right to Federal grants under the Social Security Act.

More than 400 building material dealers are expected to attend the one-day merchandising clinic sponscored by Johns-Manville at the Hotel Roosevelt today. G. Rowland Collins, assistant dean of the School of Commerce, New York University, will be the chief speaker at a luncheon.

The Michigan State College exhibited today a seedless watermelon developed by Cheong-yin Wong, a 27-year-old Chinese graduate student who, college authorities said, had succeeded where other researchers had failed.

Although the comparative youth of the trailer business makes predictions difficult, the industry is stronger today than ever before and from all indications is on the threshold of even greater expansion, according to Wilbur J. Schult, president Schult Trailers, Inc., of Elkhart Ind.
First Lieut. Jacob Kushin, Engr, -Res. 1,132 Delaware Ave., Buffalo, 73d Engineer Co., is ordered to active duty Jan. 1, Date of rank: Jan. 1, 1939. He will revert to an inactive status Jan. 14.
The Middle States Lawn Tennis Association's nominating committee announced today it had selected Paul W. Gibbons of Philadelphia for a third term as president.

Rallying spectacularly in the closing minutes, Michigan's unbeaten basketball team came from behind to conquer speedy Syracuse. 39 to 37, in an exciting contest before 5,000 persons at the Westchester County Center tonight.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today; dated Dec. 16: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Metcalfe, E. C., the Reuben James, to Hydrographic Office. Navy Dept., Washington, D. C., about May 15.

Sir Sidney Peel, who had served the British Government on many important political, financial and economic missions all over the world, died today at the age of 68. His newspaper work in Egypt attracted the attention of Sir Ernest Cassel and led to the beginning of Sir Sidney's financial career as chairman of Near East banks.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Obreiter of Bloomfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Marion Obreiter, to Emory Oakes Webster, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Preston Webster of .Tappahannock, Va.

Evidence of what the Neediest Cases Fund means in the work of the ten great charitable organizations that cooperate with it may be found in the following statement by Henriette Lund, executive secretary of the Staten 'Island Social Service, one of the Participating agencies:
Those who are familiar with the operations of the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund know that the total amount of money given each year is not an accurate measure of the warmth of people's hearts.

The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association showed another decline last week, dropping to the second lowest level since 1934. The association's index, based on the 1926-1928 average, was 72.5 for the week ended Dec. 17, compared with 72.8 for the preceding week, 73.2 a month ago and 78 a year ago.

Since "The Kreutzer Sonata," shown yesterday at the World Theatre, represents a kind of mystical collaboration of. Tolstoy and Beethoven, it is probably unnecessary to report that the picture is on the heavy side.
Ely Ave, (17-5053), n w cor of Pitman Ave, 73x95; John Baroncelli to West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association, 250 W 57th St; due as per bonds; $24,600.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 490-Henry Gross and Theresa Gross, applts., v. Title Insurance and Trust Co., et al. Appeal from the U. S. District Court for the Southern Dist. of Calif. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

A trend back to the taller beer bottles in areas outside. of New York, in which consumption of packaged beer has increased steadily in recent years, was reported here yesterday by a leading brewery, which has just completed a survey of drinking habits.

Mrs. R. H. Coats, wife of the Dominion statistician, died at her home here tonight. She was !educated at the Sorbonne University and became governess to the Children of Lord and Lady Minto. She came to Ottawa with them when Lord Minto was appointed Governor General of Canada in 1898.

While the Americans roll along comfortably in second place, the old men of Manhattan as individuals are holding down most of the choice berths in the race for scoring honors in the National Hockey League.

A dwelling on the south side of Iselin Terrace in the Larchmont Shores section of Larchmont, Westchester County, has been purchased by David H. Wright of Scarsdale, an associate of the M. J. Knoud Saddle Company of New York. The Doern Real Estate Office was the broker in the deal.

Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, chairman of the instructional affairs committee of the Board of Education, announced yesterday that the open hearing on the use of school buildings by teachers or organizations for meetings on. "controversial" subjects will be held on Jan. 6 at 8 P. M.

Federal Judge John C. Knox in accepting yesterday the recommendations of Peter B. Olney Jr., referee in the reorganization of the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation, authorized an audit of the income tax returns filed between 1919 and 1930 by David A. Schulte, as president of the corporation,

Pensioned On his own application; to take effect 12 noon, Dec. 16; PATROLMAN - William C. McKenna, 108th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed May 11, 1904. Assignment To take effect 8 A. M., Dec. 20: LIEUTENANT--Bertram Masklell, from 16th Division to 11th, Precinct. Assignment to desk duty continued.
Miss Rosamond Ely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Ely of Scarsdale, was presented to society yesterday at a luncheon given by her mother in the penthouse suite of the St. Regis.

More than 4,400 variety stores throughout the country, with aggregate sales in 1937 of $577,552,000, reported to the Bureau of the Census that their sales during the first half of 1938 were within 6.4 per cent of their sales for the same period last year, according to the Department of Commerce.

Immediate passage by the City Council of the five county government reform bills, introduced by Councilwoman Genevieve B. Earle, was recommended in a resolution sent to members of the Council by the New York Young Republican Club, William B. Hubbell, club president, announced yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Peter P. South in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday on motions before him in connection with the suit for $17,540 brought by John J. Curtin, liquidating partner of the law firm of Curtin Glynn, against David Hirshfield, former city magistrate and former Commissioner of Accounts.
An investment purchase of a recently foreclosed property on the lower East Side was made when the six five and six-story buildings at the northwest corner of Madison and Roosevelt Streets were sold.

Business failures in the week ended Dec. 15 numbered 216, as compared with 222 for the corresponding week of 1937 and 221 for the week previous, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday. This was the fifth week in succession that the total had been below 1937, but the first time in four weeks that the figure was below that for the week Previous.

The Rubsam Horrmann Brewing Company distributed $30,000 at its annual Christmas party held last Saturday at Stapleton, S. I. This represents a 12 per cent cash bonus for the 125 members of the sales force and the office employes.

The evidence linking F. Donald Coster, former head of McKesson Robbins, Inc., in the traffic of arms and munitions was brought to the surface at the public hearing yesterday morning in the office of Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall in the State Building.

As a gesture of good-will between the English-speaking nations, a party of 100 British motorists, members of the Junior Car Club of London, will bring forty British cars of a score of makes to this country in June.
