Poland's democratic parties won a striking victory in yesterday's municipal elections in fifty-two cities and towns, including Warsaw. Of the 100 seats in the Warsaw City Council, the opposition won 61, the remainder going to the Camp of National Unity, the governmental party.

Daniel Decatur Moore, former newspaper executive here and at Fort Worth, Texas, died today at his home at the age of 69. Mr. Moore at one time was editor and manager of The New Orleans Times-Picayune and later editor and publisher of The Fort Worth Record.

THE Glamour Boy of sports is Jim Thorpe. Perhaps' no American in the history of athletics captivates the imagination so much as the phenomenal Sac and Fox. A week ago when some tales were told in this space of the prodigious football skill of the big fellow, requests were made from many directions for more

Average net sales per week in the four weeks ended Oct. 29 of various types of cloths woven by 138 wool goods mills operating 30,000 looms totaled 5,886,000 yards, as compared with an average of 2,832,000 yards per week in the four-week period ended Oct. 30, 1937, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers reported yesterday.

Although most of the coaches seem to be pretty well satisfied with the rules now in force, Elmer Ripley, who resumed his post at Georgetown after an absence of nine years, would like to see a few changes. Ripley, who was one of the standout players on the original Celtics, thinks the offense is being made to carry too heavy a burden.

So much has been said recently of the success of Germany's drive for foreign trade, and so much advice has been given to the democracies, about the necessity of discarding their own old-fashioned methods and following the German lead, that it is interesting to look at the figures reported in a dispatch from Berlin yesterday.
Winds laden with sleet and snow swept over Europe today, causing at least twenty deaths and crippling communications in virtually all parts of the Continent.

A Czecho-Slovak reply to Poland was disclosed semi-officially today to have assured Warsaw that no internal movement for redeeming lost territory would be permitted within Czecho-Slovakia. The statement replied to a Polish memorandum presented. Friday.
Dr. John Livingston Lowes, wellknown Professor of English Literature at Harvard, has notified the Harvard Corporation of his intention of retiring at the close of the present academic year.

Appearing as the representative of four Pennsylvania trust institutions and four insurance companies, former United States Senator George Wharton Pepper asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to intervene in the proceedings involving consideration by the commission of the investment program for $8,000,000 submitted by United Corporation.
Miss Julia A. Peckham, former teacher in the Boonton public schools, died yesterday at her home here after a four months, illness at the age of 78.
After holding within narrowest limits in some time for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange stiffened in late trading to close with gains of 5 to 10 points.
Springfield's return to organized baseball appeared assured today when President Thomas Richardson of the Eastern League said the Trenton club would be transferred to this city in about two weeks.
Sister Mary Florence, a member of the Order of St. Joseph for forty-nine years, died yesterday of pneumonia in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, at the age of 71, after a long illness.

Announcement was made yesterday that as a result of a mutual agreement between the directors of the Anchor Line, Ltd., of Glasgow and the directors of the Waterman Agency, Ltd., the two companies will operate as separate entities.

Efforts to break the deadlock on the declaration of solidarity by the Americas in the face of external aggression continued today at the Pan-American Conference, but without apparent development to a late hou?? tonight.

Sixteen of thirty-four aspirants for teaching certificates from the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association were successful in the first test of the season held on the upper slope of the Taft Trail on Cannon Mountain in Franconia Notch, N. H., on Sunday.

Estate. more than $10,000. To Cornelfa D. J. Sharp, c/o Captain Alexander Sharp. U. S. N., Long Beach, Calif., $2.500: Laura Barman Cofroft, P. O. No. 2, New Dorp, S. I., $5,000; Robet Wills Covington, cousin, Bowling Green, Ky., silver sugar basket; Grace F. D. Robinson. niece, executrix, Brecknock Hall, Greenport, N. Y., residue.

Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick today ordered a local of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers to open its records for a search for evidence to show whether it was responsible for a sit-down strike at the Apex Hosiery Mills in 1937.
Art Griggs, veteran baseball player and president of the Tulsa Club of the Texas League, died today' of Hodgkins's disease. He was 53 years old.

The new account opened quietly but firmly on the Exchange today, pre-holiday slackness in trading keeping down the favorable movements which were shown in several directions. Initial gains in gilt-edge stocks, however, were converted into small losses.
A Domei [Japanese news agency] dispatch from Maebashi, Japan, said an army powder factory exploded there today. Fire following the explosion destroyed four buildings.

Refugees from Germany, numbering 440, who had crossed the frontier clandestinely in recent weeks were rounded up by the Amsterdam police today and transferred to two special camps. The step was prepared secretly in order to permit the gathering of the refugees at police headquarters.

The Rev. Raymond M. McDermott, O. S. M., pastor of St. Juliana Catholic Church for the last five years, died today in the Charles Godwin Jennings Hospital after a week's illness of pneumonia. He was 69years old.

Agrarian agitation in the State of Veracruz, which last week resulted in the tieup of a wide area. about the port of Veracruz, has now led to clashes in which fifteen persons have been killed and several wounded, according to press reports.
John Flaherty, a tailor at neighboring Niles whose diet for the last twenty years consisted only of milk, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 75.

Thomas Byron Caughlan, a close friend of former Governor Alfred E. Smith.during. his early years in the Assembly at Albany, was stricken fatally yesterday noon while on a southbound Sixth Avenue bus near his home at 64 Charlton Street. He was 75 years old.

Mrs. Jane Norman Smith of the national council of the National Woman's Party yesterday characterized as unfair and reactionary the movement at Lima to abolish the Inter-American Commission of Women, headed by Miss Doris Stevens.

Columbia St, 60, 26.9x100: Harry Greiff to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, mtg 2 $12,950 not to merge ($14.50). Allen St, 7, 25x87.6; Rose Block to Metropolitan Savings Bank, mtg $15,000 not to merge ($16). 14th St, 318 W. 25x103.1; Elizabeth Lobdell, et al, to Frances Breakstone, 229 W 22d St. quit claim, confirmation deed.
Charles Mason Remey gave another in a series of dinner parties, followed by music, tonight at his home, 2,440 Massachusetts Avenue, for Mrs. Claude A. Swanson, wife of the Secretary of the Navy.
Democratic Senators who have canvassed the sentiment within their party ranks regarding a third term for President Roosevelt reported today that opposition to the plan is gaining.

Members of the alumnae association of the Academy of Mount Saint Vincent will give a dance on Dec. 27 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The committee in charge includes the Misses Ella Galvin, chairman, and Carmeline M. Annunziata, Dina Dellale, Eileen Duffy, Gloria Gunther, Vera Perrotty and Eileen Sheehy, vice chairmen.

Tippy Larkin, 137, of Garfield, returned to the ring tonight after a four-month absence because of a broken right hand and gained a onesided victory over Charley Burns, 137, of Johnstown, Pa., in the feature eight-round boxing bout at Laurel Garden.
Miss Elizabeth Buskin, Brooklyn College senior, won the annual invitation tournament of the Women's Intercollegiate Fencing Association in Calkins Gymnasium of Hofstra College tonight.
Abner B. Brown, former State prohibition leader, long active in Sunday school circles, died today at a hospital here after an operation. He was 69 years old.

An Aurelio Giorni Memorial Fund, dedicated to the publication and performance of the works of the late composer, has been organized under the supervision of an advisory committee of distinguished musicians.

The nineteen buildings recently acquired at foreclosure by the Bowery Savings Bank, comprising a large part of the block front on the east side of Lexington Avenue, between Forty-sixth and Fortyseventh Streets, and extensive footage on both side streets, will be demolished and part of the land improved with a one-story building with seven stores.

Carl Marty Co., largest independent Swiss cheese manufacturer in the United States, has been sold to the Borden Company. New York, it was announced here today by Carl Marty Jr., president. No purchase price was made public.

The right of members of a President's family to live their own lives, even in the White House, was asserted today by Mrs. Roosevelt. After all, she said, only the President is elected to office, and abandonment by his wife and children of all outside interests and activities, if required, might be a very serious matter.

Traffic accidents, fatalities and injuries in this city again declined substantially last week and weekend as compared with similar figures for the corresponding periods of 1937, tabulated comparisons of the safety bureau of the Police Department showed yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Trowbridge of 895 Park Avenue have announced the marriage on Dec. 12 of their daughter, Mrs: Marjorie Anne Trowbridge Nicholas, to Louis Stevenson Thomason Jr. of Reno, Nev.

Continuing its sale of housing properties on the upper West Side and in Harlem, the Union Dime Savings Bank has disposed of the two five-story walk-up apartments at 38 and 40 West 116th Street to an investor. There are four stores and ninety-six rooms in the two buildings, which occupy a plot 54 by 100.11 feet.
By a vote of 151 to 57, Edward J. O'Mara, Assistant Corporation Counsel of Jersey City, was elected tonight president of the Hudson County Bar Association over James T. Tumulty Jr.

ANDERSON-Richard. The Association or Master Plumbers, Manhattan Branch, announces with sincere' regret the death of its beloved member and trustee, Richard Anderson. Reposing at his late residence, 1,717 West 11th St., Brooklyn, until Wednesday morning. Funeral service will be held in Eguinunk, Pa. JOSEPH F. HECK, President. HERBERT SMITH, Secretary.

Lieut. Col. Raymond V. Cramer of the Coast Artillery Corps died today at Walter Reed Hospital. He was 49 years old. Born in Portland, Conn., Colonel Cramer was graduated from West Point in 1912. He was promoted to lieutenant colonel on Aug. 1, 1935.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Nagle of Jersey City of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Margaret Nagle, to Merton Sage Neill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Neill of Medford, Mass.
Eloquent tributes to the memory of Justice Benjamin Nathan Cardozo were paid by Chief Justice Hughes and Attorney General Cummings today in the court chamber.

The price of lead advanced 10 points yesterday. The new price established by the American Smelting and Refining Company is 4.85 cents a pound at New York and that by the St. Joseph Lead Company is 4.70 cents at St. Louis.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions for Arrangement ERNEST KLEIN, grocer, 2,378 8th Ave.-Voluntary proceedings under Chapter XI of the Chandler act listing liabilities of $2,292 and assets of $180 plus insurance. A settlement of 15 per cent to unsecured creditors is proposed.

Mike Jacobs, Twentieth Century S. C. promoter, yesterday ranked twenty-five of the current crop of heavyweights according to his idea of their boxoffice appeal, then beat a hasty retreat to arrange his business affairs for a trip to Miami. He is due to depart this morning.

Acute weakness in several minor items caused The Annalist's Commodity Index to lose another onehalf point last week, putting prices at the lowest level since late in 1934. Last Saturday the index was 78.7 (1926 equalling 100), compared with 79.3 the preceding week and 85.7 a year ago.

The frenzied race of the naval powers in the building of giant battleships is described in the new edition of Jane's Fighting Ships, authoritative year book of the world's navies, which has just been published here.

The Roof Garden of the St. Regis, illuminated entirely by candlelight, was the setting last night for a supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Gossler for Mrs. Gossler's debutante daughter, Miss Marion Saffold Oates.

A brisk demand for the abridged offerings advanced cattle prices 25 to 50 cents today, with choice to prime 1,124 pound steers going at $13.50. Hogs ruled unevenly 10 to 25 cents higher. Best lightweights reached $7.65;

The action of the Chase National Bank in refusing to make advances from the principal of a $670,000 trust fund of which it was trustee to the chief beneficiary of the fund while he continued to live in Germany was upheld yesterday in a referee's report filed in Supreme Court.

Mrs. John J. Hoff, one of the leaders of French-American society since the turn of the century, died yesterday at Ouchy. Her age was 76. Her husband, former president of the Bedford Petroleum Company, and her daughter, Mrs. Albert Labouchere, were at her bedside.
Facing the prospect of a long and controversial meeting, the City Council will hold its final regular session of the year in City Hall today.

The camera and photographic supply business, which has been a big holiday sales feature since the candid camera craze began, has entered a new phase this year, local dealers reported, with dollar sales down sharply and the number of items sold substantially ahead.

Mrs. Henry Tatnall Brown Jr., wife of the dean of Haverford College and daughter of former Governor John S. Fisher, died today at her home in Haverford after an illness of several months. She was 40 years old.

Nathan Goldstein scored an upset when he eliminated William McGeehee in the metropolitan junior indoor tennis tournament yesterday on the Hamilton courts at the 102d Engineers armory. The loser, seeded second, bowed by 7-5, 6-4.

Ever since Philip Barry's "Here Come the Clowns" opened a fortnight ago there has been considerable throwing about of brains in recognition of its beauty. That is a pastime in which this column would like to join on the basis of a secondpilgrimage to Mr. Barry's shrine.
Up in Harlem a company of Negro players-under the Federal Theatre Project is giving Bernard Shaw's "Androcles and the Lion," and our Mr.

Busy Times Square paused a few moments last evening to light a Christmas tree, one of four lighted in public squares i the city by the Theatre Arts Committee as it opened its Christmas Refugee Aid campaign. Tonight the trees in city parks will be lighted with ceremonies at City Hall Park and in the various boroughs.

Supreme Court' Justice Philip J. McCook granted yesterday an injunction restraining the Spanish Anti-Fascist Committee from picketing the retail grocery store of Moneo Sons at 218 West Fourteenth Street. Mrs. Carmen Moneo,

H. D. Cox's inconsistent gelding, Abbots Hour, captured the fifth race at a mile and seventy yards and paid the biggest odds of the Fair Grounds meeting today, $119.20 for $2. He returned $36.40 to place and $17 to show.

Total automobile production last week was the highest for the year. This increase, in the face of an unchanged seasonal factor, advanced the adjusted index to 96.1 from 94.1. For the week ended Dec. 18, 1937, the figure was 91.4.

Stephen Elliott Welch, who was on Morris Island when the first shot of the Civil War was fired there from Fort Sumter, and who witnessed Lee's surrender at Appomattox, died here this afternoon at the age of 95.

Applications by mail for 1939 auto plates will begin Dec. 27, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Carroll E. Mealey announced yesterday. As a month's leeway is allowed before current tags expire at midnight, Jan. 31, no new plates may be displayed on cars until Jan. 1.

A preference for young, agile rookies with college training and experience in group athletics was expressed yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine in an affidavit submitted to Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien.

Uncertainty among canners as to the type of labels they should use when the Wheeler-Lea act goes into effect in Jane has created a production problem for label suppliers, according to food producers yesterday. Ordinarily large supplies of labels are ordered at this season for use through the coming year.

New restrictions on Hungary's Jews, possibly including limiting their voting rights, were in prospect today as the Cabinet gave final touches to a bill for the control of Jews to be introduced in Parliament on Friday.
A summary of the principal assets and liabilities of the reporting member banks, together with changes for the week and the year ended Dec. 14, 1938, follows:

W. P. Hodous, president of the Amateur, Skating Union of the United States, announced today trials of the United States Olympic team had been moved ahead four days and would be held Jan. 18 to 26 at Oconomowoc, Wis.

North Winship, counselor of the United States Embassy at Warsaw, and Mrs. Winship are at the Plaza. Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander and her son, T. J. Oakley Rhinelander 2d, are at the St. Regis for the holidays.

Leading all the way, the Long Island University basketball team vanquished a hard-fighting quintet from East Stroudsburg Teachers College, 63-33, at the Brooklyn Pharmacy gymnasium last night. It was the Blackbirds' fifth consecutive victory.
Pope Pius rested in bed today after a fatiguing day yesterday, when he attended the inauguration of the session of the Pontifical Academy, before which he spoke for nearly three-quarters of an hour.
E. W. Scheer, president of the Beading Company and the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey, announced today that the interest due Jan. 1 on all Jersey Central bonds would be paid.
Dr. Benjamin Franklin Baer Jr., a widely known eye specialist, died of pneumonia today at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital after a week's illness. He was in his sixtieth year.

Further Federal indictments in the McKesson Robbins case, involving prominent persons not connected with the drug company, were predicted yesterday by Brien McMahon, assistant United States attorney general, who arrived here by plane from Washington to take charge of the investigation.

Prices of listed bonds on the New York Stock Exchange moved within a narrow range yesterday and closed dull and mixed, the volume of trading amounting to $9,058,475, compared with $8,903,700 on Friday.

The Class 1 railroads in the first eleven months of the year bought built or rebuilt 14,947 freight cars, against 70,168 in the same period in 1937 and 39,556 in the same period in 1936, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday.

Grand Duke Vladimir, pretender to the toppled throne "of all the Russias," left by automobile today for Amorbach, near Munich Germany, to spend the Christmas holidays with his sister, Grand Duchess Marie, wife of Prince Charles of Leningen.

Teachers of consumer education subjects and leaders of consumer organizations are definitely critical of business and do not believe that it is doing the best job it can for the benefit of consumers, according to a survey conducted among 2,381 leaders in the fields by the American Consumer Magazine.

Five hundred men attended the twelfth annual Hanukkah dinner of the Metropolitan Conference of Temple Brotherhoods at the Hotel Commodore last night. Mortimer Kraus, acting president of the organization, presided.
Trustees for the Follansbee Brothers Company, now being reorganized, said tonight their 1,500 workers had voluntarily agreed to a 15 per cent wage reduction, effective Jan. 1, 1939.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had:

Two electrical contractors who last week were named with eight others in a superseding misdemeanor conspiracy indictment in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's old investigation into the alleged rigging of bids on city and private construction work, entered not guilty pleas yesterday in General Sessions.

The first step toward a showdown on Mayor La Guardia's demand for city control of salaries paid to clerical appointees of the State courts was taken yesterday by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation.

A 26-year-old ex-convict, identified by three witness as the gunman who shot and killed Fireman Thomas J. Hitter in-a payroll holdup last October, was formally booked on a charge of homicide at the Liberty Avenue police station, Brooklyn,
Should the Senate pass a resolution opposing on principle and by tradition a Presidential third term, Mr. Roosevelt's political power would be weakened in the time he has yet to serve.

John N. Reid, 32 years old, of 25 St. Nicholas Avenue, was found guilty last night by a jury in the Court of General Sessions of the theft of $600 from the Libyan Corporation, a real estate concern, at 360 West 116th Street, between October, 1937, and last March.

The extraordinary grand jury in-vestigating charges of official corruption in Brooklyn heard evidence yesterday concerning alleged irregular bail bond practices involving gambling and prostitution cases as handled in police station houses and magistrates' courts.

Miss Harriet Coverdale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hugh Coverdale, was introduced to society yesterday at a luncheon given by her mother in her home at 1,020 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Coverdale and Univers her daughter received the guests.

Several debutantes of this season, headed by Miss Nancy Post, are aiding in the sale of tickets for the preview of the new French film, "Le Mioche," which will be shown Thursday night at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse for the benefit of the work of the Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

Ancient cannon at Santiago's Morro Fortress roared a customary salute and everything looked festive to the 500 officers and men of the German school ship Schleswig-Holstein for a brief period today. Then things got cloudy.
The Erie Railroad proposed today to make its principal bondholders convert their holdings into preferred stock and new bonds of smaller denominations.

Prime Minister Chamberlain, after a defense of his foreign policy in the House of Commons yesterday, received a vote of confidence, 340 to 143. Of the Germans he said, "There is no desire to hamper their development or to cramp their tremendous vitality," but he hoped for "a sign from those who speak for the German people" that they were ready to aid peace.

Margaret Boland, in 511 E 86th St; Nathan Sheinman, in 222 W 59th St; Carol McDonald, in 320 E 53d St; Rev. Walter G. Harter, in 44 W 10th St; James Gold, in 45 5th Ave; Ruth B. Robinson, in 260 S 2d Ave, Mt. Vernon; Wm. A. White Sons, broker.
Charles Cromwell, famous old-time circus star who in 1874 walked across the Niagara River gorge at Niagara Falls on a rope, died at his home here today at the age of 83.
Joseph Fishbaeh, defending champion, was seeded first in the draw for the national junior indoor tennis championship at the offices of the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday.

Jack Dempsey's heavyweight protege, Wild Bill Boyd, added another victory to his string tonight by knocking out Big Boy_Brackey. Referee Jimmy Goodrich stopped the bout in the ninth after Brackey went down for the twelfth time from a short right chop to the jaw. The 227-pound Brackey stumbled around the ring half 'conscious for most of the fight.
Extreme cold weather in Europe and heat in Argentina resulted today in higher prices in United States grain markets.

An informal reception was given yesterday afternoon for Miss Louise Drexel Hubbard, debutante daughter of Mrs. Dahlgren Hubbard, by Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend, an aunt of the debutante, at her home, 169 East Seventy-eighth Street. Mrs. Townsend and her niece received the guests.

Inaugurating an era of closer relationship between education and retailing, a first annual Conference of Retailers and Retail Teachers will be held in connection with the twenty-eighth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at the Hotel Pennsyivania, during the week of Jan. 16.
The proxy statement of Swift Co. accompanying the notice of the annual meeting on Jan. 19, 1939, describes the personal interest of the proxies as follows:

Following ar excerpts from Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech on foreign affairs in the House of Commons today: The motion before the House today, unlike most motions previously put down by the Opposition, is both clear and brief.

The Board of Estimate yesterday declared George L. Weissbaum, West Coast scrap metal contractor, and his New York City associates in default on their contract to tear down the Sixth Avenue elevated structure and awarded the contract to the Harris Structural Steel Company of this city.

The marriage of Miss Gloria Baker, daughter of Mrs. Margaret Emerson of Sands Point, L. I., to Henry J. Topping Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Topping of New York, took place here today in the villa of the bride's mother.

Governor Lehman tonight ordered a broad investigation of law enforcement in Orange County, particularly in Newburgh. He directed Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. to supersede District Attorney Henry Hirschberg and ordered a special term of Supreme Court and an extraordinary grand jury to be convened at Goshen Feb. 6.

The Department of Agriculture, in its final crop report of the year, made known today 1938 crop yields an acre were nearly 11 per cent above the average. But the aggregate acreage harvested, the report indicated, was 31/2 per cent below averages for the 1923-32 period.

Mickey Farber, rugged little East Side lightweight, retained his place among the title challengers last pr night at the St. -Nicholas Palace when he hammered his way to the decision over Wally- Hally, Cal- wi ifornian, in the feature bout of a eight rounds before a capacity crowd of about 4.000 persons.

The annual dance in behalf of the Summer Play Schools maintained by the Child Study Association of America in cooperation, with the New York City Board of Education will take place Sunday night on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Students at the University of Puerto Rico have rated faculty members 25 in a balloting published in the student daily, Cuko, with a surprising number of "Fs," "F," it is explained, denotes that a teacher "has nothing-lacks preparation,

A stir has been caused here by statements made at the Pan-American Conference by the Bolivian Foreign Minister, Eduardo Diez de Medina, concerning Bolivia's ambition to obtain an outlet to the sea. It had been assumed here that settlement of the Chaco territorial difficulties closed the question of an Atlantic outlet, but it now appears that Bolivia looks toward the Pacific.

Professor Harry Morgan Ayres of the Columbia University Department of English has been appointed to take over the duties of Professor John J. Coss as director of Columbia's Summer session while Professor Coss is on a seven-month leave of absence, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Congressional investigators heard a lively debate today on whether the Tennessee Valley Authority showed an "operating loss" or a "net expense" of $310,171 on its power operations for the fiscal year 1938.

The eighth Pan-American Conference will not offer mediation in the Spanish War. The steering committee, composed of- the chairmen of the twenty-one delegations, voted 18 to 3 this morning that the Cuban proposal for mediation should not go before the conference.

Back from a road trip which held success and failure, the Rangers will swing into action on the ice at Madison Square Garden tonight against the Detroit Red Wings. Deadlocked with the Americans for second place in the National Hockey League,

Matthew V. B. Brinckerhoff, civic leader here, died today of a heart attack at his home in this city. His age was 76. Born in Fishkill, N. Y., Mr. Brinckerhoff was graduated from Columbia University, which later cited him for meritorious alumni work.

Charles F. Michaels, executive vice president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., resigned yesterday as one of the two trustees of the wholesale drug concern in the proceedings for its reorganization under the Chandler act.

Secretary Wallace has been told by Richard N. Elliott, acting Controller General, that loans of about $3,000,000 made for the construction, equipment and operation of silk hosiery mills on five homestead projects of the Farm Security Administration were unauthorized by law and, in addition, were "in competition with private industry."
George Bernard Shaw disclosed tonight that at the age of 82 he is writing a new historical play laid in the period of Charles II-but with Nell Gwynn playing a minor role as a court charmer.

George V. McLaughlin, president of the Brooklyn Trust Company, will speak at a meeting of the Brooklyn chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants at the Hotel Granada, Brooklyn, tomorrow evening.

1:30-4:45 P. M.-Council Meeting, at City Hall--WNYC. 5:00-5:15 P.M.-Mayor La Guardia's Message, at Lighting of Christmas Trees in City Hall Park--WNYC. 6:00-6:30 P. M.-Debate: "Is a Small Town College Better Than a City University?" Columbia vs. University of Vermont--WNYC.

More than $1,000,000 daily is paid into Federal, State and local governments through taxes on beer, according to figures in "Beer and Brewing in America," the 1938 edition of the brewing industry's economic textbook released yesterday by the United Brewers Industrial Foundation.
Sy Sussman, former national junior champion, advanced to the quarter-final round of the Brooklyn table tennis tournament last night by defeating Sid Schane, 21-6, 21-18, at the Parkway Tennis Club.

From the cellar position in the New York Amateur Hockey Association, the New York Athletic Club arose to conquer a Westchester Victoria sextet, 7-5, in a league match at the Imperial Ice Casino tonight.

Nazi agents are organizing German clubs in Alberta and arrangements are being made to send Canadian-born children of German origin to Germany to be educated, it was charged at a protest meeting here yesterday.
Leaders of nine major industries will forecast the business outlook for 1939 during a special year-end program over the NBC-Blue network on Thursday, Dec. 29, from 8:30 to 9 P. M.

After Oregon defeated St. Joseph's College, 54-44, Temple University halted Northwestern, 32-29, in the second game of the season's opening college basketball double-header at Convention Hall tonight.

A head-on collision between a heavily loaded freight train and an express, the passengers of which included Boy Scouts traveling to a jamboree and scores of laborers en route to promised jobs, killed thirty-five persons and seriously injured more than 100 today, in the worst railway accident in Brazil's history..

A forthcoming visit of Premier George Kiosseivanoff to Angora, Turkey, was announced today. It is intended to emphasize the friendly relations between Bulgaria and Turkey, who fought side by side in the World War and between whom there is no territorial problem.

Two anti-Nazi Germans, Walter P. Schuck, formerly correspondent here for the Frankfurter Zeitung and now financial editor of the -Argentinisches Tageblatt, and Ralph H. Tausk, a collaborator, faced possible deportation today.
McGraw Ave (15-3880), s s. 75 ft w of Cottagegrove Ave, 25x100; also Cottagegrove Ave, w s, 100 ft a of McGraw Ave, 50x100; Max-Gor Realty. Inc, to Ralph E O'Connell, 3,001 Spuyten Duyvil Park-way.

Pete Tyrrell, general manager of the Philadelphia Arena, said today the Philadelphia Ramblers of the International-American Hockey League had obtained Alex Singbush, a defense man, from the New Haven Eagles on "a loan agreement."

Miss Dorothy Young, evangelist who spoke Sunday night before the Young People's League of the Broadway Temple MethodistChurch at 174th Street and Broadway, of which the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner is pastor, is a daughter of the Rev. Dr. Robert S. Young of Allenhurst, N. J., and a sister of Dr. Sherman P. Young of Drew University.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey obtained yesterday from the New York County grand jury a new batch of indictments against the three living Musica brothers in the looting of the McKesson Robbins drug concern.

The American Institute of International Law met this afternoon in the famous old San Marcos University to reorganize after several years of inactivity. For nearly twenty years the institute acted as an informal adviser to Pan-American conferences, studying projects,
The Department of Agriculture estimated today that Argentina would have approximately 249,000,000 bushels of wheat available for export in 1939.

John Marshall College of Jersey City registered its third straight victory tonight by toppling the Philadelphia College of Science, 50 to 27. Harold Smith of the losers took scoring honors with 10 points. Marshall led at half-time, 27 to 12.

In April the term of Mayor Kelly of Chicago ends. Appointed to fill the unexpired term of Mayor Cermak, 19331935, in the latter year he was elected by a "record vote" of nearly 800,000. As Park Commissioner and Mayor his achievements have seemed considerable and even impressive to outlanders.

A petition for removal of the swastika flag that has flown from the staff of the Grand Central Palace at 480 Lexington Avenue since the annual German exposition of the German- American Business League, Inc.,

A new type of streamlined steam-electric locomotive, which is rated to do twice the work of the usual locomotive and make three times the usual mileage without stops for fuel or water, was tested here today in the presence of nearly 100 railroad and electrical company officials.

The committee of six named by President Roosevelt to make a study of the railroad problem and recommend remedies will report to him this week, it was stated today after a visit to the White House of two members of the committee, Carl R. Gray, vice chairman of the Union Pacific Railroad, and George H. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 14:

The text of the statement made in Tokyo by Hachiro Arita, the Japanese Foreign Minister, on the future economic relations between China and Manchukuo and the United States and other Western countries, was made public tonight by the Japanese Embassy. It follows:

Whether New York State may levy an income tax upon the salary of James B. O'Keefe, attorney for a government agency, the Home Owners Loan Corporation in New York City, will be argued before the Supreme Court.

With more stores now reporting gains, the average dollar volume of Christmas trade may yet exceed last year's figures, store executives here said yesterday. Gift items in the medium and lower-priced category dominate, but development of a broader demand for semi-luxury items has bettered sales totals.

Nine persons were held by Swiss Federal inspectors and Geneva police tonight after raids designed to break a widespread spy ring. The police said they.believed a former Italian dancer to be head of the organization.
Mayor Frank Hague returned home from a two-week vacation in Florida today and temporarily cast politics aside to make plans to attend a Christmas party at the Jersey City Medical Center.

Seeking to reestablish himself as a middleweight title contender, Ken Overlin, Virginia boxer, returns to local ring activity tonight at the New York Coliseum, the Bronx, where he will battle Eric Seelig in the principal bout of ten rounds.

A Christmas tea dance, with music by a "swing" orchestra, will be held Saturday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Opportunity Shop, one of the many activities of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

The election of Fred E. Williamson of Pelham Manor to the presidency of the Winged Foot Golf Club, in Mamaroneck, was announced yesterday. Other officers for 1939 are Edward A. Arnold, vice president; Robert J. Hyland,

The Securities and Exchange Commission has scheduled a hearing for Jan. 9 in two proceedings to determine the relationship between the Dover Casualty Insurance Company and the Associated Gas and Electric System.

Turpentine firm, 221/2c; sales, 29 barrels; receipts, 122 barrels; shipments, 1,038 barrels; stock. 52,061 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 665; receipts, 1,485; shipments. 2,692; stock, 314,525. Quote: B, $3.70; D. $3.95; E. $4.10; F. $4.25; G, H, I, K, M. $4.321/2; N, $5.35; WG, $5.80; WW, X. $6.30.

The Bethlehem Steel Company filed objections today to a finding by the Public Contracts Board that the prevailing minimum wage rates in the steel industry were 621/2 cents an hour in the North and West and 45 cents in the South.

The 102d annual report of the Girard Trust Company of Philadelphia which was presented to stockholders in Philadelphia at their meeting yesterday showed net profits for the year ended on Nov. 20 of $1,602,836.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marjorie Peyser, daughter of Mrs. James Peyser of New Rochelle and the late Mr. Peyser, to Julian F. Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Rosen of this city and Mount Vernon.
A serious new incident in which Hungarian terrorists were unofficially reported to have been backed by regular Hungarian troops was announced officially at Bratislava today.

The collaboration of Josef Hofmann, who graciously contributed his services, made a distinguished event of last night's penision-fund concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conducting, at Carnegie Hall. Mr.

Reorders on gift merchandise from near-by stores were still being received in the wholesale markets here yesterday. The volume, however, was small, and interest is shifting rapidly to preparations for post-holiday clearances.
United States financial assistance to China was described today by Hachiro Arita, Japanese Foreign Minister, as a "regrettable act" and one than which "nothing will be more dangerous."

Dartmouth College opened its basketball tour of the Middle West tonight and lost, 57 to 43, to the unbeaten University of Toledo. It was the fifth straight for the home team. Tomorrow night the Indians will play Western Reserve UniverSity in Cleveland.

Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, was greeted on his arrival today by Hungarian officials and representatives of Germany, Japan and Yugoslavia. Officially Count Ciano is here for hunting parties and to sign a cultural agreement.

THE GERMAN REICH AND AMERICANS OF GERMAN ORIGIN. (Oxford University Press, $1.50.) A dossier of documents, speeches and decrees originating in Nazi Germany, and indicating the purposes of Nazi propaganda outside the Reich.

Albert Morris Bagby's 409th Musical Morning, given yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, had for artists Zinka Milanov and Jussi Bjoerling of the Metropolitan Opera and Efrem Zimbalist, violinist., At the piano were Vladimir Sokoloff, Harry Ebert and Fritz Hitzinger. There was a large audience.

A complaint signed by J. Walton El, described as Grand Sheik of the Moorish Science Temple of America in Chicago, was filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal court to enjoin the Moorish Science Temple, the Divine and National Movement of North America, Inc., of 44 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, from continuing to use its title on the grounds of "unfair competition" by "deceit."
Price reductions ranging from 1 to 10 per cent are being made on 1939 farm machinery by the International Harvester Company and other leading implement manufacturers.
According to the Maritime Workers Union of Mexico, several Japanese ships recently operating off the northern coast of Lower California were engaged in spying activities.

The undefeated Harvard Club team strengthened its hold on the lead in the Metropolitan League Class B tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association yesterday by defeating the Crescent A. C., 4 to 1. The Crimson players now have seven victories. Crescent gained its only point by default.

A bonus totaling $25,000 was distributed by Bonwit, Teller Co. to all employes at a gathering in the store last night. The sum received by each employee was based on the length of service with the organization. Buyers did not participate,

Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich appointed tonight a committee to handle the person and property of Mrs. Florence Chester Giles de Jonghe, 75-year-old wife of Vicomte Jules de Jonghe of Belgium, who brought suit to have her removed from the home of her niece, Mrs. Margaret V. Stokes of Greenwich, Conn., where, he charged, she was being held against her will.

Sidney Wood and Donald Budge, semi-finalists in the national tennis championship at Forest Hills last Summer as well as finalists at Newport, will meet across the net again tomorrow at the Brooklyn Heights Casino.
Jack Doyle, prize fighter and film actor, dropped a technical decision and prepared to sail today for' Genoa, Italy, without using his license to marry Movita, Mexican film actress.

Price cutting on the higher-priced radio sets is widespread in some of the small specialty stores. With the 1939 model season at hand,_discounts of as much as 50 per cent from marked prices are being given to move unsold stocks.
The average rate on the Treasury's weekly sale of bills dropped today to 0.006 per cent, which, according to Secretary Morgenthau, was a new low record.

Today's events: Oratorio Society, Carnegie Hall, evening; "Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera, evening; Fisk Jubilee Singers, Town Hall, evening; Francesco Zecchino, violinist, Town Hall, afternoon; Henry Hadley Foundation concert, American Academy of Arts and Letters, 8:30 P. M.; Westminster Choir, John Wanamaker's, 6; Elmo Russ, vocal and instrumental recital, Duval Studio, Metropolitan Opera House; William J. Falk, lecturer, Sherman Square Studios, 3; City College Orchestra, City College, 8:30; Aaron Copland, lecturer, Brooklyn Academy of Music.
A plan was revealed today to expel all Jews from Danzig within three months and to deprive them of all their property, which will be turned over to the Nazi party.

The Musicians Emergency Fund faces the holiday season "with a diminished budget and a substantial increase in the need for its services," Mme. Yolanda Mero-Irion, executive director, announced yesterday.
Federal Judge John H. Druffel signed yesterday a decree permanently enjoining Edward J. Weisbaum, president of the Weisbaum Brothers-Brower Company;
A young soldier and his bride of six months were found dead of gas last night in a small two-room furnished apartment which they had occupied for a month at 559 West 161st Street.

After holding a public hearing yesterday on two Council bills involving the use and size of electric street advertisements, Mayor La Guardia took both measures under advisement without indicating whether he would sign or veto them.

The United States has decided to continue its extension of credit to China against gold held in this country, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced at his press conference this afternoon.
Mrs. Finley J. Shepard, New York philanthropist, was in serious condition tonight at her Summer home near here, after suffering a stroke of apoplexy. She is 70 years old.

The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on a total of 5,234,414 yards of textiles for complete shipment by Feb. 15, 1939. The invitations are issued as of Dec. 23, and the opening date of the bids is Dec. 30.

The body of the man who was Philip Musica was entombed yesterday in the sleet-swept abbey of Cypress Hills Cemetery, Brooklyn. Within a few days a marble slab will be slid into place. It will bear the inscription "F. Donald Coster, 1884-1938."

Richard C. Gill, American explorer of South American countries, returned yesterday on the Grace Line motor ship Santa Barbara from his second expedition into the interior of Ecuador to search for rare drugs used by the Indians.
Day Realty Corporation sold to the Lasan Realty Company a vacant parcel on the east side of the Belleville Turnpike, adjoining the south line of the Erie Railroad, in Kearny, N. J.
The American Federation of Labor won its first real test of strength today in its battle with the C. I. O. for control of Rhode Island's textile workers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has received the following applications from New York City for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-the-counter market (symbolsS, sole proprietor; P, partnership; C, corporation):

The Securities and Exchange Commission has affirmed the effectiveness of a declaration by the Federal Light and Traction Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Power and Light Company, for the issue and sale of $1,500,000 collateral promissory notes to the Irving Trust Company, New York.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color in Painting: Method and Material," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; The Christmas Story in Art (general tour), 11 A. M.; Masterpieces of Painting of the XV Century (general tour), 2 P. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.: "Interior Design: Wood," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.

Drastic changes in the terms and conditions relating to sabbatical, maternity and sick leaves of the teachers in the four city colleges were voted last night by the Board Higher Education at a meeting at the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.
Meeting here today, the Scottish Football Association council approved its selection committee's recommendation to send a team to tour Canada and the United States next year.

Under the auspices of the Committee on Research in Medical Economics, Mr. Joseph Hirsh publishes in Public Health Reports "A Study of the Economics of Pneumonia," which sheds much light on the much-debated question of medical care for the low-income class.

Gilbert A. (Gil) Zunker, star Milwaukee bowler, died at a hospital here today following a stroke. He had bowled last Tuesday with the Heil Products, recently dethroned as world match championship team. His age was 37.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 17: COMMANDER Loftin, F., Lima. Peru, to Naval Operations, Navy Department, Washington, D. C. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Culver, B. K., the Barry, to office of Inspector of Naval Material, New York District, New York, N. Y., about April 30. Dunn, J. B., VS-41, the Ranger, to command Patrol Squadron 2, in May.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Dec 15 was higher in two trade groups, unchanged in two ard lower in one, as compared with the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Two men, one carrying a submachine gun and the other a revolver, entered the Pennsauken Township National Bank in North Merchantville shortly before noon today and reappeared a few moments later with a pink shopping bag, overflowing with bank notes.

Gifts of $10,000 each from the Charles Hayden Foundation and from an anonymous donor were included in a list of more than three hundred additional contributions to the United Hospital Campaign reported yesterday by C. M. Chester, general chairman.

New York City teachers and supervisors, worried over a recent decision ordering a principal to pay $5,000 damages for injuries received by a pupil during school hours, have started action to reverse the judgement. The case is to be taken to the Court of Appeals.

WITH malice toward none and with a professional magician's interest in all, John Mulholland tells in his new book--"Beware. Familiar Spirits"*--about his adventures. and discoveries among mediums, mind readers and ghosts that he has pretty frequently found to be considerably more substantial than magical.

Tommy Farr, through his attorney, Sol Strauss, yesterday filed a brief with the New York State Athletic Commission questioning that organization's jurisdiction to act on a complaint made against him by the British Board of Boxing Control.
John Tucek, 46 years old, a New York insurance broker, was asphyxiated.by illuminating gas in his home at 244 Orient Way here today, police reported.

Peter Forster, who, with Emil Bargatzky, killed an Elite Guard last May while escaping from the Buchenwald concentration camp, has been extradited from Czecho-Slovakia and returned to Weimar to face trial before a special court.
The Securities and,Exchange Commission started sending questionnaires yesterday to' brokerage houses in a. complete check-up on deals in McKesson Robbins securities over the last several months.
The Mexican Government today pushed proposals for two new taxes. One ranges up to 50 per cent on Mexican and foreign bank profits aside from those regarded as earned in strictly banking operations.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy Virginia Lohr, daughter of Fred W. Lohr of Tuckahoe, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Lohr, to Norman Alfred Dinnsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Dinnsen of Brooklyn and Milford Conn.

Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, looked rather uncomfortable and surprised today when enthusiastic members of the Hungarian Revision League took him for a ride on their shoulders around the Italian Legation's halls.

Roy C. Wilcox, executive vice president of the International Silver Company, said tonight that a stockholder-approved plan of recapitalizaction, offering exchange of new stock for present shares of 7 per cent preferred, had been declared ineffective because an insufficient number of preferred stockholders had compiled with the conditions.
G. Alonso Irigoyen has been appointed Economio and Financial Counselor to the Argentine Embassy in Washington, the Argentine information Bureau here announced yesterday.

Delman, Inc., producers of quality shoes, will remove its factory from 304 East Forty-fifth Street to the Standard Statistics Building, 345 Hudson Street, about Feb. 1, Herman Delman, president, announced yesterday.

The New York Rangers broke their tie with the Americans to gain unchallenged possession of second place in the National Hockey League last night by trouncing the Detroit Red Wings in a free-scoring battle at Madison Square Garden. Lester Patrick's charges showed no mercy to the cellar occupants from the Automobile City and subjected them to a 6-to-2 beating.

The five-story dwelling at 115 East Seventy-third Street, formerly owned and occupied by Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

Four of the seventeen directors of McKesson Robbins, Inc., testified yesterday in Attorney General Bennett's investigation of the drug concern that they had been entirely ignorant of the crude drug department of their corporation, relying solely on the reports of the late F. Donald Coster, or Philip Musica, president of the company and head of the department.

Plans for an international music festival, "the like of which has never been presented anywhere," to be held in New York during the World's Fair with the aim of establishing this city as the music capital of the world and opening a new era in the music history of America, were. enthusiastically approved yesterday by 300 residents of the city.

The conflict between the La Guardia administration and the State Supreme Court over control of the clerical staffs of the Supreme Court divisions within the city is expected to be tested in a court action today.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition for Arrangement RODMORE CHEMISTS, INC., drug store and luncheonette, 307 5th Ave.--Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler act listing liabilities of $30,975, and assets of $25,780. A settlement of 100 per cent payable in monthly installments of 2 per cent is proposed.

Three army planes took off from the Camp Columbia air field near Havana this morning en route to Cali,Columbia, in a flight to commemorate the first anniversary of the crash of three Cuban good-will planes there last Dec. 29 in which seven fliers died.

A majority of voters in England are satisfied with Neville Chamberlain. as Prime Minister, but his popularity has declined sharply since the Munich agreement, accordin to surveys of voting sentiment conducted by the British Institute of Public Opinion, affiliate of the American Institute, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

George Slade, 30 years old, of Champaign, Ill., who, Federal agents said, confessed to twelve bank robberies in five States, was sentenced to fifteen years in the Federal penitentiary at Leavenworth, Kan., today by Federal Judge Guy L. Fake here.

President Roosevelt presented today to the Marquette League for Catholic Missions With the Indians a stone taken from the wall of a monastery at Nancy, France, where Pere Marquette spent his novitiate from 1654 to 1656.

By scoring a 5-to-O triumph over the Elizabeth Town and Country Club team yesterday, the Short Hills team won the interclub championship of the New Jersey division of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

St. Francis Prep, St. John's Prep and Brooklyn Cathedral Prep remained in a three-way deadlock for the Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. basketball lead by scoring their second victories in as many starts yesterday.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the Lewis Historical Publishing Company and its subsidiary, the American Historial Society, Inc., of New York, had entered into a stipulation agreeing to discontinue certain alleged misrepresentations in connection with the sale of books containing histories of cities, counties and States and of persons living in or associated with such localities.

Big Bill Lee, whose powerful right arm literally catapulted the Cubs into their sensational pennant victory last Fall, was the National League's outstanding pitcher for 1938 by almost any standard of measurement, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

A situation that calls for serious consideration has arisen in the ranks of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association and yesterday, as the members convened at the Hotel Lincoln for the purpose of re-electing officers, much time was devoted to discussion of the problem with which the body Is confronted.

Twenty-seven boys and girls from fifteen foreign countries and two American children sent holiday greetings to the world this afternoon in the seventh Christmas program of the Greater National Capital Committee, conducted in cooperation with the National Broadcasting Company.

Engagements of gold abroad for shipment to this country as reported to the Federal Reserve Bank here consisted of $532,000 taken in England yesterday, and $307,000 of gold as of some previous date. The daily gold statement of the bank showed no imports or exports and the earmarked metal was unchanged.

An accounting in the estate of Laurids Petersen of 113 East Twenty-eighth Street, who died.on March 25 in Bellevue Hospital of injuries received in an automobile accident, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, disclosed that he-. had been on the'relief rolls and that he had left an estate of $103,923.

Fifty employes of the Casa Cubana Club, in Fifty-first Street east of Broadway, walked out of the establishment between 9 and 11:30 P. M. yesterday, preventing the staging of the first show at 9 P. M. The workers said they had left because they had failed, to receive their salaries for two weeks.

President Roosevelt sat down tonight with his principal fiscal aides to begin preparing the budget program which he will present to Congress. He called to the White House Secretary Morgenthau, Daniel Bell,

ANDERSON--At Greenwich, Conn., suddenly, on Tuesday, Dec. 20, 1938, Walter M., beloved husband of Lucretia Mead and loving father of Delight Anderson. Notice of funeral later. BOGERT--Willet A., formerly of Englewood, N. J., on Sunday, Dec. 18, at his home, St. Petersburg Fla. Services and burial will be at Old South Church, Bergenfield, N. J., Thursday, at 3:30 P. M.

The Argentine delegates to the Pan-American conference announced today, after talking by telephone with the Foreign Office at Buenos Aires last night, that they were unable to alter their position opposing any sweeping declaration of Pan-American solidarity in the face of extraAmerican aggression.

In an apparent effort to head off new agitation for national prohibition the liquor industry through its trade association the Distilled Spirits Institute, has started a program to enlist the "informed public" in the policing of the distribution of alcoholic beverages.

Funeral services for Robert Ridgway, retired chief engineer of the Board of Transportation and one of the country's foremost authorities on subway construction, will be held Friday'at 10 A. M. in the Church of the Transfiguration, "the Little Church Around the Corner," it was announced last night. Mr. Ridgway died Monday night of corornary thrombosis in Fort Wayne, Ind. at the age of 76.

The International Miners Committee; meeting here today, adopted a resolution protesting against the International Labor Federation's collaborating with the American Federation of Labor in the United States.

The Central Maine Power Company, Augusta, Me., a subsidiary of the New England Public Service Company, has filed, under the Securities Act of 1933, a registration statement covering $4,500,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first and general mortgage bonds, Series J, due on Dec. 1, 1968, and 5,000 shares of no-par value common stock.

Field Marshal Hermann Goering- as the Four-Year plan chief, today delegated to Economics Minister Walther'Funk supervision of German industrial and labor strength to assure "central supervision in all branches."

Gifts to the 1938 Neediest Cases Fund from 763 contributors added $15,982.04 to its total yesterday and brought the aggregate amount that has been received so far in this twenty-seventh. annual appeal for A those in the greatest distress in the city to $166,332.39.
Mrs. A. W. Lee of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, widow of the founder of the Lee group of Middle Western newspapers, died here today in a hospital, where she underwent an operation on Wednesday.
" Harlequin House," the new novel by Margery Sharp, author of "The Nutmeg Tree," will be published on April 12 by Little, Brown.

Professional football was the standard-bearer for a general increase in attendance and interest in pro sports. This was the chief 1938 sports trend noted by the seventy critics who took part in the eighth annual Associated Press poll, it was announced yesterday.
Four more of the 109 Hudson County Election Board members indicted last February on charges of election law violations were acquitted by a jury today before Common Pleas Judge Thomas S. Brown, here.

Movements or vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 20, unless specified: Asheville, Hong Kong to Swatow. Erie, Cocos Island to Canal Zone, Dec. 19. Hannibal, at Port of Spain, Dec. 19. Kanawha, at San Diego. Monocacy, Kiukiang to Shanghai. Pennsylvania, Puget Sound to San Pedro via San Francisco. Sandpiper, at San Diego, Dec. 17; previous report in error.
Bitterly cold, snowy weather continued to spread suffering through Europe today, causing many deaths. Communications and transportation facilities were disrupted.
A Coast Guard plane crashed late last night at Boerne, thirty miles northwest of here, and killed four men.

The Treasury today announced its regular weekly offering of about $100,000,000 of discount bills of ninety-one-day maturity. Tenders will be received at Federal Reserve Banks and their branches until 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Friday, Dec. 23.
The Grand Trunk Western Railway announced today the appointment of P. D. Fitzpatrick, now chief engineer, as general manager, effective on the retirement of C. G. Bowker on Dec. 31.
Sixty-two bodies have been recovered from the burning wreckage of a passenger and a freight train that collided head-on yesterday at Barbacena in the State of Minas Geraes.

Directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway authorized yesterday the purchase of thirty oil-electric switching locomotives of 600 horsepower and of 900 horsepower at a cost of about $2,250,000. More equipment is to be bought later.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Yazoo Mississippi Valley Railroad Company to extend from Jan. 1, 1939, to Jan. 1, 1952, the date of maturity of $17,037,000 of 5 per cent gold improvement bonds. No objections were entered to the application.

Executors of the $10,000,000 estate of the late John E. Andrus of Yonkers, manufacturer and financier, were ordered today by Surrogate Charles D. Millard to resume the distribution of income from the estate to John E. Andrus Jr., a son, and other beneficiaries under the will.

Dr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Isaacson of 817 West End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Isaacson, to Dr. Alvin J. Gordon, son of Mrs. Isaac Gordon of New York and the late Mr. Gordon.

Doris Donaldson, an actress and dancer, was a witness yesterday before a Federal grand jury investigating charges of mail fraud against William Buckner in the sale of Philippine Railway bonds. Another witness was Captain John Stuart Hyde, retired engineer officer of the British Army.
To Fire Hazard Inspectors' School The following members are directed to report at the Fire Hazard Inspectors School, 32-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, at 1:15 P. M. on the dates specified:

The University of Toronto hockey team will meet Gonzaga at Spokane, Wash., tomorrow in the first game of a holiday tour that that will take the Blues from coast to coast, with the final contest against Dartmouth at Hanover, N. H.,
The New York Newspaper Women's Club will award four cash prizes of $100 each for outstanding work done by New York newspaper women during the past year, it was announced yesterday.

Distribution of "consumers' protection labels" of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board totaled 52,000 in the New York area yesterday, establishing a new high record for the day, it was announced yesterday.

Led by Joseph Fishbach of St. John's University, who is defending his last junior title, all the seeded players advanced as the third round of the metropolitan junior tennis championship was completed on the courts of the Engineers Armory yesterday.

Political events today moved toward reconstruction of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's Ministry during the next month's parliamentary recess and a possible general election early in the Spring on the issue of compulsory national service.
Prime Alexander Ferdinand of Hohenzollern and Mrs. irmgard Weygand, widow of a major in the German Air Force, were married today at the Dresden Garrison Church.
Stanley Bruce, Australian High Commissioner to London, hinted today that he had discussed with President Roosevelt a reciprocal trade agreement between Australia and the United States.

The Chase National Bank headed the successful banking group in the purchase yesterday of $3,957,000 Nassau County, L. I., refunding, public buildings and public works bonds, bidding 100.17 for the issue as 2.40s.

Reliable sources report disruption of railway traffic on the Peiping-Mukden line because of heavy troop movements. It was said that during the last few days five Japanese divisions had moved from North China to Manchukuo because of apprehension over. the Russo-Japanese situation.

Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, has been named a director of the International Mercantile Marine Company, leading American steamship operators in the North Atlantic field. He succeeds Kermit Roosevelt, son of the late President, who left the I. M. M. organization some months ago to return to the Kerr Line, with which he had his first steamship experience.

A celebration of the seventyeighth birthday of Miss Henrietta Szold, founder of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, was held yesterday by the national board of Junior Hadassah, 1,860 Broadway. Miss Szold is 78 years old today.
General Anton Denikin, White Russian, charged today that Nazi Germanyhas plotted a line of march eastward through the Soviet Ukraine to cut off all..the rich southern Provinces of the Soviet Union.
The annual Christmas party was held in the Morris mine of the Inland Steel Company today when, 1,500 feet below the surface, 200 miners ceased work and gathered round their Christmas tree.

A large luncheon was given yesterday by Mrs. Donald Campbell Walton at Sherry's for her debutante daughter, Miss Dona Maude Walton. Christmas decorations were used for the party. Miss Walton, who received with her mother, wore a dirndl gown of royal blue metallic cloth, a velvet hat of matching shade and a corsage of purple orchids.

The final official National Football League individual statistics released yesterday make it clear that Byron (Whizzer) White of Pittsburgh was the leading ground-gainer and that Ed Danowski of New York was the most efficient forward passer, but they do not indicate quite so plainly that Ace Parker of Brooklyn was, in reality, the big offensive gun of the pro circuit in 1938.

Charles Kniffin, a Union Army veteran, died Sunday afternoon in his home here-at the age of 95, and military honors will be paid at his funeral tomorrow in the Methodist Church, Wurtsboro, by the American Legion.

Although the Home Owners Loan Corporation has been engaged in an active sales campaign this year to dispose of the residences it was forced to take back because of mortgage defaults, it still has about 100,000 houses on its hands.

Roger Kent, Securities and Exchange Commission attorney of San Francisco, announced today he had learned an issue of a million yen of Japanese emergency bonds had been placed on sale in Hawaii and that he was conducting an investigation.

The government of this little republic, once a Spanish crown colony, called upon both sides of the Spanish civil war today to halt aerial bombardment of civilians. Antonio Rivera, president of the National Assembly, asked both Spanish factions to heed the supplication of "Spanish sons"
The featured Hollywood Purse, a six-furlong event for 3-year-olds and upward, provided a nerve-tingling finish at Tropical Park today, with three horses hitting the wire virtually on a line.

Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Dartmouth, who will meet again in the annual tournament of the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club tomorrow and Friday, have named their players. The teams will play three rounds, beginning at 9 A. M. tomorrow, for the Beldep-Stephens Trophy.

Persons close to the President's Joint Committee of Railroad Management and Labor said today that it might recommend reorganization of the Interstate Commerce Commission and revision of rate-making procedures.

The text of the Federal grand jury's indictment against the American Medical Association, three affiliated societies and twenty-one physicians on a charge of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act was as follows: District Court of the United States for the District of Columbia Holding a Criminal Term

George Rublee, American executive director of the Intergovernmental Committee on Refugees, was invited after a two months' wait today to go to Berlin to discuss plans for taking almost 700,000 Jews out of Germany.

A reply by the Port of New York Authority to the petition of the Eastern Motor Freight Conference for an increase in rates on traffic between the New York area and points in New England was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Mr. and Mrs. Dudley B. Cannafax of Houston, Texas, formerly of Great Neck, L. I., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Cannafax, to Card Elliott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott of Houston.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries, for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $11,758,316, after all operating expenses and charges.

The per capital income In the United States during 1937 was $540, compared with $494 in 1936 and the record level of $668 in 1929, the Department of Commerce reported today in a ten-year study of the national income.

Spokesmen for the Bethlehem Steel Company and several small steel companies united today in opposing the recommendation of the Public Contracts Board favoring 45 cents an hour as a minimum wage in the steel industry for twelve Southern States, and 62.5 cents an hour as the steel minimum In the rest of the country.

The West Orange Town Commission at a regular meeting here tonight tabled two proposed ordinances that would have paved the way for the construction of a gar- I den-type apartment building in the Gillespie tract on South Valley Road, here.

Nearly 400 theatrical scripts, prompt books, diaries and photographs collected by the late Winthrop Ames, producer, have been presented by Mrs. Ames to the New York Public Library, Dr. Harry Miller Lydenberg, director of the library, announced yesterday. Dr.

The executive committee of Fidelity Investment Association of Wheeling, W. Va., at a meeting here today instructed its officers to register under the Securities Act of 1933 and also approved an answer which will be filed tomorrow in the Federal Court in Detroit in the civil

Members of the Little Mothers Aid Association, of which Mrs. Frank Oliver Hall is president, will give a Christmas party for their nursery children tomorrow afternoon at the headquarters of the organization, 236 Second Avenue. Gifts for the children will be distributed by Santa Claus from a large, brightly decorated tree.
Bleecker St, 41, 30x31x irreg; Kath M. Slezak to Richard C. Whitlock, 120 Community Rd, Bayshore, L. I. ($10).

The Pure Oil Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment, under the Securities Act of 1933, to its registration statement filed in 1937 covering 5 per cent preferred stock and common stock, giving the present status of the securities issues.
Culbert L. Olson, Governor-elect of California, Visited Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday and repeated his statement that he planned to free Tom Mooney from San Quentin prison.

The Oratorio Society of New York began its sixty-fifth season in accustomed fashion, with a devout performance of Handel's "Messiah" at Carnegie Hall last night. The oratorio was prefaced by two short choruses: Bach's "To God in Whom I Trust" and Mozart's "Ave Verum," both of which were sung at the first concert of the society, then composed of twenty-eight singers, in Knabe Hall on Dec. 3, 1873, with Leopold Damrosch, the founder, conducting.

Benefactors of the Neediest Cases of New York. some of them old friends of those in great distress and others new contributors, joined yesterday in voicing the joy that they felt in helping to bring the spirit of Christmas to the broken men and women, the orphaned children, the friendless old folk for whom assistance is sought.

Glasby outran seven other starters today to take the feature event at the Fair Grounds. The favorite, timed in 1:434-5 for the mile and seventy yards, led Lucky Star and Ozark under the wire and returned $6.60 for $2.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Masterpieces of Painting of the XVI Century" (general tour), 11 A. M. "Masterpieces of Chinese Painting" (general tour), 2 P. M.

Harvard and Penn State, the East's only major undefeated soccer teams, placed two players each on the first all-Eastern eleven selected by the coaches for The Associated Press. Seven other teams were represented. They were Army,

Arrested in a 25-cent hotel room, Richard Mitman, 21 years old, was held in $25,000 bail here today as a "suspicious character" on the theory of police that he might have been involved in some of F. Donald Coster's suspected gun-running activities.

Arthur E. Boyd, assistant vice president at the Empire State office of the Manufacturers Trust Company, has been promoted to a vice president of the bank, it was announced yesterday. Joseph T. ReisI? of the investment advisory division also was made a vice president.

Plans by which the Kentucky Utilities Company, a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, and the International Utilities Corporation would divest themselves of control of the Southeastern Greyhound Lines were disclosed yesterday in an announcement that a syndicate headed by Hemphill, Noyes Co. soon would offer to the public the stock carrying control of the omnibus company.

Henry G. Singer, former chief assistant United States attorney of Brooklyn; was acquitted yesterday by a blue-ribbon jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court of a charge of conspiracy to obstruct justice by attempting to "fix" the Samuel Drukman murder case in April, 1935.
Rudyard Kipling's house and garden at Rottingdean, near Brighton, will be preserved in their present condition, if the Brighton Corporation can obtain them at a reasonable price.

Dr. Charles D. Parfitt, medical director of the Loomis Sanatorium, announced today that the institution would close on Dec. 31. The board of directors, of which the publisher, Bernarr McFadden, is chairman, hope to reopen the tuberculosis sanatorium next May.

Israel A. Horowitz and I. I. Kashdan finished play in the eighth game of their match for the championship of the American Chess Federation at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. The result was a draw in eighty moves.

Fred Apostoli, 161 1/2, of San Francisco, recognized by the New York Boxing Commission as the world's middleweight champion, barely got a workout tonight as he easily disposed of Al Cocozza, 165, of the Bronx in the fourth round of a ten-rounder. The knockout was a technical one, Referee Bill Conway calling a halt when the Bronx boy, refusing to fall, lay helpless against the ropes.

Canada's birth rate in the second quarter of 1938 showed a slight drop compared with the same period last year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. Live births totaled 57,480, giving an equivalent annual rate of 20.6 a 1,000 population, compared with 58,814 births and a rate of 21.2 for the second quarter of 1937.

Duke University and Durham joined in a noisy send-off late today for Duke's football squad, leaving to meet Southern California Jan. 2 in the Tournament of Roses game at Pasadena, Calif. The special train, due to reach Pasadena Saturday morning, carried thirty-four players of the unscored-on Blue Devils, five coaches, university officials, sports writers and fans.

Asa H. Morrill, chief engineer of the Boston Maine Railroad, the Maine Central Railroad and the Portland Terminal Company, who directed the task of restoring service for the three companies after the September hurricane, died today in the Maine General Hospital. He was 68 years old.

Support of fair trade price contracts, a demand for more effective enforcement by gasoline suppliers, approval of a retail gasoline licensing bill now pending before the City Council, and a protest against a recent price change.which reduced retailers' margins were voted at a luncheon meeting of the Garage and Gasoline Station Operators Council of Greater New York at the Center Hotel yesterday.

The National Star Spangled Banner Association was reorganized here today to conduct a movement to prevent dance orchestras from "swinging and jazzing" the national anthem and to combat organizations seeking the repeal of the United States statute making "The Star-Spangled Banner" the national anthem. The law became effective March 3, 1931.

Ken Overlin's come-back campaign struck a snag last night at the New York Coliseum, where the Chicago fighter, two years ago accounted a dangerous threat to the middleweight title, went down in defeat before stout-hearted Eric Seelig, German refugee, in a sizzling ten-round battle before about 7.000 excited fans.

Promoter Sydney Hulls today offered a purse of [Pound]4,000 ($18,700) with an option of 50 per cent of the gate for a. British Empire heavyweight title bout between Len Harvey, England, and Larry Gains, Canadian Negro boxer from Toronto. Hulls suggested the fight might.

Briefs in the reopening of the proceedings before the German-American Mixed Claims Commission were filed today, but oral argument was postponed by Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts, commission umpire, to Jan. 26.
The four-story apartment house on a plot 80 by 100 feet at 43-59 158th Street, Flushing, Queens, was sold by the Lafayette National' Bank, as trustee, to a client of Hy D. Agar, Inc., broker.
Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered less than in the preceding week. However,
Steel ingot production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index receded to 98.6, compared with 100.4 for the preceding week and 43.6 for the week ended Dec. 18, 1937.

Miss Mary W. Dewson, sole woman member of the Social Security Board and close collaborator with President' Roosevelt in studying social problems since his days as Governor of New York, resigned today for reasons of health.

Mrs. Finley J. Shepard of New York, the former Helen Gould, who was famous for her philanthropies in many fields, died at her Summer home here at 12:15 this morning, after being in a coma for more than 24 hours. She had suffered an apoplectic stroke ten days ago, and had been ill for two months. Her age was 70 years.

The retirement of W. S. and A. J. Townsend from the Townsend Advertising Research Institute to become partner in the advertising agency of Calkins Holden, and the selection of Albert E. Haase, one-time managing director of the Association of National Advertisers, as president of the institute was made known yesterday.

Valter M. Anderson, member of the Greenwich law firm of Anderson St. John, who was identified also in banking, fraternal and church circles, died of a heart attackk at his home this afternoon, soon after he had gone there from his office, where he became ill. His age was 62.

Miss Barbara Chambers, highschool senior here and daughter of Jackson Chambers, president of the Gramatan National Bank, will play the role of Mary in the pageant of the Nativity here Christmas Eve, it was announced today.

The last edition of Goya's etchings, of which one set is going to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, has not been any may never be completed, it was learned today. It is the most curious vicissitude that one of the world's greatest art treasures has suffered.

The sustained fire of the New York Americans, who attacked with five forwards in every period, proved futile tonight as the sensational goalie, Frank Brimsek, turned in his sixth shutout in seven games for the topplace Boston Bruins, giving the home sextet a 3-0 victory before 13,000 at the Boston Garden.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,276,300 barrels, compared with 3,245,100 in the previous week, an increase of 31,200, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
