Production was 29,500 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,305,800 daily by the Bureau of Mines for December. Gains of 16,500 and 7,400 barrels,

Reports that parts of the dry areas in the Oklahoma and Kansas Winter wheat belt were receiving much-needed moisture led today to fairly general selling of wheat futures on the Board of Trade here. Forecasts, too, indicated additional precipitation overnight.

James H. Payne of 140 East Fiftyfifth Street, a former auditor of the State Workmen's Insurance Fund, pleaded not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to another indictment developed in the investigation Governor Lehman ordered last Spring of alleged employers' insurance frauds.

Roy N. Bishop, retired mining man and oil company executive, died suddenly at his home here today at the age of 60. Mr. Bishop, a brother-in-law of William T. Dewart, publisher of The New York Sun, appeared in excellent health yesterday when he visited his office.

For the third consecutive session, prices on the Cotton Exchange strengthened yesterday, ending with gains of 1 to 5 points. As on each of the preceding trading days, support appeared following slight recessions, and a scarcity of contracts brought best quotations toward the close.

The International Petroleum Company, Ltd., controlled by Imperial Oil, Ltd., which in turn is controlled by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, has disposed of one-half of its interest in the crude oil production of the Mene Grande Oil Company, C. A., Venezuelan subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation,

Katharine Hepburn is returning to the footlights in a new Philip Barry comedy, "The Philadelphia Story," which the Theatre Guild has bought for its fourth produotion of the season. Miss Hepburn appeared on tour two years ago in the Guild's "Jane Eyre," but it never reached Fifty-second Street.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 19: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Lough, M. S., Inf., 21 days' leave, Jan. 25. Bingham, S. V., Cav., Hawaii, to Third Ave., Ft. Myer, Va. MAJORS Gilbert, H. N., Adjutant General's Dept., 15 days' leave, Dec. 21. Poage, R. O., Inf., 4 months' leave, Dec. 31.

Between 1929 and 1938 Loew's, Inc., realized $13,553,049 from motion pictured whose scripts had been written off as worthless on the company's books, J. Robert Rubin, a vice president, testified yesterday in a minority stockholders' accounting suit on trial before Justice Louis A. Valente in Supreme Court.

Without the slightest indication that he had been involved in a scuffle at City Hall tarlier in the day, Mayor La Guardia addressed the graduating class of the Police Academy last night after the traditional commencement program at the 165th Infantry Armory, Twenty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Led by Captain Al Carvelli, who figured in all but one of his team's scores and accounted for two goals himself, Boston University's hockey team handed Harvard's unbeaten sextet a 6to-3 defeat at the Boston Arena tonight.

Word has been received here of the engagement of Miss Louise Bricker, daughter of Major and Mrs. L. Monroe Bricker of Fort Mills, Manila Bay, the Philippines, to Lieutenant Richard H. Mattern, Coast Artillery Corps, U. S. A.

Five manikins chosen from hundreds of applicants will go to South America on the good-neighbor fashion tour sponsored by Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum, president of Bonwit Teller, in cooperation with the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday. The girls chosen,

" Business men who are interested in preserving the largest measure of freedom possible" were urged tonight by William McChesney Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, to strive for peaceful relations with the government.
Two deals on Fifty-fifth Street were among the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday. Trading was rather light, due to the approach of the Christmas holidays.

In a thrilling contest, decided on the ninth touch of the final bout, the Salle d'Armes Vince fencing team of Daniel Bukantz, Nathaniel Lubell and Sidney Kaplan retained the national junior foils championship on the strips of the Fencers Club last night.

Vladimir Koudrey, author, who served as Commissar of Army Supplies in the early days of the Soviet region and who related his exciting adventures in a book entitled "Once a Commissar," died Monday night in the Harkness Pavilion, Medical Center, of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 43 years old.

Two of the three judges of the Seventh Federal Circuit Court of Appeals held today that Federal judges had no right to comment on the evidence in jury trials. Such comment, the judges insisted, abridged the constitutional right of a defendant to a fair trial. They added that the practice should be stopped.

Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight Dec. 19: SERGEIANT-George L. McGovern, 50th Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed Feb. 5, 1912. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Dec. 21: PATROLMEN-From precincts indicated to 18th Division, designated as Third Grade Detectives: John G. Culhane, 15th Precinct. Philip J. Curtin, 25th Precinct.

Dr. H. A. Bartholomew, coroner of Warren County, today rendered a verdict absolving Miss Florence McIntyre of Philadelphia and Francis E. Martin Jr. of New York City of criminal negligence in an automobile accident on the Lake George--Bolton highway on July 16 in which two persons were killed.

A group of bankers including the principal officers of the American Bankers Association called today on President Roosevelt to assure him of their "hearty" cooperation in assisting the Administration to work out banking problems. They also invited him to address their

Production of mineral wool bats and strips in the third quarter gained 37 per cent over the second quarter and 88 per cent over the first quarter, Wharton Clay, secretary of the National Mineral Wool Association, reported yesterday.

The American Medical Association, the Medical Society of the District of Columbia the Washington Academy of Surgery of this city, the Harris County Medical Society of Houston, Texas, and twenty-one physicians of Chicago, and Washington, including some of the country's leading physicians and surgeons,

Mayor La Guardia applied a cutting torch to a girder of the Sixth Avenue elevated yesterday to begin the demolition of the obsolete structure, the removal of which is expected by city experts to raise real estate values $275,000,000 in ten years in areas along the old route.
Essex St, 141, 25x89; Silvermore Realty Corp to Albert Lowenfels, 1,255 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, extr Frederick F. Lowenfels; 5 yrs, 5 1/2 %; $8,500.

Although, he admitted he had walked off with $103,400 in gems from his former employers, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Townsend Jr. of Syosset, L. I., on Oct. 25, and pawned one of Mrs. Townsend's diamond rings for $75 to buy drinks, George Fleming, 32 years old, a chauffeur, was discharged by Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday on his own recognizance.
The assembly of a large plot opposite the Red Hook housing development in Brooklyn, upon which the buyer plans to erect a two-story business building, was announced yesterday.

George Zinovoy of New Utrecht was installed as chairman of the High School Games Committee of the Public Schools Athletic League for the next two years at the biennial election of officers at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

The problem of the 600,000 to 700,000 German Jews whose exodus is being forced by expropriation and the threat of ultimate destruction is one, and probably not the last, of a series of such problems that Nazi Germany has presented to the world.

Crown Prince Olaf and Crown Princess Martha of Norway will be the guests of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt at Hyde Park late in April when they come to this country to open the Norwegian Building at the New York World's Fair and to make a good-will tour, it was announced by the State Department today.

The memory of the eighteen former members of the Knickerbocker Greys, junior military organization, who died in the World War, was honored yesterday at the annual Christmas drill of the Greys at the 107th Infantry (Old Seventh) Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue.

The first of a series of reports based on a census of corporations whose securities are listed on the stock exchanges, covering twelve steel companies with assets of more than $100,000,000 each, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The stock market was quietly irregular today, though weakness in some groups was due more to slackness than selling pressure. Gilt-edge stocks continued to decline and an otherwise steady foreign list was distinguished by strength in French and weakness in Czech issues.

Miss Constance Louise Sherwin was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given by her father, Robert Waterston Sherwin, in the roof garden of the Pierre. The debutante, who received with' her father, wore a white tulle gown trimmed with paillettes and carried a bouquet of gardenias.

A number of deer hunters seem to subscribe to the theory that "you can't be hanged for trying," with the result that the wardens are kept busy arresting those who didn't try hard enough. Down' near Tuckerton, N. J., the other day, one hunter tried a new method for getting a deer, but it proved to be far from the success he planned.

Mrs. Marie Hite Burckhalter, 44 years old, of Hastings-on-Hudson, was indicted today by the Westchester County grand jury on a charge of first-degree manslaughter for "aiding and assisting, her husband, Eugene Y. Burckhalter, 47, to commit suicide.

Mayor La Guardia was punched in the face and knocked down on the steps of City Hall just before noon yesterday by a husky middleaged stonemason, formerly employed by the WPA, who blamed the Mayor for his misfortunes.

While it is doubtful what the final outcome will be, yesterday's broadsides on minimum steel wages ordered by the Secretary of Labor for companies eligible to bid on public contracts have served to clarify the views of a large.cross-section of the steel industry.

Shareholders of the National Power and Light Company, at a special meeting yesterday, voted to authorize the sale of the electric properties of the West Tennessee Power and Light Company, a subsidiary to the Tennessee Valley Authority and certain municipalities in the

The property known as 1,211-17 Sixth Avenue and 102 West Fortyeighth Street, consisting of a plot 80.5 by 65 feet, now improved with two four-story and three five-story buildings, and forming the southwest corner, has been leased for twenty-one years by Richard P., Marie J. and Cornelia B. Lydon and Elizabeth L. Behr to the L. and L. Realty Corporation, George Lantzounis, president.

The University Club maintained its lead among the Class B teams in Group 1 of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association last night by defeating the Squash Club, 3 to 2. With their No. 4 player, Ivy Lee Jr., defaulting and their No. I man, J.

The Department of Commerce reported yesterday that shipments of railroad locomotives in the first eleven months of the year numbered 240 units, against 463 units in the same period of 1937. Previously, the Association of American Railroads reported the railroads put in service 265 locomotives of all kinds in the period, against 401 in the same period a year previously.

A gift of a hobby horse brought a cry of "Oh, boy!" from a youngster named Julio yesterday and set the keynote for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's annual Christmas party at the Woman's Trade Union League for him and thirty-five other lads.
All was friendly again today in this Ohio River village, where the men work and women rule, after the police chief apologized for slapping the Mayor. The controversy,

George H. Clayton, 44 years old, formerly of 111-47 116th Street, Ozone Park, Queens, who was arrested as a fugitive in Canada last week on the indictment accusing him and five others of the theft of $700,000 from seven investment trusts, pleaded not guilty yesterday in General Sessions.

The attack on Mayor La Guardia yesterday provokes the Lokal-Anzeiger in a front-page editorial today to say, "Not his victim should be sympathized with, but the attacker himself." The paper declares the assailant acted out of necessity induced by conditions in the, United States fostered by Mr., La Guardia and "the people of his circle," who include among others "the gangster Musica."

Even though such a step may lead to the curtailment of production, shirt manufacturers were yesterday advised by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers to forgo hiring new, inexperienced workers until the Wages and Hours Law administrator issues a definite regulation as to the employment of learners.

Joey Fontana, 133, of Bensonhurst easily outpointed Ray Ingram, 131 1/4, of Washington, D. C., in the eight-round feature boxing contest at the Broadway Arena last night before more than 5,000 fans. Fontana won every round and had in Ingram's left eye closed and his right eye cut at the finish.

New officers for the American Record Corporation have been appointed on a temporary basis by the Columbia Broadcasting System, which, with Consolidated Film Industries, Inc., has just acquired the concern. Pending appointment of permanent executives, Adrian Murphy will be president, Frank K. White treasurer,

Alan E. Ashcraft, vice president t of Fairbanks, Morse Co., whose home and office has been in Beloit, will go to Chicago Jan. 1 to be vice president in charge of all the company's manufacturing operations, it was announced today by Colonel Robert H. Morse, president of the company.

With an assortment of jumping and downhill skis slung over his shoulders, Reidar Andersen, one of the world's outstanding jumpers and probably the premier stylist in ski competition today, arrived yesterday on the steamship Oslofjord of the Norwegian-America Line.
Raymond R. Sooy, superintendent of recording of the RCA Victor Company, died of a heart attack at his home here today at the age of 59.

Governor Moore presented the Congressional Medal of Honor today to Commander Isaac Schlossbach, member of three polar expeditions. The presentation was made in the presence of the Governor's staff and

Above the beach the pine tree flung Its branches toward the sea; For years its twisted roots had clung To rock tenaciously. Within its shade the gulls had sketched Calligraphy on sand; And centuries of waves had etched The small shell in my hand.

H. H. McCollum, character actor who played the role of Tristan I'Hermite, evil adviser of Louis XI, during the long run of "The Vagabond King" at the Casino Theatre, died Monday night of pneumonia in the Polyclinic Hospital. He was born in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., fifty-four years ago.

A suspended thirty-day sentence was imposed upon Nunzio Signorello in Tombs Court on Monday after he had pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct in connection with a fracas on Thursday night in the office of William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, at 2 Lafayette Street. THE NEW YORK TIMES reported incorrectly yesterday that he had been discharged.

Chicago's ordinance to license horse-race betting places was ruled invalid today by Circuit Judge Harry M. Fisher, who upheld an opinion of the State Attorney General's office in a quo warrant action against the city.

The will of Patrick Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, who died on Sept. 4, was formally admitted to probate yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley. The testament, which was offered on Oct. 7, was admitted after John Killoran, the probate clerk, had examined the subscribing witnesses.

Representatives of both management and labor, it is reported, will soon urge upon the President and Congress that the railroads should have greater leeway than at present in making rates. Such a request would clearly be reasonable. When the Interstate Commerce Commission was first created, the railroads were properly considered to have a monopoly of both freight and passenger transportation.

Governor Lehman will take the oath of office for his fourth term in his New York City apartment rather than. at the Executive Mansion as had been planned, Walter T. Brown, secretary to the Governor, said today.

Lotte Lehmann, German-Austrian soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, who has taken out her first papers for American citizenship, was extolled last night at a dinner in her honor at the Hotel Astor as a symbol of the cultural contribution brought to this country by refugees from Nazi persecution.

The statement of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $5,258,041 after all charges and taxes, which was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.27 a share on the 1,936,458 common shares owned by the public.

In another fairly active cattle market today steers and yearlings advanced as much as 25 cents, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Yearlings and heavy steers topped at $13.25. While hog receipts increased, the market was moderately active at mostly 10 cents lower prices, best lightweights sold at $7.50. Fat lambs were dull and bulk sales were completed at 25 to 35 cents lower, extreme top $9.35 for small lots.

A set of principles aiming at "genuine manufacturer-wholesaler" cooperation in the dry goods field, committing both groups to definite policies, has been drafted after a year's work by the Joint Committee for the Advancement of Manufacturer-Wholesaler Relations, it was announced yesterday by Henry Matter, chairman of the committee.
The Civil Service Commission put its foot down flatly today on a proposal that congenital:flat feet no longor should bar candidates from ap pointment as police and firemen.

Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet's statement in the French Chamber of Deputies and Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's statement in the British House of Commons yesterday did not evoke any vigorous reaction here.

Turpentine firm, 23c; sales 15 barrels; receipts 231 barrels; no shipments: stock 52,292 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 571; receipts 872; shipments 170; stock 315,227. Quote: B, $3.70; D, $3.95; E, $4.10; F $4.30; G, H, I, K, $4.37 1/2: M, $4.40; N $5.35; WG, $5.80; WW, x, $6.30.

Sigurd Boschen, in 42 Park Ave: Richard W. Van Horne and Kevin M. McInerney, through Apartment Renting Co, in 140 W 57th St; Donald M. Forgan, in 1,000 Park Ave; Mrs. Geoffrey Marler, in 122 E 64th St; Payson McL. Merrill Co, Inc, broker.

A committee to determine minimum wages for branches of the apparel industry affecting 500,000 employes was appointed today by Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Division of the Labor Department.

Bids were received yesterday by the city Departmentof Parks for a half million dollar, construction job on the Circumferential Parkway. This sixth contract in the project is for grading, drainage and paving of the highway between Arthur Street and Brookville Boulevard in Springfield,

The Interstate Commerce Commission granted authority today to the Railway Express Agency to issue $16,000,000 of serial notes, Series A, to be sold to a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., at 99 and accrued interest.

Benjamin Whiteley, who retired as a vice president and treasurer of the Consolidated Gas Company in 1929, died in Baltimore on Sunday,, it was announced yesterday at the Consolidated Edison offices. Funeral services were held in Baltimore yesterday.

William F. X. Geoghan; District Attorney of Brooklyn, charged yesterday in open court that Police Inspector Michael F. McDermott had "broken his word" and "run out" on a promise to join the prosecutor in recommending leniency for a defendant who had confessed that he had impersonated another -person in a criminal proceeding.
Bond prices moved narrowly in listless trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Changes mostly were restricted to no more than a point, with leading issues setting no trend.

The City of New York, 56-year-old former ice-breakig whaler which Richard E. Byrd used on his first Antarctic expedition, today was ordered sold at public auction on Jan. 5 to satisfy claims of $1,525. Federal Judge Paul Jones issued the order in connection with a. suit of the ship's caretaker,

Charging that errors of both fact and law have occurred in proceedings thus far in the negotiations for proposed fair trade practices for the wool industry, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers yesterday filed a request for a hearing before the full Federal Trade Commission.

Four spokesmen for religion broadcast a condemnation of the attitude of Nazi Germany toward religion in addresses last night over radio station WMCA and associated stations of the intercity system. The program was arranged by the NonSectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights.

Oldsmobile dealers sold 5,077 new sixes and eights during the first ten days of December, the second largest sales for that period in the entire history of the company, it was disclosed yesterday by C. L. McCuen. general manager.

The New York State Labor Relations Board yesterday handed down a final decision and order finding that the two subsidiaries of the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Company had assisted in the establishment of a company union during the Summer of 1937 and ordering the dissolution of the union.

Charles H. Strohson, clerk of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors, opened today thirteen sealed bids for the general construction work on the proposed Nassau County Court House, to be erected on the 73-acre site of the Mineola Fair Grounds. The P. J. Carlin Construction Company of 405 'Lexington Avenue, New York, submitted the lowest base bid of

A second-innings collapse by New South Wales gave South Australia victory by an innings and.55 runs in their Sheffield Shield cricket match concluded today. In reply to South Australia's record score .of 600 for eight wickets, declared, the visiting team was dismissed for total of 390 and 155.

That justice may slumber and rackets flourish in the smaller cities of the State as well as in the larger ones is indicated by Governor Lehman's order for a broad investigation of corruption in Orange County and the city of Newburgh.
Mrs. Sabina Balsor received congratulations on her 100th birthday today. Age has not impaired her hearing and she is able to read. Her husband, John Balsor, died nineteen years ago.

Marchese Filipo Crispolte, former editor of the Vatican newspaper, Osservatore Romano, and a former Catholic party Deputy, told the Senate today the government was taking steps to eliminate certain aspects of the new anti-Semitic laws.

With Christmas less than a week away, war communiques issued' at Generalissimo Francisco Franco's headquarters at Salamanca still report nightly with monotonous regularity that there is "nothing worth mentioning on any battlefront."

The vault containing the body of the Rev. William Clowery, first pastor, in 1859, of St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church at 308 East Thirty-seventh Street, was uncovered yesterday afternoon by a group of men working in the churchyard which will be a part of the plaza of the Thirty-eighth Street Midtown Tunnel. The vault was intact. Father Clowery died in 1884.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a declaration filed by the Kentucky-Tennessee Light and Power Company regarding the sale of its note of $750,000, dated Nov. 14 and maturing Oct. 14, 1939, under certain conditions, among them that the face amount of the note

Joseph R. Oppennheimer, secretary and treasurer of the West Disinfecting Company in Long Island City and active in Jewish charities of Manhattan and Brooklyn, died on Monday in Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn. He was born in Brooklyn and lived there until ten years ago, when he moved to Manhattan.
Brisk leasing of space for business occupancy was reflected yesterday in the long list of new rentals submitted by brokers and agents.
A communication line, described, as the longest in the world, was opened from the office of the Secretary of State today when radio-telephone service was begun on a commercial basis with Australia.

The annual New Year's Eve ball of the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club will take place in the clubhouse here on Dec. 31. Subscribers have been asked to wear costumes of the period "1849-1939." Mrs. Holbrook B. Cushman is chairman of the ball committee and Mrs. Ronald C. Lee heads the decorations committee.

George Charles Lewis, president and director of the L. Martin Company of 45 East Forty-second Street, dealer in lampblack, died late Monday night in the garden of his home at 167 Third Street, New Dorp, S, I. He was 64 years old.

Three deer kept the Auburn police force busy today as they played tag with shoppers and raced about the residential area. One ran through the pre-Christmas traffic in the busy shopping area of State and Dill Streets, crashed into the rear of an automobile and was taken to the Humane Society Shelter for treatment of its injuries.

Under the glare of a powerful searchlight, with the murky East River for a backdrop and the shadowy Manhattan skyscrapers towering in the distance, a drama was staged at -6 o'clock last night by Sergeant Louis Bahrenburg of the Meserole Avenue station, Brooklyn,

The general contract for erection of a $9,500,000 steam-electric generating station at Oswego, N. Y., has been awarded to the Stone Webster Engineering Corporation, it was announced yesterday by John L. Haley, president of the Central New York Power Corporation.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Conant of 410 Riverside Drive have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lorraine Halsey at Conant, to Henry Sampson Gillette, son of Dr. Curtenius Gillette of New York and Lake George. The announcement was made at a dinner given last night by Mr. and Mrs. Conant at their home.

Mr. and Mrs. John Howle Wright and Mrs. McAlpin Bell jointly gave a supper dance last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Anne Wright and Miss Shirley McAlpin Bell. Mrs. Wright and Mrs. Bell received with the debutantes.

Next year will give the home building industry its best business since 1929, P. A. Andrews, vice president of Johns-Manville, told 450 owners and managers of building materials retail establishments in this section at a one-day "clinic" on the problems of the building industry at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Noah MacDowell Jr. of 4 East Seventy-second Street and Waterford, Conn., gave a tea dance yesterday for their debutante daughter, Miss Annetta MacDowell, at their home here, at which they announced her engagement to William Stuart Harrington, son of Colonel Francis Clark Harrington of Washington, D. C., and the late Mrs. Harrington.

A contingent of 323 members of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade who fought with the Government forces in Spain returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Ausonia and were welcomed by 400 friends and relatives' assembled on the pier at West Fourteenth Street.

The large apartment building containing sixty-eight apartments and seven stores on a plot 150 by 100 feet at 1,057 Boynton Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Nathan Boris to an investing client of Goodman Friedman, attorneys.

A spirited rally in the third period enabled the St. Paul's School hockey team of Concord, N. H., to defeat the Yale freshmen at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The prep school players, trailing by a goal at the end of the second chapter, released a heavy offensive in the final frame and came through with a 3-to-2 triumph over their New Haven rivals.

The retirement system of the New York State Bankers Association, embracing 700 officers and employes of sixty-six banks, will be placed in operation on Jan. 1, Raymond F. Leinen, chairman of the board of trustees of the retirement system and executive vice president of the Lincoln-Alliance Bank and Trust Company of Rochester, an nounced yesterday.
Representatives of the German and Hungarian minorities have asked the authorities whether they will be allowed to join the newly founded National Front.

Flanked by the boys' choir of Sacred Heart Church and the Police Glee Club, Mayor La Guardia conveyed his holiday wishes to the people of the city at City Hall yesterday afternoon, as his daughter Jean pulled a switch that lighted Park Department Christmas trees in each of the five boroughs.

Colonel and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan were hosts at dinner tonight at their villa. Captain and Mrs R. Amcotts Wilson entertained with a luncheon at home for their guests, the Duchess of Sutherland, the Hon. Elizabeth Leveson Gower and Lady Margaret Egerton.

Mrs. Pauline Evanishyn, 36 years old, who gave the address 217 Twenty-first Street, Paterson, N. J., was convicted by a General Sessions jury yesterday of swindling two women and a man, from whom she was accused of obtaining about $18,000 in the last year.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the Republic Supply Company of California, a subsidiary, announced yesterday the joint acquisition of more than half of the stock of the Emsco Derrick and Equipment Company of California, including all holdings of E. M.
The new 28,000-ton liner Stockholm was destroyed today by a fire that was fanned by a gale.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has refunded $936,500 to consumers of the company in connection with a _ gas-rate reduction ordered by the Public Serviee Commission, it was announced yesterday after commission experts had examined the company's books and records.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club maintained its unbeaten pace in the New York Amateur Hockey Association last night by crushing the New York- Sporting Club skaters, 13 to 4, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. The victory was the seventh straight in the league for the St. Nicks.

A Children's Christmas Festival will be held at the Mercury Theatre from next Monday morning through the following Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Lawren and Samuel N. Benjamin, operators of the theatre.

Mary Foster Pitney and Miss Elinor Carlyle Gudger made their debuts here today. Miss Pitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shelton Pitney of New York and Morristown, N. J., and granddaughter of the late Justice Mahlon Pitney of the Supreme Court, was introduced to Washington society at a tea given by her grandmother at her home.

A hundred students, including small boys and girls, were injured today when police made two charges to disperse sit-down strikers protesting against "British imperialism." Many were taken to hospitals.

Ominously Tokyo sources announce that consideration will be given to retaliation against powers that are assisting the Chiang Kaishek regime when the third conference of the joint commission of the Peiping and Nanking regimes convenes in Peiping Friday.

Electrical Research Products, Inc., will begin the foreign distribution on Jan. 1 of a complete line of booth equipment, including projectors, lamps, screens, converters and similar products of American manufacture, it was announced yesterday by E. S. Gregg, foreign manager.

The Musicas were found yesterday to have profited little by changing their names fifteen years ago and following their brother Philip out of his criminal record and into the $86,000,000 assets of McKesson Robbins, Inc.

Hugo Fried, 44 years old, of 525 Lexington Avenue, testified yesterday in the General Sessions trial of two men for the kidnapping of his brother, Arthur Fried, 32, a Bronx business man, concerning ransom demands by the abductors.

The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the award of contracts for a total of 240,000 yards of textiles, for shipment by Dec. 30, from bids opened on Dec. 13, as follows: 823-TW--Birdseye, Riverside and Dan River Cotton Mills, Inc.,

The police of the West Twentieth Street station last night discovered a cache of 105 kegs of liquid belived to be prohibition rye whiskey in a specially constructed brick vault in the cellar of the four-story tenement building at 153 West Eighteenth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. Harry Cuneo, 53 years old, a truckman,

Five George Bernard Shaw plays, the first of which will be "The Doctor's Dilemma," will be produced in England by Gabriel Pascal for Metro, the producer-director announced today upon his arrival from New York. "Doctor's Dilemma" will be followed by "Major Barbara," "St. Joan," "Cleopatra" and "The Devil's Disciple." It is probable that but two will be made next year.

The Commodity Exchange Administration, in its annual report, published today, made known substantial progress had been made toward fulfillment of the objectives of the Grain Futures Act and the Commodity Exchange Act, both of which were adopted to insure fair practice and honest dealing on exchanges;

Gleason Ave (14-3760), n w cor of Rosedale Ave, 99x22; Marcell N. Rand to Clementina Haines, 1,209 Rosedale Ave. Walton Ave (11-2850), w s, 109 ft s of 176th St, 47x100; Barbara Vlasate to Levitt Operating Corp, 1,669 Park Ave.

The Henry Hadley Foundation announces a prize of $500 for the best musical score of any major form to be submitted within the next year. Mrs. William Vanamee, president, said that the work would be published and performed under the auspices of the foundation.

Dr. Samuel Colville Lind, dean of the Institute of Technology of the University of Minnesota, has been elected president of the American Chemical Society for 1940. Professor Charles A. Kraus of Brown University is president for 1939, succeeding Dean Frank C. Whitmore of Pennsylvania State College.

Only two newspapers commented today that it was the twentieth anniversary of the late exPresident Thomas G. Masaryk's entry into Prague after he had obtained the Constitution of the Czecho-Slovak Repubic.
The safest place to leave the question of a third term for President is with the "judgment and patriotism of the voters," said Senator Borah today.

The Dodgers yesterday acquired Luke Sewell, veteran catcher, in a deal with the White Sox. Larry MacPhail, executive vice president of the Dodgers, announced the deal, which brought the number of ball players on the Brooklyn roster to forty-one. Chicago obtained waivers on Sewell, a fourteen-year man in the American League.

In an exhibition match at the Princeton Club last night Tony Iannicelli, pro at the Short Hills club and holder of the world open professional squash tennis title, defeated Rowland Dufton, New York Athletic Club pro, 15-8, 15-8, 18-16.

F. Donald Coster wrote a suicide note last Friday after he had been exposed as Philip Musica, according to the first formal statement issued here yesterday for him and the surviving Musica brothers by their counsel, Samuel Reich, who is also United States Commissioner at Bridgeport, Conn.

One hundred and fifty of Fifth Avenue's leading merchants, including the large department stores and specialty shops, will participate, in "The Dawn of a New Day on Fifth Avenue-the City's Greatest Retail Shopping Street" to be sponsored next Wednesday morning by the Fifth Avenue Association in conjunction with the New York World's Fair Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Captain William Pedrick, president of the association.

A hard-playing and stout-hearted Panzer basketball team fought New York University's previously undefeated quintet to a standstill last night at the University Heights gymnasium to earn a 43-to-29 vietory before some 1,600 spectators.

Arthur E. Morgan, deposed chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority accused the TVA today of "surrendering" its bargaining position with respect to the proposed Fontana Dam site on te Tennessee River to the Aluminum Company of America.

Consumption of Lake Superior iron ores in November was 3,150,073 tons, the highest since October of last year, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today. In October, last year, 4,203,873 tons were burned.

MANHATTAN BRETTHAUER, LINA (Nov. 25). Estate, less than $10,000. To Karl WagenbacK, Pauline and Herman Dlehi, all of Marktstrasse 28, Gedern, Oberhessen, Germany, residue equally; eighteen varying bequests. German Society of the City of New York, 544 E. 17th St., executor.
There seems to be every indication that the United States will come out of the eighth Pan-American conference with less prestige than at any time in the last ten years.

A return of the old system of strict government control, amounting to a prohibition of long-term loans by British bankers to firms in foreign countries, was announced by Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the House of Commons today.
Plans were filed yesterday for a four-story addition to the Manhattan School of Music at 228-38 East 105th Street, by Mayers, Murray Phillip, architects.

Among the Catholics, Protestants and Jews of our country a binding sense of unity has developed in the common hatred of cruelty and the universal belief in individual freedom, peace and good-will that is the essence of the Christmas spirit, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve declared yesterday in her annual the greeting at the Barnard College Christmas assembly.

A tunnel between Japan and Korea more than eighty miles long, under the Straits of Tsushima and Korea, is contemplated by the Ministry of Communications, which has decided on a preliminary survey of the sea bottom.

Richard C. Hoyt, radio technician, who kept in daily communication from New York with the Byrd 'Antarctic expedition in 1934-for the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, with whom he was employed, died today in the Mount Vernon Hospital of injuries suffered last night when he fell under a train of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. He was 35 years old and lived at 60 East Fourth Street.

Fifty legislative representatives of the American Federation of Labor, its affiliated unions and of the railroad brotherhoods met at A. F. of L. headquarters today and made a preliminary- canvass of the major legislative program which these unions will press for consideration in the coming Congressional session.

Sunday's municipal election, whose results became available tonight, show the Socialists and democratic elements generally were the only ones to come out greatly strengthened, despite the success of the National Democrats in Western Poland.

The Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today the objections of counsel for William Fox, bankrupt motion picture producer, to questioning outside of New Jersey concerning his financial affairs. The court, in a 2-to-i opinion, Judge J. Whittaker Thompson dissenting, reversed the decision of District Judge John Boyd Avis of Camden.

" Die Walkuere" was given last night at the Metropolitan OperaHouse in a special performance for the benefit of the German-American Relief Organizations in Greater New York. A capacity house attended and there were many standees.

A tall Christams tree trimmed to the shape of the World's Fair trylon and an evergreen globe resembling the perisphere were dedicated last night in Times Square between Forty-sixth and forty-seventh Streets by Grover Whalen, with a number of theatre stars assisting.

The severest cold wave this year has brought additional hardship to 6,000 Jewish refugees from Germany marooned on the frontier. Reports from Zbonszyn, where the refugees are interned, describe their plight as tragic. Many have been frostbitten because of being herded in disused stables and mills without heating facilities.

MANHATTAN BURLINGHAM, ROBERT (May 28, 1938). Gross assets, $24,708; net, $23,474. To Dorothy T. Burlingham, widow, residue; one other bequest. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $21,830. Burlingham, Veeder, Clark Hupper, attorneys, 27 William St. DEENING, STEWART (July 17, 1938). Gross assets, $14,661; net, $13,346. To Stewart T. Denning, grandnephew. Chief assets, stocks and bonds. $10,187. Niles Johnson, attorneys, 27 William St.

The appointment of Dr. John Kirtland Wright to the post of director of the American Geographical Society, to succeed Dr. Isaiah Bowman, who resigned in 1935 to become president of Johns Hopkins University, was announced last night at the regular monthly meeting of the society, at the American Museum of Natural History. The announcement was made by Roland L. Redmond, president of the society.

Spanish Rebels are watching with- some anxiety the progress of the PanAmerican conference in Lima because they desire that the cultural and economic links between Spain and the countries to which she gave birth should be tightened.

Salaried employes of P. Ballantine Son of Newark will receive today a Christmas bonus amounting to $210,000, or 15 per cent of their year's pay, for the fourth consecutive year, it was announced yesterday by Carl W. Badenhausen, president.

Shopping crowds on Fifth Avenue in the lower-Fifties were treated to the spectacle of a woman, pistol in hand, chasing a man down the avenue yesterday afternoon. They were unaware that the woman was Detective Mary Shanley of the pickpocket squad, performing :her regular duties.

A sharp rise in the number of pneumonia cases to the greatest total for any week since that ended last April 9 was reported yesterday for the week of Dec. 11-17 by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records in the city Health Department. Mr. Duffield told Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, that 362 new cases were recorded, compared with 291 in the previous week.

Gladys Avaritt asked Santa Claus to give her life-and today had the first of a series of transfusions of the blood she must have if she is to see other Christmases. The hospital where the 10-year-old girl lies a victim of a plastic anemia, a lethal blood disease, made public yesterday this simple, oral "letter to Santa Claus":

Because of its great success, the bazaar for the relief of homeless Czechoslovakian women and children will close tonight at 25 West Forty-third Street, two days earlier than had been announced previously.

When flames today drove thirty-eight school children from the West Leroy Methodist Church, where they had been rehearsing a Christmas play, they defied the fire long enough to take with them their decorated Christmas tree, although most of them lost their hats and coats.

The President is represented by his intimates as holding that, of all the factors to be considered in choosing men and women for office, geographical distribution should and does count the least with the people. He is said to feel that if an eligible meets his other requirements for a post he need not be eliminated as a matter of policy because he happens to have official residence in a State already widely entrenched. Mr.

Today's events: "Orfeo," Metropolitan Opera, evening; Trio of New York, Town Hall, evening; Composers' Forum-Laboratory, Carnegie Chamber Hall, evening; Federal Symphony Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, evening; Down Town Glee Club, Carnegie Hall, evening; Associted Music Teachers League meeting, Steinway Hall, 10 A. M.; Schola Cantorum, John Wanamaker's, 6; Zilbert's Choir, 251 West 100th Street, evening.

Immediate efforts to reduce California's crude oil production to 600,000 barrels a day by Christmas were promised by 400 operators today. They declared an emergency in the industry is caused by overproduction.

Governor Moore signed today the bill passed by the Legislature last night appropriating $75,000 for New Jersey's participation in the New York World's Fair. Work is to be started next Tuesday on the State's building,- which is to be a reproduction of the old barracks here in which British troops were housed in colonial days.
A strike of food handlers sharply curtailed food distribution today in this city of about 600,000 population.

Several issues are involved in the fight that the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O. are making against the new Oregon Labor Law. These issues call for separate consideration. Whether, as the unions contend, the new law so affects the operation of the Oregon Unemployment Compensation Act as to deprive the State of the right to a tax credit under the Federal law is for the Social Security Board to decide.

Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, president of the International Drug Club, has sent letters to approximately 100 drug and pharmaceutical manufacturers asking their cooperation in the movement to supply urgently needed drugs and pharmaceuticals to the civilian population of Spain, it was announced yesterday.

In a unique session which was still going' early this morning the City Council bogged down in a Democratic filibuster which kept the members from acting on the five country reorganization bills, the most important items on the calendar.

The Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church now has assets of $33;000,000 compared with $10,772,000 in 1918 at the end of its first fiscal year, William Fellowes Morgan, president, reported yesterday to the trustees of the fund of which J. P. Morgan is treasurer.

Mr. and Mrs. Harris Fahnestock will give a musical on the night of Jan. 8 at their home, 15 East Sixtysixth Street. Mr. and Mrs. Marion Eppley will leave the Pierre today for Beacon Rock, their place in Newport. Mr. and Mrs. R. M. Stewart Richardson have come from Long Woods, Md., to the Carlyle.
One of the first problems for Daniel C. Roper's successor as Secretary of Commerce will be whether to continue the present system of liaison between the administration and business.
Count Johann Heinrich von Bernstorff, who was German Ambassador to the United States before America's entry into the World War, today was reported in a critical condition at Geneva General Clinic.
Mrs. Samuel Emlen of Awbury, Germantown, has announced" the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marion Emlen, to Charles J. Hepburn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Hepburn of St. Davids.

Categorical assurances were given by Germany today through Dr. Hans Thomsen, Reich Charge d'Affaires here, that there will be no discrimination against Americans, whether Jews or others, who have inherited legacies in Germany and that exchange will be provided for their obtaining the inheritances in full.
A communique today announced trade negotiations between Soviet Russia and Poland would begin in January to increase the general scope of 1939 commerce to 140,000,000 or 160,000,000 zlotys.

A radio appeal for aid picked up by an American amateur operator in the State of Washington from far-off St. Paul Island, a tiny volcanic rock in the ocean wastes between South Africa and Australia, has caused the Colonial Ministry to take steps to help a group of forty-eight, mostly French lobster fisherfolk, stranded there aboard the auxiliary schooner Ile-Bourbon.
Eustace Seligman, son of Professor E. R. A.. Seligman of the Department of Economics at Columbia University, took over yesterday the leadership of the City Club as the newly elected president.

This is the fortnight in which prediction regarding what the New Year will bring in business and finance is expected from responsible authorities. As a rule, such prophecies are somewhat cautiously conditioned, both as to scope and duration of revival or reaction--whichever is assigned for a coming year. On the present occasion, most of the prediction, taking its cue from the recovery which has marked the past six months, is cheerful.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. John Haynes Holmes is not happy when he accuses me of a "grave misstatement of fact" for saying that the so-called Spanish Government "either did not or would not or could not or willed not to grant religious freedom or stay the hand of Red madness against our God, our Christ, our church," when I was speaking of a historical period which began in 1936.

Cooperation of educators with business, labor, the farmer and other representative elements of the American public in educational planning for the defense and preservation of democracy was urged by Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, in a section of his annual report, made. public. yesterday.

Five hundred boys from seven settlement houses of the city and a group of refugee boys who arrived recently from Europe were guests of the Lions Club yesterday at a Christmas turkey dinner in the Hotel Astor.

Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, president of the International Drug Club, has sent letters to approximately 100 drug and pharmaceutical manufacturers asking their cooperation in the movement to supply urgently needed drugs and pharmaceuticals to the civilian population of Spain, it was announced yesterday.

In a unique session which was still going' early this morning the City Council bogged down in a Democratic filibuster which kept the members from acting on the five country reorganization bills, the most important items on the calendar.

The Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church now has assets of $33;000,000 compared with $10,772,000 in 1918 at the end of its first fiscal year, William Fellowes Morgan, president, reported yesterday to the trustees of the fund of which J. P. Morgan is treasurer.

Mr. and Mrs. Harris Fahnestock will give a musical on the night of Jan. 8 at their home, 15 East Sixtysixth Street. Mr. and Mrs. Marion Eppley will leave the Pierre today for Beacon Rock, their place in Newport. Mr. and Mrs. R. M. Stewart Richardson have come from Long Woods, Md., to the Carlyle.
One of the first problems for Daniel C. Roper's successor as Secretary of Commerce will be whether to continue the present system of liaison between the administration and business.

Starting Dec. 31, a distribution of $58,000 will be made to Series Q-1, New York Title and Mortgage Company certificate holders of record on Dec. 10. Of this amount $27,000 is for principal and about $31,000 on account of income.

Forty were reported to have been killed and several score injured in a train reck today about forty-five miles from Mexico City. The train was carrying more than 1,000 passengers, many of them government employes, on a vacation trip to Veracruz.

Jesse B. McCarger, president of Farnsworth Television, Inc., has announced to stockholders the creation of the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation and a plan to transfer all assets of Farnsworth Television to the new company for 690,000 shares of its stock.
The Federal Crop Reporting Board forecast today next year's Winter wheat crop at 485,000,000 bushels the smallest since 1935 and 201,000,000 bushels less than was harvested this year.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. of Oyster Bay, L. I., has been elected eighth vice president of the Girl Scout national organization, it was announced yesterday at the Girl Scout headquarters, 14 West Fortyninth Street.

The Consumers Power Company, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $10,168,000 of 31/4 per cent first mortgage bonds due on Nov. 1, 1966, giving the price to the public as 104 1/2 and accrued interest and the underwriting discount at 2 per cent.

The behavior of gilt-edge stocks set the tone for the stock market today. Leading issues eased in early trading but a late rally eliminated most of the losses. Foreign bonds also closed steadier with the exception of Czech issues, which again were weak.

Clara N. Laemmle, in 114 E. 84th St; Arline E. Edgar. in 65 E 96th St. George E. Allen, Paul J. Canady, Harlow D. Gaines, in 245 # 21st St; Charles P. Ditel, Nathan Abrams, Samuel A. Kayms, in 15 W 8th St; Byrne Bowman, Inc, Brokers. James A. Allen Jr., Earl J. Royce, in 2 Horatio St; Alice T. De Cou,

Three large Manhattan properties, consisting of a business building in the financial district and two apartment houses on the East Side, were among the ten parcels sold at auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday.

The Cubs and White Sox participated in a mild flurry of baseball trading today, with the Cubs selling a veteran pitcher and the White Sox obtaining Eric McNair from the Red Sox in a straight trade for Lou (Boze) Berger. Both Berger and McNair are infielders.

Richard W. Elliott, appraiser of real estate and for forty years president of the mortgage-loan firm of Richard W. Elliott at 38 Park Row, died Tuesday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old.

A system of "labor booklets" containing the full employment history of each Soviet worker has been decreed by the government in an effort to improve labor discipline, discourage idleness and thus increase production and reduce costs. The system will go into effect on Jan. 15.
The Federal Water Service Corportion announced yesterday that it had sold all the common stock of the Illinois Water Service Company, a subsidiary, to the Northern Illinois Water Corporation.

The Commonwealth Edison Company's offering of $25,566,600 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures to stockholders through subscription warrants was accepted so generally that no offering will be made by the group of 117 investment houses that underwrote the issue, the company announced today.

In keeping with the "tolerance" resolution adopted by the Board of Education, every New York City school will be required to present two assemblies each month, devoted to the teaching of tolerance and good-will, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday that, effective Jan. 1, Joseph L. Egan, who has been in charge of its contracts and railroad relations, will become vice president in charge of public relations and contracts.
James Stewart Lawson, an attorney here for more than forty years and a former banker, died of a heart attack on Tuesday in his home, 7,211 Shore Road, Brooklyn, at the age of 63.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Phinley Morse of 1,130 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Morse, to George Harold Waterman, son of Mrs. George A. Waterman of Nutley, N. J., and the late Mr. Waterman.

John L. Lewis, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced today that the Number 1 legislative item of his organization would be support of a bill in Congress which would compel government contractors to obey the National Labor Relations Act.

Reports of uprisings in Insurgent Spain circulated in Barcelona today, but the Spanish Government press was skeptical of them. The reports, credited to foreign newspapers, were believed in informed circles to be designed to hide Insurgent preparations for an offensive and catch the government napping.

An order directing Kenneth F. Sutherland, chief clerk of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, to show cause tomorrow ??Why he Should not be arrested for contempt of court in refusing to answer questions put by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer.

The Westchester County Park Commission, whose proposed $450,626 net operating budget for next year was reduced to $224,700 by the budget committee of the Board of Supervisors, voted this evening to turn off all lights along the county parkways beginning Jan. 1 to save $50,000 a year and "live within the budget."

The appointment of Walther Funk, the Economics Minister, as commissar for industrial "rationalization and production expansion" is greeted in German business circles with mingled feelings because its implications are so manifold that it is impossible to bring them under one common denominator.
Success in carrying out several measures to improve the economic status of China was reported today in cables to the Commerce Department.

Registrations under the Securities Act of 1933 becoming effective in November fell off substantially from the preceding month, amounting to $249,989,000, exclusive of $53,291,000 of common stock registered solely for conversion of other securities, as compared with a net total of $405,063,000 in October and $35,455,000 in November, 1937.
The basic patent on the electronic television system developed by Dr. Vladimir K. Zworykin was granted here yesterday after having been pending fifteen years in the patent office.

A foreign syndicate that has been investing its funds in New York City realty yesterday enlarged its holdings by purchasing a four-story and two five-story apartment houses at 39, 41 and 43 East Twenty-ninth Street.
The Department of Justice asked the Federal court in Wilmington, Del., today to divest the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation of all its holdings in the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company.

Attorney General Bennett yesterday turned the State's investigation of McKesson Robbins, Inc., to efforts to determine whether a $100,000 profit made by the concern out of the buying and selling of a vitamin plant from 1930 to 1935 "got into the hands of F. Donald Coster," late president of the drug corporation.

By a 2-to-1 decision the judges of the Seventh Federal District Court of Appeals hold that comment by a Federal Judge on the evidence in jury trials violates the provision of the Sixth Amendment of the Constitution guaranteeing to the accused "the right to a speedy and public trial by an impartial jury of the State" and so on.

Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Kuhn, Loeb Co. will offer today a new issue of $16,000,000 of Railway Express Agency, Inc., serial notes, Series A, maturing semi-annually in the amount of $800,000 from June 1, 1939, to Dec. 1, 1948.
Opposition Deputy Fastuchoff in Parliament today questioned the Minister of Posts about the opening of copies of Sunday editions of THE NEW YORK TIMES by the postal authorities.

The report of the Department of Agriculture, after the market's close yesterday, placing the acreage seeded to Winter wheat as of Dec. 1 at 46,173,000 was about in line with what the trade had expected.
Winners of prizes in the seven to ten-room class of the small-house competition sponsored by House Beautiful Magazine were announced yesterday.
After four games, or seven and onehalf hours of playing time, Halifax Town has defeated Mansfield Town in the second round of the English Football Cup competition.

Re-election of its principal officers was announced yesterday by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee at the close of the annual meeting held at 100 East Forty-second Street. The committee is the chief American agency aiding distressed Jewish communities in Central and Eastern Europe.

Rend Blum, brother of Leon Blum, former Premier of France, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain to supervise the theatre, music and ballet programs planned for the French pavilion at the World's Fair.

Sales of ordinary life insurance in the United States in November, exclusive of group insurance, totaled $570,648,000, according to the Life Insurance Sales Research Bureau of Hartford, Conn. It was the first month in 1938 to show a gain over the corresponding month last year. The rain was 3 per cent.
Holiday travel from New York begins today, with railroads adding extra trains to their schedules and preparing additional equipment for the peak of Christmas traffic over the week-end.

Holding a 19-10 lead at the half, the James Madison High - towers scored their fourth straight Section 2, Brooklyn P. S. A. L., victory yesterday by overpowering Samuel J. Tilden High, 44 to 13, 'on the loser's floor.

Ancient Germanic Yule rites were revived last night when Winter solstice ceremonies were performed throughout the Reich under the auspices of Nazi formations, the black shirted and brown shirted Storm Troops and the Hitler Youth.

Advertising budgets will be increased 15 per cent in 1939 by 50 per cent of the national advertisers surveyed by the Association of National Advertisers, Paul B. West, president of the organization, announced yesterday.
The Federal grand jury returned indictments today against two men on charges of transmitting to Soviet Russia several naval intelligence reports concerning American national defense.
The Corinthian Room of the Pierre was the setting last night for a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wentz Balfe for their debutante daughter, Miss Eileen Balfe.

Electric power production rose last week, but less than normally, and the adjusted index declined to 97.9 from 98.9. The figure for the week ended Dec. 18, 1937, was 97.1. The week's output, according to the report issued yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute, was 2,332,978,000 kilowatt-hours.

Civilian Conservation Corps recruits will be enrolled in New Jersey next month, Commissioner William J. Ellis of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies, who also is State director of CCC selection, announced today.

William A. Rogers has been appointed to the newly created position of consultant of the air express division of Railway Express Agency, it was announced yesterday by N. P. Ballou, assistant to the president of the agency.

British Parliamentarians were stirred today to do something toward peopling the empty spaces of the British Empire with their own folk. After a brisk debate the House of Commons, without a division, approved a motion urging that the government promote, in concert with the dominions, a resumption of empire migration.

No one ever turns around any more to stare uncomprehendingly at people trudging through New York's railroad terminals with unwieldy lengths of wood over their shoulders. The ordinary citizen has perfected the knack of ducking at just the right moment to prevent frontal fracture of the skull and, if he pays any attention at all, mutters, "Another of those ski nuts.

The American Artists Congress, 100 West Thirteenth Street, issued a statement yesterday charging the Metropolitan Museum of Art with "helping to subsidize Nazi industry" through the sale of color reproductions made in Germany of various works of art.
Bob Pastor, young New York heavyweight, won a unanimous decision from Tony Schucco, veteran Boston heavyweight, in ten rounds on the Goodwin A. C. card tonight at the Boston Garden.

The purchase of the Hart Glass Manufacturing Company of Dunkirk, Ind., has been effected by the Armstrong Cork Company of this place, it was announced today by H. W. Prentis Jr., president of the local company.
Mrs. Natica Peabody Sinclair has established residence here and will file suit to divorce Beverly Sinclair, a New York stock broker and cousin of the Duchess of Windsor.
Two funeral services will be held for Mrs. Finley J. Shepard, the former Miss Helen Gould. The first will take place at 11 A. M. today in the Jay Gould Memorial Reformed Church, Roxbury, N. Y.;

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced tonight that subscriptions for the offering of $50,000,000 of five-year 1% per cent notes of the Federal National Mortgage Association totaled about $1,170,000,000, or more than twenty-three times the amount offered.

Rejection of the proposal to construct super-highways across the continent at a cost of billions of dollars will be recommended by the Bureau of Public Roads. The bureau's report, suggesting this action, is expected to be transmitted to Congress early in January.

The Busch Jewelry Company is scheduled to apply today to Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo for an extension of the injunction he issued last June prohibiting two C. I. O. unions representing employes from picketing Busch jewelry stores.

E. L. Shutts, president of the Iowa Southern Utilities Company of Delaware, notified shareholders yesterday that, because of a suit instituted against the company by two stockholders owning 134 shares of cumulative preferred stock, the Dec. 15 payment on account of dividend arrears on the preferred issue cannot be made at this time. Mr.
The dim, massive front towers of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine lent a dignified background to a performance of an old-fashioned drama of the Nativity last night.

The Harvard, Princeton and Union League Club teams triumphed in Group I of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C competition last night, the 5-to-0 victory of the Tigers over the Yale Club being the most sweeping in that group.

President Roosevelt held his final Cabinet meeting today before the Christmas holidays. The weekly meeting was advanced from the customary hour on Friday as part of his effort to get his legislative and budgetary programs into shape to be presented to Congress.

There will be three Franklin D. Roosevelts in the White House for the holiday season. First to arrive of the President's children who will be with him this Christmas was Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., who came up from his home at Charlottesville, Va.
Police Sergeant Irving H. Smith finished decorating the Christmas tree in his home last night, lit his pipe and dropped the lighted match into artificial snow strewn about the tree.

A citizens' group threatened today to seek a Federal receivership against the Associated Gas and Electric Company of New York. The group contended that the New York holding company was preparing to compel the Virginia Public Service Company,
William Henry McDonald, secretary, charter member and Past Master of the New Rochelle Lodge 1033 of the Masons, died today.
President Roosevelt today presented the Herbert Schiff Memorial Trophy,

The twelve-meter sloop Iris has been sold for Henry L. Maxwell to Harold W. Brooks, a member of the New York Yacht Club, according to an announcement yesterday by Sparkman Stephens, Inc. Mr. Brooks formerly owned the schooner Mary Rose and the ten-meter Pixie.

Observing Forefathers' Day, the 318th anniversary of the landing of the Pilgrims and its own 116th anniversary, the Old Colony Memorial Newspaper today issued a special twenty-two-page supplement depicting the history of the town.
Miss Emma C. Dowd, author of children's books and poems, outstanding of which were the Polly series, died today in her home here.

That the American Medical Association would be indicted on the charge of obstructing group medical practice as a form of "contract medicine" was a foregone conclusion after Attorney General Homer S. Cummings and Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold published the Department of Justice's findings and threats last August.

A large part of the press today devotes much front page space to attacks on the United States Secretary of the Interior, Harold L. Ickes, for his speech before the Cleveland Zionist Society Sunday and his other "German-baiting utterances" which,

Decreases of 6 per cent in employment and 5 per cent in payrolls in November compared with the same month last year were "the most favorable comparison" that has been made with 1937, the Department of Labor said today. In November, 1937, employment decreased 5.3 per cent, while payrolls dropped 9.2 per cent.

Appointments The following persons are appointed to the position of Patrolman on Probation at $2,000 per annum, effective Dec. 20, 1938, their names appearing on certifications of eligible list of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, dated Dec. 6, 8 and 15, 1938:

Poultry came to the fore in local markets yesterday because of the Christmas trade. Some classes of meats were fairly active and others slow. Some steer cuts were lower and the lamb market was weak to lower. Other classes were mostly unchanged, considering quality.

Chandler A. Mackey was nominated yesterday to serve a fifth term as president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. If elected, he will become the first fifth-term president since 1911. W. W. Pinney,

The fortnightly statement, of the Central Bank of Argentina for Dec. 15 showed a decrease in the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation to 119.99 per cent from 124.41 per cent on Nov. 30. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities rose from 85.08 per cent on Nov. 30 to 85.60 per cent on Dec. 15.

Gaynell Tinsley, of the Cardinals and Don Hutson of the Packers shared pass receiving honors in the National Football League while Ward Cuff of the Giants and Ralph Kercheval of the Dodgers tied for the field goal title, according to the final official statistics for 1938 released yesterday.
Orders for the French Navy to hold extensive war games early in 1939 in the South Atlantic Ocean off Arfica's west coast were disclosed tonight. disclosed tonight.

A $12,600,000 Montreal Terminal project which was started nearly a decade ago and abandoned because of the depression will be proceeded with tomorrow when the Canadian National Railways call for tenders on it.

Controversy over the Pan-American Conference's solidarity declaration narrowed tonight to two proposals. These represented on the one side the wishes of a large majority of the delegations here, and on the other side Argentina's ideas.

Mr. and Mrs. George Nelson Lindsay of 791 Park Avenue and Highlands, Oyster Bay, L. I., have a nounced the engagement of their daughter,Miss Eleanor Jane Lindsay, to Cooper Schieffelin, son of Mrs. Schuyler Schieffelin of 133 East Sixty-fourth Street and Islesmere Farm, Monroe, N. Y., and the late Mr. Schieffelin.
Foreign Minister Nicolas Petrescu-Comnen resigned today and immediately was replaced by Grigore Gafencu, newspaper publisher, who long has fostered political friendship with France.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Herbert P. Bearce, Cav-Res., 460 Esplanade St., Pelham Manor, N. Y. (D), 303d Cavalry, is ordered to active duty Jan. 1, 1939, at Fort Jay, N. Y., for training. Date of rank, Dec. 17, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status Jan. 14.
An investor bought from the Lawyers Trust Company the fivestory apartment house on a plot 30 by 100 feet at 759 Melrose Avenue, southwest corner of East 157th Street, the Bronx.

Two police platoons headed by Deputy Chief Inspector Joseph Reynolds attended a solemn high requiem mass yesterday for Police Captain Edwin C. McGrath in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Nicholas of Tolentine, Fordham Road and University Avenue, the Bronx.
The three-story buildings. known as 901-3-5 Park Avenue, Union City, N. J., have been sold by the Trust Company of New Jersey to tenants of stores in the properties.

The League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers and managers which since September has been enforcing the new ticket code chiefly through the medium of stringent inspection of brokers' accounts, took steps yesterday to discipline its own membership against whom there might be complaints.
Continuation of a WPA rehabilitation project for prisoners in the city's penitentiaries and jails is being sought by Mayor La Guardia and other city officials, it became known yesterday.
William Lewis Dayton Wright, a printer in New York for almost fifty years until his retirement, died last night in his home here at the age of 82.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Homes of the Colonists" (general tour),ll A. M. "Masterpieces of Painting of the Seventeenth Century" (general tour), 2 P. M. Luncheon, Rotary Club, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "The Spirit Of Christmas," A. Hamilton Nesbitt.
Hearing on the application of Adams, Nelson Williamson for approval of the final compensation for services performed by them as attorneys for James L. Haughteling,
Hymie Caplin returned from Callfornia yesterday and proceeded to stir up arguments along the boxing front on matters involving two world titles.

Dr. Mark J. Gottlieb of 239 West Seventy-fifth Street, a specialist in diseases of the ear, nose and throat, died yesterday of a heart attack in a room in the Pennsylvania Hotel, which he was occupying temporarily while resting preparatory to performing an operation.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 19: REAR ADMIRAL Stark, H. R., relieved additional duty, commander Cruiser Division 3, Dec. 22, to additional duty as commander Cruiser Division 9.

Nancy is just one-fourth of one case among the Hundred Neediest. Nancy is 9 years old. Has some reader of this editorial a little girl of 9 in his or her home? Nancy is as dear to her sick mother as any 9-year-old to any parent, but in the night her mother hears her sobbing and cannot help her.

Mme. Violet Besson, dramatic actress, died yesterday in her home at the Hotel Somerset, 150 West Forty-seventh Street. Mme. Besson, widow of Georges Besson, who died in Paris many years ago, last appeared here in "The Country Wife," with Ruth Gordon, in the Winter season of 1936-37 in the part of Old Lady Squeamish.
A final dividend of 40 cents a share was voted yesterday on the common stock of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation. The last dividend was 50 cents paid in 4 per cent four-year notes Dec. 27, 1937.

In a report in Monday's NEW YORK TIMES of a proposal of the Westchester County Water Commission to spend more than $32,000,000 for a new water system, the statement was made that New York City "is understood to be ready to fight against Westchester 'grabbing' any watershed rights of other municipalities."

Bonds continued to drift irregularly lower yesterday in fairly active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. All major groups participated in the decline, which forced the combined price average for the corporate section down 0.17 point, and the foreign list down 0.12.

Dr. Fernando Sirgo, Cuban Ambassador. to Spain, arrived yesterday on the Champlain of the French Line, accompanied by his wife. Through the courtesy of the Deapartment of State, the envoy and his wife were taken from the liner at quarantine on a special cutter and hurried ashore in time to sail on the Cuba Mail liner Oriente, which left at 4 P. M. for Havana.

Lee Pressman, general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, supported today the ruling by the Secretary of Labor, Miss Perkins, establishing specific minimum wage rates for common laborers in the steel plants supplying government material.
In a South German city whose tranquil, sedate charm long has attracted Britons and Americans, this correspondent sought Mr. X, a Jewish resident known abroad for his activity in social work.

John Joseph McGuire, know familiarly as Spike to his colleagues in his own territory, was feeling pretty cocky yesterday afternoon, despite the fact that he is just a few days past his seventh birthday. From Tenth Avenue to Fifth Spike had gone within the span of half an hour, and he was in his glory, but slightly satirical.

Showing the same high speed that had marked his New York races and holding on better than usual under one of Eddie Arcaro's powerful rides, Shoulder Arms, in the Longchamps Farms silks of Henry Lustig, won the Homestead Purse by a head at Tropical Park today.
A dinner dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ernest Mitler of 755 Park Avenue last night at the St. Regis to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Constance Rosaline Mitler..

Mrs. Albrecht Pagenstecher 3d, chairman of the executive committee for the Koscluszko Foundation's sixth annual Night in Poland Ball, which will be given Jan. 20 at the Waldorf-Astoria, gave a reception and tea yesterday at River House for members of the debutante committee and other groups assisting with preparations for the ball.

A drop of 5 points in production of ingot steel to 53 per cent for the country in the current week may be accounted for in part by the fact that steel companies are anxious to keep their raw steel at a minimum over the inventory period and are reducing the number of active steel-making furnaces to conform closely to actual requirements over the next two weeks, Iron Age says in its weekly summary.

A far-reaching reconstruction of the Yugoslav Government was carried out today following the recent elections. Premier Milan Stoyanovitch formally offered his resignation, and he was immediately entrusted by Prince Paul with the formation of a new government.

Asserting that he had learned of "attempts to influence public officials for the purpose of stifling prosecutions in the Brooklyn bail bond racket," John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor investigating charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, obtained yesterday the commitment of Max Lippe, 53 years old, as a ..material witness under, $50,000 bail.
Power companies operating in New York State were ordered today by the Public Service Commission to retire ultimately from service all indicating types of demand meters to achieve "more accuracy."

Contributions of $12,553.65 increased the Neediest Cases Fund to $178,889.04 yesterday as 661 benefactors joined the ranks of those who have sought to bring fresh hope and opportunity to the beneficiaries of this twenty-seventh annual appeal.
The Sejm majority-all the members from the Camp of National Unitysigned a motion today urging the government to speed up mass emigration of Jews.

MANHATTAN BERNSTEIN, JOSEPH (Nov. 28). Estate, $13,000. To Bernard Bernstein, 1,191 E. 18th St., Brooklyn; Louis Bernstein, 2,212 Ditmas Ave., Brooklyn, and Philip Bernstein, 2,017 Homecrest Ave., Brooklyn, sons, $1,250 each; ten varying bequests; Leah Miller, daughter, executrix, 1,191 E. 18th St., $4,400.

Charles Hackett, operatic tenor, failed to appear in the Queens Traffic Court in Jamaica yesterday to answer a charge of speeding as a third offense, and Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert ordered a warrant issued for his arrest.

One person was killed and more than fifty persons suffered minor injuries and hundreds of automobiles were damaged late yesterday in the New York metropolitan area, when light snow and rain gave an icy coating to highways.

Sutton Vane's "Outward Bound" will be revived tonight at the Playhouse, the first premiere in two weeks. Last seen in January, 1924, at the Ritz, it is offered this time by the newly organized Playhouse company, in association with Robinson Smith, Bramwell Fletcher and William A. Brady.

World's Fair Grounds The following information with regard to additional entrances to the World's Fair grounds, available for Fire Department apparatus, is promulgated for the information of the uniformed force:

Trixie, a 25-year-old, five-ton elephant, chain-harnessed to a grading scoop, broke ground yesterday afternoon for Frank Buck's two-acre Jungleland in the amusement area of the New York World's Fair grounds.

The performance which the City Council majority put on between 12:45 P. M. Tuesday and 8:15 A. M. Wednesday was not, we are assured, a filibuster. The disclaimer seems reasonable. Why should a majority of 17 filibuster against a minority of 9?

The trade on good, choice and prime steers and yearlings was dependable at firm prices today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Best mediumweight and heavy steers topped at $13.50. Light supplies of hogs produced a 10 to 20 cent higher market. Practical top was $7.65. Fat lambs sold strong to 25 cents higher, best at $9.35.
Luis Quintanilla, the artist, left for New York this morning, carrying the first set of the last edition of Goya etchings, being done by Ruperez, noted Madrid engraver, to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today an order granting permission to certain trust and insurance companies in Pennsylvania to intervene in proceedings involving a proposed $8,000,000 investment program of the United Corporation.

The grave plight in, which civilians in Spain have been placed by the civil war, with cold weather causing increasing suffering, led the United States Government today to approve a plan for selling 3,000,000 bushels of surplus wheat to the American Red Cross for distribution to Spanish noncombatants.
