The New York Junior League squash racquets team defeated the Independent Club, 5 to 2; yesterday on the winners' courts in an interclub test in the New York division of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association. Four engagements were defaulted by the losers.

Philip W. Clarkson, senior clerk of the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, was killed at 10:50 o'clock last night when he fell or jumped in front of a southbound six-car Brighton Beach train in the B. M. T. subway at the Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway station.

Amerlean sales of machine tools to the United Kingdom in the first ten months of this year dropped to $10,214,400 from $14,678,400 in that period of 1937, according to the Deapartment of Commerce today.
A group of girls calling themselves "Forget-Me-Nots" sponsored an invitation subscription dance at the Montclair Golf Club tonight.

Miss Helene Rains, young star of the Women's Swimming Association of New York, won the 150-yard individual medley, one of the exhibition events staged by the W. S. A. in connection with the formal opening last night of the Skyline Athletic Club pool in the Hotel Capitol under the supervision of Miss Georgia Coleman, 1932 Olympic diving champion.
Men on leave from the trenches in the World War sought pleasure and forgetfulness more fervently than the civilians at home.

In order to avoid adjourned games as far as possible, teams representing Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Dartmouth will start play in the annual championship competition of. the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League for the Belden-Stephens Trophy at the Marshall Chess Club at 9 o'clock this morning.
Two parties in interest filed objections today with the Interstate Commerce Commission to plans for reorganization of the Western Pacific Railroad.

Interest in the forthcoming civil service examination for patrolman has been so great that 80,000 applications have been distributed by the Municipal Civil Service Commission, it was announced yesterday by Paul J. Kern, president.

The Sejm speaker ruled out a Ukrainian autonomy bill today. He announced he would allow several Ukrainian interpellations concerning alleged reprisals in Eastern Galicia but failed to mention the autonomy project.

The Japanese press, which hitherto has restrained its cirticism of United states and British credits to China, today revealed its anger by torrents of denunciation. Although both countries share in the invective, Great Britain is especially selected for attack and the United States is depicted as Britain's tool.
The government has adopted a new method of ridding itself of opponents. It exiles them from Baghdad to the interior of the country, where they are kept-under strict police supervision.

The Maritime Commission began an investigation today of charges that Japanese shipping interests were employing "unfair trade practices" in the trade between the Pacific Coast and the east coast of South America.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today that insurance liability under the $5,000 insurance maximum had reached $21,705,000,000 on the basis of figures for Sept. 21, 1938, submitted by 13,705 insured commercial banks.

34th St, 324-8 E, 85x98.9; Sterndor Apartments, Inc, to Samuel Jaskow, 502 Park Ave, 10 yrs, 6 per cent; $55,000. 114th St, 108 W. 26.3x100.11: 764 Corporation to Greenwich Savings Bank, p m mtg, due, etc as bond; $11,00Q.

General Commercial Acceptance Corporation is distributing a Christmas bonus of five weeks' salary to all employes with them for one year or more. A Christmas bonus of one-half a month's salary has been voted by the directors of Lawyers Trust Company to all employes and junior officers.

Illinois turned on its power in the second half to defeat Connecticut State, 49 to 23, tonight. The first half ended, 15 to 14, in favor of the Illini, after the score had been tied three times. The attendance was 4,763. The line-up:

The Fidelity Investment Association, accused of fraudulent practices in a suit filed here by the Securities and Exchange Commission, filed its answer today, denying all charges and asking dismissal of the suit.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie Hall, evening; "Tosca," evening, and "Tannhaeuser," afternoon, Metropolitan Opera; Branscombe Choral, Hotel Biltmore ballroom, evening; Lehman Engel Singers, John Wanamaker's, 6 o'clock.

Mrs. Clara Louise Hegeman, wife of William P. Hegeman and a member of one of Long Island's oldest. families, died at her home here shortly before midnight last night at the age of 74.. She had been ill for two weeks.

The auditorium of the Amalgamated Cooperative Apartments in the Bronx, center of the community activities in that project, has been named the Vladeck Auditorium in honor of the late B. Charney Vladeck.

Friends of James Williamson, European manager of Macfadden Publications, Inc., who disappeared from the German liner Potsdam as she was approaching Colombia, Ceylon, earlier in the week, still were awaiting news from the ship today to clear up the mystery.

L. A. Norton Co. announced yesterday that the firm would be dissolved at the close of business on Dec. 31, and be succeeded by Winckler, Onderdonk Co. with Beecher Winckler, C. Herbert Onderdonk and Grace T. Onderdonk as partners, effective on the same date.

Rainy weather gave way to sunshine today, and for the first time in two weeks Southern California's Trojan warhorse was geared for hard practice on the football field. It will be slippery footing for another day or so until the moisture dries out, when Head. Coach Howard Jones hopes to begin-and begin is the right word-offensive drills.
M. L. Wilson, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, has written a book, "Democracy Has Roots," which Carrick Evans will publish in March. Dr. Charles A. Beard will write the preface.

Of the holders of $543,000,000 outstanding obligations of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad covered by the company's adjustment plan, holders of $300,000,000 of the securities, or 55 per cent, have placed in assent or registered their holdings in accordance with the plan, Daniel Willard, president, announced yesterday.

Dr. Hans Albert Einstein, 34-yearold son of the physicist Albert Einstein, filed an application for American citizenship in the Federal District Court here today. Dr. Einstein gave his nationality as Swiss.
A Circuit Court jury tonight convicted Mrs. Fern Patricia Dull of manslaughter in the shooting of William Holbrook, a Benton Harbor lawyer, on Oct. 17. He was her employer.

For a year and a half Russell Smith, employee of an oil company here, belived a $10,000 Federal Reserve note, given him by a friend, 'was worthless. Today he discovered it was genuine. Officials of a bank examined the note and found nothing wrong with it.
Germany exported slightly more cotton goods, mainly fabrics, in the first nine months of this year than in that period in 1937, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Iceland "sweltered" today as Europe's great freeze added a few more deaths to the several score reported this week. The temperature at Reykjavik, Iceland's capital, usually below freezing in December, reached 45 degrees, permitting farmers to work their soil.

The body of Miss Margaret Martin, attractive 19-year-old girl of Kingston, Pa., who disappeared from her home last Saturday, was found about 3 P. M. today trussed in a burlap bag under a bridge across the Keelersburg Creek near Keelersburg, about twelve miles from here.

Taken, a 5-to-1 shot, galloped over a fast track today and finished in front of Dnieper and Sweet Adeline to take the feature event at the Fair Grounds. The winner was timed in 1:45 2-5 for the mile and a sixteenth and returned $12.60, $4.60 and $3.40.

Dr. Eduard Bones, former President of CzechoSlovakia, today obtained a temporary injunction against publication of the book "They Gave Us a Country," by Preston Hayter, which attributes to Dr. Benes unauthorized statements about European statesmen and the world situation. The injunction was obtained against Mr. Hayter and George Routledge Sons, publishers.

Government officials now enjoying the use of automobiles received a severe jolt as the result of a decree issued today by President Getulio Vargas. Unless officials are able to prove that the car is absolutely essential for business, it will be withdrawn from the official list.

A proposal that all substitute teachers who fail in the regular examinations over a period of years be stricken from the New York City teaching rolls is being considered by the Board of Examiners, Dr. Louis Marks, chairman, disclosed yesterday. A limit of five years for substitutes is also proejected.

Parts of an eight-page suicide note, handwritten by F. Donald coster after he was identified as the ex-convict Philip Musica last week, were read here yesterday to Gregory F. Noonan, acting United states Attorney.

With prideful and judicial air, Paramount meticulously records that "Artists and Models Abroad" stems from a screen play by Howard Lindsay, Russel Crouse and Ken Englund, who, by the grace of the. Screen Writers Guild, had reference to an original story by the Messrs. Lindsay and Crouse who, in turn, were inspired by an "idea by J. P. McEvoy."
Observers have not failed to note that, in the midst of attacks on New Deal spending, more than fifty successful Republican candidates for the House lent encouragement to the flock of Dr. Townsend.
Navy's eight-oared fleet, the varsity of which took national college rowing honors last year, will engage in four regattas in addition to the Poughkeepsie classic next season.

Acquisition of a sixth George Bernard Shaw property was announced today by Gabriel Pascal, who said he had secured the rights to "Newton," a historical romance written around Nell Gwynn and Charles II while at the home of Sir Isaac Newton.

Dr. Frank H. Vizetelly, whose exploration in the world of words made him a unique international figure, died at 11:05 Tuesday night in the Fifth Avenue Hospital, where he had been a patient since Dec. 2. In his seventy-fifth year, he was a victim of pneumonia and pleurisy.
Elmer F. Andrews, administrator, suggested tonight that once industry had become accustomed to working under the Wages and Hours Act drastic changes in its terms should not be proposed.
Dr. Ferdinand Durciansky, of the. Slovak Cabinet broadcast tonight an appeal for international action to hold a plebiscite in the territories recently ceded to Hungary.
The Federal Trade Commission took the position today that there was a difference between selling patented goods and leasingpatented-applying 135-ROOM HC tools;

" If the world does not restore itself to sanity, there can be no 'Peace on Earth, Good-Will to Men,'" declared Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College at a formal good-will chapel yesterday at the Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The National Labor Relations Board admitted in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today that it had erred in determining the collective bargaining agent for employes of the Stackpole Carbon Company of St. Mary's.

Peter J. Sullivan, for thirty years an agent in the New York Customs House, died at his home, 167-12 Highland Avenue, Jamaica, yesterday at the age of 60. He Was born in Manhattan and had lived in Queens for twelve years.

86th St, 517-21 E; 75x108; for 6-story tenement; Northpel Realty Corp, 391 E 149th St, Bronx, owner; A. Welser, architect: cost, $175,000. Alterations Mulberry St, 70; to 5-story school; Board of Education, 500 Park Ave, owner; A. Rogers, engineer; cost, $9,000.

Mordecai Cohen, retired ink manufacturer and a resident of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn for forty years, died yesterday at the Menorah Home for Aged and Infirm, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He had lived at the home for two years. His age was 84.
Mrs. Marion Rumsey Delavan, wife of Dr. D. Bryson Delavan, distinguished throat specialist, died yesterday at her home, 4 East Eighty-eighth Street. Born in St.
Dr. Frederick John Kalteyer, Clinical Professor of Medicine at Jefferson Medical College, where he had been on the faculty for thirty-three years, died of a heart attack in his home here last night.

Indicating a definite upturn, the first five railroads reporting for November showed that in respect. of their gross revenues the tota?? was 4.3 per cent over the total fo?? November, 1937. The net operating income rose 19.8 per cent.
Mrs. Eugene Horton Amory gave a luncheon yesterday at the Pierre for her debutante daughter, Miss Ann Amory. They were assisted in receiving by Miss Mary Alice Amory, the debutante's sister.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Foster Ernst, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton L. Ernst of New York, to Abraham J. Asohe, son of Mrs. Lazarus Asehe of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Asche, took place last night in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The sight of snow nuzzling down against window panes yesterday raised anew a hope quiescent since our White Thanksgiving. Will Christmas dress in its traditional color and really be "in character," with sleigh bells jingling all the way from Bronx to Brooklyn and beyond?
The Marine Corps announced the following changes dated Dec. 20:
A hearing on the Erie Railroad's intention to disaffirm its lease with the Northern Railroad of New Jersey was adjourned today to Jan. 25 after long arguments.
Coach Bob Neyland declared a virtual holiday today in Tennessee's preparations for the Orange Bowl game with Oklahoma in Miami, Jan. 2, when a dozen players reported for practice with colds.

A young mother walked into the Drexel State Bank on the South Side today, threatened to blow it "sky high," and thereby forced the president.to give her $5,000. A minute or so later she was captured by a daring Negro policeman.

Captain and Mrm. William E. Hallock of Islip will celebrate their seventieth wedding anniversary with a family gathering on Christmas Eve. Captain Hallock is 93 years old; his wife is 96. Four generations of the family will join in the celebration.

The British Government is insisting that Czecho-Slovakia must make "adequate provision" for the emigration of Czech refugees out of any additional money it borrows from Britain, Euan Wallace, Parliamentary Secretary of the Treasury, announced.in the House of Commons today.

The Federal Power Commission has received an application from the city of High Point, N. C., for a major license for a 30,000-horsepower hydroelectric development to be constructed on the Yadkin River about twelve miles southwest of WinstonSalem and to be connected with High Point by two twenty-six-mile transmission lines.

The New York Athletic Club Class A squash tennis team last night took undisputed possession of first place in the race for honors in the Metropolitan League by administering a decisive defeat to its closest rival, the Bayside Tennis Club.

A bundle of toys is on its way to Canada tonight to prove that Santa Claus got the note which a boy tied to a Christmas tree. The tree arrived in a shipment from Canada. Aloysius Whalen, a City Hall employee, bought the tree for his three children and found this note among the branches:
The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 607 applicants for admission to the bar were successful in the examinations conducted Oct. 25 and 26. A total of 1,284 took the examination.

Enactment of Federal legislation to provide for government supervision of unlisted or over-the-counter trading was a recommendation today of William McChesney Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange.

Georgia Tech football players charged through a brief but brisk workout today in preparation for their game with the University of California on Monday at Berkeley. Coach Bill Alexander put his boys through a snappy signal drill and ended up with a tackling session.
The congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority left the future of the inquiry in doubt today by adjourning subject to the call of its chairman.

James W. Day, manager of the Chicago office of C. J. Devine Co., Inc., has been appointed a vice president of the firm. The following also have been appointed assistant vice presidents: Arthur J. Bellinzoni and William C. Sears, associated with the New York office;

Appleton A. Mason of this village, physical education instructor at Columbia University and the Stuyvesant High School of New York, died yesterday in the New Rochelle Hospital, where he had undergone an operation. He was 58 years old.

Having disposed of the amateur tennis situation with an aplomb that leaves no room for further discussion, Donald Budge got down to serious work yesterday at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, for his debut as a player for the dollar.
Mrs. Ellen Blackmar Barker, widow of Rear Admiral Albert S. Barker, died today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Edwin Corning, suburban Kenwood, after a long illness. She was 86 years old.

Governor Lehman tonight appointed Felix C. Benvenga, head of the appeals bureau of the District Attorney's office of New York County, as a Supreme Court Justice, filling the vacancy caused by the resignation of Charles Poletti, Lieutenant Governor-elect.

Charles Franklin, counsel for the Manhattan Railway Company, announced yesterday that its board of directors had ordered him to file at once with the United States District Court an application for permission to increase the fare on elevated lines from five cents to seven cents.

After voting with unprecedented docility a budget Of 66,000,000,000 francs the French Chamber tonight. began a discussion of the measure that must provide resources to meet this expenditure and over which Pariament is believed to be sharply divided.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward yesterday for the fourth successive session and ended unchanged to a gain of 3 points. In line with previous price movements this week, recessions were limited and late covering left quotations around the top.

James Davey Cochran, who came to the United States from England fifty years ago to supervise construction of the United States Navy's first two steel-armored cruisers, died yesterday at -his home. He was 72 years old.

The touring University of Southern California hockey team will visit the Brooklyn Ice Palace tonight for a game with the St. Nicholas Hockey Club, defending champion in the New York Amateur Hockey Association. The intersectional contest is scheduled to start at 8 P. M.

Western football stars, who will meet Eastern collegians in the annual Shrine charity game here Jan. 2, assembled for the first time today to run through a light workout. The Western coaches, Orin Hollingbery of Washington State and Biff Jones of Nebraska,

Warren Webster, founder, president and general manager of the heating equipment manufacturing company here that bears his name, died today in Georgetown University Hospital, Washington, after a month's illness. He was 75 years old.

MANHATTAN BAYLIES, EDMUND L. (April 29, 1932). Gross assets, $875,844; net, $200,958. To Louisa Van Rensselaer Baylies, widow, life estate in residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $603,098. Anderson, Gasser, Ferris Anderson, attorneys, 20 Pine St.

The fifteenth annual dinner of the New York Chapter, Baseball Writers Association of America, will be held in the Hotel Commodore on Sunday, Feb. 5. Adoption of this date came yesterday at the annual meeting of the chapter in the Hotel New Yorker. At the meeting a revised constitution was adopted.
Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld gave a dinner tonight at their villa for Edgar P. Sawyer 2d., and their house guest, Miss Alice May McClusky of Easton, Pa.

John Stuart Ogilvie Jr., partner with his father in the New York insurance brokerage firm of John S. Ogilvie Company, died here tonight at the age of 31, in the Lawrence Hospital. He was a resident of this village. Mr. Ogilvie attended Columbia University.

In command all the way, Long Island University's basketball team easily subdued McGill University of Montreal, 77 to 39, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night to remain in the undefeated group.

Senator Vandenberg said today that he had no confidence in the ability of Harry L. Hopkins to fill a position of such "high responsibility" as Secretary of Commerce. The Michigan Senator, discussing rumors that Mr. Hopkins might be appointed to that post, added that he had not decided how he would vote on such a nomination.

Twenty four American organizations conducting relief activities in Spain collected $1,916,431.17 and expended $1,431,483.80 in Spain during the period from May, 1937, to November, 1938, inclusive, according to a summary of their monthly reports filed with the State Department under the neutrality statute and made public today.

Mrs. Robert Whitslar Schuette gave a supper dance last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to introduce to society her niece, Miss Carol Ormsby Streuber, daughter of E. Nielsen Streuber of this city and of the late Mrs. Martha Jarecki Streuber.

United States Treasury Department, in 104 E 25th St through J. Chr. Hupfel Co; also floor in 12 E 22d St to same tenant through Alfred M. Rau; Rotor Table Games, Inc, in 223 E 38th St through J. Chr. Hupfel Co; John Frederick Hof, broker.
Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Finland today bound themselves to accept the limitations on the size of cruisers and other warships laid down by the London Naval Treaty of 1938.

Denis RF Shell, newly elected Municipal Court justice, took the oath of office yesterday in the chambers of County Judge James M. Barrett, who administered the oath, Justice Sheil, who was formerely a member of the Board of Aldermen, defeated Justice Matthew M. Levy, who was appointed by Mayor La Guardia in January to fill a vacancy in the First Municipal Court District, the Bronx.

Expansion by Saks-Fifth Avenue of its Beverly Hills (Calif.) shop through the construction of a large addition and the purchase of adjoining property was announced yesterday by Adam L. Gimbel, president of the store.
The United States Weather Bureau issued yesterday its weekly report of crop conditions, as follows:
The Carnegie Tech football squad divided Its time between work and Christmas shopping today, while Coach Bill Kern worried about wi Southern hospitality and the effect it might have on his players.

Continued business improvement throughout 1939 was predicted today by Secretary Roper, who said there exist several elements of strength in the outlook for next year which were lacking at this time last year. He analyzed the situation at his farewell press conference before retiring to private life after a public service extending more than fortyfive years.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after operating expenses, taxes and ,other charges of $22,443,431.

The pros and cons of voluntary prepayment medical indemnity insurance versus cooperative group practice were discussed last night at a meeting of the Bronx Medical Society of Burnside Manor, Burnside and University Avenues, the Bronx, by Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd,

Miss Jean McDougall, daughter of Mrs. Taylor McDougall of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married this afternoon to John K. Deasy, son' of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Deasy of Wynnewood, by the Rev. Croswell McBee in old St. David's Church in Radnor.

Baroness Catherine Mea Charlotte those Schwartzenberg en Hohenlansberg and Wilhelm P. Montyn, Consul General of The Netherlands in New York, were married yesterday afternoon in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow through Thursday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The programs follow:

After a session of almost twenty hours marked by several threats of fisticuffs, the City Council defeated the five county reorganization bills sought by Mayor La Guardia by a vote of 17 to 9, which was taken at 8:08 yesterday morning.
The open Winter, good roads and the automobile have created an exceedingly spotty situation in retail hardware store sales, officials of the Illinois Retail Hardware Association reported today.

The Consumers League of New York desires to take issue with your editorial on the revision of the Social Security Act. It appears to us that your suggestion for the postponement of the revision of the act pending the appointment of a small full-time commission consisting of actuaries, economists, accountants and tax specialists is both inconsistent with your own view of the nature of social security legislation and contrary to the public interest.

Miss Constance Palmer Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Cliffe Johnston, was presented to society yesterday afternoon at a reception given by her parents in their home, 18 East Seventy-seventh Street.

Another royal visit to America next Spring was disclosed today with announcement that Crown Prince Olav of Norway and his wife, Princess Martha, would arrive late in April for a two-month transcontinental tour.

The seven-story concrete warehouse building at 10-18 Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, recently acquired at foreclosure by the Bowery Savings Bank, has been sold by that institution to Interstate Storage Warehouses, Inc.

Peter Forster, 27 years old, who fled to Czecho-Slovakia last May after having killed an Elite Guard in escaping from a concentration camp, was convicted of murder here today and guillotined a few hours later.

The city of Memphis, Tenn., sold yesterday $1,000,000 of sixty-day notes to the National Bank of Commerce and the Union Planters National Bank and Trust Company, both of that city, at an interest rate of 0.50 per cent, awarding the issue equally between the two banks.

65th St, 148 W. Daniel W. Blumenthal, referee, to Adolph Brodmerkel, 615 8th St, Union City, N. J., trustee of Charles Brodmerkel, foreclosure ($17.50). 94th St, 11 E, Verwel Realty Corp to Bank for Savings; mtg $45,000 held by grantee ($46).

Spokesmen for eight Southeastern States urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to continue control of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railroad by the Southern Railway and the Louisville Nashville.

Early returns indicate that there will be a record number of entrants in the 1939 Eastern States figure skating championships, which will be held at the Iceland Rink, atop Madison Square Garden, on Jan. 6-7, under the auspices of the Skating Club of New York.

Dr. Alfred E. Oakes, a practicing physician here for twenty years and a veteran of the World War, died last night at the Alexian Brothers Hospital shortly after being stricken with a heart attack while driving his car to make a call on a patient. His age was 52.

The forty-one District Courts of New Jersey operated at a $310,461 deficit in 1937, with fee collections only $315,491, compared with costs of $625,952, a report by the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce disclosed yesterday.

The marriage of Mrs. Doris Dawson of this city, daughter of Mrs. E. Ahme Dawson of Sierra City, Calif., to Robert D. Levy, son of Mrs. Isaac D. Levy of 1,107 Fifth Avenue and the late Mr. Levy, took place yesterday morning at the home of the bridegroom's mother. The Rev.

The two steamship conferences covering services between Atlantic ports and Brazil-River Plate ports, have rejected the application for membership filed some weeks ago by the Sprague Steamship Agency, Inc., of Boston.

The Down Town Glee Club, now in its thirteenth season, gave its annual Christmas concert last night in Carnegie Hall. As usual, there was a capacity house of friends. Channing LeFebvre was the conductor;
Mrs. Caspar Whitney has gone to Santa Barbara, Calif., for the holidays. Mr. and Mrs; H. Wendell Endicott have come to the Pierre from Boston.
The War Department announced today contracts totaling $2,092,366 for purchases and construction by army branches.

Many Will Street notables, including presidents of all New York Stock and Commodity Exchanges, will attend the annual Christmas reception to be held on the floor of the New York Cocoa Exchange tomorrow afternoon, it was announced yesterday.

World records for 100 yards in the breast-stroke and back-stroke events henceforth will be recognized by the International Swimming Federation. Chairman Laurence J. Johnson of the National A. A. U. swimming committee made this announcement yesterday on the receipt of a report from Max Ritter, American delegate to the international convention recently held in London.

Thomas F. Curley, Staten Island attorney, yesterday was appointed to the lifetime post of Richmond County Clerk by the Appellate Division of the Second Department. He succeeds Vincent K. Drury, whose elective three-year term expires on Dec. 31.

The French liner Normandie arrives today from Havre and Southampton. Her passengers include Demetrios Sicilianos, Greek Ambassador to the United States; Raoul Dandurand, Canadian Senator Robert Salomon, French delegate to the San Francisco Fair;
Six director of the Child Health Aseociation,. indicted on charges of violation, of the United States, BirthControl Law, pleaded not guilty before United States District Judge Robert A. Cooper today.

Governor Lehman designated eight National Guardsmen today to take entrance examinations for West Point, March 7. They are George L. Danforth Jr., of Tottenville, private; Leo M. Stettenbenz of Buffalo, corporal; Robert G. Hillman of Bayside, private; James R. Darden of Brooklyn, private; John R. Sears of New York,

Charles Howard Requa, Chicago grain merchant since 1880, died today in his home in Winnetka, Ill. He was 78 years old. Mr. Requa was born in Albany, N. Y., and came to Chicago at the age of 20 to engage in the grain business.

The Census Bureau reported today the cotton spinning industry operated during November at 83.6 per cent of- capacity, on an eighty-hour basis, compared with 81.9 per cent during October this year and 69.8 per cent during November last year.

Provident Institution for Savings sold to the Sussex Realty Corporation the two twelve-family flats at 47-49 Sussex Street, Jersey City, on a plot 50 by 100 feet. The bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $18,000.

Six-year-old Maureen Mahoney found out this morning that there is a Santa Claus even though the old gentleman -with the white whiskers has yet to deliver two dolls to her house, one for her and the other for her 4-year-old sister.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Chesapeake Ohio to issue $30,000,000 in 31/2 per cent refunding and improvement mortgage bonds, Series F, to be sold at not less than par and accrued interest, and to issue and pledge as collateral $30,000,000 of general mortgage 41/2 per cent gold bonds of 1892.

Bernard S. Deutsch, former president of the Board of Aldermen, left a net estate of $81,018 when he died on Nov. 21, 1935, while still in office, according to a transfertax appraisal filed yesterday. Mrs. Frances W. Deutsch, the widow, was named as the principal beneficiary.

A case which may have much bearing on the fight which organized medicine is making against certain group health associations came before the Supreme Court today. It was an appeal by the Pacific Health Corporation, a San Francisco group health association,

Alfred Booty, who was known on the stage as Arthur Barry, died yesterday in the Flushing, Queens, Hospital, at the age of 70. Mr. Booty, who lived at 143-33 Franklin Avenue, Flushing, entered the hospital three days ago suffering from pneumonia.

A hearing has been called by the Securities and Exchange Commission for Jan. 11 on a declaration filed by the New York and Richmond Gas Company regarding reduction of the capital represented by its 150,000 shares of common stock from $1,500,000 to $850,000 without reducing the number of shares outstanding.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from Eveline M. Burns commenting on our editorial suggestion that the problem of revision of the Social Security Act should be submitted for further study of a small full-time commission including in its membership actuaries, economists, accountants and tax specialists.

William R. Donaldson, a certified public accountant whose firm has audited the books of Loew's, Inc., since 1919, defended the company's accounting methods yesterday in Supreme Court, where he was called as a witness on behalf of company executives who are being sued by minority stockholders.
Kraft-Phenix Cheese Corporation today announced purchase of the Sanchez Cheese Corporation, an important distributor of Kraft-Phenix products in the Chicago area. T. G.

Total assets of $908,064,711, an increase of $38,500,000 over a year ago, are reported for Nov. 30 by the Royal Bank of Canada in its annual statement. The bank reports deposits $48,000,000 larger than a year ago and current loans up $18,000,000 from a year ago.

Broadway (13-3415F). w s, 450 ft 8 of 251st St, 50x108; Normandy Court, Inc, to Anders Jordahl, 15 Elweed Pl, Greenwich, Conn. Cornell Ave (16-4731), n s, 100 ft e of Chestnut St, 100x100: the Manhattan Co to Lena Shapiro, 4,495 3d Ave.

Out of her fortune Helen Gould, who became Mrs. Finley J. Shepard, gave with such abundance that she was as the woman of the parable who for two thousand years has been casting her two mites into the treasury.
The eighth Pan-American conference devoted a long plenary session this afternoon to getting out from under three of the most important problems on its agenda.

Richard Frankensteen, Detroit, first vice president of the United Automobile Workers of America, told 1,200 members of Local 222, Oshawa, tonight that a special assessment of $1 has been levied against all U. A. W. A. members to fight decentralization of the automotive industry. [In September the membership of the U. A. W. A. was put at 400,000.

A Japanese Army spokesman denied today that troops were being sent into Manchukuo. He said no trouble had been reported anywhere along the border. Peiping reports had said fifteen to twenty trainloads of Japanese troops had gone to Manohukuo from north h China daily for several days.
After pronounced weakness early in the day, the pound sterling rallied strongly in the foreign exchange market yesterday to close at $4.66 15/16, up 9/16 cent net from the previous day.

The Joint Legislative Committee on Revision of the State Insurance Law "looks with disfavor" upon proposals to permit reciprocal insurance companies in the casualty field to do business in New York State, Assemblyman R. Foster Piper, chairman of the committee, said at a hearing of his group in the State Office Building yesterday.

EVERY one who wants to talk about fascism and who doesn't, now that the newest of the double-eagles has learned to fly so high-should read "Fascism for Whom?"* by Max Ascoli and Arthur Feiler. This is a lucid, thoroughly informed double exposure of the two leading varieties.

Because of a garbled telegraphic message, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, usually very prompt on appointments, was nearly three hours late yesterday for a scheduled appearance at the Czecho-Slovak bazaar, 25 West Forty-third Street, where she purchased several lastminute Christmas presents.

A man who knew F. Donald Coster in 1916, when the latter hid his real identity as Philip Musica and worked under the name of "Johnson" in the Attorney General's office, was held yesterday in bail of $4,000 following his arrest Tuesday night on a charge of conspiracy to violate the Securities and Exchange Act.

General Sessions Judge Charles C. Nott Jr., on the motion of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, shifted, yesterday, the start of the new trial of aJmes J. Hines, the West Harlem Tammany leader, from Jan. 9 to Jan. 23.

ANDERSON-At Greenwich, Conn., suddenly, on Tuesday, Dec. 20, 1938, Walter M., beloved husband of Lucretia Mead and loving father of Delight Anderson. Funeral services at Second Congregational Church on Friday, Dec. 23, at 3 P. M. Interment private.

The marriage of Miss Cecilia Caragher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin F. Caragher of Maplewood, to C. Victor Herbert of Gloster, La., son of the late composer, took place this afternoon in the Newark City Hall.

Anthony Eden found the people of the United States "very much interested in world affairs in general and European and Far Eastern affairs in particular," he said on landing today from the liner Queen Mary after his visit.

Joseph Fishbach of St. John's, defending champion and seeded No. 1, advanced to the semi-final round of the metropolitan indoor junior tennis championship at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday. He defeated Calvin Friedman of James Madison High School, seeded No. 8, by 6-0, 6-1.

A declaration that the WPA would have to suspend operations after Feb. 7 unless Congress (as it has done in the last few years) votes a deficiency appropriation was made today by Aubrey Williams, assistant administrator.

It happened one night recently, when two local college fives met uptown. Two young men, each devoted to the cause of his favorite team, became involved in a series of arguments that soon attracted nearly as much attention as the game itself.
Approximately 15,000 manufacturers and retailers will take part in the annual National Shoe Fair, to be held here Jan. 3 to 6, inclusive, it was estimated today.

Chain stores today buy about $6,000,000,000 worth of products from manufacturers and producers, according to data accompanying the list of important taxation dates for 1939, issued yesterday by the Institute of Distribution, 570 Seventh Avenue.

In the sprawling handwriting of childish years, letters came to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday testifying to the fact that even amid the excitement of Santa Claus's impending visit many little ones had had compassion for other children whose lives have been less fortunate.

During the Christmas foreign mail period from Dec. 1 to 16, 104,010 sacks of mail, representing 27,373,565 items, were forwarded to foreign ports by 119 steamers through the Foreign Section of the New York Postoffice, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.

William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, denounced members of the Fusion administration yesterday for giving the impression to the country that "Brooklyn is a den of thieves, bandits, racketeers and conniving and dishonest public officials."
Miss Muriel Johnson and Richard Emimett Berlin, whose engagement was announced last week, were married here this afternoon at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harry T. F. Johnson.
A cold wave here ended Professor Gyula Heinitz's experiment in living like a prehistoric man. Excavations at Lake Velence, fifty miles from Budapest, brought to light a snug living room of a caveman.
A swing by Argentina toward the United States view at the Pan-American Conference would be welcomed in London, but the ability of British influence to bring this about is a cause of some doubt.
The demand for small apartments on the upper end of Manhattan Island will be met by new building projects to be undertaken as the result of sites acquired yesterday.

Sir Malcolm Campbell, holder of the world speedboat record and former holder of the automobile speed record, published a statement today saying he would not be responsible for any debts incurred by his wife, Lady Dorothy Evelyn Campbell.

Four days ago, through Andre Francois-Poncet, the French Ambassador to Rome, the Italian Foreign Minister, Count Galeazzo Ciano, forwarded a communication to the French Government, the tenor of which can be summarized as follows:

The Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $784,988 after depreciation, interest, United States income and Cuban profits taxes, provision for contingencies and other charges.

The government announced today that it would spend [Pound]20,000,000 in reinforcing private homes, apartment houses and other buildings throughout the country to protect a large part of the populace from enemy bombs.
John Lord Nisbet, 66, Atlanta real estate dealer and former president of the Georgia, Florida Alabama Railroad, was found dead in his office at suburban Buckhead tonight.

Professor and Mrs. Robert E. Rogers of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Desiree Baer Rogers, to Sherwood King, son of Professor Morland King of Lafayette College and Mrs. King of Easton, Pa.

Most of you have heard of the old Indian custom of placing an ear to the ground to determine the movements of game. Well, Captain Walt Willis, the Long Island fishing sage, accomplishes a similar result with fish by merely sniffing the briny air.
Channing L. Wegefarth, vice president of Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., has been elected to the board of directors of the New York Board of Trade, Inc.

A professor in a Main Line school challenged his class with this problem: "Name the three outstanding men in the history of Philadelphia." A 12-year-old blandly answered: "William Penn, Ben Franklin and Connie Mack."

With the British Government threatening to beat German trade competitors "at their own game," organized representatives of British industries have been seeking an understanding with their counterparts in the Reich, it was disclosed today.

Although labor conditions returned almost to normal today after yesterday's excitement when Indalecio Prieto, Spanish Loyalist leader, arrived from New York by plane, the authorities are still watchful.

Word has been received here of the marriage on Dec. 14 at the British Consulate in Cairo, Egypt, of Miss Ethelbert McKannon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Ethelbert McKannon of Columbia, Tenn., to Lleut. Col. John Robinson.

H. A. L. Simpson, elected member of the Jamaica Legislature for Kingston, died last night at the age of 66. He had been ill since his return from London, where he was this island's representative at the coronation of King George VI.

The Superior Court jury deliberating on evidence in the trial of Martin Snyder, charged with shooting Myrl Alderman, stated just before 6 o'clock (Pacific standard time) tonight that it would discontinue consideration of the case until tomorrow morning.
Turpentine firm, 231/2c; sales 15 barrels; receipts 148 barrels; shipments 98 barrels; stock 52,342 barrels. Rosin steady; sales 285; receipts 712; shipments 1.167: stock 314,772.

Clark Robinson Co. have sold to an investor a first mortgage of $7,500 on the property at 624 Avenue S, Brooklyn. The same brokers sold a $3,500 first mortgage on the two-family house at 414 Lafayette Ave. An investing client of Samuel Hurwitz bought the first mortgage of $6,000 on the four-story apartment house at 489 Tompkins Ave., Brooklyn.
The construction of large numbers of small fast destroyers as guardians of merchant shipping in wartime was foreshadowed in the House of Commons today.
Trading in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here today was confined largely to evening-up for the government's report, issued after the close of the market.

Routine and selective tests of 78,388 undergraduates in more than 500 American colleges indicate that two students out of every 1,000 are infected with syphilis, the Public Health Service announced today.

Buying by Christmas shoppers has been so heavy this month that wholesalers and factories have had trouble filling the last minute rush of orders from retail stores.. Actual shortages in a number of gift lines resulted.

With the $525,000 Essex Street enclosed retail market surviving the -Democratio assaults on the capital outlay budget, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, announced yesterday that bids for its construction would be opened Dec. 30 and that the opening date has been set for July 1, 1939.

A threat to prevent by injunction proceedings the inauguration Jan. 4 of Raymond E. Baldwin of Stratford, Republican Governor-elect, was made today by counsel for a member of the Union party following the refusal of Attorney General O'Connor to take any action on the claim that Mr. Baldwin was not entitled to the 3,046 votes cast for him on the Union party ticket.

With Julian Rivlin making three field goals in a five-minute overtime period, the Marshall College basketball team of West Virginia topped the Prospect Park Y. M. C. A. tossers, 61 to 57, on the latter's court in Brooklyn last night.

Seven men and a bulldog mascot called Yummie, who sailed out of Fort Hawkesbury, N. S., on Dec. 13 and lost their ship in a gale, were brought into port yesterday on the liner American Farmer, which rescued them two days ago.

Paul van Zeeland, former Premier sai of Belgium, told representatives of business, finance and industry yesterday that his country had adopted "a policy of equilibrium and independence and not one of neutrality," in the interest of world peace.
A long first session of the new Congress was predicted today by Speaker Bankhead upon his return to Washington to begin preparations for the opening on- Jan. 3.

On Jan. 1 the Consolidated Edison Company of New York will launch a three-month campaign to promote General Electric sun lamps and a special activity aimed to introduce the G. E. electric blanket extensively throughout the territory of the Edison system companies, it was announced jointly yesterday by E. F.

A man, armed with an iron pipe, broke into a humble home here early today, battered to death a man, his wife and their two children and killed a fifth person in the course of a trifling robbery. In beds in the one-room home onthe outskir?? of Savannah, neighbors found the bodies of J. S. Tillman, 34 years old;

Philip Bleeth of The New York Sun's financial advertising department was honored yesterday at the annual Christmas party and luncheon meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers at the Lawyers Club.

Frank J. Bryan, one of the bestknown figures in American racing, resigned as secretary of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association yesterday. Announcement of the resignation was made by Henry W. Bull, president, at the organization's offices.

A further expansion in furniture sales in 1939 was indicated today by the December and November sales sattistics of the National Retail Furniture Association and in a market analysis prepared by the American Furniture Mart in advance of the January exhibition.

The Norwegian freighter Smaragd, 1,181 gross tons, was reported to be in a sinking condition last night about 600 miles southeast of Ambrose Light, while the steamship Schodack of the United States Maritime Commission stood by in an attempt to rescue the crew of about thirty. A northwest gale was

The appearance of Georges Enesco, conductor, and several soloists, as well as the first hearings of various compositions will mark concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony during the month of January. John Barbirolli will conduct the concerts until Jan. 22, when Mr. Enesco-will take the baton for a fortnight. Then Mr. Barbirolli will continue until the end of the season.

An injunction temporarily restraining the city from refusing to consider bids on printing contracts submitted by the Burland Printing Company has been granted by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente.

After an interval of nearly fifteen years one naturally feels a little uneasy about seeing a well-loved play again. But Sutton Vane's "outward Bound," which was revived at the Playhouse last evening, seems not to have aged nor to have lost its unearthly and compassionate magic. Even after fifteen

Employers no longer will be required to keep a card index or other record of salaries, marital status and addresses of employes living within the State, Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, announced today.

The United States abruptly rejected a sharp protest the German Government sought to have delivered to the State Department yesterday against the speech of Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, in Cleveland last Sunday.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Estabrook of West Orange gave a reception this afternoon at their home to present to society their daughter, Miss Mary-Abbott Estabrook.

Federal Judge Edward J. Moinet signed today a permanent injunction restraining the Fidelity Investment Association from operating in violation of the Securities Exchange Act. The Securities and Exchange Commission had charged the Fidelity Company with fraudulent practices, particularly in alleged "misrepresentations" of the company's

To stimulate importations of United States films this government has reduced customs duties to 50 per cent. Commenting on the reduction the newspaper Novedades said: "The Nicaraguan public will again enjoy North American pictures, which are unquestionably the best in the world."

Ernst Lubitsch, who announced some months ago that he would form a profit-sharing unit with Myron Selznick to film "The Shop Around the Corner," plans for which were later abandoned, today concluded an agreement with Metro Goldwyn-Mayer whereby he will produce and direct the picture for them. Margaret Sullavan and James Stewart will be in the leads.

Two young policemen learned yesterday that they had passed the recent bar. examinations and- were duly congratulated by Police Commisioner Valentine. Louis L. Roos, 29 years old, of 1,308 Hicks Street, the Bronx, one of the. two, is attached to the department's law bureau.

Martin Snyder, former husband of Ruth Getting, was convicted by a jury today of attempting to murder Myrl Alderman, the singer's present husband and former accompanist. The conviction carries a penalty up to twenty years in prison.
Dr. Elizabeth Fear Leffingwell, specialist in gynecology, died yesterday at her home in Aurora, N. Y., at the age of 75, according to word received here.
The United States Rubber Company will redeem on Dec. 31 $1,000,000 of the $45,000,000 sinking fund 41/4 per cent bonds issued on July, last, it announced yesterday.

More than 1,000 children and their parents or other relatives, including the children of police heroes who died in service, were the guests of the Police Honor Legion yesterday at the second annual "Xmas Kiddie Show" at the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

Miss Helen Elizabeth Hughes, a former motion picture executive here, and Eugene Lowery Breen of Hollis, Queens, and this city, were married last evening in St. Patrick's Cathedral by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, vicar general of the Archdiocese of New York and rector of the cathedral.

Hard-pressed though they are by the overwhelming demands which the holiday season annually makes on them, the gray-clad men of New York's postoffice found time yesterday to send a generous gift to the least fortunate among the city's millions.

Thousands of Christmas toys were destroyed in a fire that swept through a large store of the W. T. Grant Company in a two-story building at Fordham Road and Morris Avenue, the Bronx, early this morning. The fire was discovered by a policeman at 1:15 A. M. in the Fordham Sweet Shop next door to the Grant store on Morris Avenue.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, over the dissent of three commissioners, approved conditionally today a loan of $2,824,000 to the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Prices on fed steers and yearlings today were steady to 25 cents lower, with demand less active than at previous sessions this week, choice 1,272-pound steers stopped at $12.85, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs advanced 5 to 10 cents in fairly active trade, best lightweights topping at $7.75. Lambs were steady to 10 cents lower, with load lots up to $9.25.

Messages from a lobster fishing expedition that had been reported in distress because of storms and a coal shortage in the South Indian Ocean disclosed today that all was well with the colony of forty-eight persons at isolated St. Paul Island.

In line with the efforts of the smaller stock markets to increase their business and be in a position better to serve local interests, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission applications for unlisted trading privileges in equity securities of twenty-seven companies which are registered and listed on the New York Stock Exchange or other Exchanges.
Three thousand cold but cheerful spectators watched the Eighteenth Annual Wall Street Community Christmas Tree celebration at noon yesterday at Nassau and Wall Streets.

Without referring to Chancellor Hitler by name, Secretary Ickes denounced "a brutal dictator" in his address last Sunday at a dinner of the Cleveland (Ohio) Zionist Society. Mr. Ickes said he felt that any American who accepted a decoration from a dictator "automatically foreswears his American birthright."

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted the application of the New York Stock Exchange to delist the 6 per cent refunding external sinking fund gold bonds, due on March 1, 1961 (unstamped), of the Province of Buenos Aires, Argentine Republic. The application,
New restrictions between foreign concessions in Tientsin, China, and the outside world were announced today. Traffic over the borders is permitted only in the daytime and on seven specified roads.

Joining the Giants and Dodgers, who previously had made known their intentions, the Yankees yesterday announced that 'they will allow radio broadcasting of their game's during the 1939 diamond season. General Manager Ed

Representative Wright Patman of Texas said today he had been misquoted in a news story yesterday saying he had lectured on a chain store tax bill under the occasional sponsorship of McKesson Robbins, Inc.

Officials of the Republic Steel Corporation won today against a stockholders' suit which contended that their 1930 merger and anti-merger operations lost the company $2,500,000. Cyrus S. Eaton. the "merger maker," was involved in the questioned stock transactions through three stock-dealing companies he once controlled and as a former director of Republic Steel, but not as a defendant.

Demetrius Gula, 30 years old, one of the two men on trial in General Sessions as leaders of the Ukrainian Hall gang in the kidnapping of the missing Arthur Fried from the vicinity of his White Plains home on Dec. 4, 1937, complained to a Tombs prison physician that he had been beaten many times by Federal agents, Henry Drapkin, Tombs pharmacist, testified yesterday pharmacist, testified yesterday.

A party which will fill most of the guest rooms at the White House will gather over Christmas as the guests of President and Mrs. Roosevelt. Many of the guests will be relatives, but Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator; his daughter, Diana, and Harry Hooker of New York City will be among them. Even so,

It was officially announced today that the German Government had instructed its' Charge d'Affaires in Washington to lodge a sharp protest with the United States Government against the "insulting and vulgar utterances of the American Minister of the Interior in his Cleveland speech."

Public offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. and Bonbright Co., Inc., of $10,168,000 of Consumers Power Company first mortgage 31 1/4 per cent bonds due on Nov. 1, 1966.

MANHATTAN CODY, HARRY C. (Aug. 22, 1937). Gross assets, $15,834; net, $2,052. To Edward T. Cody, brother, one-third residue; David Anderson, Helen Donnelly, Ann Meyers, Lillian McMahon and Arthur Gallager, two-fifths residue each. Chief assets, real estate, $12,000. Estra, Holley Etra, attorneys, 551 5th Ave.

Representative Stephen W. Gambrill of Laurel, Md., the fourteenth House member of the seventy-fifth Congress to die in office, was buried here today in Cedar Hill Cemetery following services at St. Mark's Church.

In June of 1936, on the last day of the Congressional session, the Senate, without debate and without. a record vote, passed a bill which had previously received very little generalattention. This bill was the Walsh-Healey
The Canadian Government clamped down today on cheap foreign souvenirs likely to be popular during the visit of the King and Queen next year. Such articles will have to pay double duty.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and Vicar General of the Archdiocese, was the celebrant of a memorial mass of requiem yesterday in honor of the Rev. William Clowrey, founder and rector of St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church, at 308 East Thirty-seventh Street. Father Clowrey died in 1884.

Despite the protests of tobacco dealers' organizations, the Board of Estimate approved the extension of the 1-cent relief tax on each package of cigarettes yesterday and authorized its continuance through the first half of next year.
The Department of Agriculture estimated today that farmers received $6,463,000,000 from sales of farm products and government benefit payments in the first eleven months of this year.

The city made Christmas plans yesterday for prisoners, the indigent and the ailing in its jails and lodging houses, while hundreds of philanthropic and social welfare groups scheduled holiday celebrations.

The current week's awards for engineering construction with $86,597,000, are the highest for any week this year and top the figure for the same week of last year by 93 per cent, according to The Engineering News Record.

The Federal Power Commission heard Guy C. Myers of New York described today as the man who cleared the way for the purchase of private utilities by Nebraska public power. districts after all other attempts at contact had failed.

Although the December Monmouth County grand jury was ordered Tuesday by Supreme Court Justice Joseph Perskie to investigate the Atlantic Highlands lottery, the operators went ahead last night with the drawing of $40,000 in prizes at a local motion picture theatre.

Charles White Nash, Albany business man and former railroad official, died to night after a short illness. He was 76 years old. He was born in Cuba, Allegany County, and as a young man was engaged in newspaper work.

The former home of the late Michael Dreicer, the jeweler, at 1,046 Fifth Avenue was sold at a voluntary auction ordered by the Baroness Rene De Kerkhov, his widow, in the Vesey Street rooms today for $40,500, the highest of the forty bids made.

Moe Liss, 37 years--old, of 716 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, and his wife, Beatrice, 27, went on trial yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Grover M; Moscowitz and a jury on an Indictment charging possession of forty-eight cubes of morphine.
The Black Hawks blew a 3-to-0 lead tonight and had to settle for a 3-to-3 overtime draw with Detroit and a third-place tie in the National Hockey League with New York's Americans, who were idle.
It is decidedly news when a belligerent denies rumors of mutiny in the enemy's forces. Loyalist circles at Barcelona refuse to take seriously

Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois, who went abroad on the Normandie after the November elections to carry on private business in London and Paris, predicted yesterday that no new social legislation of importance would be put forward at the next session of Congress.

It has been announced here that Miss Jane Gidding, daughter of Mrs. Edward Lee Irving of deal, N.J., and Jesse.D. Gidding of New York, was married Wednesday to Mervyn E. Wangenheim Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervyn E. Wangenheim of san Francisco.

In a $58,000,000 setting, with a raw wind from the East River lashing at the tails of his overcoat, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia was cheered yesterday by several hundred sandhogs when he told them that he greatly preferred their type to another kind of "hog"-the "payroll hog"-with which he has to associate.

In an affidavit submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin, Mayor La Guardia said that New York City's police force was the best paid in the world and should be most competent. For this reason, he said

Frank E. Gannett, Rochester publisher, protested today to President Roosevelt over what he termed "an unfair reflection" that "newspapers are edited in the counting room." In an open letter, Mr. Gannett answered a Presidential statement

Governor Blanton Winship of Puerto Rico informed Secretary Ickes today of an unfavorable trade balance for the first time in eight years. The balance was $11,237,605 In his report for the fiscal year ended on June 30, made public today, Governor Winship said the island had been affected by adverse world market conditions and sugar quota restrictions.

Making a determined bid to retain possession- of the Belden-Stephens trophy, which they have captured the last three years in succession and need to win twice more for permanent custody, Harvard's champion chess players made a brilliant start in the opening

One hold-up man was killed and three other men, including a paroled "lifer" were under arrest yesterday in a flurry of pre-Christmas hold-ups and burglary attempts. The dead man was Albert Weiner, 39 years old, a jailbird with a record of eighteen arrests since 1919.

Minister of Education Kapras today signed an order suspending all Jewish professors and teachers from German universities and high schools in Czecho-Slovakia. This is described in the Czech press as a step taken "within the framework of solving-the whole Jewish problem."

With the sound of hammer and crowbar echoing along Sixth Avenue to herald the passing of the old elevated structure there, realty activity in that neighborhood has picked up more promptly than even the sanguine observers had predicted.

More than 50,000 toys were distributed yesterday to needy children of the city. The Police and Fire Department gave them out at Madison Square Garden, and the WPA Toy Repair Project had an even larger party at the 71st Regiment Armory.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente took under consideration yesterday an application made by minority stockholders of Loews, Inc., for an order directing directors and executives of the company to account for allegedly excessive remuneration paid to themselves and others.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Robert B. Baker, C. A.-Res., 256 Winfield Terrace, Union, N. J. (D.), 62d Coast Artillery (A. A.), is ordered to active duty, Jan. 15, at Fort Totten, N. Y., for training with the 52d Coast Artillery (A. A.). Date of rank: May 26, 1934. He will revert to an inactive status on Jan. 28.

A survey of meat, fruit and vegetable markets by experts indicates that good Christmas dinners at reasonable prices may be obtained for Sunday. Poultry prices,-except for turkey, are well below a year ago. There are plenty of fresh fruits and vegetables at moderate prices, from Texas, Florida, Cuba and some from California. Quality is good.

The snow-covered Highlands of Scotland gave Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain his nicest Christmas present in years today with the news that the Duchess of Atholl, his bitterest critic within the Conservative party, had been defeated for re-election to Parliament.

To the accompaniment of joyous shouting and cheering on the part of about 200 boys and girls, Santa Claus distributed' 300 gifts at a Christmas party in the dispensary of Beekman Street Hospital, Beekman and Water Streets, yesterday afternoon. Santa Claus was impersonated by a staff physician, Dr. Carl H. Smith, who was assisted in presenting the gifts by former Governor Alfred E. Smith.

Poland and Lithuania, who almost went to war last March over long-strained relations. today signed a trade treaty arranging for exchange of goods worth more than $2,000,000. The treaty, running for one year, provides for Poland's use of Memel harbor for exports from Eastern Poland. Poland expects to sell to
Mr. and Mrs. Le Roy Kent Howe of 1,120 Fifth Avenue gave a tea dance yesterday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Bruce Howe.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 20: Early, Commander A. R., Edgewood Arsenal, Md., to command the Capella, -about Dec. 26. Biggs, Lieut. G. P., the Maryland, to Naval Academy, in June. Stephan, Lieut. E. C., the S-35, to command the S-28, May 25. Strozier, Junior Lieut. H. H., the Chicago to the Conyngham.

GERMANS IN THE CAMEROONS, 18841914, by Harry R. Rudin. (Yale University Press, $4.) A ease study in modern imperialism. THE DIARY OF ROGER LOWE: 16631674, edited by William L. Sachse. (Yale University Press, $2.50.) A record of country life in Southern Lancashire.

A News-Sentinel dispatch from Washington today said President Roosevelt was considering the appointment of Jonathan W. Daniels of Raleigh, N. C., to the board of directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority. The paper said if the young Southern author and newspaper editor were named he would fill the vacancy created by the President's ousting of Chairman A. E. Morgan last March for "contumacy."

J.P. Spang Jr. was appointed yesterday president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company to succeed S. C. Stampleman, who resigned to become chairman of the board of directors, Mr. Stampleman was elected president on Aug. 23, 1934,

Alexander Simpson, counsel for George W. Rogers, hero of the Morro Castle disaster and former Bayonne patrolman, found guilty recently of attempting to kill a police lieutenant with a home-made bomb, announced here today the State Supreme Court had granted a writ of error, the first step toward appeal from the conviction.

A drive by the railroads to regain automobile shipping business lost to trucks was disclosed today by the filing with the Interstate Commerce Commission of a petition from the National Automobile Transporters Association asking the commission to suspend certain proposed reductions in rail rates on new cars and to make a general investigation into rates on such commodities.
Charles Remington Adams, business manager of The Syracuse Herald, died of a heart attack today during a conference with Edward A. O'Hara, Herald publisher. He was 56 years old.
The Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic bobsled run at Lake Placid will be ready for public use on Sunday, the Conservation Department announced today.

Christmas carols were characterized as. "unnecessary noise" by Patrolman. Thomas H. Patten of the Maspeth precinct in complaints signed by him before Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto in the Long. Island City Court yesterday.

Homer G. Angles, 37 years old, who gave his address as the Park Lane Hotel, Newark, was held in $50,000 bail for the action of the grand jury today when he waived examination before Police Judge Anthony J. Botti on a charge of violating the State Securities Act. Angles,

Trading was active to slow in local markets yesterday. With the exception of a few miscellaneous cuts, the markets showed little change throughout. Kosher business was confined mostly to lamb during yesterday's trading and this market opened steady to strong. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

TIME works some remarkable changes in base ball and one can almost understand how Burleigh Grimes committed a famous faux pas of last Winter when, as manager of the Dodgers, he turned to Bill McKechnie and asked: "Bill, how about trading Al Lopez back to Brooklyn ?" Whereupon the kindly Deacon, with just a faint twinkle in his very sad eyes, replied:

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Christopher Anderson of Fairfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Murtagh Anderson, to Frank Billings Nichols, son of Mrs. George R. Nichols Jr. of Chicago and Watch Hill, R. I., and the late Mr. Nichols.

Engagements of $2.500.000 of gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. About half of the amount was understood to have been obtained at an earlier date. The engagements included $2,000,000 from England, $200,000 from Holland and $300,000 from India.
All transpacific press matter to Honolulu and the Orient was declared "hot" today and operators of Globe, R. C. A. and Mackay radio refused to handle the dispatches.

The 3,500 employes of the Third Avenue Railway System authorized the executive board-of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, yesterday to call at its discretion a strike on any or all of the street car and bus lines operated by the company in Manhattan,
Funeral services for Mrs. Helen Gould Shepard, philanthropist and daughter of the late Jay Gould, were held here today in the Gould Memorial Reformed Church.
Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday rose above the $7,000,000,000-mark for the first time in twenty-one months, or since the week of March 17, 1937, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

MANHATTAN Estate, $1,600. To Marja Zerebecka, daughter, Sieniowa, Poland, and Michael Ciurko, brother, Jaroslaw, Poland, one-half residue each. Wladyslaw Dabrowski, 118 E. 7th St., executor. GORDON, HARVEY A. (Dec. 15). Estate, $1,200. To Lyllyan Gordon, widow, executrix. 290 Riverside Dr.
Mrs. S. Orr's Orinoco defeated eight others today in the feature event for 3-year-olds and upward over a mile and seventy yards at the Fair Grounds.

The Brooklyn Free Kindergarten Society was the beneficiary of a Yuletide Ball held last night at The Towers in Brooklyn. Mrs. Horatio King Gray was chairman of the ball committee. Her aides included Mrs. Edwin C. Ward, Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard Jr., Mrs. Tremper Longman, Mrs. Francis E. Walton, Mrs. J. Christopher Meyer, Mrs. Robert A. Burdick,

Harness horse hostilities on a nationwide front loomed today as the newly formed United States Trotting Association announced it would invade in 1939 the Western and Midwestern territory hitherto ruled exclusively by the American Trotting Association of Chicago.

The University of Tennessee was rated a 6-to-5 favorite to win the Orange Bowl football game from Oklahoma University on Jan. 2. Word from Tennessee that a dozen players were suffering from colds failed to reduce the odds. .

The stock market was quiet today, with the holiday spirit more in evidence but the undertone fairly firm. Giltedge stocks advanced modestly. Foreign bonds were unchanged or fractionally lower. Transatlantic shares fluctuated narrowly and United States Steel and International Nickel eased slightly.

Samuel Insull Jr., son of the late utility operator, announced today his resignation as assistant to the chairman of the Commonwealth Edison Company. "I have made arrangements to accept, early in January, what I consider a very good business opportunity," he said in a formal statement.

Mr. and Mrs. Hooker Talcott gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Hope Talcott, a debutante of this season. Among the other guests were the Misses Valerie Hathaway, Nina Van Vechten, Elizabeth Powers and Marilyn Geer;

Manhattan Alterations 49th St, 314-16 W; to two 1-story bar and lounge; Seamens Bank for Savings, premises, owner; Mayers, Murray Phillips, architects; cost, $50,000. Rockefeller Plaza, 30; to 66-story offices Rockefeller Center, Inc, premises, owner; W. K. Harrison, architect; cost, $3,500. 32d St, 114 E; to 17-story offices and showrooms; Mutual Life Ins Co, 32 Nassau St, owner; S. Gerscovici, architect; cost, $5,000.

Applications from four European countries for transatlantic air service permits involving passenger, mail and express operations to and from the United States are before the Civil Aeronautics Authority. The applications, which propose visas, to France, Germany and Italy, are being discussed with other departments of the government.

As a prelude to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's visit to Rome, the Italian Government through Ambassador Andre Francois-Poncet has informed Paris officially that it does not consider the agreement made in January, 1935, between former Premier Pierre Laval and Premier Mussolini for the settlement of Franco-Italian differences as valid.

The Treasury settled an income tax dispute with Ed Wynn, comedian, for $174,165 today and another with the estate of Arthur Brisbane, newspaper man for $26,294. In each instance protests had been filed with the Board of Tax Appeals against deficiencies claimed by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

The general level of wholesale prices dropped last week to the lowest level since late in December, 1934, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 76.7 for the week ended on Dec. 17, compared with 77.1 on Dec. 10 and 81.5 on Dec. 18, 1937. Sharp declines in prices of raw materials, especially farm products and foods, largely accounted for the drop.

18th St, 231 W; Victor R. Kaufmann, referce, to New York Savings Bank, foreclosure ($6): 23d St, 334-6 E; David L. Schreiber, referee, to Excelsior Savings Bank, foreclosure ($2). 63d St, 668-340 E; Amor Atina, Inc, to 340 E 63d St Corp, 2 Rector St ($10).

Parcels in the Williamsburgh zone, Red Hook and in Bay Ridge figured in the Brooklyn realty deals reported yesterday. The Williamsburgh properties were quickly resold and those in Red Hook will be demolished to make way for a business building.

The Interstate Commerce Commission completed today action on reorganization of the Savannah Atlanta Railroad Company by authorizing the new company to take over assets of the old one, to issue various securities and to borrow $1,700,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The University Club squash racquets team dethroned the Harvard Club as Class A champion in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association race when it defeated the defenders, 3 to 2, last night on the winners courts.
A southern polar route that would cut about 10,000 miles from the air journey between South Africa and Australia is suggested in a government White Paper, an official report.

Benjamin Franklin. High's basketball team, defending city P. S. A. L. champion, scored its fourth straight lower Manhattan Division success land gained a firmer hold on first place by downing the High School of Commerce, 29 to 16, on the loser's floor yesterday.

TODAY-New England: Clear, except partly cloudy to clear over Eastern Maine; continued cold with freezing temperatures over all portions. New York State: Clear, except clear followed by increasing cloudiness in west, snow flurries along lake shores; continued cold, freezing temperatures over entire State. Pennsylvania:

The Pan-American Conference at today's plenary session passed a vote of thanks to the Inter-American Commission of Women and ruled that it should continue its work--as adviser to Pan-American Conferences on questions affecting women.

Twelve events, which are expected to bring together the foremost athletes of the country, will make up the program of the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, indoor track and field meet at the 245th Coast Artillery Armory in Brooklyn on Jan. 7, it was announced yesterday by Frank A. Madden, director of the games.

Walter A. Mohr was elected yesterday a vice president of James Talcott, Inc. He was previously assistant secretary and assistant credit manager of the corporation, and has been with the organization for almost ten years.

Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, was silent today as to a statement issued yesterday by Neville Miller, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, denouncing as "an evil not to be tolerated" radio
The Police Department expects the New Year's celebration to be protracted and lively, a teletype order sent to all precincts from Police Headquarters indicated last evening.

Samuel Leopold, retired New York textile manufacturer, died here this afternoon at the age of 87. Born in Ellenville, N. Y., he was one of the founders of Carl Guttman Co., underwear manufacturers of New York.

The increased flow of contributions to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund in the last week before Christmas is encouraging, but it is not equal to last year's showing. It must be, if every waiting family is to receive adequate and friendly care.

PRINCESS FUR CORP., manufacturers of fur garments, 36. Central Ave., Pearl River-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler act listing liabilities of $13,018 and assets of $7,355. A settlement of 100 per cent. in ten equal installments is proposed. ALBERT ZABEN, doing business as White Star Dairy, 912 Amsterdam Ave.-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler act listing liabilities of $3,703 and assets of $865, exclusive of fixtures subject to chattel mortgages.

Captain Alastair Mackintosh entertained with a luncheon at today's opening of the Alibi.. Attending were the Duke and Duchess of Sutherland, Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Captain and Mrs. R. Amcotts Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas, Mr. and

State and defense attorneys who have been examining veniremen since Nov. 29 to get ten jurors for the trial of the Waterbury municipal fraud case started a week's vacation today before resuming efforts to pick the final two needed for the trial.

A banking group composed of John Nuveen Co., C. W. McNear Co. and Kelley, Richardson Co., Inc., submitted yesterday the only bid for $3,000,000 of electric light and power bonds of Cleveland, according to advices received in bond circles.

Prime Minister W. F. Mackenzie King announced tonight the naming of a commission, complementary to that named by President Roosevelt, to report on the facts, but not to recommend action,- on the proposed American highway through British Columbia to Alaska.

Mrs. Ida Hatch Campbell Clarke, Widow of former Presiding Justice John Proctor Clarke of the Appellate Division, First Department, was killed today when an-automobile in which she was riding was in collision with a truck on the Providence-Fall River road.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, principal subsidiary of United States Steel Corporation, on Jan. 1 will restore the salary cuts of about 9 per cent made last February by putting into effect a fulltime work week of five and onehalf days, to which will apply

Dr. Henry W. Berg, an authority on infectious diseases and internal medicine, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 10 East Seventy-third Street after an illness of six months. He would have been 79 years old on Sunday.
L. Chester Goldberg, national sales agent for, the Graewil Sportswear Company, with offices in New York, died yesterday of coronary thrombosis at his home here. He was 43 years old. During the World

Charles E. Brinley, president of the American Pulley Company since 1919, was elected today president of the. Baldwin Locomotive Works to succeed George H. Houston, who resigned in August. A director and
Miss Katherine Lemoine Fenimore Cooper made her debut last night at a dinner dance given for her by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Henry Sage Fenimore Cooper, in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center.

Contracts for a total of 20,000 square feet of space in two locations for occupancy by one firm were announced yesterday. The Mardell Manufacturing Company, Inc., dealers in bedspreads, draperies and allied lines, took 15,000 square feet in 151-63 West Twenty-sixth Street for manufacturing and 5,000 square feet in 258-60 Fifth Avenue for salesrooms.
Brigadier Ernest R. Holz, a Salvation Army officer, died today in the United States Veterans Hospital at the age of 48.

First steps were taken today to establish a permanent repository at Hyde Park for President Roosevelt's personal papers and collection of books and paintings. The Franklin D.
