Roosevelt Library, Inc., was incorporated by New York's Secretary of State nearly two weeks after Mr. Roosevelt announced plans for the project, which he said would be financed ...

Following is the text of the suicide note made public here yesterday by Samuel Reich as counsel for F. Donald Coster, who shot himself last Friday: Mr. Reich: Bankers, lawyers, auditors, appraisers and incompetent high salaried executives,

Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College, lit the Yule log with last year's firebrand at the traditional Christmas ceremony held yesterday on the Bronx campus, Navy Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard. More than 2,000 students and faculty members joined in the singing of Christmas carols.
Walter Scheib, who owns the building at 80 St. Mark's Place, where he operates the Walter Scheib Bar and Grill, Inc., has made plans for expanding his restaurant and cabaret business there.

Dr. Michael S. Granelli, Hoboken physician and veteran of two wars, died here today in City Hospital after a long illness. He was 57 years old. Dr. Granelli was a soldier in the Spanish-American War and then studied medicine.

While debutantes of this season were feted yesterday at another round of parties, girls who will not make their formal debuts for another year or two attended the Christmas Dolphin Dance last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre. The Dolphin Dances, a series of subscription entertainments, are given each season during the Christmas and Spring holidays for young people at home from schools and colleges.

A 14-point spurt in the closing minutes of the first period while the opposition was shut out, gave the University of Michigan: basketball team a 27-13 edge. over Cornell at half-time tonight, and thereafter the Wolverines romped to a 42-27 victory before 5,000 persons at the Westchester County Center.

Accused of heaving a brick last night through a window of the postoffice here, an unemployed clerk from Washington, D. C., told the police today he was "disgusted" with the New Deal and was on his way to Hyde Park to toss a brick at the President's house when he passed the postoffice and chose that instead.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, when John Barbirolli conducted its orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, offered its audience stage arrangements and the sequences of a program applicable in greater part to the Christmas season. The program - included choral music of Christmastide.

Armed police are guarding all roads around Belfast tonight, following the arrest of thirty-four men who were taken from their beds t early this morning on suspicion of being concerned in a plot to assassinate Viscount Craigavon, Ulster Premier, several members of his Cabinet and a number of police officials and to seize the government.

A dinner dance was given by Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren of this city and Newport last night in the balcony of the St. Regis Iridium Room for her debutante granddaughter, Miss Louise Drexel Hubbard, daughter of Mrs. Dahlgren Hubbard.

Senator Charles Reibel has introduced a motion that all foreigners having French work permits should be subject to army duty in time of war. Special brigades would be established for these drafted foreigners; and the Senator also proposes that such foreigners between the ages of 21 and 30 be compelled to do two years' military service, just as Frenchmen are.
Mr. and Mrs. Dana H. Ferrin of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Ferrin, to Joseph Guy Sutton, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Sutton of Cedar Grove, N. J.
Mr. and Mrs. H. Maynard Kidder and Mrs. Stuart Scott gave a dinner dance last -night at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce their respective daughters, the Misses Maria La G. Kidder and Barbara Scott.

Although it was still a question whether Christmas trade here would show an average gain over last year for the period from Dec. 1 to 24, the last few days have brought sharp improvement both in comparative dollar volume and in the size of the average sale.

A large temporary fall in excess reserves and a further shrinkage in the commercial loans of New York City banks to the lowest levels in years were the outstanding developments revealed in the weekly Federal Reserve statistics for the period ended on Wednesday, which were issued yesterday.

A state of emergency has been proclaimed as a result of a rebellion against British authority. It is believed to foreshadow the possibility of large-scale arrests. The Governor has returned from Mandalay, where he had gone to spend Christmas.

Count Galeazzo Oiano, Italian Foreign Minister, for Rome invited Count Stephen Csaky, Hungarian Foreign Minister, to visit the Italian capital. No official statement as to the result of their conversations was issued, but it is generally believed that the extension of the Rome-Berlin axis was the main matter discussed.

The American republics declared today at a plenary session of the Pan-American conference their conviction that "all--persecutions from racial or religious motives which place a number of human beings in the impossibility of obtaining a decent.
Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau said today that he would recommend to Congress continuance- of the stabilization fund of $2,000,000,000, authority to operate which will expire on June 30.

" Window Shopping," a farce by Louis E. Shecter and Norman Clark, in which the central figure is a woman who demonstrates household appliances in a store window, opens tonight at the Longacre. The cast is headed by George Sidney and Gerta Rozan.

Charles F. Michaels, who was elected president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., last Tuesday to succeed the late F. Donald Coster, admitted yesterday that all the drug company's common stock that he and his immediate family possessed was sold out within three weeks
A big University of Southern California, sextet, making its. initial showing in New York, defeated the St. Nicks hockey team, 5 to 3, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Michael Chekhov, former actordirector of the Moscow Art Theatre and a nephew of the noted dramatist, Anton Chekhov, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie to arrange for the transfer of his theatre studio from Dartington Hall, England, to the United States.
The following dispatch, the fourth of a series, was sent by a staff correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES after a tour of Germany and Czecho-Slovakia. It was written in Paris and so was not censored.
Dr. Americo Garibaldi, a Peruvian pursuing research work in' cancer at Fordham University, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 45 years old.

George Briggs Lynes, formerly an editor of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, died today in his home here at the age of 66. Born in Middleburgh, N. Y., Mr. Lynes was graduated from Union College in 1898 as first honor man of his class.

Little orphaned Adelene Hunt will be the -beneficiary of an award of $40,000 made by a jury in the Queens Suprem- court yesterday against a bus company and driver held responsible for the death of both the little girl's parents.
Democratic members of the next Congress and some State leaders of that party have been returning to their offices from the White House lately with uneasy minds. They have been telling

Scoring 15 points in the last six minutes of the game, the Crescent Athletic Club basketball team turned back the Prospect Park Y. M. C. A., 46 to 41, on the New Mooners' court in Brooklyn last night. Thomas of the Crescents was high scorer with 18 points.

Notre Dame, after losing to two other Big Ten basketball teams, finally found itself tonight against Northwestern and walloped the Wildcats, 48 to 30. The defeat was the worst Notre Dame has given Northwestern in twelve years on the court.

Key men of Green Bay's high-powered offense, finished one-two at the head of the National Football League scorers with 58 and 57 points respectively, according to the final official statistics, released yesterday.

In festively decorated Deutschlandhalle here tonight Chancellor Hitler entertained 7,000 workers who are building the mammoth new Chancellery. He presented to each an autographed photograph as a Christmas. gift and after dinner briefly addressed them.

Mrs. Bertram Gordon Waters of Boston has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Mrs.-Sally Waters Richardson, to John Elting of New York, son of Victor Elting of Chicago and the late Mrs. Elting.

James H. Hutchens, business manager for the last twenty-six years of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, died here last night in his home after a long illness. He was 77 years old.
One officer and six members of the Belgian liner Elisabethville are being detained here in connection with the disappearance of $475,000 worth of gold bars and diamonds from the ship's safe.

Repeal of the Wagner Labor Relations Act and enactment in its place of a "more equitable" law to safeguard the rights of employers and employes was urged yesterday by the board of directors of the Twenty-third Street Association.
Ace Parker, former all-America football player at Duke University, who played baseball last year for the Athletics, was purchased today by Chattanooga of the Southern Association.

Contrary to the usual seasonal trend, employment continued to rise-in November, according to Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor, who made public today figures showing for that month a gain of 30,000 jobs in non-agricultural employment.

Two more cases of American manufacturers building plants abroad were reported by the Department of Commerce today. The Chilean branch of a concern making phonograph and radio products is investing $150,000 in construction of a plant near Santiago. Chile imported last year-more than 200 tons of the products this plant will make.

The New York Rangers strengthened their hold on second place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 5 to 2, for their third straight victory over the flying Frenchmen.

Joseph Fishbach of St. John's and Nathan Goldstein of Brooklyn College triumphed in semi-final round matches yesterday in the junior metropolitan indoor tennis singles championship at the 102d Engineers Armory and will meet there at 2:30 o'clock today for the title.

NEW York standardizes practically everything except itself-and books about it continue to reflect the town's permanent variety. Here, for example, are two conspicuously disparate views. * One is a collection of twenty-three Profiles from the pages of The New Yorker, portraits of celebrities done in wrought irony.
Collections of internal revenue in November aggregated $304,571,878, a decrease of $21,164,262, compared with the previous month, the Bureau of Internal Revenue reported today.

Business circles predicted today that Economics Minister Walther Funk. would-lead a German delegation to London early-in January in an effort to work out an arrangement for improving British-German trade.
Robert C. Bickwell, formerly associated with the realty department of the Equitable Building, is now with the Sixty Wall Tower Corporation.

During the week ended Dec. 21 member bank reserve balances decreased $562,000,000; Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $612,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $85,000,000 in money

The Rev. Samuel Dancy of Belltown, retired Baptist minister, died yesterday at the home of his son, North Dancy of Darien, after a long illness; He was 83 years old and had lived with his son for a year.

Mrs. Ruth Wilmerding Montgomery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Wilmerding, was married yesterday at the home of her parents, 12 East Eighty-ninth Street, to John A. McVickar Jr., son of the late Mrs. Dorothea Crouse McVickar, and of John A. McVickar.
Eighteen "former" Communists were released from Dachau concentration camp today and entertained at a Christmas party by Julius Streicher, Franconian Nazi leader, in a holiday gesture of amnesty.

New York shipping men are awaiting the outcome of a threatened fight between the two United States-Brazil reight conferences and the Sprague Steamship Agency, Inc., to which was denied membership in the conferences on Wednesday.

Frank Henius, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., in 277 Park Ave; Morgenthau-Seixas Co, Inc, brokers. Charles A. Rosenswalke, in 107 W 86th St; Albert M. Greenfield Co, Inc, agents. Gerry Fairbanks, Ralph B. Vallarino, Wm. G. Mattews, in 3,117 Broadway;Josep Greenspan Ben Copper,

Death Announced Retired engineer of steamer Michael J. Arneth. formerly a member of Engine Co. 264, residing at 63 Rogers Ave., Inwood, L. I., died on Dec. 19., Advancements In Grade To take effect at 12:01 A. M., on date specified:

An advance in prices for the fifth consecutive day featured trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and, with gains of 2 to 7 points, the list ended at the highest level since Dec. 2. Mill price-fixing of unusually heavy volume, in which a few houses took contracts for more than 20,000 bales from the ring, brought the best figures of the day in final dealings.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 21: MAJOR GENERAL Beck, R. M. Jr., General Staff Corps, one day leave, Dec. 27. COLONEL Michie, H. C. Jr., Med. Corps, Philippine Department to Fort Benjamin Harrison, Ind.

Sponsors of the Sugar- Bowl week of athletics, which starts Monday with a regatta and ends Jan. 2 with a football game between Carnegie Tech and Texas Christian, looked on their labor today and pronounced it. perfect.

Adding to the success enjoyed here by Mr. and Mrs. B. F. Whitaker and Jockey Eddie Arcaro, the 3-year-old colt, Sickle T., raced to a smartly-achieved triumph in the featured Florida City Purse of six furlongs today. The victory was the second of the day for the Texas-owned Whitaker establishment and the powerful veteran, Arcaro. rcaro.

The General Motors and Chrysler Corporations yesterday closed contracts with the Universal Trading Corporation with respect to 500 G. M. C. trucks and 500 Dodge trucks for shipment to China, where they will replace the railroad systems lost to the Japanese during the invasion.

Trailing by 23-21 at the half, the New York University School of Jamaica Commerce basketball team rallied to down the City College Evening Session squad, 35 to 31, at the City College gymnasium last night.

John Weil of the host school, Stephen Salat of St. John's University and Ted Olmstead of Loomis were the three winners in the third annual invitation fencing meet staged yesterday at the Riverdale Country Day School.

Results of Operations Listed by Other Corporations, With Comparative Figures John Morrell Co., meat packers, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in a condition statement for the fiscal year, ended on Oct. 29, net earnings of $1,016,227 after taxes and charges.

" Weehawkenzapoppin," an informal musical show that has been put on by and for the edification of commuters on the New York Central ferry oat from Weehawken to Cortlandt Street every morning and evening for three years, has a special Christmas presentation yesterday morning.

3d Ave, 4,062, 5-story tenement, 33.6x100; Bonaventure F. Broderick et al, trustees, against John La Monaco, due, $33,453 taxes, , $739; to plaintiff for $2,500. By VINCENT J. DEO Loring Place, 1,845, 2-story dwelling, 28.5x105; Mortgage Commission of State of New York against Catherine Muller, due,
Continued efforts by buyers of wool piece goods to obtain quicker deliveries of orders written four to six weeks ago were without success this week, the New York Wool Top Exchange reported yesterday.

Dr. and Mrs. William Sargent Ladd of 25 East Eighty-third Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Wood Ladd, to Herbert Garthwaite Hanan of East Port Chester, Conn., son of Mrs. Herbert Wilmer Hanan of 1,070 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Hanan.

County Clerk Harold Mercer, in charge of the Westchester Automobile Bureau, said today he had complied with the wish of Mayor Howard Dunscomb of Ossigning for a low license number by selling the 1939 tag "9V 60" to him.

Announcement has been made here by Miss Ruth E. Thompson of Brunswick, Me., of the engagement of her niece, Miss Helen Elizabeth Thompson, to William Thompson Matthews,. son of Dr. and Mrs. Schuyler C. Matthews of Brooklyn.

Henry Ittleson, president of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, announced yesterday the consummation of the negotiations for the purchase of all the minority stock of the Universal Credit Corporation by C. I. T. on the terms announced early this month.

A suit for damages has been filed by the City of New York against the General Electric Company, it was learned yesterday, charging the company with intimidation and interference in the execution of a lighting fixture contract let by the city to a competitor of the company.

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania and Senator Robert R. Reynolds of South Carolina returned on the French liner Normandie yesterday with the conviction that the Europe of the future would be dominated economically and politically by Germany and Adolf Hitler.

Collegiate basketball closes its pre-Christmas schedule in this vicinity tonight with three varsity encounters. The cagers of City College, Long Island University and St. Francis will start against out-of-town opponents as the main attractions for New York City followers of the court sport.

Kensuke Horinouchi presented his credentials to President Roosevelt today as the Japanese Ambassador and declared he would strive "to increase the understanding, promote the good-will and further the valuable interests existing in the relations between our two countries."

Transfer Ordered To take effect 8 A. M., Dec. 23. PATROLMAN Ralph R. DeBiase, from 9th Division to 5th Precinct, assignment to duty in Plain Clothes discontinued. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT James Sabatino, from 15th Division to 18th Division. for duty in D. A. Office. Queens, for 11 days, from 8 A. M., Dec. 21.

James H. Hatch, former international president of the Upholsterers International Union, A. F. of L., and long prominent in the American labor movement, died on Wednesday night in his home, 235 East Fifty-seventh Street, after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

For the fourth successive year Shirley Temple has been voted by the theatre owners in America as the number one box-office star, according to' the results of a 'survey conducted by the trade' publication, Motion Picture Herald, and made public yesterday. Second place went to Clark Gable, a position which the actor has maintained for three consecutive years.

John Henry McDonald, who retired two years ago as assistant cashier of the Prudential Insurance Company after thirty-five years' service with the concern, died yesterday at his home here after a year's illness. A native of Newark,

Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, accompanied by Count Stephen Csaky, Hungarian Foreign Minister, and other notables, participated in a hunting party yesterday. They returned to Budapest last evening. Count Ciano will leave today for Rome.
Fire today destroyed Notgrove Manor, an imposing Cotswold country house where descendants of Dick Whittington, London's famous fourteenth century Lord Mayor, lived for hundreds of years.

University 3, Harvard 2 Bernard H. Ridder, University, defeated Donald M. Frame, 15-10, 11-15, 15-14, 17-18, 15-8; Germain G. Gliddem, Harvard, defeated Herbert D. Lancaster, 15-13, 15-18, 15-12, 15-11; Samuel

The John G. Woodward Candy Company, established in 1860 and once the largest candy factory west of the Mississippi River, has been sold to the Union Standard Company, New York City. It is assumed that the Union Standard Company will discontinue operations here.

Dr. Douglas Hyde, 78-year-old President of Ireland, spoke for the first time over the radio tonight in a Christmas message to the United States in which he stressed the friendship between the two countries.

Retail credit collections during November showed an increase of 0.21 per cent, according to the twenty local store index, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The average collection percentage for the month was 50.40, against 50.19 in the same period a year ago.

Miss Mary M. Shinnick, a teacher in the Brooklyn School for Homemaking and of Manhattan College Extension Courses, died yesterday in the Victory Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of three weeks. A native of Brooklyn,

Max Lippe, 53-year-old bail bondsman, who has been described by John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor investigating charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, as a key witness to "attempts to influence public officials for the purpose of stifling prosecutions in the Brooklyn bail bond racket,"

When critics of the British Government's air-raid precautions cited in the House of Commons today Barcelona's large communal shelters as models, Sir John Anderson, Minister for Civilian Defense, said that what Barcelona had suffered was "trivial compared with what might happen to Britain if she ever engaged in a major war."

Wheat prices were on the up-grade here today as the result of buying induced by a bullish construction put on an estimate by the Department of Agriculture late yesterday on the probable 1939 harvest. There was some buying of the May contract, which brokers attributed to mills.

The reduction of $500,000,000 in excess reserves reported in yesterday's Federal Reserve statements was somewhat smaller than had been expected. Actual reserves were off $562,000,000, but requirements fell $62,000,000 owing to smaller deposits.

Luncheons, dinners and parties are being given daily for boys and girls home from schools and colleges for the holidays. Yesterday Mrs. George D. Barron of Rye gave a luncheon at the Versailles for her granddaughter, Miss Joy Coster. The other guests were classmates of Miss Coster's at Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Conn.
The sale on Wednesday of an old Wendel family holding on West Twenty-sixth Street for an apart-house was followed yesterday by announcement of another deal in the Chelsea section.

The President's annual greeting as Commander-in-chief to all the armed forces of thee United" States went out today by telegraph wireless and cable to every point where American soldiers or sailors are serving.

The Rev. Francis deSales Howle, Jesuit educator, writer and orator, died yesterday at the Jesuit Seminary at St. Andrews-on-Hudson, Poughkeepsie, N. Y., according to word received at Brooklyn Preparatory School, where he had been chaplain from 1923 until his retirement last June.

The Eastern championship ice yachting regatta will be held the week-end of Jan. 15 or soon thereafter, depending on the weather, it was learned yesterday following a meeting of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association. The place will be decided upon when ice conditions are determined.

National Distillers Products Corporation, one of the largest distillers of domestic whiskeys, will expand into the field of domestic wine and brandy production early next year, according to an announcement yesterday.

A policy of holding only one trade opening a year will be followed by the floor coverings industry in the future, Herbert Gutterson, president of the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc., announced yesterday.

J. Chester Cuppia, a leader in the recent reform movement in the New York Curb Exchange, has been asked to accept nomination for the chairmanship of the Exchange, it was disclosed yesterday. Mr. Cuppia was a member of the board of governors from 1929

Three important problems remain unsolved in the study by the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission of the question of segregating the underwriting and commission functions of brokerage houses by allowing the firms to establish security affiliates.

A decidedly better undertone prevailed yesterday throughout the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Almost all of the major groups reflected the improvement in varying degrees as the trading pace was stepped up to a turnover of $9,391,100, against $8,846,875 on Wednesday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an additional opinion by William Werntz, chief accountant, dealing with the balance sheet presentation of preferred or other senior classes of capital stock having preference on involuntary liquidation in excess of the par or stated value.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired one of the rare examples of monumental Mohammedan sculpture, it is announced in the museum's December bulletin, which is released today. The piece shows a warrior on horseback, carved in high relief. The carving is recessed in an arched tympanum.

Mexicans may now send their complaints to President Lazaro Cardenas by telegraph-free of charge. The government press bureau announced that an office of complaints had been created to aid "farmers, workers, communities,
Brazil's new immigration law became effective today. It regulates further admission of aliens and requires the registration of about 3,000,000 who are already in Brazil.

Burke Ave (16-4580), s w cor of Yates Ave, 50x100; Eugene J.\ Morris, referee, to Siegfried Salomon, 440 West End Ave. Cruger Ave (15-4288), e s, 100 ft s of Lydig Ave, 150x200; Lemust Holding Corp to Holland Construction Corp, 332 E 149th St: mtg S28.000.

Representatives of the Bridgeport Brass Company from twenty-one branch offices throughout the country will attend a national convention here on- Jan. 9, Herman W. Steinkraus, vice president in charge of sales, announced today.

The Scott Paper Company gave yesterday Christmas service awards to 1,200 persons. Employes who joined the organization before Jan. 1, 1938, received $25 plus an additional $1 for each year of continuous service. Others received $10 and $5.

The hearing before the Maritime Commission involving charges that two of the largest of the Japanese shipping lines are engaged in unfair trade practices, which threatened chaos in the Pacific Coast - East Coast of South America trade, came to an unexpected end today.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

Business in the Pittsburgh district fell off a little more last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. As in the preceding week, greaterthan-seasonal decreases in industrial production and in originating freight shipments accounted for the drop.

Many Eastern skiers. are expected to spend Christmas cutting capers on snowy slopes and trails, for, according to reports yesterday, good running is possible at a number of popular resorts. However, for ski centers in the Berkshires, Catskills and Poconos nothing is in the offing, unless the weather man comes to the rescue.

" Address Unknown," a short story by Kressman Taylor that was published originally in the September-October issue of Story Magazine, will be brought out in book form sometime ii January by Simon Schuster.

Oak St, 31, 25.6x70; Antoinette Villano to Sara A. Gulack, 790 Grand Concourse, installments, 6 per cent: $1,000. 70th St, 30 E, 25x100.5; Zareh M. Sourian to Marden Realty Corp, 68 William St, due Jan. 1, 1944, 4 1/2 per cent; $31,000. 81st St, 407 E, 25x102.2; Harry Klein to Central Savings Bank, 5 years, 5 per cent; $13,000.

Mother Joseph, former provincial superior of the Third Order of St. Francis of which Mount St. Francis Convent here is a unit, died there early today of bronchial pneumonia after a week's illness. She was 74 years old.

A man of 25 to 35 years of age, mildmannered and suave, was sought today as the slayer of Margaret Martin, 19 years old, honor graduate of a business college, whose body was found in a grain sack fished from Keelersburg Creek yesterday at a desolate spot twelve miles from Tunkhannock.

New Jersey legislative leaders have been writing letters to Santa Claus, and if all their requests were placed end to end the list would be a modest one. "What do you want from Santa Claus?" was the question asked several of their number. Even Governor A. Harry Moore revealed his preference. Here are some answers:

A plan for the reorganization of the Hudson River Navigation Corporation, which formerly operated the night line to Albany, was filed yesterday with Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard in behalf of the corporation.

Putting the question of confidence three times during debate on the budget and decree laws, Premier Edouard Daladier saw his majority increase from a record low of seven yesterday morning to fifty-seven and then finally to 137 in the last vote, taken after 1 o'clock this morning.

Merchandise licensed by the World's Fair went on display yesterday in a room on the second floor of the Press and Promotion Building. Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair corporation, presided at a formal ceremony marking the opening of the room.

With its entrance guarded by two jovial papier-mache Santa Clauses, the roof garden of the Pierre was the setting last night for Miss Barbara Carleton Baker's introduction to society at a supper dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Newcombe Chandler Baker of Rumson, N. J.
A Purdue rally which netted eight points in the last three minutes of play came too late and Southern California defeated the Big Ten basketball title defenders,- 35 to 30, before 6,000 fans tonight.

New regulations affecting the sabbatical leaves of New York City's 40,000 teachers and supervisors have been approved by the Board of Education's law committee, James Marshall, president of the board, announced yesterday.

The Federal Trade Commission stated today that it had served the General Baking Company, New York City, with a complaint charging that it sells a 20-ounce loaf of bread for 10 cents in Quantico, Va., and for only 8 cents farther away, at Fredericksburg, Va.

The sage Deputy Mayor, Henry H. Curran, who prefers to do his fighting by mail, made another try yesterday to win a decision over his much younger but less experienced adversary, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx.
Miss Elizabeth Gardner Berger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Spencer Berger, was presented to society by her parents tonight at a reception and dance in the New Haven Lawn Club.

Marshall College of West Virginia registered its fourth basketball victory of the season by conquering John Marshall College of Jersey City tonight, 40--28. Jack Morlock scored 12 points to lead the victors, who trailed at half time, 13 to 12.

Silvio Giolito of New York University once again proved his great ability with the sword when he survived three grueling rounds to win the New York Athletic Club annual intercollegiate fencing tournament last night.
The Deutsche Volkswirtschaft, economic weekly, declared today that "German foreign trade can look forward to future development in Latin America with confidence."

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is of royal descent, standing nineteen generations removed from King Edward I, according to Anthony R. Wagner, Portcullis Pursuivant of Arms of the College of Heralds.

Ten days after a delegation of unionized artists, actors, musicians and writers had won a stay of any lay-offs on the five WPA Federal Arts Projects in this city, WPA executives in Washington renewed yesterday their order that 1,500 workers be dropped from the arts projects here. The cut, originally

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, played Santa Claus yesterday in her offices in the Woolworth Building. Her face wreathed in smiles,' she distributed more than $15,000 in back-wages to workers whom the NLRB had found discharged for union activities and ordered reinstated in their old jobs.
" The Declaration of Lima," over which there has been much discord, was announced "prematurely" by the president of the Pan-American Conference last night, but the announcement produced a new snarl.

A reliable source disclosed today that several bank employees and Japanese business men had been subpoenaed by Roger Kent, Federal Securities and Exchange Commission attorney, in his investigation of alleged plans to sell unregistered Japanese emergency bonds in Hawaii.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania is due today from Southampton via Cherbourg. Passengers include United States Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland and Mrs. Tydings, Pearl Buck, winner of the Nobel Prize this year;

The suicide note written by F. Donald Coster last Friday and made public by his attorney yesterday charges "some" directors of McKesson Robbins, Inc., with "knowledge" that he had inflated the drug corporation's assets during the last eight years by $18,000,000.

If Harry L. Hopkins is appointed Secretary of Commerce, as political observers forecast, he will face the problem of overcoming popular prejudice against him which has accumulated during.. his years of handling one of the toughest jobs of the New Deal-unemployment relief.

The American Bar Association filed with the Federal Third District Court of Appeals in Philadelphia yesterday a brief condemning Mayor Frank Hague and Jersey City for denial of the right of assembly, while in Trenton the State Supreme Court upheld

About fifty members of an unemployed workers' movement, including three women, walked into the grill room of the Ritz Hotel in Piccadilly today and asked to have tea served, saying that they Were willing to pay. They were told that they could not be served and the police were called.

One of the horrible ironies of today's situation is that there is an enormous world surplus of food simultaneously with widespread and unsatisfied hunger. Readers of this page may recall the recent statement that the world carry-over of wheat, as of next July, is estimated at 1,165,000,000 bushels.

The death of Philip W. Clarkson, senior clerk in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn, who fell or jumped under a subway train Wednesday night, will not hamper two separate investigations which have been quietly in progress in the court for the past five weeks, it was indicated yesterday.

The commission of Harry L. Hopkins as Secretary of Commerce has actually been executed at the State Department and awaits only formal presentation and announcement, it was learned on good authority today. The resignation of Secretary Roper becomes effective tomorrow.

One-family dwellings in the Bronx were sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation as follows: 2,443 Morris Avenue, near Fordham Road; 359 West 262d Street, in the Riverdale section, and 3,143 Sedgwick Avenue. Edward A. Kelly, Inc., was the broker.

" Tosca" returned to the repertory at the Metropolitan Opera House last night after an absence of more than two years. puccini's sure-fire thriller was last attempted in March, 1936. Evidently it had been missed." The week before Christmas is a poor one for the opera house as well as the theatre, but there was a large assemblage last night for "Tosca." Not least in this audience were the hundreds of standees.

Rufus Oliver, special investigator for the District Attorney's office of Corpus Christi, Texas, and who was also employed as house detective at the Nueces Hotel in that city, and eighteen others were named defendants in an indictment opened yesterday charging mail fraud.

Johnny Mize, hard-clouting first baseman of the Cardinals, and his renowned team-mate, Joe Medwick, carried off the. major slugging honors in the National League for 1938, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Lewis Bloom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Bloom of 255. West End Avenue, to D. Harold Levin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Levin of 1 West Eighty-first Street, took place last evening at the Hotel Esplanade, 305 West End Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Edward Lissman of the Riverside Plaza Synagogue.

Amused at the behavior of members of the City Council in their famous all-night session last Tuesday, the members of the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to offer phonograph records of the session for public sale after Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx ...
The Netherlands abandoned the principle of free trade today when after a sharp debate the upper house by a majority of four approved the government Tariff Bill adopted in the lower house a month ago.

The Narodni Politika reports Polish troops have been withdrawn from the Teschen district and sent to the Ukraine and Gdynia. According to this paper, the army order issued to these troops reads: "Soldiers! The Polish fatherland in the east is in danger. Enemy forces are working to break up the Ukraine.

Senator Adams of Colorado, chairman of the subcommittee which handles relief appropriations, estimated today that $700,000,000 would be needed to keep the Works Progress Administration running from February, 1939, to the end of the fiscal year June 30.
Acting Secretary of State Welles took the proper course and the only course available in the circumstances when he rejected a German demand for an official apology by our Government.

President Roosevelt in person will outline his legislative program to Congress at a joint session to be held in the House at 1 P. M. on Jan. 4. Preliminary arrangements were made by the President and Speaker Bankhead today at a conference in which the prospects for the session were discussed in detail.
A comprehensive report on the railroad situation will be given to President Roosevelt this week-end to form the basis of recommendations he is expected to make to Congress.

Herman Oliphant, general counsel of the Treasury Department, suffered a severe heart attack at his apartment here at about 2:30 o'clock this morning and shortly afterward was taken to Naval Hospital where it was said tonight that he was resting quietly.
Foreign health authorities announced tonight that smallpox had reached epidemic proportions in the Shanghai district. Some said that the city was facing its worst health emergency since 1874.

John J. McManus, former Corporation Counsel and an expert in real estate law and tax matters, died last night after a long illness. He was 65. Mr. McManus was prominent in Republican politics under the regime of William Barnes.
Captain Isaac R. Tracy, a pilot on the Delaware River for fifty years, died here yesterday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Walter C. Fullmer after a long illness. He was 78 years old.
A group of scientists led by Captain Ritscher left here today aboard the motorship Schwabenland for an Antarctic expedition, it was announced. today.

The heaviest holiday air travel in the history of the New York office was predicted yesterday for the Christmas week-end by C. R. Speers, district sales manager of American Airlines. All flights were sold out yesterday and several extra sections were flown to accommodate excess passengers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Jan. 24 at its offices in New York to determine whether the registration of Robert E. Lancaster and Robert E. Lancaster Co., Inc., 110 East Forty-second Street, New York, as broker-dealer in the over-the-counter market should be suspended or revoked.
Eastern football stars, twenty-two of the outstanding college players from beyond the Mississippi, arrived today for the East-West charity game Jan. 2.
A comprehensive sports review of 1938, including illustrated articles covering fifty-nine sports and a list of approximately 800 of the year's champions, will appear in THE NEW YORK TIMES Sunday.

With the authorities in both Loyalist and Rebel Spain claiming to have discovered networks of espionage, hundreds of arrests are taking place. With Generalissimo Francisco Franco's much-heralded offensive still hanging fire, any public impatience that may be due to military inactivity has now been offset by the discovery of a spy ring in Rebel Spain and the mystery of a British consular bag in which
Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Foster Carey have come from Tuxedo Park to the Weylin. Viscountess Castlerosse of London, who arrived on the Normandie, is at the Ambassador before going to Palm Beach.
Dr. Vizetelly's inexhaustible industry and curiosity were always a wonder. They are expressed only partially in the amazing number of publications of which he was author or editor.

A court decision of wide interest in realty circles has just been rendered by Supreme Court Justice Charles V. McLaughlin, reducing slightly the assessed valuations on the Beresford Apartments, Central Park West, from. Eighty-first to Eighty-second Street, for the tax years 1932 and 1933.

Former Mayor William Hale (Big Bill). Thompson turned over $72,749.79 to the American Red Cross today ending a seven-year legal battle over the money he collected in 1927 for the relief of suffers in the Mississippi flood.

New York led all States in the production of sparkling wines during the 1938 fiscal year, reports compiled by the Treasury showed today. New York State production was 3,892,974 half-pint units. California was second with a production of 1,582,676 half-pint units. New York,

Dr. Edith Summerskill, Labor member of the British House of Commons, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie for a lecture tour under the auspices of the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to aid Spanish Democracy. Funds raised on the tour will be used to supply food
A state of emergency in Rangoon was declared tonight as the result of a civil disobedience campaign which is being run with the cry, "Burma for the Burmans."

Henry Wise Mears, funeral director who insisted he had proof that John Wilkes Booth, assassin of Abraham Lincoln, was buried in Greemount Cemetery here, died today. He would have been 91 years old on Christmas Day.

Two army fliers, whose plane, a witness said, "just kept coming straight down" in a "terrific" dive, were killed on the outskirts of Norfolk today when their two-seat pursuit craft crashed, broke into fragments and burned.

Elmer F. Andrews, administrator of the Wages and Hours Division of the Labor Department, stated today that he was considering- the provision of the law on overtime pay so far as it relates to permanent and

Directors of the Consolidated Edison Company were freed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente of charges of wasting corporate assets through the employment of underwriters to market security issues instead of having the company sell them directly.

The future of Memel as Chancellor Hitler had it in mind at the time of the September crisis was disclosed today by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, who was asked in the House of Commons by Geoffrey Mander, Liberal, whether he had received any assurances at Munich that Germany had no territorial ambitions in that direction.

Japan's conditions for peace with China were announced tonight in a statement issued by Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye. The statement embodies the decisions recently approved by the Imperial Conference, the announcement of which was delayed for reasons still unclear. Japan's conditions are:

Following is the United States version of the interview yesterday between Dr. Hans Thomsen, Charge d'Affaires of Germany, and Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State: Dr. Thomsen began the interview by informing Mr. Welles that his government desired to make a formal protest with regard to the address of Secretary Ickes.
The tomb of Napoleon and the French War Museum were threatened tonight by a fire that broke out in the Hotel des Invalides shortly before 11 o'clock. e 11 o'clock.

Juan Antonio Castro, commander of the Spanish Government destroyer Jose Luis Diez, now lying in Gibraltar harbor for repairs, was fined o25 with the alternative of six relief weeks in jail today for operating a wireless station without a license. Two other Spaniards attached to the consulate in Gibraltar received the same sentences.
Dartmouth's basketball team found the mile-high altitude a stimulant and scored the first victory of its cross-country junket tonight, a 56-42 decision over Denver of the Big Seven conference.

Thomas Mann, exiled German author, has been elected an honorary corresponding member -of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president.
Mrs. Annie Florence Handy Cross, mother of Mrs. Henry T. Kilburn of North Maple Avenue, died last night at the Kilburn home at the age of 63. rn in Brooklyn, the

Announcement has been made by Mrs. R. H. Wakefield of Detroit of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Louise R. Fulton, to Silas Burling Weeks of Cooperstown, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Weeks of East Williston, L. I.

The United Hospital Campaign Committee announced yesterday the receipt of gifts of $3,000 from Bernard M. Baruch and $2,500 from the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation. Gifts of $1,000 each were reported from the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, William Ziegler Jr., William R. Coe and an anonymous donor.
In an overtime battle the Brooklyn College Evening quintet defeated the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy last night, 49 to 43, on the losers' floor.

Every year at this time inquiries begin pouring in on the matter of Southern fishing: where to go, whom to contact, what to expect and how much. Some inquiries concern specific fishing areas; others want general information.

Discussion of effective operation of social security laws will feature meetings of store controllers at the twenty-eighth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania during the week of Jan. 16.

Wagner's "Tannhaeuser" received its second performance of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, where it was given a special non-subscription presentation under the auspices of the Girl Scouts Federation of Greater New York, Inc., before an enthusiastic capacity audience.
A three-judge Federal court upheld today the Treasury's authority to demand that whisky labeled "Scotch" be all Scotch-made. The court refused a request from William Jameson Co., Inc., New York,

The fish industry can be revived from its "moribund" condition and put on a profitable basis if retailers will cooperate in persuading consumers to purchase through the week instead of confining the demand to Fridays, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, declared yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was interested in a letter by Paul Starrett of Greenwich, Conn., which appeared on your editorial page of Dec. 18. Mr. Starrett, like many other persons interested in American agriculture, was impressed by an account in the current issue of the "Readers' Digest" of the method used by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in handling the farms it has taken over through foreclosure.

A small Christmas tea dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Weicker yesterday at their home, 1,115 Fifth Avenue, for their nieces and nephew, Miss Winthrop B. Palmer, Miss Rosalind Palmer and Lowell M. Palmer 2d, daughters and son of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton H. Palmer.

Further increase in production of 1939 Lincoln-Zephyr motor cars, bringing the total to 750 units weekly, was ordered yesterday in Detroit, it was announced at the offices of the Lincoln Motor Company.

Appointments to chairmanships of the thirty-three committees entrusted with handling the vast detail work of the Amateur Athletic Union for the coming year were announced yesterday by President Samuel E. Hoyt. Eight changes have been made, two of them taking place previously this year.

For the first time in the history of' the Fire Department a father and son will hold the same rank of deputy chief under a series of seventy-two promotions that Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott will make at 11 o'clock this morning.
Germany has obtained new influences in Czecho-Slovakia through a radio agreement reached during Czecho-Slovak-German cultural negotiations.

The Music Hall rolled in its Yule log yesterday, tossed it on the fire and permitted us to bask a while before its radiant glow. "A Christmas Carol," Metro's film of Dickens's beloved fable, is the season's most delightful gift.
Mr. and Mrs. William Kent Dupre gave a supper last night at their home, 180 East Seventy-ninth Street, for their son, Thomas K. Dupre, who is home from Phillips Exeter for the holidays.
Lumber production declined less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index rose to 75.9. The figure was 72.7 for the preceding week and 54.4 for the week ended Dec. 18, 1937.

An automobile thief made off with a railroad executive's town car on West 231st Street at 9:20 o'clock last night. Ten minutes later the thief, and two accomplices in another machine, had drawn the pursuit of two patrolmen in a police radio car.

A serious threat to radio broadcasting for advertising purposes, through a sharp increase in talent costs is contained in the latest wage proposals advanced by the American Federation of Radio Artists to the Advertising Agency Conference Committee. C. J. LaRoche,
Nine hundred and thirty-four passengers arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie from Havre.

Through its special Committee on the Bill of Rights the American Bar Association came into court yesterday to plead the case of the labor organizations the American Civil Liberties Union and six designated individuals who contest Mayor Hague's denial of free speech and free assembly in Jersey City.
The Neediest Cases Fund received $12,875.37 yesterday from 583 contributors, whose joint efforts brought its total for the twenty-seventh annual appeal to $191,764.41.

James H. Morrell was elected treasurer of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors. Mr. Morrell, who was assistant controller, succeeds W. Paxton Little, who has retired.

Woburn, a manufacturing community of about 20,000 population, today was indicted -by the Middlesex County grand jury for failure to provide sufficient money to pay school salaries. Under a law enacted many years ago the city, if convicted, would be liable to a fine of about $700,000,

Stockholders of the Dow Chemical Company this afternoon approved a merger with the Great Western Electro-Chemical Company of San Francisco. Ames T. Pardee, chairman of the board, who presided at the meeting, said 792.000 of the 940,000 shares of

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Ann Gibson of Princeton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Perlee Gibson of Lamont, Mich., to Donald Harvard Morrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis F. Morrison of Morgantown, W. Va., took place this afternoon in the Marquand transept of the Princeton University chapel.
Karl Allen Drummond, 21, former aircraft plant employee, was convicted on two counts of espionage in Federal court tonight and-will be sentenced tomorrow by Judge Leon Yankwich.

French prohibition of the transport of war supplies to China by way of the Indo-China frontier has dashed hopes that the through the French colony as the major channels for the import of war materials. That route would replace railway, river and highway
The Western Long Island Sound Fleet of the International Star Class sliced off some of the area over which it has jurisdiction at the annual meeting last night at the Williams Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Preston Gaylord of Lincoln, Neb., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Esther Gaylord of New York, to Harry Whitfield Howze, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Howze of Texarkana, Texas.

The Southern Natural Gas Company, Birmingham, Ala., has filed a plan of recapitalization under the Holding Company Act asking for a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission and has filed a declaration concerning the solicitation of consents to the plan.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 22 unless specified: At San Diego: Cummings, Wright. At Hong Kong: Mindanao, Tulsa. At San Pedro: Pennsylvania, Sonoma. Davis, Boston to Washington, via Newport Dec. 20. Henderson, at Manila. Kewaydin, Washington to Quantico. Reid, Mare Island, to San Diego.

Charitable organizations receive a total of $289,202 from the estate of Miss Annie Miller, who died on Jan. 3, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. She left a net estate of $353,203, most of which was invested in stocks and bonds.

With a surplus of 26,500,000 francs, the French budget, as approved by the Chamher of Deputies yesterday, was laid before the Senate today. It is hoped it will be disposed of before the end of the year.
The neutrality problem of the Baltic States--Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and Finland--assumes everincreasing importance in consequence of 'Germany's expected moves in Eastern Europe.

A detailed program calling for the expenditure in this city next year of $208,800,688 on WPA construction and white-collar projects and insuring the continued employment of 15,000 relief workers who were to have been dismissed by Jan. 1, was sent to WPA executives in Washington yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.

The upward trend in furniture activity, which has been steady since early Summer, came to a halt in November, when new orders were off 10 per cent from October, although 22 per cent above November, 1937, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, reported yesterday.
Groups such as the Dies committee do more harm than good by driving the middle class toward a form of fascism, according to Professor Jerome G. Kerwin of the University of Chicago.

Employment and payrolls in New York State retail stores increased 1.2 per d cent each from October to November, the Labor Department said today. The increase "followed more substantial advances reported during the previous two months."

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 22: COLONELS Avery, R. L., C. W. S., one month leave, Jan. 1, with permission to visit foreign countries. Arnold, W. R., Chief of Chaplains, four days' leave. Dec. 27.
Robert L. Riggs tops the ranking of the country's lawn tennis players as compiled by J. Donald Budge and announced yesterday.
Prime Minister Vladas Mironas told Parliament today that the government was taking account of Germany's interest in Memel and the fulfilling of German wishes there.

The Minister of Justice in a press statement today undertook to justify the terms of the new Hungarian anti-Semitic law. He pointed out that at the time that the first minor anti-Semitic bill was initiated in Hungary only Germany had instituted an anti-Semitic regime. Since then, he said, Poland,

Tribute to Senator Carter Glass of Virginia as sponsor and defender of the Federal Reserve Act was paid today by President Roosevelt and other officials at ceremonies commemo rating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the signing of the act by President Wilson. A bas-relief of Senator Glass was unveiled in the course of ceremonies at the Federal Reserve Building.

Suicide, not the bullet of a plucky assistant manager with the will to fight back, ended the criminal career of Albert Weiner, 39-year-old ex-convict with a record of eighteen arrests, an autopsy revealed yesterday.

Manor Ave. 1,162, 25x100; United States Life Insurance Co in the City of New York against Victor Loft, et al. due, $9,767; taxes, etc., $430; to plaintiff for 1,000. Crosby Ave, 1,448-50, 25x100; John W. Emmler, et al. trustees, against Anna Mazur. due. $2.641: to plaintiff for 1,000.
Clutching an atomizer and a bottle of nose drops, Coach Bob Neyland announced today he would hurry his Tennessee football team, down to Miami's Orange Bowl a day ahead of schedule.

Frederick C. Brooks of 1,148 Fifth Avenue, New York City, owned a badly damaged Christmas present tonight but considered himself fortunate to have escaped injury with a friend when a giftplane he was piloting collided with two others on landing here this afternoon.
Eddie Gardner, an in-and-out performer owned by C. Goff, had one of his "in" days at the Fair Grounds today and scored an easy victory in the featured sixth race.

The Appellate Division upheld yesterday the validity of the Lyons Residence Law requiring city employes to reside within the city and banning the appointment of any one who has not lived here for three years prior to his selection for a city job.
Two stars of the athletic world-Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, the versatile Beaumont, Texas, girl who skyrocketed to fame in the 1932 Olympics, and George Zaharias, the wrestler, were wed late today.
George Myatt, rookie third baseman of the Giants, had his appendix removed Tuesday, it became known today.

George W. Rogers, 41 years old, hero of the Morro Castle fire, who is under sentence of twelve to twenty years for attempting to kill his superior officer with a home-made bomb while a member of the Bayonne Police Department, obtained a review of his conviction from the State Supreme Court today.

The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, analyzing today American foreign trade during the first nine months of 1938. declared that in this period American exports have suffered "their first major setback" in five years. It added that exports fell 3.5 per cent in value in the period, while imports fell 39.4 per cent.
Southern California's football team resumed practice today to find the means of making the first points against the unbeaten and untied Duke University eleven.

The marriage of Miss Doris Anne Harger, daughter of Mrs. Oscar G. Harger of Maplewood and the late Mr. Harger, to Grant Critchfield Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Critchfield of Summit, took place this evening in the home of the bride's mother. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Nelson Butz, pastor of the Prospect Presbyterian Church.

Miss Ione Allen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Butler Allen of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to John Bancroft 3d, son of John Bancroft Jr. of Wilmington and of Mrs. Hermann Ruoff of Munich, Germany. The ceremony was performed in the Church of St. Martin's-in-the-Fields.

Walter T. Griffiths, president of the National Union of Railwaymen, one of the most powerful labor organizations in the country, fell to his death from a train near Swindon today. He was 54 years old.

Dr. Joseph S. Schofield, 83 years old, of 12 Austin Place, Port Chester, died today in the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital of injuries suffered last night when struck by an automobile in East Port Chester, Conn. Police said Dr. Schofield was walking on Ritch Avenue when a car driven by William Pennela, 19, of Greenwich, struck him. A charge of reckless driving was filed against Mr. Pennela.

Miss Ruth Brown Shurtleff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Flavel Shurtleff of this city, became the bride tonight of Robert, Leland Crowell, son of T. Irving Crowell of Upper Montclair and the late Mrs. Crowell. The ceremony was performed in the Union Congregational Church of Upper Montclair by the pastor, the Rev. George Clark Vincent.

The United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange of the resignation of H. J. Moffett as vice president, of Harry Rubenoff as treasurer and of Wallace Groves as a director.
Henry H. Kohn, Illinois Republican leader and prominent in public life in this State for nearly fifty years, died today at his home here at the age of 77.

Ward's Automotive Reports predicted today that the automobile industry would assemble 1,000,000 cars and trucks in the first quarter of 1939, marking a gain of almost 50 per cent over the comparable 1938 period.
Attorneys for Yale University filed a petition in Circuit Court today intervening in litigation over the $2,000,000 estate of Hazlett Kyle Campbell, aged recluse who died here last March.

Henry Goddard Leach, editor or Forum Magazine and chairman of the American Scandinavian Foundation, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after spending three weeks in Denmark, Norway and Sweden arranging for the exchange of advanced students of engineering and banking.

Robert Herrick, government secretary of the Virgin Islands, died today in Charlotte Amalie as the result of a heart attack suffered five days ago, according to advices reaching here. Mr. Herrick, who was 70 years old, had been in ill health for several months.

In a holiday setting of green, silver and gold Miss Mary Jane Cuddihy was introduced at a dinner dance last night given for her by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy of this city and Southampton, L. I., in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's.
A brief funeral service for Dr. Frank H. Vizetelly, lexicographer and editor of the Standard Dictionary, was held last night in the Cooke Funeral Chapel, 1 West 190th Street, in the Bronx.

State-wide protest over the pardon granted Wednesday by Governor Hurley and his executive council to Raymond Partriarca, gunman, who had served only 126 days of a long-term sentence for armed robbery, was followed today by a demand by Representative Roland D. Sawyer, veteran Democratic member of the Legislature, for an investigation of the activities of the Governor and his council since the September primaries.

The Bronx Playgrounds Operetta and Orchestral Clubs, a group of ninety talented children trained by the recreational directors of the city Parks Department since last Spring, will present Gilbert and Sullivan's "Pirates of Pebnzance" next Wednesday night at the Museum of Natural History.

Mrs. Margaret O'Donovan Olcott of this city and Saratoga Springs, N. Y., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Martin O'Donovan and widow of Chauncey Olcott, the tenor, was married yesterday afternoon to Ralph Stuyvesant-Brown, a descendant of Peter Stuyvesant,

Engagements of $1,461,000 of gold abroad for shipment here-$1,111,000 in The Netherlands and $350,000 in England-were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Further, there were reported imports of $11,853,000 of the metal, of which $9,793,000 came from England, $1,756,000, Holland, and $304,000, India.
Calling suggestions for a relief appropriation of $1,000,000,000 "simply shocking," Senator Glass of Virginia, urged today that the relief problem be turned back to the States and cities.

On the morning before announcement was made of the appointment of Harry L. Hopkins as Secretary of Commerce, the American Institute of Public Opinion published the results of a survey showing that two-thirds of the voters questioned who expressed an opinion did not approve his nomination for that office.

Wheat reflected a firm undertone from the start of trading today. Failure of expected rain or snow to fall in the Southwest, buying of futures, which brokers believed represented the removal of hedges against sales to the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation and strength in Liverpool induced professional operators on the Board of Trade here to take a less bearish view of the situation.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 17 amounted to 606,314 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 21: COMMANDERS Chambers, I. R., the Winslow, to instruction, Naval War College, Newport. R. I., in May or June. Reinecke, F. G., the Capello, to continue treatment. Norfolk Naval Hospital. Portsmouth, Va. Shoemaker, J. M.. Paris, France, to Naval Operations. Washington. D. C., Jan. 20.

With chess players from Pennsylvania and Cornell in town for the holidays, Columbia, for a long time champion of the old C. H. Y. P. league, took part in two matches to inaugurate the activities of the informal Triangular College Chess League at John Jay Hall yesterday.

Miss Jamye Martin, daughter of Mrs. James Nelson Martin of Sanford, N. C., and the late Mr. Martin, was married to Joel Castleberry Layton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel G. Layton of Lillington, N. C., here yesterday at noon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

The hearing on an application to have Kenneth F. Sutherland, chief clerk of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, committed to jail for refusal to answer questions asked of him by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, was at Mr. Sutherland's request postponed yesterday until next Friday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin.
Bishop William T. Manning issued yesterday a Christmas message to the clergy and lay people of the Episcopal Diocese of New York. The message,
Mrs. Susy Ganson Dillingham, for many years a welfare and church worker in New York, died yesterday at her home, 500 West End Avenue.

The announcement of the findings by the Presidential board appointed to investigate railroad conditions met with favor in railroad circles. Virtually all the recommendations made in the report had been suggested at one time or another by well-wishers of the railroads.

Centralization of regulation for all forms of transportation under the Interstate Commerce Commission and a proposed new Transportation Board was recommended today by President Roosevelt's special committee of railroad management and labor executives.

Explosion of a high pressure oil line as technicians prepared to test a seaplane catapult on the aircraft carrier Enterprise injured ten men today, one seriously, and hurled an eleventh from the deck into the water at Norfolk Navy Yard.

Praising the work done by the Congressional committee investigating un-American activities, headed by Representative Martin Dies, the board of managers of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York will urge Congress to continue the committee and to appropriate the necessary funds to carry on the work.

An interesting transformation has just taken place in the ninety-yearold house at 28 Bank Street, one of a row of Greenwich Village "country homes" dating back to 1849. The owners in this block are proud of their private dwellings, and not long ago they formed the Bank Street Association to aid in preserving the charm of the neighborhood,

Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland, who arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania after a holiday visit with United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies in Belgium, believes war in Europe is quite possible in the next year or two.
With his mission a complete success, John Buchanan, Chile's "Ambassador on Skis" to the United States, sailed for his homeland yesterday aboard the Grace liner Santa Barbara.

Mexico's budget for 1939 includes 10,000,000 pesos for the payment of indemnities for both American and Mexican-owned lands that have been expropriated. The budget, based on estimated income of 445,000,000 pesos and passed by the Chamber of Deputies with proposed expenditures of that amount, is the highest in Mexico's history.

The 51-year old American Trotting Association, Secretary C. H. Perry said today, is opposed unalterably -to any merger of harness racing groups which fails to give the West, where the American Association has 273 members in more than ten States, "equal representation with the East. "

Department store sales for the week ended on Dec. 17 were 2 per cent more than for the corresponding period last year, but were 1 per cent lower for the four weeks ended Dec. 17 than for the similar period in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
Shipments of tires by manufacturers in the United States in November were 4,442,296 units, the largest for any month since August, 1937, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association, Inc.
An excited young woman called the postoffice and asked for the return of a letter she hal mailed to a charitable organization.
On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight. PATROLMAN Michael H. Crowley. 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 23, 1903.

City College's fast and-clever basketball team routed McGill University of Montreal, 43 to 28, last night in the C. C. N. I. gymnasium. It was the fourth meeting between the rivals. The aggressive Beavers, with better passing and presenting an efficient defense which forced the visitors to resort to long-range shooting, led most of the way as they kept City's record in the McGill series unblemished.

Four persons-possibly seven or eight-were killed tonight in the crash of a twin-motored army bomber two and a half miles southeast of here. A terrific explosion, apparently before the plummeting plane struck the earth in a rainstorm, scattered wreckage over a 100-yard area.

Bids for approximately $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills, to be dated Dec. 28 and to mature on March 29, 1939, were opened today at Federal Reserve Banks, the Treasury announced. Of $507,427,000 applied for, $101,032,000 was accepted.

After fleeing safely with other tenants from a blazing three-story apartment house at 10 Cambridge Avenue here this afternoon, Mrs. Selina Crockett rushed back into the building to get a photograph of her late husband and was burned to death.

For the third time in two months the New York City school system has a good job that is going begging. Never before, officials said, has the department experienced such difficulty in filling high-salaried administrative posts.

An accounting in the estate of Captain Joseph Raphael De Lamar, capitalist, mine owner and sportsman, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, disclosed that the president and fellows of Harvard University and the trustees of Columbia and Johns Hopkins Universities on April 12, 1921, made an absolute assignment of their remainder interests in a $10,000,000 trust fund to Miss Alice-A. De Lamar, daughter of the decedent.

Attorneys for Mrs. Mathilda R. Wilson filed an answer today to Mrs. Annie Laurine Dodge's request that the Oakland County Probate Court reopen the final accounting of Mrs. Wilson's guardianship over her son, Daniel Dodge, who was drowned last Summer in Georgian Bay shortly after his marriage.

The great Insurgent offensive on the Segre River began at dawn today when batteries all along the lines from Serros north of Tremp opened up against Republican positions. Italians are taking part in this offensive.

Within the minster tower there's holiday Among the bells. Ring out! Ring out! The throng Takes up their tune, and long-forgotten May Upon her sunny slope recalls no song As lovely as this hymn of Christmas Town.

Police raided a Riviera bar in Villefranche late last night and broke up a gambling game patronized entirely by United States sailors on shore leave. Sixty to seventy sailors were arrested as they scattered through the various doors and windows of the establishment, but all were later released.

Leases of business quarters over a wide area were announced yesterday by brokers. Unity Motors, Inc., leased from J. H. Riker the entire two-story building at 160 West Eighteenth Street through the Duross Company, broker.

President Roosevelt will broadcast his Christmas greetings to the country at the lighting of a national community Christmas tree between 5 and 5:30 P. M., Eastern standard time, tomorrow in Lafayette Square.
" Everywhere I Roam" has decided to set back its premiere from next Monday to Thursday at the National. It is understood additional polishing is necessary on the script.

New bond financing this week dropped to a total of $36,884,000, compared with $55,039,850 in new issues marketed last week, but showed a substantial increase over the corresponding period of last year when only $3,030,000 in bonds were offered.

Miss Martha Stephenson, daughter of Mrs. Paul Forester of 320 East Fifty-seventh Street and a debutante of last season, will be married next month to Hal Kemp, dance orchestra leader, it was announced yesterday by the prospective bride's mother.

President Roosevelt today appointed Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator and one of his close political confidants, to the Cabinet rank of Secretary of Commerce. He succeeds Daniel C. Roper, whose resignation became effective at midnight tonight.
The Weather Bureau yesterday issued the following week-end forecast for Winter sports areas in the East:

It was indicated this afternoon that among the radical measures contemplated by the Popular Front government, that will be inaugurated tomorrow under the presidency of Pedro Aguirre, was the creation of a new Ministry of National Economy.

Mayor La Guardia received an American flag from the Lieutenant Quentin Roosevelt Post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars at City Hall yesterday, and later in the day received a gift of plants from a children's class at the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens.
An evening of American Negro music shook the stage, the rafters and the audience at Carnegie Hall last night. It had a little of everything-and a lot of swing.

Except for the arrival of the University of Minnesota's squad this morning for its game with New York University at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night, in the nightcap of a double-header that also will bring together Illinois and Manhattan, a Christmas Eve lull prevails over the metropolitan basketball front today.

Mild weather dampened Christmas sales in Canada, according to a review by the Bank of Montreal "Late reports; however," the review continued, "show a brisker note, and it is now hoped that the season's trade,

The Cinderella Dance was held last night at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn for young women who will make their debuts in forthcoming seasons. The event was founded more than twenty-five years ago by Mrs. James Guthrie Shaw and is the oldest dance to be given consecutively in Brooklyn.

The Attorney General's offices will soon be transferred to some other government building because of the Supreme Court's decision to return its present quarters to the Estate Mier y Pesado, a foundation for private charity.

Mrs. Charlotte Elliott De Angelis, former actress and widow of Jefferson De Angelis, famous comedian, died Thursday night at her home, 42 West Fifty-second Street, after a long illness. She was 43 years old.

The 1938 American Hebrew Medal has been awarded to President Roosevelt for outstanding service in promoting better understanding between Christians and Jews, according to an announcement by Joseph H. Biben, editor and publisher of The American Hebrew.

Strength in several groups of secondary railroad issues was the feature of more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Dealings in the corporate list were on an unusually active scale for a pre-holiday session with the turnover reaching $10,485,00, the largest since Dec. 15, last, and compared with sales of $9,391,100 on Thursday.
Fifteen unemployed men stood fast against police reinforcements at the gate of Buckingham Palace today and presented a petition for Winter relief to an aide of King George.

73d St. 115 E; Francis J. Wazeter, referee, to United States Trust Co, foreclosure (%90). 122d St, 132 W; Harold Nurse to violet A. Nurse, 132 W 122d St; mtg, $8,650 ($2.45). West End Av, 625; Gael Holding Corp to George F. Bauerdorf, 290 Park Ave; mtg, $343.000 ($1). 128th St, 213 W; Alixe L. Gough, executrix of Frances S. Quinn, to Alixe L. Gough, Drewville Rd, Brewster, N.Y.; mtg, $2,200 (50c).

Petition to Reorganize 1924 REALTY CORP., 58 E. Mt. Eden Ave.--Involuntary proceeding under Chapter X of the Chandler Act by estate of David Dows, Susan Dows Herter Dakin and Norma B. Kastl, holders of mortgage certificates aggregating $70,000. The petition states foreclosure proceedings are pending against the principal asset of the corporation, an apartment house situated at 10 W. 86th St., valued at about $500,000. Encumbrances include outstanding certificates and unpaid interest amounting to $484,200.

75th St, 7 E, 5-story dwelling, 30x102.2; Bank for Savings in the City of New York against James W. Barney et al.; due, $106,219; taxes, etc., $600; to plaintiff for $50,000. By WALTER JACOBSEN 1st Ave,-1,114, 5-story tenement, 25x95, Parcel 1: also 1,116 1st Ave. 5-story tenement, 25x95, Parcel 2; Bank for Savings in the City of New York against Iole Muratori; due, $50,843; taxes, etc., $800; to plaintiff for $18,000.
The Grace Church Choir, directed by Dr. Ernest Mitchell, will give a program of Christmas music today at 4:45 P. M. at Wanamaker's.

It would seem, after all these years and all those wartime aviation films, that time and custom should have inured us to the sight and sound of droning planes rising into the morning mist, to hectic dog fights in the clouds, to shots of screaming Nieuports spinning like smoke-tailed comets to the earth, to the reckless cognac drinking and gallant comrade-toasting in the canteen.
A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $1,400,000 of advancement fund bonds of Lake County, Ind., on a bid of 100.654 for 21/2s.
After another advance into the highest ground this month, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday reflected the effects of week-end profit-taking and ended unchanged to a loss of 3 points.

Pierre Blanchet entertained with a Christmas tea yesterday afternoon in his apartment at the. Weylin. Among his guests were his brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Lee Blanchet; Mrs. Sterling Hammond, Mrs. Torlonia Lord, Mrs. Curtis Wagstaff, Mrs. Frederick C. Havemeyer and Mr. and Mrs. Jorge R. Andre Jr.

Cotton-mill activity broadened more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 126.6 from 125.6, the revised figure for the preceding week. For the week ended Dec. 18, 1937, the index stood at 92.1.
James P. Hall, retired engineer and former partner in the engineering firm of Rovegno-Hall Company in Jersey City, died last night at his home here. His age was 86.

' TWAS the night before Christmas when all through the house not a creature was stirring, not even a-well, you get the idea anyway. Santa Claus is on his way with a cheery smile and an overflowing sack to brighten the lives of one and all.
WINDOW SHOPPING, a comedy in three acts, by Louis E. Shecter and Norman ClarK. Staged by Arthur Sircom; settings by Tom Adrian Cracraft; produced by Thomas Kilpatrick. At the Longacre Theatre.

What answer to make to the Italian rejection of the agreement of 1935 and what policy to adopt toward Italy will be discussed by the French cabinet tomorrow following the reception of a note from Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, through Andre Francois - Poncet,

Effective on Jan. 1, Pemberton Berman, Francis R. Pemberton and Thomas L. Perkins will form the New York Stock Exchange firm of Pemberton Berman Co. Edward G. Hubbard Co. became a Stock Exchange member firm on Dec. 22, with Catherine Lamm and Edward G. Hubbard as partners.

Bids were received yesterday for grading and draining another threemile stretch of the Circumferential Parkway, the seventh contract to be let since the Board of Estimate authorized the belt highway on Oct. 13. Work is to being at once,

Promoter Mike Jacobs said today an agreement had been reached for a match in New York in May between the former heavyweight champion, Max Baer, and Lou Nova, Californian who is considered by some as a possible challenger to Joe Louis.

The Art Institute of Chicago has purchased a painting by Barent Fabritius, pupil of Rembrandt, it was announced yesterday by M. Knoedler Co., through whom the sale was made. The work shows Eli and Samuel.

ANTONIADES, COSTA (June 18, 1938). Gross assets, $19,101; net. $8,515. To wife, Nellie Antoniades. Jewelry, household furnishings, automobile and life income from residuary estate; daughters. Eleanor and Bertha Antoniades, one-half remainder interest each in residuary estate.
