Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $4,966; jointly owned property, $10,700; miscellaneous property, $3.434. Raymond J. McGrover, attorney, 2.6850 Atlantic Ave.

More than 7,000 instrumentalists and vocalists on the rolls of the Federal Music Project and thousands of children and adults trained in the project's classes will participate today in twilight Christmas carol festivals throughout the United States.
Poland protested vigorously to Czecho-Slovakia today against alleged military activities along the Polish border and anti-Polish propaganda radio broadcasts from Prague.

Post time for the first race at Tropical Park on Jan. 2 will be 10:15 A. M., Racing Secretary R. S. Shelley announced today. This will enable the racing patrons and visiting football fans to get to the Orange Bowl in time for the game between Tennessee and Oklahoma.

The city's highest transportation officials, exports in subway construction and others well known in engineering circles were among 1,200 persons who attended a funeral service yesterday morning for Robert Ridgway, retired chief engineer of the Board of Transportation, in the Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Crowds in the financial district on their way to work early yesterday morning were frightened by an explosion in a transformer atop a setback on the twenty-first floor of the fifty-story Irving Trust Company Building at 1 Wall Street.

Dressed alike in gowns of wine trimmed with gold, the Pierrettes, a group of young women from prominent Newark families, received tonight at their seventh annual charity subscription dance at Essex County Country Club here. Parents of members served as patrons.
William F. Granger, veteran stage and screen actor who appeared in the Broadway stage play "Lightnin'," died here today. His age was 84.

United States diplomatic ties with Latin America were further strengthened today when President Roosevelt elevated the American Legation in Venezuela to an embassy. Venezuela also will open an embassy here.

Mrs. H. T. Welty, secretary of the City Manager League of Yonkers, announced today that suit would be filed in the State Supreme Court to compel a Yonkers newspaper to reveal who ordered and paid for advertisements opposing the city-manager form of government in the recent referendum on the proposition, which was won by proponents of the city-manager plan.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is a moderate movement in wool on Summer Street, at prices which are steadily maintained on the basis established last week-end.

Herbert E. Pickett, Yale, '39, of Roland Park, Md., has. won the Thomas F. Curtin Jr. memorial scholarship, which is awarded each year to that senior in Yale College who most nearly approaches the combined standards of good scholarship and athletic -proficiency which Thomas F. Curtin, '36, exemplified.

With carillons and chimes playing carols and bells peeling joyous notes the celebration of Christmas will begin today at noon and continue through tomorrow. The first Yuletide services will be at 12 o'clock today for those in the financial area at old Trinity Church.

An investment purchase for cash of two apartment houses. in the Bronx was announced yesterday by the Eugene J. Busher Company, broker in the deal. The buildings were sold by the I. T. C. Corporation of 30 Broad Street, Manhattan, to the Gerosa Paladino Holding Corporation of 286 East 137th Street, the Bronx.

CHESTERTONIANS will find the garland of his fugitive nonsense rhymes, tales and drawings called "The Colored Lands"* rather like a one-man edition of Mr. Punch's Christmas annual. Some of these things were done when he was very young. Some were for various friends.

Mrs. Fanny Graubard, wife of Morris Graubard, State Assemblyman, 1907-12, and New York City Alderman, 1912-19, died at her home here today, after a long illness, at the age of 67. She and her husband celebrated their golden wedding anniversary last September.
A comprehensive sports review of 1938, including illustrated artides covering fifty-nine sports and a list of approximately 800 of the year's champions, will appear in THE NEW YORK TIMES tomorrow.

Joseph Fishbach of St. John's University defeated Nathan Goldstein of Brooklyn College, 6-2, 6-1, 6-1, yesterday to retain his metropolitan junior indoor tennis singles title at the 102d Engineers Armory.

National Socialist party organs are making much of the news that the 1938 American Hebrew Medal for outstanding service in promoting better understanding between Christians and Jews has been awarded to President Roosevelt.

Duplicating in many respects the experience Loyalist Spain has had with war supplies from France, China's efforts to obtain military equipment by way of Indo-China have been an unhappy series of broken promises.

The Republican party apparently won the right today to 'organize the State Senate, as well as the House of Representatives, by a ruling of the Supreme Court, under which Dr. P. J. Henney, a Democratic Senator, of McKee's Rocks, said he would resign to retain his post of coroner of Allegheny County.

The indications are for occasional rain with rising temperatures today and generally fair weather with moderate temperatures tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

A large taxpayer property in Forest Hills and one of the few remaining Queens truck farms, consisting of about forty-three acres in Bayside, changed hands in the Long Island realty deals reported yesterday.
The Commodity Exchange Commission issued an order today placing limits on speculative trading in grain in the nation's futures contracts markets.
Pope Pius will leave the Vatican for a long sojourn at Castel Gandolfo on or about Jan. 15, it was learned from authoritative Vatican sources today.

McClellan St, n e cor of Gerard Ave, 100x94; 6-story tenement; Morris Marcus, 35 Van Cortlandt Ave, owner; H. H. Lilien, architect; cost, $225,000. 262d St, s s, 21 ft e of Tyndall Ave, 21x30; 2-story dwelling and garage; John J. Kennedy, 5,816 Mosholu Ave, owner and ar-chitect; cost, $5,000.
The appointment of William A. Hollingsworth as sales manager for Dunhill cigarettes for the entire country was announced yesterday by Dunhill, International. The appointment is effective Jan. 1.

Nine sororities at Hunter College are celebrating the Christmas holidays with parties and dances. Alpha Epsilon Phi will hold its annual Winter dance tonight in the grill of the Hotel Roosevelt, with Rita Burger as dance chairman.

Michael Press, Russian concert violinist, conductor, teacher and composer, died in a hospital here fast night following a heart attack. His age was 67. He had been connected with the Michigan State College Music School for eleven years until his retirement last Spring.
With one day still to go, Christmas trade here on the average is ranging within 2 to 3 per cent of last year's figures for the period from Dec. 1 to 24, merchants estimated yesterday.

The St. Francis College basketball team scored its sixth consecutive victory of the season when it defeated the strong Marshall College quintet of Huntington, W. Va., 45-33, on the Brooklyn team's court last night.
Plans approved this week by several American and Canadian States and municipalities for advertising campaigns indicate that these types of drives will register a substantial upturn in 1939.
The Farley bill, setting June 20 for a referendum on the proposal to legalize pari-mutuel horse-race betting and appropriating $400,000 for the cost of the vote, was signed today by Governor Moore.
Opening a stack of Christmas cards today, Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, came to one that bore several lines of writing. He read: "Want to buy some. bombs this morning?"
Henry Hohorst, who in 1914 founded Henry Hohorst, Inc., a company that operates bus lines on Central and Bergen Avenues, Jersey City, died today of a heart ailment here at his home at the age of 73.

Christmas bonuses of more than $100,000 will be distributed by the Curtiss-Wright Aeroplane Corporation to - employes in Buffalo, Paterson, N. J. and St. Louis, Mo., according to an announcement made yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia won yesterday a part victory in his fight for municipal control over judicial payrolls when the Appellate Division in Manhattan ruled unanimously that Surrogate John C. Boylan of Richmond lacked the power to fill two vacancies on his staff without the approval of the Budget Director.

Herbert Bijur, assistant to the director of publicity at John Wanamaker, New York, has been appointed director of advertising and publicity for Jane Engel, specialty store, succeeding Martin O. Kahn, who has resigned, Miss Engel announced yesterday.

Colonel H. Nelson Jackson received word today that he had been decorated as a commanded of the Equestrian Order of the Crown of Italy. Colonel Jackson, who has been active in American Legion affairs, is president of the Burlington Trust Company, publisher of The Burlington Daily News and owner of radio station WCAX.
Eastern and Western football stars, who will meet in the annual charity game here Jan. 2, got down to business today after a series of receptions, luncheons and sight-seeing trips.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Abraham Blumenthal, son, 165 W. 91st St., $25,000 in trust and Interests in business and residue; Dora Blumenthal, Fannie Blumenthal and Isaac Blumenthal, executor, all of 165 W. 91st St., equal remainders in $25,000 trusts, business and residuary interests.

Harry Maloney, supervisor of the night staff of the classified advertising department of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died yesterday in the Union Hospital, 260 East 188th Street, the Bronx, of a stomach ailment.

A number of decisions taken at today's Cabinet meeting will doubtless be regarded in Germany as a welcome present from CzechoSlovakia. They will scarcely come as a surprise, however, since the decisions were taken as a result of Germany's insistence and CzechoSlovakia's inability to obtain support to resist them.

William E. Darden of New York City, formerly Western manager of General Household Utilities, has been appointed a member of the executive staff of the National Warm Air Heating and Air Conditioning Association, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Darden will have the title of assistant to the president.
Led by John Simmons, who recorded 18 points, Flushing High's basketball team downed Jamaica High, 52 to 40, in a Queens Division P. S. A. L. battle played on the Flushing Y. M. C. A. court yesterday.

Mrs. Josie Philipps, mother of Postmaster Oscar Philipps of Santa Claus, died of double pneumonia last night at her home in Troy, near here. Her age was 75. The postmaster and his brother, Albert, were at her bedside.

A horse owned by B. F. Whitaker, trained by Jack Howard and ridden by Eddie Arcaro, once again stole the spotlight at Tropical Park today. This time it was the 7-yearold gelding, Quasimodo, that turned the trick.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York has granted $2,000 to the American Foundation for the Blind for the compilation of an annotated bibliography of publications covering various aspects of blindnessmedical, vocational, psychological, educational and recreational.
H. S. Wherrett, president of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, said today that the outlook for 1939 was "hopeful" and he expected recent gains to extend well through the year.

James H. Falconer, a member of an old New York family who was long active in welfare and religious work, died on Thursday at the Murray Hill Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Falconer, a native of New York, lived at 45 East Fiftyfifth Street. His age was 72.

The Whitney Museum of American Art will be closed today, Sunday and Monday and will reopen from next Tuesday until Saturday. The museum will be closed on New Year's day and Jan. 2. Thereafter the usual hours will be resumed. The memorial exhibition of William Glackens's work will continue through Jan. 15.

Guy C. Myers of New York told the Federal Power Commission today how, by long months of negotiating, he had persuaded all but one of the private electrical companies in Nebraska to sell their properties to the public power districts.

For the first eleven months of this year the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company estimated yesterday its net income at $3,513,277, after deductions for interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization and Federal income taxes.
Eugene E. Cerf, a member of the New York Curb Exchange, died early today at a ranch near here. His age was 62.

A maintenance crew will be placed aboard F. Donald Coster's oceangoing pleasure yacht Carolita by a United States marshal in compliance with an order signed today by Judge Edwin S. Thomas of the United States District Court In Hartford following the filing of admirality libel papers.
Middletown Rd (18-5394, 5396); s e cor of Edison Ave, 75x91; also Middletown Rd, s e cor of Gillespie Ave, 50x100; I. T. C. Corp to Gerosa Paladino Holding Corp, 286 E 137th St.

Several promotions and appointments were announced yesterday by the Bank of the Manhattan Company and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company. The latter announced that William J. Rahill, formerly a member of the bank's staff but more recently president of the Louisville Trust Company, Louisville, Ky., had been appointed an assistant vice president.

An appreciable increase in the searching of all Chinese by Japanese sentries along the British and French Concession boundaries here is causing a certain amount of bewilderment among foreign authorities, since at the same time other Japanese activities have slackened.

Armed soldiers mounted guard today before the still-smoldering facade of the Hotel des Invalides, which houses military offices, the army museum and Napoleon's tomb, were fiermen had smothered a blaze that threatened France's military plans.
Governor Lloyd C. Stark threw the weight of his Administration tonight into a campaign to eradicate "crime and corruption from Kansas City"-stronghold of his political foe, "Boss" Tom Pendergast.

With Bob Johnson, wingman, making all three goals, the Brooklyn Technical High School ice hockey team remained unbeaten in the race for the city P. S. A. L. title by blanking Andrew Jackson High, 3-0, in one of three contests played at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Each of the following Reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 77th Dlvision-2d Lt. Adolph Baker, Inf.Res., 475 Linden Blvd., Brooklyn, N. Y., 2d Lt. John A. Ruehle, Inf.-Res., 600 W. 169th St., New York, N. Y. 40th Infantry (R.A.I.)-2d Lt. Harry M. Koneke. Inf.-Res., 250 W. 78th St., New York, N. Y.

Prices on the Stock Exchange took a turn for the better today, and with the holiday atmosphere predominant -business was on a fair scale. Gilt-edge securities moved up slightly, but bonds in the foreign section were idle.

William P. Buckner Jr., young promoter who is accused of defrauding the public of more than $1,000,000 through the sale of bonds of the Philippine- Railway, was allowed yesterday to leave this jurisdiction under a bond of $5,000.. Federal Judge William Bondy, disregarding the expressed fear of William Power Maloney, assistant United States Attorney, that Buckner would not come back, allowed him to go to Los Angeles.

Sister Mary Ludwina died of pneumonia Thursday night in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City. Born in Ireland seventy-five years ago, she joined the Order of St. Joseph here fifty-three years ago. For the last two years she had been in St. Joseph's Convent in Flushing.
The hearing before the trade-agreement organization of the State Department on revising the trade agreement between Cuba and the United States has been set for Jan. 3.

It may not be merry for all unless their neighbors come to their rescue in time. Not, perhaps, for a family of eleven trying to live on $33 a week. Not for the porter, his hand crippled in a street accident, who is frantic with anxiety because he can no longer support his family.

Trading was active to slow in local markets yesterday. Fresh pork cuts lower: other classes of traefer meats unchanged from Thursday. On the kosher markets yesterday beef opened higher; veal sharply higher; lambs stronger. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Dr. and Mrs. Daniel J. McCarthy entertained a large group with tea and cocktails today at Blarneagh, in honor of their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Homer. Captain and Mrs. R. Amcotts Wilson had an informal dinner at home for Mr. and Mrs. Goeffrey Gates of New York.

The State Supreme Court gave the City Council today virtually absolute t power to dictate expense and income sides of the municipal budget. Upsetting a practice of city officials for the last nineteen years, the court ruled that the council, instead of the City Controller, might make binding estimates of the revenues from taxation.

Under the aegis of the National Socialist regime, millions in Germany who still draw the welcome Winter Relief to supplement their meager wages, despite the economic upswing and full employment, were gathered together tonight in halls over all of Germany to celebrate the "Volksweinacht" and receive gifts from the "Winterhilfe."

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that shareholders in the National Steel Car Company, Ltd., have been called to a special meeting on Dec. 28 to authorize an increase in capital stock to 250,000 shares. If authorized,

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch has invited Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, to take part in a large diplomatic shooting party arranged for the end of January and Count Ciano has accepted the invitation.
The Chinese press reported today that a unit of Japan's Manchukuoan troops stationed at Taokow, railway terminal in North Honan Province, had mutinied and killed 100 Japanese.

Jozeph L. Eland, Dutch painter from The Hague who is making his first visit to the United States to paint murals at the World's Fairs in San Francisco and New York, arrived yesterday on the Holland American liner Statendam.

Old friends of the Neediest and newcomers to the ranks of their benefactors rallied in increasing numbers to the aid of the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. Many of them expressed concern at the news that the fund has lagged be hind its last year's receipts;

A Columbia University graduate student experimenting in gases in Havemeyer Hall was fatally injured yesterday when his apparatus exploded and spread fire through the laboratory. Another man conducting research experiments near by burned his hands painfully when he tried to extinguish the flames.

New South Wales compiled 294 runs in the opening day's play of a Sheffield Shield cricket match with Victoria today When stumps were drawn the home team had made nine runs without loss in reply. Sidney Barnes, 21-year-old New South Wales batting star,

A creche has been erected in the garden of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street, west of Second Avenue. It is eight feet high, six feet deep and ten feet long. The stable in which Jesus Christ was born is duplicated with a thatched roof.

A new organization, the "Instituto Antiracial," created with the idea of protecting Jews from unfair treatment and persecution by totalitarian governments, was established yesterday under the presidency of Senator Cristobal Saenz, It is supported by prominent representatives of banking, trade and social circles.

In the six months ended Aug. 31, the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn has a gross operating income of $543,700, as against $576,300 in the same period of 1937, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc. Net for interest on the bonds was about $92,000, as against $112,000 last year.

The five-story twenty-five family apartment house at 3-5 Potter Place, Weehawken, N. J., on a plot 62 by 115 feet, was sold by Paul E. Lux, trustee to the 3-5 Potter Place Corporation, for an indicated consideration of $64,000. The buyer gave to the Hudson City Savings Bank a purchase money mortgage for $45.000.

The Appellate Division in a 4-to-1 decision held yesterday that a Supreme Court justice has power to enjoin all picketing, even when it is peaceful, in a labor dispute after he has found that the right to picket is being abused through violence and coercion.

Forsaking musical roles for the time being, Eddie Cantor will appear in "The Flying Yorkshireman" by Eric Knight, purchase of which was announced today by RKO. The story deals with the exploits of a daredevil pilot to be played by Cantor.
Carol singers from churches and clubs of Westchester County sang Christmas songs this afternoon on the steps of the Court House here and in the corridors of hospitals throughout the county.

The Long Island University basketball team beat the Montclair State Teachers College, 63--40, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy last night. Coach Clair F. Bee started a veteran quintet, but a sophomore array went into action after nine minutes of the first half and kept the Blackbirds in front.

In recent years governmental policy has been directed to an entirely laudable effort to improve the welfare of labor. If only because the workers constitute much the major part of our population, it cannot be too strongly insisted that their well-being must be our primary economic concern.
The New York Stock Exchange's committee on member firms has issued a bulletin pointing out that rules with regard to options apply to "all kindred arrangements."

The Appellate Division, in a unanimous decision, reversed yesterday a decree signed by Justice William Harman Black holding that Charles M. Schwab, William L. Batt and other directors of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers were "flagrantly careless" in the expenditure of more than $200,000 of the society's funds in the publication of a weekly and annual index of engineering articles between 1927 and 1934.

Despite an increase of 38,370 in the number of families and single persons receiving public and private assistance in this city, the amount spent on relief declined $408,653 last month, as compared with November, 1937, according to figures made public yesterday by the Welfare Council.

" Half of Cardiff" was delivered by the Marquess of Bute to new owners today. Estimates of the price involved in the sale last May 17 by the Marquess, which involved, among other things, 20,000 houses and 250 saloons, have ranged from $25,000,000 to $100,000,000.
The annual Get-Together Christmas dance for juniors was held last evening in the ballroom of the Pierre. Another dance will be held during the Easter holidays.

Ruling that the Board of Elections may fix the number and salaries of its employee within the amounts appropriated for it by the Board of Estimate, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn affirmed yesterday a Supreme Court decision direacting the Municipal Civil Service Commission to install Frank G. Frosch and Anthony J. Fugazy as clerks to the Board of Elections.
Police Commissioner Valentine, in a circular order sent to all station houses yesterday for the bulletin boards, extended the season's greetings to the members of the force and their families.

In a unanimous decision, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court vacated yesterday an order permitting Arthur A. Ballantine as bankruptcy receiver for the Continental Securities Corporation, one of the investment trusts whose looting was disclosed recently, to sell to Edward C. Leffler for $5,000 a controlling interest in Corporate Administration, Inc.

The Great Lakes Regional Advisory Board estimated today that its members would need 33.9 per cent more freight cars for their business in the first quarter of 1939 than in the same three months of 1938. The board is an organization of shippers along the southern shore of Lake Erie.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for the final week of the year shows the usual seasonal drop, the aggregate for sixty-two communities being only $20,198,120, as compared with the revised total of $34,558,839 for this week.

BARDACH-Adele. Reposing Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West 79th. BERG-Dr. Henry W., at his home, on Dec. 22, beloved brother of Mrs. Delia Warschauer, Mrs. Samuel D. Levy, Abraham Berg and Dr. Albert A. Berg. Services at Temple Emanu-El, 65th St. and 5th Ave., on Monday, Dec. 26, at 10 A. M.

After heavy gold shipments here, the Japanese Government has ordered eleven gold mines in Korea to produce more, the Department of Commerce reports today. Six of the biggest companies have also been ordered to supply full details of their operations, including production schedules, under the Gold Production Increase Law.
The laughter and chatter of 150 girl orphans rang through New York's Executive Mansion today as Governor Lehman laid aside the cares of State to help spread the Yuletide spirit.

The recommendations of the President's special transportation committee, consisting of three representatives each from railway management and labor, are at once so sweeping and so comprehensive that no final judgment can be passed upon them until they have been careful studied both separately and as a whole.

Miss. Sheila Crimmins and Miss Sophy Carr Mason were introduced to society together last night at a dinner dance given in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Crimmins and Mr. and Mrs. L. Randolph Mason. The debutantes received with their parents.

The Dry Dock Savings Institution sold to a client of James Felt Co., brokers, the six-story old-law tenement house at 626-East Fifth Street. The building is on a lot 24.9 by 96.2 feet and is assessed at $20,000. It was sold subject to a first mortgage of $14,750.

Dr. Lucy Porter Sutton, Assistant Professor of Pediatrics at New York University and an associate visiting physician at Bellevue Hospital, died yesterday at New York Hospital after an illness 'of five weeks. Her age was 47.

Mrs. Pamela Camroux Colgate, daughter of George F. M. Camroux of Pulborough, Sussex, England, and the late Mrs. Camroux, was married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church to Jacques de Montaudoin, son of Mme.
Being the youngest member of Congress apparently will have its draw-backs for 25-year-old Representative-elect Lindley Beckwith, Democrat, of Texas.

William Case, an 84-year-old farmer known as "Santa Claus" because of his long white beard and his annual Christmas gift of nickels to the children of his community, shot and killed William Rousseau, 37 years old, and wounded his wife, Minnie, 29, early this morning because he found them helping themselves to a Christmas tree for their little daughters, Geraldine, 11, and Sarah, 8.

As a first step in its program to revive the Pacific Coast shipbuilding industry the Maritime Commission awarded today to the Moore Drydock Company of Oakland at $5,715,520 a contract for the construction of two fast freighters of the C-3 type. The vessels, of about 11,000 tons displacement, will be built to specifications approved by the Navy Department.

Playing Santa Claus, the United Automobile Workers (C. I. O.) presented to 11-year-old Dorothy Hess today an artificial leg they bought with tobacco coupons. She gave it an immediate trial, walking for the first time in eight months; and wished her hundreds of unknown benefactors a "Christmas as merry as mine."

The Cunard White Star liner Laconia is due to sail today for Scotland, Ireland and England. Passengers include H. H. Balch, United States Consul General to Dublin; John Macrae, Captain and Mrs. C. C. Mann, Mr. and Mrs. Sydney R. Hill, Mrs. E. M. Wilde, W. T. Boyd, W. L. Burns and Mr. and Mrs. F. W. Gardner.

Mrs. Guy M. Grandin of Warren, Pa., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Dingley Grandin, to David Rumsey Donovan, son of Colonel and Mrs. William J. Donovan of New York and Buffalo.

A colorful Christmas party was given today for fifty young patients at the Hospital for the Crippled and Ruptured at 321 East Forty-second Street. Gaily decked out in Indian costumes, sailor suits and cowboy uniforms and glowing with excitement, the children forgot their infirmities as they watched a program of songs and dances organized by the Rita Violet Bridge Club of New York.
Abram Grynszpan and his wife, uncle and aunt of Herschel Grynszpan, Slayer of Ernst vom Rath, Were released provisionally from jail today.

The hog market top was restored to $8 per hundredweight today for the first time in seven weeks, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Trading was active at the advance. Cattle were steady in a quiet Christmas market, with common and medium grades all classes predominating at prices 25 to 75 cents over late last week. Lambs held steady, with top at $9.35.
Each of Marshfield's 2,683 school children is receiving a twopound box of cheese this week as a personal Christmas gift from Louis A. Hartl, banker and brewer.

Shortages of stocks in many lines held back full expansion of sales in wholesale and retail markets this week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Requests for holiday goods were as numerous as in the week before in many centers, but broken lines and, in some instances, actual scarcities lost business for wholesale houses.

Navy and Princeton carried off the honors- in the first annual Christmas invitation three-weapon fencing tournament among teams representing Navy, Harvard, Princeton and Yale at the 107th Regiment Armory last night.

Automobile traffic in the vehicular underpass running under Park Avenue, between Thirty-third and Fortieth Streets, was diverted yesterday afternoon for two hours after a head-on 'collision between two vehicles at Thirty-eighth Street in the tunnel. Two persons were injured.

Fifteen medals and awards were presented yesterday afternoon at Police Headquarters to members of the department for heroic efforts. Commissioner Valentine, Herbert L. Satterlee, president of the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York, and Robert M. Livingston, the association's secretary, participated in the service.
Fire Commissioner John J. MeElligott emphasized the promotion opportunities of the Fire Department yesterday as he elevated seventy-two officers and men to higher rank.

The 1938 Neediest Cases Fund was carried well past the $200,000 mark yesterday by a splendid flow of gifts that brought it $23,328.46by far the largest sum received in any single day since the twentyseventh annual appeal opened-and brought the aggregate amount that has been received for it to $215,092.87.
Following is an official summary of the conclusions reached by the committee appointed by the President on Sept. 20 to consider the transportation problem:

Executives of most industries are experiencing more than the usual difficulty in their efforts to forecast the outlook for next year. As this year draws to a close, the picture generally is confusing.

Miss Laura Hurd of this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hurd of Nutley, was married tonight in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here to Robert Motion of Madison and Trinidad, British West Indies, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Motion of Madison.

The final week of Christmas shopping brought gains in dollar comparisons and in the size of the average sale. While on a day-forday comparison average gains over a year ago were not achieved, the fact that the week has six business days against five last year will produce an increase in the week-toweek comparison.

Karl Allen Drummond, convicted of trying to sell stolen plans and pictures of American military planes to Japan, received the maximum sentence of two years' imprisonment today. Following a lecture on patriotism by Federal Judge Leon R. Yankwich, the 21-year-old former aircraft worker from Wichita, Kan.. said:

An appeal from a recent decision of the Brooklyn Appellate Division affirming the city's right to obtain emergency relief revenue by levying a 2 per cent personal property tax on certain purchases made outside the city and State by concerns within the city limits is scheduled for argument before the Court of Appeals in Albany on Jan. 19, it was learned yesterday.

Argentina this afternoon sighed the eighth Pan-American Conference's Declaration of Lima on the solidarity of the Americas. Only the signature of Brazil was lacking at a late hour to make the consent unanimous.

Leaders in society and finance joined with representatives of many patriotic and religious organizations in tribute to Mrs. Finley J. Shepard, philanthropist, at funeral services yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. More than 1,500 persons,

Orders issued by the Navy Department today and effective Jan. 6 constituted the United States Atlantic Squadron, which is now operating directly under Admiral William D. Leahy, chief of naval operations.

Wreaths and candles brightened the halls of the Peabody Home at 1,000 Pelham Parkway yesterday for the annual Christmas party for the aged and indigent women who are its guests. Second, third and fourth generations among the callers testified to the loyalty of certain families to the home, to which they have lent their aid and services for most of its sixty-five years.
Jewish services scheduled for today and tomorrow in the city follow:

Glenn Cunningham, peer of all milers, will try to keep on running, but automobiles and the rules of the game may stop him, The Kansan, who set the world mile record of 4:04.4 at Dartmouth last March, is training for a Sugar Bowl race Jan. 1 and he explained today that his track future was uncertain because of the Amateur Athletic Union's rule preventing athletes from capitalizing on their fame or ability.

Led by Bernie Carnevale, who scored 17 points, the New York A. C. basketball team defeated the Stock Exchange quintet on the former's court last night, 49 to 44. The battle was closely fought, and the Winged Footers won with a late spurt.

The American Association's president, George M. Trautman, considered today a suggestion that he put his umpires through a rigid ocular examination before allowing them on the field next season in baseball's centennial campaign.
Mrs. Pearl Buck, the novelist, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania yesterday from Sweden, where she received the Nobel Prize for Literature from King Gustav.

That the Civil Aeronautics Authority is actively considering, with other departments of the Government, applications for the establishment of air service in the Atlantic by a number of foreign governments is gratifying news from Washington.
The opponents in the Sugar Bowl football game Jan. 2, Carnegie Tech and Texas Christian University, are rounding into form.

The defeat of Garden City Casino, seven-time winner of the tournament, by Central in the first round provided the feature of the early Metropolitan Badminton Association interteam competition. Led by George Harris and Paul Vansco, third and seventh ranked players in this district, respectively, Central upset the Long Islanders, 3 to 2, in a men's Class A match.

This Maryland community has sent its annual Christmas greeting to Salisbury, England. "A very Merry Christmas, a most Happy New Year to everybody in Salisbury, England, from everybody in Salisbury, Md., U. S. A.," Mayor Arthur W. Boyce cabled the English city's Lord Mayor.
In regard to that thrilling City College-Oregon basketball game at Madison Square Garden last Saturday, I'd like to make one important point that all the sports writers seem to have missed.

A contribution of $10,000 worth of codfish, purchased in New Brunswick and the Magdalen Islands, has been made by the Dominion Government to the International Commission for the Assistance of Child Refugees in Spain, Prime Minister Mackenzie King announced today.
Forecasts of snow tonight and tomorrow gladdened hundreds of skiers who have begun moving into Northern New England for the holidays.

Although believed to have slipped well over the hill when he moved from the Cardinals to the Dodgers a year ago, Leo Durocher, now manager-of the Brooklyn club, was the National League's ranking shortstop for 1938, according to the official fielding averages released for publication today.

If Premier Fumimaro Konoye's statement yesterday on peace conditions is considered as the terms of a victor, diplomatic observers here find in it an air of moderation that compares favorably with various modern European examples.

Nebraska railroads, seeking to strike back at truck competition, received authority today from the State Railway Commission to establish intrastate freight rates comparable to those charged by motor carriers. The effective date is Jan. 2.
Macon police announced today the arrest of three men in connection with the slaying of five persons in Savannah Tuesday night.
The New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor spent $1,561,955 to aid 45,281 persons in 21,061 families in the last fiscal year, Barklie Henry, president, announced yesterday.
The Trades and Labor Congress of Canada will soon suspend international unions in the Dominion affiliated with the C. I. O., according to predictions in labor circles today.

Mayor Frank Hague charged here today that Morris L. Ernst, counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, had "engineered the manoeuvres" that led the American Bar Association to file in United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia a brief accusing the Jersey City official of "serious abridgement of the constitutional right to peaceably assemble."
The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee decided today to devote a special section of its report to the Senate to its investigation of charges of WPA political activity in Tennessee and Kentucky.
We just received an interesting letter from Lee Smits, who spends most of his waking moments in a fine cause-that of spreading the gospel of the National Wildlife Federation.

Trading by members in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Dec. 3 was 18.32 per cent of total volume, compared with 19.86 per cent the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The volume was 5,586,610 shares sold, compared with 4,779,250.
Guy Forbes, retired silk manufaoturer and former president of the Village of Scarsdale, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

A cloudy, warm Christmas Eve following occasional rain was forecast last night by the Weather Bureau, with Christmas Day clear and mild. The light snow that fell yesterday caused delays to many of the thousands of persons who left the city for the holidays, and gave promise of remaining long enough to make it a "white" Christmas, at least in parts of the country.

Mrs. Sayles Booker gave a supper dance last night at the River Club to present to society her daughter, Miss Mary Sayles Booker. The debutante wore a white tulle gown, trimmed with appliques of lace and small sequins, and carried a bouquet of white orchids. Mrs. Booker's gown was of black velvet adorned with a corsage of gardenias.

Miss Katherine Romer Albertson and Thomas Ashley Bissell of this city were married yesterday at the home of her parents, the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll Albertson of 952 Fifth Avenue. The ceremony was performed by Dr. Albertson, who retired in 1928 from the pastorate of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn.

Is there any ground for supposing that among the ancient German tribes a man could eat his cake and have it, that the fat did not go with the lean, that people could blow hot and cold, that people made their beds and did not lie in them?

Christmas can't be too long. When does it begin? How long does it come before it comes? Even a punctilious calculator would have to start with last night. The night before the night before Christmas the police and the firemen were giving parties and scattering toys among toyless children.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A. Gibbs of Four Corners, Germantown, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Elizabeth Gibbs to Lawrence Singmaster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Singmaster of Germantown.

The United States was the largest purchaser of Nicaraguan products in 1938, buying 65 per cent of the total exports. Germany, The Netherlands and France followed in that order. Nicaragua purchased 68 per cent of her imports from the United States. Great Britain, Germany,
The following Foreign Service changes were announced today by the State Department: Stephen C. Brown of Herndon, Va., vice consul at Shanghai, has been assigned vice consul at Yunnanfu, China.

In a driving hailstorm and heavy seas, the American freighter Schodack rescued eighteen seamen and two women yesterday from the tiny Norwegian freighter Smaragd, foundering 600 miles southeast of New York.
President Roosevelt today personally greeted more than 100 members of the White House office force in a reception celebrating the Christmas holidays.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City was attacked in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today as a "heresy hunter" and defended as a tolerant and popular executive eager to protect his "decent and ideal city" from possible riot and bloodshed.

Dr. Alexander C. Flick, New York State historian, said today that President Roosevelt intends to invite political colleagues and Cabinet members to place their personal and private papers in the proposed Roosevelt repository at Hyde Park, N. Y.

A 35-year-old man who had boasted to the police last Aug. 11 that he did not need their help against the man who had shot him in the stomach, that "I'll settle with him myself," was found dead last night, battered and wounded, in the alleyway adjoining the house at 1,035 Sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn. The body appeared to have been dumped there from a passing automobile.

A policy of seeing that money appropriated by Congress for relief goes to those for whom it was intended was proclaimed today by Colonel F. C. Harrington, who becomes Acting Administrator of the Works Progress Administration tomorrow, succeeding Harry L. Hopkins. Harry L. Hopkins.
The Public Service Commission today reopened consideration of its order directing hotels to reduce service charges for local and long-distance calls.

The American Cities Power and Light Corporation declared yesterday an optional dividend on the convertible Class A stock, optional dividend series, of 75 cents cash or one thirty-second share of Class B stock.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at 640 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Rollin S. Saltus has left her home in Mount Kisco for The Deck, Hobe Sound, Fla., where she will pass the Winter.
Connie Mack, whose great ambition is to turn out one more great baseball team, hinted tonight at another goal-to live to be 100.

Harvard chess players, in making a clean sweep in the annual series of team matches against Dartmouth, which bowed by 4-0; Princeton, which the Crimson defeated by 3-1, and Yale, over which it prevailed by 21/2--11/2, for a team total of 91/2 out of a possible 12 points, came through yesterday with another merited success in the competition for the StephensBelden Trophy at the Marshall Chess Club.

Another stone in the all the American republics are trying to erect between them and totalitarian influences was put in place today when the Pan-American conference unanimously agreed to recommend legislation by the American governments denying to foreigners resident in their countries collective exercise of pretended political rights accorded to them by their countries of origin.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,072,000 bales, against 1,086,000 a week ago, 1,091,000 two weeks ago, 1,088,000 three weeks ago and 1,054,000 a year ago; of which American, 501,000 bales, against 511,000 a week ago, 517,000 two weeks ago, 528,000 three weeks ago and 635,000 a year ago.

A suit entered by Joseph V. Burns as Martin act receiver for Campagnoll Co., Inc., security dealers, to recover $207,800 from William G. Maguire, president of the MissouriKansas Pipe Line Company, was dismissed yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in a unanimous decision. The court held that the receiver lacked the legal capacity to maintain the suit.
Announcement was made tonight that Venezuela and the United States were raising their legations to the status of embassies, effective as soon as the necessary legislative stens he taken.

A joint protest of American Christendom against the atrocities perpetrated on the Jews in Germany, labeling all totalitarianism-Communist and Fascist-as incompatible with Christianity and calling on all Christians to pray at this Christmastide for peace and good-will was made public yesterday by the participating church organizations.

Charges of homicide against John Hamilton, 26 years old, -of 9 Willow Place, Yonkers, N. Y., and Frank Tait, 43, of 498 Central Avenue, Jersey City, were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Leonard McGee

Approximately 7,000 Jews have been freed from concentration camps in the last two weeks, Jewish quarters estimated today, in a tempering of the action Nazis took in the anti-Jewish violence that broke out Nov. 10.

Toseph J. Mitchell, 66 years old. the father of nine children, receive notification today from the State Board of Bar Examiners that he had passed tne examination to become an attorney. Lawyers and judges here said they could recall no older person ever embarking on a career of law.
Santa Claus was absent from the Ginza last night and Japanese children were heard asking if he had gone to China.

Figure skating as a sport as well as a source of entertainment reached a new high mark during the past year. In New York, as well as in other principal cities of the nation, skaters took part in ice carnivals and shows that were attended by thousands of enthusiastic spectators.
At noon on Wednesday Schrafft's will open its latest bar and cocktail lounge at 39 East Fifty-eighth Street, between Madison and Park Avenues.

The season's outstanding Christmas gift, in so far as the travel field is concerned, was purchased by Mrs. Harry Milne McIntosh of 1,130 Sheridan Road, Lake Forest, Ill., who sailed Friday night on the Grace liner Santa Elena for a sixteen-day cruise of West Indies ports.

The nation, and more particularly the nation's capital, is slowly beginning to realize just what Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska did when he devised his "lame duck" amendment to the Constitution. Back in the old days Congress would now have been in session a full three weeks and come Jan. 3, it would be resuming after the Christmas holidays, full of spirit.

When Edward Conde of Montclair, N. J., becomes old enough to take his first shave, he may use the shaving cup once used by Senator Hamilton F. Kean of New Jersey in the Senate barber shop. The cup, bearing Mr. Kean's name in big gold letters, was sent to the boy today as a Christmas present by Robert W. Kean, Republican Representative-elect from New Jersey, a son of the former Senator.
The Maple Leafs gave close to 12,000 fans a Christmas Eve gift tonight in the form of a 2-0 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game.

In a season unparalleled from the standpoint of volume in the whole history of horse racing, there were produced an unbeaten 2-year-old champion, a 3-year-old leader who also was the leading money winner and a handicap star who added new laurels to an already large collection.

In an effort to promote better understanding with South America, Oberlin College will give a full tuition scholarship, board and room to some student from a South American university for next year, it was announced today by President Ernest H. Wilkins.

The Federal Trade Commission accused nineteen producers of hardwood charcoal today of price-fixing conspiracies to suppress competition. The commission said these producers made about 70 per cent of the country's output of hardwood charcoal, which was used mainly as fuel.

Mr. and Mrs. George Thayer Lane of West Newton, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Crawford Lane, to Kimball Russ Hitchcock, son of Mrs. William Raymond Hitchcock of New York and Deposit, N. Y., and the late Dr. Hitchcock.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Walter Plummer of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Plummer, to John H. Davis Jr., first classman at the United States Military Academy at West Point.
Mrs. Watson Payne Gooch of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julia Davis Gooch, to Gale Richmond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Richmond of Providence, R.I.

TICONDEROGA. - Two new Winter sports areas, each within easy overnight dis tance from New York by week-end snow-train service, will be open for skiers in the Adirondack region this Winter, one at historic Ticonderoga, the other further away in the mountains at Keene Valley.

For the third successive year, J. Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and Miss Alice Marble of Beverly Hills, Calif., head the rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association as announced last night. The list must be approved by the annual meeting on Feb. 4 before it becomes final.

Toy manufacturers have reported more unfilled orders from retailers at the end of this year, particularly in the higher price lines, than at any other time in the history of the industry, according to James L. Fri, managing director of the Toy Manufacturers of the United States of America. Orders from many retailers were delayed well into the Fall season, with the result that producers were unable to make deliveries at the last minute.

DR. VLADIMIR K. ZWORY KIN has been granted the basic patent on the electronic television system, the key elements of which are the teleeyes, known at the receiver as the iconoscopee" and at the camera as the "kinescope." The patent has been pending fifteen years in the United States Patent Office.

All was amazingly quiet at the front today and, while it cannot be said the Rebel offensive is over, there is every reason to believe, from the state of affairs I found in the lines, there is as yet no important threat to Catalonia in this drive.

Viewed from its many angles, the sport of showing horses in competition enjoyed its most successful year. It was not a twelvemonth of spectacular achievement; rather the record was of steady progress and healthy growth.

Following is the text of Pope Plus's annual Christmas address to the College of Cardinals: With great and profound emotion of the heart we have heard and enjoyed the beautiful and good things which the very eminent dean of the Sacred College

Two first-year men were recognized, while one of the game's outstanding veterans was passed over, by the National Professional Football Writers Association, whose 1938 National Football League all-star selections, based on a poll of 205 members and announced from Chicago yesterday, are considerably at variance with the elevens favored by the league coaches.

Harvey D. Burrill, president-editor of the Syracuse Newspapers, Inc., publishers of The Syracuse Journal and The Syracuse Sunday American, and for more than half a century associated with The Syracuse Journal, died tonight at his home here at the age of 70.

" Prisoner, stand up! You have been tried and convicted under the national anti-trust laws of conducting a monopoly in the distribution of Christmas gifts. It has been proved that you had a hand in every one of them. Your assets have been recklessly dissipated and your liabilities are simply scandalous.

ALTER--Rose, on Dec. 24. Services at Hirsch Funeral Home, Prospect Ave., corner 165th St., Bronx, Monday, 2 P. M. Interment Mount Hebron Cemetery. AUSTIN--Captain John Adams Austin, U. S. A., at Ogden, Utah. He is survived by his wife, Ann Writer Austin; his son, John Adams Austin Jr.,

John C. Bancroft, president of the International Match Realization Company, Ltd., of Bermuda, in a letter to the holders of voting-trust certificates makes known that there has been no material change in the status of assets except that Continental Investment A. G. was liquidated and dissolved in November, the company receiving a final liquidating dividend of $5,369 from this holding.

Despite Indications that the passing years were finally beginning to catch up with him, Lou Gehrig, redoubtable Iron Horse of the world champion Yankees, nevertheless succeeded in breaking eight major league records and tying one other in 1938, according to official American League figures released for publication today.

In a cash transaction, Alfred Hafner has purchased from Colgate University and others the eightstory loft building at 29 East Tenth Street, between Broadway and University Place, for investment and for expansion of his publishing business.

Debaters at Rutgers University will engage in the most extensive program this year in the history of the activity at the university. About 125 varsity and freshmen matches with college teams from all sections of the country will be faced during the campaign.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Franklin McNeil of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Bowen McNeil, to William Edward Rauth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rogers Rauth of Edgewater Park and Bay Head, N. J.

The 60 per cent of the University of Buffalo's 1938 graduating class in dentistry now serving as hospital internes illustrates the growing tendency of dental graduates to seek additional training, according to a survey of the fifteen years of the university's so-called "Buffalo Plan"
In his annual report this month as president of the Carnegie Corporation, Dr. Frederick P. Keppel raised some questions concerning the graduate school which for long years, he said,

The Pan American Conference at tonight's plenary session adopted an eightpoint declaration of American principles designed to strengthen the Declaration of Lima by setting forth a general rule of action for the American States.

The majority of Americans, believing another European war is inevitable and that the United States will be involved, favors joining with other democratic powers to prevent further expansion by Hitler and Mussolini, it was indicated in a survey of public opinion announced Friday by the magazine Fortune.

The first undergraduate to conduct the Hamilton College choir was Sam L. Lake, 39, of Pleasantville, N. Y., who last Sunday officiated while the director, Professor Paul A. Fancher, was on his way to France.

Because there is a scarcity of private funds and a large prison population, Sing Sing prisoners did not fare as well this year in the matter of gifts as usual, but today each of 2,790 prisoners received a toothbrush, toothpaste and a box contraining a pound of candy.

Christmas is observed at sea by ships of all Christian nations more than any other festival. No matter whether the vessel is cruising in the Red Sea, being buffeted by big seas off the Cape of Good Hope in a stiff northeaster or even battered by a "Southerly Buster" in the

MR. VAN LOON and Miss Castagnetta have once again provided a song book which is at the same time a delightful picture book. Mr. Van Loon's drawings have never been better. They catch the romantic quality of Tom Moore's "Rich and Rare Were the Gems She Wore,"
LAST week Mayor La Guardia personally presented one of the City of New York's Christmas gifts to motorists who travel between Manhattan and the boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens.
MONTREAL.-Provided snow conditions are appropriate, 35,000 persons are expected to spend the Christmas and New Year holidays in the Laurentian Mountains, just north of Montreal.

Mrs. Neal Sanford Conley of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Kernan Patten Waterbury, to Second Lieutenant Theodore Eustace Crocker, F. A. Res., of Fort Hoyle, Md., of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Crocker of New York.
SOUTHERN PINES, N. C.--The calendar of events here for the holidays includes fox hunting, hunter trials, equestrian gymkhanas and golf.

The relationship of good health to a good scholastic record is gaining increasing recognition at Cornell University, where the Department of the Hygiene and Preventive Medicine is cooperating in the investigation of causes for scholastic delinquency, continuing its cold-prevention program, emphasizing mental hygiene by adding psychiatric examinations to its activities and conducting long-time surveys of health problems.

Department stores, specialty shops and other stores on Fifth Avenue will unite in ceremonies observing "The Dawn of a New Day on Fifth Avenue" at 9:30 A. M. Wednesday on the terrace in front of the New York Public Library, under the auspices of the Fifth Avenue Association.

Between sessions with his precious cosmic ray balloons, Dr. Robert A. Millikan has amplified his attitude toward religion and asserted that it was a hopeful sign that youth was "sloughing all the old-time superstations and outworn creeds."
An Italian-born dancer, Virginia Rata Capt, was disclosed today to be on a hunger strike in the cell where the Swiss Government is holding her as the master mind of an international spy ring.

The African Violet (Saintpaulia ionantha) has become more generally available to the grower of house plants during the last year or two. And with the success or failure of bringing this commendable and attractive house plant through the Winter arise the debatable questions of a proper soil mixture and most favorable situation for it.

For the first time in the fortyeight-year history of the Amateur Skating Union of the United States one man, 21-year-old Vic Ronchetti of Chicago, dominated the sport of speed skating in 1938 to so great an extent that he Captured three of the four major championships of the organization.

Floor coverings made of asphalt compositions, points out the Painter and Decorator, whether laid in plastic form like cement or in tile or rolls, may give the painter trouble unless he finishes them with the proper method.

Sixty-one per cent of the orphaned and dependent children under care of agencies affiliated with the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities were cared for by foster mothers in individual boarding homes in Greater New York this year, as compared with 22 per cent in 1923, according to a report yesterday by Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, president of the New York Federation.

WASHINGTON. - New evidence bearing on the relation of drinking to safe driving and the value of so-called tests for accident proneness of drivers was reported to the Highway Research Board at its eighteenth annual meeting here last week.

BROADCASTS from "Radio Nations," from 7 until 7:45 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Sunday are heard on 9.345 megacycles. The weekly talk from this League station at Geneva, which is inserted between fifteen-minute periods of selected orchestral music, has centered exclusively of late on education, and better diet for the masses.

The close of the women's national field hockey tournament, held Thanksgiving week-end at the Merion Cricket Club in Philadelphia on a field from which the players themselves removed eight inches of snow and ice, found the Southeast team winning national honors for the second year in succession.

When an old house is bought with the intention of modernizing it the services of an expert are generally required to determine to what extent modernization is necessary make the house comfortable for modern living.

An excellent source of materials quite generally overlooked for use in making Winter arrangements is the utilization of clippings from the foliage of house plants, or from the various evergreen shrubs and plants in the garden.

A "Perfume Entry Fashion Show" will be presented during the dinner hour on Jan. 17 at the Cafe Louis XIV as a benefit for the Russian Refugee Children's Welfare Society, Inc. Since 1926 the beneficiary has fed, clothed and sheltered children of impoverished Russian families in this country.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Chubbuck of this city of the engagement of their granddaughter, Miss Helen Spencer Chubbuck, to Bruce Henderson Zacherle, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Zacherle of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.

The New York Athletic Club, long dominant in water polo, again swept all the national titles in this game of submarine wrestling during the past year. The Winged Footers captured indoor and outdoor crowns in the hard-ball phase of the sport and the indoor title in soft-ball.

DURING the last few years in photographic exhibition work there has been a regrettable lack of costume photography. Pictures of historical characters that suggest a story have been missing from salons where it would seem that they naturally should have a place, and to many the omission is inexplicable.

Samuel J. Foley, District Attorney of the Bronx, joined yesterday with Mayor La Guardia, Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney of New York County, and Lewis J. Valentine, Police Commissioner, in supporting the plan of the Municipal Civil Service Commission to give special credits to applicants who have passed relevant college courses or are specially trained in athletics, in the examination for patrolmen to be held on Jan. 7.

Superior Court Judge John D. Humphries ruled today that school teachers of Atlanta and Fulton Counties could not be dismissed because of marriage. He issued the decision in connection with an appeal against dismissal filed by Mrs. Mary Jones Hughie, former principal, who was not permitted to return to her job last Fall because she married during the 1937-38 term.

The total cost of new construction work in the United States for the year 1939 is estimated at $6,385,000,000, being a 23 per cent increase over the approximate total of $5,185,000,000 expended for allbuilding activities during the present year.

Christmas Eve finds Chicago already on the verge of a sizzling Mayoralty contest, although the primary election is still two months away. Intense fights for nomination are assured in both major parties and the nominees may face an independent candidacy at the run-off election in April.

Everybody connected with the Newark Importing Company's five retail stores in Newark, East Orange and Bloomfield received a Christmas bonus tonight except the boss-Irving Kirsch of Jersey City. A hold-up man relieved Mr.

Rabbi Abram Simon, Jewish leader, educator and orator, died of a heart attack late today in his hotel apartment. He was 66 years old. Death came less than three hours after he preached at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

For the average American the year 1938 has been chiefly memorable for events which took place in Europe, rather than for what happened here in the United States. Leading all other events of the year in public interest was the struggle which began in Czecho-Slovakia and threatened to involve the rest of Europe in a new war.

Announcement has been made here by Dr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Holmes of Winchester, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Wright Holmes, to Duncan Upham Hunter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy D. Hunter of Claremont, N. H.

Women's sports took another forward step in 1938, a year marked by a number of sparkling individual feats, by the continued success of American teams in international golf and tennis and by the increased popularity among women of several lines of athletic endeavor.

ANHALT-Lieutenant and Mrs. Abbie Anhalt of 48 Loring Ave., Yonkers, N. Y., announce their twenty-fifth wedding anniversary on Sunday, Dec. 25. NOWVE-Mr. and Mrs. Henry L., celebrate their twentieth wedding anniversary. Greetings from their children, Raymond L., Marilyn E. and Joan Barbara, and friends.

A MILE or two outside of St. Germain-en-Laye, cradle of Louis XIV and of Claude Debussy, stands the Chateau Du Belloy. For some time past this inconspicuous but beautifully situated estate has been the shelter of a motley company of about 100 young people who in part dress like performers in some exotic Iberian ballet or operetta and who converse animatedly in the mysterious language of the Basques.

To Roger Conti, veteran French cue expert, went the most important championship in billiard circles last March when he dethroned Welker Cochran of San Francisco as the world professional three - cushion title-holder.
Supreme Court Justice James A. Dunne of the Second Judicial District died early yesterday morning of a heart attack in his home, 24 Monroe Place, Brooklyn. He was 64 years old.
Alfred M. Landon, speaking before a plenary session of the Lima Conference tonight, declared that the American republics seek a passage through present difficulties without conflict or war.

The first subscription dance under the auspices of the newly formed junior league of Irvington House will be known as a Cinderella Ball and will be held on Thursday on the St. Regis Roof. Plans for the event are being formulated in keening with its title.

Their great talents will have to balance their small numbers if women sculptors are not to be obscured in the art panorama of the New York World's Fair. Only a quartet of the feminine wielders of chisel and clay won commissions for the 1939 exposition-but the selection was a discriminating one. Malvina Hoffman, Gertrude V. Whitney, Brenda Putnam and Augusta Savage have more than maintained the even keel.

A large subscription has been reported for the tea dance in aid of Greenwich House which has been arranged by a group of students from Barnard College for next Thursday in the Silver Room of the Ambassador.

Jacob A. Rich, who as Jacob Reich or Jack Sullivan was a chief defense witness in the two trials of Police Lieutenant Charles Becker for the murder of Hefman Rosenthal, died early yesterday in the Home for Incurables, Third Avenue and 183d Street, the Bronx.

An explosion aboard the clam boat Missie K. today took the life of Cornelius Ott, 74, a few hours before he was to play Santa Claus for his young nephew and several other children. Mr. Ott descended to the cabin to light a kerosene stove. The flame ignited fumes which had collected in the hold. John Boyle, 73, who was on deck, escaped injury.

A dance under the auspices of the Alumnae Association of the Academy of Mount Saint Vincent will be held Tuesday at the WaldorfAstoria. Miss Ella Galvin heads the group in charge of the arrangements. Serving with her are the Misses Carmeline M. Annunziata, Dina Dellale, Eileen Duffy, Gloria Gu??. Vera Perrotty and Eileen Sheehy.

" A HAPPY CHRISTMAS!" Everyman's greeting of good will warms the hearts of millions today. But there are neighbors whom that greeting does not reach -the child whom no one wants-the widowed mother worn out in the struggle to care for her children-the couple, nearing the end of life, ill and friendless-and all the others caught in the web of tragedy.

A comprehensive review of sports in 1938 is printed today in Section 5 of THE NEW YORK TIMES. The year is shown to have been one of sensational record-breaking, with men, machines and horses all contributing new speed marks.

Lester Herzog, son of Harry Herzog, local coal dealer, lost a two - carat diamond Thursday while working in the bins at his father's coal yard. Customers who have received coal since Thursday are sifting ashes after an advertisement in the local weekly offered a $50 reward for return of the diamond.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Frances Hackett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hackett of this place, to Ensign Harold S. Bottomley Jr., U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bottomley of Merchantville, N. J.

IS there a Santa Claus for children who are "progressively" educated? Should there be a Santa Claus for small boys and girls trained according to the latest ideas of the child-study laboratory? Can his fat old legendary figure be fitted into the cold-fact background of the ultramodern school?

The several hundred students in the Berry Schools, Mount Berry, Ga., who are children of indigent parents in Southern mountain States, will be aided by a benefit performance of Noel Coward's new revue, "Set to Music," on Jan. 31 at the Music Box Theatre.

The engagement of Miss Aneita Frances Cleary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cleary of Montclair, formerly of New Rochelle, N. Y., to the Rev. John James Kirkpatrick of Glen Ridge, son of Mrs. John Wesley Kirkpatrick, formerly of Caldwell, and the late Mr. Kirkpatrick, has been announced by her parents.

An original three - act musical comedy, tentatively called "Opus 40," will go into rehearsal after the holidays as the annual show of the junior class at Barnard College.

WITH all the economic strain of a year and a half of fighting on a large scale still heavy, Japan is taking active steps to gain commercial air supremacy of a vast area, from the Siberian and Indo-China frontiers almost to the equator.

Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Campbell of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Elizabeth Campbell, to Francis German Wrightson 3d of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Dawson Wrightson of Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-From this week-end's informal family gatherings and traditional Christmas parties until the elaborate New Year's Eve celebrations, the ensuing six days will be devoted to social affairs.

The desperate plight of 7,000 Jews expelled from Germany, who for almost two months have been sheltered in barns near the PolishGerman frontier, is being investigated by Robert Briscoe, a member of the Irish Parliament.
THE fabulous story of the Musica brothers and their amazing exploits, a front-page event in the newspapers, somehow missed the essential elements of being adapted for broadcasting.

The WPA is planning to spend more than $1,000,000 next year in each of eight city parks, it became known yesterday. In three other parks the cost of improved play facilities will fall just short of the $1,000,000-mark, an analysis of the program worked out by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, and Park Commissioner Robert Moses disclosed.

Directors of the personnel training course at Radcliffe, encouraged by the success of the first year and by the ability and cooperation shown in this second year, will announce after the holidays plans for the third year.

To promote dental health among School pupils and provide practical Training for dental assistants and technicians, the Board of Education is conducting a free clinic to serve the needy among the 50,000 boys and girls in the New York City vocational high schools.

IT is quite impossible to consider dispassionately an album of Christmas Carols sung by the Wiener Saengerknaben. Here is a boys choir that dates back four hundred and forty years; to the time when Columbus, the Cabots, de Gama and Vespucci were still voyaging and Maximilian, its founder, was moulding German nationality and dreaming of world empire.

THIS is the week we usually devote to the annual report, thereby clearing the schedule for the list of the best ten, the results of the New York Film Critics' vote and other odds and ends of the dead year.

The New York Stock Exchange has suspended from dealings Deutsche Bank stamped American participation certifications extended to Sept. 1, 1935, representing participation in the five-year 6 per cent note due Sept. 1. 1932.

ART," observed Rabindranath Tagore in the third issue of the French quarterly Verve (which forms the theme of a current show at the Pierre Matisse), "represents the inexhaustible magnificence of creative spirit. It is generous in its acceptance and generous in its bestowal. It is unique in its manner and universal in its appeal. * * * Its vision is new, though its view may be old."

The total volume of building permits for the town of Greenwich this year will fall below the 1937 aggregate and the current month already shows a continued decrease. The decline is expected to be about $400,000. The present total for the eleven-month period is $2,932,120, as compared with $3,326,932 for the 1937 period, these sums representing estimated costs of the buildings for which permits were filed.

The extent to which the New York World's Fair of 1939 is cooperating with authors and publishers to insure the public of authentic descriptive and pictorial matter concerning the fair was revealed yesterday when Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, made public a list of seventeen publications.

I am glad to see you seriously taking up the question of Grane. An old gentleman of my acquaintance says that granted that the curse must work itself out, he doesn't see why they couldn't let off the horse, who had had no share in the skulduggery that brought on the general doom.

Three post-Christmas parties will be given this week by the Catholic Action Guild of the Catholic Young Women's Club. Forty orphan girls of grammar school age will be entertained at the club headquarters, 641 Lexington Avenue, tomorrow at 3:30 P. M. On Tuesday at 7:30 P. M.

TANGANYIKA is in the news these days, both in discussions of the return of former German colonies and of havens for German refugees. Tanganyika territory is the major portion of the former German East Africa. This former German colony was occupied by British, Belgian and Portuguese troops during the World War and subsequently divided among them.

The Pan American Conference at tonight's plenary session adopted an eightpoint declaration of American principles designed to strengthen the Declaration of Lima by setting forth a general rule of action for the American States.

PREFERENCE: New York's Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine last week said he wished more rookies were college-trained. He prefers young men trained in group athletics. He dislikes rookies who, nearing middle life, have acquired receding hairlines and expanding waistlines.

Jai-alai or pelota, the fast court game that is a favorite in Spanishspeaking countries, was brought to New York last Fall by Richard Berenson, owner of the Biscayne fronton in Miami; Mike Jacobs and Lee Shubert, and installed in the Hippodrome.

THE suggestion is strong in Mr. Riggs's entertaining book that human nature is a fairly permanent thing. By his topical arrangement of his chapters the former editor of Art and Archaeology emphasizes the point.

DETROIT. -- Probably influenced to some extent by the pre-holiday period and also by the recent demands of labor for a thirty-two hour week, automotive production during the week just past fell to the lowest point this month.
Expansion seems to be the keynote of four North Carolina colleges, two of them celebrating 100th anniversaries, and all have recently made known outstanding gifts and memorials.

Dr. and Mrs. N. Chandler Foot of 47 East Eighty-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Ellen Bellows Foot, to Dr. Charles Neumann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Neumann of New Rochelle, N. Y.

With the United States Government holding some 2,500,000,000 ounces of silver, most of which has been acquired in the last five years at cost of more than $1,000,000,000, the controversial question of the government's silver program likely will come up for discussion the next Congress, which will be convened on Jan. 3.

The Nazi press declared today that United StatesGerman relations were at their "lowest point" as a result of the "Ickes incident," which a Propaganda Ministry spokesman declared was closed diplomatically.

Celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding at Hunter College, Phil Sigma Sigma, national philanthropic sorority, held a fourday silver jubilee convention at the Hotel Biltmore last Week.

The percentage lease with a minimum guarantee is the only form to be recommended, William M. Morris, vice president of Adams Co. and chairman of the stores' subcommittee of the Real Estate Board of New York's rental conditions committee, declared last week at a meeting of the management division of the board.

The engagement of Miss Mildred Whittlesey Felt to Frank M. Gordon of Orange, N. J., son of Mrs. James F. Gordon and the late Mr. Gordon of Madison, N. J., has been announced to friends here by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Felt of Peiping.

Mrs. Charles Augustine Moran of Atlanta, Ga., has announced here the engagement of her granddaughter, Miss Elizabeth Cornelia Everett of Atlanta and New York, to Ashton Clagett Bonnafon of. Ardmore, Pa., son of Captain Edmund Walters Bonnafon,
