Under a gray and lowering sky the ducks, swans, geese and assorted birds of Central Park assembled at the Fifty-ninth Street lake yesterday - morning- at 9 o'clock for their eighth annual Christmas stocking.

Sweet Briar Day, which will be observed by alumnae of the college throughout the country on Wednesday, will be marked here by a luncheon of the combined clubs of New York, Westchester, Long Island and New Jersey.

Mrs. William Pfeiffer of 839 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Pfeiffer, to Richard Jackson, son of Mrs. Henry C. Jackson of Medford, Mass., and the late Mr. Jackson.
The recent agreement between Mexico and the YUnited States regarding the payment of indemnity for expropriated American-owned lands was ratified by the Senate during a secret session on Thursday.
Stanley H. Bergesen, who embezzled money from the bank which employed him so he could aid charitable activities, received a Christmas gift today by being put on probation for five years.
IN the Far East they call them Old China Hands. In the Far West they call them Old Cowhands. They mean the boys who have been at it a long, long time--insiders, who know the ropes.
HAMILTON, Bermuda. --A Christmas Day in the real Dickens tradition, with such variations as Bermuda has made through the years, will open this colony's celebration of the Yuletide season today.

With a somewhat extensive building program at Amherst College having been brought to an end with the completion of the alumni gymnasium and Harold I. Pratt swimming pool, a new infirmary, the Kirby Memorial Theatre and an addition to the Converse Memorial Library, the administration is now directing its attention to the problems of housing and eating, which have become acute in recent years because of the record enrollment of students.

NO sooner had Fritjof Nansen secured the Nansen passport for refugees at a conference in Geneva in July, 1922, than he turned from the gigantic task of working with the refugee problem in Russia to the new catastrophe involved in the exchange of Greek and Turkish populations.

carctinal Leo de Skrbensky, died today in Niederlangendorf, Moravia, at the age of 75. Before becoming Archbishop of Olmutz he was Archbishop of Prague. In 1920 he was injured in an automobile accident, later resigned and retired to his family seat. Before being ordained he was a lieutenant in the Austrian Hussars.

The fourth annual sophomorefreshman masque ball will be held by St. Peter's College, Jersey City, Wednesday evening at the Collins Memorial Gymnasium in Jersey City. William P. von der Leith is chairman.

ENCOURAGED by the mounting enthusiasm for Winter sports shown by city dwellers, railroads operating out of New York have enlarged their snow-train schedules and equipment and are ready for a busy season. Plans of the various lines follow:

Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur L. Cummings of 320 Park Avenue and Round Hill, Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Molly Cummings, to William Amory Gardner Minot, son of Grafton Winthrop Minot of Chateau d'Azay-sur-Indre, France, and of Mrs. Presley Morgan Taylor of Philadelphia.

ONE of the oldest and most reprehensible reprobates in Hollywood is a grave young man of 40 or so named Walter Brennan. When prizes are given for old codgers who are no better than they should be, Brennan is the chap who wins 'em. He deserved one for his work in "Barbary Coast" and he earned one for his work in "Come and Get It."

Encouraged by President Carmichael, himself an active scientist. Tufts undergraduates have taken the first step in broadening student interest in the biological sciences and especially in biological research by founding an honorary biology club with a limited membership.

A SPECIAL performance of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" will be given at the Chicago Civic Opera House on New Year's Eve under the management of Harry Zelzer. The work will be sung by Maria Kurenko, Ada Paggi, Joseph Bentonelli, George Czapliki, Nino Ruisi, Zittorio Trevisan and Giuseppe Cavadore. Jerzy Bojanowski will conduct.

The New York Curb Exchange has removed from listing and registration Super Power Company of Illinois first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds series of 1928, due March 1, 1968, and first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds series of 1930, due Sept. 1, 1970.

The mortality rate of pneumonia patients has been reduced to about 8 per cent in seventy-five cases treated at hospitals in this city with a new drug of the sulfanilamide family, according to a report in the current issue of The American Journal of the Medical Sciences by Drs. Harrison F. Flippin and D. Sergeant Pepper of the University of Pennsylvania Medical School.

Taylor Strawn, Chicago manufacturer and civic leader, died today. He was a nephew of Silas Strawn. A former vice president of the Elgin Watch Company, at his death he was president of Dent-A-Firm Laboratories, manufacturers of dental products. Mr. Strawn served also as president of The Plan for Hospital Care, a low-cost, nonprofit group hospitalization plan, which he helped organize;

An opportunity to compare the oil paintings of students throughout the country is offered by the Department of the Interior in an exhibition now on view in the Fine Arts Gallery at Washington. Sponsored by the Office of Education with the purpose of stimulating art and art education in universities, colleges and endowed art schools, the exhibition in the college wing of the gallery is composed of work done by students of college grade.

The student of today has too much of interest before him to be vitally concerned with the learning and philosophies of the Middle Ages except as they may contribute to the solution of the problems that face him today,

The construction industry in the metropolitan district is winding up the year with brisk activity which augurs well for the early months of 1939 in nearly all classes of building work. The late months of the year have helped to build up a favorable margin over 1937 in the New York area,

Colonel Richard C. Patterson Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce and a member of the Temporary National Economic Committee, will speak on "New Frontiers for Industry" at the annual holiday luncheon of the Columbia University Alumni Federation next Tuesday at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street. Many holiday festivities have been planned in Greenwich. The Greenwich Country Club will give a dance Monday for young married couples and sub-debutantes. The children's party will be held at the club Wednesday.

New York City's defending team champions in schoolboy sports fared much better during 1938 than in 1937, when only two titles were kept. This year, in senior high school activities of the Public Schools Athletic League alone, four crowns were retained.
Ptarmigan will take the place of turkey for Royal Canadian Mounted Police stationed at this most northerly outpost of Canada on Christmas Day.

The Foreign Trade Bureau of the Department of Agriculture reported today that this season's overseas purchases of American cotton-long this nation's leading farm export commodity-were the smallest in twenty years and 41 per cent less than a year ago.

The value of permits for residential buildings issued throughout the country was 65 per cent higher in November than during the same month of last year, making that month the fifth consecutive one in 1938 to show a gain over the similar period of 1937, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins announced yesterday.

Wrestling did not succeed in altering its status as the Ishmael of the sports world during the past year. The pastime which once took rank as one of the leading and most popular forms of athletic endeavor continued to find itself beset by wrangling and discord among those at the promotional head of the professional branch of the game.

Death struck the sports world with a heavy hand during the past year as notable figures in all spheres of athletic activity succumbed. Baseball lost colorful figures in Colonel Tillinghast L'Hommedieu Huston, former co-owner of the Yankees; the venerable Stephen W.

For a few brief hours last Sunday evening those Russians who have lived for twenty years in exile in Paris permitted themselves the luxury of revived hope as they did homage to Grand Duke Vladimir, the young man who, they are agreed, should be their Czar.

THIS folio volume on the theatre in America is by an authority on the American theatre. The portion devoted to the motion picture in this country is by an authority in that field. There have been many competent histories of the American theatre and many competent books on the motion picture.

Arthur C. Veatch, well-known consulting geologist, who was head of the exploration department of the Sinclair Oil Company from 1919 to 1928, died here today at his home, 5 Central Drive, after a year's illness, at the age of 60.

All survivors of the wrecked motorship Patterson were safe today as Coast Guard cutters sped nine seamen shoreward for Christmas. Two of the twenty crew members drowned when the Patterson was driven onto bleak Cape

No new laurels are needed at this point by those masters of comic opera in English, William Schwenk Gilbert and Arthur Sullivan. Their works are already classics, known by every one, acted at one time or another by almost every one, and ardently supported by such groups as the Gilbert and Sullivan Society.
The Christmas gift of the NBC Symphony Orchestra to its radio audience was the Schoenberg arrangement of the G-minor Brahms piano quartet which Artur Rodzinski conducted last night at Radio City.
Robbers who boarded an express train en route here from Baguio killed two messengers and robbed the baggage safe of $150,000 in cash and gold bullion tonight.

The Norfolk Western Railroad has filed suit in Federal Court here asking for a judgment and accounting from the city of Chicago for $770,000 of special assessment improvements bonds issued in 1928 and due from 1932 to 1936. The road says it has received only a microscopic payment on the bonds.
The "safest November on record" was reported today by the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, which listed 237 traffic fatalities last month as compared with 273 in November, 1937.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Langley of this place, formerly of College Hill, Cincinnati, gave a tea at their home here this afternoon, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Hale Langley, to John Harris Patterson of Cincinnati, eldest son of Mrs. John H. Harris of Monrovia, Calif., and Fort Benton, Mont.
Orestes Ferrara, Secretary of State in the deposed government of President Gerardo Machado, returned to Cuba today after five years' exile.

The New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards is preparing a petition to the Governor and the Legislature of that State, requesting that they refuse to sanction any piecemeal changes in the tax laws tending to increase the tax on property until a complete revision of the taxing system has been accompolished.
SHANGHAI.-Americans residing in China for the purpose of promoting Chinese-American trade have been heavy losers during the eighteen months of hostilities between Japan and China.

The government today ordered complete administrative reorganization of the city of Marseille where there recently have been numerous robberies.

Miss Anne Frankenthaler, youngest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Frankenthaler, was guest of honor at a dinner given by her parents last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Others in the party included the Misses Ellen Marshall,
Early last week the Morrison prize of $500 was awarded to Professor Hans Bethe (Cornell) for giving us a picture of the mechanism whereby the sun and stars shine and send out heat.

THE trapper or miner or mounted policeman, doctor and wife, nursing sister or missionary, who sits up on top of the world in the frozen Arctic during the long Winter months is not nearly so isolated as most people would think.

It is good news that a hundred British motorists, members of the Junior Car Club of London, are to visit the United States next June and bring some forty English cars with them for a tour of 2,000 miles in the Eastern States. There are few ways in which to get to know any country and its people better than by touring it in a motor car.

Amendments to the Social Security Law, proposed this week by the Advisory Council on Social Security, will blossom forth in the form of new bills when Congress convenes, or in renewed support for bills presented last year.

William S. Read has been selected president of the Heights Taxpayers Protective Association. Other officers elected are: William Levy, first vice president; Louis C. Moser, second vice president; John Yackeren, third vice president; Louis Stern, treasurer; Joseph J. Karp, secretary, and Emanuel Goldberg, counsel.

Your Business, a four-page newspaper edited by Mayor Dickmann, was distributed a few days ago to more than 180,000 St. Louis homes as his unusual method of asking the taxpayers what should be done to meet present deficits, provide funds for maintaining necessary services and at the same time not increase taxes.

James W. Dunaway, for the last six years in charge of sales in the New York division of Charles P. Cochrane Company, carpet and rug manufacturers, Bridgeport, Pa., has been named general sales manager of the company, it was announced yesterday by Peter P. Hagan, president. Mrs. Ella Hervey, retired leader in Newark musical circles and widow of Daniel E., former music editor of The Newark Sunday Call, died tonight at her home, 25 Sheppard Avenue, at the age of 85.

The entire nineteenth floor of the Hotel McAlpin has been redecorated and furnished to meet the modern woman's tastes and henceforth will be used to meet the special needs of the business and traveling woman, John J. Woelfle, general manager, announced yesterday. A special library, equipped with books to meet all women's tastes, is part of the floor.
The Bureau of Supplies and Accounts of the United States Navy Department has ordered thirty-nine flat cars of fifty-ton capacity each from the Magor Car Corporation, according to Railway Age.

Mrs. Armour-Tucker of Westbury, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Elizabeth-Ann Tucker Blakemore, to W. Gillette Bird, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Kerr Bird of 375 Park Avenue and Lake George.

General Hugh S. Johnson, chairman of the Greater New York Committee for the Infantile Paralysis Fund, predicted yesterday the establishment in New York City of an infantile paralysis foundation, which would furnish free medical attention to every one in need regardless of race or creed.

Virgil Homer Hunter, New York manager of the Werner G. Smith Company of Cleveland, importers of vegetable oils, died today in the New Rochelle Hospital after an illness of one week. He was 59 years old and lived here.

Two world records were established by Americans in a year that was marked by general improvement of performances and increased interest in weight-lifting in this country. The new marks were credited to A. Lemma of Paterson, N. J., the national 112-pound champion, and A. Terlazzo of York, Pa., the 148-pound king.

Miss Dorothy Kenyon, New York attorney, will sail tomorrow on the Normandie for Geneva for the second meeting of the League of Nations Committee on the Legal Status of Women, of which she is the lone American member.

Thomas M. Duncan, former secretary and close adviser to Governor La Follette, received a pardon today from the Governor, enabling him to leave the Milwaukee House of Correction and spend Christmas with his family in Milwaukee.

Ignoring if not repudiating its stand of three years ago in favor of compulsory State health insurance, the California Medical Association has come out with a plan for a voluntary State-wide system of insurance which it hopes to put into effect by March.

Major and minor insignia awards of the Student Council were made to nine undergraduates at the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, for outstanding scholarship and extra-curricular service at the college.

A midseason term expanded to include government, economics, politics, business administration, music and dance courses will open at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, Tuesday.

Several hundred young people formed the greater part of a throng which filled the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon for a gala Christmas tea dance given in behalf of the Opportunity Shop, one of the various welfare activities of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

With the death toll fixed definitely at seven, officers today pressed their examination of scattered wreckage to learn why an Army airplane exploded and crashed near here last night.

Mrs. Millie H. Renskorf, widow of Charles Renskorf, left a bequest of $5,000 to establish "a perpetual bed in the children's ward of Mount Sinai Hospital in memory of her daughter Louise" in her will,

Miss Frani Blough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Blough of New York and Tiverton, L. I., was married to Curt Muser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Muser of this city, yesterday at noon in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Matthew Imrie.

Some of the members of Congress arriving in Washington gave notice today that reports of unnecessary spending by some government bureaus would be "smoked out" and that an effort would be made to retrieve some of the powers turned over previously to the President.
From the way tickets were going today, it looked as if the Orange Bowl football meeting of Tennessee and Oklahoma, Jan. 2, would be a tight squeeze for 29,906 spectators.

Five adult schools, each of from two to four days' duration, will be conducted at Goddard College during January: a school of agriculture, a school of handicraft, a school of Vermont cooperatives, a ski school and a conference on "Fitting the College to the Needs of Democracy."

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. George H. Gill Jr. of Albany of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Bowne Gill, to Edward Spring Gallagher, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. A. Gallagher of Great Neck, L. I.

Christmas trade wound up with a rush of buying which appeared to have been large enough to overcome merchants' fear that they would not equal the 1937 figures. The fact that a gain over 1937 was registered in the previous week brought encouragement to store executives, and their final Christmas week was sufficiently active to indicate that part of the earlier losses were made up.

The declaration of American solidarity that was finally signed today at the PanAmerican Conference is a compromise draft drawn up to conciliate twenty-one conflicting viewpoints. It does not go as far as the United States had hoped, nor nearly as far as several other countries, including Brazil, wanted to go.

IN the Italian Alps and Dolomites, Winter sports are now attracting both foreign and local visitors. Solda, near the National Park of Ortles-Cevedale, draws a varied crowd to its large skiing fields, ski school, hotels and snow festivals. Balls, music and indoor entertainments amuse persons who take their outdoor exercise in small doses.

HERE, on this bright Christmas morning, is a suggestion offered in generous holday spirit without charge to any inspired millionaire, personal or corporate, who cares to accept it. It is guaranteed to result in a great contribution to American culture, and to produce for its sponsors considerable glory besides perhaps the worst nervous breakdown in recorded history.

OUR semi-postal and two full postage stamps-with twelve varieties in all because of six counterpart items with inscriptions in Afrikaans-are the Union of South Africa's postal contributions to the national observance of the centenary of Dingaan's Day, a "bloody Sunday" in December of 1838 when a group of Dutch farmers, the historic Voortrekkers of that period, were slaughtered by black natives in Southern Africa.

Announcing its support of the Baldwin anti-peddling bill, the Uptown Chamber of Commerce made public yesterday a letter sent to Albert D. Schanzer, chairman of the City Council's Committee on Markets.

The decision of rug manufacturers to hold only one trade showing a year hereafter added a new element to the existing controversy among furniture producers about openings in that industry. Reports in the wholesale market Friday were that a number of furniture producers were in favor of the move by the rug mills and considered it worth adopting.

Miss Emma C. Haviland of this city, who retired in 1930 after serving fifty years as an employee of the New York public school system, twenty of them as prinicpal of P. S. 121, East 104th Street died in White Plains Hospital early today of injuries suffered when she slipped and fell here on Wednesday. Her age was 78.
The clay target smashers have had a busy year, and in addition to welcoming a legion of new scattergun enthusiasts to their ranks, have set new world and national records in trap and skeet.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the executive committee of the United Palestine Appeal, announced yesterday that a national conference would be held on Jan. 14 and 15 in Washington to consider the mass emigration proposals suggested by the Intergovernment Committee on Refugees in London. Jan Masaryk, former Czecho-Slovak Minister to London, will be the principal speaker.

EVERY now and then, producers, meeting together, get talking of "The Black Eye," a James Bridie play done in London in 1935 and by the Brattleboro people in Brooklyn last season. The latest name connected with the show is that of John Krimsky who now is thinking of doing it here.

Preliminary reports for the first three weeks in December show some slowing down of the advance in industrial production that began early -last Summer, but in several items the usual seasonal decrease did not occur, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Motion-picture celebrities came to this San Joaquin Valley farming community today to wish "Merry Christmas" to 5,000 children refugees from the Midwest's "dust bowl."
Press and radio reports of a bewitched child bouncing in bed, beds jumping up from the floor, chairs moving alone, ghost hands and mysterious vanishing things have recently come from here.

A collection comprising thousands of newspaper clippings relating to the World War has been presented to the library of the University of Pennsylvania by Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury. The collection is contained in 240 bound scrapbooks and is accompanied by specially constructed bookcases.

General business conditions in the United States and Canada remained unchanged in the last thirty days but there were a number of cases of improvement in specific lines, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported yesterday. Gains compared with the month before were noticeable in the movement of holiday goods,

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

WINTER sports, we are assured, have now come into their own. As soon as the professional hockey leagues go into action and the ice ballets open shop we are reminded on every hand that it is time to buy ski pants or skating skirts and that there is or soon will be ice on the lakes and snow in the Adirondacks.

The adequate daytime illumination within the house, the window area should equal 17 per cent of the floor area, according to a Soule Steel Company report based on a United States Public Health Service survey.

Captain Granville Conway, head of the Maritime Commission office in New York, announced last night that the commission's freighter Schodak, carrying eighteen seamen and two women rescued at sea on Friday, would arrive in New York early this afternoon. Captain Clifton Smith, master of the rescue ship, reported he would reach Quarantine at 2 P. M. and dock in Hoboken several hours later.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Buist C. Chitty of Miami, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Chitty, to James Spencer Taintor Jr. of Miami, son of Mr. and Mrs. Taintor of West Hartford, Conn.

More than 1,000 delegates and visitors from American schools and colleges are expected to attend the fourth national convention of the American Student Union which will open at City College, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, tomorrow morning. Sessions will continue through Friday.

New York State Socialists will join the American Labor party as individuals, Harry W. Laidler, State chairman of the Socialist party, announced yesterday. This action, the result of a referendum vote of Socialist party members just completed, followed the loss of legal political party status

Miss Josephine Schain, chairman of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, has been appointed president of the Chautauqua Woman's Club, a fifty-yearold organization. She is its fifth president, the others having been Mrs. Emily Huntington Miller, Mrs. B. T. Vincent, Mrs. Percy V. Pennybacker and Mrs. William H. Alexender.

The State Labor Relations Board yesterday certified the American Federation of Labor Organization Council of 635 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, as collective bargaining agent for persons employed in the delivery, maintenance, store service, warehousing,

Expenditures on the recreation centers as well as the parks and parkways in Westchester County will be curtailed in 1939 if the new budgets under consideration by the Board of Supervisors are adopted. Drafted by board leaders, the budgets probably will be approved next Thursday, supervisors said.

Members of a junior committee, headed by Miss Patricia Schepps, are working on plans for a special performance of monologues by Cornelia Otis Skinner on Jan. 6 at the New York Junior League. Proceeds of the event, the program of which will include "The Wives of Henry VIII," will aid the Church Mission of Help.

A program under which the State of New York would guarantee mortgages was advanced last week by Frederick W. Nehring of Nehring Brothers, Inc., at a meeting of the Heights Taxpayers Protective Association.

To be new in design, furniture need not necessarily follow the contemporary style; it may suggest styles of the past. Early American maple pieces, for example, have formed the basis for the so-called colonial modern, and the baroque style has been reinterpreted in today's more restrained taste.

Three years ago he was a sharecropper-had been one for twenty years and expected he always would be one. With his wife and four children he lived in a typical cropper's cabin-poorly furnished, with cracks in the walls inadequately covered with paper. At the end of the year his "furnish" from the

In the week that remains of the old year, leaders in women's organizations and clubs may find it profitable to review their annals for 1938, if only in preparation for the new year which gives every promise of calling on them for new resourcefulness and abilities.

With the revised CanadaUnited States trade agreement coming into operation on Jan. 1, the National Revenue Department has issued new instructions for administering clauses in the tariff schedule dealing with iron and steel machinery and cotton fabrics.

Doremus Co. of New York City, an advertising agency, said today in behalf of Dillon, Read Co. of New York, investment bankers, that the banking house had "no interest whatsoever" in the proposed financing of the Nebraska Public Power Districts' purchase of private electric properties in Nebraska.

Mr. and Mrs. George Walker Sykes of Conifer, N. Y., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Louise Sykes, to Dr. Philip Medford Le Compte of New Haven, Conn., son of Professor Irville Charles Le Compte of the University of Minnesota and Mrs. Le Compte.

The marriage of Miss Edith Grabois, daughter of Mrs. Nathan Grabois of New York and the late Mr. Grabois, to Joseph Wald, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wald, also of this city, took place last evening in the Embassy suite of the Ambassador.
Engagements of $4,975,000 of gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the amount $4,232,000 was engaged in England and $743,000 in Holland.

Professional football, which had set a new attendance record in drawing more than a million spectators the season before, continued its sensational progress during the past year as it touched a new high in crowd appeal, more than 1,100,000 fans making the turnstiles click at National League games.

With more and more women seeking jobs in business and industry, one of America's most debated individuals in 1939 may be the married woman who holds on to her job in order to increase the family income. Is she right or isn't she?

To the Art Editor: NATHALIE SWAN, in her letter of last Sunday, is making no startling revelation by pointing out that various European art movements had their influence on the Bauhaus. The Bauhaus never denied this.

HERMAN, DORA C. (Dec. 16). Estate, approximately $10,000. To Jessica J. Plehn, niece, executrix, 23 W. 73d St., residue. RENSKORF, MILLIE H. (Dec. 23). Estate, more than $10,000. To Mount Sinai Hospital, $5,000; Paul M. Herzog, nephew, 333 E. 57th St.:

To help continue the work of occupational therapy, which in 1938 brought release and happiness to 7,000 patients at Bellevue Hospital, a tea dance will be given on Jan. 6 in the Embassy suite of the Ambassador. The proceeds will augment a fund which is used to bring back the use of mind and muscle by carefully graded occupation.

The Real Estate Board of New York reports the addition of twenty-one names to its roster. Those added to the brokerage division are Louis Fisch, H. C. Lemle, E. M. Simmonds, J. T. Hebb Greenwell Jr., Thomas E. Murray, Clyde S. Blair Jr., A. K. Howell, Marcel Leschot, H. L. Mitchell, M. Edward Reiner, A. G. Robertson, J. N. Burt, Louis Eierman and Harold N. Warsawer.

Considerable research work is being done toward solving the problem of how to make houses quieter, according to the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. The trend in the construction of the better type of houses is to keep harsh outdoor noises from entering the house and to reduce the volume of indoor noise.

WITHIN the short time that my heart has been in the highlands between Thirtyeighth and Fifty-second Streets I have heard a good deal about that play on Byron which one person or another seems to set himself to every calendar year. Brian Aherne once said that he had read nineteen plays on the poet-a fact that does not make the author of this play burst with pride.

Bonds maintained a firm undertone through the short pre-holiday session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Further sizable gains in several sections of the railroad list were registered, with many of the secondary carrier loans gaining 1 to 2 points.

Students of the Marymount Day School will hold their annual tea dance tomorrow in the Walnut Room of the school at 1,027 Fifth Avenue for their philanthropic enterprises. In charge of arrangements is Miss Madelon Friel, whose aides include the Misses Joan Murray, Mary Frances Lasette, Adrienne Mordaunt, Joan Kelly, Jane Glynn, Muriel Fullen and Betty Mullins.
Major Gen. Philippe Fequant, World War hero and inspector general of French military aviation, died today at the age of 55 of a heart ailment.
HOLLYWOOD. AGAIN the arroyos and the canyons of the West are resounding to the declamations of the glamour boys astride their pintos.
The New York Rovers staged a four-goal rally in the third period and tied the Atlantic City Sea Gulls in an Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League overtime game tonight. The score was 5 to 5.

Sefiora Salvadora de Bayle Somoza, wife of the President, distributed 25,000 gifts to poor children today, the largest group of children ever assembled in Managua. The wives of Cabinet members and high government officials helped make the children happy.

" The Giant's Awakening" may soon be the play enacted in official Washington, as the result of the change in the command of the Commerce Department, which is housed in one of the largest Federal buildings in the capital.

The money market here has sensed the shortage of supplies at the year-end as a result of the efflux of foreign money that has left Great Britain in recent months, and today dealers paid the Bank of England 2 1/2 per cent for small amounts over Jan. 1, although the Bank rate was only 2 per cent.

Better constructed and better designed buildings will be erected in the coming year of prosperity forecasted for the United States by N. Max Dunning, chairman of the structural service committee of the American Institute of Architects.

General Severiano Martinez Anido, Insurgent Minister of Public Order, one of the high ranking officials of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's government, died today. He was Secretary of State under Premier Primo de Rivera and was a former Governor of Barcelona Province.

Cornelius Otto, 74-year-old fisherman, of 108 Colton Avenue, Sayville, was killed in the cabin of his 35-foot clamming boat, Missie K, at 8 o'clock today when gasoline fumes in its hold became ignited and exploded, tearing the cabin from the vessel.

The discovery of radium has placed Canada in a prominent position in the world uranium market as well as in the supply of one of the most important modern adjuncts of medical science, declares the Canadian Pacific.

Thomas J. Watson, who as president of the International Chamber of Commerce recently surveyed conditions in European countries, will speak on his observations abroad at the fortieth annual dinner of the Society of the Genesee, on Monday night, Jan. 23, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, according to an announcement yesterday by Jesse S. Phillips, president of the society.

The indictment here this week for alleged violation of the anti-trust laws of the American Medical Association and two constituent bodies has brought into the public eye probably the most powerful professional society in America-one exercising almost as strong influence over its field as ever the medieval guilds did over theirs.

Christmas cards received today by friends of John Montague, "wizard" of golf, and Mrs. Esther Plunkett, wealthy Beverly Hills matron, revealed that the couple had been married. Reached at her home, she said that the wedding had taken place "some time ago in California," but declined to give details.

At its last meeting before the holidays the Cabinet Council issued an order today prohibiting the fornation of new political parties without previous government approval. In so doing the government apparently intends to perpetuate the present two-party system.

PRINTS and paintings of musical interest, by old and modern masters, are a feature of the exhibition of antique musical instruments at the Newark Museum until March 26. The exhibition was arranged in connection with the museum's series of Sunday afternoon concerts and the community program of the Griffith Music Foundation.

ONE of the most frenzied battles of the century is on, one that will take its place in history beside the epic of the short skirt and the struggle over to-bob-or-not-to-bob. This one assumes major proportions because after about two and a half centuries of doing more or less as they have been told, American females are stirring in rebellion at a fashion edict.

T. H. Lawrence led in a field of twenty-five in a Christmas shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. He scored by breaking 97 out of 100. N. E. Sprague and B. M. Higginson topped the Class A handicap group with 97 each.

MARY CONGER was a little girl in the Nineties in a solid and spacious brownstone house in West Twentieth Street. and with those memories she begins and ends her singularly vivid and colorful little book But the memories of her family in New York go back 300 years and six generations, and it is these which furnish forth this full-bodied tale.

Lieut. Col. Joseph P. Vachon, U. S. A., and Mrs. Vachon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Mary Vachon, to Cadet Everett DeWitt Light of the United States Military Academy at West Point.

Archery's 1938 national champions were Miss Jean Tenney of Clearspring, Md., and Pat Chambers of Portland, Ore. These contestants came through against large fields of strong rivals in the fifty-eighth annual meet of the National Archery Association, held during August in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park.

The country telephone line, with all the neighbors listening in and joining the conversation every now and then, was not much worse than the present overcrowded radio ranges in use on the nation's airways, and the only solution is a change to

Mrs. Edward H. Loftin of Washington, D. C., has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Loftin, to Dr. Carl Gifford Whitbeck, son of Judge and Mrs. John V. Whitbeck Jr. of Hudson, N. Y.

ONE of the happiest customs of our great holiday season, the custom of drinking a health, comes to us from the earliest times. Not that health drinking is confined to the Christmas season, but certainly at that time there seems to be a deep and real sincerity in good wishes proffered one to another.

Reports that Quebec Provincial police officers had ordered Montreal landlords within the past few days to evict tenants of known Communist tendencies under threat of padlocking the occupied premises were confirmed in part by the police tonight.

ABEL--MARKOE--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Markoe announce the marriage of their daughter, Dorothy, to Mr. Ezra Abel on Sunday, Nov. 27, 1938. BARNETT--SCHULMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Schulman, 850 St. Mark's Ave., Brooklyn, announce marriage of daughter, Ada, to Mr. Sidney Barnett, taking place Dec. 25, 1938.

A revision of the first five books of the Bible, the Pentateuch, of the King James Version -will near completion this month when the American Standard Bible Committee meets in the divinity school at Yale University.

Many seats have been purchased for the concert to be given by present and former members of the choir of St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, L. I., on Wednesday afternoon at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street, to raise funds for the restoration of the church's pipe organ, which was damaged by the hurricane last September.

The Middle West made a clean sweep of all the major honors in bowling during 1938, winning every title in sight at the thirty-eighth American Bowling Congress tournament for men at Chicago and the twenty-first Women's International Bowling Congress meet at Cincinnati.

THESE are big days for books on monopoly. On the jacket of this one is an octopus holding in its tentacles production, refining, pipe lines, patents, exports, jobbers, dealer and consumer, and prices ( of oil). The octopus represents the major oil companies of the United States, both Standard and others.

Gifts and bequests to Princeton University during the last fiscal year totaled $2,015,390, according to the annual report of Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president, to the board of trustees, which is made public each year on Christmas Eve.
Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Sommers of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Sommers, to Robert Greenson of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Green of South Orange.

SACRAMENTO, Calif. (Science Service).-A special safety drive directed at Christmas shoppers each December and "conspicuous policing" on the open road in the summertime are recommendations for safety work made here by Victor W. Killick, chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the California Department of Motor Vehicles, on the basis of a statistical analysis of California automobile accidents.

One of the most important movements in the history of the light harness turf in the United States was initiated during the Autumn, and successive steps since have brought nearer to fruition an eventuality that has been the ideal of leaders of the trotting world for many years.

Cozy basement recreation rooms, clean and airy, are being provided in an increasing number of modern homes, it is reported. They are used for game and party rooms by youngsters and adults. The introduction of bin-feeding stokers is said to be giving impetus to the movement.
Adding one more chapter to the volume of unexpected sports achievements, the Chicago Black Hawks won the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the professional hockey championship of the world, last April.

The Little Theatre at Wheaton College, now the background for experimental production of drama as old as Shakespeare's "The Tempest" and as new as Auden's "Dog Beneath the Skin," traces its origin to an abandoned garage where in 1932 college girls first made their properties from old boxes and their stage curtains from burlap bags.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Allerton Kingman of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Kingman, to John Weir Perry, son of Bishop and Mrs. James DeWolf Perry, also of Providence. Bishop Perry is a former Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

ANTHOLOGIES of prose, poetry and plays appear this season with the same frequency that plans for spending germinate in Washington, and this poses the question of what service, if any, is rendered by such piecemeal collections.

THE first five of the twelve chamber music programs this season at the Library of Congress under the auspices of the Gertrude Clarke Whittall Foundation have been performed this month by the Budapest and the Gordon string quartets.

IN a strong finish, holiday trade for the country as a whole probably ran ahead of last year's in dollars as well as physical volume. The final spurt brought a lift in the unit transaction, and the extra shopping day in the week lent the needed push to achieve the figures required. The closing strength of consumer purchasing had been underestimated.

During the thirty-five years since the First American Rhodes scholars were sent to Oxford University Princeton University has contributed sixty-one scholars to the total list of 1,126. Harvard is second with forty-five, closely pressed by Yale with forty-two.

LORD MACAULAY VICTORIAN LIBERAL. By Richmond Croom Beatty Svo. Norman, Okla.: University of Oklahoma Press. $3. A biography by the author of "Bayard Taylor." JOHN MILTON THE ELDER AND HIS MUSIC. By Ernest Brennecke Jr. Svo. New York: Columbia University Press. $3.50. A biographical and critical study of the Elizabethan composer.

The gardens, lawns and rooms of the Towers formed the setting today for a large tea and cocktail party, at which A. Atwater Kent was host. A lighted Christmas tree stood on the lawn and another in the living room and at dusk a male quartet sang carols and old songs in which the guests joined.

GEORGE GERSHWIN died on July 11, 1937, and now, more than a year later, comes this collective tribute to the man and the artist. It contains almost forty pieces of varying length by men and women who worked with George Gershwin or who valued his music. Composers, conductors, stage directors, singers, playwrights and critics are among those represented.

There will be no live puppies in the stockings of the Dionne quintuplets tomorrow although they asked Santa Claus through their friend, Dr. Allan R. Dafoe, for dogs such as they played with in their latest moving picture.

A nation-wide study of the operation of the Unemployment Compensation Act is being carried on by the League of Women Voters to prepare its members for any changes that may be introduced in Legislatures at their next sessions.

The most significant step taken in lawn bowling during the year was the formation of an Eastern and a Western division to govern the sport, both with their own officers and both running their own tournaments, but remaining under the jurisdiction of the American Lawn Bowling Association.

Plans for the cooperation of the Aeronautical Engineering Society at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the faculty are being formulated and a construction program will be put into effect as soon as the necessary money is raised by a drive among alumni and faculty This canvass will be started soon, but already sufficient funds have been obtained to begin the first phase of the work.

Modern bowmen have been shooting at deer and other game all over the country, but three Nashville archers are going into the "hit-orelse" department with a foray against wild boars. Dr. Harlan G. Metcalf of the Peabody College faculty, Tom McNish and Ed McNish have been

SHEPHERDS still watch their flocks on the rugged slopes below Bethlehem of Judaea. "abiding in the field" by night. just as did the shepherds of long ago who saw "the angel of the Lord" and heard the first Christmas message.
The Socialist party congress, after attempting to forestall a split over foreign policy by appointing a compromise committee at its opening meeting, failed tonight to reach the projected compromise.

Howard E. Morton, Sunday editor of The New York Journal and American, died late Friday night at the Lenox Hill Hospital following an attack of heart disease. He was 60 years old and had been associated with the Hearst newspapers since, 1900 in capacities ranging from reporter, feature writer and foreign correspondent to editor.

Preparations were made for ice yachting on a large scale last Winter. The Eastern Ice Yachting Association was formed and a check showed more than 300 ice yachts within a radius of fifty miles of New York City.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gershaw of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Lorraine Gershaw, to Robert Kenneth Leon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Leon, also of Brooklyn.

Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, and Israel A. Horowitz met in the ninth game of their match for the championship of the American Chess Federation at the Manhattan rooms yesterday, the result being another draw in sixty moves.

According to the United States Board of Tax Appeals, a corporation is subject to the undistributed profits tax (under the Revenue Act of 1936) despite the existence of a deficit and irrespective of the fact that the laws of the State of incorportion prohibit the payment of dividends except out of surplus.

Duke University's football squad, flanked by 200 rooters and trailed by more, reached the Rose Bowl battlefront today to conclude preparations for the encounter Jan. 2 with Southern California. A warm greeting was extended to the lads from Durham, N. C., a team with a season's record never before equaled by a- Rose Bowl eleven.

Unless the dictators soon give Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain something that he can call a "sign" of their peaceful intentions, there is going to be a formidable energizing of the British rearmament program before 1939 grows old.

With real chinchilla coats selling anywhere from $50,000 to $100,000 apiece-there are said to be only about twelve in the world-it occurred to Fletcher Roberts, a New Zealander residing in England, that it might be worthwhile to attempt to raise chinchillas.

A forum for the discussion of retailer-manufacturer problems to be held in conjunction with the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, either during or after the sessions, has been suggested by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., in a letter to Lew Hahn, general manager of the retailers' organization.
Declaration of the Solidarity of America. Eighth Inter-American Conference of American States. Considering:

The publicity committee of the Woman's Press Club will have charge of the December program to be given Saturday at 2 P. M. at the Pennsylvania Hotel. It will include an address by Mrs. Anna Steese Richardson, on "What Should Today's Woman Know?"

TO the literature of disillusionment that has followed on the collapse of the League of Nations and the full flowering of power politics should be added the keen analysis of the period of illusion now offered by the Professor of Economics at Smith College.

Explaining the French prohibition on munitions shipments across the Indo-China frontier to China, high French officials here virtually admit the existence of an informal French-Japanese accord by which the Japanese will not occupy Hainan Island in return for a French ban on armaments cargoes to the Chinese.
ASTOR-Pygmalion: Leslie Howard, Wendy Hiller.* BELMONT-The Little Flower of Jesus.* CAMEO-Professor Mamlock.* CAPITOL-Sweethearts: Nelson Eddy, Jeanette MacDonald.
Christmas morning finds the Neediest Cases Fund for 1938 standing at a total of $226,423.85, to which it was raised by 701 gifts aggregating $11,330.98 that were received yesterday.

Horace Hutchins Work Jr. of Madison, N. J., who was married to Miss Leonie Tilghman, also of Madison, N. J., has purchased a tract of forty-seven acres at New Vernon, in Morris County, N. J.,close to Madison, for early improvement with a large residence.

Mrs. Alfred Leeb of South Orange gave a large Christmas Eve tea dance this afternoon at the Rock Spring Club, West Orange, to introduce to society her two granddaughters, the Misses Martha and Joan Leeb, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Brian P. Leeb of Llewellyn Park.
Football players from Georgia Tech and University of California will be knocking each other all over the lot on Monday, but tonight they got together to act as chummy as a bunch of bugs in a blanket.

Swordsmen from New York University shattered all precedents last season by winning the intercollegiate three-weapon crown for the fourth year in a low. Thus they contributed the standout feat of the 1938 fencing campaign.

THOUSANDS of new radios with electrified music running through their thin copper arteries for the first time find the old, traditional songs of Christmas, such as "Adeste Fideles" and "Silent Night, Holy Night," mark this day on the air.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur John Bowron of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lorol Roden Bowron, to Norris Rediker of New York, son of Mrs. Amasa Clair Boobar of Calais, Me., and of the late Randolph Sanford Rediker of Minneapolis.

Dr. Bernhard Kugelmann of 3,247 Johnson Avenue, Riverdale, Bronx, a specialist in internal medicine, who came to this country as a refugee from Germany in 1934, died yesterday in the Wickersham Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 38.

Mr. and Mrs. George E. Dennen of 82 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Rita Dennen, to John Banker Muldoon, son of Mrs. Thomas J. Muldoon, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Muldoon.

Because Philadelphia faces a serious financial crisis, the city was urged today by Dr. George E. Nitzsche, Recorder of the University of Pennsylvania, to sell Independence Hall and Independence Square to raise funds to balance the municipal budget.

As usual, books for children sold very well before Christmas. On such evidence we might flatter ourselves that we are building up the best sort of reading habits among the young-habits that will last through childhood, youth, and perhaps even later life. Any such conclusion would be flattery indeed.

Electrical and other heating devices were used by English football clubs to defeat wintry conditions that earlier in the week promised to force postponement of opening games in the heavy holiday program.

No less real because he lives only in the imagination of the very young, Santa Claus comes to town again today, sans cold, sans snow, sans sleigh, but with his pack bulging with toys and food for old and young, rich and poor, a welcome visitor to a world glad to forget its troubles for a day and relive one of life's most pleasant experiences, the giving and receiving of gifts.
Colonel W. F. (Bill) Hooker, former newspaper man, Western pioneer and author of books about the West, died here today after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

Congressional opposition developed today to some recommendations of President Roosevelt's special committee on railroad legislation. Chairman Wheeler of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee and Senator Norris said that they would fight any effort to repeal the long-and-short haul rate clause of the Interstate Commerce Act.

Three hundred and sixty-eight starting craft on the opening day of Larchmont Race Week, which was a new record for a single regatta in this country, forty-three contestants in the race to Bermuda, which was won by Henry C. Taylor's yawl Baruna, and the activity of the international twelve-meter sloops were the outstanding features of the past yachting year.

It is the night before Christmas, but all through the House--and the Senate-creatures much larger than mice can be heard stirring. Lambs are turning into lions on the Democratic side, and already it is evident that when Congress meets on Jan. 3 the roaring will begin.

The Rev. and Mrs. E. Atkinson Ware of Washington, Ga., and Lakeland, Fla., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Frances Ware Cox, to Edward Richard Ahlborn, son of Mrs. Edward J. R. Ahlborn of New York, and the late Mr. Ahlborn.

LAKELAND, Fla.-If any of the 2,500,000 visitors expected in Florida this season fail- to find diversion to their liking, it will be perfectly proper to set them down as hopeless misanthropes who enjoy being miserable, for there never has been such resolute preparation to make tourists have a good time. Community calendars are fairly bulging with events.

The fourteen-room house on a plot 100 by 115 feet at 810-12 Castile Point, Hoboken, N. J., has been sold by the estate of the late Mayor Patrick Griffin to the trustees of the Sigma House Association of Hoboken.

THE unusual string of successes for women players in competition with the best men during the past year was mentioned in this column last Sunday. On the same day Mrs. Edith Russell and Mrs. Anne Naiman won the Mayfair Bridge Club's special tournament for an all-expense trip to the Southeastern tournament which begins in Hollywood Beach, Fla., on March 16.

Austrian and German refugees gathered before a Christmas tree at the Hotel Commodore yesterday to give thanks that they were safe and free in this country, and to promise "everlasting allegiance" to their new homeland.

Although the 1938 campaign will ways be recalled as the one which aw Marse Joe McCarthy's Yankees achieve the unprecedented feat of inning their third straight world eries title, the past year was one whichh supplied more than its share f unusual and startling happenigs.

Speaker Bankhead carried Winston County, Ala., in the last election for the first time in his political career, but a Republican colleague in the House jokingly claimed the credit today. Representative Dewey Short of Missouri sent a "bill" to the Speaker for his contribution.

Many home properties in Brooklyn have been sold by the Mortgagees Realty Service, Inc., real estate decision of the Home Title Guaranty Company, as agent for various individual and institutional investors. The transactions included the one-family houses at 81 Lefferts Place, to the Rev. Isaac I. Alleyne; 1,324 East Thirty-seventh Street to Rose Hempfling, through Richard Reimer;

Nostalgia for the hot sun pounding through a cloudless, brilliant blue sky, for palm trees nodding in the breeze, for a wide coral beach and a sparkling, welcoming sea seizes the window shopper who combs through the clothes and odds and ends in the shops meant for lucky girls who can take a Winter vacation.

This year, for the first time, a new ruling became effective at the annual Sieger or championship show for German shepherd dogs held in Cologne. The famous exhibition is given under the auspices of the Fachschaft fuer Deutsche Schaeferhunde, the parent club of the breed in Germany.
The Department of Commerce said today that the United States furnished 50.2 per cent of Colombia's imports for the first nine months of this year.
TODAY Music Hall of the Air symphony orchestra, conducted by Erno Rapee, with Robert Weede, baritone, in an hour Christmas broadcast: WJZ, 12 M. Fantasy, from "Hansel and Gretel,"
A "pattern of values" of the average student of Hiram College has been evolved from a summary of anonymous questionnaires circulated over a period of nine weeks at the college.

Shots that rang out over Marco Polo Bridge in far-off Ch in July of 1937 re-echoed through the sports world last Summer wh Japan, deep in her undeclared with China, yielded her right stage the 1940 Olympic Games.

To the Drama Editor: THINGS about Broadway that a visiting fireman can't understand: How a playwright of long training in the theatre like Elmer Rice can write a deplorable mess like "American Landscape."

Declaring that legal censorship of motion pictures had failed to attain any worthwhile ends, Professor Frederic M. Thrasher, technical director of the Metropolitan Motion Picture Council and director of the Motion Picture Study at New York University,

Arguments over the German claim that a shortage of international exchange has forced her into barter transactions in world trade gave rise to widespread discussions among foreign traders here last week. A large group of exporters, headed by Louis B. Potter, export manager of the Block Drug Company,
Although held down most of the time by accurate bowling, England scored 326 runs for six wickets in the opening day's play of the first of the five-game test series against South Africa yesterday.

Two men accused of attempted extortion from a Police Department applicant were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate August Dreyer in the Felony Court and held without bail for a hearing next Tuesday.

Charging that the business of two concerns was "not conducted in public interest," Charles F. J. Harrington, State Insurance Commissioner, today ordered the Broad Street Mutual Casualty Company and the Canton Mutual Liability Company, both of Boston, to suspend business immediately.

Bishop William T. Manning conducted the annual Crib Service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday. After leading in a recitation of the Lord's Prayer, the Bishop gave his blessing to the congregation.

Chairmen and vice chairmen of twenty-five standing committees for 1939 were announced yesterday by the board of governors of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx, headed by Henry G. Waltemade, president. Among the chairmen chosen are: James A. Houlihan, admissions;

Speed-boat racing weathered two hurricanes in 1938, both during September. One tossed thousands of pleasure craft on the beach and will give factories and shipyards overtime work during the Winter and Spring, replacing a few million dollars' worth of hulls, motors and accessories.
THE gowns that bridge 1938 and 1939 are indicative of the temper of the woman of today. They show only too plainly her determination to accept what will best express her endorsement of charm.

WITH Winter, the second of her semi-annual tourist seasons at hand, Mexico again is offering to visitors the daylight rail trip in either direction between Mexico City and Vera Cruz as one of her attractions.

Mussolini now wishes to go back on the record for twenty years and to collect what he thinks was due Italy for fighting on the side of the Allies in the World War. This was made clear to France in the communication from Rome notifying Paris that the 1935 understanding between Mussolini and Premier Laval was no longer in force. The Italians have also notified Britain of their position.

An order that a $550,000 trust fund be set up under the will of Dever H. Warner, Bridgeport industrialist, for the benefit of his widow, Mrs. Flora Martin Warner, was entered today by Judge William Bent in Fairfield Probate Court.
Formal study of the art of debate has become one of the favored electives in the curriculum of Georgian Court College, officials of the institution announced today after a three-month survey.

According to authoritative statements, the subscription of the latest 1,500,000,000mark government loan, announced Nov. 19, is proceeding "normally," and Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, has announced that half the loan has already been subscribed, although subscriptions will not close until Jan. 19.

About 4,000 volumes of old and Rare school books have been added to the shelves of the general and Clements libraries of the University of Michigan, according to announcement in the university's School of Education Bulletin.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Pike Fessenden of Newton Center, Mass., and Franklin, N. H., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Ruth Fessenden, to Calvin Powell Eldred 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Powell Eldred of Dedham, Mass.

An elaborate extension of the broadcasting building with five underground studios sunk deeper than the vaults of the Bank of England, the whole costing more than $5,000,000, is announced in the London papers by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

The pleasure of searching the stars with an instrument made by their own hands has been realized by astronomy students at Mount Holyoke College, who recently completed several years of work in constructing a six-inch reflecting telescope now housed in Williston Observatory.

When this Fund was inaugurated in 1912 it was hoped that it might reach a hundred of the neediest in this great city and it was therefore named the "Hundred" Neediest Fund. But that hope was disappointed. There were only 177 gifts and only 14 cases were relieved.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-With Christmas carols ringing through the lobbies local hotel men are busy completing arrangements for a week of entertainment for their guests.

Nearly all the large estates in the hunting country of Virginia are filled over the holidays with house parties made up largely of New Yorkers with a sprinkling of Washingtonians, and with chasing the fox as the Yuletide sport.

Mild as the Winter of 1937-38 was, it did not provide the complete washout of the Winter before as far as bobsledding was concerned. Thus, there was competition at Lake Placid for the North American four-man, the North American two-man and the national four and two-man titles.

After four straight favorites had failed to show the proper Yuletide spirit, along came the reliable Jockey Eddie Arcaro astride the Larch Hill Stable's consistent Histrionic to break the ice in the Christmas Eve Purse, feature at Tropical Park today.

A VISITOR from another world, looking round at the Earth people, would note that enormous numbers of them appear in the news. Presidents, prime ministers, park commissioners, district attorneys, debutantes, ambassadors, actresses, airmen, quintuplets, skaters, spies, sword-rattlers--day after day they troop through the newspapers, the news reels and the radio bulletins in a personality parade so long that the strange visitor would say it included the bulk of the human race.

Declaring that the traditional American "melting-pot" ideal has so far proved to be a failure, Professor Francis J. Brown of the Deapartment of Sociology of the New York University School of Education yesterday issued a seven-point program designed to combat the rise of racial group intolerance in the United States.

The Atlantia Ocean will assume an increased significance in the world's naval strategy early next year when the fleets of two nationsthe American and thee French-hold extensive naval manoeuvres over a widespread area of the "Western Ocean."

The Phliadelphia State Hospital at Byberry, known as the Philadelphia Hospital for Mental Diseases until the Pennsylvania government took it over two months ago, "does not rate the appellation of hospital," its new superintendent, Dr. H. C. Woolley, reported to the board of trustees today.

Only two champions were able to retain their crowns in the cycling realm through the past year. Jan Van der Vyver of The Netherlands kept his title as the amateur sprint champion of the world and Mickey Francoise of Montclair, N. J., for the third time in succession, held his sway over the amateur sprint pedallers of the United States.

LIKE all Dorothy Lathrop's drawings of small, shy animals, those in "Hide and Go Seek" give the reader the feeling that he is going tiptoe through the woods in order not to disturb the small creatures which this artist so magically shows him.

The American-Hawaiian Steam, ship Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, for the eleven months to Nov. 30, reports a net profit of $536,718, after expenses and depreciation, but before Federal income taxes. This compares with a net profit of $130,737 for the first eleven months of last year.

The Eighth Pan-American Conference crowned its labors today with the unanimous announcement that the republics of the Western Hemisphere intend to make common cause in the face of a threat to the peace, security or territorial integrity of any one of them whatever may be the nature of the acts deemed threatening.

THE story of Soviet China is told by Nym Wales in her THE book, "Inside Red China," which Doubleday, Doran Co. will publish in January. Nym Wales is the wife of Edgar Snow, the correspondent who wrote "Red Star Over China."

A new combination of governmentinsured savings accounts with life insurance is being offered by a group of Federal savings and loan associations in this city, it was announced yesterday. Under the plan, for $5 a month a saver can accumulate $1,000 in about fifteen years. If he dies before the contract is

Oscar Pinder, 39 years old, of 42-07 Bell Boulevard, Bayside, and Joseph Herbert, 23, of 131-38 Forty-first Avenue, Flushing, were freed yesterday from the Queens city prison in Long Island City on an order resulting from Supreme Court Justice Algeron I. Nova's decision.
Canadian gold production in October amounted to $14,525,809, against $14,385,573 in September, according to figures by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

The Rev. John J. Brennan, 31 years old, assistant rector of St. Donato's Catholic Church in West Philadelphia, was burned to death this morning when fire, attributed to a short-circuit in electrical Christmas decorations, swept the rectory.

TO modern audiences the Nativity plays have an innocent quality that is wholly disarming. In comparison with the trumpery and bravado of modern playmaking, the artless words of the sacred fable and the meager business of the Nativity ritual glow with the homage of simple people;

With a somewhat extensive building program at Amherst College having been brought to an end with the completion of the alumni gymnasium and Harold I. Pratt swimming pool, a new infirmary, the Kirby Memorial Theatre and an addition to the Converse Memorial Library, the administration is now directing its attention to the problems of housing and eating, which have become acute in recent years because of the record enrollment of students.
Lord Selsdon, former Postmaster General, died in London tonight following a collapse Friday. His age was 61. He had just returned from Italy, apparently in perfect health, when he was stricken.

The American Federation of Labor, in an editorial today in its weekly news service, declared that the unemployment benefits under the Social Security Act were inadequate. "The evident inadequacy of the weekly compensation to provide jobless workers and their dependents

A four-day series of twenty leatures an real estate management will be given by the institute of real estate management, affiliate the National. Association of Real Estate Boards, at the Wardman Park Hotel, Washington, D. C., Feb. 13, 14, 15 and 16.

THIS easy flowing Canadian study makes a most useful and unclouded narrative, although it is based on a slight bibliography and does not approach Anglo-American relations with any new information or approach. The growth of AngloAmerican friendship cannot be fully explained by a diplomatic study of "world politics";

Lock 24, Baldwinsville, was adjudged today the best in New York's barge canal system. State Canals Commissioner Harvey O. Schermerhorn said the award was made after an annual inspection to determine the ability of the employes, the efficiency of maintenance and operation of equipment.

OUR contemporary, The Railroad Trainman, published by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, is responsible for the following apt definition: "The smallest perceptible unit of time has been defined as the difference between the moment the traffic light changes and the driver of the car behind you honks his horn. "

Activity in residential realty in the Great Neck section of Long Island is reported by Howard L. Friend, broker. Saddle Rock Estates is constructing an eight-room colonial house on Robin Way for Theodore J. Israel, New York coffee broker, under a building contract arranged by Mr. Friend.

The year 1938 in boxing will always be known for the ascendency of the Negro. Never in modern history has the domination of ebonycolored warriors been so emphatic. Joe Louis reigned supreme. Henry Armstrong was so weighted with ring crowns he found it expedient voluntarily to surrender one, but he was the proud possessor of two as the year closed.

Poor Christmas spirit! Sometimes it seems as dead as Marley's ghost. In some countries it is illegal and can only be expressed furtively. Hang up the wreaths, trim the fireplace with holly, sing the English carols, or that fine old hymn of Luther's, or that lovely, reverent song that Father Josef Mohr of Salzburg wrote:

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity corsisted principally of small amounts of municipal, public utility, foreign and real estate issues. A majority of the prepayments ordered will be effected in January. Bonds called for redemption in December to date now total $289,-

George H. Davis, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared in a year-end statement today on the business situation that an upturn was in progress and that it had sufficient momentum...

The engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Graves of 86 East End Avenue, this city, to Jerome B. Fisher Jr. of New York and Jamestown, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fisher of Jamestown, has been announced by Mrs. Charles Everett Holmes of Allenhurst, N. J.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Zimmerman of this city gave a dinner tonight at the Duluth Woman's Club, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Fay Zimmerman, to Bernard James Miller, son of Mrs. James L. Miller of Northampton, Mass., and the late Mr. Miller.

Domei, Japanese news agency, dispatches from Hakodate reported that the Soviet Consulate there had been closed on orders of the Soviet Embassy "because of the present state of RussoJapanese relations," strained over negotiating a new fishing rights treaty.

The juiciest bit of political news that gossips have had to chew on in a long time was supplied this week in the form of an attempt by a number of junior Ministers to force Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to speed up the progress of British rearmament.

The traditional colorful, solemn celebration of the Nativity was held at St. Patrick's Cathedral, with severald thousand persons, including many non-Catholics, attending. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of the cathedral, was the celebrant of the mass, with two young men from St. Joseph's Seminary, not yet ordained to the priesthood, as deacon and subdeacon.

As president of the World Alliance for International Friendship through the churches, the Rev. Dr. G. Ashton Oldham, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Albany, N. Y., has issued a Christmas message, made public in News Letter, the official publication of the alliance.

Another year is about to relinquish its place on the calendar, and to the angler or hunter who has followed his sport with any degree of consistency during the past twelve months it has been a period productive of many pleasant memories.

Owing to a mistake on the part of a representative of the builders, the house at 3 Saddle Rock Estates, Great Neck, L. I., a picture of which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday, Dec. 18, was listed erroneously as having been bought by George Cobb.

Unique in canine competition, spectacular in the later stages through its closeness and the intense interest in the ultimate result, the contest for the annual prize offered by the American Kennel Club for the best American-bred dog was the sensational episode of the dog show year.

Alfred L. Aiken, president of the New York Life Insurance Company, said yesterday that 1938 results had been satisfactory, with recent sales substantially ahead of those in the corresponding period of 1937.

While plans for an active building campaign early in the Spring are being made by many of the leading home developers in the residential communities on Long Island in Queens and Nassau Counties, several builders are continuing construction work right through the Winter in anticipation of a big buying demand for medium-priced homes during the opening months of 1939.
Navy achieved ranking as the top team in intercollegiate lacrosse during 1938,- a year which saw Princeton and Maryland, great teams still, slip a bit from their eminence of the year before.

Work was begun this week to make the second floor of the Hamilton Smith Library a fine arts center for University of New Hampshire students. Arrangements have been made for art exhibits and a library and collections of reprints of famous paintings for student use.

Expressions of appreciation for the generosity of contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund have been transmitted to THE NEW YORK TIMES from the officers and directors of two of the ten leading charitable organizations of the city that annually cooperate in the appeal for the Neediest.

Little Man, the Federal tax expert is looking you over in his search for more revenue to pay for armaments, relief and other governmental costs. He has tapped the high income brackets for about all they can stand, and he is wondering if it is politically and economically feasible to tackle you next.

Are the American and British credits to China the first steps in a carefully calculated policy designed to make Japan slacken her grip on China, or are they gestures and half measures, in part a warning to Japan, in part a concession to liberal opinion and to indignant business men at home?
An important question that may be resolved by the Seventy-sixth Congress is the size of the menu cards in the legislative dining halls on Capitol Hill.
Laszlo Bellak of Hiungary kept the men's United States singles championship in table tennis but otherwise 1938 saw new players move into important title berths.

The three remaining Music brothers who went under the names of George and Robert Dietrich and George Vernard were left to spend Christmas in the Federal House of Detention as efforts yesterday to raise the bail required to free them on indictments in the McKesson Robbins Drug company case failed.

FROM a North American viewpoint nothing of importance is believed to have taken place in Peru between the time of Pizarro and the current emergence of Lima into the limelight as the seat of the Pan-American conference. Knowledge of that romantic country is usually limited to a reading of Prescott, and every one is familiar with the story of the proud and noble race of Incas and their savage and brutal conquest by the invaders.
Once again the national championship at soccer, as represented by the National Challenge Cup competition under the auspices of the United States Football Association, went to the West this year.

The following dispatch, the fifth of a series, was sent by a staff correspondent of THE NEW YORK. TIMES after a tour of provincial Germany and Czecho-Slovakia. It was written in Paris and so was not censored.

Miss Sarah Patterson Shiras of 10 Gracie Square, New York, was married here this afternoon in the Union Church to Barclay Markham Hudson, also of that city, formerly of St. Louis. The Rev. Philip Adams Job, the pastor, performed the ceremony in the presence of a small group of friends.

THE management of the Metropolitan Opera is currently pointing with pride to an aspect of its repertory that has not been remarked upon: its inclusion of at least five great comic operas by as many composers in one season. "Falstaff" and "Der Rosenkavalier" have already been performed, and shortly "Die Meistersinger," "Don Giovanni" and "The Barber of Seville" will be along.

The difficulties which the Pan-American Conference has suffered trying to define the position of the Americas amid contemporary world disorder may one day be viewed as labor pains attending the birth of a new Pan-Americanism. This conference, which is the eighth regularly scheduled meeting of the American republics, has grappled with more fundamental matters than have any of its precursors.
American tennis led the world again in 1938, but the player who won unprecedented honors for himself and his country was lost to the amateur ranks and to the future defense of the Davis Cup.
An other chapter in the long-drawn out controversy as to whether The Dartmouth, student daily, should be controlled by an alumnus as trustee will be written during the Christmas vacation period.

The principal European markets and many of the commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday, but for the first time in many years when a Saturday preceded a two-day holiday no petition for closing the New York Stock Exchange was circulated among the members.

WITZERLAND will issue early in the new year a series of nine stamps, in three sets of three with identifying inscriptions in three languages, as postal propaganda on behalf of the National Exposition of Switzerland at Zurich next May through October.
" TOUT Paris" is preparing for a holiday season of Winter sports. A very sporting atmosphere the resorts will present. There is a big return to essentially practical costumes.

The headaches of one farm program are not entirely eased before those of another begin to be felt. The hangover from the old program just now is being experienced in the impatience of farmers with the inability to handle corn loan applications as fast as the farmers can make them.

The modest but growing Museum of Classical Antiquities in Hatfield Hall is becoming essentially a working collection freely used for classroom study. Objects are handled by students as illustrations of techniques which also have a vivifying power equal to that of literature and history.

A fire started by an overturned oil stove swept through two three-story frame tenements, occupied by Negroes, at 209 and 211 Broome Street, shortly after 11 o'clock tonight, driving ten families to the street and fatally burning four persons, one a child.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Janet Huntington Jessup, daughter of Mrs. Foote Jessup of this city, and of John Colgate Jessup of West Palm Beach, Fla., to Roger Olcott, son of Mrs. Adeline Cheney Olcott

President-elect Theodore F. Appleby of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards announces that the first meeting of the 1939 board of governors will be held Jan. 20 at the Newark Athletic Club.
