Mr. and Mrs. William Hazel of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Clare Hazel, to John Schuyler Houseknecht of New York.

BERGAMO. SECOND novelty in Bergamo's experimental opera season was the three - act lyric legend, styled "La Cattedrale," which Mario Mariotti has set to a book by Alessandro de Stefani from the play, "Axel and Valborg," of the Danish poet, Oehlenschlaeger.

Every time Germany scores an international victory, as in her unopposed acquisition of the Sudentenland, speculation arises in Western Europe as to whether the Soviet Union will arrange a rapprochement with Germany.

The start of a survey of public library costs, planned as national in scope, and undertaken with the aid of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, was announced here Thursday by officials of the Montclair Free Public Library.

The announcement last week by Secretary o- the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. that he would ask Congress to continue the life of the stabilization fund after June 30, when it is scheduled to expire, was received in Wall Street banking circles with entire approval.

For the week ended Dec. 3, reported new business of important mills was slightly above the previous week, and production and shipments were appreciably greater, according to the National Lumber Manufacturers Association.

Wholesale market activity last week centered about holiday merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers, although a good volume of business was placed on January white sales items and early Spring apparel.

THE chairman of the house committee was awakened from a sound slumber and asked to make his regular report on the happenings of the last year. Pulling his scattered faculties together, he reported as follows: January-The big bowling tournament gets under way.... California defeats Alabama in the Rose Bowl, Santa Clara tops Louisiana State in the Sugar Bowl, Rice conquers Colorado in the Cotton Bowl and various other bowlers bowl over a few more victims....

PARIS.-Every year on Jan. 6 the inhabitants of Domremy, in the Vosges Mountains, celebrate the birthday anniversary of Joan of Arc, the warrior saint who placed this inconspicuous Lorraine village in all the history books of Europe and America. "Our Joan" will be the heroine of the day as the villagers this year observe the 527th anniversary of her birth.

Two iron-nerved Englishmen battling for the world's land speed record over the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah and Floyd Roberts of Van Nuys, Calif., roaring to victory in the 500-mile Indianapolis classic, provided 1938's automobileracing highlights on this side of the Atlantic.

More than 3,000 residents of Bronxville and neighboring communities crowded the slushy pavement of the village square tonight to witness the twenty-fifth annual presentation of the Pageant of the Nativity on Sunset Hill, opposite Village Hall.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leo Goldschmidt of 574 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Caroline Goldschmidt, to Theodore G. Meyerhoff, son of Mrs. Charles Meyerhoff of Flatbush and the late Mr. Meyerhoff.

MORE than two years after the death of G. K. Chesterton a book is brought together from his penand from his pencil and paint box-which has not only a literary interest in itself but a peculiar value from the point of view of literary biography. The earliest writing in "The Coloured Lands" was done by the schoolboy Chesterton at the age of 17.

The engagement of Miss Louise Hurlbut, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Nathan Hurlbut of Pelham Manor. N. Y., to Roy Tilden Parker Jr. of Pelham and Westport, Conn., has been announced by her parents.

The new year which is just around the corner will bring the twentieth anniversary of the adoption by Congress of the national woman suffrage amendment. It is twenty-two years since Montana, which had already adopted woman suffrage, sent to the House of Representatives its first woman member, Miss Jeanette Rankin.

THE English civil service has often deserved well of the world of letters. It has provided many distinguished authors with an adequate livelihood, thus saving them from the necessity of writing potboilers. and the routine duties it has imposed on them have not been a severe mental strain, so that in their hours of leisure they have brought an unwearied brain to the exercise of their gifts on more congenial tasks.

Outstanding in 1938 water sports was a competitive tour of Central Europe undertaken during the Summer by an American team composed of seven swimmers and two divers. Not only did our representatives make an excellent showing throughout but they defeated an all-Europe contingent, 38 to 36, in a dual meet in Berlin.

Outstanding among the activities of chess followers during 1938 was the A. V. R. O. international masters' tournament played during November in ten different cities of the Netherlands and proclaimed to be the greatest tournament of the century.

Many dinners will precede the holiday dance to be held here on Wednesday at the Wee Burn Club under the direction of Mrs. Graham T. Johnston. One of the largest of these will be given by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Baldwin of New Canaan for Miss Barbara Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Fairfield Thompson of New Canaan and Brooklyn.
Savings deposits in the country on June 30 amounted to $24,625,514,000, compared with $24,491,957,000 a year before, according to an annual survey by the American Bankers Association.

The Civilian Conservation Corps plays the role of the country's handy man in the Interior Department's chapter of the annual CCC report, published on Friday. Its odd jobs in 1938 ranged from fixing up a rundown 800-room apartment house...
LONDON. THE legend of the Vanishing Lady is old and famous, the more famous because not long ago Alexander Woollcott recapitulated and retold it.

National Guard troops numbering about 200 took charge at the scene of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation refinery strike in West Tulsa late tonight and about 100 pickets quietly broke rank and moved from their position on the

Wide advances in industry in the United States in 1939 have been forecast generally by editors of trade publications throughout the country as spokesmen for the industries and professions that their journals represent. Upturns that occurred in many fields in recent months are expected to continue and expand.

Mrs. Charles Thaddeus Terry of 850 Park Avenue has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Beatrice Hendrick Terry, to Arthur Broughton Avent, which took place on Dec. 15 in St. James Church, Old Milverton, Warwickshire, England.

What ordinarily would be the quietest basketball week of the season will be vitalized by Madison Square Garden double-headers Tuesday and Friday, the most pretentious bit of schedule-making that Promoter Ned Irish has attempted to date.

Margaret Martin was buried today while the State motor police continued their search for the man who strangled her to death after posing by telephone last Saturday as a prospective employer and making an appointment to interview her for a stenographer's job.

Steady evolution of "liberal" policies by certified public accountants, in the interest of protecting credit grantors, stockholders and the public, largely and chiefly in respect to those industries whose turnover is rapid and in which the mortality rate is high, was predicted last week by John L. Redmond, president of the New York Credit Men's Association.

Followers of checkers had a rather quiet year, inasmuch as no meeting of the American Checkers Association was held, but there is large planning for the next three years, culminating in a possible international team match between the United States and Great Britain, to be contested in London and Glasgow in 1941.

The savings, building and loan sociations of the country will disburse a sum approximating $91,000,000, representing the earnings of the last six-month period of the year, to their investors reports the United States Building and Loan League.

Award of contracts amounting to $1,610,000 for construction of the Federal low-rent housing project in Syracuse was announced today by the Syracuse Housing Authority, following approval by Washington authorities. The contracts were to:

With the American President, a member of his Cabinet and the chairman of the Senate's Foreign Relations Committee now leading the attack on dictatorships, numerous German editors suddenly find themselves compelled to readjust their range finders.

Announcement was made yesterday by Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman of the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York, that, by a decision of Justice Alfred Frankenthaler of the Supreme Court, the interest of certificate holders in the sum of $181,800 is held to be superior to the interest of the Union Guarantee and Mortgage Company in the sum of $50,700 in the certificated issue covering 165 Bennett Avenue, Manhattan.

A resolution supporting an independence movement to unite 45,000,000 Ukrainians in Russia, Poland and Rumania under an autonomous Greater Ukraine has been adopted by the executive council of the United Ukrainian Organizations of the United States, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Luke Myshuha, secretary.

The greater part of the 1,000-acre tract comprising the Paulinskill Lake development on Route 8, three miles beyond Newton, Sussex County, N. J., having been opened to skiers and coasters, Winter sports are now in full swing, the John R. Franke company reported yesterday.
William W. Wood, superintendent of the safety and welfare departments of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, H died last night at his home here at the age of 77.
W. F. Mannagh's Chief Nadi easily defeated eight others in the Carrollton Handicap today, over the sixfurlong route for all ages at the Fair Grounds.

Leading underwriters of investment securities have been scrutinizing closely for more than a week a regulation issued by the SecuriLies and Exchange Commisison conearningg "sub-underwriting," in the hope of finding in the rule a more Liberal interpretation of the Securities Act of 1933 which would permit "sub-underwriting" in what is

The fifty-fifth annual convention of the Modern Language Association of America will open here on Wednesday and continue through Friday, with sessions at Columbia University and in the Hotel Pennsylvania. More than 175 papers on linguistic subjects will be presented before the 2,500 members expected to attend.

HERE is a real album of ballet, alive and moving. There are more than 200 photographs in this book, and every one was taken during a ballet performance. The pictures show forty ballets, from the stillliving classic of "Giselle" to Frederick Ashton's bright drolleries in "Wedding Bouquet," and the whole collection is aptly described by the book's title. Most ballet pictures, as published, are posed;

Ernie Riedel was canoeing's outstanding figure in 1938. The veteran paddling ace of the Pendleton Club of New York carried off the lion's share of the individual honors in the ninth annual national championship meet of the American Canoeing. Association on the Potomac River, as the Yonkers Canoeing Club gained the team title for the second successive year.

Mr. and Mrs. George H. Cook of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Fuller Cook, to Ray C. Sherman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray W. Sherman of Flushing, Queens. Miss Cook was graduated from Barnard College.

Mrs. Margaret Krietzer, aged 100, surrounded by her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, enjoyed a Christmas tree today and the 100 candles on a huge cake baked by her daughter, Mrs. Joseph Sitzman. Mrs. Krietzer, white-haired and jolly, who came to this country from Austria at the age of 23, was not much excited.
James Mulvihill, city health department attendant, was identified today as the donor of blood for a transfusion for a New York priest with streptococcus viridans, a deadly blood stream infection.

The Westchester Assembly will sponsor a dance Wednesday at the Apawamis Club, Rye. The patronesses include Mrs. James S. Alexander, Mrs. Albert B. Baker, Mrs. Arthur L. Besse, Mrs. R. Clifford Black, Mrs.

Another dinner and "musical soiree" in behalf of the Musicians Emergency Fund - an entertainment reminiscent of the fete entitled "A Night at the Palace of Prince Esterhazy," given last Winter for the same cause-will take place on Jan. 22 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

IN a criticism of the new American automobiles from the stand point of design, F. A. Whiting Jr., editor, in the Magazine of Art, published by the American Federation of Arts in Washington, is not generally laudatory.

Still another 1938 racing season prize must be awarded before the old year can be rung out. As a sort of Christmas present Freddy Jacoby Jr. is about to receive from Stanley W. Ferguson of Boston, treasurer of the American Power Boat Association, a diamond medal to signify the national best-performance championship for the last season.
Roast turkey served with sausage will provide the principal course for the Christmas dinner So be served in the White House. The menu for the meal was announced today by the White House as follows:

HAVING double-tracked the Atlantic and wiped the mud of the Newfoundland marshes from his shoes, that perennial playboy, Harry Richman, is now making history of another sort in that palatial pub, that night club for the ages,

Total dividends, aggregating $90,000,000, will have been paid by Federal savings and loan associations to their investors at the end of this year, the Federal Home Loan Bank board announced yesterday.

Two brisk practices, with players fitting into roles with unusual smoothness, were written into the training routine today of Eastern and Western football stars who will meet here in the annual charity game Jan. 2.

Shipping men are preparing to close their books at the year's end with a spirit of optimism that has not been evident in several years. Apart from the usual cheer that flows through the industry at Christmas time, regardless of the balance sheets,

The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle and chairman of the National Scottsboro Committee has released correspondence to support a charge that Governor Bibb Graves of Alabama had broken his promise to parole the last of the nine Negroes in prison for criminally assaulting Victoria Price, a white woman.

The Postoffice Department announced today that first-day sales for the thirty-seven new postage stamps issued during 1938 totaled 10,101,978 stamps, representing a cash sale of $712,395.65. First-day covers canceled totaled 3,463,990.

WASHINGTON.--The day is coming, and coming fast, when the American traveler will be able to journey to any part of the world in American ships-ships which represent the last word in comfort and in safety, every one American built and operating under the American flag.

" A Christmas display, by far the best we have ever had," is the enthusiastic comment of T. H. Everett of the New York Botanical Garden, in reference to the holiday plant show in the newly opened remodeled conservatory on the west side of Bronx Park.

The developments of the last few days have been viewed in unofficial but informed circles in Washington as clarifying more than any similar string of events in recent months the foreign policy which the United States Government would choose to follow if it could be assured of the continuing support of the population which gives it substance.

George Bohehigan, 45, tenant on a dairy farm at Findley Lake, was stabbed to death with an ice pick last night. Edwin G. O'Connor, assistant district attorney, said death came after a quarrel with Hachig Simonian, 64, owner of the farm, over a $114 milk check.

As part of a Christmas Eve celebration at the New York World's Fair of 1939 yesterday at noon, 2,000 employes of the fair entered the perisphere, the 200-foot theme building and beneath its star-studded dome rode the "magic carpets" in the first official trial of the two circular moving platforms which are expected to provide a thrill for thousands of visitors.
Seabiscuit may be shipped to Santa Anita at once to prepare for the $100,000 stake race, Charles S. Howard, the handicap champion's owner, said today.
The fifty paintings of the Willits J. Hole art collection, given last week to the University of California, will be placed on permanent display on the Los Angeles campus.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Congratulations upon your recent ediorial "The Bill of Rights." You are ndeed right in stating that "we need gain to refresh our faith in these funamental liberties of the American people "
George Wheeler of the First United Presbyterian Community House of Pittsburgh carried off the major share of the 1938 honors in gymnastics.

FRENCH THEATRE OF NEW YORK-Tomorrow evening at the Barbizon-Plaza, they will be doing "Le Faiseur," Balzac's comedy, which never before has been presented in this country. For two weeks. ATTENTION, CHILDREN!-These are the offerings designed for younger members of the audience: A children's Christmas Festival will open tomorrow morning at the Mercury Theatre, with various pantomimes and plays on the program.
Miss Mary Isabel Augsberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Augsberger of this place, was married this afternoon to William Jay Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Lee, also of Nutley.

The new Museum of Modern Art building under erection at 11 West Fifty-third Street and expected to be completed next Spring will contain many departures from traditional museum structures. Philip L. Goodwin and Edward D. Stone are the architects.

In answer to the Italian Government's note of last Saturday announcing that it regarded the Laval-Mussolini agreement of January, 1935, as non-valid "because of changed circumstances that have developed in the interval,"

The year was made memorable in cricket by another visit of an Australian team to England, the home of the game, and a record match for "The Ashes" at the Oval in London, where, during August, England won by the huge margin of 579 runs, with an innings to spare.

Dr. and Mrs. Nevil Monroe Hopkins have gone to Washington to spend the Christmas holidays with Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Langhorne. Mr. and Mrs. George Waters Stieff of Baltimore have joined her mother, Mrs. Elisha C. Tower, at the Savoy-Plaza.

In 1937, two young New Yorkers dominated the most expensive and exclusive of all indoor court games. In 1938, Robert Grant 3d reached even greater heights in racquets, but in court tennis Ogden Phipps, owing to an unfortunate injury, was shorn of his crown.
Francis L. Field, Brooklyn attorney, who long was active in the borough's American Legion organization, died suddenly Friday night at the age of 45.
More than 5,000 Americans, men from all trades and professions, but united by a common love of powder smoke, gathered this year at Camp Perry, Ohio, for the national rifle and pistol matches.

LAST week's PWA announcement that work is about to begin on sewage-treatment plants for ten towns in the metropolitan area marks another step toward the demise of one of the most archaic customs in modern America-the dumping of a billionodd gallons of untreated sewage into New York waterways daily.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended Dec. 17 has dropped back to 93.7 from 94.4 (revised) for the preceding week and compares with 84.6 for the corresponding week a year ago.
Although a tacit truce applies to both sides and the curfew in Jerusalem is being relaxed, Palestine is facing tonight its third successive cheerless Christmas owing to the general insecurity.
A sad Christmas eve, softened only by the generosity of friends, was the lot tonight of two little girls whose father was killed as he attempted to get them a Christmas tree.

Santa Claus had to shake a real snow off his shoulders for the first time in eleven years as he scrambled down London's chimneys early this morning. Dozens of villages in the north of Lincolnshire are cut off by snowdrifts from the rest of the world and are without food for Christmas dinner.
Mr. and Mrs. George H. Levi of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Emma Levi, to Jonathan Randolph Keim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hervey C. Keim of Norberth, Pa.

THE revival of Beethoven's "Fidelio," with Flagstad singing the title role, the first performances this season of "Hansel und Gretel" and "Lakme," and the first appearance of Richard Bonelli as Iago, will be features of the sixth week of opera at the Metropolitan.

THIS is a Merry Christmas-this Christmas of 1938. I want to say that firmly and decisively, and to add that, if you look at it the right way, it's one of the Merriest Christmases the world has known since the first one.
FORTY years ago Hall Caine the Manxman was in the heyday of a sensa tional success.The journalist had written best-sellers, and the best-sellers. acted as plays,had enriched the box office.

Many entertainments have been arranged for guests at country places and visitors at the clubs and inns in the snow-covered Berkshire Hills. Miss Mary Parsons is having at Stonover, Lenox, one of the largest Yuletide house parties.

Miss Hildegard Martha Pietzsch of Plainfield, N. J., has announced the engagement of her sister, Miss Vera Elizabeth Pietzsch, to William Thomas Bell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Bell of Glen Ridge, N. J.

The war in China is getting to be a pretty gloomy business to the average Japanese soldier. So gloomy, in fact, that he is beginning to talk about it, but not very often, for there is a very strict rule against discussing the war.

While the Archbishop of Canterbury was blessing the Christmas crib, representing the Holy Family with the babe in the manger in an old English barn, in Canterbury Cathedral today a man rushed forward and shouted:

The potential consumer market for electric appliances in this country is valued at approximately $4,000,000,000 and in no one division of the industry is there anything approaching a saturation point, according to a study based on the number of appliances now in use and the distribution of incomes among single individuals and families in this country just completed by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

HAVE you a little leprechaun in your home? If you have, almost any major studio will be glad to offer him (or her) a motion-picture contract, for supernatural stars are very much in demand right now. A favorite Hollywood formula seems to be boy-meets-ghoul.

Senator Lewis, Democrat, of Illinois, said today that he was considering resigning his post as Senate whip. The Senator said he had several measures which he wished to push in the forthcoming session, and explained that, as whip, -he was prevented from attaching his name to
Looking back over another year of gardening, it seems to the writer that one of the most significant trends has been the revival of the interest in the growing of plants indoors.
Despite holiday dullness, the wheat market showed a firm undertone today. Scattered buying of the May delivery on the Board of Trade here was in evidence through commission houses.

The continued dominance in the national championship of Old Westbury, organized a year ago by C. V. (Sonny) Whitney and considered by many the greatest team to play in our championship in recent years, featured the 1938 season in polo.
FIVE underground studios will be incorporated in the extension of Broadcasting House, headquarters of the British Broadcasting Corporation, known as London's "Radio City."

The Agriculture Department reported yesterday that for the eleventh consecutive year New Jersey had the highest milk production per milk cow in the country. The State's average this year as of Dec. 1 was 18.2 pounds per cow, the report said. The 1938 figure was an increase of five-tenths of a pound over last year's mark.

How many fussy, cranky, tired and sick children will there be in the land tonight? There are more than 20,000,000 children between the ages of 2 and 10. And it's a pretty safe bet that most of those who have any share in this giant Christmas celebration of ours will exhibit some of these annoying traits at the end of the day.
Once one of the world's gayest capitals, Madrid is facing a cold Christmas of virtual starvation with an Insurgent army still at its gates.
CRISTOBAL, C. Z.--Piece de rsistance of our luggage is a gray portable wardrobe trunk, bearing the scars and the gaudy labels of a hundred journeys,
The Tracy Bartholomew family are holding a Christmas reunion by wire tonight, using a Tokyo-to-Pittsburgh telephone hook-up to link four generations from six cities.

After thirty-nine years as a member of the faculty of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary, the Rev. Dr. John Howard Raven, one of the nation's leading Hebrew scholars, has resigned. Impaired eyesight was given as the reason in the seminary's announcement.
Early next year the Department of Health will inaugurate a new project to supplement and extend the work of the Bureau of Health Education. This project is of special interest to parents.

Eugene Schou, chief of the structural engineering division of the Bureau of Construction of the Board of Education, died yesterday at his home, 1,167 Eighty-second Street, Brooklyn. He had been ill for several months. He was 69 years old.

Ten fraternities at City College announced yesterday the names of fifty-six undergraduates as pledgees of the Greek letter societies for the current semester. The selection of the students ended a six-week elimination program, during which the prospective pledgees were rushed.

Almost any window can be enhanced as a decorative feature of a room. That oddly shaped window on a landing, for instance, or at the end of a narrow passageway; in a dark dining room or in a contrastingly sunny enclosed porch; in a den or living room-any of them can be developed into something striking, with grace and distinction, by suitable plant material.

Mrs. Henry H. Richardson gave a tea at her home here this afternoon at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Juliet Richardson, to Waters Kellogg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Kellogg of 1,021 Park Avenue, New York.

THE forenoon of Sept 20, 1839, the British Queen the largest and finest steamship ever built," poked her long bowsprit between the Narrows of New York Harbor. That arrival on that date marks the beginning of photography in America.

About 2,300 men whose livelihood depends on the Cleveland Cliffs' Iron Company had a Christmas present today in the form of longer hours and larger pay checks. S. R. Elliott, company mining manager, announced that all soft ore mines of the company on the Marauette

Gasoline is carried in bags instead of in metal tanks in Glenn L. Martin's new airplanes, the manufacturer revealed today. The new type fuel containers, for which the Martin Company has just obtained patents,

Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Brown of 136 East Sixty-fourth Street and Sayville, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Halsey Brown, to David M. Manton, son of Federal Judge and Mrs. Martin T. Manton of the Madison and Bayport, L. I.
LONDON--The old school-tie tradition in the London police force has just sustained a heavy blow from the decision to remodel the Police Training College at Hendon on more democratic lines.

" Land valued at $24 in trinkets piled before the wondering eyes of the Canarsie Indians by Peter Minuit when he purchased the magic island of Manhattan, today, three centuries later, is assessed at about $4,000,000,000," J. Charles Laue, secretary to the Tax Commission of the City of New York, said at the recent annual conference at Cincinnati, Ohio, of the National Association of Assessing Officers.

United States curlers regained the Gordon International Medal, first competed for in 1884, in one of the highlights of the sport during 1938. Led by John Anderson, president of the Grand National Curling Club, the United States team defeated the Canadian branch of the Royal Caledonia Curling Club, 228 to 145, one of the most decisive scores in years.

Horseshoe pitching's 1938 king was 25-year-old Hubert Trinkle, who came from Madison County, Ind., to capture the national singles and doubles titles, the latter in partnership with Walter Lane, in the second annual A. A. U. championships, held in September at Willowbrook Park, New Springville, S. I.
News Letters, describing some phase of the program and aims of the school, are mailed once each term to parents of students in the Garden City High School.

The Stouffer Corporation's newest restaurant, to be opened in March in the Pershing Square Building, Park Avenue and Forty-second Street, will seat 850 persons and will occupy 26,000 square feet on two floors, Vernon B. Stouffer, president and treasurer, reported yesterday.

Replying to the good wishes of the Sacred College of Cardinals, the Pope delivered an address today-quiet in tone but strong in substance-that attacked the Fascist Italian Government's racial laws forbidding "mixed marriages" of various sorts, particularly between Italian "Aryans" and Jews.

The picket line in the Press Wireless, Inc., labor dispute became an imaginary one today when striking employes and the company called a thirty-six-hour truce so that the pickets might join family Christmas parties. Pickets for the striking C. I. O.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Floyd T. Taylor of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Bottimore Taylor, to Edward Alfred Norman Jr. of Englewood.

Having won the World War twenty years after the guns ceased firing, "Great Germany" now is proceeding not only to turn the tables on the victors in respect to power politics but also in the levy of counter-reparations on the world in general and world Jewry, which the National Socialists blame for Germany's previous defeat, in particular.

Phoebe, a 5-year-old spaniel, was named as one of the principal beneficiaries in the will of Miss Henrietta M. Edwards, 115 Tysen Street, New Brighton, S. I., which was filed for probate yesterday at St. George.

Sir Charles Frederick Higham, British advertising expert, died today in London, where he was born sixty-two years ago. Starting as a chemist's assistant, he tried sixteen jobs in nineteen years in America until he embarked in the advertising field and became a public figure and Great Britain's "slogan king."

A dramatization of Hector Malot's juvenile story, "Nobody's Boy," familiar to youthful French students as "Sans Famille," will form the nucleus of a children's holiday party to be given Tuesday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the Social Service Auxiliary of the Cancer Institute.

Contemporary Club of White Plains--Dance sponsored by philanthropic committee. Floral Park Woman's Club-Sub-deb league tea dance, 3 P. M., Stewart Manor Country Club. Hackensack (N. J.) Junior Women's Club-Tea dance, 4 P. M., Golf Club.

Rowing in 1988, as far as the colleges were concerned, was featured by the return of the East to the head of the river at Poughkeepsie with the breaking of the long string of Western successes there in the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

Dredging work in the slips adjacent to the city-owned Tiffany Street pier in the East Bronx to permit use of the dock by larger vessels will be started about the middle of January, William E. Matthews, executive secretary of the Bronx Board of Trade, announced yesterday.
Bennington College closed Wednesday and 281 girls left the campus for their two-month field and reading period. They will separate to many different jobs all over the country and in Panama.
President Roosevelt, in a Christmas greeting broadcast to all men tonight, renewed "before all the world" the "pledge I have so often given to my own countrymen" to

Into a dark and silent crypt in Cypress Cemetery one day last week attendants slid the coffin of a restless man. In due course the crypt will be sealed with a stone marked with the inscription "F. Donald Coster, 1884-1938." Yet the restless one was not "F. Donald Coster," and the birth date on the door of the tomb may, like the name, be fiction.

The benefit concert to be given tomorrow night in Carnegie Hall to raise funds for German and Austrian refugees has enlisted the support of many persons of social, political and business prominence in the city and State.
Five thousand shivering Frenchmen took time from their Christmas preparation to watch two teams of Americans demonstrate their game of football today.

Fairly brisk last-minute shopping yesterday brought Christmas trade here for the period from Dec. 1 to Dec. 24 to about even with or slightly ahead of the holiday period a year ago, according to store executives. Volume up to Friday night had been estimated at from 2 to 3 per cent behind last year,

PROFESSOR McMAHON'S new book (his last previous volume, "The Meaning of Art." was published eight years ago) expressly aims to answer the questions and to meet the pedagogic needs not of a small class of art students but of a wide general public interested in art.

Fourteen of the city's hospitalspublic and private-will be serviced in the new year by a central council of hospital libraries, the first organization of its kind to be staffed almost completely by volunteer workers.

The announcement last week that Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, had resigned as one of the three representatives of the public on the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange after less than three months in the post raised new questions as to the status of stock market reform and regulation.

BRAHMS was a past master of the variation form; he was also in the habit of doing things in pairs. But the "St. Anthony" variations remain the single example of variations for orchestra standing on their own ground and, unlike the passacaglia of the Fourth symphony, not even spiritually related to other movements.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Frances McLaughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. McLaughlin of this city, to John R. Holland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert J. Holland, also of Pittsburgh.

Standards for librarians are set too low by library trustees and administrators, and those who use libraries are too easily satisfied with mediocre service, Dean Charles C. Williamson of the Columbia University School of Library Service declared in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler,

Yale's nine undergraduate colleges are young, but in the fertile soil of the university's long history each has taken strong root and is already blossoming in individual customs. It is only five years since the college plan of residence went into effect with seven colleges, and since then the transformation of Yale from the typical American university has been gradual but steady.
The engagement of Miss Rita L. L Jane Finkelstein and Dr. H. Lawrence Jacobius, both of this city, has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Harry Finkelstein of 123 West Eighty-sixth Street.

Operating for the first time under a new and radically revised code, basketball was stepped up on the court and in regard of its vast army of followers last season to reach new heights of popularity. The jump ball at center was eliminated and the game seemed to be all the faster and all the better for it.

Texas Tech's Red Raiders, tough as nails on the gridiron, dressed in their flashing scarlet and black togs today and played Santa Claus to crippled children at the Scottish Rite Hospital. Answering the children's plea that the Raiders model their football apparel, the players marched in wearing their war regalia and distributed cookies and candy.

We have had so much housing legislation since 1933 that the layman can hardly be blamed for some confusion about it all. Two statements recently published illustrate the situation. One said that the FHA would like to insure another billion dollars' worth of houseing. The other reported a large number of defaults, particularly in this State, on HOLC loans.

The staid Union League Club was stripped of every vestige of its usual dignity yesterday as 250 underprivileged children, some of them cripples, from the East Side poured through its Park Avenue doors. It was no invasion, however. The doorman grinned as he admitted the mob. 'Twas the day before Christmas and the children were there by invitation.

The performance of the new Noel Coward revue, "Set to Music," on the night of Jan. 20 at the Music Box Theatre will be given to augment the scholarship fund of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre.
It takes the nice decision of a gourmet to plan the dinner for New Year's Day. That dinner comes at what might be a difficult moment, when ordinary food could taste worse than dull.

A long black limousine drove away from the Christmas-decorated White House last Wednesday evening and headed north into the Winter-brown countryside of Maryland. President Roosevelt was dining out, a rare event for him. His host was Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes. They dined on eggs laid by hens on the Secretary's farm.

Not While my legs are still goon and my voice holds out," exclaimed the white-haired veteran of three decades in the National League today as he waved a 1939 contract. A letter Ford C. Frick, league president, enclosed with the contract contained the following: "I took up with the league the i
With the excavation completed, pile driving for the foundation of the new hospital of the Medical College of Virginia at Richmond got under way last week.

Brown University will be host to more than 600 scientists, scholars and teachers from Tuesday to Friday, when the Archeological Institute of America, the American Philological Association and the Division of Physical Chemistry of the American Chemical Society hold their annual meetings here.

The first "Popular Front" government on the American continent was solemnly inaugurated this afternoon with the taking of office of President Pedro Aguirre Cerda. He was the Leftist winner on Oct. 29 in the most bitter and important struggle for political supremacy that has been registered in Chile's history.

TORONTO. - Canada's wheatgrowing prairies have entered into competition with her Atlantic and Pacific coast fisheries. They are now sending fish to all parts of the North American continent. The fisheries of the Prairie Provinces are becoming more important each year. Their output in recent years has averaged more than $4,000,000.
The review of amateur singles competition in squash racquets and squash tennis during the past year is almost solely a story of two men--Germain G. Glidden and Harry F. Wolf.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorials on "The Nicaragua Canal" and on the "Needs of the Army" illustrate your interest in the problem of our national defense. My idea is that we ought to maintain naval, military and air forces adequate to defend our borders and coasts and to control the parts of the oceans in the vicinity of our own coasts.
Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT--Harry C. Bilms, from 6th Precinct to 18th Division, for 15 days, from 4 P. M., Jan. 1. From commands indicated to Police Academy, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., Jan. 1:

The Chicago Black Hawks, holders of the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world, will encounter the New York Amerians in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The battle will be the first on local ice since Tuesday night and promises to attract a crowd of 12,000.

EVEN if the submarine cables across the English Channel were severed in time of war, the British Isles are not to be cut off from telephonic communication with the Continent, for an ultrashortwave "talk-bridge" is to be erected between Dover and Calais.

Bottled beer now accounts for approximately 91 per cent of all packaged beer sales, according to the 1938 "national beer packaging survey" conducted by the Glass Container Association. The survey covers 554 of the -620 producing brewers in the country and is the second to have been made by the association.

The presentation this week of a new Polish note protesting the attitude of the Czecho-Slovak press calls attention to the position of Ruthenia. Of all the difficulties created for Czecho-Slovakia by "the Munich unsettlement," none is graver than her dilemma over Ruthenia,

Handball history was made in 1938 when Joe Platak of Chicago fought his way through a strong field in the Memphis tournament to capture the national A. A. U. fourwall singles championship for the fourth straight time, a feat never before accomplished by any player.

The matinee on Feb. 10 at the Metropolitan Opera House of "La Boheme," with Grace Moore and Jan Kiepura, which will augment the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York, has the support of a large group of patrons and patronesses.

Felix C. Benvenga, appointed by Governor Lehman as a justice of the Supreme Court to succeed Lieutenant Governor-elect Charles Poletti, will be sworn in at noon Tuesday by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division, First Department,

Leaving in its wake a jumbled heap of shattered records, another year of sport has run its measured course and when the end is tolled at midnight Saturday only one record of any account is expected to survive.

WASHINGTON-The widely published statements of Pilot Charles Stead that radio performance was a factor in his forced landing of a passenger plane Nov. 29 off Point Reyes near San Francisco has fofused public attention on the part which radio plays in the safety of the modern air transport.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had ordered Gold Medal Books, Inc., of New York City, to discontinue "misrepresenting the character, quality or value" of certain books it advertised.

The rise of a brilliant new star, 20-year-old William Markham of the Old Sixty-ninth B. C., and a general increase of interest in the game in this area and throughout the country were among the outstanding developments in the sport of badminton in 1938.

For the seventeenth year, the Humane Society of New York entertained yesterday the pets of poor East Side youngsters and adults. So popular has the annual affair become that the tiny headquarters building at 313 East Fifty-eighth Street and the street outside were thronged by a crowd of 2,000 pet owners.

A woman driver decided something was wrong when a driverless automobile bumped her car gently from the rear. She investigated and found the bumpers of a driverless car locked in the bumpers of her own car. She drove to a parking lot and

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eleanor Francis Ganzel, daughter of Mrs. Louis Charles Ganzel of Westfield, N. J., and the late Mr. Ganzel, to Robert Boer Oltman of Grand Rapids, Mich., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredrick C. Oltman of Chicago.

Major John Waller Hills, former Financial Secretary to the Treasury and a Conservative member of the House of Commons, died today. A champion of social reform, he obtained passage of the Sex Disqualification Removal Act in 1918 and his activities led to measures that gave women university degrees and entry into the legal profession.

ADDITIONAL information as to the progress of aviation in Eu rope was made available here last week when Captain Jimmy Haizlip, former speed pilot, and his almost equally famous wife, Mae Haizlip, returned from an extensive survey of the European scene.

Intercollegiate football in 1938 enjoyed a highly prosperous season that was as generally gratifying as any since Princeton and Rutgers started the ball rolling in 1869. The usual discordant note was sounded by those who object to the big revenues accruing from the game.

With high hopes for the best Winter sport weather that has prevailed during the event for the past two or three years, Lake Placid is preparing for another Christmas Week of skiing, skating and hockey, with the eighteenth annual Lake Placid Club college invitation ski meet as the feature. All of the usual trimmings of the week are planned again.

SWINGING back through 1938's melody lane, the song favorites rated by listeners were "A-Tisket, A-Tasket," "Ti Pi Tin" and "My Reverie," each leading the popularity poll compiled by WABC's "Hit Parade" surveyists for six weeks each. Other favorites were "Love Walked In," "Music, Maestro, Please" and "I've Got a Pocketful of Dreams," all of which led in the balloting for four weeks.

With snow conditions slightly better than those of the disastrous 1936-37 season, the many skiers in this part of the country confined their trail and open slope running to a few good week-ends during the past Winter.

A benefit entertainment of the midwinter which is receiving the support of many persons of prominence is a theatre-supper party to be held the night of Jan. 17 to augment the resources of an endowment fund enabling students to begin or continue their studies at the Turtle Bay Music School.
To aid him in his projected longrange development program for Centre College in Kentucky, Dr. Robert L. McLeod Jr., the new president, has engaged Bernard P. Taylor,
All gardeners appreciate gifts of potted plants, especially if they carry gay blossoms to brighten their Winter window gardens, which are inclined to be on the "green side" this month.

Two years ago a neighbor of Coy Galyen, a farmer of Tilden, had a mongrel dog he did not want any longer. Galyen gave the dog a home. Tonight he credited the mongrel with saving his life. Galyen is in a hospital here with a broken leg, suffered when a load of wood upset, and from exposure from lying nineteen hours in the cold.

Frank Balcerak, 23, of East Portchester, was killed in an automobile accident this afternoon when a car operated by Michael Masna, 20, also of East Portchester, left the highway on Rith Avenue and struck a tree.

SEASON'S Greetings: To Charlie Chaplin, who announced last week that he would make that burlesque on the Hitler dictatorship, after all, starting in January. . . . To Walter Wanger, who made the staggeringly obvious suggestion that producers, sick of Nazi-Fascist censorship, should simply withdraw their product from the market in "dictator nations."

Robert Shannon, formerly vice president and general manager of the RCA Manufacturing Company, has been elected executive vice president, effective Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by George K. Throckmorton, president of the company. Mr. Shannon, who is 46 years old, has been identified with radio manufacturing and administration since the earliest days of radio.

Because a landlord did not have the heart to put a family out on the streets the day before Christmas, an eviction order issued against Mrs. Rena Strunz, a WPA clerical worker, was not served yesterday.

NASSAU, Bahamas. - Artificial sponge cultivation suffered a serious setback in the Bahamas recently when it was discovered that a bed comprising 180,000 sponges, representing five years' labor and an investment of pound5,000 had died overnight at Water Cay Channel, Andros Island. The bed was owned by P. C. and Wilfred Smith of Nassau.

A survey of home building during the current year in cities of different population groups recently completed by the Federal Home Loan Bank discloses that, in proportion to their population, the cities from 10,000 to 25,000 were the leaders in the country for new residential construction for the first nine months of the present year.

MANY have been called for examination, but only four will be chosen to fill the vacancies on WNYC's announcing staff, now under the civil service. More than 1,000 applicants have taken the intensive written test, the questions of which sound like a sample of the "Information Please" broadcast in an effort to stump the experts.

Five thousand dollars raised by the German colony for bail enabled Gisbert Wilhelm Groos, German spy suspect, to leave jail to spend Christmas in freedom. Groos is one of the four Germans, one a girl, arrested Oct. 16 on charges of photographing key defenses of the Panama Canal in violation of the United States Espionage Act.

GovernorElect Leverett Saltonstall's demand that the State Racing Commission postpone scheduled hearings on next year's horse racing dates until after his inauguration was put up to the full commission today for decision.

In a Hanukkah-Christmas message to the people of Germany, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, said yesterday: "We who are Jews join with our Christian brethren here in a message to them of good-will.

Once again, in 1938, it was Don Lash, former Indiana University ace, who dominated cross-country. The Hoosier star, now representing the Indiana State Police, annexed the national senior championship for the fifth successive year with a close victory over Victor Dyrgall of the Millrose A. A. in the annual 10,000-meter test at Newark, N. J.

ACKERMAN - BERNSTEIN - Mrs. M. Knecht announces the engagement of her sister, Augusta Bernstein, to Mr. Robert Ackerman. Sunday, Dec. 25, 1938. BARNETT-FRISCH-Mr. and Mrs. Louis Frisch of 1,993 East 5th St., Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter, Sylvia, to Dr. Theodore Barnett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Barnett of 1,502 Pitkin Ave., Brooklyn, N. Y.

The work of the Protestant Big Sisters In rehabilitating delinquent girls is helped annually through a large theatre party. This year the performance the night of Jan. 5 of Thornton Wilder's farce, "The Merchant of Yonkers," will serve as a benefit for the organization. The play will open on Wednesday at the Guild Theatre.

Arthur T. Vanderbilt, former president of the American Bar Association, denied yesterday an assertion made by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, that Mr. Vanderbilt "for a large fat fee" dominated the association's committee that filed a brief with the United

Uncle Sam, through the Federal Bureau of Home Economics, has been studying the delicate little matter of carving the holiday turkey. Among other things, he has found time to study what kinds of knives are best for carving the bird and what position the carver can assume for performing his task with the greatest of ease.
Following is the text of the address made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at the plenary session of the Pan American Conference in Lima tonight, as given out by the State Department:

With towns and the countryside liberally blanketed with snow, Germany is enjoying her first white Christmas in many years. Outwardly the scene suggests the complete Yuletide contentment that gives the Teutonic Christmas its familiar flavor.

The voluntary hospitals of the city and the compensation insurance companies have compromised their dispute concerning the rates at which the hospitals shall be paid for the care of injured and sick workers covered by insurance, it was announced yesterday by Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, and Louis H. Pink, State Insurance Superintendent.

Ruth E. Clayton, in 14 5th Ave: C. Gunther Kauffman, Emma K. Nielsen, in 38 Gramercy Park; Morris Cornovsky, in University Pl: Thomas J. Maginnis, in 35 W 9th St; Holger E. Hagen, in 3 E 10th St; John A. Cregier, in 21 E 10th St; Lillian Eddy. Dr. Nathan Rifkinson. Virginia R. Swain. in 421 E 21st St: Alexander Bunyan, in 120 W 58th St; H. Stanley Hillyer, Inc, broker.
The American football squad closed its demonstrations today with an exhibition game won by the "All-Stars," 37 to 34, before 6,000 bewildered Frenchmen in the Municipal Stadium.
Two thousand years ago the star was bright, And wise men journeyed humbly where it led. Shepherds came softly through the wide, blue night To find the young Child in His strawlaid bed.

Joseph A. Calvy, a Newark patrolman for the last fifteen years and possessor of a spotless record, was booked at Police Headquarters here tonight on a charge of holding up a local diner and taking a shot at its manager before he fled with $9.50 about 8 o'clock this morning.
Frank N. Hoffstot, retired manufacturer and banker, former president of the Pressed Steel Car Company, died yesterday at his residence, 1,030 Fifth Avenue, after an illness of six weeks.

The marriage of Miss Miriam Gottesman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Samuel of Mr. and Mrs. David Samuel Gottesman of 730 Park Avenue, this city, and Lawrence, L. I., to Ira David Wallach, son of Mr. and Mrs.. Joseph Wallach of New York, took place here yesterday afternoon at the pierre.

The Rev. and Mrs. Samuel H. Edsall of this place have announced the engagement of Mrs. Edsall's daughter, Miss Mary Gillett, to Benoni Johnson Truslow, son of Mrs. Ernest K. Truslow of Southport. Conn., and Canaan, N. Y.

Compiling the same figures they did a year ago, the Detroit Tigers carried off team-fielding honors in the American League for the fifth consecutive season in 1938, according to the official averages released for publication today.
The following dispatch, the sixth of a series, was sent by a staff correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES after a tour of Germany and Czecho-Slovakia. It was written in Paris and so was not censored.

Lester A. Goodrich, a native of New Haven, N. Y., and a former State representative, died last night at the age of 86. He was a former member of the Board of Education, had served in the City Council and was Mayor of Hillsdale for twelve terms.
A national conference to lay the foundation for the extension of the children's museum movement, in which the Brooklyn Children's Museum served as a pioneer, will be held at the Hotel Astor Jan. 11,
Marshall Scott Collingwood, treasurer of the trustees of the Presbyterian Board of Publication and Sabbath School Work, died in his home here today at the age of 73.

Joan Hildreth, 10 months old, saw her first and last Christmas yesterday. While her father, Charles 26 years old, a bank clerk, and mother, Harriet, 22, were in: another part of their home at 353 Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, she was: smothered to death by a blanket in her crib.

The engagement of Miss Gladys Weinberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Weinberg of 900 West End Avenue, to Robert Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Morris of this city, has been announced by her parents.

Mr. and Mrs. Aglar Cook gave a tea this afternoon at Broadfield Farm, their home here, at which they announced the engagement of Mrs. Cook's daughter, Miss Marjorie Tomlinson, to Harrison Shed Fraker of Plainfield.
While snow drifted down on the estate where he had enjoyed spending old-fashioned family Christmases,
The other day we heard the story' of a man who went to great lengths to avoid breaking a game law, and in these days of many and varied laws it was a refreshing tale.
Stocks irregular on the week in moderate trading; turnover, 5,980,342 shares. Second-grade rail bonds strong; other bonds mixed; trading second largest of year for a week at $52,078,125.

The Workers Alliance of Greater New York spent $20,190 for organizational and administrative purposes between July 13 and Nov. 30, according to a financial statement made public yesterday by Sam Wiseman, executive secretary of the group. The money was obtained from WPA workers, home relief recipients and sympathizers.

Mrs. Gussie Joyce, widow of Isaac Joyce, former vice president of Temple Adath Israel in the Bronx, died yesterday of a stroke at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Samuel Plumer of 140 East Twenty-eighth Street, after an illness of two days. She was 78 years old.
The sort of weather that is traditionally connected with Christmas was experi'enced throughout Northern Italy today where snow had been falling plentifully for several days.

BRENNER--LEVINE--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Levine of 272 West 90th St. announce the marriage of their daughter, Shirley, to Mr. Louis Brenner, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Brenner of New Jersey, on Friday, Dec. 23, 1938. COHEN--HANFLING--Frances B. Hanfling to Harold G. Cohen, Dec. 24, 1938.
The French genral wholesale price index on Dec. 17 was unchanged from the week before at 654.

A demand for a legislative investigation of what was termed the "absolute breakdown" in administration of unemployment insurance mingled today with announcement of a move to speed payment of 270,000 unsatisfied claims.

The formation of a Joint Committee on Folk Arts "to explore the folkways of America" was announced by Ellen S. Woodward, assistant administrator of the WPA. Described as a collation of "all the oral, popular and traditional materials that express ways of living in the our country," the material already collected includes legends and folktales, folk music, games, dances, rituals and all formas of folk art.

Mrs. Julia Trimmer, 80-year-old blind home relief recipient, was fatally burned today when her clothing became ignited while she was building a fire in the living room of her home on Mount Horeb Road, Warren Township, where she lived alone.

The General Motors-Cornell world price index of forty basic commodities for the week ended on Dec. 17 was at the thirty-year low of 60.4, and 0.1 point below the revised figure of 60.5 for the preceding week.

" Susan and God," with Lily Cahill, begins a week's engagement this afternoon at the reopened 4 Majestic Theatre, Brooklyn. Others in the cast include Paul Gilbert, Ethel Britton, Damian O'Flynn and Lucille Sears.

Robert Neill Brace, superintendent of the New York Children's Aid Society for thirty-five years until his retirement eight years ago, died at his home here Saturday ton night after a week's illness. His and age was 77.

Whether the famed honeymoon bridge at Niagara Falls, N. Y., destroyed by an ice jam last January, will be replaced by public or private interests may depend on the outcome of a test case pending before the District of Columbia Federal Court.
Hugh E. Bayne, former New York and Paris lawyer who took up painting several years ago, today presented to the Mobile Bar Association a portrait of his grandfather,

James B. Herbert, fleet middledistance runner from New York University, yesterday filed his entry for the Columbus 500, one of the feature events of the Columbus Council, Knights of' Columbus, meet, which will open the major indoor track campaign in the East at the 245th Coast Artillery Armory in Brooklyn on Jan. 7.
Tens of thousands of persons crowded snow-covered cathedrals in Insurgent Spain today to celebrate the Nativity and pray for an early peace in the civil war.

Today's events: "Hansel and Gretel," afternoon, "Falstaff," evening, Metropolitan Opera House; Refugee Concert, Hulda Lashanska, soprano, Emanuel Feuermann, 'cellist, and Mischa Elman, violinist, Carnegie Hall evening; Giorni Memorial Concert, Town Hall, afternoon; Dusolina Giannini, soprano, Waldorf-Astoria, 11 A. M.

We seem no nearer to peace than we were years ago, and we are no nearer to Christ either, the Rev. George A. Trowbridge, rector of All Angels' Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street, said in his sermon there yesterday.

Avukah, national intercollegiate organization of Jewish youth, opened a 3-day conference at the Hotel Claridge yesterday afternoon to clarify the organization's policies and outline a program of political action. Harold Goldblatt, chairman of the conference, presided.
Christmas and the current severely cold weather combined to reduce financial activity here last week to the lowest of the year.

Ageold Christmas ceremonies were carried out here last night and this morning while thousands of British troops, some in armored cars and some at machine-gun posts, ringed the little town to frustrate any attempt to mar the celebration.

Today was celebrated as a national holiday in China. It is called "National Rebirth Day" and marks the anniversary of Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's safe return from the city of Sian following his kidnapping by Communists in 1936.

Total income payments to all persons in this country rose in November for the sixth consecutive month and showed the largest increase for any month in the current recovery movement, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce reported today.
A Christmas gift of $1,000 from friends in America will be sent tomorrow to Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian labor leader, to aid him in his religious work in Japan.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, in his annual report as president of Columbia University made public yesterday, warned that government regimentation and compulsion would bring a slow death to institutions of public service such as universities, colleges, hospitals, libraries and museums which depend on private benefactions for support.

A revolutionary principle of air compression has been discovered and a machine to carry out the theory perfected by L. V. Jones of Phoenix. After a year of experimentation at the California Institute of Technology, Pasaneda, Mr. Jones has filed application for a patent.

The theatre's busiest week of the season begins today with a matinee premiere of the Shubert revival of "Blossom Time." Everett Marshall has the role of Franz Schubert in the operetta. The curtain is at 2:30 P. M. at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre.

Three persons, an of Detroit, were buried to death Saturday night when the car they were riding in exploded and burst into flames after being struck at nearby Maidstone by an eastbound New York Central Railway flyer.

In a world torn by war, cruelty and persecution it is "travesty" for clergymen to stand before congregations and say, "Peace on garth, toward men of good-will," the Rev. Dr. George Caleb Moor said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street.

More than $1,500,000 in lump sum payments has been distributed to 29,969 New York State wage-earners or their families under the Federal old-age insurance program, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, announced yesterday.

The University Settlement dental and nutrition clinic of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor has been moved from 184 Eldridge Street to larger quarters at 363 West Twenty-third Street, Bailey B. Burritt, general director of the association, announced yesterday.
Samuel M. Griffiths, president of the Binghamton Slag Roofing Company, died Friday night in City Hospital after a short illness. His age was 73.

A Japanese army spokesman said today that the appearance of the Soviet flag atop 165-foot towers on the Russian side of the-Siber ian-Manchukuoan border had led to erroneous reports of new tension in the disputed area near the Korean frontier.

Alfred M. Landon, one of the United States delegates to the Pan-American Conference, will leave Lima by plane tomorrow. He is scheduled to arrive in Cristobal, Canal Zone, Tuesday afternoon and will proceed the next day to Guatemala, where he will remain until Friday morning visiting the Maya ruins.

College football stars from, the East and West, who will meet in the big charity game here Jan. 2, mixed brisk. workouts today with Christmas celebrations. The Eastern players, training in Berkeley, practiced for two hours, running through signals, trying new formations and perfecting their passing.

Two four-story buildings at the southwest corner of Murray and West Streets have been sold by the heirs of Catherine A. Phelps to a client of Louis J. Witkin, attorney. They occupy a plot 49.11 by 44.4 feet and were sold for cash over a mortgage of $27,000. George F.

The activities of the Pan-American conference at Lima have been watched with the keenest interest here because Britain, although barred from the conference itself, has an interest in South America equal to that of the United States.

Among those sharing in the city's celebration of Christmas yesterday were 300 old folk, who gathered at 23 Park Avenue as guests of the Advertising Club. It was the eleventh annual Christmas party given by the club and the guests were chosen, as usual, by the Association for the Improvement of the Condition of the Poor.

Praise for the work college student groups are doing to improve social conditions was contained in a letter from President Roosevelt to Joseph P. Lash, national secretary of the American Student Union, made public yesterday.

When the Eighth Pan-American Conference adjourns tomorrow at Lima it will leave behind it a far more impressive record of achievement than seemed likely to be the case a week ago. At that time the conference was deadlocked over the drafting of a resolution expressing the "solidarity" of the twenty-one American republics.

Trade Interest in the wheat market is shifting slowly from the current supply of that grain to the outlook for next year's harvest. While crop reports are not expected to be a major influence for several months, the situation is regarded as restricting the tendency of speculators to take the short side on declines.

-Mrs. Anna De Lucian, 40 years old, of Middle Country Road, Coram, L. I., was killed early today when struck by an automobile near her home. Police said the driver was Charles E. Owens, 21, of Middle Island.

John F. Cogan, president of the John F. Cogan Company, contractors, with offices in the Grand Central Terminal Building, died yesterday of bronchial pneumonia, at the age of 78, at his home, 6,703 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn.

The new bill which came on at the downtown National Theatre on Houston Street over the week-end contains a double novelty. The first is that it marks the local debut of Gisela Werbezirk, an exile from medieval Germany, of whose stage she is a veteran comedienne.

While the New York staff of The Associated Press put in the traditionally "slow" Christmas Day in the organization's new headquarters in Rockefeller Center, a National Broadcasting Company program of a full hour yesterday marked the official dedication of the new offices and the ninetieth anniversary of the organization.

The Connecticut Humane ciety's medal committee will be asked to award medals to the two adopted children of Mrs. Alma Gracey of Center Groton for their rescue of livestock in the hurricane of Sept. 21, Reed W. Hitchcock, director of the animal division of the society, has announced.
After marking time throughout the second day of its congress, the Socialist party split tonight on the interpretation of the French-Soviet pact.

The press and public opinion have put Congress "on the spot" because of its equivocal action and attitude in reference to a cable from Diego Martinez Barrio, President of the Spanish Cortes, pleading for support in the stopping of the bombing of civilian populations and open cities.
L. Jackson Sheffield, no occupation, filed a petition in bankruptcy today, listing liabilities at S17.303 and no assets.

Senator James P. Pope of Idaho, whose term is to expire on Jan. 3, has accepted appointment to the Tennessee Valley Authority board of directors, an informed person said today. This person said that President Roosevelt would send Mr. Pope's nomination to the Senate- immediately after Congress convenes.

Two world swimming records were bettered today by Philadelphia stars in the Miami Biltmore pool. Peter Fick set out to break the 50-meter record, but his foot caught in a rope at the last turn on the 25-yard course.
Professor Arthur E. Holt of the Chicago Theological Seminary and the University of Chicago and Mrs. Holt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Eugenie Holt, to the Rev.

The State, County and Municipal Workers of America, a C. I. O. A union of government employes, an- L nounced yesterday that it had appealed to Mayor La Guardia to find other employment for 3,000 clerks in the home relief division of the Department of Welfare who are schedule for dismissal when the division goes under civil service.

WHEN Beverley Baxter was a young jouralist mastering the typewriter, one sentence must have sunk deeply iIto his subconscious--"Now is the )ime for all good men to come to the aid of the party." For now that he is 'a Conservative member of Parliament, he brings to the aid of his party a typewriter vibrant with loyalty.

Mrs. Elizabeth Scripps, 21 years old, won an uncontested divorce here yesterday from John P. Scripps Jr., 26, member of the newspaper-owning family, on charges of cruelty. Superior Judge H. G. Ames granted her $500 a month alimony and $150 a month for the support of their daughter, Edith, 2 years old, but refused her plea for $25,000-attorney fees.

In the first three days of this week, the rise in French securities progressed farther, especially in government obligations, but on Thursday the Stock Exchange was affected badly by the lean majority of seven votes obtained in the Chamber of Deputies by Premier Edouard Daladier in the morning.
Dr. Martin W. Barr, a psychiatrist, died at his home here today, five days after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 78 years old.

Workmen and empdoyes in several hundred department stores and specialty shops; along Fifth Avenue will be busy today and tomorrow preparing windpw displays in the World's Fair theme for the ceremonies on Wednesday observing "The Dawn of a New Day on Fifth Avenue-the City's Greatest Retail Shopping Street."
The Madison Square Boys Club held a Christmas party for fifty boys of the East Side yesterday morning at the club headquarters 312 East 30th street.
Only two days ago everybody was quoting "The Night Before Christmas." But it is a curious thing that in the whole

The great vaults of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine were filled with chants that Christians have sung in their churches since the fourteenth century as a choir of sixty male voices participated yesterday afternoon in the impressive annual Christmas carol service.
An apparent increase of reading throughout the nation in 1938 was reported today by Carl H. Milam, secretary of the American Library Association.

Two sailors have been arrested and three of their colleagues are being held here for questioning following the discovery of a regular organization selling "de luxe stowaway passages" to the United States on French Line boats.

Despite the attraction of AAA payments at a time of very low wheat prices, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration has been able to achieve only 60 per cent of the desired reduction in 1939 Winter wheat acreage.
Shackelford Bauer of 65 East Ninety-sixth Street, died yesterday afternoon in Roosevelt Hospital after a three months' illness from an intestinal ailment. His age was 22.

Frederick S. Freed, supervising customs agent for the United States Treasury Department for the New England district, who had been prominent in government work for forty years, died today at his home in Brookline, after an illness of two weeks. His age was 63.

Karel Capek, one of Czecho-Slovakia's most prominent authors, died of influenza here today at the age of 48. Mr. Capek was an exponent of the modern Czech literature and politically he adhered to the Benes camp and thus fell in disgrace with the new regime.

In a statement today to mark the end of the third year of Social Security as a national program, Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, declared that the changer which the new year was likely to bring in the Social Security laws would be welcome, "for we now have experience upon which we can build in extending and strengthening these laws."

The twenty-third national junior indoor tennis championship will get under way at 10 A. M. today in the Seventh Regiment Armory, with a record field of ninety-seven entered. Joseph Fishbach, defending champion, heads the seeded list.
Dr. Alfred 0. Lee, prominent scholar in languages at the University of Michigan, died today. He was 65 years old.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William MacMullen of Valley Stream, L. I., formerly of Rutherford, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ross MacMullen, to Manville Fenner Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Smith of Rutherford.

Richmond will be the intellectual center of the world this week, beginning Tuesday, when the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the largest scientific body of its kind in the world, with 20,000 members and nearly 1,000,000 members of 166 affiliated societies, will convene here for its 103d meeting, regarded as America's "Parliament of Science."
Eighty persons were reported killed and 150 injured today in a collision of passenger trains in Bessarabia, south of Kishinev.
Virgino Gayda, authoritative fascist editor, declared today that French Premier Edouard Daladier's plans to visit Corsica and Tunisia were a "provocation" toward Italy.
Governor-elect and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt entertained for relatives and guests at Oakland Farm today.

Jewell Young, the willowy Purdue sharpshooter who hung up an all-time basketball scoring record for the Big Ten last Winter, was named the outstanding athlete in the Western Conference during 1938 in a poll of sports writers, coaches and officials conducted by the Associated Press.

A bit of the North Pole was transposed to the grill of the Hotel McAlpin yesterday as the manager, John J. Woelfle, played host to a group of New York's professional Santa Clauses and served them their Christmas dinners in a modern setting. All the Santas attended in their gay red costumes, complete with boots and white beards which were later removed for eating.
The Yuletide spirit pervaded the Rose Bowl football camps of Duke and Southern California today. Santa Claus packed the sock of the U. S. C. team with a big surprise.

Fulton Ave; 1,699 (11-2929); Imperial Mortgage and Business Co. to Isaac J. Hurwitz, 1,325 Grand Concourse, due Nov. 8, 1940, 6%. $10,000. Burnside Ave (11-2814), s w s at e s of Anthony Ave. 58x118; Kellwood Realty Corp. to Sterling National Bank Trust Co., 1 year, 6%, $160,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Krock's column of Dec. 22, in discussing at the very close the inconsistent attitude of New England toward Federal interference when New England wants something, sums it all up as follows:

The Rev. Dr. Alfred Grant Walton, preaching yesterday at Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, Brooklyn, declared, "We need to realize that more than all treaties and pacts, more than all trade conferences and agreements, the world needs the good-will, the faith and the idealism which vital religion brings."

Along a 2,000-mile line connecting the northern outposts of civilization Christmas was celebrated today in style. From Pangnirtung on the Atlantic shoreline of Baffin Island, Resolution Island in Hudson Strait,
A two-alarm fire in a vacant loft building in the heart of the lower East Side awakened many families in the vicinity of Forsythe, Eldridge and Stanton Streets at 3:30 A. M. yesterday.
Alfred H. Lyon, former chief of the Binghamton Fire Bureau, died late yesterday at his home after a short illness. He was 75 years old.

Frank C. B. Page, who retired in 1935 as president of the E. W. Bliss Company, heavy machinery manufacturers, Fifty-third Street and Second Avenue, Brooklyn, died Saturday at his residence, 19 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn. He was born in Brooklyn 68 years ago.

Christianity lies apart from current events and much would be lost by a union of the two, warned the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Church, Wall Street and Broadway, in a sermon yesterday morning.

The greatest mistake of the church today is the attempt to explain to congregations things that cannot be made clear, declared the Rev. Dr. J. Valdemar Moldenhawer yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.

Taking advantage of two lapses in the home team's defense in the second period to manufacture both of their goals, the Atlantic City Sea Gulls downed the front-running New York Rovers, 2 to 1, in an Eastern Hockey League struggle, feature of 'the amateur doubleheader, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Miss Ruth Evelyn Terborgh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Teyborgh of Oberlin, Ohio, was married here this afternoon to Dr. John Wolcott Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris King Murray of Flushing, L. I.

The engagement of Miss Elsie Perronnet Beaumont of 37 East Sixtyfifth Street, New York, daughter of Andre A. Beaumont of Fortyfort, Pa., and the late Mrs. Elsie Butler Beaumont, to Robert Russell French, 72 University Place,

Never in mankind's history has the need for the Christmas gospel been so great as it is today, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday morning at the 11 o'clock Christmas Day communion service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reports that the total movement of freight by motor carriers in November was 19.4 per cent greater than correspondingly last year, but represented a decrease of 4.4 per cent, compared with October of this year.
The Detroit Red Wings took a firmer grasp on sixth place in the National Hockey League and shoved the Montreal Canadiens deeper into the cellar by downing the Habitants, 4 to 1, tonight before 7,200.
For eleven years Thew Wright Jr. and Benjamin McDonnell have been playing golf matches on Christmas Day. Yesterday found Wright in Dallas, Texas, and McDonnell in Buffalo.
Generalissimo Francisco Franco's forces reported today a continued advance in their Catalan offensive.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles MacBride of this city last night were hosts at a dinner and reception at the Winfield Scott Hotel here in observance of their fiftieth wedding anniversary.
Irving A. Lindberg, Nicaraguan Collector-General of Customs, soon will begin his twenty-eighth year with the Nicaraguan Government. He has served under twelve Nicaraguan Presidents.
The high point of the day in Lima today was an old-fashioned American Christmas dinner. It was given at the American Embassy to the entire staff of the United States delegation.

In a letter scolding Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, for a speech at Boston on Dec. 10, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve System, offered a defense of the swollen Federal debt, the spending program and other fiscal policies of the New Deal which the Virginia Senator had criticized. Mr.
Weehawken St, 8, Goldie Miller to Milton Lent, 386 West St: quitclaim, all right, title and interest (50c). Same property. Hattye Wittner to same: quitclaim. all right, title and interest (50c).

That the British Government should have reimposed, in the matter of for eign loans of British capital, the restrictions relaxed since Feb. 1 recognized plainly the recent heavy shipment of British capital to the United States and the consequent rapid fall in sterling.
Mozart's "Don Giovanni" and Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" will receive their first performances of the Winter during the seventh week of the Metropolitan opera season, beginning next Monday.

Sailors, rowers and boxers will open New Orleans' midwinter program of sports tomorrow. They will be the first performers in the week of events sponsored by the New Orleans Midwinter Sports Association which will come to a climax Jan. 2 with the Sugar Bowl football game between Carnegie Tech and Texas Christian Uniersity.

A sign, "no Jews wanted," appeared on the door of one of Trieste's leading cafes today.
