The cafe's action, similar to exclusion of Jews from certain theatres and the appearance of "Aryan shop" signs in many stores elsewhere in Italy, emphasized an aspect of the anti-Semitic campaign that has become a subject of controversy.
Washington Fayette Norton, one of this town's leading citizens, died today of pneumonia at his home here at the age of 94.
A light overnight snowfall that provided a white Christmas for this city also created what the police described as the worst driving conditions in a year,

Despite the remaining gloom over recent events Prague celebrated Christmas as usual today. The 150,000 refugees from Sudetenland, scattered throughout the country, received money and food that has been collected for them.

Santa Claus, who never had visited the Seminole Indian reservations in the Florida Everglades before, arrived in a dugout canoe today and there were squeals of joy from about 100 squaws and their papooses when he arrived.
Friday's ovation to Senator Carter Glass, at the twenty-fifth anniversary of the signing of the Federal Reserve Law, was a spontaneous and proper recognition of his services in that law's enactment.

Holt has reached an agreement with Robert Frost for the publication of his future books, prose as well as verse. A new edition of his "Collected Poems," which will include the poems published in "A Further Range" (1936), will be brought out late in the Winter.

Japanese bombers systematically raided important Chinese cities today in three provinces. At Kweilin, capital of Kwangsi Province, 100 houses were destroyed and a direct hit demolished a dugout on the grounds of the Baptist church.

Expectation of January reinvestment gave the California municipal bond market a much stronger tone last week. Reflecting this rise, the price average closed at 122.149, indicating a 3.02 per cent yield, compared with 121.392 and 3.06 per cent the week before.

Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, was a dinner hostess today at Sagamore Hill, her home here, to twenty-two members of her family, including two great-grandchildren, son and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. ...
The money market here was subjected last week to many conflicting factors, but, on balance, reflected an easier tone and tendency to lower rates.
From the financial point of view, the decline in the money rate last week was immediately profitable to the Treasury, reducing correspondingly the interest rate on the notes it issues.
James G. Blaine, president of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday the fund had made Christmas payments totaling $1,927,582 to the organization's participating health and welfare services.

The self-styled No. 1 "bad man" of the Philippines, Anselmo Balagtas, calmly surrendered at constabulary headquarters here today after a seventy-two-hour escapade in which an innocent man was killed when mistaken for the desperado.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Heydt of Bronxville, N. Y., and Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Margaret Heydt, to Richard Curtis Miles, son of Professor and Mrs. Egbert J. Miles of New Haven, Conn.

Weather conditions in Aregentina during the next few weeks are expected to have considerable effect on the North American corn markets. Drought and temperatures of 100 degrees and more have ruled in the northern part of the Argentina corn belt for the last week.

Religion and the moral power which it conveys were held up to the nation as guideposts toward a settlement of the world's troubles, by nine speakers representing major segments of the national scene in a "Reconciliation Forum" broadcast to the nation tonight under the auspices of The United States News.

Paul Whiteman, who for twenty years has been making jazz fit for Society, is still busy trying to make it fit for Art. At Carnegie Hall last night he and his All American Band put on a concert of "modern American music" which he called an "experiment," thus playing safe by promising nothing.
Working with only ten minutes' grace, two policemen gave Professor Emeritus Albert Bushnell Hart, Harvard historian, a welcome Christmas present just before he left for Chicago tonight.

No matter what anger may be felt at the wrongdoing of other peoples the celebration of the birth of Christ should not be observed in a spirit of hatred, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman told the congregation of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.
The New York Rangers abandoned their "streamlined" hockey for a much more cautious brand and defeated the Boston Bruins, 1 to 0, tonight before an overflow crowd of 16,000 at the Boston Garden.
Christmas was a day of duty for about 200 National Guardsmen as well as striking oil workers at the West Tulsa refinery of the MidContinent Petroleum Corporation.

Christmas trade here was brisk, being stimulated by the payment of full wages to the workers during the holidays, as decreed last year by Field Marshal Goering, and by the more, liberal bonuses paid by various concerns to their employes.
Harry Rushworth Kurrie, for twenty-four years president of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railroad-the Monon line--died today of a heart attack in his home here. He was 63 years old.

Mrs. Arthur Devries of 284 Wall Avenue, this city, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Augusta Devries, to Mr. William Henry Watkins White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph White, of Hampton, Va.
The projects approved by the Pan-American conference numbered 110, a check by the United States delegation showed today.

The Tennessee and Oklahoma football squads, unbeaten and untied champions of their conferences, rode toward Miami today for the Jan. 2 Orange Bowl game assured that a capacity crowd of 30,000 spectators would attend.

Martha Graham and her dance group gave their second recital of the season at the Alvin Theatre last night. The program had as its major item the long work, "American Document," seen here earlier in the season, music by Ray Green and a spoken text written by Miss Graham herself.

Heaping plates of roast turkey, with plenty of stuffing, cranberry sauce, candied sweet potatoes and string beans, provided the mainstay of a Christmas feast for 100 newsboys and other homeless youths at the Brace Memorial Newsboys House, 244 William Street, yesterday.
Georgia Tech's Engineers and the University of California's Bears will ring down the curtain on 1938 college football tomorrow in a game expected to attract 25,000.

El Mercurio, Chile's leading newspaper, today supports the Argentine modifications in the text of the continental solidarity formula adopted by the Pan-American Conference in Lima, Peru, as revealing the policy of South American countries.

The persecution tactics of modern dictators approximate those of King Herod, who sought to slay the Christ Child, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America at Washington declared in a sermon yesterday at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street east of Broadway.

Dr. Edgar Starr Barney, educator and transportation company official, who was principal of the Hebrew Technical Institute for more than fifty years, died at 6 o'clock last night at his home, 48 South Eighth Street, Brooklyn, from the effects of a stroke suffered ten days ago. He was 77 years old.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Silas E. Moore of 810 Westfield Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris S. Moore, to John Betz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Betz, also of this city.

The Rev. Leslie Moss, United States delegate to the International Christian Conference, called upon all nations today to outlaw war. "There is a strong feeling that as Christians we must work for some world order based on moral law and justice to small as well as large nations, justice which will be able to hold outlaw nations in

Christmas was viewed as a miracle accepted by "many who claim that they have ruled the fact of miracles out of their lives completely," in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Campbell at the First Reformed Church of Flushing, Bowne Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Queens, yesterday morning.

A letter from sixty-nine college economists to President Roosevelt, asking him to stop a cut in Works Progress Administration rolls, was made public here tonight by professor Paul M. Sweezy, of the Harvard Economics Department, one of the signers.

The hypocrisy of nations which "pretend to be faithful to their religions of peace and good-will and go on arming for war" was attacked yesterday by John Haynes Holmes in his Christmas service of Community Church in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

The marriage of Miss Eileen Egan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Egan, to Louis C. George, son of Mrs. Louis W. George of this city and the late Mr. George, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 178 East Seventy-second Street.

The German export and foreign trade situation continues to be a matter of grave concern. The Deutsche Bank estimates the adverse trade balance for 1938 for Greater Germany, including Austria, at 450,000,000 marks, against the old Reich's export surplus of 423,000,000 marks in 1937.

Administration farm leaders said today that unless agricultural prices improved considerably in the next few months the new Congress might be asked to appropriate at least $750,000,000 for benefit payments to farmers for the 1940 crop year to obtain compliance with surplus-reducing programs.

Miss Adrienne Lande, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Lande of the Croydon Hotel and the late Mr. Lande, was married last night at the same hotel to Herbert Warren Rubin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Solomon H. Rubin of Brookline, Mass.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,564,187,850. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's and Wanamaker's:

The greatest event in history is the most simply told, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks declared yesterday morning at a special Christmas service held in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.
Joe McCarthy's Christmas message to the baseball world today was that "we are going to win another pennant and set a league record."

The Hispanos defeated the Trenton Highlanders by 2-1 in an American Soccer League game at Celtic Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. After ten minutes of play in the final half, Sweeny of the Highlanders made the first goal.

C. C. N. Y., N. Y. U., Brooklyn College, Yeshiva and possibly Columbia will meet tomorrow morning at the Manhattan C. C. for the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League. The Phillips Trophy, donated by Harold M. Phillips, president of the league and club will be at stake.

Raymond Dumont, president of the National Semi-Pro Baseball Congress, announced today he had signed a contract with Teofilo Maldonado, Puerto Rican commissioner of athletics, for the first semipro world series-a four-out-ofseven-game play-off at Mayaguez, Puerto Rico, starting Sept. 6, 1939.
A second-period bombardment which saw them score three direct hits served the New York Amer?cans admirably in their celebration of Christmas Night.

Eleven-year-old Earl Baker found a new leg in his Christmas stocking today-an artificial one. The gift of sympathetic friends in this community, it replaces the right leg which the boy lost eight months ago when he took a dare to hop a moving freight.

Miss Helen L. Sites, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. D. Sites of Dayton; Va., and a member of the faculty of Woodrow Wilson School here, became the bride of Willard W. Peck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Peck of Cove, Ore.,

Gold imports in Great Britain in November amounted to [pound]3,989,267 and exports to [pound]24,440,137. Of the imports [pound]59,091 came from the Transvaal; [pound]321,262 from Rhodesia; [pound]192,082, West Africa; [pound]10,476, East Africa; [pound]904,856, India; [pound]343,700, Uruguay; [pound]1,275,620, Germany; [pound]376,218, Switzerland; [pound]74,322, France; [pound]36,219, Holland; and the balance from other countries.

Although today was a time of rejoicing throughout the world, there were few scenes more touching than those enacted in a huge country house near here where 120 Basque children celebrated their second Christmas in the hospitable country that has given them refuge from the horrors of war.

The New York Rangers will return to their home ice tonight when they oppose the fast skating Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden. Considering that the teams are rivals of long standing, and that the Rangers have not been seen here for six days, the game promises to attract a large crowd.
Theodore Gliedt, New Jersey legal representative of the German Consul General in New York for the last fifteen years, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 74.
Mrs. Fred C. Grumman of this city and Westport, Conn., has announced the engagement of her sis ter, Miss Ella T. Beaver, to Frederick W. Appell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Appell of New York.
Senator William H. King, Democrat of Utah, proposed today that the United States sever diplomatic relations with Germany and then break off commercial ties with the Nazis.

The Swedish F. C. booters gained undisputed possession of first place in the international division of the National Soccer League by defeating the New York Hakoah A. C., 5-0, yesterday at Dana Park, Brooklyn.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 79.7, which compared with 79.8 the week before, 79.8 two weeks before, 80.4 three weeks before and 80.5 four weeks before.
The mass of Germans under Nazi rule cherish steadfastly the old-fashioned- Christmas-even in the face of some of the more radical Nazi neo-pagan notions-and today's Christmas was no exception.
Mrs. Edwina Booth Crossman, only daughter of Edwin Booth, died suddenly yesterday at the age of 77 in the home of her son, Edwin Booth Grossman at the Holley Chambers, 33 Washington Square.
Mr. and Mrs. John R. Shea of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Dorothy Shea, to James Kenneth McMahon, son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. McMahon of Newark.

The gifts of 465 contributors reached the Neediest Cases Fund on Christmas Day and added $6,734.17 to its total. This brought the aggregate amount that has been received for the twenty-seventh annual appeal for those in the worst distress in New York to $233,158.02.
Although information concerning Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's London visit leaked out slowly and unofficially, more than sufficient has become known to explain its failure.

The three adults and a child burned to death late last night when fire swept a three-story double house at 209-211 Broome Street here were identified today as Thomas V. Dallas, 35 years old; Harvey Garrett, 35; Mrs. Anna Williams, 60, and Eleanor Cooper, 8, all Negroes.
Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader, and members of his family were checking over the contents of his home at 206 East Eighteenth Street yesterday to determine if anything had been stolen.

Assemblyman and Mrs. Fred W. DeVoe of this city gave a dinner at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Frances DeVoe, to Robert Rey Windeler, son of Mrs. John Henry Windeler of New York and Framingdale, N. J., and the late the Rev. Dr: Windeler.

Mr. and Mrs J. Frederick Talcott will give a dinner tomorrow night in the Persian Roomof the Plaza for Mr. Talcott's granddaughter, Miss Mary Hope Talcott, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Talcott. Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Withers will come to the Waldorf-Astoria today from Pittsburgh.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jane Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Vincent Campbell of 16 East Ninety-eighth Street, to Frederick Warner Hamilton, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Arnold Hamilton of Hartford, Conn.
Liquidation by holders of lard futures developed last week and all deliveries sold at new low levels for the season, while cash lard dropped to a new low price since 1934.

The lower tip of Manhattan was a quiet, deserted place yesterday. The financial district was empty and only a few stragglers lounged in the sun along the waterfront. In contrast, one building was a beehive of activity.

The French liner Normandie is due to sail today for France and England. Her passenger list ineludes Paul van Zeeland, former Premier of Belgium; P. E. Naggiar, French Ambassador to Soviet Russia; Dr. F. Tudela,
Senator Vandenberg, the Republican leader from Michigan, put forward today his personal program for the approaching. Seventy-sixth Congress.

Women representatives in the State Legislatures dropped from 149 in thirty-eight States to 127 in twenty-seven States in the last decade, while those in Congress declined from nine to five, the National League of Women voters announced today.
Playing in the mud at Starlight Park, the Kearny Scots-Americans subdued the favored Brookhattans by 2-0, before a crowd of 3,000 in an American Soccer League fixture yesterday.
The undefeated Crescent A. C. basketball team halted the New York Fire Department quintet, 42-32, at the Crescent clubhouse in Brooklyn yesterday.

The recent announcement of Sir John Anderson, new British Minister for Civilian Defense, that Britain would spend some [pound]20,000,000 in reinforcing private homes, apartment houses and other structures to provide splinter and blast-proof shelters must be welcome news to those millions of Londoners who experienced the terror of unpreparedness during the recent crisis.

Prices of cotton made a slow advance last week. Net changes from day to day were small and, except on Friday, they were all in the upward direction. Active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 6 to 20 points.
Paris celebrated Christmas with its usual enthusiasm, with cafes and restaurants crowded and theatres and cinemas playing to capacity audiences.

Miss Margaret Martin, 19-year-old Kingston girl who was strangled to death, apparently by a man who posed as a prospective employer, was eulogized in Catholic churches in this area today as "a martyr."

For the second consecutive Sunday, a group of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's supporters picketed radio station WMCA, 1,657 Broadway, between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, protesting the station's refusal to carry the Royal Oak (Mich.) priest's broadcasts unless he submitted advance copies of his talks.

Seasonal and holiday factors last week combined to reduce the nation-wide steel ingot rate from 58 to 52 per cent. A further leveling-off is expected for the current week, since many plants shut down on Friday and will not start again until Tuesday. Some companies, however, plan to make up the operating deficiency.

In his own backyard Santa Claus is just a "bogeyman" unless he wears mufti. Mrs. Donald B. Macmillan, wife of the Arctic explorer, said today that when a reduniformed, bewhiskered Santa first made his appearance at the Macmillan-Moravian School in Northern Labrador, the Eskimo children fled and hid in closets.
The composite balance sheet of all German banks for the end of November released this week-end, shows an increase of the banks' holdings of Reich bonds by 445,000,000 marks in a single month.
A more just attitude toward the roots of the Jewish people was asked yesterday morning at the service of the Free Synagogue by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise in his sermon, "Jews and Jesus-Roots and Flower:"

BRODY--RUBI--Mr. and Mrs. Jacob S. Brody of 12 West 72d St. announce the engagement of their daughter, Elinor Ann, to Edwin George Rubin, son of Mrs. Fay Rubin and the late Louis J. Rubin of Chicago. ENDELSON --ASSAR -- Mr. and Mrs. Harry Massar of 40 West 77th St., Manhattan, announce the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie, to Mr. Jack Endelson.

Charged with the kidnapping of a one-month-old child, A n d r e w O'Rorke, 37 years old, a laborer, of 799 East 150th Street, the Bronx, was held in $5,000 bail for a hearing tomorrow by Magistrate William Klapp in Bronx Magistrates' Court yesterday.

" Santa Claus is coming," chanted more than a score of boys and girls at the Medical Center here today as Mayor Frank Hague and a man dressed in the traditional red garb of St. Nicholas entered the children's medical ward of the hospital to distribute toys donated by the Jersey City Elks Club.

The marriage of Representative Bert Lord and Mrs. George Gregg on Dec. 6 at Orange, Va., by the Rev. Dr. William Adams of Afton, near Binghamton, where both bride and bridegroom also reside, has been revealed here.
Tony Canzoneri is rounding into form for the next battle in his comeback campaign, a ten-rounder against Eddie Zivic of Pittsburgh at the Hippodrome on Friday night.
The postman soaks his feet in hot water and, without wishing anybody any harm, is glad that the flood of good-will, in so far as it comes through the mails, is about to abate.

In the closing week of the year there has been an ominous accumulation of evidence that many, perhaps even most of the difficulties and tensions under which the German economic structure is laboring, are due to the precipitate and excessive tempo at which the government's building and other programs are being carried out.

Eighteen men and two women were landed last night at the Battery after being rescued from their sinking ship, the Smaragd, by the American freighter Schodack Friday morning when there was a 65mile northwest gale blowing and a forty-foot sea running.
Miss Rita Singstad, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ole Singstad, gave a tea yesterday at the home of her parents, 1,035 Fifth Avenue.

The Christmas message and New Year wish of Miss Alice Paul, founder of the Woman's party, is that women everywhere may take as their watchword the warning that "eternal vigilance is the price of liberty."

Considering only internal economic conditions, the results of the government's new policy- show real improvement, which Finance Minister Paul Reynaud emphasized in his last speech in the Chamber of Deputies.

Although basketball activities in metropolitan college circles were curtailed to some extent on account of the holidays last week, the unbeaten teams in the city were reduced from six to five as N. Y. U. fell by the wayside.
Mrs. Thomas H. Blodgett was chairman of the Christmas committee of the Great Barrington Visiting Nurse Association, which distributed baskets of food, clothing and toys to needy families.
The steamer Comet arrived here today from New York and reported one of its passengers apparently leaped to his death off the Connecticut coast.

For man to think that he can remove the sins of the world without faith in Jesus Christ is "mere prattle" and as unavailing as trying to lift one's self by one's own bootstraps, the Rev. Arthur R. Kleps said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Immanuel Lutheran Church, Eighty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, Administrator of the Archdiocese of New York, celebrated pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday and bestowed his blessing upon a congregation of about 2,000 as the ritual ended.

Warners have opened negotiations with George Abbott and Rodgers and Hart for the screen rights to "The Boys From Syracuse." If the deal is completed, Eddie Albert, who is appearing in the Broadway production, will be featured.

The world is a much kindlier place, cynics to the contrary, than it was when Christ was born in a stable, the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, the pastor, said yesterday at Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Wadsworth Avenue and 174th Street.

IT'S no fish story. The figures of the Census Bureau in Washington, as reported recently, verify it. Twenty-four cents of every dollar spent for athletic goods in the United States are put on the line for fishing tackle. No wonder Santa's reindeer objected to the drag on their load Saturday night, with all those 16-0 reels aboard.

A plane piloted by George H. Earle, Pennsylvania's flying Governor, carrying a party from Harrisburg to this city for a Christmas dinner, crashed late today and overturned on Wings Field, eighteen miles northwest of Philadelphia.

Christmas is the festival of a personality whom the world has found it impossible to escape, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday morning in his sermon at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

THE LADY VANISHES, from a screen play by Sidney Gillatt and Frank Launder,. based on Ethel Lina White's story, "The Wheel Spins"; directed by Alfred Hitchcock and produced by Gaumont-British. At the Gobe.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, was 68.6 on Dec. 21, compared with 68.4 a fortnight before, 69 the preceding month and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, immediately before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The official 1939 schedules for the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League and the International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League were announced yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, executive director of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics, with which these groups are affiliated.

The final concert in the series of Diaz Tuesday Afternoon Musicales will take place this afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. artists will be Ezio Pinza of the Metropolitan Opera; Prince Irakli Orbeliani, pianist; and members of the Pro Arpa Quartet, harpists.

The Sugar Bowl's week of sports started today with plying of oars, sails and boxing gloves. The Orleans Rowing Club opened the program with a two-length victory over the Rollins College crew of Winter Park, Fla., in a fouroared race on the new basin canal's mile and a quarter course.
Tass, official news agency, reported tonight that Russia had decided to close her consulate at Milan, Italy, because of a "hooligan attack" by Italian Fasoists during an anti-French demonstration.

Madeleine Carroll, movie actress, sailed yesterday on the Normandle to spend two weeks in London and Paris. She will give her annual charity performance at the St. Honore Orphange. She is scheduled to start work on a new motion picture early next month.

Two days after Christmas the 1938 Neediest Cases Fund stands at $236,146.27 as the result of 235 contributions received yesterday, aggregating $2,988.25. Many of the letters that came with gifts had been mailed on Christmas Day and their messages were filled with the spirit of the day. Lucy T. Lythgoe voiced the sentiment of many others when she wrote:

W. H. Cowley, president of Hamilton College, announced tonight that the college would award to Miss Helen Hayes, the actress, and Dr. Gustav Eckstein, the author, honorary degrees of Doctor of Humane Letters next month.

Before sailing for Brussels yesterday on the Normandle, Paul Van Zeeland, former Premier of Belgium, who had been in the United States for two months, said one of America's most precious gifts was an ocean on each side.
Mrs. Harriet Flower Farwell, wife of John V. Farwell, retired head of the former wholesale drygoods house bearing his name, died today at the age of 73.

Mailed applications for motor vehicle licenses will be filled today and hereafter at offices of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau at 155 Worth Street, Manhattan, in Brooklyn and at county clerks' offices in other counties.

Today's events: Philadelphia Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, evening; Alexander Kipnis, bass-baritone, Town Hall, evening; Nutchuk, lecturer, Steinway Hall, afternoon; vocal recital, Salle des Artistes, 8:30.

During the coming year the New York City school system will have 1,980 teaching and supervisory vavancies to fill, it was announced at the Board of Education office yesterday. From all indications 1939 will be a boom year for prospective teachers.

European diplomats and observers stationed here have been hard put to it to explain in their dispatches concerning the Pan-American Conference the sudden United States conversion to collective security, although It appears to them to be on a small scale.

A recommendation that the State authorize $200,000,000 in loans for housing projects, and annual subsidies of $1,000,000 for 1939 and 1940, the maximum permitted under the law, was made to Republican legislative leaders yesterday by the Legislative Advisory Committee of the New York County Republican Committee.
A sympathetic message from the British Foreign Office has disclosed the third attempt in less than four years on the life of Luang Bipul Songgram, who was named Premier on Dec. 15.

The newspaper Telegrafo calls attention to the action by the recent Congress requiring foreign concessionaries exporting minerals and fruit to sell 20 per cent of their value in gold or gold exchange to the government central bank.

Edwin O. Perrin, national commander of the American Veterans Association, alleged today that a pension program sponsored by the Veterans of Foreign Wars would be so costly that "it would ultimately divert funds from the Treasury which are urgently needed to strengthen national defenses."

The Centro Espanol of Hunter College will give performances of "Mariana Pineda" by Federico Garcia Lorca, at Columbia University today at 2:30 and 8:45 P. M., under the auspices of the Spanish Institute of the United States.
More and more States are coming to recognize the practical as well as the esthetic importance of protecting the beauties of their countryside, particularly along the main highway routes.
An official announcement tonight said that an exchange of notes had approved documents and maps defining and marking the 600-mile frontier between Finland and Soviet Russia.

Probate Judge Harold L. Knapp of Greenwich has purchased a residence and various outbuildings and about one-sixth of an acre of land, owned by Mrs. Anna S. Irwin. The house has a commanding view of Long Island Sound and adjoins Judge Knapp's estate.

The Citizens Savings Bank will open its first uptown branch office, at 570 Lexington Avenue, tomorrow. Since the bank was founded, about seventy-eight years ago, its operations have been conducted downtown, first at 12 Avenue A, and since 1862, in its present location on the southwest corner of Canal Street and the Bowery.

The Doubleday, Doran Spring list, which closed last week, includes seventy titles for publication between March 10 and July 21. Among the Spring books are "The Letters of T. E. Lawrence," edited by David Garnett; "Edgar Wallace: The Biography of a Phenomenon," by Margaret Lane;

Evidently Stuart isn't the only "warm" sailfish port in Florida these days, for the West Palm Beach Fishing Club reports that it has just awarded a gold button to S. J. Devine of New York for an 8-foot 1 1/2inch sail.

Egbert Moxham Jr. and Walter Voelbel were the winning skippers in Manhasset Bay's weekly frostbite dinghy regatta today. Fifteen boats sailed windward and leeward courses in light and rather fluky airs.

Reports that Wang Ching-wei, former President of the Chinese Executive Yuan, was en route to Hong Kong to discuss "truce" terms with Japanese emissaries have caused lively discussion in diplomatic circles here.

There is a new and more brilliant sun at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History, it was announced yesterday. "This new sun," the announcement said, "is unique in that it only rises because its only function is to throw spectacular dawn effects upon the planetarium's morning sky. The old sun will,
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The death of Helen Miller Gould Shepard last week makes possible a more complete summary of her gifts to New York University than has hitherto been available.

The possibility of a city-wide strike of more than 10,000 taxicab drivers appeared yesterday with the announcement by the Transport Workers Union, that special meetings of cab drivers have been called for Thursday to consider terms of new agreements with various cab companies.

Closely following the recent sale of a large apartment house site in the Cord Meyer Development center of Forest Hills, L. I., that company announces the sale of another large vacant plot for apartment house improvement to Display Homes, Inc., of Brooklyn, Joseph Tabor. president.
Three debutantes of the Oranges were introduced to society tonight at a supper dance at the Essex County Country Club. They are Miss Marion P. Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Bruce ...
William F. Bleakley, president of the Westchester County Commission, made a plea for religious and racial tolerance in a broadcast yesterday over Station WMCA.

The close of the holiday selling period last week left most wholesale markets in a very healthy conedition, with unusually light invenstories reported in men's and boys' furnishings, children's and girls' coats and dresses, lingerie, housecoats, sports items and accessories.

Full military honors will be accorded today to Master Sergeant Gordon McKenzie, senior non-commissioned officer in charge of United States Army information service in the Second Corps area in the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, who died of a heart attack in his office Saturday night. Funeral services will be held at 9:30 A. M. today in the Catholic chapel on the army reservation on Governors Island. He had been in the service eighteen Years.

The Province of Mendoza, Argentina, has extended the period for acceptance of its offer of June 1, last, to holders of its external per cent bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1926, and due on June 1, 1951, to exchange these obligations for new readjustment bonds, according to an announcement by Edmundo

THE outstanding achievements of the passing year have been duly chronicled. Sports' foremost experts in the last few days have gone over their chosen fields with a fine-tooth comb and with that easy familiarity known only to men who spend every waking hour with their subject and then dream of it at night.

It is pleasant to learn that despite mild zero weather which slows up dogsledding the holiday season along the Arctic Circle has been a merry one. Little clusters of civilized life-hospitals, trading posts, supply depots, police barracks and radio stations-now link the frozen frontier from Baffin Land, through the shores of Hudson Bay to the mouth of the Mackenzie.

The football forces of Duke and Southern California, standing the strain of Rose Bowl training far better than their camp followers, today began final drills for their clash next Monday with all the snap and vigor of a herd of colts.

Distribution of Recovery Board labels in the coat and suit industry last week total 205,700, this figure being higher than the sales for the corresponding week of any previous year under the Recovery Board and the NRA, according to an announcement for publication today.

A change in the plans for the East River Drive to preserve the unobstructed view of the old Gracie Mansion in Carl Shurz Park from the East River and from the park that slopes down to the river was announced yesterday by Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan.

Edwin S. Jarrett of Wild Goose Farm, Shepherdstown, W. Va., a consulting civil engineer and former head of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, who had been associated with the design and building of many important structures throughout the country, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was born in Brooklyn seventysix years ago.
Motion pictures, which aid gridiron mentors during the season, will play an equally prominent part in the annual convention of the National Football Coaches Association, which begins tomorrow night.

The prediction that trade will probably continue its upward trend in the first part of the new year is made by Banking, the official publocation of the American Bankers Association in Its survey of business in the current issue. In its broadest aspects, the survey says, the business outlook can be described

Playing in 80-degree weather, Clearwater's Crimson Tornado defeated the Cardinals from Pompton Lakes, N. J., 20 to 6, today in an intersectional high school football game. The Cardinal touchdown came in the second period when Mylon took a 26-yard pass from Redinger. Williams failed to convert.

Disturbing news has been received from Jibuti. It can be summarized as follows: From day to day, the Italian authorities are doing their best to persuade the natives that the French will be swept out of French Somaliland and thrown out into the sea before long.

C. T. Jackson and F. A. Cauchois tied at 94 for the high-over-all scratch cup in the 100-target event at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. In the first shoot-off, the rivals hit 24 each. Jackson then scored, 24 to 28.
The executive committee of the World Jewish Congress today accused the government of the Free City of Danzig of organizing a pogrom to drive Jews out of the highly Nazilied city.
Mr. and Mrs. Russell Charles Veit of 9 East Seventy-fifth Street gave a dinner with dancing last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Amelie.Veit.

George W. Loft, who is developing the forty-acre Loft estate property at Baldwin, L. I., announced yesterday that he would continue home construction throughout the Winter in that community on the Sunrise Highway and Merrick Road between the Baldwin and Rockville Center railroad stations.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday that nine students of the New York University Graduate Division for Training in Public Service had been chosen to serve as research associates in the city's Department of Investigation.

James Loucheim, Civil War veteran, former Village Clerk here and a former business man, builder and newspaper man, died today at 53 Washington Avenue here, where he lived with a daughter, Mrs. Harry Rascovar. His age was 93.

Automobile production declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index dropped to 90.3 from 96.1. The figure was 89.9 for the week ended Dec. 25, 1937. The week's output totaled 92,890 units, according to the estimate of Ward's Automotive Reports. This compared with 102,905 for the previous week and 67,230 for the corresponding week last year.

Young Richard J. Bender, representing Pingry School of Elizabeth, N. J., stole the spotlight from six seeded contestants yesterday as competition opened in the annual national junior indoor tennis championship on the Seventh Regiment Armory's reconditioned floor courts.

The National Coal Association said today that Representative Dirksen, Republican, of Illinois. had protested to the State Department against any trade agreement with Venezuela which would "freeze" the excise tax on petroleum imports at the current rate of a half-cent a gallon.

In a Christmas setting of evergreens and white flowers, Miss Betsy Jane Smith was introduced to society at a supper dance given tonight by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Howard Smith, at the Short Hills Club.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today that United States grain markets were inclined to maintain firm prices on wheat as a result of government predictions of a relatively small Winter wheat crop next year.

The Toronto Maple Leafs scored early in their game with. the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night and thereafter resisted successfully the most strenuous efforts made by the Blue Shirts. The incessant aggressiveness of Lester Patrick's charges was not enough to overcome the Leafs, who, finding a spot for a third period goal, blanked the local skaters, 2 to 0.

The presidtum of the Supreme Soviet decided today to honor the late Valery Chkaloff, who flew with two other Russian aviators from Moscow to Vancouver, Wash., in 1937, by renaming the city of Orenburg in his memory.
Ambassador Jules Henry, who was for many years attached to the French Embassy in Washington, left Paris this evening for Barcelona to take up the post of Ambassador to which he'had been appointed.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, announced yesterday the appointment of five scholars, two from the United States, as visiting professors at American and European universities under the endowment.

Sports leaders in all parts of the country have enlisted in the campaign against infantile paralysis, Grantland Rice, chairman of the sports council of the committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday, announced yesterday.

The Cuban team tonight won its first match against an American array in the international fencing tournament being held at the Sports Palace. The score was tied at 16 points each but the decision was given to the Cubans, who received 36 touches to the Americans' 38. Epees were used in the match.

The New York Americans and Brookhattan, old soccer rivals, played an American League game interspersed with thrills and fisticuffs at Starlight Park yesterday before a crowd of 4,000. After a scoreless first half,

A speedy Southern California basketball team will bring an eight-game winning streak to Madison Square Garden Friday night against L. I. U. The unbeaten Trojans, setting a fast pace, easily took the measure of Temple University, 46-34, at Convention Hall tonight, making a great impression on 10,476 persons who witnessed the encounter.

The engagement of Miss Jeanne Marie Aubry to James J. Sexton Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Stephen Aubry of Belle Harbor, L. I. Miss Aubry is a graduate of Our Lady of Wisdom Academy and St. Joseph's College.
Mikhal Kolzoff, former editor- in - chief of Pravda, organ of the Communist party, is the latest victim of the purge by Soviet secret police, it was revealed in Moscow today.

Contending that a sandspit of Provincetown Harbor, and not "the mythical rock" at Plymouth, is the. "holy ground" on which the Pilgrims first trod, Cape Codders propose to dig up tombstones here to prove that at least some of the pious pioneers went ashore for forty days.

Timely arrival of a telegraphed Christmas greeting saved fourteen persons from asphyxiation at a family reunion here last night. He smelled "something burning," the messenger told Claude Gaston as he delivered the greeting.
The Junior employment offices of the National Youth Administration found jobs in private industry for 7.009 youths in November, according to a report issued today by the

A new issue of $349,000 of 2 1/4 per cent bonds of Linden, N. J., will be offered to the public today by M. M. Freeman Co., Inc., at prices to yield from 0.60 per cent to 2.2 per cent. The bonds, which are dated Sept. 15, 1938, and will mature from 1939 to 1956, have been issued to provide funds for school, library, general improvement and assessment purposes.

Lights along the Westchester County parkways should be extinguished permanently if the Westchester Lighting Company refuses to reduce its charges for them from $50,000 a year to about $14,000, Gordon M. Wagner, secretary of the Westchester Council of Utility Rate Committees, declared today.

A number of up-State farms were reported yesterday as having been sold through H. A. Tillson, broker of Walden. Included was one of 145 acres, formerly owned by Thomas Malley, near Montgomery, which was purchased by Fred Dobrick of East Paterson. N. J.

Pete Scalzo, 127, West Side, outpointed Paul Lee, 125, Indianapolis, in the feature eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 2,500. In the eight-round semi-final, Joe Ferrando, 134, Jersey City, gained the decision over Chalky Wright, 127 1/4, California. Walter Franklin,
The Spanish Insurgent military command reported tonight the capture of Borjas Blancas, a strategic town sixteen miles southeast of Lerida on the main highway to Tarragona on the Mediterranean coast.
Arab raiders are believed to have kidnapped a British bank manager, Louis le Bouvier, this afternoon.

While fleeing from the scene of an attempted grocery store hold-up at 203 West Eighty-second Street last night, David Holmes, 15-yearold Haaren High School student of 169 West 102d Street, was captured after being injured seriously in a fall from the roof of a five-story tenement. Two other youths were also arrested.

Miss Marguerite Amelia Huvelle, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rene H. Huvelle of 168 East Seventy-fourth Street, was introduced to society yesterday afternoon at a tea dance given for her by her parents at Sherry's.
Mr. and Mrs. Hale Anderson of this place announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Anderson, to Francis Cushman St. John at a Christmas party at their home last night.

Queena Mario, American lyric soprano, gave her farewell performance as a member of the Metropolitan Opera at yesterday afternoon's special performance of "Hansel and Gretel" at the opera house. Miss Mario has been a member of the company for seventeen years. She has decided to devote virtually all her time to teaching.
Trainer Tom Smith prepared tonight to ship Seabiscuit, voted the year's outstanding horse, to California, and another meeting between the Biscuit and War Admiral appeared only a remote possibility.

Funeral services for Dr. Henry W. Berg of 10 East Seventy-third Street, authority on infectious diseases and internal medicine, were held at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in Temple Emanu-El, Sixtyfifth Street and Fifth Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson officiated.

Fifteen men with prices on their. heads, Sudeten-German Social Demcrats who sought to preserve the Sudetenland for Czecho-Slovakia, have found refuge here. They are busy learning the arts of the woodsman and the farmer to fit themselves for a new life in Canada.
Mr. and Mrs. John N. MacDonald an nounced at a dinner tonight in their home here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary MacDonald to Major J. Gibb Stewart.
Here's a real fish story-one about a twotailed goldfish which could not swim because the two tails worked against each other.

With many distinguished persons in the audience, a benefit concert for German and Austrian refugees, irrespective of creed, was given last night at Carnegie Hall at which a capacity audience paid more than $30,000 for seats.

Annual meeting, Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Disease, Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, 9 A. M. Continues tomorrow. Metropolitan Museum of Art. Masterpieces of Painting, XVII Century, Altman Collection (general tour), 11 A. M.; Stories from Greek Vases (general tour), 2 P. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.

The celebration of Christmas ended yesterday with a whirl of travel to return to the workaday world. And as a change from the pleasant weather of the last few days, a cold rain fell in a biting drizzle late last night as the prelude to a real Winter cold snap expected by tonight.

France sent a note to Italy today accepting her denunciation of the 1935 Laval-Mussolini agreement, indicating the possibility of further discussion, but warning, it is understood, that such discussions must be between these two countries only.

Importers who are fighting the government's regulation requiring "Made-in-Germany" marking on goods shipped from the Sudeten region after Nov. 10 are hoping for a preliminary decision on their protests before the end of January, spokesmen said here yesterday.
Henry Donnett, 32 years old, cut off his right hand with a pocketknife to save his life, and physicians said today that he was recovering.

A two-pound, seven-ounce airplane radio antenna weight, which apparently had fallen from a plane pausing over Hoboken Sunday night, was found today in the fourth-floor hallway of a building at 528 Washington Street, Hoboken. The weight,
Declaring that home building for owners' occupancy in 1939 will be more active throughout the thirtyseven States east of the Rockies than at any previous time since the depression, F. Bruce Forward,

About the only reason for tacking the word "Republican" to the proposals submitted yesterday to the legislative leaders at Albany by Harold Riegelman's committee is that the Republicans are the people to appeal to if one wishes action in the forthcoming session. In essence,

West defeated East in the intersectional relay competition at the fourth annual Aquatic Forum today. The Westerners piled up 72 points to 54 for the Easterners. The relays followed a pageant of peace, featuring an address by Senator Robert Bulkley of Ohio.

Discovery of a coating that makes glass invisible was announced today by Dr. Katharine B. Blodgett. The purest glass transmits about 92 per cent of light, as against more than 99 per cent with the new coating, she stated. Acoated pane is visible only by its dimly outlined edges.

Harry Myers, veteran motion picture actor, died here yesterday at the age of 56. Mr. Myers, celebrated for his portrayal of the star role in the silent version of "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court," had been ill but three days.
Samuel Goldwyn has placed "I am a Doctor" on his production schedule. Joel McCrea and Walter Brennan will be featured. Richard Bennette also may be seen.

Models and drawings depleting geologic foundations and conditions affecting the construction of tunnels, skyscrapers and bridges on Manhattan Island will be shown during the semi-centennial meeting of the Geological Society of America opening tomorrow at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A 17-year-old schoolboy was found guilty last night by Magistrate Louis Brodsky in Night Court of making a petty racket out of the practice of some gamins of sneaking into motion picture theatres by way of exits to avoid paying admission.
The Bureau of Agriculture Economics announced today that beginning on Jan. 2, its livestock market news reports would include only "salable supplies" in the livestock receipt data.

Former Premier Leon Blum, fighting to keep control of the Socialist party at its annual convention, obtained approval today for a program of cooperation by France, the United States and Britain to curb Italy, Germany and Japan.

The fundamental question in the economic outlook, stated in its broadest terms, is whether business as now organized can function effectively under the restraints that have been and may be placed upon it by outside forces, the Guaranty Trust Company asserts in its review of 1938, published in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Potter of this place and North Newcastle, Me., announced yesterday at a family Christmas party in their home here the engagement of their, daughter, Miss Elizabeth Bradford Potter, to John Nicholas Vandemoer of Chihuahua City, Mexico.

Franklin E. Pierce, director of the bureau of teacher preparation under the State Board of Education, died yesterday at his home in West Hartford at the age of 61. He came to Connecticut from New Jersey in November, 1924, and in November, 1930, he became director of the bureau of teacher preparation.

Harold M. Phillips, president of the Intercollegiate Chess League and donor of the challenge trophy which will be competed for this week, announced yesterday that he would open the annual meeting of that organiaztion at the rooms of the Manhattan Chess Club in the Hotel Alamac at 9:30 o'clock this morning.

To demonstrate that a lion would not bite, Sylvester M. Kirby, 35, thrust his hand into a cage at an ocean park concession where he was employed. The lion seized him and clawed him so badly his arm had to be amputated. The animal was shot today because its owner feared it might become a killer.

Less than twenty-four hours after a plane which he was piloting turned over yesterday in landing at Wings Field, near Ambler, Governor George H. Earle was flying again today. Limping because of an injured

Two more entries were received yesterday for the Columbus Council, K. of C., indoor track and field meet a week from Saturday at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory Brooklyn, according to an announcement by Frank A. Madden, director of the games.
The United States cruiser Phoenix came here on a shakedown cruise today and steamed right into the midst of an excited welcome by the Italian population to two newly arrived Italian cruisers.

Seeking background for a history of medicine slated to occupy him for a decade, Dr. Henry E. Sigerist, Johns Hopkins University scientist, will leave next November for Egypt, hoping to delve more than 3,500 years into the past.

The 210 members of the crew of the S. S. Seattle, receiving ship at the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, entertained fifty underprivileged children yesterday at a Chrisimas party aboard the vessel and in the reception hall at the yard. The children were all under the care of the Salvation Army.

Sixteen years ago the Theatre Guild produced Karel Capek's "R. U. R." and added the word "robot" to' the American language. Now Capek is dead of influenza in Prague at the age of 48. Holding with former President Benes and with the democratic ideals which were permitted to prevail in CzechoSlovakia prior to last October, he died, as the dispatch says, "in disgrace with the new regime." "R. U. R."
Mrs. M. Q. Allyn of Cleveland has announced the engagement of her sister, Miss Elizabeth Turner, to John Somervell Williams of New York, son of Mrs. Somervell Williams of Baltimore.

Chairman Eccles's letter to Senator Byrd is a defense not only of the Government's budget policy but a frank expression of the belief that in bad years it is an actual advantage to achieve a deficit. The heart of Mr.

Because Robert M. Hutchins, the president the University of Chicago, is a clot friend of William O. Douglas, chairman of the SEC, Mr. Hutchins's abrupt re ignation as one of the three public go ernors of the New York Stock E change produced both verbal and wri ten reports that the SEC and th Exchange had split again.

The Washington Post said tonight that supporters of Representative Martin of Massachusetts claimed 140 of the 169 Republican votes in the House in the contest for the House Republican leadership. Mr. Martin was quoted as saying that his election to the leadership.

A railroad fireman spotted the limp form of a man on the opposite track as his train pulled across the Lynn marshes today. The engineer brought the train to a stop and the crew took the man aboard, four minutes before another train was due on the other track.

The most comprehensive symposium on mental health ever held, with the country's leading authorities in the field participating in an effort to map out a far-reaching frontal attack on one of the nation's most serious spiritual, social and economic problems, will be an outstanding feature of the 103d meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, known as the National Parliament of Science, which opens here tomorrow.

Mayor Frank Hague declared here tonight that the Civil Liberties Committee of the American Bar Association acted in behalf of a group "manipulated by the three Communist leaders of the country" when it filed in United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia a brief charging the Jersey City official with "serious abridgement of the constitutional right to Peaceably assemble."

United States Army tanks are technically equal, and in some respects superior, to any other tanks in the world, Major J. K. Christmas, army automotive expert, will state in an article to appear this week in Army Ordnance, published by the Army Ordnance Association.

Patrick Gallagher, 66 years old, and his wife, Elizabeth, 70, were found dead of gas poisoning yesterday afternoon when a patrolman broke into their four-room- flat on the top floor of 709 Ninth Avenue.

A $408,000 mortgage for ten years after completion of the building, with interest at 5 per cent during construction and 4 1/2 per cent thereafter, has been arranged on the sixstory apartment house under construction on the east side of Fort Washington Avenue, 421.42 feet north of West 190th Street, Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers who negotiated the deal, announced yesterday. The Fort Tryon Garden,

The annual national bird census of the National Association of Audubon Societies ended last night as more than 2,000 ornithologists laid aside their binoculars, cameras, wading boots and counters after a day spent searching field and stream through the length and breadth of the country.

Julian T. Saxe, a retired real estate man who had been a member of the former realty firm of Coon, Saxe Co., died Sunday in the Beth David Hospital of pneumonia. In the course of forty years in business in this city he had been interested in the construction of many buildings, including the Old Hotel Oxford at Fifty-eighth Street and Park Avenue, and the apartment house at 151 Central Park West.

The national highway users conference urged State Legislatures today to prevent diversion of special motor vehicle fees and taxes to other than highway purposes. In a public statement on this and other highway questions, the conference said it spoke for groups representative of farmers, retailers, dairymen and organizations in the automotivehighway field.
O. E. Carlson and J. A. Topping tied for first today in the fourth qualifying round of the thirtieth annual Snobirds' tournament at Siwanoy. Carlson returned 82-17-65, and Topping 85-20-65.

Arthur C. Durfee, who rose from office boy to treasurer of the Buffalo, Rochester Pittsburgh Railway, now part of the Baltimore Ohio System, died on Christmas Eve at his home here after a year's illness. Born in Rochester sixty-eight years ago, Mr. Durfee entered the railroad's employment at the age of 14, and twenty years later became treasurer.

American exporters in South American countries are handicapped by their practice of sending salesmen who do not understand and make allowances for the Latin temperament, according to Julie Wentzel of the Foreign Language Employment Bureau.

There is a stirring significance in the message signed and issued by leaders of the Roman Catholic Church, the Protestant Episcopal Church, the Southern Baptist Convention, the Presbyterian Church and the twenty-five bodies constituent to the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America against the religious persecutions now going on in Germany.

Richard H. Cummings, veteran actor, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 80. Born in New Haven, Conn., he went on the stage as a vaudeville actor, turned later to minstrels and finally to legitimate productions. He started in pictures in 1912 in New

Mrs. Peyton J. Van Rensselaer entertained -with a tea today at Casa Rosada del Lago. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. John M. L. Rutherford, Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Henderson, Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West, Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Kent Jr., Dr. and Mrs. Hobart Endicott Warren, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio and Dr. and Mrs. George A. Waterman.
Outplayed for part of the game and tricked at times by old football plays, the University of California rallied in the last period today to score twice and defeat Georgia Tech, 13 to 0.
Emil Flohri, whose "full dinner pail" cartoons helped elect William McKinley President, died at his Van Nuys home Saturday at the age of 69.

Professor Peter Kapitza, former director of the Royal Society's Mond Laboratory at Cambridge, England, whose retention by the Soviet Government to head a great new laboratory here stirred the scientific world in 1935, has perfected a new method of liquefying gases.

One woman was killed, and a score of other persons escaped death or injury by a margin of a few moments, as a swiftly spreading fire blocked the stairways of a tenement at 745 Columbus Avenue, near Ninety-sixth Street, at 11 o'clock last night.

A crowd of 25,000 saw England assume a commanding position in the second day's play of the opening cricket test against South Africa today. The touring team completed its innings for 422 runs, and at the adjournment the Springboks had lost five wickets for 166.
Another suicide was added today to the list of persons who have ended their lives in protest against the proposed Hungarian laws putting restrictions on Jews.

The University of Tennessee's football team arrived today and practiced blocking and tackling in a hot sun. The Volunteers' Orange Bowl opponents, the Sooners of Oklahoma University, were en route here by train. They will arrive tomorrow.
Miami High School scored after a pass interception in the closing minutes to defeat McKeesport (Pa.) High, 19 to 13, in a football game before 5,490 spectators today.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York is asking business concerns located on the city's longer thoroughfares to save time for prospective patrons by placing the name of the nearest intersecting street, as well as the numbered address of the building they occupy, on their letterheads and advertising. Charles T. Gwynne,

Henry W. (Bunny) Austin of England is the leading amateur tennis player in the world, according to Donald Budge, who announced his rankings yesterday. Budge, who will make his professional debut in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday against Ellsworth Vines, placed four American nlavers on his list of ten.

City, State and Federal authorities will resume today their attempts to get at the bottom of the complicated financial operations of the late F. Donald Coster (Philip Musica) and some of his associates in the drug company of McKesson Robbins, Inc.
Mr. and Mrs. George Prentiss Butler Jr. of Mount Kisco, N. Y., and this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Butler, to Fitzwilliam Sargent 3d,

A memorial concert in honor of the late composer and pianist, Aurelio Giorni, was given yesterday afternoon at Town Hall before a large audience. It was the firstt event presented by the Giorni Memorial Fund, which was recently organized for the furthering of performances and publication of the composer's music.

Frank E. Campbell, Cornelius I Shields and C. E. Turney were the winners in the holiday dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club today. The races, eleven in all in morning and afternoon, were sailed in a light easterly wind and under ideal weather conditions. It was one of the finest days of the sport during the Winter season. Twenty-three craft entered the competition.

United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew was understood to have made reprerentations today to Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita over ten incidents in which Japanese planes allegedly bombed American property in China.

Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Astor will give a dinner Thursday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for two debutantes-Miss Alison Pyne, daughter of Mrs. Grafton H. Pyne, and Miss Leila Webb, daughter of Mrs. J. Griswold Webb.
The opening of the new Schrafft's bar and cocktail lounge, at 39 East Fifty-eight Street, originally set for tomorrow noon, has been postponed until Thursday.
Francis William Gruen, former vice president and attorney for the Gruen Watch Company of Cincinnati, died at his home here last night of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 59.
Concern over the possibility that rayon may "nose out" cotton in the newly developed field of sports clothing for men was expressed by, some fabric producers last weeks

Three unbeaten teams will take the floor tonight in the second of the series of college basketball double-headers at Madison Square Garden. Illinois and Minnesota of the Big Ten Conference and Manhattan are the colleges yet to taste defeat, while the fourth one to see action, N. Y. U., has been beaten only once.

Consumers' income this year has been about the same as in 1936 and, in recent months, has approximated the average for 1937, and this in face of a 59 per cent drop in profits reported by 120 industrial concerns in comprison with a year ago.

Under the Federal policy of providing financial assistance to vocational education in the States, more than 7,000 young men are training to become aviation mechanics, J. W. Studebaker, Commissioner of Education, reported today to Secretary of the Interior Ickes.

Phil Plant, who recently married Marjorie King, sailed yesterday on the Normandie with his bride to, spend two months in British East Africa collecting leopards and monkeys for the American Museum of Natural History.

Local Welfare Commissioners, County Supervisors, Mayors, leaders of private social agencies and all other interested citizens will have the chance to help the State Board of Social Welfare to revise and codify the State Public Welfare and State Charities Laws, it was announced here today by David C. Adie, Commissioner of the State Department of Social. Welfare.
Official quarters said today eighty-eight persons had been killed and 250 seriously injured in the passenger-train collision last night between the south Bessarabian stations of Frekatzei and Etulea.
On Christmas Eve two Croat peasants were shot dead and four were Wounded by Serb gendarmes in a Croat Catholic pilgrimage in the village of Maria Bistriza.

Thirty-four savings, building and loan association members of the United States Building and Loan League had assets of more than $10,000,000 each on July 1 last, A. D. Theobald, vice president of the league reported yesterday.
Generally healthy business conditions in the motion picture industry this year are reflected in the annual suryey of the entire field published today in The Film Daily, trade journal.

Alexander Richmond Hart, retired publisher and a leader in the development of photo-engraving, died at his home, 115 Whitehall Boulevard here this morning. Mr. Hart was in his eighty-fifth year and had retired from his numerous business enterprises thirty-five years ago.

In an article printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 24, reporting a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, it was erroneously said that Administered Fund Second, Inc., was an investment trust alleged to have been looted in a conspiracy by various persons,
The Rightist press opened fire today on the Popular Front government in view of the first two decrees signed by President Pedro Aguirre Cerda after he had taken office on Saturday.

Another two years having elapsed Ruth Draper has returned in a limited engagement of character sketches, which opened at the Little last evening. Since she first peopled the stage with shadows and shapes a good many years ago

Hitting the cords twice for goals in the first period and adding one in both the second and third, the New York Rovers remained far in front in the race for the Eastern Hockey League title by humbling the Hershey (Pa.) Cubs. 4 to 2, in the main attraction of an amateur twin-bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

All the shops in the recently completed store building adjoining the Munsey Park development on Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, L. I., have rented, according to David T. Wile Jr. The Robel Realty Company of Brooklyn was the builder.
At a dinner party in a German home recently a flippant foreigner, passing the none too well filled butter plate said: "Will you have some butter, Madame-or do you refer guns?"

Fearing that an effort may be made at the next session of the Legislature for passage of a bill creating a new Department of Industry and Commerce, the Merchants Association of New York went on record yesterday as opposing such an agency on the ground that it would "become a propaganda agency for whatever administration happened to be in power rather than a servant of industry and commerce."
THE DUST BIN, by Nathan Boone Williams. (W. F. Roberts Company, Washington, D. C., $2.) A study in government. GAY FIESTA, by Anne Duffield. (Arcadia, $2.) A novel.
The funeral of General Severiano Martinez Anido, Spanish Insurgent Minister of Public Order, who died at the age of 76 at Valladolid Saturday, was held there at noon today.

William Robbins Seigle, chairman of the board and research director of Johns-Mansville Corporation, died early today at St. Mary's Hospital here after having undergone an operation at the Mayo Clinic on Dec. 6. His age was 59.
Mr. and Mrs. William C. F. Dietz of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Dietz, to the Rev. William Howard Melish, assistant rector of Christ Church here.
The marriage of Miss Virginia Shoemaker, daughter of Mr and Mrs. James Morris Shoemaker of Bayview Road, Plandome, and George Pomeroy Bassett 3d, son of Mrs. George Pomeroy Bassett Jr. of
Dr. and Mrs. Thurston Scott Welton of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Welton, to Dr. E. Ellsworth Keet, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest E, Keet of Jamaica, Queens.

The United States continues to increase its lead as the principal exporter of women's apparel to Great Britain, while such imports from Germany and Austria, once dominant in the British market, continue to decline.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Van Loan of this place gave a tea dance at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Mary Helene Van Loan, to William Lewis Fader Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lewis Fader of Sewickley. Pa.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Van Loan of this place gave a tea dance at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Mary Helene Van Loan, to William Lewis Fader Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lewis Fader of Sewickley. Pa.

Mrs. Katherine Fales Stoeckel, wife of Robbins B. Stoeckel, former Connecticut Motor Vehicle Commissioner and now Research Professor of Transportation at Yale University, died today at her home here in her sixty-ninth year.
Exports of iron and steel products other than scrap registered a slight decline in November, compared with October, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Gustave S. Roth of 92 Margaret Avenue, Lawrence, L. I., former president of the Israel Zion Hospital, 4,810 Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn, died yesterday at that hospital after a brief illness of pneumonia. He was 74 years old.

Observing that "it would appear on the surface that the 'good neighbor' policy has gone far enough," Elliott Roosevelt asserted in a broadcast tonight that Mexican sales of oil from expropriated properties to Germany, Japan and Italy had created a problem for this nation which must be met.

A course in every American college designed as a "Primer for Democracy" in answer to Germany's "Nazi Primer," and the conversion of the National Youth Administration student aid into a permanent system of Federal scholarships, were advocated in a report made public yesterday at the opening of the fourth annual convention here of the American Student Union.

J. Stanley Brown of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company has been appointed chairman of the committee in charge of the thirty-eighth annual dinner of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking to be held on Feb. 4 at the Hotel Astor. New York.

Colonel John Stilwell, president of the Greater New York Safety Council, said yesterday that, barring a major catastrophe during the last few days, accidental deaths in New. York City in 1938 would be about 10 per cent fewer than last year.

The administration of the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 has so improved the condition of the American Indians through restoration of a large control of their tribal life, land and institutions that they are experiencing a renaissance, according to the report of a survey made public yesterday.

Renewed efforts for ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment by eight more States in 1939, provided validity of ratification is upheld by the United States Supreme Court in the cases pending before it, were urged yesterday by the National Child Labor Committee.

Sweeping revision of the parole system in this State was recommended today in a report submitted to Governor Earle by the commission named by him some months ago to investigate parole operation in Pennsylvania.
Jan Sibelius, renowned Finnish composer, will conduct the Helsingfors Symphony Orchestra in his first international broadcast as a conductor on New Year's Day. The celebrated composer,

A crowd of 13,299, wagering $277,530 on the eight races at Tropical Park today, saw Apprentice Warren Yarberry ride four winners and Mucho Gusto, a 4-to-5 favorite, finish next to last in the Christmas Handicap, in which five competed.
Members of the Modern Language Association to the number of 2,500 are expected in town this week fo their forty-fifth annual

D. A. Woods's 4-year-old Busy K., who raced against some of the best horses in training last Summer with only o --.sional success, was dropped into cheaper company at the Fair Grounds today and romped off with the $2,000-added Christmas Handicap.

A Spanish Insurgent communique today announced that fifty persons had been arrested as a result of the discovery of espionage documents in a valise carried by a British vice consul and that two British subjects would be tried by Insurgent judges.

Patrolman John Daly sprained his back and got wet feet and Nicholas Flerro, a Park Department employee, also got his feet wet yesterday when they ventured forth in a leaky rowboat to rescue a female German shepherd dog in the Central Park lake near 110th Street.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, is rated No. 1 pugilist of the year by an international jury whose poll is to be published in a copyrighted article in the February issue of The Ring, boxing magazine, of which Nat Fleischer is publisher.

Cornell, Williams and Hamilton hockey teams won tonight in the annual round-robin hockey series for the Samuel H. Packer Trophy. Scoring twice in the second period, Williams whipped Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 2 to 1, in the final game of the opening night's play. Cornell beat St. Lawrence, 11 to 1, and Hamilton downed Massachusetts State, 3 to 1.

Dr. Leo S. Rowe, director general of the Pan American Union, made a radio address from Lima, Peru, last night on the results of the Pan-American Conference there. His address was carried on the networks of the National Broadcasting Company. He spoke in part as follows:
The St. Mary's Celtics and the Hispanos battled to a 2-2 tie in an American Soccer League game at Celtic Park, Brooklyn, yesterday before 3,000 fans. All the goals were made in the first half.
Miss Joan Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Gilman Myers of Lawrence Park, this place, made her debut this afternoon at a tea dance given by her parents at the Bronxville Women's Club.
Legislation designed to make New York State's insurance code a "model for other States" will be introduced at Albany in February, Assemblyman R. Foster Piper announced today.

J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, may be called as a prosecution witness at the trial in General Sessions Court of two men accused of kidnapping Arthur Fried, well-to-do White Plains resident, it was indicated yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Jacob Rosenblum.

IF there are things in this day of rapid obsolescence that can await with indifference the coming of another new year, some of them must be the work of master craftsmen, endowed with ever fecund beauty.

Burg Brothers. embroideries, 15 W 26th St; Mansfield Furniture Co., Inc.. in 126 W 22d St.; Ruben Leather Goods Corp, ladies handbags, in 22 W 32d St; Richter Blanck, clothing, in 3 W 18th St; renewals by Bastine Co, Inc, agent.

Three policemen and two men whose lives they saved in separate waterfront rescues were reported recovering last night from the effects of submersion and exposure. Patrolmen James Dolan, 35 years old, and Edward Kopple, 33, both of the Fourth Avenue Station,

Herman Delman, president of Delman, Inc., who is chairman of the Uptown Retail Shoe Guild, has been named chairman of the World's Fair Committee for the shoe industry, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Love, president of the parel and Accessories Associates, Inc. Other members include Manuel Garton of Saks Fifth Avenue and Joseph McGee of Jodel, Inc.

Colgate's hockey team inaugurated its season at the Playland Ice Casino tonight with a 2-1 upset victory over Brown. John Reilly made the deciding goal with less than a minute left in the overtime period. Following his own shot from the blue line, Reilly took the rebound from Goalie Al Curtis and bounced the disk into the net at 9:10. It was Brown's second setback in four games.

Mr. and Mrs. James Garretson of 160 East Seventy-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Juliet Sewell Garretson, to Dickerman Hollister, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Clay Hollister of Lawrence Park, Bronxville.

Bernarr Macfadden, magazine publisher, escaped unhurt today when his five-passenger cabin plane nosed over as he was landing at Barnes Airport. Mr. Macfadden was en route from New York to visit his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Roland Hebert, of Holyoke.
A blizzard caused suspension of all air transport services between the Continent and England today for the first time in ten years.

High-lighted by the Everton-Derby County 2-2 draw on the former's grounds, English Football League Boxing Day matches were played in adverse weather conditions. Of the forty-five matches carded, ten were postponed owing to frost and snow, and one contest abandoned after sixty-three minutes' play.

The Rev. and Mrs. William Merriam Crane of Morningface at Richmond have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Frances Whitney Crane to Richard Compton Harrison Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Harrison of New York and Kenmore, Richmond.

The foreign trade division of the Department of Agriculture today said that price and quality were being superseded by political factors in the world's markets. No longer, it was asserted, is a nation that contrives the cheapest prices on its commodities assured of ready sales.

Three Bronx American Legion posts and one in Manhattan announced yesterday that they would attempt on Jan. 3 to launch a national campaign against the decision of national Legion leaders to oppose making the United States an asylum.for refugees.

Eastern and Western college football luminaries, preparing for the Shriners' charity game next Monday, took a busman's holiday today. After brisk workouts, forty-two of the forty-four players, from nearly all sections of the country, attended the Georgia Tech-California game at Berkelevy.

President Roosevelt was reported authoritatively today to have decided on a double-barreled recommendation to Congress for reinforcements of the national defense which are of unprecedented peacetime magnitude.

The Christmas week stampede for holiday gold gains its full force tonight with three premieres. The number is one less than scheduled because "Blackbirds" was postponed again, deciding instead to open on Thursday night. A previous Thursday night expectation, "Policy Kings," was deferred until Friday.

Miss Margaret Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Allen of Brooklyn, was married to Laurence E. Stock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Stock of Buffalo, yesterday morning in the St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gerald Treacey.
