The program of Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, for restoring world peace will be formally adopted as a policy of the American hemisphere here tomorrow morning when the delegations of the twenty-one American nations solemnly sign the declarations, resolutions and other acts approved at the Eighth Pan-American Conference.
Supply contracts valued at $9,376,635 were awarded during the week ended Dec. 17 by thirteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Deapartment announced today.

Captain Reginald Whitaker, Corps of Engineers, U. S. A., and Mrs. Whitaker of Evanston, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Mary Whitaker, to Cadet William Calvin Banning of the 1939 class at the United States Military Academy.
The atmosphere on the Bourse today as the new week's account opened was pessimistic, the entire list, with a few exceptions in international stocks, dipping.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today, the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4188-United States v. American Import Co. Opinion by Judge Garrett. The U. S. Customs Court judgment reversed. Judge Hatfield specially concurs. 4162-United States v. Fisher Scientific Co. Opinion by Judge Garrett. The government appealed and the judgment of the lower court affirmed.

William J. Fallon, 49 years old, a former oil-stock promoter, who gave the Delmonico Hotel as his address, was sentenced in Special Sessions yesterday to an indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years.

The New York A. C. scored a 5-to-4 triumph over the Crescent A. C. in a New York Amateur Hockey Association contest at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Elmer Berggren of the Winged i Footers scored three goals.

Eleven public organizations received bequests totaling $31,500 under the will of Mrs. Helen Gould Shepard, filed today in the Westchester County Surrogate's office. Her husband, Finley Johnson Shepard, inherited the bulk of the estate, receiving $250,000 and the residue after payment of other legacies.

One of the intriguing things about hunting or fishing is the fact that you can never tell when the impossible will happen. In the course of a year we hear a number of impossible stories, but we have discovered that they are only impossible to those who know little about these sports.

Many of the country's industrial leaders were declared today to be indirectly responsible for a majority of the crimes committed. The industrial slums around factories produce the most criminals, both old and young, Dr. Paul L.

The advance sale for the professional debut of Donald Budge at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night has broken all records for tennis there. Promoter Jack Harris arrived in town from Chicago yesterday to learn that $14,858 worth of tickets had been disposed of a week before Budge's match with Ellsworth Vines of California, the world professional champion.

Now that the WPA system and setup have been abandoned (if only temporarily) by the Administration, and its chief salvaged by appointment as Secretary of Commerce, the forthcoming report of Senator Sheppard's special committee will have less impact than it would have had last Autumn.
A dinner dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Karsner Stafford last night at the St. Regis to introduce to society Mrs. Stafford's daughter, Miss Alice Marie Fleitmann.

The Federal Power Commission approved today the sale of certain interstate electrical properties of the Iowa-Nebraska Light and Power Company, second largest power utility in Nebraska, to two Nebraska public power districts.
W. F. Hufstader, Buick general sales manager, disclosed yesterday that sales in the first twenty days of December exceeded those of the corresponding period of 1937 by some 30 per cent.

A dinner dance last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria served to introduce to society Miss Mary Tolfree Paige. The party was given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Paige of Bellport, L. I., and her grandmother, Mrs. Frederick Edey, also of Bellport.

The movement of the United States Fleet from the Pacific to the Atlantic for its annual manoeuvres and for its visit to the opening of the World's Fair in New York is expected to start in great secrecy early tomorrow morning.

Lewis Gannett, 47 years old, of 120 East Sixteenth Street, book reviewer for The New York Herald Tribune, was struck by an automo- a bile at Fourth Avenue and Seventeenth Street at about 7 o'clock last night.

Two new trustees of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine were elected yesterday at the stated meeting of trustees at the synod house on the cathedral grounds, 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, rector of St. James's Church, was elected to fill the vacancy caused by the death of the Rev. R. Townsend Henshaw, and Gano Dunn, president of Cooper Union, was elected to succeed the late Courtlandt Nicoll.

The engagement of Miss Helen Jane Fryling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Fryling, to Robert J. Staub, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Staub, both of this place, was announced today at a luncheon given by Mrs. Fryling and her daughter at the Canoe Brook County Club here.

A new method of detecting the presence of a chemical that causes cancer was described today before the American Physical Society meeting in annual session. According to Dr. Alexander Hollaender and Dr. Peter A. Cole of the Washington Biophysical Institute of the National Institute of Health, a biological method of determining the presence of the cancer-causing chemical,

George H. Sisler, high commissioner of the National Semi-Professional Baseball Congress, announced today that players on the suspended list of organized baseball would be barred from participation in three major semi-pro tournaments in 1939.

A union-shop agreement, reached after ten months of negotiation, was ratified early today by the Hotel Association of New York City after a closed meeting at the Chamber Music Hall in Carnegie Hall. The agreement, which must now be ratified by the unions affected, was drafted by a committee

Mrs. C. S. Bromley's Roar, a fast sprinter that frequently falters, stuck it out in gamer than usual fashion to win the Key West Purse at Tropical Park today. The recently reinstated Don Meade rode the 3-year-old gelding under the wire first by a halflength.

The elected representatives of workers in all shops of the Endicott Johnson Corporation in this city, Endicott, Johnson City and Owego tonight petitioned the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the American Federation of Labor and National Labor Relations Board to "desist from activities directed toward the organization of Endicott Johnson workers into union groups."

Tomorrow's Official Gazette will announce the dissolution of the Communist party after eighteen years of existence here. The dissolution, which fulfills German demands, will simultaneously cancel the mandates of Communist Deputies and Senators.

Lin Yutang has written a new section of 24,000 words to be added to "My Country and My People." A 1939 edition, containing this new material. which covers the war period and the future outlook for China, will be published soon by John Day.

Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight. Dec. 31: PATROLMAN-Jeremah C. Sullivan, 43d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 5, 1910. Temporary Assignments For 15 days, from 8 A. M., Jan. 1: LIEUTENANTS-Charles R. Michie, from 5th Division to Emergency Service Division, assignment to desk duty continued.

The defending champion, Miss Helen Bernhard of New York, won her opening match today in the junior girls' national indoor tennis tournament at the Longwood covered courts by defeating Miss Polly Kimball of Winchester, 6-1, 6-3.

Minister of Government Ayora has assured the Newspaper Guild of Quito that there will be no censorship of the press during the present administration. He explained that newspaper men' imprisoned during the recent unrest had been improperly arrested and had received their liberty as soon as the mistake was discovered.

Sir James Sexton, British labor leader, died today in his Liverpool home at the age of 82. As a poet Sir James wrote under the name of "Tatters" and after being knighted in 1931 told an interviewer "to cut out the 'sir.'

Having visited, while the Eighth Pan-American Conference was in session at Lima, the three most important Latin-American Republics south of Panama-Brazil, Argentina and Chile-and the smallest, Uruguay, this correspondent is in a position to view his impressions of the four in perspective, and draw from them the following deductions:

In considering the requirements of a program of national defense-particularly in the matter of airplanes-it is important to be on guard against the fetish of mere numbers. What the United States needs is the reinforcement of our present forces in the air in order to create a flying fleet adapted to our own particular geographical and strategical needs, and inferior, when thus employed, to no other.
The international stock market indices for Dec. 24, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
Mrs. Susan MacDowell Eakins, widow of Thomas Eakins, noted painter, sculptor and teacher, and hereself known as a talented artist, died today in her eighty-seventh year.

Despite the downward sweep of the business curve in a large part of this year. the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey's publication, The Lamp, estimates that the total demand for all oils in 1938 will slip little from last year's high record consumption of 1,340,000,000 barrels.

Dr. Theodore V. Ketcham, retired dentist, who practiced in Stamford for many years, died yesterday in a hospital in St. Augustine, Fla., at the age of 79. Dr. Ketcham had been in failing health for some time and entered the hospital ten days ago.

The Chamber of Deputies has passed an amendment to Mexico's Constitution providing that exploitation of oil and hydrocarbides shall no longer be a matter of concessions for private companies but shall be handled directly by the government.
Commodity prices advanced last week for the first time in almost a month The Annalist says this week. It attributes part of the rise to buyers taking advantage of low prices.

Two large brooder houses containing 7,500 young ducks were destroyed early today when fire of undetermined cause swept through part of Gallo's duck farm on Patchogue Road, here, causing damage estimated at $10,000.

Key figures in the ranks of motion-picture executives, Broadway producers and playwrights are negotiating a resumption of Hollywood financing of legitimate plays, and their plans have reached the point where they may be described as "very close" to final execution, it was learned yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Jean Collier Lamb, daughter of Mrs. Charles H. Lamb of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Lamb, to Albert M. Hall, son of Professor and Mrs. Edgar A. Hall, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, 111 Martense Street, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John G. Addy.

Sixteen players of the starting field came through the first round as play in the fourth annual intercollegiate invitation squash racquets tournament began on the courts of the University Club yesterday. The survivors represent .
Dr. Calvin B. Bridges, authority in the science of genetics, died here today after an illness of four months. His age was 49.

Between 6 and 9 P. M. Monday, firemen in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn were busily engaged answering five false alarms. It was when the fifth false alarm was turned in that Detectives Harold Kahn and Thomas Gerrity finally caught up with the culprits at Voorhies Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

Steel ingot output was reduced last week, countering a nominal seasonal upturn, and the adjusted index declined to 88.0 from 98.6. The figure for the week ended Dec. 25, 1937, was 35.9. The rate of operations in the industry was estimated by THE NEW YORK TIMES at 52 per cent of capacity,

Mrs. Florence Merwin Clothier, who was active in philanthropic enterprises, died of heart disease today at her home in Haverford. She was the widow of Clarkson Clothier and the stepmother of Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University.

Dr. John William McGarvey, instructor in the department of philosophy and psychology at Mount Holyoke Colege, died yesterday at Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass., of pneumonia following a month's illness. A native of Kansas City and a member of the Mount Holyoke faculty for the last year and a half, Dr. McGarvey was 31 years old.

The task of leading a volunteer lifeboat crew to rescue thirteen persons from a sinking ship in a sixty-five-mile gale and a forty-foot running sea was just another job to Carl Bentsen, second officer of the American freighter Schodack.

Mrs. Henry Graves 3d of Ardsleyon-Hudson, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Florence Barbara Graves, to Alvin Cleveland Jenks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rice Jenks of Pawtucket and Barrington, R. I.
Following the trend of previous months, foreign trade of the United States in November was less than correspondingly the year before, the Department of Commerce reported today.

47th St. 228-48 W, 217.6x200.10xirreg: to 46th St, 233 W; Milnag Realty Corp, Charles Kramer, president, to Hotel Edison Corp, 224 W 47th St; mtg $3,983,666. 47th St, 224-26 W, 32x100.5xirreg; Centrum Corp, Fred A. Thomas. president, to Fifth Ave Estates, A Corp, 70 Broadway ($300).
From an apartment window overlooking Kingston Corners, three members of one family saw the meeting ten days ago of Margaret Martin and her supposed slayer, the police now believe.

Six inches of steel or two of three feet of aluminum alloy are as transparent as plate glass to the new X-ray apparatus developed at the National Research Council laboratories here. It is primarily used for detecting flaws in metal castings.

John Howard Drake, director of the National Electric Manufacturers Association of New York, died unexpectedly yesterday in a hospital here. A native of Elmira, N. Y., Mr. Drake was graduated from Stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken, N. J., and joined the testing department of the General Electric Company here.

Citing "the income tax laws" through which Al Capone was confined in Alcatraz and Waxey Gordon put into another Federal prison, and State tax laws that have helped District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to convict racketeers, Mark Eisner, former chairman of the Board of Higher Education, made a plea last night for extension of such laws to expose propagandists.

Although the railroads expect increased traffic in 1939, they will be unable to make both ends meet unless some public action is taken to help them, A. D. McDonald, president of the Southern Pacific Company, said today in a year-end review.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederick Talcott gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for their granddaughter, Miss Mary Hope Talcott, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Talcott of Rye, N. Y. Miss Talcott was introduced formally at a supper dance given for her on Sept. 18 in Rye.

Mrs. Lorenzo D. Armstrong will give a reception tomorrow afternoon in her home, 5 East Eightyfirst Street, to introduce her daughter, Miss Gloria Armstrong, to older friends of the family. Mr. and Mrs. W. Haggin Perry, who were at the Pierre, have gone to Beau Val, their place at Cobham, Va.
Louis PaulDubois, political and financial writer, died at his Paris home today after a- long illness. His age was 70.

What is perhaps the long-expected drive toward Sian, the capital of Shensi Province, started yesterday when Japanese forces commenced a series of attacks against Chinese troops entrenched throughout Southwestern and Central Shansi.

In their news broadcasts yesterday neither the National Broadcasting Company nor the Columbia Broadcasting System made mention of Press Radio Bureau, which for several years has been supplying material for four five-minute news broadcasts daily.

A committee headed by Kenneth S. Guiterman of 120 Broadway announced yesterday that it would seek dissolution of the voting trust through which control of the Pennroad Corporation was placed in the hands of officials friendly to the Pennsylvania Railroad. The voting trust will expire on May 1 next.

The names of 250 jurors who will constitute a special blue-ribbon panel for the second trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader under indictment for conspiracy in the policy racket, were drawn yesterday afternoon in the division of jurors of the County Clerk's office in the Hall of Records.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marvin Nelson of 860 Park Avenue gave a tea dance yesterday at Sherry's to introduce their daughter, Miss Daphne Brown Nelson, who is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Marion Brown of Bermuda, formerly of St. Louis, and a greatgranddaughter of the late Judge Daniel Fisher of St. Louis.

The New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Control Commissioner, D. Frederick Burnett, was upheld today by the New Jersey Supreme Court for revoking a liquor license issued to Silver Rod Stores, Inc., 135 Main Street,

Assembling members of Congress found today that the House chamber had been wired for sound. Workmen put the finishing touches on a public address system described by David Lynn, Capitol architect, as the "most up-to-date in existence."

Charles Lockyer, 62 years old, former fire chief here, and chief bookkeeper in the New York office of the Western Union Telegraph Company, was killed today when run down by. an automobile as he was on his way to the Erie Railroad station here to board a train for New York.

The Muehlhausen Spring Corporation, Logansport, Ind., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the sale of 125,000 shares of nopar common stock at $6 a share, 55,000 of which will be taken by the issuer and used to redeen $100 par 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock and for working capital.

Three Cuban military planes and one transport plane left Panama today for Call, Colombia, to participate in memorial ceremonies for Cuban fliers who were killed near there on Dec. 29, 1937, in the crash of three planes on a good-will flight in behalf of the Columbus Memorial Lighthouse in the Dominican Republic.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 21: Increases of $253,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations and of $107,000,000 in government deposits and decreases of $465,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks; $133,000,000 in amounts due from banks and $406,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Union demands for recognition have threatened the future of the French Theatre of New York, according to Miss Robinson Smith, president of the organization, which she described yesterday as a cultural and educational effort promoted on an "altruistic and nonprofit-making basis."
Detective Captain William H. Peters said tonight that Jane Akowsky, 17 years old, who disappeared on Christmas Eve, had been found by a posse in a lonely mountain shack, hysterical, but unharmed.
Engagements of $5,541,000 gold abroad for shipment here-$4,613,000 in England and $928,000 in The Netherlands-were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A strange and as yet unexplained phenomenon occurring in the process of vaporization of a liquid or solid was described today by Professor Joseph E. Mayer of Johns Hopkins University at the American Chemical Society symposium on "Intermolecular Action" at Brown University.

Dickie Lee, a 5-year-old Chinese boy who has been appearing as a regular speaker in behalf of groups seeking to assist the Chinese cause, was the guest of honor at a reception given by the China Aid Council yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin. final Dickie, whose full name is Richard Gum Loon Lee, is an American citizen and the grandson of Philip Lee, treasurer of the Chinese Nationalist party in this country.

The speed of Illinois and Minnesota was a bit too much for Manhattan and N. Y. U. at Madison Square Garden last night before a gathering of 17,488 as the Illini crushed the Jaspers, 60 to 41, and the Gophers toppled the Violet, 39 to 32.

A bi-partisan movement against the making of any new reciprocal trade agreements without Senate ratification appeared to be getting under way on Capitol Hill tonight. From several sources, Democratic and Republican alike, came criticism of the act which gives the President authority to lower tariffs in return for concessions from other countries.

Pausing only long enough to receive decorations made from oranges, Oklahoma football team was hustled from the station to the practice field upon its arrival today for the Orange Bowl game with Tennessee next Monday.

Steel operations for the present week are scheduled at 38.8 per cent of ingot capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, as compared to 51.7 per cent in the previous week. The decrease was 12.9 points, or 24.9 per cent. One month ago the rate was 60.7 per cent, the decline since then being 36 per cent.

One of the most useful things that can be done at the session of Congress which begins next week is to reconsider in the light of present needs the various "emergency powers" which have been granted to the Chief Executive during the past five years.

Both major political parties in the State will hold conferences next week to discuss party policies. The Democratic conference, announced yesterday by the Democratic. State Committee, has been called for Saturday, Jan. 7, at 9:30 A. M., at the Hotel Biltmore.

Edgar M. Church, an investment broker who had the distinction of having captained three football teams at the University of Pennsylvania, died of pneumonia at his home here last night. He was 71 years old.

Hundreds of public officials and judges paid a final tribute yesterday morning at the funeral services for Supreme Court Justice James A. Dunne in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Charles Borromeo, Sidney Place, Brooklyn. Justice Dunne died Saturday.

Mr. and Mrs. Hugh H. Price of Metuchen and Marksboro, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Virginia Price, to John Oscar Simpkiss Jr. of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simpkiss of Bristol, Tenn.

Deaths Announced Fireman First Grade Thomas Barragry of Engine Co. 241, died Dec. 24, in the performance of duty, from over-exertion while operating at Station 5-7-2653, fire at premises Long Island Railroad Cut, 2d Ave. at 66th St., Brooklyn. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 460 62d St.,

European refugees of all faiths were guests last night at a Christmas festival presented by the staff of the Hotel Astor in the Grand Ballroom of the hotel. Thirty-nine nationalities were represented among the employes. Boxholders included Harold G. Hoffman, former Governor of New Jersey; Fred A.

The Oriente of the New York and Cuba Mail Line will sail today for Havana. Those leaving include Miss Grace Alder, Mr. and Mrs. B. H. Ayers, Mr. and Mrs. H. W. Chadbourne, Mrs. Dora Charney, Dr. and Mrs. Lester J. DuBrul, E. A. Counihan, Mrs. John F. Harlow and Mr. and Mrs. B. S.Wellman.

The Treasury today invited bids for $100,000,000 of 91-day bills to be sold on the usual discount basis to highest bidders. Tenders will be received by the Federal Reserve banks and their branches until 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Friday.

Paul List, a native of Germany and former member of the International Brigade of the Spanish Loyalist army, arrived yesterday on the Oriente from Havana where he had obtained a visa for entry into the United States. He landed as a non-quota immigrant on the

Patrolman Joseph A. Calvey of the Newark Police Department was arraigned before Recorder Thomas J. Holleran here today on charges of hold-up, robbery and atrocious assault and battery with intent to kill.

The Polish Minister to Prague has made a new protest against Polish agitation along the PolishCzech frontier and at Maerisch-Ostrau. Czecho-Slovak newspapers publish sensational stories concerning antiCzech activities in territories recentlv ceded to Poland.

The Virginia Hot Springs Company, operator of the Homestead Hotel, was placed in emergency receivership in Bath County Circuit Court today upon a petition fixing its indebtedness at about $2,820,900. Fay Ingalls, president of the company since 1922 and its largest

" Falstaff" will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday evening, Jan. 7, instead of "Traviata," as previously announced. This change has been made in response to an increasing demand for the inclusion of this work among the productions given at popular prices on Saturday nights.

Declaring that the extinguishing of lights along the Westchester County parkways would result in many accidents and that the $50,000 annual saving to the county would be "blood money," the Automobile Club of New York announced today a move to induce county officials to provide sufficient money in the 1939 budget for the continuance of the lights.

Argentina's prosperity declined gradually through 1938, although most lines of business and industry except textiles remained active, aided by reserves carried over from the previous year, the Department of Commerce reported today on the basis of a dispatch from its attache in Buenos Aires.

Turpentlne firm, 22 1/2c bid; no sales; receipts 57 barrels; shipments 35 barrels; stock 52,781 barrels. Rosin steady; sales 142; receipts 1,291; shipments 2,705: stock 315.615. Quote: B, $3.75; D, $3.95; E, $4.10; F, $4.25; G, H, I, $4.35; M, $4.40; N, $5.35; WG, $5.80; WW, X, $6.30.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday refused to take the action against Tommy Farr requested by the British Board of Boxing Control. This decision closed an incident which had its origin in 1937 when Farr came here to fight Joe Louis for the heavyweight title.

The Bruins peppered Goalie Hal Broda with sizzling shots from all angles while overwhelming Toronto, 8-2, in a National League hockey game tonight before a near-capacity crowd of 15,000 at the Boston Garden.

Tales of the prodigious memories of New York State's Ramapo mountaineers, who, though unable to read or write, contend they can learn 100 verses of folksongs in one evening, were told yesterday by Herbert Halpert, head of the folksong department of the Federal Theatre's national service bureau, at the opening of the thirty-seventh annual conference of the American Anthropological Association and allied societies at the Hotel Commodore.

A new kind of mineral was exbibited today by Ward's Natural Science Establishment of the University of Rochester. The ore was a new species, Dr. Dean Gamble, head of the science establishment, announced on receipt of word from Dr. Charles Palache,
The coaches of the Sugar Bowl football teams which will meet here Monday pronounced their teams in top physical condition today, but said they were dissatisfied with certain practice features.

Assertions that the Veterans of Foreign Wars was sponsoring pension legislation "so costly it would ultimately endanger the national defense program" were declared today by Millard W. Rice, legislative representative of the V. F. W., to be "full of fantastic inaccuracies." The assertions were made yesterday by Edwin 0. Perrin, National Commander of the American Veterans Association.

The assignee of Markus Preminger, a former Austrian judge and lawyer, gave notice yesterday in Supreme Court that she was bringing suit for $255,000 against Stefan Mendl, who was described as a former outstanding industrialist of Vienna who came to the United States in 1937 in anticipation man absorption of Austria.

A forecast of next year's business was made today by K. T. Keller, president of Chrysler Corporation, who said: "Judging from encouraging public response to the automobile industry's 1939 models and the velocity of turnover of new cars, optimism tempered with caution is justified in any attempt at appraisal of prospects for the new year.

Emile Vandervelde, who for more than fifty years had taken an active part in the political life of Belgium as a leader of the Socialist party and often as a Minister, died early this morning in his home here after only a few hours' illness.

Many luncheons will be given today before the twelfth annual opera benefit for the Near East College Association. Members of the organization have taken over the matinee performance of "Sregfried" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The Continental Can Company, Inc., had a consolidated net income of $7,111,429 after all charges, according to the report for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, released for publication today by O. C. Huffman, president.
Dr. George D. Birkhoff, mathematician and dean of the faculty of arts and science at Harvard, in his address tonight as retiring president of the American Association for the Advancement of .Science,
The Public Service Commission announced today that motor-truck operators may extend credit for freight bills for seven days, excluding Sundays and legal holidays but including Saturday half-holidays.

More than fifty teams will compete in the 1939 metropolitan E A. A. U. championship basketball b tournament, it was announced last it night following a meeting of officials at that body's downtown offices.

Despite rises in similar categories throughout the nation during the holidays, accidents, fatalities and injuries in traffic in New York City declined last week compared with those of the corresponding period of 1937, a report of the safety bureau at Police Headquarters showed yesterday.

More than 8,000 peasants at the town of Tantoyuca, State of Veracruz, after a parade on Sunday bearing placards asking for full religious freedom, reopened a church that had been closed for eight years.

The Swiss Parliament today approved an armament program that it was estimated would cost 350, 000,000 Swiss francs. The program was drawn up by Also the Federal Council, which submitted it to the Legislature for final decision. It embodies the following six general plans:

Robert Rodenkirchen, New York A. C. runner who won the Great American Sprint series last year, will be among the participants in the Columbus Council K. of C. track meet at the 245th Coast Artillery Armory, Brooklyn, on Jan. 7. Rodenkirchen, now a freshman at North Texas State Teachers College, will defend the John McGroarty Memorial Trophy.

One man was shot to death and several persons were injured today when Hungarian gendarmes fired into a crowd of Slovaks who were demonstrating for the return of the Hungarian border city of Nagysurany to Czecho-Slovakia.

The twelve-story apartment house on a plot 75 by 100.11 feet at 606 West 116th Street was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by the Forelli Realty Corporation, as plaintiff, for $275,500.

Colonel Graham Woodwark, Mayor of King's Lynn and former Liberal member of Parliament, died yesterday at the age of 64. He served on the special mission sent to the United States by the British Government in 1918.

Miss Shirley Ruth Foote was introduced to society last night at a supper dance and skating party given by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Merrill N. Foote of 405 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. Dancing and supper were in the Cafe Louis XIV, Rockefeller Center, and the Rockefeller Plaza rink had been taken over for the skating.
Looking more like a winged dirigible than an airplane, the latest contribution to air travel was rolled from the assembly plant of the Boeing Aircraft Company here today to undergo engine tests.

Mrs. Zona Gale Breese, novelist, playwright and essayist, died tonight in the Passavant Hospital at the age of 64. Suffering from pneumonia, she had been in an oxygen tent since Dec. 21. Her husband, William Llewellyn Breese, was with her when she died.

Announcing the result of a year's survey, the American Jewish Congress reported yesterday that discrimination against the employment of Jews in the United States had increased since Hitler's rise to power and was now at a record high mark.

The constitutionality of the Federal-State-milk-marketing pact, designed to regulate the handling of milk supplied to the metropolitan area, was assailed in Federal court today by four dairy companies that are defendants in an action brought by the Federal Government to compel compliance with the agreement.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday were well below the preceding week and less than in the corresponding week a year ago for the first time in three months, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Brig. Gen. Hugh M. Dyer, five times mentioned in dispatches during the World War, died here Sunday night after a two weeks' illness. A prominent agriculturist, he was 79 years old.

The Rev. Daniel O'Sullivan, assistant pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Incarnation, was elected president of the Cathedral College Alumni Association at the annual meeting, attended by 300 members, last night at the Hotel Commodore.

Sir Dennison Ross, educator and author who has just concluded a visit to this country, is one Englishman who has treated admission requirements lightly and got away with it. When he applied for a visa and was confounded by the amount of information he was required to give

" The Merchant of Yonkers," by Thornton Wilder, whose "Our Town" won this year's Pulitzer Prize, arrives tonight at the Guild Theatre. Staged by Max Reinhardt and produced by Herman Shumlin it is the second subscription offering of the Theatre Guild.

Henning Ryden, portrait painter and steel-cutting artist, died today of pneumonia at the age of 69. A native of Sweden, he was the brother of the late Dr. Bernerrs Ryden, for years Minister of Education in Sweden and founder of its present school system.

One point in connection with Chairman Eccles's letter to Senator Byrd ought not to be overlooked. Mr. Eccles favors a continuation of the present policy of Government spending not primarily because of the total amount spent but precisely because of the size of the deficit it creates.

Teachers of public speaking in convention here were advised today to take a lesson from President Roosevelt. The suggestion came from Dr. Sara Stinchfiec Hawk of the University of Southern California.

Eastern and Western college football stars, in training for the charity game here Jan. 2, reversed practice plans today. The East counted six players on the injured or ailing list after a sharp scrimmage yesterday,

The 1939 national open golf championship probably will be played on a par 69 course for the first time in history, Melville Curtis, chairman of the Philadelphia Country Club golf committee, said today.

Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Haire of 1,120 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Haire, to Justin Carmody McCann, son of Mrs. Alfred W. McCann of Park Hill, Yonkers, and the late Mr. McCann.

An anti-Jewish "Jim Crow" decree segregating in special compartments or special cars all Jews, including those of foreign citizenship, traveling on German railways is demanded today by the Schwarze Korps, organ of the secret police and Hitler Elite Guard, whose previous proposals for the treatment of Jews have always been put into effect.
Charles F. Sawyer, treasurer of the Sawyer Regan Company, woolen manufacturers of Dalton, died early today at his home there in his seventieth year. He had suffered a paralytic stroke yesterday.

A fire engine turned over as it swerved sharply to avoid hitting an automobile at an intersection in Bath Beach, Brooklyn, last night, and then crashed into a parked car, injuring four women, none of them seriously.

Jerome Chester Cuppia of E. A. Pierce Co. announced yesterday that he would allow his name to be used as a candidate for chairman of the board of the New York Curb Exchange. His announcement took the form of a letter which he had addressed on Saturday to William H. Hassinger, chairman of the Curb's nominating committee.

Recording his fifth straight ring triumph, Bernie Friedkin of Brownsville trounced Jerry Mazza of Bensonhurst in the eight-round main event at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of t 2,200 was on hand.

Lieutenant Harry J. (Hank) Hardwick, former football coach at the United States Naval Academy, got his wish today-he's going back to sea duty. His transfer was announced laconically by the Navy Department"Lieutenant Harry J. Hardwick,

The special grand jury of October, 1937, sought reinstatement today' of the twenty-one indictments it returned last Fall against Mayor Wilson on charges of misbehavior in office, including failure to suppress gambling. The indictments were quashed last month by Judge Harry S. McDevitt.
The International Missionary Conference adopted a resolution. today extending sympathy to "the multitude of peoples in the zones of conflict" in the Far East, Spain and Palestine.
The Ed Smith family was driving its fleet of seven automobiles today, thanks to Christmas and the discovery of oil on the Smith farm in Fayette County.

An offering by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of $50,000,000 of Federal National Mortgage Association five-year 1 5/8 per cent notes has been subscribed twentythree times, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, announced tonight. Subscriptions by 2,000 applicants aggregated $1,750,000,000.

Derby County established superiority over Everton, its chief rival for English Football League leadership, by winning today, 2-1. Yesterday the teams drew, 2-2, at Everton in the first of their homeand-away Christmas holiday matches.

Football has developed so fast during the last fifteen years, Harry Stuhldreher said today, "that we coaches will have to catch up with the game or be left behind." Stuhldreher, Wisconsin's athletic director and head gridiron coach, is president of the National Football Coaches Association, which tomorrow will swing into the business schedule of its eighteenth annual meeting.
Suspension of all WPA work at the S. Davis Wilson airport, Philadelphia's municipal field, was ordered today as a result of a controversy between city officials and the Civil Aeronautics Authority.

James M. Mead, Democratic Senator-elect from New York, proposed today that the merit system be extended to cover not only all Federal employes but employes of State agencies as well if they are receiving Federal aid.

Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, announced yesterday that in view of the substantial improvement in sales volume since the introduction of its 1939 models and the outlook for a sustained high level of the company's business in 1939,

The Port of New York Authority today called upon the Interstate Commerce Commission to reserve to local tunnel authorities the right to regulate transportation of explosives through tunnels such as the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels under the Hudson River.

Jimmy Foxx, hard-clouting first baseman of the Red Sox, whose spectacular comeback provided one of the high lights of the 1938 campaign, carried off the individual batting championship of the American League last season with a mark of .349, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

One of two ex-convicts being tried in General Sessions Court on charges of kidnapping Arthur Fried, a young Bronx business man, from his home in White Plains on Dec. 4, 1937, testified yesterday that Federal agents kept beating him for almost a week until he confessed the kidnapping.
En.rico Caputo, 28 years old, of 222 South Seventh Avenue, Mount Vernon, was arrested here today on suspicion of a felony in the death of Mrs. Lucy Landrum, 70, of 835 Mile Square Road, Yonkers,
A salute of nineteen guns fired in Capitol Park will mark the moment Monday when Governor Lehman takes the oath of office as the State's first Chief Executive to enter a four-year term.

With the teams battling on even terms have past the half-way mark, a draw is likely in the first South Africa-England cricket test which will end tomorrow. The Springboks today playing made 390 runs in reply to the visitors' first innings of 422 and the latter in their second venture lost one wicket for 103 before the close.

Completion of plans for the training of 20,000 college students annually as civilian pilots in what was termed here as the greatest aeronautics mass movement ever undertaken was announced today by President Roosevelt.

A large Manhattan apartment property, just north of the theatrical district and close to the condemned Sixth Avenue elevated structure, figured in the city realty deals reported yesterday. The twelve-story building on the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, known as the Oregon,

Ransackinig five rooms of the four-story home of Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, at 206 East Eighteenth Street, some time Christmas Eve or early Sunday while the Thomas family was spending the holidays on Long Island, a thief or thieves made off with several valued heirlooms.

Arthur J. Dolan, Ocean Beach guardian who estimated he had rescued nearly 200 persons from the surf in thirty-one years of patrol duty, died here yesterday at the age of 57. His "beat" on horseback covered a three-mile stretch along the beach.

One of the most unusual ceremonies ever staged on Fifth Avenue will be held by the Fifth Avenue Association in cooperation with the World's Fair at 9:30 o'clock this morning when Mayor La Guardia presses a switch, blinking the traffic lights on Fifth Avenue five
McGill University took the lead in the international intercollegiate ski meet today, capturing first, fourth and fifth places in the jumping which opened the three-day competition.

Cornell University's basketball team launched a road tour tonight with an easy 52-to-32 victory over Canisius College. Led by Captain Walter Foertsch at center, the Cornell quintet took the lead in the opening minutes and was never headed.

Benjamin G. Hadfield, postal inspector, who was instrumental in the arrest of the Fall River (Mass.) mail bandits, died here today after a brief illness. His age was 55. For the last two years he had been engaged in reorganizing the mail delivery service of Chicago, Detroit and Fort Worth.

BACHMANN-Lillian C., at her residence, Dec. 27, beloved mother of Charles, Harry, Louis, Robert, Eugene and sister of Ida Pfaffenbach. Funeral service Thursday Dec. 29, at 8:30 P. M., at Universal Chapel, 597 Lexington Ave. Interment Friday.

Acting Federal Attorney Gregory F. Noonan caused the arrest here yesterday of two men and a woman as a beginning of the promised round-up of a group that he charged with blackmailing F. Donaid Coster, president of McKesson Robbins, Inc.,

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., yesterday received the award of a new issue of $1,345,000 of Cincinnati, Ohio, water works, street, university and sewer bonds on a bid of 100.019 for a combination of $200,000 as 3 3/4s and $1,145,000 as 1 3/4s, or at a net interest cost to the city of 1.86 per cent.
An expenditure of about $430,000 is contemplated for new buildings in Brooklyn and Queens for which plans were filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday.

Suffolk County, N. Y., today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a petition seeking a further hearing on the application of the Long Island Railroad to abandon its Sag Harbor branch, a 4.39-mile spur from Bridgehampton.

Miss Brenda Diana Duff Frazier made her debut last night at a ball given in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton by her mother, Mrs. Frederic N. Watriss. It was the largest debutante dance of the season thus far, the hundreds of guests including many older friends of Miss Frazier's family, as well as the majority of the younger members of society who have participated in the holiday entertaining for debutantes.
James F. Mundy, Collector of Internal Revenue at Wilkes-Barre, died in Temple University Hospital here tonight after an operation at the age of 68. He had been ill two months.

Today's largest event was the tea and cocktail party given by Mrs. W. Longfellow Foulke at La Torre Bianca where her son, C. Pardee Foulke of Princeton, N. J., and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Kelly of New York are guests.

After looking through the poems and the records, Stanley Young has attempted to capture some of the tumult of Lord Byron in a biographical play, "Bright Rebel," which was put on at the Lyceum last evening. Something of a poet himself, Mr. Young contributed a verse play to last season, 'Robin Landing," and, since he is one of the current John Golden Fellows, it is expected'that plays will pour out of him from now on.

" With European powers arming at a furious rate; with Germany redrawing the map of Europe and with wars already in progress in the Orient and Spain, American sentimeat for armed preparedness has increased steadily in the three-year period from 1935 to 1938," according to the results of a survey made publie yesterday by Dr. George Gallup.

President Roosevelt today termed the Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, a great success. His comment, which under White House rules could not be quoted directly, was brought forth by a question as to his opinion of the results

In fine fettle after a tour to the Pacific Coast, Argentinita-and her little company of Spanish dancers and musicians-opened a series of seven holiday performances at the Fifty-first Street Theatre last night. The program was for the greater part new, though several of the most popular items from earlier in the season were again included, and rightly so.
A 310-pound wild Prussian boar, enraged by a party of hunters equipped with bows and arrows, chased the group up trees four times today before he was killed by an archer.

Annual meeting, Geographical Society of America, Hotel WaldorfAstoria, 9 A. M. Continues to Dec. 30. Meeting, American Astronomical Society, Columbia University, 9 A. M. Continues tomorrow. Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Homes of the Romans (general tour),

Philippe Roy, Canadian Minister to France, was made a "Citizen of Paris" today. The announcement was made here tonight at a gathering in honor of the retiring Minister by members of the Municipal Council.

John J. Malloy, veteran stage manager here, died yesterday after a year's illness at the age of 65. His death came only a few hours before his sister, Teresa Dale, opened in a new play, "The Primrose Path," in a Baltimore theatre.

The United States should devote more time and energy to the development of its trade in South America and elsewhere, and less to pursuit of the ogre of European ideological infiltration, Representative Francis D. Culkin of New York declared yesterday on his return from South America on the American Republics liner Brazil.
Dr. John W. Bowler died early today of pneumonia after a long career of athletic achievements and physical education work in Boston, Harvard University and Dartmouth College.

Miss Patricia Mary Ware, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond Ames Ware of Bronxville, was married to Byrne Bauer of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Hudson Bauer of 215 East Seventy-second Street, New York, here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph.

Charles Laughton, who will be busy for the next three months with a film called "Jamaica Inn," soon starting production at Elstree, told THE NEW YORK TIMES tonight there was no truth in a report from New York that he would play King Lear there next month.
Contributions of $4,507.89 from 268 donors reached the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, bringing the total amount that has been received for this twenty-seventh annual appeal to $240,644.16.

Business was slow inlocal markets yesterday following the Christmas holidays. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to higher, fresh pork cuts strong to sharply higher, some lamb cuts weak to lower and other classes of traefer meats unchanged from Friday. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
The newspaper Machine Building today published statements by several Soviet engineers agreeing that the time had come for experimental production of a low-priced popular automobile.
The wholesale price index of the National Fertilizer Association advanced moderately in the week ended Dec. 24, primarily because of a rise in farm product prices.

Joseph Dorf, New York real estate man, died today at his home here after a week's illness. His age was 73. Born in Austria, Mr. Dorf came to America as a child and for many years was in the real estate business in New York until about 1907, when he entered the liquor business.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that two New Jersey dealers in drugs and chemical products have entered into stipulations to cease and desist from misleading representations in their advertising.

Galliano Masini, Italian tenor, was cordially received in his Philadelphia debut with the Metropolitan Opera Association in Puccini's "Tosca" at the Academy of Music tonight. He sang the role of Mario Cavaradossi.

Mayor La Guardia called a special meeting of the City Council for 2 o'clock this afternoon in City Hall to hear his veto message on the $415,000 in items stricken out of the capital outlay budget by the Council in its all-night session last Tuesday.

In the Jade and Basildon Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell last night gave a dinner dance for their debutante daughter, Miss Ruth Mason Bissell, for whom they gave a reception at their home earlier this month.

C. M. Stenberg, assistant cashier of the First National Bank here, received for Christmas a name plate fashioned by one of the bandits, now serving forty-year terms in the penitentiary, who locked him in a vault in a robbery eight years ago.

Curran University set up a oneman course in history yesterday with Park Commissioner Robert Moses designated as the student body by Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, who is president of the university in his off moments.

The Pittsburgh West Virginia Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to sell to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation or have the RFC guarantee the payment of $1,500,000 in equipment-trust certificates.

The Americas have reached a new epoch in their evolution toward solidarity, Dr. Carlos Concha, chairman of the Pan-American Conference, told the delegates in formally closing their deliberations tonight.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Philip H. Ash, brother, 106 Pinehurst Ave., $1,500 annually from trust of one-half residue; George Ash, brother, executor, 210 W. 70th St., onehalf residue outright; several contingent bequests.

The Citizens Savings Bank, which began business seventy-eight years ago at 13 Avenue A, will open today its first uptown office, in the General Electric Building, 570 Lexington Avenue, at Fifty-first Street.

William Haynes, publisher and editor of Chemical Industries, has resigned as a director of Chemical Fund, Inc. Rudolph I. Ehrlichman has been appointed head of the dealer service department of the Independence Fund of North America, Inc., according to H. J. Simonson Jr., president.
After two years of marriage a young wife was deserted by her husband. The couple had bought $400 worth of furniture on which installments had been paid regularly until the husband disappeared.

Miss Florence Gottwald, 26-year-old radio factory worker, was in critical condition tonight, wounded by. ten bullets which police said were fired by a suitor twenty years her senior because she spurned his Christmas gift.

Form had an inning yesterday in the national junior indoor tennis championship on the resurfaced courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory as eleven of the twelve seeded players emerged from their second-round matches with victories to their credit.

Warren Stephens of the Rutgers B. C. reached the semi-final round of the Eastern junior badminton championship tournament, conducted under the auspices of the old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club, yesterday by defeating Alden Asherman of Friends Seminary, 15-5, 15-4. Stephens, seeded No. 1,

The State Department made public here the text of the address of Secretary of State Cordell Hull at the farewell dinner given to the delegates to the Eighth International Conference of American States at Lima tonight by President Oscar Benavides of Peru. It follows:

November production in the men's shirt and pajama industry rose to a level 25 per cent greater than that for the corresponding month of last year, while unfilled orders were 28 per cent higher, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the National Association of Shirt |and Pajama Manufacturers.

The Very Rev. Monsignor David W. Petry, since 1913 assistant pastor of the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, died last evening at the rectory, 472 West 142d Street, after an illness of six months. He was born in this city fifty-two years ago.

A new approach to the curing of alcoholism through the use of the drug benzedrine, which acts as a substitute for alcohol while the personality defect that caused the patient to become addicted to drink is corrected, was described yesterday by Dr. Wilfred Bloomberg,

Souvenir hunters who might be tempted to lift cutlery, glassware or napkins from the "native" restaurants and tearooms planned for a number of the foreign exhibits at the World's Fair will be under close scrutiny of managers of the establishments,

A new rule under the Public Utility Holding Company Act requiring affirmative proof of the reasonableness of any fee paid in connectionwith the issue, sale, or acquisition of any security by a registeered holding company by a registered holding company or subsidiary where there appears to be an absence of arm'slength bargaining was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective March

Mrs. Stella M. Crater Kunz was Germany-bound on the liner Normandie yesterday when her counsel filed for probate the will of her former husband, Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, whose strange disappearance on Aug. 6, 1930, has never been solved.

A number of the new tenancies listed in the business rental reports submitted yesterday involved fullfloor and loft units in the midtown district. Grossman Handel, manufacturers of dresses, leased a floor in the building at 36 West Thirty-third Street, between Broadway and Fifth Avenue, through Tankoos, Smith Co., brokers.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 23: MAJOR GENERAL Sunderland, A. H., Chief of Coast Artillery, two days' leave, Dec. 25. COLONEL Hamilton, 0. S., Inf., upon own application, to retirement. LIEUTENANT COLONEL Nalle, W., (Cav.), General Staff Corps, two days' leave, Dec. 27.

A cold wave struck New York City last night as Winter took hold on the country from the Atlantic to the Rocky Mountains and from Canada to the Gulf. The temperature was due to drop to 20 degrees or lower in the city this morning, remain in the twenties today and begin. tomorrow a slow rise expected to reach the thirties by the end of the week.

Harry Duke, 26 years old, of this city, who recently wrote for a detective magazine an article entitled "Confessions of an Atlantic City Racket Muscle Man," was sentenced to 364 days in the Atlantic County jail, in Mays Landing, today as an undesirable person.

" Contribute a Mile!" is the official slogan of the National Ski Association in its effort to raise sufficient money to send a complete squad of men and women to the Federation International de Ski Games, equivalent to the world championships, in Norway in 1940.
The curtain of secrecy was drawn around the battle plans of Duke and Southern California tonight after the rival Rose Bowl football teams went through their last semipublic practice.

Edward J. Storey, Director of Health and Physical Education in the Mamaroneck Schools, told a group of physical education teachers at a general session of five State associations here today the results he is having with the new State physical education program in his school system.
Errol Flynn,' Irish motion picture actor, faces the loss of his $25,000 yacht Sirocco because it exceeds tonnage and length limitations imposed by the Federal government on alien-owned craft.

Twenty-three Communists were arrested on Christmas Eve at the house of one of them, where they had met to celebrate and consult about a Communist program in Austria. It is reported that about thirty Communists were involved in the group, which had close relations with Communist organizations in Prague and Budapest.

In a ruling by Dr. Frank P. Graves, Commissioner of Education in New York State, the city Board of Education was ordered yesterday to fill a $10,000 position, vacant since early 1936, which school officials have termed unnecessary and a waste of taxpayers' money.

William H. Hodge, formerly vice president and manager of the sales and advertising division of the Public Utility Engineering and Service Corporation, and associated with the corporation and its predecessor organizations in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system for twenty-eight years, has resigned.

Though the American Association for the Advancement of Science will listen to nearly 500 technical papers and therefore concern itself primarily with laboratory discoveries and procedures, its deliberations on the social aspects of research will be of deeper public interest. Not in three centuries has science stood in such peril of losing its freedom of thought, its objectivity.

Announcement yesterday. by the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., that its shares would continue listed on the New York Stock Exchange was -taken to mean that the company had settled its difficulties with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Buying of wheat futures was stimulated on the Board of Trade here today by reports of a severe cold wave over T most of the belt. Zero temperatures ruled south into Kansas, and caught the crop without snow protection.

Postmaster General Farley.reported to President Roosevelt today that the Postoffice Department spent $43,811,556 more than its income ip the fiscal year 1938, but said it would have made $4,412,821 profit if it had not had the expense of its free services.

A wild-eyed hold-up man threatened yesterday to blow up the central cable office building of the Western Union Company at 40 Broad Street, near the scene of the Wall Street explosion of 1920. A terrified clerk handed him $33 and he fled.

Leander W. Faber of 85-32 178th Street, Jamaica, Queens, pleaded not guilty yesterday before County Judge- Charles S. Colden to a perjury indictment based on his reports concerning Supreme Court receiverships.

Mayor Livingston Platt of Rye offered a $25 reward today for information leading to the arrest of persons who stole an eight-foot Christmas candle from the green of the Village Hall, beside the Boston Post Road.

The Rev. Otis G. Dale, formerly editor of The Toledo Blade, dean of men at Moody Bible Institute, Chicago; lecturer at the University of Toronto and pastor of the largest Presbyterian Church in that city, died last night in a Santa Barbara rest home. He was 68 years old.

One man was convicted in Special Sessions yesterday and three others were sent to jail in the conspiracy uncovered last Summer by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, in which policy game collectors, with previous court convictions on which they might receive long jail terms, were using "stand-ins" to receive new sentences for them.

An airplane will be used to measure the speed of radio waves. The plan, which has been authorized by the American Geophysical Union, was described here today to the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. Harlan T. Stetson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

A search was started yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Herman H. Robbie of 570 Seventh Avenue, securities dealer, who was to have appeared for examination in Supreme Court yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Van Dyk MacBride of Nutley, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy MacBride, to Duncan Kenneth Finlayson of Boston. Miss MacBride attended the Prospect Hill Country Day School in Newark and was graduated from the Knox School in Cooperstown, N. Y., in 1934.

The residence here of Representative Henry K. Porter of Pennsylvania, who died in 1921, has been deeded to the Library of Congress by his stepdaughter, Miss Annie May Hegeman of New York, as a joint gift to the library and the Smithsonian Institution.

Miss Ruth Caroline Fewsmith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Livingston Fewsmith of this city and Spring Lake, made her debut this afternoon at a reception given by her parents and Mrs. Frederick W. Parker at the Newark home of the latter.
With clearance sales off to a good start yesterday, merchants here predicted that sales for December could be kept within 2 or 3 per cent of a year ago, despite slow buying early in the month.

Professor Edwin G. Conklin, Princeton biologist, who is past president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, strongly challenged today the right of Mathias Schleiden and Theodore Schwann, German scientists, to credit as the originators of the cell theory, the centenary of which is being celebrated throughout the scientific world this year.

Fewer than 1 per cent of those families who more than a year ago moved into Williamsburg and Harlem Houses, the two largest government-conducted low-rental projects in the city, have been asked to move, it was learned yesterday.

" Racket-busting" Thomas E. Dewey, who leveled his legal broadsides at Tammany leader James J. Hines and his political oratory at Governor Herbert H. Lehman, was the leading New York State headline maker of 1938.

The yachtsmen are going to do something about the amateur situation as it affects those who sail boats for sport. "Once a professional always a professional," will no longer obtain in yachting as it does in other sports if an amendment to the rules of the North American Yacht Racing Union goes through at a meeting on Jan. 6.

The army is preparing to outfit troops in five States with its new slateblue uniform, a proposed substitute for the familiar olive drab. War Department officials said today the uniforms had been delivered and will be donned by the men of eight units next month.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions for Arrangement INTEGRITY AMUSEMENT CORP., skating rink. So. Kensico Ave. and Oakley Ave., White Plains-Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler act listing liabilities of S87,348 and assets of S139,969.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York appealed to President Roosevelt yesterday to intercede in behalf of the nation's merchant marine interests in regard to the Pettengill bill, affecting the long and short haul clause of the Interstate Commerce Act.

New gains in Catalonia were credited to the Spanish Insurgent armies today. In the five days of the new drive Insurgents estimated they had cut 230 square miles from Catalonia, the northeastern third of government Spain, which .is separated from the Madrid-Valencia area by an Insurgent wedge to the Mediterranean 100 miles southwest of Barcelona.

President Ismet Inonu was elected to life leadership in the Republican Peoples party today. This was taken as a further sign of the determination to maintain the political structure established by the late President Kemal Ataturk.

The forthcoming publication of a monthly magazine, News From Italy, containing reports that exiled Italian intellectuals believe to be authentic concerning events in Italy, was announced last night at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt in honor of G. A. Borgese, former Professor of Esthetics at- the University of Milan and author of "Goliath: The Slovaks. March of Fescism."
Boston College conquered the Colgate team, 3 to 1, tonight in a fast ice hockey session, the second match in an eight-game series at the Playland Casino.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

One gets to wondering, in these final days of the year, about the nature of time. Day after day, one looks from the window and one sees the coming of dusk and the breaking forth of lights. It is as though an endless stream were flowing, sometimes in dazzling brilliancy, sometimes in shadow, but always flowing.

Charles Burchfield's first oneman show since 1936 opened yesterday at the Rehn Gallery, 683 Fifth Avenue, to be on through January. With a single exception all of the work is in water-color. This exception is the big oil called "Old House by the Creek,"

The Securities and Exchange Commission today conditionally made effective declarations of the Pennsylvania Power Company, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corportion, covering the issue and sale of 42,000 shares of $5 cumulative, no-par preferred stock,

Today's events: "Siegfried," afternoon, and "Mignon," evening, Metropolitan Opera; Marcel Maas and Alfred Dubois, violin-piano sonatas, Town Hall, evening. The Italian Women's Forum is sponsoring a concert to be given this evening at the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island, for the benefit of welfare work among needy Italian families. The program will be instrumental and vocal.

An exhibition of American patent models will be opened today on the men's floor and in the Fifth Avenue windows of Lord Taylor. These models represent not only the hopes and dreams of many men from many walks of life but also the embryonic stages of some useful present-day inventions.

Felix C. Benvenga, recently appointed a justice of the Supreme Court to replace Lieutenant Governor-elect Charles Poletti, was sworn yesterday by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division in the library of the Appellate Division Court House

Miss Bertha Blanchard Thomson of 6 East Sixty-fifth Street, daughter of Mrs. William S. Thomson of Pictou. Nova Scotia, and the late Mr. Thomson, was married last night to Robert James Wilkins, son of Mrs. Harry P. Wilkins of Los Angeles, formerly of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. Wilkins.

Herschel. Grynszpan, Jewish youth awaiting trial in Paris for killing a German Embassy attache, wants no contributions for his defense. He returned a contribution to Dr. George Herzog, San Francisco physician, with the wish that the money be given to "the 1,200 innocent Jews robbed and exiled and suffering from cold and hunger on the Polish border."

The 1938 Christmas Seal sale of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, which will end this Saturday, fell somewhat below that of last year, it was announced yesterday, but Frank Kiernan, director of the association,

The marriage of Miss Eleanor L. McCandless, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. McCandless, to Archibald Stark, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Stark of Boston, took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 103 Kensington Road.

The troublesome problem of Federal unemployment relief, made all the more explosive by the part played by the Works Progress Administration forces in the recent primary and general election campaigns, is expected to burst full in the face of the new Congress on the opening day.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 22: LIEUTENANT Hardwick, H. J., Naval Academy, to Asiatic Station. JUNIOR LIEUTENANTS Garrison, M. E., the S-20, to Navy Yard, Portsmouth, N. H. Islev-Petersen, H. J., the San Francisco, to the Zane.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt gave a Christmas dance tonight at the White House to present to Washington society her niece and namesake, Miss Eleanor Roosevelt of Dedham, Mass., daughter of Hall Roosevelt.

It was officially admitted tonight that ninety-three persons had been killed in the railroad collision at Etulia in Bessarabia on Christmas Day. Only fifty-three could be identified. Among the 340 injured 120 are in a serious condition.

Asserting that it was the biggest loan conversion of its kind ever obtained, Finance Minister Paul Reynaud of France announced tonight to the press and over the radio to the country that he had concluded with a group of Netherland and Swiss banks negotiations for a loan of 175,000,000 florins, the bonds to be issued at 95,

The Pennsylivania Investing Corporation has filed application for approval of the sale of $1,400,000 of Kentucky-Tennessee Light a n d Power Company's first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds due on May 1, 1954, for $1,232,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. A hearing on the application will be held here on Jan. 5.

Two new trustees were elected yesterday to the board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.-Mrs. Kenneth B. Norton of Bronxville, the first woman to serve on the directorate of the country's largest utility, and Neal Dow Becker, president of the Intertype Corporation.
The news pictures from time to time will show us a distinguished public figure overcome, as the classic phrase goes, by emotion.

Strains of a crazy, flat-footed swing tune, as harmonious as such a ditty possibly could be, shattered the serenity of Penn Station yesterday morning. A casual observer might have mistaken the party alighting from the train as a happy group of jitterbugs,
President Roosevelt said at a press conference today that he would have no Federal appointments to announce before Monday or Tuesday.

Five hundred refugees from Germany, Austria and Hungary, who landed at various Bulgarian ports in the last few weeks and subsequently were concentrated at Varna, left yesterday en route to an undisclosed destination. Jewish organizations and Bulgarians gave them food and clothing and provided medical attention.

Professor H. S. Kemp, Harvard geographer, today awarded the decision to Provincetown over Plymouth in the perennial battle concerning the first landing place of the Pilgrim Fathers, but said that the sojourn on the Cape Cod tip was no longer than a week-end visit.

The tea trade has been greatly encouaged by the work of the Tea Market Expansion Bureau and the future outlook is promising as a result of the bureau's $1,000,000 advertising campaign, H. A. Lewis, president of the Tea Association of the United States, declared yesterday. Consumer education, he said.

Trading in bonds yesterday following the week-end holiday was at a fairly active pace. Leading issues, however, drifted irregularly lower. Railroad and public utility loans again appeared to be the targets for year-end selling, while elsewhere throughout the list representative loans fluctuated within comparatively narrow limits.

The death of Alfonso Maria de Margarita, Bourbon, Marquis of Santa Fe and a cousin of former King Alfonso, from wounds suffered at the front, where he served as an Insurgent cavalry major, was announced today from Valladolid.
Odd-lot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday and Saturday were reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as follows: Friday:

Brooklyn College chess players, who won the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League and custody of the Harold M. Phillips trophy last year, made a brilliant start in the first round of the 1938 tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.

In line with the increasing number of colonial schools that are preparing Germans for colonial careers, Gerhard Wagner, the Reich medical leader, announced today the preparation of a colonial medical course and issued a call for colonial physicians.

A spokesman for the Humble Oil and Refining Company said today that a deal involving $8,500,000 cash and three-eighths royalty for oil properties and leases of the West Production Company, an independent producer, was being considered but had not been closed.

The $10,000 added New Year's Day Stakes at Santa Anita next Monday drew fourteen crack nominees today, including Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Heelfly, Bert Baroni's Specify and the Binglin Stable's Argentine, Ligaroti.

A scroll in recognition of the assistance given in furthering welfare and civic programs, signed by fortythree metropolitan organizations, will be presented today to Spear Co. at a reception and tea to be held at 22 West Thirty-fourth Street.

There seems to be no displacing that man Gottselig from the head of the National Hockey League's scorers. Stickhandling Johnny was at the front in the league's first compilation of statistics five weeks ago and he's still there in the list released tonight.

The Mount St. Michael High School basketball team defeated the St. Joseph's Seminary quintet of Callicoon, N. Y., 45 to 33, on the winner's court last night. At the half-way mark, Mount St. Michael held a 23-8 lead.

Many luncheons for children were given by their elders yesterday in the Sert Room of he Waldorf-Astoria in conjunction with the entertainment known as the "Children's Holiday Party" for the benefit of the Social Service Auxiliary of the Cancer Institute.

Mrs. Michael H. Wegman of 41 Fifth Avenue, this city, and Philadelphia has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Ruth Wegman, to Irwin S. Mason, son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris A. Mason, also of this city.

The State Department announced today that the United States had signed a regional agreement with Central American republics and Panama which "involved consideration of the needs of the military radio facilities related to the defense of the Panama Canal."

Frank Bloom, trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, recommended in an intermediate report today that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation disown its system (called "plans") for representation of its 100,000 employes.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Abbott gave a dinner dance last night at the River Club for Mrs. Abbott's debutante daughter, Miss Catharine B. Gamble. The guests afterward went to the ball for Miss Brenda Frazier at the Ritz-Carlton.

In Vienna, the capital of their newly-conquered eastern colony, the Nazis have been busily polishing, painting and cleaning up the somewhat rundown old city. Public works have cut unemployment in Austria in two and in due course Vienna's aspect will be altered by ultra-modern and ultraplain buildings, such as are scattered over Germany.

Secretary of Agriculture Wallace charged today that Cargill, Inc., of Minneapolis, grain dealers, violated provisions of the Commodity Exchange Act in connection with trading operations in corn futures contracts in 1937.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt blamed general apathy of women today for the numerical decrease in women legislators and members of Congress. There are plenty of capable women to hold legislative positions, Mrs. Roosevelt told her press conference.
Application blanks for 1939 automobile license plates were made available for the first time yesterday at all offices of the Motor Vehicle Bureau throughout the State and at most police stations.

3d Ave. 1.702, 27x100; Isidor Berger to Savings Banks Trust Co; building loan, 5 years, 3-4 per cent; $3,000. Extensions 47th St. 228-48 W: also 46th St, 233 W; extends mtg, $2,927,000, to Dec. 31, 1948. at 4 1/2 per cent; Hotel Edison Corp to New York Trust Co and Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co.
Throughout the eighth Pan-American Conference the more than a dozen Nazi and Fascist newspaper correspondents have maintained a haughty attitude of disapproval of the entire proceedings.

Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd E. Wilson of San Francisco asked the Board of Tax Appeals today for an Income tax exemption for an unborn child. They brought forward the claim to refute the Internal. Revenue Bureau's contention that they owed $6.18 income tax for 1936.

Congressional action at the coming session in an effort to solve the problems of the railroads was pictured as possible today after Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Committee, had conferred for almost an hour with President Roosevelt.

Planned sales on profitable items instead of dependence on normal sales and loss leaders were credited for business gains reported for 1938 by members of the Independent Grocers Alliance of America, J. Sidney Johnson,

Two more parcels in the vicinity of the Bronx housing project of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company passed into new ownership in deals reported yesterday. A vacant plot 104 by 174 feet on the northwest corner of Westchester and Castle Hill Avenues was acquired by Klein Jackson, Inc.,

Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Powers of Hazelton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hannah Smedley Powers, to Carl Ferenbach Jr., son of Mrs. Carl Ferenbach of 277 Park Avenue, New York.

Leonard Del Genio, Harlem welterweight, defeated Andre Jessurun of the Bronx in the star bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum last night. The battle was close and many in the crowd of 3,500 persons disagreed with the verdict. Del Genio weighed 1443/4, as against 1471/2 for Jessurun.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, headed by Eugene Ormandy, paid a holiday call at Carnegie Hall last night and introduced the winner of the Schubert Memorial Award, Jacques Abram, young American pianist. Mr. Abram was the soloist in MacDowell's Second Concerto in D minor and scored heavily with the audience.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Dec. 21 aggregated $11,534,000,000, or 36 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 13 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Miss Lucy McIntyre Parton made her debut this afternoon at a large tea dance given at the Bronxville Woman's Club by her grandmother, Mrs. Harry Whiting Brown. The debutante is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Parton of this place.

Mr. and Mrs. Egbert D. Corson of Lockport have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catharine Alice Corson, to Burton Allan MacLean, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles Chalmers MacLean of Batavia.

The name of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., investment banking, will be changed on Jan. 1 to Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday by Joseph P. Ripley, president. The change was made primarily because of confusion created by the similarity of its old name with that of Brown Brothers Harriman Co., one of the oldest commercial banking firms in the country.

" The Return of th Cisco Kid," sequel to the early talkie success, "Cisco Kid," will go before the Fox-Twentieth Century cameras on Jan. 23 with Warner Baxter again playing the part of the ingratiating bandit. Today Lynn Bari was assigned to the feminine lead with Cesar Romero as Baxter's lieutenant. Herbert I. Leeds will direct the scenario by Milton Sperling.

There was a fairly active trend in all livestock departments today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Steers and yearlings cashed on a firm basis, top $13.60 for 1,229 pound weights. Hogs were steady to strong, and some sold 10 cents higher at a top of $8. Fat lambs ruled steady to strong with spots 10 to 15 cents higher; best load lots brought 59.40.

LAWRENCE OF ARABIA remains the-most famously obscure man of our time. It seems impossible to speak of his celebrity without emphasizing his mysteriousness.
