When he engaged in public affairs it was widely observed that he was really up to far more weird enterprises than ever met the eye, and when he seemed to be bent on concealing himself it was triumphantly pointed out that thousands knew precisely what he was doing.

District ttorneyy William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn denied yesterday that his office had engaged in anti-labor activity after the Brooklyn Labor and Citizen's Committee had made that charge in a 15,000-word survey of the subject that it sent to William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation.

The superiority of real wages-the purchasing power of wagesin the United States over the wages earned by workers in dictatorship nations was emphasized in the report of a study made public yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.
Mr. and Mrs. Dwight R. G. Palmer of South Orange gave a large supper dance last night at the Essex County Country Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Jeannette Palmer.

A plea that foreign languages be restored to their former place of importance in the secondary school curriculum was made by speakers yesterday at the tenth annual meeting of the American Association of Teachers of French at the Hotel Commodore.

Leaders in the financial affairs of the nation appeared yesterday before Magistrate August Dreyer in a summons action brought by Mrs. Dorothy Ledyard Knight, daughter of the late Lewis Cass Ledyard and wife of a lawyer, against Thomas H. Wilson, a vice president of the United States Trust Company of New York.

Deportation of all Communists to Russia was advocated today by the Rev. Frederie Siedenburg, head of the University of Detroit, in an address before 250 Catholic sociologists, meeting under the auspices of Loyola University.
Cooperation between industry and government in "socially useful" industrial research was urged yesterday by Richard C. Patterson Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce,

" What can be done to provide better living quarters in large cities for families with incomes of $1,000 to $1,800 annually?" That question is heard almost every time there is a general discussion of the housing problem.

Seven generals of the Chilean Army retired today at the suggestion of the Defense Ministry as the new Popular Front government headed by President Pedro Aguirre Cerda busily organized its administrative machinery.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am prompted by THE TIME'S recent editorial "A Musical Center" and a letter contributed by Virginia Livingston Hunt to submit certain ideas which, in view of the more pressing problems agitating the world at large, I have permitted to lie dormant since Nazi-controlled Salzburg first became anathema to all true lovers of music.

That pugnacious "little Shrimp," Captain Myles Standish, was in and about what was to become Provincetown, Mass., three hundred and eighteen years ago. He has left spiritual inheritors there. The Mayflower dropped anchor off Cape Cod's "sandy fist," as Thoreau calls Provincetown, Saturday, Nov. 21, 1620.

Wilson, a vice president of the United States Trust Company of New York.

Mayor La Guardia, welcoming delegates at the opening business session yesterday of the fourth anhual convention of the American Student Union, took occasion to denounce the Democratic majority of the City Council for "obstructing" tactics and to criticize new political parties for acquiring quickly the "bad habit" of demanding patronage.

Mrs. Charlotte Goodridge Morton, widow of Paul Morton, Secretary of the Navy in President Theodore Roosevelt's Cabinet, died yesterday at her residence, 1 Sutton Place South, after a brief illness. She was born in Chicago eighty years ago.
Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. John W. Keeler of Hammondsport of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Lucy Keeler, to George Andrew Law rence of New York.

There was ice skating yesterday for the first time this season at six public playgrounds in Manhattan, Queens and Staten Island, besides the parking field at Jacob Riis Park on Rockaway Point. If freezing weather continues, the city Department of Parks expects all its 103 wading pools and fifteen tennis courts throughout the city to be ready for skaters today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission gave today conditional approval to a declaration of General Public Utilities, Inc., a subsidiary of the Community Power and Light Company, covering the issuance of a maximum amount of 15,212 shares of no-par common stock in connection with an optional dividend.

Dr. Raymond W. Murray of the University of Notre Dame was elected president today of the American Catholic Sociological Society. Other officers named were: Vice president, Dr. Paul Hanley Furfey of the Catholic University of America;

Several luncheons and dinners were given here today. Mrs. James H. Kennedy entertained with a dinner at Kenlewinal At Sandy Loam Farm, Hugh Dillman gave a buffet luncheon. Mrs. Orlando F. Weber was a dinner hostess at the Breakers.

Joe Louis came East from Chicago yesterday morning, and repaired immediately to Pompton Lakes, N. J., where he will prepare for the defense of his world heavyweight crown against John Henry Lewis, light heavyweight titleholder, in a fifteen-round bout scheduled for Jan. 25 in Madison Square Garden.
Of the fifteen points for reform of the New York Stock Exchange contained in William O. Douglas's pronunciamento of Oct. 31, few remain awaiting solution.

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, whose brilliant showing in the final stages of the recent A. V. R. O. international meet encouraged his countrymen in the belief that he might soon be able to recover the world championship, drew his opening game today in the masters tournament at the annual Christmas Congress of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club.

ADLER, JUDAH (Dec. 22) Estate, more than $10,000. To Carrie Adler, sister, 935 Park Ave., $125,000, contingent remainder in $40,000 and residue; Herbert Grinnell, grandnephew, 935 Park Ave., temporary estate in $40,000 trust; Frances L. Greenbaum. 240 E. 79th St.:

How the news of a "concentration" of Italian troops on the frontier of French Somaliland reached the world has been traced. It originated with a French nun who left Ethiopia several weeks ago and went to Rome.

Defending his company's employee representation plans, Eugene G. Grace, president of Bethlehem Steel Company, issued a statement yesterday announcing that the intermediate report of Frank Bloom, a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, recommending their dissolution, would be contested.

The Bruins' sensational goal-tender, Frank Brimsek, will be seen in action tonight in Madison Square Garden in the fourth game of the National Hockey League championship season between Red Dutton's Americans and the Boston squad.

Hermod Peterson, former general manager of the Norwegian State Telegraph and pioneer in wireless telegraphy and broadcasting, died today at the age of 65. He laid claim to the invention of the first system of sending pictures by wireless in 1919, but the system is not used now.

The independent Rightist Deputy Henri de Kerillis set Paris to laughing and wondering today by publishing in his newspaper, the Epoque, an imaginary telephone conversation in which Aolf Hitler tells Benito Mussolini how to take France's colonies.
Ligaroti, the flashy South American horse owned by Bing Crosby and Lin Howard, drew top weight of 126 pounds today for the running of the $10,000 New Year's Handicap next Monday at Santa Anita Park.

Dr. Charles J. Stucky, former head of the Bio-Chemistry Department of the Medical School of Georgetown University, died Monday night, after a long illness, in Clinton, Conn., according to announcement here last night.

New Zealand's social security plan, covering one-sixth of the national income, has been postponed indefinitely. Health Minister Fraser said it was impossible to fix a date when the benefits would be available.

A suit to collect $47,562 in insurance on the life of a youth who disappeared mysteriously more than four years ago was on file here today in the United States District Clerk's office. Mr. and Mrs. Isador Schwartz of Carteret, parents of the vouth.

College and high school students gathered at the fourth annual convention of the American Student Union, held at the City College Commerce Center, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, delved into current political issues at yesterday's sessions.

Word of an Arctic tragedy which cost the life of a young British scientist three months ago reached this Hudson Bay post today from the wastes beyond the Arctic Circle. A wireless report told of the death of R. J. O. Bray,

The Government's plan for the education of pilots-20,000 annually is the tentative figure set by the Civil Aeronautics Authority-must be carefully developed and soundly directed if it is to achieve even partial success. Advanced as a project to train civilian fliers at our colleges in order to meet an unexplained "aeronautical crisis now facing the country," the plan is plainly intended to provide a reserve of military fliers for a time of emergency.

For the second time in six months Detective Mary Shanley of the pickpocket squad failed to send Charles Herbert, 47 years old, to jail yesterday when Magistrate Ford in Yorkville Court refused to believe her story that Herbert was loitering in a Fifth Avenue store with criminal intent and dismissed the charge against him.

The girl guidance bureau of the Girls Service League of America aided 1,022 homeless, maladjusted, penniless or otherwise unfortunate girls in the year ended on Sept. 30, according to the annual report of the bureau, made public yesterday from its offices at 138 East Nineteenth Street.
The government of the tiny independent Principality of Liechtenstein is preparing to oust a number of Jews and others regarded as undesirable aliens.

Uncle Sam missed one mail, so he could not play Santa Claus to 10,000 cane growers, but he is going to make good before Three Kings Day, Puerto Rico's second Christmas, Jan. 6, on the last sugar crop compensation payments, totaling $8,000,000.

It is announced that the French group that held 50 per cent of the Skoda munitions shares has disposed of its holdings to the Czecho-Slovak Government. The French group, known as Centre European, represented the Schneider-Creusot munitions firm.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Luther G. Battin of Riverview Manor, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Battin, to John Wright Waterbury, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Waterbury of Irvington-on-Hudson.

After fifty-eight years of continuous service with the New York Central Railroad System, beginning as a waterboy for a construction gang, Edward H. Pullis of 725 Paterson Turnpike here, will retire Saturday on a pension of $90 a month. Since his birth seventy years ago, he has lived in the same house.
Harcourt, Brace announce a second printing of "Dr. Norton's Wife," Mildred Walker's new novel out today. The book is the Literary Guild selection for January.

74th St, 307 W, 5-story dwelling, 24x67; Greenwich Savings Bank against Mary M. Munro, due, $24,526; to plaintiff for $20,000. Rivington St, 56, 3-story tenement, 21x80: W. Barton Chapin, etc, against Isider Siegal, due, $6,636; to plaintiff for $4,000.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teavher-in-training in history and civics In day secondary schools other than junior high schools, be issued, as of Dec. 23, 1938, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefor:

Rhinelander Ave (15-4270), n e cor of Hone Ave, 75x100: Joseph E. Well to Henry Cohen, 941 Stebbins Ave. East Fordham Rd (11-3154), n w side, 149 ft s w of Kingsbridge Rd. 50x156; Howard T. Thompson to Chase National Bank, 18 Pine St; mtg $125,000. Tryon Ave (12-3343), n e cor of Reservoir Oval, 200x105; 1,024 Third Ave Corp to Lancashire Realty Corp, 260 W 39th St; mtg 225.483.

Some 300 delegates are expected to attend the twenty-second annual convention of the American Association of Teachers of Spanish tomorrow and Saturday at the Hotel Commodore and New York University, it was announced yesterday by Dr. E. Herman Hespelt, Associate Professor of Spanish at the N. Y. U. Washington Square College.

Professor Felix FranKrurter or the Harvard Law School and Dr. Cyrus Adler, the educator, are among five Jewish leaders who will be inducted tomorrow night as honorary members into Zeta Beta Tau, national college fraternity,
The mysterious source of the cosmic ray and of the variations in its intensity occupied the attention today of members of the American Physical Society on the second day of their annual meeting.
The United States fencing team took the second match of its series with Cuban swordsmen tonight, 18 to 14. The visitors had been defeated in the opening engagement on touches after a tie at 16--all.
Simon F. Pauxtis, Philadelphia, today was appointed head football coach at Pennsylvania Military College. He succeeds Judson A. Timm, resigned.

If a world confronted by chaos and seemingly insoluble problems is to survive and to go on to new roads of progress, the scientific method must be applied in studying and in solving the political and economic enigmas ahead of us, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday in welcoming more than 1,000 delegates to the fifty-first annual meeting of the Geological Society of America.

Although rated only fourth under the peculiar method of classification adopted by his circuit, Charlie Ruffing, burly right-hander of the Yankees, was the American League's foremost pitcher for 1938, according to the official averages released for publication today.

The report of the American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after expenses and charges of $9,768,050, as compared with a net of $11,276,647 in the twelve months to Nov. 30, 1937.

The six teams in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League will start tournament play Saturday night, Jan. 7, when games will be contested at the Squadron A Armory, Manhattan; the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, and the Essex Troop Armory, Newark.

Administrators of the estate of J. Clarence Davies of New York City asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to review the government's claim that the estate owed $45,735 in taxes. At the same time they sought a refund A. M. of $37,259 or more.
Building projects for which plans were filed yesterday included several large apartment houses in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. The plans follow:
A new note in anti-Semitism was struck in the agrarian newspaper Vecer which said that antiSemitism was "protection against anti-Aryanism."

William F. Casey Jr., 12 years old, son of City Commissioner William F. Casey, has been appointed a page in the United States Senate, it was announced here today at Senator, William H. Smathers's office.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Kibbe of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Kibbe, to Ethan Wolcott Hitchcock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucius W. Hitchcock of Southport, Me., and New Rochelle, N. Y.
A series of eight bills introduced in Parliament tonight would give The Netherland Governernment extraordinary powers in case of war, including power to requisition shipping and aviation.

Thirty thousand clothing workers in this city will give one day's pay to aid European refugees of all faiths under a resolution adopted yesterday by the New York joint board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate.

With the racing strip muddy--a condition that prevails only a few times during the Florida season--the fields were small at Tropical Park today. The Long Key Purse of six furlongs attracted seven 2-year-olds and the W. C. Stroube-J. L. Collins entry of Sirasia and

Meeting, American Astronomical Society, Columbia University, 9 A. M. Continues tomorrow. Metropolitan Museum of Art. Masterpieces of painting of the nineteenth century (general tour), 11 A. M.; collection of Greek art (general tour), 2 P. M.
The Wooster College basketball team opened its Eastern tour with a 57-33 triumph over the Rider College quintet at the Trenton Central High gymnasium tonight.

New York City's celebration to welcome the New Year will be marked, as of old, by gay revels at hotels, restaurants and night clubs. The festivities this year in many cases will be linked to the World's Fair, using as their theme "Dawn of a New Day," the late George Gershwin's last song, which will serve as the theme song of the fair.

A banking group, headed by tne Chase National Bank, R. H. Moulton Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers, purchased yesterday from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation $13,556,000 Metropolitan Water District of Southern California 4 per cent Colorado River Waterworks refunding bonds.
The following Marine Corps changes were released today, dated Dec. 27: Col. C. B. Matthews, detail as assistant adjutant and inspector revoked, effective Dec. 23.

CROWN DECORATORS, INC., 33 E. 170th St.--Voluntary proceeding under Chapter XI of the Chandler Act listing liabilities of $18,166 and assets of $23,048. A settlement of 90 per cent in deferred payments is proposed.

The government agreed today to accept $1,537,000 in settlement of sixty income tax claims totaling $3,700,000 against the Western Union Telegraph Company and eleven subsidiaries. Some of the cases had been contested since 1920.

Max Sessler, in 110 E 87th St; Dr. John A. Saxton Jr, in 430 E 86th St; Mrs. Margaret L. Dixon, in 180 E 78th St; Charles Fuller Young, in 60 E 67th St; Fred Vaughan, in 345 E 57th St; Frederick Laist, in 1,067 5th Ave; Culver, Hollyday Co. Inc. brokers.

Stockholders of the National Steel Car Corporation approved yesterday in Hamilton, Ont., an increase in authorized capital from 130,000 no-par shares to 250,000 no-par shares. Of the new stock, 45,500 shares will be offered as rights to all shareholders of record of Jan. 3 on the basis of 31/2 new shares for each ten shares held, at a price of $35 a share.

An intellectual depression has hit the American universities, as evidenced by the decline of the humancities and the growth of nationalism, Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University declared yesterday at the morning session of the American Association of Teachers of French,
The WPA finished 1,827 public buildings and repaired and enlarged 5,125 more between July 1 and Nov. 1. Colonel F. C. Harrington, Works Progress Administrator, said today that many of the

At capacity audience turned out for the special matinee of Wagner's "Siegfried" at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday. The performance was for the benefit of the Near East College Association. The proceeds that accrued to the association were estimated at about $7.500.

If deposit accounts in insured banks were insured up to $10,000, instead of the present $5,000 limit, as proposed in a bill introduced in the last session of Congress by Representative Steagall, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, the amount of insured deposits would be increased by $3,000,000,000 from the present $21,700,000,000, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today.

South Africa and England will go into the second test cricket match at Caps Town Saturday on even terms. The initial fourd-ay encounter in the five-game series ended today in a draw, with the Springboks 216 runs short of victory with nine wickets to fall.

Mrs. Ellen Elizabeth King, wife of Elmer King, dean of Morris County law yers, and mother of former State Senator Elmer S. King of Morristown, died in her home here today in her sixty-eighth year. Born in Stanhope, Mrs. King was graduated from the Centenary Collegiate Institute at Hackettstown.

Miss Eleanor Frances Edgar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Edgar, and John Stuart Booth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Booth, both of Bernardsville, were married last night in St. Bernard's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Thomas A. Conover, the rector, assisted by Rev. Dr. Lauren G. Bennett, pastor of the Basking Ridge Presbyterian Church.

A Rebel drive on the Balaguer bridgehead, in the center of the Segre battle line, began this morning with a tremendous plane, artillery and tank attack from Asentiu in the direction of Agramunt. This evening at the army headquarters, where the writer had passed much of the afternoon, all reports from the commanders in that sector said the attack had been repulsed.
Stimulated by a strong stock market and an advance in Liverpool after the holiday recess, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved 12 to 15 points yesterday under the most active trading in some time.

After being twice postponed, "Everywhere I Roam," an allegory of farmers in the West, comes tonight to the National. Arnold Sundgaard wrote what is described officially as the "original version," which was seen last Summer at the Barter Theatre, Abingdon, Va., and for the Broadway production collaborated with Marc Connelly, who is producing it with Bela Blau.

Dr. Percival James Eaton of Province-town, Mass., traveler, author and physician, died here this morning in Olean General Hospital at the age of 76. He had been ill most of the time since he came to visit his daughter, Mrs. Joseph Groves, on May 10.
The Burear Navigation released the following order today, dated Dec. 23:

James Weddell of the British Navy, whose fame as an explorer rests upon accounts of a trip by a sailing vessel in 1823 to a point 1,500 miles south of the lower tip of South America, was branded a "fake explorer" today by Professor William H. Hobbs of the University of Michigan.

The athlete of the year in Canadian sports was football's Hugh (Bummer) Stirling, who said farewell to the gridiron less than two weeks ago after ten seasons as an outstanding halfback with the Sarnia Imperials of the Ontario Rugby Football Union.
Italian sources indicated today that Italy. virtually had abandoned any hope of territorial gains at France's expense and said that the Fascisti had no intention of invading French Somaliland.

The nationalism of the dictators and the resulting world "anarchy" were laid yesterday to the failure of President Woodrow Wilson's League of. Nations idea, and this in turn was laid to Senators Lodge, Borah and Johnson, by Dr. James T. Shotwell, Professor of History at Columbia University.

An advertising appropriation of $1,000,000 has been decided upon for the coming year by the Scott Paper Company, Chester, Pa., Harry C. Pardee, advertising manager, announced yesterday at a meeting of fifty sales representatives from New York City, Buffalo and the New England area at the Hotel Roosevelt. The conference yesterday was devoted to the retail sales division, while today plans for the industrial products will be out-lined.

Northern Bridge Estates, Inc., representing Charles Walzer, the operator, sold the six-story apartment house for fifty-six families at 910 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of 162d Street, to a client of Milton M. Jacobs, attorney.

More than 50,000 tons of rubbish and waste was collected for final disposition over the Christmas holiday by regular employes of the Sanitation Department, according to an announcement yesterday by William F. Carey, head of the department.

McGill skiers regained their lead in the international intercollegiate meet today with a victory in the slalom event after they had been ousted from first place earlier as a result of Dartmouth University's triumph in the downhill competition.

The Federal Power Commission dismissed today without prejudice the application of the Tennessee Valley Authority for approval of parts of an agreement with the Gibson County Electric Membership Corporation.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was the heaviest of the year, transactions amounting to $15,499,000, the largest since Oct. 19, 1937, and compared with $10,883,550 on Tuesday.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Harkness Lockwood of 115 Willow Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Lockwood, to John Jacques Mendel, son of Mrs. Jules Mendel of 1,120 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Mendel. The announcement was made last night at a dinner given at the St. Regis.
The last building in a group of ten purchased by the Robin Realty Company from the North River Savings Bank was resold to Pinton Buildings, Inc.

Strictly good, choice and prime steers and yearlings sold today at fully steady prices, but other cattle were weak to 25 cents lower the United States Department of Agriculture reports. The top for yearlings and light steers was $13.65. Hogs sold unevenly.

Counsel for Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, in a brief filed today, asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here to reverse the so-called "free speech" injunction against Jersey City authorities on the ground that the court of Federal Judge William Clark, who granted it, had lacked jurisdiction. The brief was in reply to questions raised in last Friday's arguments.

Student representatives of twenty-three colleges met yesterday to form a permanent Intercollegiate Committee to Aid Student Refugees by bringing together "American students interested in helping fellow students who have been forced to discontinue their studies in their native land."

Over the objections of government counsel, Frank Cooper, Federal district judge, ordered Secretary Wallace today to disclose the number of votes cast by all milk cooperatives in the referendum which resulted in approval of a seven-State milk marketing pact for producers supplying metropolitan New York.

The City Council rejected yesterday Mayor La Guardia's veto of cuts in the 1939 capital outlay budget, but later the Mayor declared that the rejection was ineffective and that he would proceed on the assumption that the few items at issue were still in the budget.
The directors of the Association of American Railroads are to discuss the report of the President's committee on railroads, which was recently issued, at a meeting in Washington tomorrow.
Fifteen foreign men and women, mostly Americans, were robbed of money and jewels tonight in the biggest hold-up in the Shanghai area in years.

Generalissimo Francisco Franco's military intelligence service, investigating the "British consular valise affair," stung by an intimation in the British press that only Spaniards were involved and that perhaps the incriminating docunents were "planted," today made additional disclosures.
Alfred R. Heath has purchased from the Suffolk County Trust Company the eight-room colonial dwelling at 10 Cedar Place, Garden City, L. I., on a plot 75 by 112.5 feet. Mr. Heath,

Manufacturers of most department store merchandise lines, well satisfied with their last quarter business and holding only moderate year-end stocks, are "ready to go" on Spring merchandise and are willing to liquidate their current goods at sacrifices, it developed yesterday when two groups of deapartment stores began mass buying drives in which they will spend $1,000,000 within the next few days.

Aboard the Santa Clara out of Callao, after patiently hewing another step or two in the long stairway to world acceptance of his international program, Secretary of State Hull is coming home to find domestic sappers at work on the foundations of his structure.

We were down in the books for a cold spell and now it has been delivered, with a turn for the worse threatened. Though the blizzards which are blanketing many States have missed us thus far, the predictions are not entirely reassuring; it is already cold enough to suit any reasonable person.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,449,700 barrels, an increase of 173,400 over the 3,276,300 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 143,900 barrels more than the calculation of 3,305,800 daily by the Bureau of Mines for December.

Gertrude Maitland, an actress, died of a heart ailment yesterday morning at the Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 58 years old. Born in Boston, Miss Maitland first appeared in Jere McAuliffe's Repertory Company in Lynn, Mass., and in several stock companies before playing on Broadway in "The Brat" in 1916.

Miss Minnie Maud Glidden, formerly a teacher in the kindergarten school of Pratt Institute, died yesterday in the Klassen Nursing Home, 320 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, where she had resided since 1931. She was born seventy-three years ago in Milwaukee, a daughter of Carlos Glidden, typewriter inventor.

The American Institute of Accountants, 13 East Forty-first Street, issued a statement through its secretary, John L. Carey, following a meeting of its executive committee yesterday afternoon announcing that the institute would review auditing procedure "to determine what, if any, changes in procedure should be adopted by the profession in the light of the revelations in the McKesson Robbins case."
The value of Canada's imports in November was 21.5 per cent lower than in the same month last year, totaling $63,304,000, against $80,641,000, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Possibility that the Erie Railroad may abandon its line into Rochester was heard today when the directors of the Rochester Genesee Valley Railroad met to consider a proposal by the Erie to reduce the rental rate for the Genesee Valley trackage from 6 to 3 per cent interest on the capital stock.

Cooperating with the government's program of facilitating the exchange of professors and students with Latin America, the American Republics Line, the Grace Line and the Mississippi Shipping Company, beginning the first of the year, will grant 50 per cent reductions from advertised fares for students, teachers and professors traveling between the United States and South America.

A scientist--Dr. George E. Simpson, youthful assistant professor of sociology at Temple University, Philadelphia-who spent nearly nine months studying voodooism in Haiti, rose yesterday to the defense of certain aspects of the weird rites,

The season's second performance of "Mignon" was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House before a large audience that included many standees. The cast was identical with that of the first performance, namely, Rise Stevens in the title role, Josephine Antoine as Philine, Richard Crooks as Wilhelm Meister, Ezio Pinza as Lothario, Alessio De Paolis as Laerte,

Francis McComas, California artist who specialized, in painting the gnarled beauty of old cypress trees, died yesterday at the age of 64. A cypress tree will be planted near the grave during a private ceremony tomorrow in accordance with his wish.

A check for $10,900,000, representing the inheritance levy on the estate of Frederick W. Vanderbilt, former vice president of the New York Central Railroad, was delivered to the State Tax Department today.
Prices of wheat worked slowly upward today and closing trades bn the Board of Trade were at the top, with net gains of 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel and the highest since October.

Brooklyn Cathedral Prep defeated New York Cathedral Prep, 33 to 18, in their annual basketball game on the loser's court yesterday. Laurie, with 9 points, was high scorer for the Brooklynites, who held a 16-5 lead at half-time.
The WPA Federal Theatre's Yiddish version of "Awake and Sing" will be presented for matinee and evening performances on Sundays, the Monday and Tuesday evening performances being omitted.

The Oil City Derrick said today the bringing in of a "wildcat" gas well in Potter County, near the State line and south of the gas field in New York, "probably" would mean the opening of a new Oriskany sand gas field.

Walter W. Ogier Jr., executive vice president of the Pure Carbonic Corporation of New York, manufacturers of carbonic acid gas and dry ice, died here today of pneumonia in the Northern Westchester Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived at Briar Hills, Pleasantville.
James Arthur Batley, former British Davis Cup team captain and for many years on the council of the Lawn Tennis Association, died today. His age was 63.

The net operating income of the Class I railroads in the United States in November is estimated to have reached about $50,000,000, compared with $32,440,920 in November, 1937, a gain of 54 per cent. Gross revenues were estimated at $320,000,000, against $318,180,377 in November, 1937, a gain of 5.7 per

Representative Gearhart,, Republican, of California, proposed today a constitutional amendment abolishing life tenure for Supreme Court justices and providing for their appointment for eighteen-year terms.

The stock market opened quietly today but held up fairly well despite international political uncertainty. Giltedge stocks improved in late dealing, although movements were small. Foreign bonds were irregular, with Czech and German issues lower.

As a citizen Zona Gale was the worthy descendant of an officer in Shays's Rebellion. She rebelled against everything that she regarded as unjust or oppressive. Her most fruitful years were spent in Wisconsin, where her "passion for reform" could be satisfied in some part.

Miss Edith Abbot Beardall, daughter of Captain John R. Beardall, U. S .N., and Mrs. Beardall, was married this afternoon to Yellott Fitzhugh Hardcastle Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hardcastle of Haverford, Pa.

Frank Murphy, Governor of Michigan and an active supporter of the New Deal who was defeated for re-election in November, will be appointed Attorney General of the United States to succeed Homer S. Cummings, it was learned today. The President decided on this when he made Harry L. Hopkins Secretary of Commerce, Administration leaders said.

Duke's gridiron followers turned to the lighter side of their Rose Bowl engagement today, leaving the Blue Devil team to finish unattended its training for the coming encounter with the Trojans of the University of Southern California.

A Chamber of Deputies committee voted 5 to 3 today to permit former President Arturo Alessandri to leave the country. Senior Alessandri was succeeded Dec. 24 by President Pedro Aguirre Gerda and the first Popular Front government in South America.

Harry Linn, the State's new assistant secretary of agriculture, was flabbergasted last night when at a dinner given here in his honor he opened an untampered chicken egg and extracted a message of good wishes, written on onion skin paper by his hosts.
Two early scores gave the Williams College hockey team a 4-to-3 victory over Cornell tonight in the final of the Lake Placid Club's annual collegiate tourney.

To evaluate the activity program experiment under way in seventy elementary schools in New York City, the Board of Education at its meeting yesterday voted to ask the State Department of Education to make a survey to determine whether the project had been a success.

The coming naval manoeuvres in the Atlantic will not involve all the fighting units of the fleet. One division of battleships, at least two heavy cruisers, several flotillas of destroyers, one aircraft carrier and the submarines based on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, will remain in the Pacific.

Paying for the last war still costs the French people 15,000,000,000 francs a year and the necessary preparations for the avoidance or winning of another will reach 40,000,000,000 francs during the next year, Finance Minister Paul Reynaud told the Senate today when the budget discussion got under way.

Disappointment with the volume of trade was expressed by department store executives here yesterday. Early indications that clearances this week would lift the total volume for December to within a few points of last December are now unlikely to be borne out, the store men said.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Dec. 22 increased in three out of five trade groups compared with the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Marcel Maas, pianist, and Alfred Dubois, violinist, gave the fourth of their series of five sonata recitals last night at Town Hall. The Belgian artists pooled their talents in interpretations that were warmly received by an audience of good size.

A fee-collecting racket in the City Controller's office that apparently had flourished undetected and unchanged through a half-century of administrative upheavals, reform tempests and progress in general, was revealed yesterday by two investigators from the office of William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Austin Clark of Flushing and Southampton, L. I., gave a tea dance yesterday in the ballroom of the Colony Club for their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Dixon Clark, a debutante of last season.
Miss Jane Remsen Darlington was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton by her parents, the Rev. and Mrs. Gilbert Darlington.

Government-directed economy looked into the rubber situation today and put in force measures to bolster production, domestic consumption and exports. Brazil, once the world's chief rubber supplier, imported this year $2,750,000 worth and used only $750,000 worth of native rubber.

All one-day records for air express shipments in and out of New York City were broken on Dec. 22, when the total for the twenty-four hours ended at midnight was 2,964, an increase of 35 per cent over the corresponding day of 1937, the air express division of the Railway Express Agency reported yesterday.

Four hundred WPA employes associated with the five Federal arts projects staged an orderly demonstration last night in the Times Square district in protest against the proposed dismissal of 1,500 persons on Jan. 13. The demonstration was under the auspices of the Five Arts Council, an affiliate of the Workers Alliance.

Stricter enforcement of the city's parking regulations has resulted in the issuance of 25,527 summonses to violators in the seventeen days from Dec. 10 to Dec. 27, Police Commissioner Valentine reported yesterday.

The official explanation given for the calling up of a large number of Austrian reservists for service in various parts of Germany-is that the men who have served in the former Austrian Army -require further training to attain efficiency equal to German Army standards.

Testimony given during the past two weeks by officials and directors of McKesson Robbins, Inc., that they had no reason to question their president, F. Donald Coster, was contradicted here yesterday on the witness stand at the State Fraud Bureau by Waddill Catchings, expert analyst and corporation executive.

The other day a friend dropped in to show his most prized Christmas present, a new fly rod, and not the old kind,either, he pointed out. It was one of those so-called parabolic rods, and we immediately recalled a recent discussion we heard on these rods.

The Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures intends to file its report next Tuesday. The criticism is expected to center on the present form of administering unemployment relief and particularly its susceptibility to political use.

On behalf of forty-three women's organizations, Mrs. Katherine McNary of the American Hobby Federation presented a scroll to Nathaniel Spear Jr., executive vice president of Spear Co., at a reception held yesterday at 22 West Thirty-fourth Street.

Traffic lights along Fifth Avenue, under the control of Mayor La Guardia for five seconds yesterday morning, blinked five times to herald "The Dawn of a New Day," the avenue's salute in window displays and flags to the New York World's Fair, 1939.

Trading was active to slow in local markets yesterday. The entire beef market showed considerable strength; other classes, excepting a few cuts, were unchanged in price. Early trading in kosher meats. indicated beef and veal to be steady to strong with Tuesday's late decline and lamb about steady with Tuesday's close.
The Interstate Commerce Commission increased today the compensation of Transcontineitial and Western Air, Inc., for carrying the mail over Route 2 between Newark, N. J., and Los Angeles.

A motion to dismiss indictments charging conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case against William W. Kleinman, former Assistant District Attorney of Brooklyn, and Detective Guiseppe F. L. Dardis will be made today by Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd before Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday.

The Baltimore Orioles defeated the league-leading New York Rovers, 4 to 2, in the opener of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League's Boardwalk Cup series tonight and moved into undisputed possession of second place in the league.

Nat Holman, City College basketball coach, has accepted an appointment as national athletic director of Aleph Zadik Aleph, junior B'nai B'rith, according to an announcement from Washington yesterday by Sam Beber, president of the supreme advisory council.

An investing client of Paul Akst, attorney, has purchased from Irving Honigsberg's Haig 'Management Corporation the three-story apartment house on the northwest corner of Hawthorne Street and Rogers Avenue, Brooklyn, for cash above a first mortgage of $30,300.

The marriage of Miss Sylvia Beatrice Klarsfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome R. Klarsfeld of New York, to Dr. Stanford L. Hermann, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour M. Hermann, also of this city took place last night in Temple Israel. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William F. Rosenblum.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William F. Schafer of Mount Vernon, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Beale Shafer, to Edwin Shirley Lapham, son of Mrs. Daniel W. Lapham of Wading River, L. I., and the late Mr. Lapham.
In order to forestall trouble with its minorities, such as that CzechoSlovakia incurred, the Rumanian Government today started negotiations with them.

Being in a light-headed mood, Thornton Wilder has put together a giddy jest entitled "The Merchant of Yonkers," which was acted at the Guild Theatre last evening. It is based, he says, on a Viennese comedy of a century ago, which in turn was based on an English original.

Tonight's events: PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "Alda," Metropolitan Opera; Bernard Gabriel, lecturer, and Louise Arnoux, disease. Sherman Square Studios, 8:15; Christmas carols of all nations, men and boys' choir of the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer and the girls' choir of the St. Vincent Ferrer High School, at the church, 8.
It is learned here that the French Government has refused admission to Syria and Lebanon of five Arab leaders who are due at Port Said Sunday from Seychelle Island.

Senator Van Nuys, co-author with Senator Wagner of an anti-lynching bill which was finally withdrawn at the last session in the face of an unbreakable filibuster, plans to reintroduce the bill in the new Congress, he said today.

Organization of a "Pennsylvania Days" campaign, in which products of that State will be featured in several local and national chain stores, will be undertaken today at a meeting at the Penn Athletic Club, Philadelphia.
Earl Bingham Harris, Wall Street statistician, died yesterday of heart disease in his home at 31 Grace Court, Brooklyn. He was 44 years old.
France prepared virtually to double her military and naval forces in Somaliland today with orders for new reinforcements to face any threats from Italy's East African empire.
Sir Edward Marsh Merewether, who was formerly Governor of the Leeward Islands and had held many other administrative posts, died today at the age of 80.

The marriage of Miss Annabel Elizabeth Darlington, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Goodliffe Darlington of New York, to Albert WVoodberry Ricker, also of this city, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Otto Lee Ricker, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

The Navy awarded a $30,000 contract for wheels today to the Carborundum Company, Niagara Falls, N. Y. Other contracts included: International Nickel Company, New York City, nickel-chromium alloy, $10,575; Sarco Company, Inc., New York City, valves, $7,148;

Miss Helen Bernhard of New York, the two-time defending champion in the girls' national indoor tennis play at Longwood, today headed the advance into the semi-finals by defeating Miss Carolin Cooke of Newton without losing a game.

The most important news story of 1938, according to a survey conducted by the Columbia Broadcasting System among 142 newspaper and news association editors, was the Czech crisis in September, it was announced yesterday.

Expulsion of the remaining 7,000 Jews from Danzig, final unification of all of the Free City's political, professional and labor orgainzations with those in Germany, adoption of Germany's legal system and, last but not least, creation of a small conscript armed force-these are the four chief items in the Danzig Nazis' plans for 1939.

Mayor La Guardia told meeting of youth delegates that there are two ways on getting on in politics. One way is to affiliate with a major party and stay regular at all costs until some day reward comes in the form of high office.
Turpentine firm, 221/2c; sales, 183 barrels; receipts, 190 barrels; shipments, 115 barrels; stock 52,856 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 404; receipts, 443; shipments, 90: stock, 315,968.
Grace Moore sailed for New York on the liner Conte di Savoia today amid a controversy she aroused by giving the Duchess of Windsor a deep curtsy in public.

Marcel Melliand, proprietor and N. editor of the Melliand Textile Reports, Heidelberg, Germany, will arrive today on the Hamburg to study economic conditions. He will make his headquarters with Oscar of A. Geier, patent attorney, at 274 Madison Avenue.

Success in treating asthma with the psychological methods ordinarily used by neurologists in the treatment of nervous diseases was reported yesterday by Dr. Felix Deutsch of Boston at the annual meeting of the Association for Research in.Nervous and Mental Disease at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Edison Gurfein, Inc, diamond importers, in 576 5th Ave; Max Gamsa Co, men's clothing cutters, through David A. Bernstein, floor in 133 5th Ave; Paul Frank, fabric importers, in 460 4th Ave; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc, brokers.

The thermometer was doing a nose-dive yesterday as the city shivered in its new cold wave, but in baseball circles the time was thought propitious to think of Spring, and beyond that of the pleasant days of Summer.

BACHMANN--Lillian C., at her residence, Dec. 27, beloved mother of Charles, Harry, Louis, Robert, Eugene and sister of Ida Pfaffenbach. Funeral service Thursday, Dec. 29, at 8:30 P. M., at Universal Chapel, 597 Lexington Ave. Interment Friday. BAEHR-Hannah (nee Goldsmith), beloved wife of George, dear sister of Samuel and Lena Nekle. Services Midtown Memorial Chapel, 171 West 85th St., Thursday, Dec. 29, at 2 P. M.

Listing of three issues of securities has been authorized by the New York Stock Exchange's committee on stock list. They are $700,000 additional of Allied Stores Corporation 41/2 per cent debentures due in 1951, 86,988 additional shares of Dow Chemical Company common stock and $55,000,000 of Wisconsin Electric Power Company 31/2 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1968.

Realty experts who are studying the prospects for their industry during 1939 seem to agree that home building will be one of the major factors in stimulating general business in the months just ahead.

An offer to resume interest payments in dollars on $14,000,000 of outstanding participating debentures of Siemens Halske A. G., German electrical manufacturer, will be made formally today to holders of the bonds in the United States.

In his annual report, covering the 1937-38 school year, Dr. Charles H. Elliott, State Commissioner of Education, says New Jersey's high schools "are making a distinct contribution to training in the meaning of American democracy and in preparing for a high type of citizenship."
Seabiscuit, outstanding race horse of the year, left tonight by train for Los Angeles. Calif., where he will continue training for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap on March 4.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer reserved decision yesterday on a motion made by Kenneth Sutherland, general clerk of the Brooklyn Supreme Court, to compel the city to pay him the $9,000 annual salary fixed by the justices of the court. The city contends that it has the right to determine whether his position is a necessary one and to fix his pay.

For his service to refugees from Germany, Professor Joseph P. Chamberlain of Columbia University will receive the 1938 Pi Lambda Phi Medal, awarded to "that American who has most courageously achieved recognition as a true exponent of tolerance" at the fortyfourth annual dinner of the fraternity at the Hotel Biltmore tomorrow night, it was announced yesterday.

Six swimmers were selected yesterday by the National A. A. U. to represent the United States in a series of meets in Argentina late next month. Four men and two women will comprise the squad, which is scheduled to sail Saturday on the American Republics liner Brazil. William Leonard, president of the Adirondack Association of the A. A. U., will be in charge of the group.

Despite a gain of 189,000 in the number of factory workers, total employment in the United States declined 0.1 per cent last month, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. Unemployment increased 1.3 per cent during the month, according to the report, which estimated that 9,211,000 persons were jobless in November.

Economic dangers and opportunities for profit in the upward surge of business expected with the new year will be studied by store credit managers attending the twenty-eighth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania Jan. 16 to 20.

Because she brought pie-making to Puerto Rico as the island's first supervisor of domestic science in the public schools, Miss Grace J. Ferguson returned for the anniversary of the founding of the Domestic Science Association today and carved pies for the Silver Jubilee luncheon.

Prague is not a German city, yet it is in effect subject to the Reich. It is the capital of what in reality is a German protectorate. The overwhelming German influence in Czecho-Slovakia is seen in the attitude toward the Jews as well as in the policies of the State.
A dance was given tonight at the Ridgewood Woman's Club by the Misses Elizabeth Williamson and Isabel Gardner. The event was held in a setting of white, silver and blue Christmas decorations.
The retirement of Frederick Winsor, headmaster of Middlesex School since its founding in 1901, was announced today by the trustees.

The Rev. and Mrs. Osmon P. Hoyt of Shrub Oak, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Hoyt, to Norman Manning Vaughn, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Remsen Vaughn of Pleasantville, N. Y.

The marriage of Mrs. Fred Wettach Jr., the former Miss Barbara Guggenheim, to Henry Obre was announced yesterday in a statement made in behalf of Mr. and Mrs. S. R. Guggenheim, parents of the bride, by the law firm of Stanch-field Levy. The marriage took place at Darien, Conn., on Dec. 6 in the presence of members of both amilies, it was announced.

Retired Pilot Herbert E. Whittcomb, formerly a member of Engine Co. 86, residing at 42-79 Murray St., Flushing, Queens, died on Dec. 25. Funeral will take place from 149-47 Barclay Ave.. Flushing, at 10 A. M., Thursday, Dec. 29. Interment at St. Marv's Cemetery.

A considerable portion of the public and press of leading South American capitals has expressed the belief that the eighth Pan-American Conference, which closed at Lima, Peru, yesterday, served an unmistakable warning on Germany, Italy and Japan to keep out of the Western Hemisphere..
Dr. Henri Dreyfus, co-managing director of British Celanese, Ltd., has been named to receive the Perkin Medal of the Society of Dyers and Colourists of Great Britain, it was announced here yesterday.

Many leaders of diverse faiths in the capital's religious and community life joined today in paying tribute to Dr. Abram Simon, rabbi of the Washington Hebrew Congregation, at funeral services for him in the congregation's temple.

Dr. T. Wingate Todd, anatomist, died today after a heart attack at the ageof 53. He was director of the Brush Foundation, which has made extensive measurements of the human body. He also headed the Department of Anatomy at Western Reserve University.

An application by the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company for a rehearing and stay on the order directing the company to reduce its electric rates to general consumers between $520,000 and $530,000, effective Jan. 1, was denied yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The order was issued Dec. 20.

The highest Soviet authorities adopted measures today to tighten up labor discipline by reducing the amount of time lost through unjustifiable absences and unearned vacations and by discouraging a tendency of Soviet workers to leave one job for another elsewhere, where they have heard that better housing or better supplies are available.

Miss Donna Larrabee of Greenwich B. C. and Warren Stephens of Rutgers B. C. won the singles titles in the Eastern junior badminton championships, which were concluded on the courts of the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yesterday.

The injunction against picketing of the Busch Jewelry Company stores expired last midnight and members of two striking C. I. O. unions laid immediate plans for the resumption of picketing this morning.

A funeral service for William Henry Donnell, an auditor of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey for forty years, until his retirement in 1920, will be held tomorrow at 2 P. M. at the Home for Services here.

John W. Scoville, statistician for the Chrysler Motor Corporation, described the 1936-37 business boom as "a C. I. O. bulge" and asserted that the labor organization was the major factor in producing the upward spurt and the subsequent depression of 1938.

Appendicitis is more prevalent in the interior of the United States than along the seacoast, according to Dr. Roland M. Harper of Alabama, reporting to the American Association for the Advancement of Science today.
Dr. Charles Pelton Hutchins, former president of the Big Ten Football Conference, died at his home here today after a week's illness. He was 66 years old.

A scientific experiment shows that the words of Adolf Hitler reduce his listeners to a submissive state bordering closely on hypnotism, Professor M. D. Steer of Purdue University told the American speech teachers' convention here today.

Dollar volume of retail automobile financing by 456 organizations amounted to $67,252,459 in October, a decrease of 38.4 per cent from the corresponding 1937 figure, according to statistics released today by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce.
The will of F. Donald Coster, which bequeathed his entire estate to his widow, was admitted to probate today in brief proceedings before Judge Bradford Boardman in Fairfield Probate Court.

Five men accused of swindling Midwestern banks and business concerns of $1,200,000 were convicted by a Federal court jury today of using the mails to defraud. The five, who are officials of the Continental Credit Corporation of Winchester, Ind., and associated firms, will be sentenced Jan. 5.
Four Japanese columns assigned to mop up Southwestern Shansi Province were reported today to be routing an army under General Yen Hsi-shan, former Governor of the province.

In a frigid setting of near-zero weather, but with clear, wind-swept skies, competition in the skiing events of the Lake Placid Club College Week began today with the women's downhill race at Scotts Cobble.

Harry Richmond Leonard, formerly of this city and New York, died Tuesday in Moose Jaw, Sask., after a long illness. He was 62 years old. After graduation from Amherst College in 1902 Mr. Leonard was employed by the Western Electric Company in New York.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Tonkin, daughter of Mrs. S. E. Tonkin of Kingston and the late Dr. Tonkin, to Robert Carlton Rinehimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Stanley Rinehimer, also of Kingston, was announced today.

Gross assets, $20,762; net, $19,588. To George A.. Robert A. and Arthur J. Carleton children. equally. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $14,653. Arthur J. Carleton, attorney, 1 E. 43d St.

King George's recent visit to Brussels, where he was the guest of King Leopold, has given rise to the rumor of a possible marriage between the Greek monarch's sister, Princess Irene, and the King of the Belgians.
The Salvation Army in New York served more than one hundred thousand individuals this year and carried on religious and social activities in sixty-four centers.

Coming from behind in each of his two matches, Jerry Waters, a junior at Yale, led the way into the fourth round of the fourth annual intercollegiate invitation squash racquets tournament, being played on the courts of the University Club, yesterday.

With Mayor La Guardia preparing his campaign to get additional State reimbursement on city relief costs, the Board of Estimate voted $28,807,550 yesterday for home relief in January, February and March of next year.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 28, unless specified: Antares, San Pedro to Canal Zone. Arctic. San Diego to Canal Zone.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow through Monday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The programs follow:
Announcement has been made by Mrs. Mary V. Dunn of Brooklyn of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Marie Dunn, to Francis P. Kilcoyne, son of Mr. and Mrs. P. H. Kilcoyne of Lawrence, Mass.

The importance of the teaching of religion in colleges as well as in secondary schools was stressed yesterday by 100 members of the National Assocation of Biblical Instructors as they closed their twenty-ninth annual two-day meeting at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday adjourned until next Wednesday argument on an order issued against Martin Stockman of 71-47 Austin Street, Forest Hills, and Sophie and Bertha Friedland of 2,119 Nostrand

As a means of aiding the police in the recovery of stolen articles, the occupants of Nassau County's 80,000 homes will be asked to make inventories of their valuables, place secret marks upon them and take snapshots of costly possessions such as jewelry.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's new rule U-12-F-2, made bublic yesterday, is designed to break the alleged hold that certain investment banking houses have on the financing of utility companies, according to a reliable interpretation obtained today.
Albert Christian Henderson von Tornow, a Shakespearean actor, whose stage name was Albert Henderson, died in his home today at the age of 71.

The Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the four months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $1,054,422 after depreciation, amortization, interest, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other charges.

The student aid program of the National Youth Administration employed in October 312,893 students, Aubrey Williams, Administrator, said today. This was 68,000 more than in October, 1937, the rise being mainly in the number of high school students.

Colonel George Chase Lewis, U. S. A., and Mrs. Lewis, of 1,240 Park Avenue, this city, and Miss Edith Hubbard of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., gave a tea danee yesterday at the Officers Club on Governors Island.

Once again form prevailed in the national junior indoor tennis championships as eleven seeded players yesterday moved into the fourth round of the annual event, which is being played on the eight courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Half-frozen and semi-conscious, William Judge, 28 years old, of 2,016 East Sixty-third Street, Brooklyn, was rescued yesterday morning from the Great Meadow Patch, a desolate marsh in Jamaica Bay, where he was forced to spend an agonizing night when a strong tide defeated his every effort to row ashore.

Miss Edith Adams Greene, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Allen Greene of this city, was married tonight to Francis Cowles Strickland of Washington, D. C., in Blanchard Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott, the pastor.

A Soviet decree today authorized medals for workers, entitling them to ride free on all Soviet street ears for life. The medals for "labor valor" and "labor prominence" carry with them monthly stipends of ten and five rubles, respectively.
Jumping in excellent form, the second team of the Saxon Woods Hunt Club of White Plains, N. Y., yesterday captured the event for junior hunt teams at the first horse show of the Winter season.

The 1,200 change agents employed by the B. M. T., most of whom are women, will hold an election Jan. 7 to choose between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, and the Amalgamated Association of Street,

President Roosevelt was urged by a delegation of the National Peace Conference today to take the initiative looking to collaboration with democratic countries for calling a world conference for economic and military disarmament "before another world crisis develops."
Led by Stan Pearson Jr. of Philadel- phia, the Princeton University squash racquets team defeated Purdue on the University Club courts today, 5-0.

Following a clean sweep over Yeshiva in the first round, chess players of Brooklyn College continued their good work in defense of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy yesterday by defeating the C.C.N.Y. School of Business, 3 1/2--1/2, in the annual Intercollegiate League tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club.

A comprehensive revision of some New Deal laws to make them more workable and less controversial is looked upon by Congressional leaders who have talked to President Roosevelt lately as the chief job for the new Congress, so far as domestic policy is concerned.
Purdue's Boilermakers outscored a taller University of Arkansas team, 57-51, in the fourth annual Sugar Bowl basketball game tonight before an estimated 5,000 fans.

Florence Lawrence, once a star of the silent films, killed herself today by swallowing poison in her home here. She had a 1 P. M. call at M-G-M, but had telephoned the casting office that she was ill and could not appear.

Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan, in Chancery Court, issued this afternoon an injunction restraining the use of stockholders' proxies in the election of a new board of directors for Burco, Inc., of 15 Exchange Place, this city, until all investors in the company could be informed of charges made against its president and vice president and a director.

Announcement has been made to friends here of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Burton Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwinel B. Thompson of Pleasantville, N. Y., to Merritt Leland Ryder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leland C. Ryder of Carmel, N. Y.

Princess Maria of Savoia, the fifth and youngest child of King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Elene., will be married to Prince Louis of Bourbon-Parme, fifteenth child of the late Duke Robert of Bourbon-Parme, on Jan. 15.

Although the response of the British public to appeals on behalf of refugees from Spain, Czecho-Slovakia and other countries has been hearty and generous, its efforts to relieve the misery among victims of German persecution dwarf even these activities.
Pitt's much heralded fast-break play clicked frequently in the closing minutes tonight to provide the Panthers with a 50-39 victory over Blair Gullion's Cornell basketball team.

Samuel B. Russell of Lewistown, banker, horseman and fair manager, died in Hahnemann Hospital here today after an operation for a kidney ailment. Mr. Russell succeeded his late father as president of the Russell National Bank at Lewis-town.

Joseph Visotski, 32-year-old former Throop Borough police chief, was held by detectives today on a charge of arson in connection with a Christmas Day fire which damaged his home and apparently burned to death Michael Mazak, 32, a church organist.

Freedom in scientific pursuit of truth is one of the fundamental cornerstones of democracy and of civilization as a whole, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, told the American Association for the Advancement of Science tonight In an address on "Science and Freedom."

Snow and colder weather before the end of the week were forecast last night by the Weather Bureau. Following a day in which the temperature stayed below freezing, slowly rising temperatures were promised for today.
Mr. and Mrs. James Herold Wallace of South Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Wallace, to Edwin Allen Kirch 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Harrison Kirch of Maplewood.
RIDE A CROOKED MILE. from a story and screen play by Ferdinand Reyher and John C. Moffitt directed by Alfred E. Green; produced by Jeff Lazarus for Paramount. At the Criterion.

The number of WPA workers in this city declined '1,000 between Nov. 21 and Dec. 23 as a result of the WPA's decision to stop filling vacancies from the home-relief rolls, according to figures made public yesterday by Lieut.

Annexing five of the seven events, Main Division won the semi-annual intercenter swimming meet of the City College evening sessions at the City College pool last night. A total of 36 points gave Main a substantial edge over Commerce, which had 20, and Brooklyn, which had only 5.

Charles F. Darlington, retired lawyer and prominent Presbyterian layman, died last night at his city residence, 944 Fifth Avenue. He was born in Brooklyn seventy-eight years ago, a son of Thomas and Hannah Goodliffe Darlington.

One out of every five tons of freight hauled by American railroads in 1937 represented shipments of raw materials to plants of the steel industry or shipments of finished products from steel mills, says Steel Facts.
The Wear Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 27: COLONELS Browning, W. S., F.A., orders to Walter Reed General Hospital for observation and treatment revoked.
Organization of a social-civic curriculum for boys and girls on the senior high school level was urged here today by Dr. Lloyd N. Morrisett, Assistant Superintendent of Schools in Yonkers.

James J. Sullivan, who for almost forty years had been in charge of the Queens bureau of the Bureau of Weights and Measures, died yesterday in his home, 41-27 Case Street, Elmhurst. He was 67 years old.
THE CHARAKA CLUB. (Richard C. Smith, $5.) The ninth volume of the proceedings of the club. DR. NORTON'S WIFE, by Mildred Walker. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50. A novel set in a modern medical school.
Incorporation papers for the Bondholders Protective Corporation of Salaah Temple, Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine, have been filed today in the Essex County Clerk's office.

An undertaken may be the life-giver needed by the Rev. Jeremiah Toomey, Professor of Morals at Dunwoodie Seminary, Yonkers, who is gravely ill of streptococcus viridans in St. Elizabeth's Hospital, 869 Fort Washington Avenue.

Paced by Captain Al Lenowicz, who tallied 14 points, St. Francis College defeated a team of alumni stars, 45-35, on the home court last night. It was the seventh straight victory for the Terriers, who have lost only one game this season.

A Federal grand jury investigating charges of mail fraud against William P. Buckner and William J. Gillespie, young brokers, in the sale of Philippine Railway bonds, heard the testimony yesterday of Noel Carter, an actress, who is supposed to have been part of an entertainment program the defendants staged for legislators in Washington on Aug. 21, 1937.
The election of Clarence L. Law of Pelham as a director of the Westchester Lighting Company and the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company was announced here today.

Dr. Justus Sinexon, a nose and throat specialist who had practiced medicine in this city more than a half century, died at the home of his son, Justus Sinexon Jr., in Highland Park yesterday after an illness of two weeks.

Holders of voting trust certificates of the Middle States Petroleum Corporation authorized yesterday an amendment to the company's certificate of incorporation which would permit the payment of dividends on the Class A and Class B stocks.

21st St. 329-333 E: 329 E. 21st St., Inc to Wintown Realty Co, 270 Bway; mtg $7.000 ($9.50). 98th St, 31 W; 31 W. 98th St. Corp. to Joseph Tetz, 3,396 12th Ave., Brooklyn; mtg $9.000 and purchase money mtg S7,000 ($9.50).

Burly Ki Aldrich, Texas Christian's pepperpot All-America center, was treated tonight for a serious eye ailment that may keep him out of the Sugar Bowl game against Carnegie Tech at New Orleans Monday.

Two vandals, who stripped the community Christmas tree in the village park here of its vari-colored light bulbs last night, were so emboldened that they risked similar depredations on the tree in front of Police Headquarters and in homes in the village, including St. Joseph's Catholic Church rectory.
Mr. and Mrs. Odell Hauser of Merwood, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris De Windt Hauser, to Webster Fairbanks Williams Jr. of Bridgeport, Conn.

Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, has settled the government's claim against him for back income taxes. This became known yesterday when Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District, filed in the Federal court here notice of satisfaction of a lien for $1,384,222, representing taxes, interest and penalties on Mr. Mitchell's 1929 income. The lien was satisfied on Tuesday.

Certificates of deposit representing the entire funded debt of the Seiberling Rubber Company, out-standing in the amount of $2,350,000 of 6 per cent debentures, were bid in at auction yesterday by W. A. M. Vaughan, representing the company, for $752,000, or 32 per cent of the face value of the debentures.

Mr. and Mrs. Morris E. Kinnan gave a tea dance yesterday at their home, 510 Park Avenue, to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Augusta Kinnan. The debutante and her mother were assisted in receiving by Miss Mary Beecher Budd of this city and Miss Betty Jane Nevins of Springfield, Mass.

The annual meeting of sharenolaers of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was adjourned yesterday until March 28 because of lack of a quorum. Only 109,461 voting capital shares out of the 175.001 shares necessary to
Oh, how were we to know that these Were things that made our Christmases A certain house by certain hills; Soft lights that poured through window-sills;
Six associate member firms of the N ew York Curb Exchange yesterday took advantage of the new constitution to continue their membership by replacing partners who had retired.

A fifty-six-family apartment house in the West Bronx changed hands yesterday when Louis Sachs bought for investment the six-story elevator building at 120 West 183d Street, southwest corner of Loring Place. The house was erected two and one-half years ago and contains apartments ranging from two to four and one-half rooms.

Alterations complying with the Multiple Dwelling Law will be made in the five-story dwelling at 29 West Eighty-second Street. The house is on a lot 22.6 by 102 feet and has been leased by the Wood, Dolson Company, as broker, for the Dry Dock Savings Institution, as owner.

George P. Kennedy, president of the Lafayette National Bank of Brooklyn, will serve as general chairman of the 1939 maintenance fund campaign of the Brooklyn Council, Boy Scouts of America, it was announced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway, president of the council.

The speed of inter-continent travel by air has increased the danger of introduction of "dread diseases" into the United States, Dr. John A. Kolmer, Professor of Medicine at Temple University, said today at the Association of Medical Students' convention.

There came to the ears. of Lewis Rosenquest not long ago something that at the moment seemed incredible. It was bruited about in the manufacturing department of Harper Brothers, where he has been employed a long time, that he was about to be guest of honor at a dinner celebrating his fiftieth anniversary with the firm.

Under the influence of year-end caution in steel buying and affected by the holiday shutdown of all plants, ingot production this week will not exceed 40 per cent of the industry's capacity, Iron Age says this week, but adds that a rebound to about 50 per cent is indicated for next week, when there will be no holiday shutdown.

It is an unhappy paradox that at the period of the Christmas holidays, when good cheer should be the universal watchword, sadness and loss are likely to reach their height in the field of traffic accidents.

At the request of minority bondholders of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, in process of reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick held up today sale of 44,201 acres of the company's land to the State pending an investigation.
The National Safety Council predicted tonight that traffic deaths in the United States this year would total 31,500 if the trend of the first eleven months continued until Jan. 1.

Miss Ruth Brisco, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norris A. Brisco of this city, was married to David Hamlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Hamlin, tonight in Calvary Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Walter O. Kinsolving.
Lowell R. Burch of New York City, president of the New York Air Brake Company, has bought "a substantial interest" in the Glens Falls Portland Cement Company, it was announced today.

Miss Ann Bywater Cluett, daughter of Representative and Mrs. E. Harold Cluett of this city, was married to the Rev. Nelson M. Burroughs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Burroughs, here at noon today in St. John's Episcopal Church, of which the bridegroom is rector.

New orders booked by the structural steel industry during November totaled 150,988 tons, the largest figure for any month since July, 1937, the American Institute of Steel Construction reported yesterday.
To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 2: LIEUTENANTS-Stephen J. O'Neill, from 68th Precinct to Mounted Squadron 1, assignment changed from desk duty to mounted duty. Assignment to dask dutv discontinued.

A thousand orphans gathered yesterday afternoon at the New Livingston, 301 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, for David F. Soden's eighth annual Christmas party. Mr. Soden is the New York State District Tax Supervisor for Brooklyn and Long Island.
Sister Mary Philip, superintendent of the infirmary at Georgian Court College here, died today in the Paul Kimball Hospital, Lakewood, of pneumonia. She was 62 years old.
Manager Joe McCarthy's nicest Christmas present, he said today, was a silver plaque presented to him by the three-time baseball world champion New York Yankee players.
The Commercial Club of Rhame, N. D., asked Senator Frazier today to arrange for Federal purchase of the town if the government proceeds with its plans to buy most of the surrounding farm land.

Michael Romaine of Brooklyn and Catherine Kneitsek of Astoria became the principals today in a court action to determine whether Northern Virginia is to become the East's "Gretna Green." They volunteered to test Arlington County's new policy of requiring a three-day waiting period between issuance of a marriage license nd the ceremony.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank Erbin Wattles of Buffalo have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Wattles, to Robert Francis Pulleyn of this city.
Robert C. Read and Walter J. Ash have been elected directors of the Consolidated Decalcomania Corporation. Mr. Read was also elected executive vice president and Mr. Ash a vice president.
The adjutant general released the following orders today: Hickok, 2d Lt. Donald S., 107th Infantry, commissioned for assignment to Company G.

A field goal in the last five seconds by Edwin Pollack, former Brooklyn College captain, gave the Union Temple basketball team a 30-to-28 decision over the Columbus Council K. of C. on the winner's court last night.

A thousand copies of an "inventory" of WPA accomplishments, compiled under the direction of Harry L. Hopkins, are being sent through the mails from the local offices of the WPA on instructions from Washington, it became known yesterday.

The work on ,the exterior of the World's Fair perisphere and trylon is fast approaching completion. A third of the scaffolding on the perisphere had been removed yesterday and half of that on the trylon.

The New York State Natural Gas Corporation has challenged the jurisdiction of the Federal Power Commission to act in the complaint filed by the New York State Public Service Commission that the rates charged for gas it sells to the Central New York Power Corporation were unreasonable, the FPC announced today.

A girl stowaway, believed to be Rebecca Weitzenfeld, 13 years old, of 277 Walnut Street, Trenton, is being returned from Bermuda on the Queen of Bermuda, scheduled to dock at 9 o'clock this morning at the foot of West Fifty-seventh Street. She will be met by a "reception committee" consisting of New York and Trenton detectives, a Mercer County probation officer and members of the Weitzenfeld family.

Senator Arthur Capper of Kansas today predicted the election of a Republican President in 1940 of a type representing "sane, forward-looking policies" and against "wasteful Federal expenditures." He had a talk with Senator McNary, Republican Senate leader, and then listed five possible candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Eamon de Valera, Prime Minister of Ireland, now officially called Eire, has accepted President Roosevelt's invitation to be an overnight guest at the White House next May 7.

The State ing. Conference of Mayors called today for greater State aid for home relief, or, as alternatives, new State taxes to raise relief funds, or an authorization for municipalities to impose new taxes to finance relief.

Archie San Romani, who set a native American record of 8:27.4 in a hair's-breadth triumph over Don Lash in the Conklin 3-000-meter run in the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, games last January, yesterday accepted an invitation to compete again in this event,

At a meeting of the board of directors of the New York Telephone Company yesterday, Frank P. Lawrence was elected vice president and general manager for the Manhattan area of the company to succeed Marshall B. Downing, who will retire on Jan. 1 after more than thirty-nine years of telephone service.

Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, former superintendent of the New Jersey State police, has resigned as general manager and vice president of the Middlesex Transportation Company here, it was disclosed today. He has been succeeded by Lincoln Jones Jr.,

Mortimer L. Shuford, 54 years old, an attorney, died in Sydenham Hospital at 11:40 A. M. yesterday, an hour after he had shot himself in the bathroom of his apartment at 370 Riverside Drive with a .22-caliber rifle.
