A bitter attack on the Vitican is made today in the Angriff, the organ of Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, presumably as a tardy answer to Pope Pius's recent criticism of the totalitarian doctrine.

Mrs. Arthur A. Fowler gave a luncheon yesterday at Hampshire House. Among the guests were Countess Ferdinand ColloredoMannsfeld, Mrs. William C. Breed, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Marquls San Felice di Monteforte, Angus C. Malcolm of the British Embassy, James Beck and Tullio Carminati.

Vicente Cortes Herrera, general manager of the Mexican Petroleum Administration, in a radio message tonight appealed to workers in the oil industry to cooperate fully toward successful exploitation of the oil resources of this country in order to show "Mexicans' capacity."

With the exhibition opening today, the Municipal Art Galleries reach the twoscore mark in the number of shows put on since the inception of the project. Since the opening of the galleries some 1,700 artists have shown work without jury and without expense to the exhibitors.

Miss Martha Louise Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Darwin Powers of Chicago, was married to George Edward Larsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Larsen of New Rochelle, N. Y., last night in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Howard C. Hopson, who for fifteen years has been a dominant figure in the affairs of the Associated Gas and Electric Company system, has decided to withdraw the service organizations controlled by him from any future business dealings with the Associated system, it was announced yesterday by J. I. Mange, president of Associated Gas and Electric.

If, in his letter to THE TIMES, the Rev. John Cole McKim had condemned Secretary Ickes for his needless attack upon the good taste and discretion, and by inference upon the patriotism, of two such Americans as Henry Ford and Colonel Charles Lindbergh,
The Finance Ministry "announced today that Japan had a favorable trade balance this year for the first time since 1932. Exports exceeded imports by 13,000,000 yen, the announcement said.

James Starr, secretary-treasurer of the United Textile Workers of America, announced today that charges of anti-union activity, dual unionism and violation of contract between the Textile Workers Organizing Committee and the U. T. W. had been filed with him against Frances Gorman, by George Baldanzi, vice president of the U. T. W., and Frank Banti, vice president of the Dyers Federation.

Nearly 1,500 educators, transportation officials and others attended funeral services for Dr. Edgar Starr Barney at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, yesterday. Dr. Barney, principal of the Hebrew Technical Institute for more than fifty years, died Sunday night from the effects of a stroke suffered ten days earlier. He was 77 years old.

Amsterdam Ave, 827, 25.3x75; Eugene Van Den Bossche to Mayybelle Primus, 675 Walton Ave; p m mtg, due Jan. 1, 1942, 6 per cent: $3,400. Catherine St. 4-6. 34.4x60.11, to Chatham Sq, 15-16, 42.10x32; 63 Eighth Ave. Inc, to Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co; p m mtg, due Dec. 21, 1943, 4 per cent; S12.500.

A Massachusetts legislative commission studying savings bank life insurance started today for Washington to interview Associate Justice Louis D. Brandeis of the United States Supreme Court. Justice Brandeis was the founder of the savings bank life insurance system in Massachusetts.
George Hawke, Sunday editor and former city editor of The Los Angeles Times, who had been a member of the editorial staff for seventeen years, died today.

The Vaucluse gold mine, which Henry Ford once bought for $10,000 to get possession of its antiquated machinery for his Dearborn museum, was sold at public auction here today for $800. The 200-acre property near Wilderness, Orange County, put on the block by the V. M. Corporation which worked the old mine for three years, was bought by Alex Gayle, real estate dealer, who said he planned no mining operations.

Miss Betsy Grant Canfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Withington Canfield, was married to Philip Adams Rorty Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rorty of Goshen, here tonight at the home of her parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold L. Andress.

Jonn J. Cornwell, general counsel of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, said today in an interview that "an act which would make legal an agreement between railroad managements and two-thirds of their bondolders is of more immediate importance to the railroads than results which may follow the report of President Roosevelt's railroad committee."

In an effort to obtain united' action by members of the Hotel Association of .New York City on a proposed union agreement, officers of the association will meet today with representatives of the hotel operators who walked out of a meeting of the association on Tuesday night

The ancient world, which like ours had its "isms," "deals" and "corporate group States," perished because it developed a "gross maldistribution of wealth" which led to stagnation of social and individual enterprise and ultimately to decay,

Since pedestrians are involved in more than two-thirds of all high-way fatalities their aid is being enlisted by organized motordom for the 1939 campaign to reduce the toll of automobile accidents, William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York, said yesterday.

Intercollegiate football, the nation's gridiron coaches decided today, is humming along smoothly and doesn't need any general overhauling. A meeting of the National Football Coaches' Association's rules committee failed to produce a single recommendation for a major change in the sport's regulations.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Cameron Spear of Rahway, N. J., formerly of Metuchen, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Spear, to Victor M. Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Jones, also of Rahway.

The Greater New York Committee for the National Infantile Paralysis Foundation will seek to raise $250,000 in the campaign that begins Jan. 1 and ends on President Roosevelt's fifty-seventh birthday, Jan. 30, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon of the medical advisory committee of the campaign in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Local importers opposing the government's order requiring "made-in-Germany" marking on merchandise completed in Czech territory before the German occupation, but shipped here after that event, moved a step nearer a test case of the ruling yesterday.

THE unveiling of Donald Budge as a professional will take place at the Garden Tuesday night. For weeks there have been pieces in the papers about this young man, pieces couched in complimentary terms that have been written for no other tennis player leaving the amateur fold.

Schenley Distillers Corporation has formed a new sales territory in New England, taking in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut, J. L. Leban, general sales executive, announced yesterday. Hiram Srenco.

Broadway theatrical attractions enjoyed yesterday afternoon the best matinee business since 1929, ten shows playing to standees and the others receiving patronage far above their normal. A reported total of 681 persons paid for standing room to see the shows.

An authoritative Soviet journal declared today that talk of German ambitions concerning the Russian Ukraine was merely a smokescreen to hide the totalitarian powers' real designs elsewhere, notably in French Tunisia.

Robert Taylor will be starred with Hedy Lamarr in "Lady of the Tropics," Metro announced today. The picture will start early in February under the direction of Josef von Sternberg. It will be followed on Taylor's schedule with "Hands Across the Border" and then "Northwest Passage," which was started last Summer, but abandoned because of the late season. Anthony Allen replaced Tom Neal in "Fast and Loose."

The Viennese Roof of the St. Regis was the setting last night for a supper dance given by Mrs. Walter Harvey Close of 131 East Sixtysixth Street and London to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Suzanne Close.

Mr. and Mrs. A. Alexander Thomas of 26 East Ninety-first Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Elizabeth Thomas, to Boies E. Whitcomb, son of Mrs. Eugene A. Whitcomb of Buffalo and the late Mr. Whitcomb.

If Dr. Horatio M. Pollock of the Nev York State Department of Menta Hygiene is right, our bill for menta disease amounted in 1937 to nearly a billion dollars, which includes both loss of earnings and the cost of institutiona land home care.

Roswell Magill, Professor of Law at Columbia University and former Under-Secretary of the United States Treasury, and Dr. Carl Shoup, Professor of Economics at Columbia, arrived here from Miami this morning at the invitation of the Cuban Government to survey the tax system with the view to recommending reforms.

Dartmouth scored its second victory of the season by routing the Brown sextet, 9 to 2, before 1,200 persons at the Playland Casino ice rink tonight. Dan Sullivan, Fred Maloon and Dave Walsh each scored twice for the Indians, who opened a three-night stand here with this triumph.

Trustees appointed by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to administer the $10,000,000 Series Q certificated guaranteed mortgageissue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, now in liquidation, announced yesterday that they were making an income distribution on the reduced principal amount of certificates to holders of record of Dec. 30.

Arthur A. Hughart, banker, educator and civic leader, died here yesterday at the age of 74. Mr. Hughart served as superintendent of Porter County and Valparaiso schools and also of Coffeyville, Kan., schools.

The Hon. and Mrs. E. Langton Iliffe of London, who have been at the Waldorf-Astoria, are leaving today for Palm Beach. Mrs. Paul Fitz Simons of Newport is at the Madison. Mrs. George Mesta has returned to 44 East Seventy-fourth Street from Boston, where she had been visiting her sister, Mrs. George Tyson.

Prospects for air transport in 1939 look "substantially brighter than 1938," W. A. Patterson of United Air Lines declared yesterday in a year-end statement. The two world's fairs, he believes, will help business.
Professor and Mrs. William Myers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Myers, to John Kahler MacNab of Bismarck, N. D., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. MacNab.

Mr. and Mrs. O. Edward Payne of the Oak Lane colony here, announced today the engagement of their elder-daughter, Miss Ruth Bowne Payne, to Leo W. Hesselman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hesselman of Garden City.

A delegation of officials from the Federation of Arts Unions, the organization of crafts represented on the WPA arts projects, left for Washington by train at 4:30 P. M. yesterday to protest the impending reduction in personnel on the relief projects. Edward Everett Hale 3d.

It will be a long time before Lewis (Pick) Dehner's performance on the Garden floor on Tuesday night is forgotten. All yesterday, wherever basketball fans met, the talk centered about the Illinois ace's feat in amassing 25 points against Manhattan, a new college record at the Eighth Avenue arena.

Sears, Roebuck Co. and Montgomery Ward Co. bid today for sales gains in the first two months of 1939 through midwinter "flier" catalogues featuring price reductions of 5 to 20 per cent on special items. In a few extreme cases of fashion merchandise, cuts ran as high as 40 per cent.

The marriage of Miss Miriam Murray Bruce, daughter of Mrs. Murray Bruce of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Bruce, to Cornelius George Martin, son of Mrs. George Martin of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Martin, took place yesterday afternoon in the Bay Ridge Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Albert E. Beebe and the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Poten.
Baron Takashi Msuda died today at the age of 91 His death removes the last living link between present-day and medieval Japan, to which Townsend Harris came as the first American envoy.

Federal grants of between $2,000,000 and $6,000,000 for rural library development will be sought by the American Library Association, Forrest B. Spaulding of Des Moines said at the mid-Winter meeting of the American Library Association today.
Secretary Ickes in his press conference today discussed power, public works and parks, avoiding the controversy on miners' safety and questions on Chicago politics.

A plea for a "free society" with the maximum of latitude for the thinking individual but with forcible restraint of those who are demonstrably anti-social, was made today before the American Association of Physics Teachers by Professor P. W. Bridgman of Harvard.
A demand for good store locations, in Manhattan was indicated yesterday by reports of business renting.

The Consumers Power Company will redeem on May 1, 1939, at 102 3/4. at the City Bank Famers Trust Company all of its first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds due in 1944. Holders may surrender these bonds, however, for payment at any time on or after Dec. 30, 1938, and receive full payment to the redemption date.
The Yale Uniiversity squash racquets team lost only one match, as it defeated Purdue, 4 to 1, on the courts of the Yale Club last night.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The seventh and eighth recommendations of the "Final Report of the Advisory Council on Social Security," published in the newspapers of Dec. 19, are incalculably dangerous. Boiled down, these recommendations are:
Miss Roxane Page Ruhl and Charles Herbert Simmons Jr., both of this city, whose engagement was announced on Thanksgiving Day, were married yesterday afternoon in the Brick Presbyterian Church.
Wheat futures were on the upgrade again today and went into new ground since the war scare last September.

Works Progress Administration employment decreased by 55,996 persons in the week ending Dec. 17, falling to 3,083,249, Colonel F. C. Harrington, administrator, stated today. In numbers, the decrease of 11,372 was the greatest in Pennsylvania, where there are 275,415 persons on the WPA rolls.

A man who made a door-to-door canvas of the neighborhood, craftily getting information on the whereabouts of occupants and whether they had dogs, is believed to be responsible for the theft of $500 in jewelry yesterday from the home of General James G. Harbord, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America.

Pursuant to foreclosure proceedings brought by the New York Trust Company against the Benenson Building Corporation, the twenty-six-story Benenson Building, known as 165 Broadway, with the adjoining five-story building at 99 Liberty Street, will be sold at auction at 18 Vesey Street today by James R. Murphy, auctioneer.

Mrs. Sarah N. Berlin, active in Jewish charitable affairs in Brooklyn and Manhattan for many years, died early yesterday at her home, 1,188 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, after an illness of two weeks. She was 82 years old.

The Rev. Wendell Phillips, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church of New Rochelle, has accepted a call to the pulpit of Christ's Church here to succeed the late Rev. R. Townsend Henshaw, who died last August. Formal announcement of the change will be made in both churches next Sunday.

The Washington Terminal Company, operator of the Union Station, through which all passenger trains serve Washington, filed today a bill in equity in the Federal District Court to test a demand by some railroad brotherhoods that special crews be put on trains to back empty passenger cars from the passenger station to a storage yard.

Under the caption "Roosevelt's Fantastic Armament Plans," the Voelkischer Beobachter this morning states that it would not be surprising if President Roosevelt should attempt to justify his plans by alleging that they are necessary to protect the United States and Canada from threats by the totalitarian States.

The Beatrice Creamery Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Nov. 30 a consolidated net profit of $397,214 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

The entry of John Borican of the Shore A. C., Elberon, N. J., was announced yesterday for the Columbus 500, one of the feature events of the Columbus Council, K. of C., track meet at the 245th Coast Artillery Armory, Brooklyn, on Jan. 7. Borican,
The outstanding development of last year was the improvement in business sentiment, in the opinion of the First National Bank of Boston, as expressed in its current monthly letter.

Christmas lingered very definitely in the antelope house at the Central Park Zoo yesterday. She is expected to make her home there for some time to come. Christmas, in this case, is a baby llama that arrived at 2:30 A. M. on Dec. 25.
A banking group composed of Lehman Brothers, Phelps, Fenn Co. and Watling, Lerchen Hayes, received yesterday the award of a new issue of $600,000 city of New Haven, Conn., public improvement bonds,

Stanley Pearson Jr. of Princeton and Malcolm Muir of Yale, seeded No. 1 and 2, respectively, battled their way into the final of the fourth annual intercollegiate squash racquets tournament as two rounds were concluded on the courts of the University Club yesterday.

At the personal invitation of President Roosevelt, a committee of ten prominent Americans has been formed to raise an estimated $500,000 necessary to process and ship 600,000 barrels of flour from the United States to feed starving civilians on both sides in Spain, starting next month.

Trading was mostly active to fair in local markets yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to higher and some steer cuts higher. Other classes were mostly steady to strong. Thursday being an off kosher day, trading in those meats was limited largely to lamb at steady prices. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
A jury tonight denied Mrs. Osa Johnson the $706,539 damages she sought for the death of her husband, Martin Johnson, explorer, and her own injuries in an airplane crash near here Jan. 12, 1937.
Christmas week theatrical performances, which on Wednesday afternoon did the best business since 1929, continued yesterday to achieve record grosses at the box office.

The Rev. Jeremiah Toomey, a Roman Catholic priest of Yonkers, N. Y., never heard of James R. Clegg, an undertaker who lives in ,Toledo, but he received yesterday a pint of Mr. Clegg's blood, a gift that may mean life for the priest.

The volume of engineering construction awards this week, with $59,510,000, is 32 per cent higher than in the same week of last year, when $44,989,000 was reported, according to The Engineering NewsRecord.

A professional football team in every baseball park in the country! That's the ultimate goal of a program mapped today by Joe F. Carr, veteran founder and president of the National Football League and promotional director of the minor baseball leagues.
At the Plainfield Country Club here tonight Mrs. William Wallace Coriell gave a supper dance to introduce her daughter, Miss Betty Coriell.
More than 400 persons attended a testimonial dinner last night at the Hotel Biltmore for Sheriff George A. Casey of Westchester County, re-elected to office last month for three years.

Five of America's ranking Davis Cup hopefuls advanced through the opening round of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today. Gene Mako, third ranking United States star, had some trouble winning. Mako eliminated Burtz Boulware, former Georgia Tech ace, 6-2, 10-8, after having a 5-1 lead and game point in the second set.

Argentinita and her Spanish foursome gave a new program in their holiday season at the Fifty-first Street Theatre last night, and made it quite the best of the series thus far. If some of the favorites which previously seemed indispensable were missing, others were added to replace them, until by now the list of indispensables has become too to long to be included in any one evening's activities.

While maintaining its support of a peace program, the American Student Union took another step away from its former pacifist position yesterday by adopting a peace resolution calling for study of the defense needs of the United States and by modifying its attitude toward the Reserve Officers Training Corps.
Edward Doerken of Ridgewood died today at the Barnert Memorial Hospital here while undergoing a blood transfusion preparatory to an operation. His age was 71.
The marriage of Miss Mary Churchill Mellon, daughter of Edward Purcell Mellon of 1,030 Fifth Avenue and Villa Maria, Southampton, L. I., and the late Mrs. Mellon, to Henry Alexander Wise Jr.,

The Spanish Government destroyer Jose Luis Diez, which for several weeks had been undergoing repairs at Gibraltar, attempted early this morning to run the gantlet of several Insurgent warships lying in wait outside the harbor and failed.

More than 2,000 teachers and scholars from colleges and univercities throughout the nation, attending the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the Modern Language Association of America in its second day's sessions at Columbia University, unanimously passed a resolution yesterday expressing opposition to racial, religious and political discrimination.

Mr. Harry Scherman's article in The Saturday Evening Post was obviously written before Chairman Eccles's letter to Senator Byrd was published, yet the article constitutes a striking answer to Mr. Eccles's argument that Federal deficits bring prosperity.
Federal Judge William Clark awarded today a judgment of $313,730 to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation against the township of South Hackensack, formerly the township of Lodi.

Deploring what it termed the conscription and distortion of anthropology "in many countries" to "serve the cause of an unscientific racialism," the American Anthropological Association formally attacked the Aryan theories of racialism yesterday, declaring that the terms Aryan and Semitic have "no racial significance whatsoever," but "simply denote linguistic families."

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after expenses and charges of $4,418,637, compared with a net of $9,905,143 in the twelve months to Nov. 30, 1937.
Delibes's "Lakme" will receive its first performance of the season tonight at 8:30 o'clock at the Metropolitan Opera House, with a castheaded by Lily Pons, Frederick Jagel and Ezio Pinza.

Miss Gertrude E. Smiles, principal of School 3, died yesterday in Pittston, Pa., where she had been visiting her mother. Her age was 40. She had been a member of the Ridgefield school system for seventeen years.
The annual deer and bear hunt in Pisgah Forest Game Preserve, North Carolina, certainly resulted in one of the highest kill ratios we've encountered in some time.
Al Simmons, one of the greatest hitters in the history of baseball, was sold to the Bees today for a sum believed to be about $3,000-which wouldn't fetch a fair minor leaguer.

Mrs. Sophie Huber Farrell, widow of Tony Farrell, who toured the vaudeville circuits more than a half century ago as a member of the Leland Sisters, a song-and-dance team, and more recently operated a hotel for theatrical figures at St. James, L. I., died yesterday at her home here. She was 78 years old.

An annual Christmas-New Year's party was given last night at the clubhouse of the American Women's Association, 353 West Fiftyseventh Street, where 200 elderly persons were the guests. The party was under the auspices of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

Mrs. Alma Clayburgh gave a dinner last night at Sherry's, followed by a musical in her apartment at 300 Park Avenue, for her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. James Hooper Grew, who are visiting her from Andover, Mass., and for Mrs. Gertrude Atherton, novelist.

Gold in the amount of $3,000,000 was engaged in England for shipment here yesterday as the pound sterling again weakened in the foreign exchange market. Dealings in the exchanges were somewhat more active than earlier in the week as the influence of the holidays diminished.

Active buying of print cloths developed yesterday, after buyers had failed in efforts to bid prices down from the levels established in a flurry of buying earlier in the month. While the day's volume, estimated at about 7,000,000 yards, was not large for a buying spurt, the activity was considered significant because it marked an end of slow trading, which had been caused by fear of inventory weakness.

Since his arrival in Australia for the Science Congress to be held in January at Canberra, H. G. Wells, noted British author, has repeatedly urged close relations between Australia and the United States for Australia's own protection.
The general level of wholesale prices for the week ended Dec. 24 again declined to a new low for the period since 1934, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
Westchester County budgets for 1939 totaling $15,868,033 were adopted late today by the Board of Supervisors by a vote of 26 to 11, the Democrats voting in opposition.

Preliminary plans for development of a large part of the 441acre Iselin family properties, lying partly in Eastchester and partly in New Rochelle, Westchester County, were announced yesterday by Winfred Watson, vice president of the realty firm of William A. White Sons.

With a view to working out a new Franco-Syrian agreement, there is now talk of sending a French mission to Syria, reportedly at the instigation of Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Warren Newkirk of this community of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Newkirk, to Franklin Elrod McGuffin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McGuffin of Worcester, Mass.

Unless on final consideration the President should eliminate the name of Frank Murphy from his new Cabinet slate as he eliminated that of Solicitor-General Robert H. Jackson, one of the most earnest, interesting and able men in public life will function in the Capital for the first time in a long and turbulent political career.

Repeating the procedure followed when Sudeten areas of Czecho-Slovakia were declared part of Germany for customs purposes, the Treasury Department late yesterday afternoon notified collectors of customs that goods from parts of Czecho-Slovakia taken over by Hungary and Poland would be regarded as products of those two countries starting today.

In tje face of warnings of disaster to Philadelphia business, the City Council today voted a 8 per cent retail sales tax for next year. Mayor Wilson immediately stated that he would veto the ordinance, but the margin, 15 to 5, by which it was adopted, indicated that the tax proponents would have no difficulty in passing it over a veto.
Dr.Lloyd Logan, head of the Chemical Engineering Department of the College of Applied Science, Syracuse University, died at his home here this morning after a long illness. He was 47 years old.

An asserted demand that. seven union stagehands receive' eight hours' pay for four hours' work on a WPA project led to cancellation last night of a scheduled piano con- t certo performance at the Federal a Music Theatre, 254 West Fiftyfourth Street.

Accident mortality in the United States decreased this year, despite a hurricane, floods, tornadoes and the most serious railroad accident in recent years, according to a report yesterday by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

The marriage of Miss Indra Elizabeth Maher, daughter of Mrs. Augustine F. Maher of this city and the late Mr. Maher, to Philip Francis Belcher of Hartford took place today in the rectory of St. Brendan's Church.

Louis Le Bouvier, manager of a British bank here, who had been missing since Monday, returned today after having been held for three days and nights by Arab kidnappers with whom he played checkers to while away the time and who clashed in a furious argument over which one was to have his dress coat and shoes "for keeps."

Thorne Smith's fantasy, "Topper Takes a Trip," which Hal Roach brought to the Music Hall yesterday, is a case where the spirits are willing but the freshness is weak. Mr. Smith's lively spooks can defy some natural laws by remaining on earth in a state of transient translucence, but the law of diminishing returns is one not even a dematerialized terrier can romp through.

Seven thousand stockholders of the French PathE film company joined today in preferring charges of fraud and conspiracy against Bernard Tanenzapf, also known as Bernard Natan, once called "the czar of the Paris film industry," whose arrest brought reports of close personal association with members of Parliament.

Carrying an extradition warrant signed by Governor Moore, a representative of Prosecutor John J. Breslin of Bergen County left today for Seattle, Wash., by plane to bring back Henry J. Meyerhoff, former bank official, who is wanted here for violation of parole.
Robin Redbreast's feather colors were given to white leghorn chickens in a new genetic experiment reported today to the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The strong and well-balanced St. Nicholas Hockey Club sextet downed Colgate University, 6 to 1, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. last night to add another victory to its fine record for the current campaign.

Citrus fruits and butter, two of the cheapest and most highly nutritious foods now in the markets, deserve a more prominent place on current menus, Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, director of the consumers' division of the Department of Markets, said yesterday. In urging a higher consumption of these foods, Mrs. Gannon cited advantages to the consumer and the producer.

TODAY-New England: Cloudy, followed by snow accumulating moderately with slight rise in temperature over north; snow accumulating light to moderately with slight rise in temperature over central and southern portions, but becoming colder at night. New York State:
Five changes in high school education in the State are recommended by the regents' inquiry into the cost and character of public education in New York,
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

King George VI was reported tonight to have given orders for a shake-up of the system of court presentations to keep "cash and curtsy" debutantes out of Buckingham Palace's white and gold throne room.

General Robert E. Wood, president of Sears, Roebuck Co., was elected chairman of the boards at a meeting yesterday of directors of the All-State Insurance Company and All-State Fire Insurance Company. E. J. Polick,
The War Office announced tonight the removal of Major Gen. Kazumoto Machijiri as chief of its Military Affairs Bureau on a charge of losing "important military papers."

Nelson T. Johnson, United States Ambassador to China, arrived here today en route to Washington, having traveled 2,100 miles by automobile since leaving Chungking, provisional Chinese capital, on Dec. 12.
The Administration is expected to submit within the next few days its own plan for removing the suspicion of politics from the administration of Federal unemployment relief.

Miss Gloria Armstrong, debutante daughter of Mr. and.Mrs. Lorenzo D. Armstrong, was introduced to older friends of the family yesterday at an afternoon reception given for her by her parents at their home, 5 East Eighty-first Street.

Several important topographical discoveries, crowning eight years of excavation in the Athenian Agora by archaeologists attached to the American School of Classical Studies at Athens, were reported by Professor T. Leslie Shear of Princeton in a paper read before the Archaeological Institute of America at its session at Brown University today.

The Cities Service Gas Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company, has completed arrangements for the issuance and sale of $35,000,000 of first-mortgage pipeline bonds at interest rates of 31/4 per cent and 33/4 per cent, it was announced yesterday.

Precedents and interpretations are the ivy vines that grow on the once bare surfaces of new instruments of government. Our revised City Charter is undergoing this process, as the dispute between the Mayor and Council over certain items in the capital budget shows.

Three-a-day variety, under the appropriate title of "Vaudeville Marches On," makes an appearance tonight at the Majestic under Kurt Robitschek's banner. The first undiluted vaudeville since the premovie era of the Palace, the bill will include Molly Picon, Al Trahan, Eddie Garr, Fats Waller and Myra Johnson, the Wiere Brothers, Cinda Glenn and Bernice Stone.
The promotional campaign which has been carried on recently by the town of Belleville, N. J., to stress its advantages as a business and industrial location has borne good fruit.

Captain Alfred M. Moore, master of the United States liner American Banker, will be honored today by the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York for his rescue of the crew of the schooner Pioneer on Oct. 1. It will be his third award for life saving exploits at sea.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Raskob of Pioneer Point Farms, Centreville, Md., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nina Barbara Raskob, to Charles Wesley Lyon Jr., son of Charles W. Lyon of Los Angeles.
75th St, 327 E, 28.4x102.2; Marbur Realty Corp to Wm. Goldstone, 23 W 73d St; demand, 6 per cent: $2,000.

The The Hupp Motor Car Corporation filed today a registration statement covering a transaction under which six underwriting companies will underwrite a public offering of shares of $1 par common stock reserved for purchase warrants held by the concerns, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

A balance between health protection and health education, rather than emphasis on student health service, should be the aim of the American Student Health Association, according to its president, Dr. Charles E. Shepard of Stanford University, who addressed the annual meeting of the organization yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.

Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan stayed today enforcement of an order of the Public Service Commission directing the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company to reduce its rates approximately $530,000 a year.
Arnott M. Pressinger, retired assistant controller of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, died yesterday in his home at 77 Park Avenue after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

An ultramicroscope which magnifies objects up to a million times and separates objects as close together as one twenty-fifth of one-millionth of an inch, was demonstrated today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. Vladimir K. Zworykin of the electronic research laboratories of the Radio Corporation of America.
Members of the Society of the Four Arts were guests today at a reception and musical given by Alfred G. Kay, president, and Mrs. Kay. Miss Nancy Fairchild and Miss Irene Botts were the artists.

Two 15-year-old boys from an orphanage at San Rafael broke into the supposedly "burglar-proof" as well as fire-proof, bomb-proof and earthquake-proof San Francisco mint last night, but disturbed nothing more than the equanimity of Federal officials, who wrestled today with the problem of making the $1,000,000 building really safe from unwanted visitors.

Visualizing a Royal Navy that will be roughly one-third afloat, one-third in the air and one-third under the sea, the Admiralty tonight called for 7,00C recruits to enlarge the present fleet air arm of 3,000 officers and men to about 10,000.

Marshall E. Dimock of Chocago, consultant to the National Resources Committee, was appointed by President Roosevelt today second assistant seeretary of labor. The post has been vacant since Arthur J. Altmeyer was appointed to the Social Security Board in 1936. The appointment does not require Senate confirmation.

During the Senate's discussion this afternoon on the air budget the reporter of the committee, Baron Amaury de la Grange, stated that the major part of the credits of 20,000,000,000 francs will be devoted to constructing new planes and that France's air force this year will reach more than 82,000 men, of whom 4,442 will be officers.

GENERAL WASHINGTON'S ragged and heroic Continentals march through quite a lot of antiquarian lore on their way to the American Revolution's immortal Winter encampment as Harry Emerson Wildes presents it in his story of Valley Forge.* Mr. Wildes's book is a wide-ranging, informal history of the locality through two and a half centuries, and it is interestingly-if somewhat discursively-told.

Jews here are alarmed by a rumor, said to come from a reliable source, that the 20 per cent capital levy on their property imposed as a fine for the assassination of Ernest vom Rath, German legation secretary in Paris, is to be increased to 30 per cent.

Natica Lady Lister-Kaye of London, who is passing the Winter at the Ambassador, gave a luncheon in the Trianon Room of the hotel yesterday for Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President. Mrs. Armstead Davis of Washington is expected to arrive today at the Carlyle, where she will be for the remainder of the season.

Buoyancy ruled yesterday in most sections of the bond market in a sharply reduced trading volume. While the fresh display of strength was most conspicuous throughout the list of secondary corporate loans, other classifications of issues participated in varying degrees in the broad upturn.

There will be no "must" legislation put before the coming session of Congress. The President, we are told, will make "affirmative suggestions" in his message, particularly on national defense, but he will adopt a definite policy of leaving the job of drafting bills and resolutions to the legislative branch. With the exception of a few major items Congress will be left to its own devices.

C. E. Calder, president of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., announced yesterday that a payment of $2,000,000 had been made on the outstanding notes payable to banks and the Electric Bond and Share Company.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 28: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Christiansen, O. J., Dental Corps. Panama Canal Dept., to New York Port of Emharkation. Brooklyn. N. Y.
Operators and investors were principals in several of the Brooklyn realty deals announced yesterday, when a number of multi-family properties in scattered sections were traded.

The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected today as unreasonable a proposal by the West Shore Railroad Company to increase local passenger ferry fares between Weehawken and West Forty-second Street from 4 to 6 cents and from Weehawken to Cortlandt Street from 6 to 10 cents.

The new year will bring a determined attempt by British statesmanship to consolidate the front of moral resistance to what the Pope has called the "pagan" doctrine of the adoration of force as the sole instrument for settling disputes between nations.

Caleb B. Starbuck, village treasurer since 1930, died at his home here last night following a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 75 years old. Mr. Starbuck retired five years ago after sixty years' service in the main office of Wells Fargo Co. in New York.

Gross assets, $165,141; net, $152,035. To Frances T. Buel, Margaret B. H. Smith and Asa W. Thompson, nieces and nephew, cneninth residue each; Charlotte J. Blake and Henrietta Blake, sisters, one-third residue each. Chief assets, real estate. $117,430. Gifford, Woody, Carter Hays, attorneys. 1 Wall St.

Dollar volume of department Atore sales in this Federal Reserve district for the four weeks ended Dec. 24, the Christmas shopping Period, was about 1 per cent above the sales of the corresponding four weeks of 1937, according to the monthly review of credit and busiless conditions issued yesterday by ;he Federal Reserve Bank of New work.

With Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's visit to Rome only a fortnight off, the French charge d'affaires, Roger Cambon, called at the Foreign Office today and, it is understood, asserted France's contention that Italy's present demands were such that they must be solved by France herself.

Steers and yearlings fairly active today especially on upper crust, with prices fully steady, top $13.65 for 1,135 pound weights, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Values at the year's high point. Hogs sold unevenly 10 to 25 cents lower, most decline on kinds over 200 pounds, with the top at $7.85. Fat lambs sold 25 to 50 cents lower; best at $9.15.
London will lose its most popular diplomat tomorrow when Jan Masaryk, son of Czecho-Slovakia's founder and for fourteen years its Minister here, sails on the liner Washington for the United States.

St. John's and Long Island University will risk their unblemished basketball records in tonight's double-header at Madison Square Garden. St. John's will meet the oncebeaten Colorado quintet at 8 :15 o'clock, and in the second game L. I. U. will oppose undefeated Southern California.

Crosley Corporation of Cincinnati signed a contract yesterday for three-quarters of an acre of space on the grounds of the New York World's Fair. According to Powel Crosley Jr., corporation president; who came here from Cincinnati to participate in the contract-signing ceremony at the fair grounds, an exhibit hall and broadcasting studio will be erected on the plot.

Mrs. Louisa W. Bowe, 50 years old, of 35-40 Eighty-third Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, plunged ten stories to her death this aft noon from a bedroom window in the home of her sister, Mrs. Emma Heimroth, in the Fulton Towers apartment here.

Dartmouth College won the international intercollegiate ski meet today by scoring a clean-cut victory in the crosscountry race, last and deciding event of the three-day contest in which six teams took part.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a revision of its rule of practice known as Rule XVII to permit any interested government body, State or local, to intervene as a matter of right in proceedings before the commission.

The Ryan Aeronautical Company of San Diego, Calif., has filed a registration statement covering 300,000 rights for $1-par common stock to be. issued to stockholders and 75,000 shares of the common stock to be offered through underwriters at the market, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Illegal and fraudulent withdrawal of large sums of money and market manipulation were charged to Amadeo P. Giannini and other directors of Transamerica Corporation in a suit filed late today by Rose Breakstone, suing for herself and other stockholders of the concern.
Twenty-three of the best players in the professional football ranks were selected today to comprise the all-star squad which will battle the New York Giants, National League champions, here Jan. 15.

Because he was "unable to sleep," according to police, John Koppenal, 49 years old, of 12 Hopper Street, here, walked into the Wayne Township police headquarters near here at noon today and said he was the driver of the hit-and-run automobile which struck two men Christmas Day while they were walking along Hamburg Turnpike in Wayne Township.
With some dissenting notes, nine national business leaders last night expressed optimism about the outlook for 1939, in radio talks over the National Broadcasting Company's WJZ network.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 29, unless specified: San Pedro to Canal Zone: Argonne, Medusa. Utah, Vestal. San Diego to Canal Zone: Boggs, Brazos, Bridge, Cuyama, Dorsey, Elliot, Holland, Kanawha, Lamberton, Neches, Relief. Kewaydin, Indlanhead to Quantico.

At least 50,000 German-Jewish refugees of Polish origin must be given technical and agricultural training if they are to emigrate to other countries from camps in which they are held, Dr. David Lvovitch of Paris, economist and vice president of the World ORT, declared last night in a report on the organization's work overseas.

Enactment of a State wage-hour law to supplement the Federal wage-hour law is the leading feature of the legislative Isrogram of the American Labor party, made public yesterday by Alex Rose, State executive secretary.
Mayor La Guardia of New York remembered his military etiquette today as photographers asked him to pose when he called at WPA headquarters to see Colonel Francis C. Harrington, the new administrator.

Tony Canzoneri faces the sternest test of his comback campaign thus far when he boxes Eddie Zivic, Pittsburgh welterweight, at the New York Hippodrome tonight. The veteran Brooklyn boxer, who once held the featherwieght championship of the world and later the lightweight title,

Miss Lillian Roth, screen actress, and Ben Shalleek, municipal judge of New York, have reached the parting of their ways. Miss Roth said today that when her engagement at a local theatre isover, she will go to Rego for a divorce.

Galliano Masini, the Italian tenor, who is serving his first season at the Metropolitan, added a third role to his local repertory when he sang Radames in "Aida" last night. Previously he had sung in "Lucia di Lammermoor" and "Tosca," both lyric roles. Radames, however, is more weighty and exacting, and Mr. Masini made a brave effort to meet its demands.

Melvin T. Ott, home-run champion of the National League for 1938 and perennial "boy wonder" came the second member of the Giants to accept terms for 1939, according to an announcement by Secretary Eddie Brannick. He also was named their new field captain.

Karel Capek's funeral today in Ss. Peter and Paul Church, situated within the precincts of the old fortress Vysehrad, was attended by representatives of the government, both houses of Parliament, the army and persons prominent in literature, art and the theatre.

The possibility of another change in the map of Europe, involving Italy, Hungary and Yugoslavia, was discussed tonight with the announcement that Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, would arrive here Jan. 19 on an official visit.

Following Wednesday's sharp upturn which carried March contracts to the best quotations of this month, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange eased slightly yesterday to end with losses of 5 to 9 points.

Two of the largest natural gas companies in Pennsylvania - the People's Natural Gas Company and the Columbia Natural Gas Company- W were merged officially today. J. French Robinson, president of both companies, said the consolidation would become effective on Saturday.

A check-off system for the collection of union dues has been instituted by the gas division of the Consolidated Edison Company at the request of three locals of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate, it became known yesterday.

Miss Carolyn Gray, long prominent in nursing circles and former secretary to the State Board of Nurse Examiners, died yesterday in Miami, Fla., at the age of 65, according to word received here. Born in New York, Miss Gray was graduated from the School of Nursing of City Hospital on Welfare Island in 1893.
Cheering. at football games does as much damage to the larynx as a wielded hammer would do to a Stradivarius violin, Dr. Chevalier Jackson said today.

Gifts amounting to $4,037.66 reached the 1938 Neediest Cases Fund yesterday from 184 contributors, whose joint efforts to aid its work of mercy brought the total that has been received for the Fund in this twenty-seventh annual appeal to $248,729.82.

The reported transfer of the Schneider-Creusot shares in the Skoda armaments company to a Czech holding company is accepted in German financial and industrial circles as a logical sequence of the dismemberment of the Czech State and the resultant demolition of the "system of political friendship" formerly existing in Southeastern Europe.

The cold weather in the last two days here speeded up to a certain extent movement of men's suits and overcoats offered in clearance sales by stores, retail executives reported yesterday. Low-price goods were most in demand, with suits up to $25 and overcoats in the $20 range selling the best.
Two sons of Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, were disclosed today to have suffered slight injuries in skiing accidents.

Federal Court reorganization trustees of the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company have filed notice they will appeal United States District Court Judge Guy L. Fake's ruling on Sept. 20 that the company was not entitled to an income tax refund of $2,828,786 for the taxable year of 1918.
Negotiations for purchase of the Memphis Power and Light Company by the city of Memphis will be reopened on Thursday, it was announced today.

Another period of colder weather was forecast last night for New York. Following higher temperatures, the mercury was expected to drop some time today, and the prospect was for a New Year's week end of colder weather.
Spanish Rebel forces said yesterday they had broken through the defense lines in Catalonia near Balaguer, in the center, and at Granadella, on the southern flank.

Bishop Thomas F. Lillis, head of the Kansas City Diocese of the Catholic Church since 1913, died early today at the age of 77. When he celebrated his golden anniversary in the priesthood three years ago he was appointed by the Pope as an assistant at the pontifical throne.

The City College varsity team, making a sweep of four games against the Washington Square branch of New York University in the third round at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, assumed the lead in the annual tournament for the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League and custody of the Harold M. Phillips trophy.

Announcement was made today by Corporation Counsel James A. Hamill that Assistant Corporation Counsel Edward J. O'Mara had submitted his resignation, effective Saturday. Mr. O'Mara has been one of Mayor Hague's most active counsel in the civil liberties case and it was indicated he would continue as counsel in that litigation.

For the "true provincial" a native New Yorker or a London cockney meets the specifications of Professor Mark Jefferson of Ypsilanti State Teachers College, Michigan, who presented to the Association of American Geographers today a study of the world's greatest cities.

Chancellor Hitler will spend New Year's Eve at a performance of "The' Merry Widow" 'at the Charlottenburg Opera House. The Lehar operetta is being revived on a lavish scale and the composer will conduct. Herr Hitler is interrupting his yearend holiday at Lerchtesgaden to attend.

The membership of the New York Hotel Trades Council unanimously ratified last night a union contract with the Hotel Association of New York, culminating ten months' negotiations for the first city-wide hotel employes' agreement ever reached.

College boxing, already unique for its regulations against spectators" applause or any other encouragement of the "killer" instinct, will attempt to divorce itself completely this season from the forms of fighting seen in other rings.

While wreckers were busy yesterday on the task of razing the old George M. Cohan Theatre preparatory to improving the plot and adjoining land with a store and office building plans were filed for a store building to displace another theatre landmark on Broadway.

The Red Wings, who seem to play their best when their casualty list in topheavy routed Chicago, 4 to 1, in a National Hockey League game tonight. Seven thousand saw the game. Detroit took the lead on a goal by Marty Barry after only 19 seconds of play, tallied again in the second period and twice in the final stanza.
Southern Blvd (11-2975). w. S. 25 ft n of for Home St., 50x109: Macaba Corp to Na- State tional Assn of Audubon Societies for Protection of Wild Birds and Animals, -1,775 Bway; mtg, $29.100.
The Jersey City Industrial Terminal, Inc., a syndicate headed by Edmund B. Hourigan, attorney, bought yesterday a tract of fortyfive acres here for improvement as a large industrial terminal.

The first official peep the Duke and Southern California football teams will get of the famed Rose Bowl will be a most auspiciouis one, unless plans are changed. Flags and banners will flutter from a hundred mastheads, band music will fill the air and a roaring corwd of 90,000 will cram the huge stadium from rim to rim.

The stock market advanced modestly today to higher prices, more active trading being assisted by the strength shown in Wall Street. Gilt-edged stocks again were stronger without, however, holding to their best levels of the day. Chilean bonds rose in the foreign list on the announcement of increased interest payments.

For one at "Everywhere I Roam," which was acted at the National last evening, is an overwhelming experience in the theatre. It is a stylized and symbolized story of the early days of America, by Arnold Sundgaard, who first showed it at Robert Porterfield's Barter Theatre in Virginia last Summer, and Marc Connelly, who has staged and collaborated on the current version.
Dr. and Mrs. Wilbur A. Sawyer of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Sawyer, to Dr. Roger William Howell, son of Dr. Robert B. Howell of Ann Arbor, Mich.

American interests with an investment in this country of something like three-quarters of a billion dollars-second only, in Latin America, to our stake in Cuba-face the possibility of heavily increased taxation, or of even still more drastic action,

Carefully avoiding any direct mention of Austria, Czechoslovakia, Spain or China, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain expressed the belief tonight that "the trials and anxieties" of the past year had been "far outweighed by its gains" in the direction of world peace.
Lumber output declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index receded to 75.1, compared with 75.9 for the preceding i week and 77.1 for the week ended Dec. 25, 1937.

August C. Dreyer, manager of the manufacturing trade division of the Singer Sewing Machine Company in Newark, died at his home here last night at the age of 58. Born in Elizabeth, he was associated with the Singer company forty-three years.

A John Buchan omnibus is promised for Spring publication by Houghton Mifflin. Under the title, "The Adventures of Richard Hannay," it will contain such Buchan favorites as "The Thirty-nine Steps," "Greenmantle" and "Mr. Steadfast."

Mrs.Caroline A. Moore, known as Mother Moore to sailors and waterfront workers whom she has aided for fifty-three years, received the Gimbel award of $1,000 today and the accompanying title of "Philadelphia's outstanding woman of 1938."
Lack of trade rather than preparations for impending war caused the sharp drop in world production of iron and steel in 1938, in the opinion of the magazine Steel.

At a tea dance yesterday afternoon at Sherry's, Miss Sylvia Shethar was introduced to society by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Burke Shethar of Rye, N. Y. The debutante, who attended Miss Hall's School in Pittsfield, Mass., received with her mother before a screen of cybotium ferns. The walls of the room were decorated with smilax and poinsettias.

As General Francisco Franco launches his "final assault" against the Loyalists along the Catalonia front, American public sympathy continues to be with the Loyalist forces in the Spanish civil war, according to a national survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.
Bertram G. Nelson, Associate Professor Emeritus of English at the University of Chicago, died last night of a heart attack at the age of 62.
The world's foremost professional tennis player arrived in town yesterday to add another handsome sum to the big nest egg he has made for himself by hitting a ball over a net.

Mrs. China Watson, penthouse in 25 Prospect PI; Nicholas Cottrell, in 124 E 84th St; Morris Adler, in 207 W 105th St; Frances R. Jafin, broker. G. G. Serkau, in 17 W 54th St; Morgenthau-Seixas Co, Inc, broker.
Customers' men, long familiar figures of the Wall Street scene, will disappear next Spring if the New York Stock Exchange department of member firms achieves its expected goal.

Annual meeting, American Association of Teachers of Spanish, Hotel Commodore, 10 A. M. Dinner 7:30 P. M. Speakers: Dr. E. Herman Hespelt, Emilio L. Guerra. Sessions tomorrow morning at New York University.

The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers announced yesterday that the David W. Taylor Medal had been awarded to William L. R. Emmet, honorary vice president of the society and consulting engineer of the General Electric Company.

Designs for a new type of junior high school, an eight-story "skyscraper" building-a marked departure from the usual three and four story elementary schools-have been submitted to the Board of Education by the Bureau of Construction and Maintenance.
Trustees of Series B-K mortgage investments of the New York Title and Mortgage Company have announced a 2 per cent distribution on account of interest on Dec. 31

Estate, more than $10,000. To Jean and Nancy Cowperthwaite, daughters, 471 Park Ave., one-half jewelry, one-quarter personal effects and six-twentieths residue in trust each; Morgan Cowperthwaite Jr., son, 471 Park Ave., diamond ring, onequarter personal effects and five-twentieths residue; John K. Cowperthwaite,

With a handful of her men watching solemnly in the falling dusk, the old training ship U. S. S. Briarcliff went down at sea twenty-five miles south of Ambrose Lightship last night, scuttled on order of the government.

The performance of "The Merchant of Yonkers," Thornton Wilder's play, comprised part of a benefit theatre-supper party arranged in behalf of the Edward McDowell Association, which maintains the McDowell Colony for creative artists at Peterborough, N. H.
Wednesday was the last day in 1938 for transactions in listed securities calling for delivery in the usual way. Late selling for tax purposes must be done "for cash," meaning immediate delivery.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

The advertising appeal approved by most advertising men as being honest and sincere is the one stating that goods will be sent "on approval," according to a survey conducted by Robert Orr, and reported yesterday by the Direct Mail Advertising Association. Approximately 96 per cent of those questioned endorsed this appeal.

A scheduled hearing of a motion to confirm an amended plan of reorganization for the Radio-KeithOrpheum Corporation was adjourned yesterday until Jan. 5 so that all interested parties could have an opportunity to consider a proposal made by counsel for the Atlas Corporation, sponsor of the plan, for a further modification that would reduce the status of Rockefeller Center, Inc., from a $5,000,000 to a $4,150,000 creditor.

A luncheon was given yesterday at the Pierre by Mrs. Maximillian Arthur Ramirez of 830 Park Avenue for her debutante daughter, Miss Rosalie Ramirez. The debutante received with her mother and grandmother, Mrs. Peter O'Boyle of West Pittston, Pa.

The commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City shrank $7,000,000 more in the week ended Wednesday to $1,377,000,000, according to the regular condition statement of the banks, issued yesterday.

Beginning a study which is intended to cover the entire field of corporation accounting, the Securities and Exchange Commission last night called public hearings on the auditing aspects of the McKesson Robbins case.
Mrs. Mary Kilmer Butler, wife of Walter P. Butler, died today in Saratoga Hospital. She collapsed yesterday of a heart attack in the postoffice. Her age was 71.
Thirty thousand Italian laborers will come to Germany in the near future to work on construction projects, thereby augmenting the Reich's depleted labor force, it was announced here today.

The dollar value of manufacturers' sales in November increased 3.6 per cent over November, 1937, the first increase over last-year figures for any month this year, and comparing with declines in other months ranging up to 29.3 per cent for April according to reports, made public today, from manufacturers cooperating in the monthly joint study of the National Association of Credit Men and the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

An exhibition of paintings and black-and-whites by Frank Callcott will open today in the foyer of the west ballroom of the Hotel Commodore on the occasion of the twentysecond annual convention of the American Association of Teachers of Spanish.

A marked decrease in lynchings in the last three years was reported today by Tuskegee Institute. President F. D. Patterson said that records showed six persons were lynched in 1938, compared with eight each in 1937 and 1936, and twenty in 1935.

Miss Helen Bernhard, the 18-yearold New Yorker who has won the last two girls' national indoor singles tennis titles, and 15-year-old Miss Cissy Madden of Boston, last year's runner-up, today gained the final round of the 1938 championship.

The New York Curb Exchange has approved the application of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation to list 100,000 additional $1-par common shares, and of National City Lines, Inc., to list 5,500 additional $50-par $3 convertible cumulative preference shares and 11,000 additional $1-par common shares.

The "forgotten children" of the lower East Side and part of Brooklyn who did not receive gifts at Christmas time will be remembered at parties this afternoon by members of the Police Athletic League and others.

The secret police have scored what the press today hails as a sensationally important coup. They discovered several clandestine printing presses and a whole variety of literature intended for circulation for the purpose of encouraging disbelief in a dictatorship.

Alphonse Drouant, famous Paris restaurant proprietor, died here today at the age of 70. He founded the restaurant Drouant near the Gare de l'Est, one of the best known Paris restaurants. Later M. Drouant was director of the restaurant Marguery in the Boulevard Bonne Nouveille.

George Sherman Lewis, one of the best-known figures in the New England lumber world, and active in a score of other interests, died suddenly today at his home on Fairfield Avenue of a heart ailment. His age was 73.

Fred Wettach, divorced husband of the former Barbara Guggenheim, copper heiress, will contest the Florida divorce she obtained last Fall and also seek custody of their 8-year-old son, according to an announcement today by Mr. Wettach's attorney, Vincent P. Keuper.

The following members of the department having been tried before Francis X. Glaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on date specified. for violation of rules and regulations, 1937. the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:
President Roosevelt will announce through morning newspapers on Sunday the price to be paid by the Treasury for newly mined domestic: silver in the coming year.

Governor Lehman made application for the first savings bank life insurance policy in this State yesterday. He filled out the application in his home, 820 Park Avenue, and handed it with his check for' the $69.07 premium for the first year on a $1,000 policy to Edward

The property at 108 West Fiftysixth Street has been bought by the owners of the adjoining McMillen Garage at 110-112 West Fifty-sixth Street. It rounds out a plot of 75 by 100 feet, according to Samuel Kheel, who arranged the sale in conjunction with the Mitchell Realty Company.

Dick Metz of Chicago, practicing for the $3,000 Houston open golf tournament, cracked the River Oaks course record today with a 64, 7 under par. He breezed through the first nine holes in 34, then shot birdies on No. 10, 11, 13, 15, 17 and 18 for a total of 30 on the incoming nine.

Governor Lehman and Lieutenant Governor-elect Charles Poletti will take their oaths of office tomorrow afternoon at 5 o'clock at the Governor's home, 820 Park Avenue. The oaths will be administered by the Governor's brother, Associate Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a F whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

A client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., brokers, has purchased from the Manufacturers Trust Company, trustee, the four-story apartment house at 1,806 Greenport Road, Far Rockaway, Queens, for cash above a first mortgage of $70,000.

On police surgeon's certificate-To take effect 12 midnight, Dec. 31: PATROLMAN-Gustave P. Primont Jr., 19th Division, office of Chief Inspector, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 14, 1911. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-From precincts indicated to 18th Division, for 30 days, from 8 A. M., Dec. 28:

George P. Winn, chief engineer of the Chamber of Commerce of the Borough of Queens, died last night of- a heart attack at his home, 84-08 165th Street, Jamaica, Queens. He was 54 years old. A native of Nashua, N. H., Mr. Winn was the son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Winn.

New York Stock Exchange memberships were transferred yesterday from Henry A. McGoldrick to William V. Couchman of Cohu Brothers Georgeson; from Gardner Dominick Stout to Sheldon E. Prentice of Dominick Dominick; from James A. S. MacMeekin to Daniel F. Rice of Daniel F. Rice Co., Chicago.

Announcement has been made by President William E. Weld of Wells College and Mrs. Weld of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Elder Weld, to George Nesbitt of Clinton, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Nesbitt of Schenevus.

176th St, 52 W; 2-story dwelling, 50x100; HOLC against Judith S. Mandel; due, $17,533; to plaintiff for $8600. Faile St, 640; 2-story dwelling, 20.10x100; John M. Bissert et al, trustee, against Michael Lipner: due, $4,924; taxes, etc, $599: to plaintiff for $500.

Directors of the Lee Rubber and Tire Corrporation declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share. On Feb. 1 last one of 25 cents was distributed. John J. Watson, president, announced that this was the first dividend of the new fiscal year and compared with a dividend of 25 cents a share paid in the corresponding period of the previous year.
The Maryland racing season will continue to be 100 days at major tracks and fifty days at betting-privileged half-mile tracks-if the State Racing Commission has its way as it has had in the past.

In the Federal Government's drive to wipe out the sale of Irish Hospitals Sweepstakes tickets in the United States, a Federal grand jury indicted yesterday eight men accused by the government of having been the principal agents in this country for the distribution and sale of the tickets in 1936.
Columbia St. 68; 68 Columbia St Realty Corp to Kayess Co. 41 Park Row (50c). 17th St. 226 W; New York Savings Bank to Jontee Holding Corp, 551 5th Ave; mtg $10,000 ($5).
Miss Evelyn Cortelyou Fry, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Henry Fry, was introduced to society at a reception and tea dance given this afternoon at her home on Knollwood Drive, Greenwich.

Hearing on a proposed reorganization plan for the Hudson River Navigation Corporation, under which the steamships Berkshire, Trojan, Rensselaer and Benjamin B. Odell, previously chartered from the Berkshire Operating Company and the Trojan Steamship Corporation, would be acquired by merger was adjourned yesterday until next Thursday.

Dartmouth routed Boston College, 11 to 4, before 1,034 fans on the Playland Casino ice tonight to score its second consecutive hockey victory of the local intercollegiate holiday program and its third straight of the season.

Seven seeded players advanced into the quarter-final round of the national junior indoor tennis singles championship as a result of yesterday's triumphs registered on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory. Heading the list was Joseph Fishbach of New York, 19-year-old St. John's University senior and defending titleholder.
The marriage of Miss Eleanor Janney, daughter of Mrs. Cornelius Lynde of this place and of Laurance A. Janney of Stamford, Conn., to Walter Miles Harvey Jr., son of Mr.

Paris boulevardiers, who like nothing better than to talk a duel, were in an uproar today over a duel that was not fought. The principals are among France's best-known figures-the verbally violent deputy Henri de Kerillis and Fernand de Brinon, journalist and friend of Premier Edouard Daladier and former Premier Pierre Laval.

Dr. Walter Louis Horn, specialist in the diseases of the ear, nose and throat, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a four-day illness. For the last ten years he had been an honorary Police Department surgeon and had done much free work for members of the department and their families. His home was at 1,050 Park Avenue and his office at 1,040 Park Avenue. His age was 47.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Ordway of 25 East End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Ordway, to Charles James Mills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Mills of 944 Park Avenue.

Miss Janice Barbara Markey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Markey of City Island, was married to Peter John Sinnott Jr., son of Peter J. Sinnott of New York and the late Mrs. Sinnott, yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary Star of the Sea, City Island. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur J. Hagan of Boston.

Warners have revised their cast of "Three Cheers for the Irish," a story of the New York Police Department, and expect to place it before the cameras in February. Geraldine Fitzgerald, a Dublin import whose first picture will be "Dark Victory," will be leading woman opposite Pat O'Brien.

The last eight years have been difficult ones for the average musician, the man who cannot call himself a great artist yet who cannot exist by any other means than music. Indeed, many of our leading performers have not escaped.

The Mozart Boys Choir, consisting of twenty voices from the Haydn Basilica of the Church of the Virgin in Vienna, arrived last night on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg on the beginning of a world tour which will include approximately sixty concerts in the United States.

Several Senators predicted today that if Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan were nominated by the President for Attorney General he would be questioned about his handling of sit-down strikes, but ultimately would be confirmed by the Senate.

Miss. Margaret Livingston Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howell G. Lord of this city, became the bride tonight of John Griswold Merrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Merrow, also of Newark. Dean Arthur Dumper of Trinity Cathedral here performed the ceremony in the Lord home.

Liberalization of unemployment insurance laws was urged by William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare in New York City, at the joint meeting today of the American Association for Labor Legislation and the American Sociological Society.
Leo Rodak of Chicago, ranked by the National Boxing Association as No. 1 challenger for the world featherweight championship, was awarded an unpopular decision tonight over Leone Efrati of Italy.

An accounting of one of the trusts which make up the estate of Brenda Diana Duff Frazier, debutante who recently made her bow to society, disclosed that she has a total of about $4,051,000. This was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court where Surrogate James A. Foley signed a decree settling the account.

Two more arrests were made yesterday by the New York police for the Federal authorities who are exploring the methods by which F. Donald Coster, as president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., silenced those who knew him when he was Philip Musica, ex-convict.

The Rev. Dr. Harry L. Bowlby, national secretary of the Lord's Day Alliance, appeared in the local police court today as a complainant against a liquor licensee, who pleaded guilty to a charge of failing to close his bar at midnight Christmas Eve.

As had been expected after her performance yesterday in the opening event, the downhill race, Miss Peggy Johannsen of McGill won the second and final event of the thirteenth annual college women's invitation ski meet of the Lake Placid Club today.

James A. Horan, deputy county welfare commissioner, died last night after he was stricken at a Christmas party at the County Home for the Aged. He was 59 years old. Survivors are his widow, two daughters, Miss Edna Horan and Mrs. Elsie Ployinske; a son,

Dr. John R. Mott of New York, at the closing session today of the International Christian Conference, appealed to Christians to work for justice in a world where the "ancient pestilences which destroy mankind are abroad with unparalleled virulence."

The first anniversary of the crash of Cuban good-will planes at Cali, Colombia, which killed seven fliers, was observed by the Cuban armed forces with commemorative services this afternoon at Colon Cemetery, where the aviators are buried.

The story of "postalized rates" for railroads entered into official consideration of the railroad problem today to William M. W. Splawn, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Committee, gave it partial endorsement and asked an opinion from the Interstate Commerce Commission as to whether it is feasible from the standpoint of the railroads.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve a debt readjustment plan for it and its subsidiaries, the Pennsylvania New York Canal and Railroad Company and the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company of New Jersey.

Retail deliveries of Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation continued to increase through the second ten days of December, totaling 5,008 cars compared with 4,969 in the first ten days, 4,840 in the second ten days last month and 3,080 in the second ten days of December, 1937.

Selection of Dr. Homer Price Rainey, director of the American Youth Commission, as president of the University of Texas was announced today by Dr. Edward Randall, chairman of the Board of Regents. Dr. Rainey will take over the presidency at the end of the semester in June.

Mrs. Irene Cowen Fraser, who was long active in New York and Westchester County welfare work and gave generously to charitable enterprises, died last night at the Dobbs Ferry (N. Y.) Hospital, near here, at the age of 74.

Approximately 6,000 members o' the taxi division of the Transpor Workers Union at two separated meetings yesterday voted to strike whenever the call is issued by the union's executive board. The indications last night were that the city was facing a major taxicab strike but that the drivers would not go out until after they had profited from the New Year's Eve trade.

Asserting that their three-year inquiry into the Samuel Drukman murder case had disclosed "the attempt to interfere with the orderly processes of law" was typical of conditions existing in the administration of criminal justice in Brooklyn, the extraordinary grand jury investigating the case was discharged at its own request yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn.

Colonel F. C. Harrington, Works Progress Administrator, took under consideration a proposal made him today by a delegation from the Federation of Arts Unions to rescind the 25 per cent cut ordered in arts projects, according to one of the delegation, Edward Everett Hale, secretary of the Federation and WPA representative of the Actors Equity Association.

The cry of "Track!" will resound throughout the upper stretches of the "Northlands" the next few days as thousands of gayly attired skiers thrill to the delight of poling along snow-covered wooded trails or zooming down challenging slopes.

Dartmouth, defending champions in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, defeated Stanford tonight at the civic auditorium, 48-47. Stanford is defending Coast champion. The game went into overtime.
The Republic Steel Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of D. D. Buchanan as manager of operations of the Union Drawn Steel division at Massillon, Ohio. P. J. Sandmaier,

Mrs.Nellie Packard Webb, widow of James A. Webb Jr., died yesterday in Fair Oaks Sanitarium, Summit, after long illness. Her age was 77. She was born in Wales, Mass., the daughter of David and Ellen Packard, and was graduated from Smith College. She was married in 1885 in Springfield, Mass.,
Cora Adler, beloved wife of Sigmund Adler of 105 Winchester St., Brookline, Mass. Funeral services at the Eastman Funeral Home, 896 Beacon St., Boston, on Friday, Dec. 30, at 3 P. M.

The United States Government today presented another note to the German Foreign Office requesting assurances that the Reich decree of Dec. 23 excluding "non-Aryans" from positions as executive officers, managers or assistant managers in commercial

The Cunard White Star liner Samaria sails today for Ireland and England. Her passengers include H. S. Latham, Mrs. Charles A. Latham, H. A. Balch, United States Consul in Dublin; Hugh C. McClelland, B. S. Andrews, E. H. Kyle, A. J. Young, Hal W. Johnson, E. H. Besly, R. J. W. Stacy, Mrs. G. M. Thompson, Miss I. J. Ingham and Mrs. Frank Reid.

The new Foreign Minister, Grigore Garfencu broadcast a programmatic declaration tonight stressing that Rumania was maintraining her well-proved alliance with Poland, would Continue friendly relations with Czecho-Slovakia and would cooperate in all fields of political action with her Yugoslavally.

The brokerage businesses of Post Flagg and of Gray Wilmerding through the formation of a new firm retaining the name of Post Flagg will become effective on Sunday, following the dissolution of the previously existing partnerships, it was announced yesterday.

A five-year budget plan for each of the two judicial departments in the city was suggested yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission as the feature of a six-point plan aimed at ending the- dispute between Mayor La Guardia and the judges over court salaries.

Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, contributed $100 to the United Hospital campaign, according to a report last night by the campaign committee. He has Leen a patient for several weeks in Presbyterian Hospital, one of the ninety-two voluntary hospitals participating in the campaign.

As a nurse made frantic efforts to stop her, Mrs. Miriam Rieber, wife of Torkild Rieber, chairman of the board of the Texas Company, jumped to her death shortly after 11 o'clock last night from a window of her thirty-fifth floor apartment at Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South.

An Erie locomotive and its string of ten passenger cars parted company briefly at 8:25 this morning as the train was approaching the Jersey City Terminal with 400 commuters picked up en route from Suffern, N. Y.

Princeton's hockey team sprang something of a surprise tonight by taking the first game of a three-game series from Harvard by a score of 3 to 2. Late in the first period Princeton counted when Douglas Cochrane took a short pass from Tom Barnicle and flipped in an angled drive

Proposals to set up bipartisan boards to settle relief disputes drew criticism today from Mayor La Guardia of New York City. President Roosevelt was reported to be considering the creation of bipartisan boards as a means of taking politics out of relief. Mayor La Guardia commented:
Joseph A. Sisto, head of the brokerage firm of J. A. Sisto Co. A of 63 Wall Street was expelled yesterday from the New York Stock Exchange. The charges brought by the committee on member...
