In the early afternoon of Sept. 30, 1930, Richard Whitney, then the president of the New York Stock Exchange but now in Sing Sing, arose to announce the suspension of J. A. Sisto Co., a financial house, for inability to meet its liabilities.

Soja Henie, skating and film star, was named co-defendant today in a $3,000,000 damage suit alleging that the Twentieth Century Film Corporation and four subsidiaries had pirated a motion-picture plot.

Branch Rickey, vice president of the St. Louis Cardinals, told the nation's football coaches and athletic directors today that a few violators of the amateur code were incorrectly coloring the "whole intercollegiate set-up" and said the problem was partly one of the coaches' own making.

A moderate increase in trade in the Pittsburgh district last week was offset by small declines in production and shipments, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. As a result the index of general business activity remained at 84.6 per cent of the 1923-25 aaVerage.

Nazi District Leader Odilo Globocnik said in a newspaper interview today that about 52,000 Catholics had left the Church after Oct. 8, when Theodore Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna, attacked nazism and was himself assailed by the Nazis, being hurt by a flying glass splinter when a crowd stoned a window of his private chapel.

Word reached here tonight that the little brigantine Florence C. Robinson, which survived a hurricane and fire at sea, had reached the Panama Canal safely, probably had cleared the Isthmus and was well out on the Pacific, en route to Tahiti from Gloucester.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt today gave a Christmas party for their grandchildren, Sara and Kate, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. James Roosevelt, and for Diana Hopkins, daughter of Harry L. Hopkins, Secretary of Commerce.

Arrow Distillers, Inc., of Peoria, Ill., not to be confused with a company of similar name in Detroit, Mich., today appealed to the Supreme Court from an order announced today by the Federal Alcohol Administration suspending its basic permits for thirty days, beginning Jan. 5.

Professor Oldfather of the University of Illinois is so ripe a classical scholar that laymen may feel that there is a certain impudence in differing with him. Yesterday's papers quoted him as saying at Brown University that "Horace always remained at heart a peasant,"
Sir Richard Gregory, British scientist and former editor of Nature, gave an address before the American Association for the Advancement of Science tonight on "Science in Religion," in which he said:

Retention of the present periodic inspection of automobiles, extension of the Merritt Parkway, abolition of constables' fee system, especially because of the New York World's Fair, and other recommendations are contained in the biennial report made today to Governor Cross by the State Highway Safety Commission.

In a long dispatch reviewing the first week of the, Nationalist [Rebel] attack in Catalonia, the results of which are "yet relatively small but susceptible of being exploited," the special correspondent of The Times of Londen in Hendaye, France, suggests that the Italians may be making their last appearance in the Spanish Rebel army.
A Catholic school in the German community of Sao Jose, near here, was closed today under the government's school nationalization program.
Dr. Erich Kleiber, German conductor, has declined to conduct at the famed La Scala Opera House here because of what the opera house described today as "absurd racial motives."

Warren Westervelt Higgons, president of the Charles N. Mead Company, operator of department stores at Greenwich, Conn., and Scarsdale, died here today in his home after a long illness. He was 65 years old.
Severe fighting is continuing in southwest Shansi Province, where an artillery duel is in progress over the strategic Yellow River crossing at its north Fen tributary.

Loom activity in rayon weaving plants last week was off slightly to 73 per cent of capacity for standard fabrics, compared with 75 per cent in the previous week, according to a compilation by the National Rayon Weavers Association.

A lag in the seasons behind the times assigned to them by the position of the sun has been charted by the United States Weather Bureau, E. W. Woolard, government meteorologist, told a meeting yesterday of the American Astronomical Society in the Physics Building at Columbia University.

Miss Beatrice Short, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Robson Short of this place, was married here this evening in the Winnetka Congregational Church to Christopher George Janus of New York, son of Mrs. George Janus of Athens and the late Mr. Janus. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Samuel Harkness.

Three members of' the faculty of Teachers College, actively identified with liberal and labor causes, resigned from membership in the American Federation of Teachers within the last year, it became known yesterday.
The Intergovernmental Refugee Committee, hampered by failure to find new homes for all German refugees, turned today to plans for moving 150,000 young Jews out of Germany.

The Rev. William Norman Guthrie, who once permitted the practice of exotic religions, including the Parsee, in the historic Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, has filed suit against the church for $1,000 as the unpaid part of an annual $2,000 life annuity.

An increase of $4,248,000 in deposits of chartered banks was shown today in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended yesterday. Dominion Government deposits were down by $7,954,000 while notes in circulation showed an increase of $399,000. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 53.65 per cent this week and 54.87 last week.

The status of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, formerly a submarine commander and later the militant leader of the Protestant opposition to the National Socialist regime's church policy, appears to have been stabilized. Along with Kurt Schuschnigg, former Chancellor of Austria, he is now mentioned as one of the Nazis two "de luxe prisoners."

The cost of State and local financing would increase about $113,000,000 annually if the Treasury Deapartment's proposal to lift the immunity from Federal income tax levies on those issues should be carried out, according to Dr. Harley L. Lutz, Professor of Public Finance at Princeton University.

Discovery of a prehistoric American culture, probably antedating the ancient cilivizations of Egypt and Mesopotamia, which existed in the Great Plains section of the United States prior to the modern race of Indians was reported yesterday before the fifty-first annual meeting of the Geological Society of America.

The Federal Wages and Hours Law has met with widespread cooperation from industry and labor unions, with the immediate result that employment has increased in thirty-one of the forty-eight States, Elmer F. Andrews, national administrator, declared today before the convention of the American Association of Labor Legislation.
Electric power output increased more than normally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 98.9 from 97.9. For the week ended Dec. 25, 1937, the index was 96.9.

Miss Noel MacDonald, 23year-old stenographer who has been ranked the best center in women's basketball for five years, is Canada's outstanding girl athlete of 1938. The 'ace sharpshooter of the famous Edmonton Grads won the honor in the annual Canadian Press poll of sports editors.
A complete portable electric range with cooking surfaces which fold when not in use will be put on the market by the Eureka Vacuum Cleaner Company, Fred Wardell, president, announced today.
Mysterious private conferences among members of the Cabinet were continued last night at the suburban home of Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye.

The Class I railways will show in the aggregate for 1938 after all charges a net loss of $125,000,000 as compared with a net income of $98,000,000 in 1937, according to the annual statement of J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.
Mr. and Mrs. Glen E. Osborne of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Marie Osborne, to Richard A. White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Arthur White of Saugerties, N. Y.

Discoveries made today seemed to indicate that the scene of the murder of Miss Margaret Martin was a sawmill, high in the mountains of Wyoming County, and that she was slain the night of Dec. 17. less than twelve hours after she had been lured from her home here by a telephone call from a prospective emplayer.

Shoulder Arms, in the red and goldblocked silks of Henry Lustig's Longchamps Farms, kept his record perfect for the meeting when he won the featured Surfside purse in game fashion at Tropical Park today.

L. Szabo of Budapest gained his second straight victory today in the international chess masters' tournament at the annual Christmas Congress of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club. His opponent was E. Klein of Vienna.

M. S. Bates, American' Professor of History in Nanking University, reported today that "armed chaos" existed in the Nanking region, which the Japanese occupied on Dec. 13, 1937, after a six weeks' campaign.

Vincent Joseph McBrien, 27-yearold son of a Hartford, Conn., meat packer, sought by the police since last April when he is alleged to have shot to death his sister Elizabeth in their Hartford home, was arrested last night at Fifty-first Street and First Avenue.
Mr. and Mrs. Howard Ogden Wood gave a dinner dance last night in the Crystal Garden of the RitzCarlton to present to society their daughter, Miss Caryl Hackstaff Wood.
Total receipts of the Autonomous the Public Debt of the Republic of Chile in 1938, available for debt service, amount to $14,135,573, compared with $6,106,751 last year, it was announced yesterday.

W. E. McKell, president of the New York Casualty Company and vice president of the American Surety Company, was elected president of the New York Board of Trade yesterday at a luncheon of the board of directors at the Hotel Vanderbilt. Mr. McKell succeeds Percy C. Magnus, who becomes chairman of the board.

THE University of Southern California is not located in Indiana. Coach Sam Barry insists that his Trojans really hail from Los Angeles, although other members of the Pacific Coast Conference have stolen a line from Virgil and applied it to the lads from Troy,

Andrew Zawalik, 30 years old, of 118 Pulaski Street, Newark, former boxer who pleaded guilty Nov. 17 to a charge that he intended to interfere with Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, while the latter was making a speech in Military Park here on June 4, was sentenced by Police Judge Carl Duveneck today to serve thirty days in the Newark jail.
Dictatorship over almost all German athletics and sports under the direction of Hans von Tschammer und Osten, Reich sports leader, has been decreed by Chancellor Hitler.

Second place ona list of the twelve biggest news stories of 1938 is assigned by a vote of nearly 150 editors to young Douglas Corrigan and his vice versa flight across the Atlantic. He is only a few points behind the Czech crisis in first place.

Yvonne Georgi and her Netherlands ballet left here today to board the Wasington at Havre for New York. It is the first Dutch ballet ever to tour in America. Madame Georgi has toured in the United States four times in recent years.

The New York Americans found the way past Frank Brimsek, the Bruins' sensational rookie goaltender, with comparative ease last night at Madison Square Garden. The mighty Boston sextet, which has been making a runaway of the National Hockey League race,

It is nearly fifteen years since the two houses of Congress, by a combined vote of nearly four to one, submitted the Federal Child Labor Amendment to the States. As Courtenay Dinwiddie, general secretary of the National Child Labor Committee, reminds us in his annual report, eight States are still needed to write this amendment into the Constitution. Meanwhile,

American business was urged yesterday by Charles R. Hook, retiring president and new chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, to be ever mindful of its duty to adopt and maintain the highest possible standards of conduct in all its dealings.

Due to the observance of the Christmas holiday, bank clearings for the final week of 1938, which included only five days, declined from the previous week. The total, however, was also 3.3 per cent below the corresponding five days of 1937.

Minnesota gained its sixteenth consecutive victory tonight by downing a fighting Temple team at Convention Hall, 38-35, after Illinois had snapped Villanova's six-game winning streak, 28-22, before 8,926 fans.

Determinedly progressive under the forward-looking direction of William McC. Martin Jr., its "reform" president, the New York Stock Exchange celebrated yesterday the passage of 1938 a day ahead of time.

Alma Milstead, soprano, who appeared in recitalat the Town Hall last night, has a light, lyric voice of agreeable quality. It was at its best in the middle register, where it was t produced easily. There was some strain in the production of top tones. She sang with feeling and sincerity.

The pound sterling continued yesterday to weaken in the foreign exchange market. Selling that was not large but which met with insufficient buying pushed the British unit down to $4.64.3/4, a new low on the current downswing and only 4 3/4. cents above the year's low established in the midst of the CzechoSlovak crisis on Sept. 28.

" Lakme," which had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, may not be an opera of power and passion, but it makes an attractive show. It has color, pleasant tunes, a varied ballet placed where even late comers and early departers cannot miss it and a simple story that is guaranteed not to befuddle the unilingual.

The Count of Paris, heir to the pretender to the French throne, in an article in his newspaper, the Courrier Royale, today condemns antiSemitism. "The spiritual atmosphere of France, permeated as it is with Christianity, reason and humanity," he says, "has no place for racial struggles.
The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad filed today an amendment to its reorganization plan which, if approved, would make the company's common stook worthless.
At a tea given today at their home, Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Whiting of this city announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Caldwell Whiting, to Ernest Bevier Wright, son of Mr.

Fairly active Curtin, trading featured the closing market of the old year. No choice or prime steers arrived, but all classes of cattle were readily absorbed at fully steady prices, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Light hogs worked a little higher with top at $7.90. Weighty butchers sold off. Lambs held steady with bulk at $8.85 to $9 and top at $9.15.

John P. Bickell, senior partner in Thomson McKinnon, New York Exchange member house, will retire today. Press of other business is understood to be responsible. An important figure in the business of Canada as well as that of the United States, Mr. Bickell is president of McIntyre Porcupine Mines, Ltd., and a director of the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

Laconia Ave (16-4711), e s, 100 ft s of Fish Ave. 43x96; Bronx White Corp to Nelle Mandikas, 891 Tiffany St. Grand Concourse (11-2821), s e cor of Mt. Eden Ave, 268x12; Scherman Development Corp fo Moro Realty Corp, 95 Nassau St; mtg $629.800.

The stage is set for New York City's gayest of all holiday nights, the celebration of New Year's Eve. As the old year passes into history tonight there is every indication that 1939 will get the liveliest and noisiest welcome in many years.

Ruth Hilde Somer, 16-year-old Viennese pianist, made her first New York appearance last night at Carnegie Hall in an exacting program in which she was assisted by an orchestra composed of seventy members of the Philharmonic-Symphony, under Hans Schwieger, a young German conductor also new here.
Mrs. Ellen S. Woodward, taking the oath today as a member of the Social Security Board, pledged herself to work for more aid for underprivileged children.

Although the outlook was decidedly gloomy at one time, the varsity chess team representing the College of the City of New York maintained its lead when it played the champion Brooklyn team to a 2-2 tie yesterday in the fourth round of the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League at the Manhattan Chess Club.

A twenty-foot putt which dropped for a birdie 3 on the nineteenth hole gave Ted Scofield, Yale University star, a hard-earned victory over Fred B. Alexander Jr. of New York in the first round of the annual Midwinter amateur golf tournament as play was resumed today over the championship No. 2 course of Pinehurst Country Club.

Three women were overcome by man could smoke and a patrolman and a neighbor suffered lacerations last night in a fire which partly destroyed the two-and-one-half-story frame dwelling at 335 Bayside Place, Rockaway Beach, Queens.

A smoky basement fire in the Republic Theatre at 209 West Fortysecond Street, just off Times Square, attracted a large crowd early yesterday afternoon. Four engine companies, two hook and ladder companies, a police emergency squad, and a truck containing fire-fighting chemicals partly blocked traffic for an hour between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. About 350 patrons left the theatre without panic or injury. The damage was minor.

An anonymous gift of $1,000 has increased the prize awards offered in the architectural competition sponsored by the American National Theatre and Academy for the design of a "festival theatre" planned at the College of William and Mary, at Williamsburg, Va. Prizes will amount to $2,500, of which $1,000 will go to the winner and $600 to the second design.

Revision of the Anglo-German naval pacts to increase Germany's striking power was believed to have been initiated today when the German' Government issued a communique saying that representatives of the British Admiralty had arrived in Berlin to discuss questions arising out of the Germans' decision to exercise certain rights accruing to them by vir tue of those pacts.
Italian cinema fans face a gloomy 1939, for American films, which are invariably recognized as standing in a class apart for their excellence, are to disappear from the Italian market.

Government competition with private teachers of music by provision for free instruction of pupils able to pay for such training was denounced at today's concluding session of the Music Teachers' National Association in annual convention here.

Miss Marguerita (Cissy) Madden, 16-year-old Boston girl and one of the most promising of the New England tennis juniors, today gained the girls' national indoor singles title by dethroning Miss Helen Bernhard, 18, of New York. 6-8, 8-6, 6-3, in a three-hour final at Longwood.

Dwellings and apartment houses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn changed hands in deals reported yesterday by brokers. A Harlem transaction involved the five-story flat at 1,572 Madison Avenue, between East 105th and 106th Streets, which was sold by the Cetnral Savings Bank to a client of Murry Lefcourt.
The Treasury received today for its conscience fund a Federal Reserve note of $1,000 from an unidentified person living in Massachusetts. The following letter accompanied the bill:

The arson and burglary squads of the Nassau County Police Department were investigating tonight suspicious aspects of a fire early this morning at the home of Frank J. Bradley, retired broker, of 110 Stewart Avenue here.

The Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers and managers, were accused yesterday of illegal restraint of trade in enforcing their new code to outlaw speculation in the sale of theatre tickets.

Freshened since his New York campaign, Shadytown, speedy son of Jamestown who carries the Woolford Farm silks of Herbert M. Woolf, easily outfooted six other sprinters in the Star Island Purse at Tropical today.
E. Halsey Malone, a practicing lawyer in New York since 1908, died yesterday morning of a heart ailment at his home, 1 East End Avenue. His age was 53.

The combined power of a stalwart line and a superior passing attack had installed Texas Christian's Horned Frogs a slight choice tonight for their Sugar Bowl football game wtih the Tartans of Carnegie Tech Monday.

ARTHUR GODFREY KILMER BROWN raced 400 meters not so long ago in 46.9 seconds. That, per se, is hardly enough to raise an eyebrow on this side of the water, because the spectacled Englishman is quite capable of such a feat. But what caused a bit of wonderment were the trimmings embroidered like fancy lace around the outer edges of this performance.

Princeton again downed the Har vard hockey sextet tonight in the second of their three-game series. The score, 3-1, gave the Tigers a 6-3 advantage in total goals. on which basis the series will be decided. Th final game will be played tomorrow night.

At least two attractions, "Window Shopping" and "Michael Drops In," will not be around to greet the New Year after tonight's performances. Both of them have decided to close shop at the Longacre and Golden, respectively.

Stimulated by low temperatures, consumer response to retail clearances here this week was reported fairly good. Dollar volume for the week was estimated as slightly under last year because of the price difference, but it was believed that the showing for the month as a whole will equal or show a slight increase over December, 1937. Retailers will launch their white goods sales next week.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation had filed an application under the Holding Company Act for an order approving the declaration and payment of quarterly dividends payable on Feb. 15, 1939, as follows:

The fifty-sixth annual mass of the New York Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Society will be celebrated Monday morning at 11 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The celebrant will be Mgr. William A. Courtney, pastor of St. Stephen's Church, and the preacher will be the Rev. Arthur J. E. Quinn, pastor of the Church of the Annunciation.

Recent achievements in celestial photography, using newly perfected film, sensitized to color, were described yesterday before the sixtyfirst meeting of the American Astronomical Society, in session at Columbia University.
Police sought tonight to determine whether two young women and a married man found in a -gas-filled automobile died in a suicide pact or whether both women were slain.
The Alexander Hamilton High basketball team downed Sayville High, 24-18, tonight in a game that was close until the last quarter. At half time the winners led, 9-8.

A CALM, precise and extraordinarily illuminating revelation of Nazi propaganda in this country is present. in, a new book called "The German Reich and. Alericans of German Origin."* Here -- without undue editorializing - reproductiona of German proclamations, documents and speeches by Nazi leaders shown in facsimile and in translation.
Miss Eleanor Hepburn Fisk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pliny Fisk of New York, was married to Hugh Fraser Noall of New York at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Child here today.

Cities Service Gas Company will redeem on Feb. 28, 1939, all its first mortgage pipeline 5 1/2 per cent bonds, series of 1927 and 1928, due May 1, 1942, at 101 and interest. Payment will be made at the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

The "Player of the Year" plaque, awarded annually by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association to the outstanding big league star, has been voted to Jimmy Foxx of the Red Sox for 1939, it was announced yesterday.

Alexander Cardinal Kakowski, Catholic Archbishop of Warsaw, died today of a heart ailment after an attack of pneumonia. His age was 76. He was the first Pole elevated to the dignity of a Cardinal after the republic was established in 1918.

Production in Japan of woolen cloth for domestic use has been ordered curtailed 40 per cent by the Japanese Government, the Commerce Department reports. Stocks of raw wool have been falling rapidly, necessitating the present curtailment, which began last July.

Thomas Bayard McCabe, president of the Scott Paper Company, Chester, Pa., has been appointed chairman of the board and Federal Reserve Agent of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia for 1939, it was announced yesterday by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System.

The "excessive taxation" levied against industry by the national administration is the essential factor retarding the return of true prosperity in this country, former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared yesterday morning.

The War D partment released the following orders toa day, dated Dec. 29: COLONELS Glover, F. W., Cav., Charleston, S. C., to Ft. Bliss, Texas, Jan. 15. Harwood T. E. Jr., Med Corps, Ft. Omaha, Neb., to Edgewood Arsenal, Md., Marca 1.
Seven persons, including four Columbia University engineering students, were injured seriously totonight when their automobile skidded on Bantam Lake Road here and crashed into a tree.

Samuel Gladstone, retired wholesale woolen merchant, who was in business in New York for about fifty years and was active in Jewish charitable and religious enterprises, died of a heart attack on Thursday in Miami Beach, Fla. Mr. Gladstone, who lived at 1,460 Popham Avenue, the Bronx, was 73 years old.
The Biblical Archaeologist brings us in its latest number reliable word of a recent find in the Holy Land whose "real significance can hardly be exaggerated."

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Mrs. Evelyn Kelley del Barrio of this city, formerly of Havana, Cuba, to Charles Henry Fonda of Deerlake Plantation, which is in both Ten-nessee and Arkansas.
Plenty of snow for skiing, sled dog races and horse racing on ice tonight await those who wish to welcome 1939 in Northern New England.

The National chili Labor Relations Act has been responsible for increased union membership, greater enjoyment of civil liberties, better employer-employe relationships, and few strikes, J. Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, asserted today.

In a day of fierce fighting in all three Segre sectors the Insurgents appear to have battered their way forward scarcely more than a mile at any point. The fighting was continuing full blast at dusk, so it will not be until tomorrow morning that the outcome Will be known.

A suggestion that Spanish teachers, through their research and classroom work, can bring about better understanding and good-will between the United States and the Latin American nations was voiced yesterday by President Roosevelt and Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles.

The American fencing team tonight captured the Colonel Batista Trophy by winning the final match of the series at the sports palace. The score was 16 to 16, but the athletes from the United States obtained the decision by receiving 35 touches to the Cubans'-37.

The year was notable for important advances in research and engineering, although it was not "a big year as far as business is concerned," according to a statement made public yesterday by George H. Bucher, president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, East Pittsburgh, Pa.
An eleven-man squad will be sent overseas by the A. A. U. to compete in the world amateur ice hockey championships in Switzerland, Feb. 3-12, it was announced yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had become a party, under the amendments to the Federal Bankruptcy Act made by the Chandler act, to nine additional reorganization proceedings, three of them in the United Stated District Court for the District of New Jersey.

Charging a "conspiracy" to two members, a majority, of the Massachusetts Racing Commission, the Eastern Racing Association, which operates the huge Suffolk Downs horse race track, today sought a Superior Court injunction to block licensing.
Five hundred thousand parents visited the New York City public schools during "Open School Week" which began on Nov. 7, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, reported yesterday.
A low-cost newsprint made from Pennsylvania wheat straw will have its first tryout on newspaper presses soon, Dr. F. W. Hochstetter said today.

A reactionary tendency developed today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade for the first time in more than a week. Fairly good buying was in evidence at the start, but it was not in sufficient volume to carry prices above yesterday's high point, and, later in the session, brokers who frequently act for Eastern interests sold freely.
The Tennessee Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the National Power and Light Company, has retired from business in Knoxville, Tenn., it was announced yesterday. The company,

Winter clothing is now being distributed among more than 4,000,000 persons by the Works Progress Administration from its purchase of $15,750,000 worth of manufacturers' excess inventories, Corrington Gill, assistant administrator, said today.

More than 300 clergy of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese, led by the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, the administrator, participated yesterday in a solemn high mass of requiem for Mgr. David W. Petry, assistant pastor of Our Lady of Lourdes Church, West 142d Street near Amsterdam Avenue.

Contracts for all types of building construction in Manhattan during the first eleven months of 1938 totaled $81,788,000, according to an analysis by Emile Coene Jr. of the F. W. Dodge Corporation. With activity rising in recent months, residential and nonresidential contracts for the eleven months of this year are well ahead of the total for the corresponding period in 1937.

Transactions intended to end double taxation incurred by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. on income from its indirect holdings of 9,843,750 common shares of the General Motors Corporation and to segregate completely the interest of certain executives of General

Enrollment of the Civilian Conservation Corps for 1939 will begin next Tuesday with 1,100 junior CCC men, who will report to the United States Army Recruiting Office at 39 Whitehall Street, according to an announcement yesterday.
Citizens of Danzig will be deported from Poland if the Free City authorities attempt to expel Polish Jews from their territory, the Polish Commissioner has told the Danzig Government.

While men die amid the thunder of guns along the Ebro an international project for increased nonpartisan civilian relief in Spain makes a step forward. This project was conceived by Ernest Toller, exiled German playwright, once a revolutionary leader.

NELLY KELLY HATS, Inc., 49 Church St.--By Dreswell Hats, Inc., for $226; J. Fishman, Inc., $49; Do Ber Hat Co., $80; Goldsmith Perlman. $154. Petitions Filed-By BELLA BERKOWITZ, secretary, 730 Coster St.-Liabilities $621; no assets. SERAFINO CICCONE, Sr., presser, 353 W. 34th St.-Liabilities $747; assets $5, exclusive of insurance.

MANHATTAN ARMSTRONG ARTHUR SOPER (Jan. 13, 1938). Gross assets, $75,540; net, $35,921. To Mabel R. Armstrong, widow, Syms C., and Arthur S. Armstrong Jr., sons, one-third each. Chief assets, real estate, $60,068. Reynolds, Richards McCutcheon attorneys. 68 William St.

Secreary Morgenthau announced today he retirement of Louis A. Simon, supervising architect of the public buildingg branch of the Treasury Department. LeRoy Barton will succeed him, becoming acting susupervising architect Jan. 1.

An increase in traffic- fines in 1938 over 1937 of $465,547, exclusive of those collected in the Staten Island Court since its establishment- six months ago, was reported yesterday by Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Chief City Magistrate.

An insight into the unshakeable religious beliefs of followers of the Old Order Amish sect, whose customs, -after more than 200 years In the "great melting pot" of America, have not altered from those of their sixteenth century SwissGerman forefathers, was given to the American Folklore Society yesterday by Professor John M. Umble of Goshen College, Goshen, Ind.
Gambling is intercollegiate football's "No. 1 parasite," the nation's gridiron coaches were told today at the closing session of their eighteenth annual meeting.

An assertion that colleges were wasting money on too many stupid students and especially on too many stupid teacher-training students was made today before the American Sociological Society by Dr. Herbert L. Spencer, president of the Pennsylvania College for Women.

Professor Joseph D. Chamberlain of Columbia University, chairman of the National Coordinating Committee for aid to refugees and emigrants coming from Germany, was awarded the gold medal of the Pi Lumbda Phi fraternity for tolerance last night at the annual dinner in the Hotel Biltmore.

The cooperative production credit system established by the government in 1933 made loans amounting to $300,000,000 in 1938, an increase of about $15,000,000 over the figures for 1937, F. F.. Hill, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, announced today.

Miss Lois Hughes Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Miller of New York and Lake Mahopac, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Officers Club, Governors Island, to Lieutenant Thomas Charles Compton, U. S. A., of the Eighteenth Field Artillery at Fort Sill, Okla., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Compton of Fort Lewis, Wash.
A desire on the part of Germany that France and Italy settle their Mediterranean dispute before it grows into another European war crisis was reported in Fascist quarters today.
Cotton - mill activity slackened, more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index slumped to 116.3 from 126.6. For the week ended Dec. 25, 1937, the figure was 90.1.

The National Council of Catholic Men today directed an unqualified attack against the Spanish Government as "persecutors" of Catholics by initiating the circulation of a petition for extension of the Neutrality Act, due to expire next year, and strengthening it to embargo ship.ments of arms to participants in "civil as well as international conflicts."

Mrs.Therese A. Jones, a member of the Kearny Board of Education and a former Mayor here, died today of pneumonia at the home of her sister, Mrs. J. O. Weitig, in Englewood. She lived at 635 Belgrove Drive, Arlington. Her age was 66.

For most Americans an eventful year ends on a note of hope. The nation is at peace. Its relations with its neighbors in this hemisphere were never on a basis of better understanding or more solid friendship.

The log and guest book of F. Donald Coster's yacht Carolita was being examined yesterday by Assistant United States Attorney Gregory F. Noonan to determine whom the president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., entertained on his boat.

Mrs. Jesselyn Emily Pierce Carvalho, wife of Bertram N. Carvalho, president of the Rossia Insurance Company, died today at her home in West Hartford at the age of 61. A native of New York, she was married to Mr. Carvalho in 1903 and they moved here nine years later, when the insurance company transferred its offices to this city.

Michael J. Cruise, Tammany leader of the Twelfth Assembly District in Manhattan, was declared New York's official City Clerk by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin in a ruling handed down yesterday.

The Propaganda Ministry said tonight that Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels had recovered sufficiently from his recent illness to make a New Year's address tomorrow night. The Ministry spokesman said that Dr. Goebbels would speak for about twenty minutes, starting at 10 P. M.

Joseph J. Dowd, 38 years old, of 7,119 Shore Road, Brooklyn, an employe of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, was killed instantly last night when he drove his automobile underneath a parked freight car on Second Avenue at Thirty-third Street. Brooklyn. The freight car,

The Committee of Terminal Employes, an independent union of chauffeurs and garagemen of the , Terminal System, Inc., taxicab concern, announced last night that telegrams protesting the strike plans of the Transport Workers Union, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street,

Police Lieutenant Michael Golden died Thursday night at his home, 2,914 Randall Avenue, the Bronx, of a heart attack after a brief illness. He was 54 years old. He was a member of the staff of Inspector James S. P. Brady of the Eighth Division.

A mere two-tenths of 1 per cent today separated Dartmouth and McGill in the team standings for the slalom, opening event of the eighteenth annual college men's skiing competition at the Lake Placid Club.

The Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago, St. Louis Railway (The Big Four Route), a subsidiary of the New York Central, filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue 529,040,000 of refunding and improvement mortgage 41/2s, Series F, The new bonds would replace others which have been called or will maLure soon.

Renewed activity in the cotton goods markets stimulated trade price-fixing on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and prices advanced in the final trading session of the year. Aside from scattered yearend liquidation, offerings were restricted and final quotations showed gains of 3 to 7 points for the day.

Predicting that production of automobiles and trucks in January would be Park "considerably higher than is seasonally normal," Ward's Automotive Reports today estimated that 325,000 units would be assembled next month.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Price of Rutherford, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Anne Price, to H Bleecker Morse, son of Mrs. Mabel L. Morse of New York.
Steve Bradley of Dar led twenty undergraduate crosscountry racers over the finish line today in the first event of the threeday intercollegiate skiing tournament.

Led by the veteran Davis Cup performers, Gene Mako of Los Angeles and Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament progressed to the semifinals today after the ranks of seeded players were thinned by an upset.

The town of Antwerp, which refused State relief aid under the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration a few years ago, and later turned down WPA help, today reported relief expenses for 1938 of $1,621.92.

Kenneth J. Dunstan, former vice president of the Bell Telephone Company, died at his home late today. He would have been 80 years old next month. At the age of 19 he was the first telephone operator in the British Empire. At the time the Hamilton Telephone Company owned one of the world's two switchboards, and the other was in New Haven, Conn.
The . Interstate Commerce Commission suspended today for investigation tariffs filet by railroads proposing to increase-estimated weights on shipments of vegetables and deciduous fruits.

The battle between Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran and Park Commissioner Robert Moses over the restoration of City Hall Park widened out a bit yesterday as Mr. Moses said he would stick to his original park plans and Mr. Curran called him a "road-builder with a passion for uglifiess."

Stanley Pearson Jr., Princeton sophomore and son of the former three-time national squash racquets champion, conquered Malcolm Muir, captain of the Yale team, in the final to capture the fourth annual intercollegiate invitation squash racquets tournament on the courts of the University Club yesterday.

The Dazian Foundation for Medical Research at 142 West Fortyfourth Street receives $1,325,288 from the estate of its founder, Henry Dazian, stage costumer, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The foundation was named as residuary legatee of the estate, which had a net value of $1,470,385.

George G. Hynson Jr. and associates have bought the entire remaining holdings of the estate of the late Clarence H. Mackay in the securities of the Postal Telegraph and table Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

The "edited" report of the State Department of Correction on abuses in the Kings County Court probation system was revealed yesterday by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, as having been emasculated of its most condemnatory parts, which depicted a virtual breakdown of justice in the court and a lack of discipline verging on the scandalous.

The new output records currently being made by the electric power industry stand in marked contrast to the performance of industry as a whole. The nation's industrial output even now is little greater than in 1923-25 (the base period for the Federal Reserve Board's index) notwithstanding a growth during the interim of close to 15 per cent in the nation's population.

The long-suspected but cleverly concealed serious rifts within the Chinese Government have been finally revealed by a statement addressed to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek by Wang Ching-wei the text of which was circulated by the semi-official Japanese news agency Domei from Hong Kong.

The stock markets ended the year on a cheerful note, although business was restricted by holiday influences. Nevertheless, the brighter view enabled dealers to indulge in the usual "window-dressing" by marking up prices.

Sinclair Lewis, his voice a bit thin and his carriage not quite natural, resumed his professional acting career tonight and won ten curtain calls. The author, winner of Nobel and Pulitzer prizes, graduated into bigtime theatre by appearing as the lead in his own play, "Angela Is Twenty-Two."

In the line-up at police headquarters yesterday, Vincent Joseph McBrien, 27 years old, of 129 West Seventy-first Street, admitted shooting and killing his sister, Elizabeth, and firing a shot at his father in the McBrien home at Hartford, Conn., last April 29.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave leave to intervene in the reorganization of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company to six representatives of eighty-five mutual savings banks owning the corporation's securities.

Mrs. George B. Wagstaff and Miss Dorothy Wagstaff of Mudridge Farm, Litchfield, Conn., are at the Waldorf-Astoria before going to their Winter home in Aiken. Mrs. Gerald Gray, daughter of Mrs. Tobin, Clark of San Mateo, Calif., will come to the Savoy-. Plaza today from San Francisco.
Stocks mixed in trends, closed irregularly higher; turnover, 1,400,010 shares. Second-grade rails strong, other bonds irregularly higher; transactions, $9,468,765.

Honors in the boys' and junior national indoor tennis championships yesterday went to Chicago as two of the Windy City's representatives, James Evert and Gardner Larned, gained the boys' doubles title and also advanced into the semi-final round of the singles. A third,

Former Assemblyman Henry M. Deitz of 35-33 Eighty-sixth Street, Jackson Heights, an active worker in the Queens Democratic party organization, was arrested yesterday on charges by an Astoria physician that Deitz bad obtained $2,200 from him under the promise that he could bring about his appointment as a member of the medical staff of the Triborough Bridge Authority.

Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 24 were 13 per cent more than for the corresponding week in 1937 and for the four weeks ended Dec. 24 were 3 per cent more than for the similar period last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Christ Church here was the setting this evening for the marriage of Miss Claire Sheffield to William Henry Linkroum Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Edgar Cook of Hackensack and the Rev. Hollis W. Colwell of Beverly.

William Harman Black and Richard P. Lydon retire tonight as justices of the Supreme Court after serving sixteen and eighteen years, respectively. The terms of both were automatically cut short because they reached the constitutional retirement age of 70 last year.

Circus days of two generations ago, when there was plenty of room in what is now the midtown section of Manhattan and the "big tent" often was pitched in the Thirtyfourth Street block now occupied by Macy's, are recalled by a deal involving the property at 126 West Thirty-fourth Street.

William P. Buckner Jr., member of an old New York family, and William J. Gillespie, his partner in the promotion of bonds of the Philippine Railway Company, were named defendants yesterday in a mail fraud and conspiracy indictment charging them with the misapplication of more than $50,000.

Passed by the Senate on its first reading today, the budget will be returned to the Chamber tomorrow when both houses will hold a continuous session until a measure has been obtained acceptable to both.

The White House made public today a report from the National Labor Relations Board, saying it had averted 662 strikes involving 169,809 workers since it was created three years ago. "The President is always unusually interested in the accomDlishments of the board,"

Ballots to determine the American citizen who recorded the outstanding achievement in sport during 1938 were circulated yesterday to the 215 members of the Advisory Committee of Sports of the New York World's Fair. The winner will receive the Fair's "Golden Laurel."

A tiny doll, a plaster figure of a little boy in a green play suit, was given away yesterday afternoon among 350 other toys and playthings to a like number of East Side youngsters whom Santa forgot. It was a little different from ir the other gifts.

Winners and still champions, the Toronto Argonauts have been voted the outstanding team in Canadian sport for the second straight year. Capturing the fancy of sports editors from coast to coast, the football. Argos received 79 points of a possible 93 in the annual Canadian press poll.

The Rangers and the Bruins will meet in a National Hockey League contest at Madison Square Garden tonight. A crowd of 16.000 persons, one of the largest gatherings of the current season, is expected to witness the game between the rival sextets, who have been picked generally to finish one-two in the league race.

Beethoveli's "Fidelio" will be revived this afternoon at 2 o'clock at the Metropolitan with Kirsten Flagstad in the title role. At night, "Otello" will be given with Martinelli in the name part and Helen Jepson and Richard Bonelli singing Desdemona and Iago for the first time here.

The year 1938 will be rung out and the year 1939 will be rung in tonight by carillons, chimes and bells of the city's churches as the congregations attend watch-night and holy communion services. From Trinity and Old John Street Methodist Churches in the financial district to Washington Heights
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 28: COMMANDER Hall, W. R., Chaplain Corps. U. S. Fleet, to temporary duty 11th Naval District, Dec. 29.

One man lost his life as the result of a two-alarm blaze that started before dawn yesterday in the Hotel Lido, 59 West Sixty-fifth Street.. Three persons were rescued from a seventh-story ledge and eightyfive others were driven into the street, many of them climbing down fire escapes to adjoining roofs.
Anthony Provost, Sioux Indian chief, who traveled all over the world with Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show, died today in his home here. He was 85 years old.

Governor Lehman announced yesterday the selection of Michael J. Walsh of Brooklyn, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, for Secretary of State to succeed Edward J. Flynn, who dedined reappointment because of ill health.

Combining the stories from two previous films, Warners today placed on schedule "Floating Paradine" as a vehicle for Ann Sheridan. The yarn, which is being adapted by Anthony Coldeway, deals with a girl on a gambling boat. Parts of "The House on 56th Street," which Kay Francis made in 1933, and "Gambling Lady," in which Barbara Stanwyck appeared in 1934, will form the dramatic structure.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 24 amounted to 574,462 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 31,852 cars, or 5.3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 116,641 cars, or 25.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 12,244 cars, or 2.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.
extension of the brisk advance among the secondary and medium grade railroad issues was the feature yesterday of the year's last full trading session in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange.

President Roosevelt was advised today that "all records for volume of PWA construction within a comparable period" had been broken in the six months since Congress authorized the spending of $1,800,000,000 on public works, provided they could be contracted for and started by Jan. 1 and substantially finished by June 30, 1940.

Henry Mazza, commander of David Latkin Post, 1,176 of the American Legion in the Bronx, denied yesterday that the post's executive committee had endorsed opposition to the stand taken by National Commander Stephen F. Chadwick that it would be inimical to the welfare of the nation to provide asylum for refugees in the United States.

Augustine L. Rafter, who retired nine years ago after serving twenty-five years as assistant school superintendent in Boston, died today at his home in Dorchester. He was 79 years old. Born in Damariscotta, Me.. he attended Holy Cross College and Boston College and was graduated from the latter in 1882. In 1892 he received an M. A. from Boston College.

Dr. Hugh Mercer Blain, former newspaper man and founder of the Departments of Journalism at Tulane, Louisiana State and Loyola Universities, died here today at the age of 63. Dr. Blain received a leave of absence from Loyola last June because of ill health.

A rousing rally in the closing mrinutes that had a crowd of 18,039 rocking the rafters of Madison Square Garden with the bedlam of its applause gave St. John's a spectacular victory over Colorado last night as the Redmen scored two baskets in the last two minutes for a sensational 39-to-37 triumph.
Representatives of potato growers in twenty-seven major producing States debated today whether they should recommend government regulation of the marketing of their crop next year.

Share prices moved irregularly higher yesterday in the penultimate session of the year. Last minute tax selling "for cash" and profittaking in many of the leaders of Thursday's bull market combined to produce an irregular market throughout the day.

Grand Concourse, 1.560 (11-2821): Moro Realty Corp to Scherman Development Corp. 4.701 5th Ave, Brooklyn; installments, 6 per cent; $15,000. Eagle Ave, 585 to 589 (10-2616): Specialty Paper Bag Co to Metropolitan Savings Bank; installments, 4 per cent; $22,000.

With its sharpshooting trio, Captain Walter Foertsch, George Polzer and Jim Bennett, popping in goals from all angles of the court, Cornell University's basketball team crushed Baldwin-Wallace College, 54 to 36, tonight.

Mrs. Jane Herland Reidenbach, who was married eight days ago to Allan K. Reidenbach, former millwork company executive, shot and killed herself late this afternoon in her new home at 239 South Columbus Avenue here, according to police. She was 34 years old.

Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee plans to give his committee's attention first to amendments of the Social Security Act in the coming session, and defer taxation studies until Spring, he said today.

The Great American Prospectors Association urged the Federal Government today to raise the price of domestic silver to $1.29 an ounce. The government now pays 64.64 cents, compared with a world price of about 43 cents. The statutory value of the white metal is $1.29.

70th St, 135-45 W; to 8-story meeting rooms; Greater Pythian Temple Association of N Y, premises, owner; Thomas W. Lamb, Inc, architect; cost, $17,000. 3d Ave. 626: to 4-story tenement and store; Conrad Metterle, 232-22 143d Ave, Laurelton, L I, owner; G. Dress, architect; cost. $8.000.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by te Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Allocation of $135,000,000 of Federal-aid highway funds to the States for road improvement and grade-crossing elimination in the next fiscal year was announced today by Secretary Wallace. The funds were authorized by the Federal Highway Law and consist of $100,000,000 for highways, including extentions through cities; $15,000,000 for secondary or feeder roads and $20,000,000 for eliminating grade crossings.

Expecting a crowd of 50,000, Santa Anita Park tonight stood in readiness for the opening of its fifth meeting tomorrow. Feature race on the program will be the $10,000 added California Breeders championship at one mile.

New bond financing during the final week of the year was restricted exclusively to tax-exempt securities with eleven individual issues placed on the market for publie subscription in the aggregate amount of $22,554,000.

The problem of customer com plaints will be studied by store managers attending the twenty-eighth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania Jan. 16 to 20.

Tony Canzoneri advanced along the comeback trail at the New York Hippodrome last night. The Brooklyn veteran, who previously held the featherweight, junior lightweight and lightweight championships of the world, pounded out a convincing triumph over Eddie Zivic of the fighting Pittsburgh family in a ten-round bout which featured the card in the historic theatre.
Treasury agents seized smuggled opium and heroin worth about $100,000 on the Italian steamer Arsa, in Savannah today, Treasury officials said.

Leonard Dodson shot a 69 in the first round of the fifty-four hole Houston open golf tournament today to put in the shade such stars as Sammy Snead and Jimmy Demarket, who were in a seven-way tie for twentieth place.
Mexican tennis players won four out of five matches today to take a 6--3 lead over their Texas rivals in their international series. The teams split the opening day's program, 2-2, yesterday.
Making his eighth goal of the game in a sudden-death overtime session, Christian led the Cornell polo team to a 15-to-14 victory over the First Cavalry riders tonight.

Frank D. Comerford, chairman of the New England Power Association, said yesterday in a message to shareholders accompanying January preferred dividend checks that there have been many indications of substantial business improvement in the association's territory in the past two months.

Although the New York Stock Exchange, the New York Curb Exchange, the Commodity Exchange, Inc.; the Chicago Board of Trade and other important financial and commodity Exchanges throughout the country will be open for the short session today, certain commodity markets in this city will observe a three-day holiday starting today.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The year is ending in the wool market on a cheerful tone in spite of the political difficulties confronting the trade.

Emile Mond, a chemist who in 1919 established the Francis Mond Professorship in Aeronautical Engineering at Cambridge University in memory of his eldest son, who was killed flying in the World War, died today. His age was 73.
This afternoon Governor Lehman will take for the fourth time his oath of office. At the end of his term he will have served ten years. That is a rare, indeed it may be fairly called a unique, record.

The Catholic newspaper Germania, official organ of the Catholic Centrist party during the Weimar regime and for a half century before that the most influential Catholic newspaper under the monarchy, ceases publication with today's issue.
Miss L. C. White's Good Omen got the nod in a four-horse photo finish today in the feature race at the Fair Grounds. This claiming event, for 3-year-olds and upward, was over the six-furlong course.

William Valentine Alexander, a real estate operator and former newspaper and magazine editorial executive, died at his home in Wayne today after an illness of two weeks. He was 79 years old. Mr. Alexander was a former managing editor of The Ladies Home Journal and before that had been for some years with The Boston Transcript.

A debutante party unusual in form-a luncheon with dancingwas given yesterday at Sherry's by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Everett Grant of 994 Fifth Avenue and Bernardsville, -N. J., and Sanford Robinson. of Greenwich, to introduce their respective daughters, Miss Nancibelle Grant and Miss Ruth Robinson.
The following forecast for the Winter sports areas was issued yesterday by the local Weather Bureau: Maine and White Mountain District-Snow flurries and much colder; tomorrow probably fair and cold.
Sherman Page Allen, who served in 1910 and 1911 as assistant secretary to President Taft and in the next two years as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, died today. He was 63 years old.

Announcement of the award of honorary membership in the Zeta ing Beta Tau fraternity to Professor Felix Frankfurter of Harvard University; Edward Lazansky, presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Deapartment;

The dollar value of sales on national securities exchanges fell in November, amounting to ,1,446,052,343, a decrease of 16.9 per cent compared with October and 2.9 per cent below November, 1937, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Sales of stocks,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Paul Starrett in his letter to THE TIMES seems to overlook the elemental difference between the functions and objectives of private financial institutions and those of the State.

Publication of the fourth half-yearly statement of the position of the British Exchange Equalization Fund tonight reveals that gold holdings last Sept. 30 amounted to [Pound]690,000,000, compared with [Pound]835,000,000 March 31 and [Pound]815,000,000 Sept. 30, 1937.

Formation of a new Schenley sales ' territory, the mid-Atlantic region, to handle business in New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware and the District of Columbia, was announced yesterday by J. L. Leban, general sales executive of Schenley Distillers Corporation.

Trading was active to slow in local markets yesterday. The veal market showed strength for the first time in several weeks and lamb carcasses were also slightly stronger. The pork loin market weakened considerably, but other fresh Pork cuts as well as other classes were unchanged from Thursday. The kosher markets opened with veal sharply higher;beef steady; lamb stronger. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Senator and Mrs. Morris Sheppard of Texas gave a dinner dance tonight in the Garden Room at the Mayflower Hotel to present to their friends in ashington their daughter, Miss Lucille Sheppard.

MANHATTAN APPELL, LOUISA (Dec. 21). Estate, more than $10,000. To Wilhelmina Appell, daughter, and Edward J. Appell, son, both of 242 W. 10th St., executors, equally. LOWASSEY, ROSE (Nov. 30). Estate, $1,800. To Emilie Weiss, sister; Torok Szentmiklos, Battanyi utcza szam 112, Hungary, residue. Theresa Opermann, 755 Oakland PI., Bronx, and James Buzasz, 313 E. 14th St., executors.
The mail volume and postal revenues of the 1938 Christmas period were the highest in the history of the Postal Service, Postmaster General Farley said today.

Edward Sheldon and Margaret Ayer Barnes, authors of the "Dishonored Lady," which United States Circuit Court recently held to have been plagiarized in the motion picture "Letty Lynton," received awards of $532,153.48 for damages yesterday from Federal Judge Vincent L. Liebell.
Byron Wall Anderson, descendant of George Taylor, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, died yesterday in his home here after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for the first week of the new year totals only $6,777,572, to be represented by twenty-seven municipalities, compared with the revised total of $18.734,920 for this week.

A total of 53,084 pre-marital blood tests has been made in the laborastories of the city's Department of Health since a State law requiring proof of freedom from venereal disease on the part of applicants for a marriage license went into effect last Summer, it was announced yesterday.

Transferring his practice sessions from the canvas surface of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn to the board floor of Rip's Indoor Tennis Courts on Park Avenue, Ellsworth Vines gave a convincing demonstration of his tremendous hitting power yesterday as he prepared for his match with Donald Budge at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night.

The cooperation shown by the universities and colleges of the United States in the nation-wide drive on syphilis and gonorrhea was lauded yesterday by Dr. Raymond Vondelehr, Assistant Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, speaking before the nineteenth annual convention of the American Student Health Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

Major Henry G. Opdycke of the Hotel Ansonia, a civil engineer who specialized in problems concerning vibration, died of pneumonia yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old. During construction of the first subway, Major Opdycke advised city departments and contractors about questions of vibration and concussion in connection with adjoining properties.

A. P. Giannini, founder of the Transamerica Corporation, said today that he would force to quick trial a suit charging fraudulent use of the corporation's money. He issued a formal statement which, he said, answered attacks on his personal integrity.

Dartmouth overseas by scored a 4-0 hockey victory over Williams as the two undefeated teams, each with three triumphs, battled before 1,350 in the fifth game of the Playland Casino intercollegiate series tonight.

The possibility that the causes of Joseph A. Sisto's expulsion from the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, added to previous abuses of broken control over investment trusts, will move the Securities and Exchange Commission to seek Federal legislation segregating brokerage from trust activities was seen yesterday by SEC officials.

In line with Germany's intensified armament race and the degree to which it is hampered by a growing labor shortage, Minister of Labor Franz Seldte issued new labor decrees today permitting exceptions to the eight-hour work day law and the rest provisions for Sundays and holidays.

The Spanish Government destroyer Jose Luis Diez, driven aground in Catalan Bay, near Gibraltar, in a battle this morning with Insurgent warships, was successfully refloated today by three British Admiralty tugs.

Because of the desire of bidders to obtain the tax-exempt securities for various reasons, the Treasury today marketed its regular offering of about $100,000,000 of ninety-oneday discount bills at a premium of $557. All bids received were at par or above par.

Fire tonight damaged the white brick colonial home of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., a student at the University of Virginia Law School, while he and Mrs. Roosevelt were away on a holiday vacation. The blaze started in a garage attached to the rear of the house and spread through part of the lower floor and the half-story above before being brought under control.
Another plot in the vicinity of th World's Fair grounds has been purchased for improvement with a multi-family dwelling in one of the Queens realty deals reported yesterday.

Year-end bargain offerings by wholesalers were scarce this week and increasing evidence of low stocks heralded an auspicious opening for the new year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly review.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 30, unless specified: Helm, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Dec. 28. Henderson, Woosung to Chinwangtao. Kewaydin, Yorktown to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk.

A prediction that excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System will rise about $900,000,000 in the five weeks ending on Jan. 25 is made in the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, published yesterday. Such an increase would carry the total of excess reserves to about $3,900,000,000, a high record.

Harry A. Moul, an engineer with the Philadelphia Housing Association for fifteen years, died on Tuesday at his home here in his forty-seventh year. He was born in Hanover, Pa., and was graduated from the University of Michigan in 1916.

Dr. and Mrs. Barclay Acheson of 800 Riverside Drive have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Louise Acheson, to Frederick Delos Thompson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thompson, also of this city.

A blanket order permitting John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor investigating charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, to take prisoners from any city prison or correctional hospital and question them anywhere in the city was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Francis D. McCurn in Brooklyn, who was designated by Governor Lehman to preside over the inquiry.

About 150,000 major and minor jobs will ti fall into the hands of Republicans h of the country as the result of winning fourteen new Governorships , and capturing offices in over 400 county seats, according to an estimate of the Republican National Committee, which is now weighing the effect of the November victory in the terms of building up the organization for the 1940 election.

Once more Iran, that Persian kingdom in Western Asia, has decided that it does not appreciate the French journalistic sense of humor, and for the second time within two years it has emphasized this by breaking off diplomatic relations with France over newspaper articles.

Edward C. Carrington, retired business man and lawyer who was prominent in Republican activities for many years, died this afternoon at his home on St. Paul Street, after a heart attack. He was 66 years old.
For the first time since Germany lodged its protest ten days ago with the United States State Department against Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior,
The former world champion, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, played to a draw with L. Szabo

Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Muir of 160 East Seventy-second Street gave a tea dance yesterday in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Eleanor Warfield Muir. A silver and pink decor was effected for the ballroom.

The scheduled dismissal tonight of 223 employes of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department has been canceled and the employes are to be retained "temporarily" pending reorganization of the division, it was learned yesterday.

Larry Knohl, 33 years old, an auctioneer and- active in Republican politics in Suffolk County, was found guilty yesterday by a jury in Federal Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, on an indictment charging two counts of embezzlement. Knohl will be sentenced next Friday.

Hungary will maintain her independence while continuing her foreign policy based on the Rome-Berlin axis, Premier Bela Imredy dedared in a speech today announcing the government's policy for the new year.

The President Roosevelt of the United States Lines is due today from the Channel ports. Among her passengers are Marion Miller, F. M. Withers and E. G. Bookout. The Brazil of the American Republics Line is sailing today for f Brazil and Argentina.

Over three centuries ago Anthony van Leeuwenhoek saw strange sights in a drop of water through a powerful small lens of his own making. Just as the ocean was alive, so this drop teemed with wriggling, swimming, fighting, voracious creatures.

Trained economists plumbed the business indexes today at the joint meeting of the American Statistical Association and the American Marketing Association. They forecast an - upsurge of business and industry in 1939, with the automobile industry well in the van.

Discovery of the existence of a specific unit of heredity which appears to increase the rate of change of the entire heredity mechanism, and may have played a very important part in speeding up the process of evolution,
Peace came to the Saugatuck Valley today as the last legal barrier to the construction of a reservoir by the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company was removed.

The Westchester County Board of Supervisors adopted today a county tax equalization table for 1939 which, compared with this year's, was said to place a larger total tax on each city and town in Westchester County except Pelham and Rye. The vote was 30 to 7.
Led by a Peoria boy, Captain ChuckKellogg, the Yale basketball team, making its first tour west of Ohio, fell before Bradley Tech, 53 to 30, before a crowd of 5,000 tonight.

A sevenman conservation commission to supervise all Maryland conservation activities wras recommended as men from all parts of the State met here :yesterday to draw up a comprehensive program to be submitted to the Legislature.
Within the next few days the Administration is expected to submit its own plan for "removing the suspicion of politics" from Federal relief of unemployment.

A campaign to give Florida's Grapefruit League the status of official competition was under way today following announcement this week of the first schedules for major league exhibition baseball games on the Spring circuit.

The Duke and Southern California football teams today slowed preparations for their encounter Monday in the Rose Bowl. An air of quiet confidence issued from each camp after today's workout, but predictions on the outcome of this twenty-fourth annual struggle were carefully wrapped with reservations.

Albert G. Gaum of, Winchester, Mass., a former Yale student, was held under $10;000 bond for trial Jan. 10 on a charge of burglary. Police of Yale University campus and New Haven City identified him at the railroad station early this morning.

The marriage of Miss Doris Bjorn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Bjorn of Barre, to Jay Te Winburn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Winburn of 399 Park Avenue, New York, took place here this afternoon in the First Universalist Church.

Vice President Garner was becoming more and more today the leading actor in pre-Congress manoeuvring as persons with knotty problems, both in the Administration and on Capitol Hill, made bee-lines to his office to seek his counsel and advice. It had come to the point where the most oft-repeated question of the "hill" was:

Contracts totaling nearly $500,000 for equipment and repairs to the city's public elementary and high schools were voted yesterday at a special Board of Education meeting-the final one for 1938. Covered in the awards were funds for electribal work, fire-proofing, sanitary equipment and lights.

Mr. and Mrs. William Halsted Vander Poel and Miss Wendy Vander Poel gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Dorothy Aylesworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merlin Hall Aylesworth, and her fiance, Robert G. Knott, whose marriage will take place Wednesday in St. Bartholomew's Church.

A first mortgage of $80,000 has been obtained by the Paul Hammond Company on the three-story building at 3,376 Fenton Avenue, the Bronx, from the Dollar Savings Bank for the M. J. H. Realty Corportion. The loan runs for five years and carries interest of 41/2 cent.

With the college section of the American Federation of Teachers under attack by -some members of the faculty of Teachers College, Dr. Franz Boas, Professor Emeritus of Anthropology at Columbia University and former president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, applied for membership in the union yesterday.

The eighth Pan-American Conference changed Pan-Americanism from an idealistic dream into a practical reality, in the opinion of President Oscar Raimundes Benavides of Peru. In an interview with this correspondent this afternoon the President expressed the enthusiastic opinion that the Lima conference was one of the most successful of all Pan-American conferences.

LONDON, Jan. 9.--The large transfer of gold to the exchange fund reassured the stock markets today and a spurt in gilt-edge stocks set the pace for a small general improvement.

LONDON, Jan. 9.--In one of the most remarkable feats of roadbuilding in history the Chinese have driven a road from Chunking 1,400 miles to the Burmese border and so provided themselves with a completely practicable route for munitions and other supplies, which can be landed at Rangoon and other places in Burma and taken into the war area.

Frank Irvin was elected to the board of governors for a three-year term, and Mr. Peterson was retained as a governor.

Sixty skiing enthusiasts who, for business or financial reasons, are unable to take the ski trains to New England waxed their runners yesterday and went to Central Park. They straightway ran afoul of the law.

George E. Palmer, secretary manager of the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association, reports total resources of $10,447,957 at the close of 1938. Savings receipts in 1938 were 77 per cent over 1937, he said.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J.--Next week-end will find a group of the nation's leading squash players here for the tenth annual Atlantic Coast Squash Racquets championship for men on the courts of Haddon Hall.

A Federal aid to education bill of 1939, sponsored by Senators Harrison and Thomas, is ready for the present Congress.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 14.-- The Williams hockey team handed Army its first defeat of the season tonight in the cadet rink, scoring by 2--0.

BERLIN, Jan. 14.--Johann Strauss, orchestral conductor, died here today at the age of 73. He was the son of Eduard Strauss, conductor of the Vienna count balls, whom he succeeded for some years. He was a nephew of Johann Strauss, the "waltz king." After leaving Vienna he settled here and toured with his own orchestra, interpreting Strauss music.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation yesterday filed a libel in Brooklyn Federal Court against the 200-ton schooner Anna Sophia, whose owner is listed as Frank T. Lang of 69-01 Metropolitan Avenue, Maspeth, Queens. The libel was filed in a proceeding to foreclose two mortgages which the RFC holds on the schooner.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark.--This Federal-owned Spa will again join other communities throughout the nation in celebrating President Roosevelt's birthday, Jan. 30. There will be balls at the Arlington, Eastman and Majestic Hotels and the Club Belvedere.

Patrolman Charles Benesh, 41 years old, of 67-30 Fifty-second Road, Maspeth, Queens, a member of the force since 1921, and Joseph Esposito, 21, a laborer, of 107-24 Corona Avenue, Corona, Queens, were arrested yesterday morning at the home of Mrs. Ethel Block, 4550 Forty-eighth Street, Woodside, Queens, on charges growing out of the theft of a diamond ring which Mrs. Block valued at $300.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 14. --Gold production in Nicaragua increased 50 per cent in 1938. United States and Canadian interests bought many mines in the interior and on the east coast of Nicaragua and production this year is expected to increase 50 to 100 per cent.

PARIS. JUDGING by the data available the 1939 stylescape will be gay and gallant. Like that of the eighteenth century, from which it will "borrow so many plumes," it will unite grandeur and frivolity; a taste for the panache and a love of mathematical precision. Inspired by French Revolutionary engravings, outlines will grow more dramatic and colors more intense.

ROME, Jan. 14.--Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain left Rome at noon today, taking back to London no more than he had brought with him but also committed to nothing more than when he came here. British emphasis is laid on the lack of further commitments. There had been some apprehension on this point after Munich.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 14 (AP).--Three hundred refugee Jews from Germany and Italy who were on their way to make new homes in Paraguay found themselves stranded in Montevideo today as the Paraguayan Government canceled their visas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--Amid increasing evidence that the House's rebellion against the Administration's spending policies had spread to the other end of the Capitol, the Senate's Special Committee on Unemployment and Relief came forward today with a program for a wholesale revision of the entire Federal relief system so as to put it on a permanent basis and insulate it from partisan politics.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Jan. 14.-- New combinations of subjects at Swarthmore College may be chosen by juniors and seniors studying under the honors system, under a new policy in the divisions of humanities and social sciences. The purpose is to stress integration of subjectmatter rather than adherence to strict departmental lines.

A public hearing on the possibility of giving WPA teachers credit toward their regular New York City public school licenses will be held at 500 Park Avenue Jan. 31 at 8 P.M., James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, announced yesterday. The WPA teachers seek credit for the work they are doing in the WPA school projects.

Mme. Alex Dupont, French widow, held the winning ticket for the 1,000,000-franc prize in the September drawing of the national lottery. The chief difficulty to collecting was that she couldn't find the ticket.

The New York League of Girls Clubs, Inc., celebrated its fiftyfourth anniversary last night with a dinner at Stouffer's, 540 Fifth Avenue, attended by more than 100 women. The league is one of the oldest non-sectarian organizations for business girls of the city.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 14.--The Navy led Duke, 15--14, as the first half of their basketball game closed today, but Ed Swindell and Rush Bergman led a devastating attack which put Duke ahead, 20 to 18, four minutes after the resumption of play and resulted in a final verdict of 44 to 37 in Duke's favor.

The ninth defendant charged with perjury as an outgrowth of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's investigation into the selection of a Kings County grand jury panel was remanded to Brooklyn city prison yesterday when he was unable to raise $2,500 bail. Eight defendants now are at liberty on similar bail.

ATLANTA, Jan. 14.--Trade declined in the Sixth Federal Reserve District last week. Department store sales were 4.9 per cent below the previous week and 4.8 per cent under those for the correspoding period a year ago. In Atlanta, department store trade was 8 per cent down from the previous week and 2.1 per cent below last year.

Benjamin Franklin's birthday was Jan. 17. Perhaps the reason why its anniversary was not celebrated last Tuesday, or on the corresponding date in former years, is that Franklin did not survive into the period of our national history; he died exactly one year after Washington's first inauguration. Nevertheless, his personality is probably more familiar to the average American than that of any public man in our past save Lincoln.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21.-- Pilots change tomorrow on The Yale Daily News, the oldest college daily newspaper in the country, as the sixteen members of the 1940 board take over the helm from the retiring board of 1939.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 21. --In a general survey of the financial and economic prospects of the Australian Commonwealth, R.G. Casey, the Treasurer, states that the reasonably optimistic statements in the budget of last September are true today. The internal position is remarkably good.
