CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 21-- Seventeen juniors and seniors in electrical engineering at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, selected for their ability to do independent study without course credits, have been tested for the last two weeks in a series of comprehensive written and oral examinations conducted by a corps of examiners including men from other universities and outside industries.
Led by Jack Fink, who collected six goals, Evergreen Farms conquered the Winged Foot team, 12--9, to feature last night's indoor polo triple-header at the Squadron C Armory.

In its sixth annual report just presented to Congress, the Federal Home Loan Bank board urges the elimination of labor's jurisdictional disputes and advises a revision of building industry practices so as to "give the home buyer more value for his dollar."

THE most successful convention in the twenty-three-year history of the National Aero nautic Association closed last week in St. Louis after three days of study and discussion of aviation's problems. A feeling that aviation had made large gains during the last year was evident at every turn.

DETROIT, Jan. 21(AP)--A Statewide strike of union truck drivers Monday was announced tonight by J.M. O'Laughlin, president of the drivers' union. Previously Governor Fitzgerald had intervened in the hope of preventing the strike, the result of a jurisdictional dispute between two American Federation of Labor unions.

SINCE the Rattle Watch, 280 years ago, patrolled New Amsterdam from the southern tip of Manhattan to the northern boundary at Wall Street, New York City's paid policemen have undergone a series of unsubtle evolutions. The Rattle Watch was a squad of eight sorry-looking Dutchmen who carried muskets or fowling pieces slung across their backs as they slogged their muddy beats, smoking long-stemmed porcelain pipes.

Although confidence is fairly general that business will register a 15 to 20 per cent upturn this year, the Spring selling campaign that will be launched by national advertisers next month and in March is only moderately larger than those of last year, according to opinions expressed by sales and advertising managers last week.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 21 (AP).--Word was received here today of the death in Fort Myers, Fla., of Charles Shumway Ruffner, electrical engineer and chairman of the board of directors of the Schenectady Trust Company. His age was 58.

While steamships, cutters and patrol boats were converging on the scene where the Cavalier was down at sea, army, navy and Coast Guard airplanes made a valiant but unsuccessful effort yesterday to aid the search for the flying boat and, if conditions permitted, make a record-breaking air rescue at sea.

BERLIN, Jan. 21.--The brownshirted Nazi Storm Troopers were today charged by Chancellor Adolf Hitler with "the defense education and training" of all German men over 17 who are not in military service or who do not receive this "education" through their connection with some other party organization such as the Hitler Elite Guard or the National Socialist Flying Corps.

At a number of the larger flower shows many visitors have had their first glimpse of the oddly flowered Shrimp-plant, Beloperone guttata. HAMILTON, Bermuda.--The thirty-six-hole team tournament for the Spey Royal Tro phy, an annual event, takes place today over the Belmont Manor golf course with a large entry of visiting and local players.

Next Thursday is the day for the final closing of entries for the sixty-third annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club to be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 13 to 15, inclusive. Once more the total number of entries to be accepted will be approximately 3,000.

Specialty shops so far have taken the lead in the buying of women's Spring apparel, trade reports here yesterday indicated. WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--A competition to select an architect for the new Smithsonian Gallery of Art here was announced today. The Smithsonian Gallery of Art Commission issued also a description of the objectives sought in the structure if and when Congress provides funds to build it.

MONTREAL, Que.--Slalom and downhill races to be held by the Sutton Ski Club next Sun day mark the season's opening of this Eastern township, approximately seventy miles from Montreal and near the United States border, to competitive skiing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--The way of an economizer in Con-- gress is hard. The way of a spender is easy. Behind the economizers at the moment there probably is a large national majority, but it is unorganized and only occasionally audible. Behind the spenders is constantly a group of active, vocative minorities, fully and completely organized and expert in "turning on the heat." With these pro-spending minorities the President now is ranged, as often before.

Roche, the 93-year-old local Overseer of the Poor, died this afternoon of a heart attack soon after distributing relief orders at his office in the Municipal Building. In the Manhattan realty deals made known yesterday two large apartment house properties close to Riverside Drive and a dwelling on the West Side passed into new ownership.

Lee Ephraim and A.L. Berman, theatrical attorney, left last night for Hollywood to look for a cast and a director for a production in New York of "The Widow With the Pink Gloves," written by Maurice De Kobra and based on the author's novel of the same name.

Herman Speier of 393 West End Avenue, a retired insurance man who had been executive secretary of the United Rumanian Jews of America since 1923, died Sunday evening in the Fordham Hospital after collapsing in the street from a heart attack a few hours earlier. He was born in Iassy, Rumania, sixty-seven years ago.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28.--Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld gave a small dinner tonight for Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks and Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Kountze Douglas. Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Barmore Maclay were entertained by Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Terry with a tea at the Terry residence.
Librarianship everywhere is an underpaid profession. It will probably never be rewarded in proportion to the training and the natural gifts it demands.

LONDON, Jan. 23.--In the firmest speech he has made in months, former Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden replied tonight to Italian and German threats against France by urging Britain and France to show "unshaken firmness" in defense of their own interests in the Mediterranean and elsewhere.

The site of the old Fitzgerald Building and the George M. Cohan Theatre, on the southeast corner of Broadway and Forty-third Street will be improved with a three-story building and a 600-seat motion picture theatre if preliminary plans filed yesterday are carried through. Demolition of the present structure is well under way.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--An estate exceeding $10,000,000 was left by George Horace Lorimer, editor of The Saturday Evening Post, at his death on Oct. 22, 1937, it was revealed today in an inventory filed with the Register of Wills of Montgomery County, at Norristown.
The British freighter Silverash, scheduled to sail for Manila with a general cargo yesterday morning, was destroyed by an early morning fire at its pier at the foot of Fiftyseventh Street, Brooklyn.

A three-alarm fire, which started with flames followed by an explosion in a dry-cleaning shop at 45-44 Forty-sixth Street, Long Island City, Queens, swept through sixteen one-story shops and stores on Forty-sixth Street and Greenpoint Avenue early today. It was unofficially estimated that the damage might reach $250,000.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23.--When competitive golf becomes anything more than fun to Miss Patty Berg she will quit--if she follows the advice of her father --but thus far she has found it plenty of fun.

ROME, Jan. 23.--Premier Mussolini began his talks with Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain with this statement: "I do not want war, because I am not sure what the effect would be on my regime and because I am sure what the effect would be on European civilization."

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 28.--After having insisted earlier that the Palestine Arab Defense party be fully represented on the Palestinian Arab delegation to the forthcoming London conference, the British Government accepted tonight the position of the Mufti of Jerusalem and the Defense party will not be represented.

Preliminary steps in the formation of an association of customers' men were taken at a meeting yesterday of an organizing committee consisting of representatives from New York Stock Exchange firms at the Columbia University Club.

New fears of an imminent outbreak of war in Europe swept through the international money markets yesterday to give the foreign exchanges the worst tossing they have had since Germany and Czecho-Slovakia faced each other last September.

DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 23 (Canadian Press).--Breaking a deadlock in the series, England today defeated South Africa in the third cricket test by an innings and 13 runs. Eight thousand saw the match end a day ahead of schedule. Previous tests at Johannesburg and Cape Town had ended in stalemates.

Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn endorsed yesterday the plan announced by Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority, for a bridge between the Battery and Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The Democratic majority in the House restored a $3,500,000 cut which had been effected by the Republicans in the First Deficiency Bill today and passed the $9,979,000 measure.

A meat salesman and an insurance broker were chosen yesterday as two of the blue-ribbon jurors who will try James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, on charges of participating in the policy racket that the murdered Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer dominated.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 23.--Virtually dormant as Winter sports centers since the recordbreaking 1936 season, the Bear Mountain and Harriman areas of the Palisades Interstate Park once again have become popular with metropolitan ice and snow enthusiasts.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 23.--The advance of socialism in Chilean politics was revealed beyond question in yesterday's elections for three members of the Chamber of Deputies. More than two-thirds of the votes in Santiago Province went to the Socialist candidate, a bookmaker, Gerardo Lopez.

A heavy accumulation of selling orders, most of them originating in Europe, greeted the stock market at the opening yesterday, and initial prices were down fractions to more than 2 points from Saturday's final quotations.

BARCELONA, Spain, Jan. 23.-- Despite bombings and the approach of the Insurgents, the temporary United States Embassy at Caldetas, about twenty-five miles northeast of Barcelona, remains open. Walter C. Thurston, Counselor of the Embassy, continues working for the State Department and for the American colony here.

ROME, Jan. 26.--Exultantly addressing a cheering crowd of scores of thousands, gathered outside the Palazzo Venezia to celebrate the fall of Barcelona, Premier Benito Mussolini indicated quite clearly this evening that the march of the Italian legionaries would not end in the capital of Catalonia.

The guilder was pounded again by selling in the foreign exchange market yesterday. While other exchanges showed only moderate weakness the guilder plunged to 53.86 cents, its cheapest price since the Czecho-Slovak crisis last September, and closed at 53.88 cents, off 12 points.

Garland Day and John A. Donlon were appointed assistant trust officers of the Public National Bank and Trust Company of New York at a meeting of directors, E. Chester Gersten, president, announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 26.--The Education Committees of both Houses today introduced the School Centralization Bill sponsored by the State Department of Education.

Probably the beating he took at the hands of Joe Louis disturbed John Henry Lewis's cerebral functions. Then again, John Henry Lewis may be the bravest boxer in the world. At any rate, there can't be any other explanation for what John Henry said yesterday at the New York Hippodrome.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--The position of the United States in the Far East could be stabilized and assured for the predictable future by the establishment of a powerful advanced fleet base at Guam comparable to the British base at Singapore, Rear Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn told the House Naval Affairs Committee today.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 26.--Attorneys for four more of the thirteen defendants on trial here before Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flan-- nagan and a fourteen-man Jury on charges of conspiring to defraud the city of Newark through purchases of river front meadowland, made their opening addresses to the jury today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--Some 2,500,000 rural families face loss of twenty-four-hour telephone service unless the Wages and Hours Law can be amended or Elmer F. Andrews, administrator, changes his present ruling so that these companies will be exempt from the law,

Complete fields for the various special events at the Prout Memorial Games at the Boston Garden tomorrow night were revealed yesterday and the program looks as brilliant as any ever drawn up for the meet. Indubitably this will get the major season off to a flying start.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--Wholesalers of cotton textiles here admit that January has been disappointing as to sales, but, nevertheless, are confident of better business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--Amendments to extend and tighten the provisions of the Walsh-Healey act, which sets standards of employment by companies having government contracts, were introduced in the Senate and House today by Senator Walsh and Representative Healey.
The Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in the annual statement for 1938, consolidated profits of $4,317,000, after interest, depreciation, taxes and other charges.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 16. --Vasile Christescu, a leader of the Fascist Iron Guard, committed suicide this afternoon, turning his revolver upon himself after having wounded a detective in a party that had cornered him.

PORT DEPOSIT, Md., Jan. 26 (AP).--Dr. Joseph I. France, former United States Senator, was found dead in bed today by servants at his home. He was 65 years old. His physician said Dr. France apparently had died of a heart attack in his sleep.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 26 (AP).--Newell Sanders, industrialist and former United States Senator, died tonight in his home on Lookout Mountain here, at the age of 88. He had been in failing health for several years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--American Red Cross, army and commercial air line facilities today were placed at the disposal of the Chilean Government as official reports to the State Department from Ambassador Norman Armour at Santiago placed the number of earthquake disaster victims at 8,000 dead and 20,000 injured at Chillan alone.

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer was not only aware that F. Donald Coster was really an exconvict named Philip Musica, but was associated with him in illegal liquor dealings from 1927 until the gangster's murder eight years later, it was disclosed yesterday at the Federal Building.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 26.--Sidney Morse, 64, of Darien, shot himself through the roof of the mouth soon after noon today in front of the Norwalk Hospital and died instantly.
PARIS, Jan. 26.--Premier Edouard Daladier told a cheering Chamber of Deputies tonight that France "will let no one touch her territorial integrity or her colonial empire or her free communications."

Deals for space in buildings in the midtown section of Manhattan yesterday included leases of quarters to art galleries.

Long Island University and St. John's will attempt to continue their basketball journey along parallel roads tonight when these two unbeaten quintets face strong outof-town teams in a double-header at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Jan. 26.--The British Empire is invincible and any "blind and foolish people" who think otherwise will have the shock of their lives, Sir Samuel Hoare, Home Secretary and a member of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's "Inner Cabinet," told a mass meeting at Swansea tonight.

The Cunard White Star liner Samaria will sail today for Galway and Liverpool. Among the passengers are J. Grierson Clayton, W.F. Court, Professor and Mrs. A.T. Davidson, Mr. and Mrs. James E. Keegan, Noel G. Moss, Dr. Henry Miller, Dr. F. Wilkie Smith and J.C.J. Wilson.

The dates for the hunts racing season were arranged and announced yesterday at a meeting of the hunts committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, which at the same session considered a number of concrete suggestions for the improvement of steeplechasing during the coming season.

A low temperature of 7 degrees combined yesterday with a biting northwest wind rushing in from the Canadian border Provinces to give New York City its coldest day of the Winter. As darkness fell midtown Manhattan had snow flurries.

ROME, Jan. 27.--What will happen next in Europe is anybody's guess.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27.--Trading in wheat futures today on the Board of Trade was very slow. Prices held within a range of about cent a bushel. Professional speculators were on the sidelines awaiting developments in the European political situation.

Plans for organizing the business interests of the city to "sell" New York to visitors to the World's Fair, and thus build up good-will for the city in other parts of the country, were advanced yesterday at a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street.

City officials joined Grower A. Whalers, president of the New York World's Fair yesterday in backing a proposed local law requiring the licensing and registration of all rooming houses for the protection of fair visitors.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP).--Lou Ambers, Former lightweight champion, half-blinded Paul Junior, 29-yearold Lewiston (Me.) veteran, with his accurate left and right hooks while coasting along to a unanimous ten-round decision tonight before 10,000 at the Boston Garden.

ROME, Jan. 27.--Alfonso and Victoria, exiled King and Queen of Spain, with their entire family made their first public gesture in favor of the Franco Government today when they attended a Te Deum in the National Spanish Church here to celebrate the taking of Barcelona.

Two sharp departures developed yesterday in the second trial of Tammany Leader James J. Hines as District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey began the presentation of evidence on which the charge that Nines was part of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket is based.

"THE LONG LANE," by Phil Stong, is a novel of midland America in a somewhat Tarkingtonian moon. The time is during the last completely insular years before the World War began; the scene is, of course, Mr. Stong's Iowa --and the characters are largely Iowans who talk as though they'd all studied repartee under the same teacher in New York.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 27.-- Charles Whitehead of South River, the New Jersey State champion, was defeated by Frank Allan of Pittston, Pa., at the thirty-seventh hole in the final round of the annual Florida Winter golf championship for the Ponce de Leon Cup over St. Augustine links today.

One hundred thousand jobs could be provided if the New York State budget were cut 25 per cent, Mrs. Andrew J. Noe, president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, said yesterday in making public an appeal to women's organizations to support the Statewide movement for a reduction in the 1939 State budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--President Roosevelt asked Speaker Bankhead for $50,000,000 appropriation to buy 565 army planes and revealed that he had given permission to France to buy military planes in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--An assertion that the Federal Government's inability to succeed in getting private industry to put men back to work endangered longrange prosperity in the United States was made today by the American Federation of Labor in its monthly Survey of business.
The victim rescued the attacker last night in a crime drama with a nautical flavor that centered about the coal barge Hollywood, tied up at Smith Street on the Gowanus Canal, Brooklyn.

Miss Henrietta A. Larkin gave a supper last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Carol Prichitt, daughter of Mrs. Tames Tilley Houghton and of the late Hugh Kirkman Prichitt, and Edward Godfrey Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Godfrey Miller of Havana, Cuba, whose marriage will take place Friday in the Church of the Resurrection.

Demetrios Callimahos, the young Greek flutist who has ere this won handsome recognition for his performances in this city, gave a recital when he had the collaboration of Walter Gieseking as composer and pianist, and of Paul Ulansky, pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall.

Too few voters know how to think straight, allowing labels and superficial side issues to interfere with intelligent judgment, it was charged yesterday at the second annual Metropolitan Conference on Adult Education at the Hotel Astor.

The first concrete indication of the policy to be followed by Colonel F.C. Harrington, newly appointed National Works Progress Administrator, in dealing with Workers Alliance demonstrations was given yesterday in telegrams to Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA chief, and other Federal relief executives throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--Friends and critics of Thomas R. Amlie, President Roosevelt's nominee to the Interstate Commerce Commission, were assured today of an opportunity of airing their views at a public hearing.

From all indications, this will be a record year for the placement of graduates from the New York City vocational high schools. Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation schools, predicted yesterday.

By the memorable brief in defense of the right of public assembly filed in the Hague case by the special committee on the Bill of Rights of the American Bar Association, that company of lawyers stirred wide public interest.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27.--Henry Jaffe of New Jersey, a former employe of the Moscow News, a Soviet English-language publication, is believed by persons who knew him to have been arrested a year or more ago.
A moderate improvement developed yesterday in the listed bond market. With many operators inclined to await further developments in the foreign situation, the volume was sharply curtailed.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27.--The nation's first stake race on grass, a racing surface familiar in some other countries but rather a rarity here, will be run at Hialeah tomorrow with twelve horses named for the $5,000 added purse. In other years the Miami Beach Handicap was a stake event, but it was not run on the turf.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27.--Real progress was made today in the international chess masters tournament when eight of the nine games scheduled for the sixteenth round were completed. In addition, ten of the games adjourned from earlier rounds were finished.
Robert Hallowell, publisher and artist, died suddenly Thursday of a heart attack in the Staten Island Hospital at New Brighton. He was 53 years old and lived at 178 Franklin Avenue, New Brighton.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 27.--Each of the warring factions which claims official leadership, of the United Automobile Workers of America made preparations today for staring a legal test when the Circuit Court will be asked tomorrow to decide the question of rightful possession of the union's treasury, offices and records.

In the first case under the drastic new statute against kidnapping in this State, Demetrius Gula and Joseph A. Sacoda, each 27 years old, were found guilty of kidnapping at 8:50 o'clock last night by a General Sessions jury which returned no recommendation for mercy. This makes death sentences mandatory for the two men.

The role of the Boy Scouts of America in helping to safeguard democracy will be emphasized in a program to be started next week by the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, Inc., it was announced yesterday by J. Stewart Baker, president of the foundation.

The annual Blue Ridge Ball for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Virginia took place last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The event drew an attendance of several hundred persons actively interested in philanthropic projects in this city and in Southern districts.

At the last election tie city voted for transit unification by an overwhelming majority. It did not vote for partial unification or crippled unification, but for a system of operation which would remain wholly in control of the city.

Local track stars will head in two directions today, some to the metropolitan A.A.U. championships at the new Jersey City Armory and others to the Prout Memorial games in the Boston Garden, where the major indoor campaign will get under way with a rush.

Capturing two individual crowns and the runner-up laurels in three other events, Erasmus Hall High School's well-balanced squad won the city P.S.A.L. swimming team title in the Columbia University pool last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27.-- With only a few assignments still unfilled, Selznick-International today completed the major portions of its cast, for "Gone With the Wind." The picture went before the cameras yesterday.

Denials that F. Donald Coster as head of the wholesale drug firm of McKesson Robbins was associated with Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in illegal liquor dealings during prohibition were made yesterday by Samuel Reich, attorney for the Coster-Musica family, and by one of Coster's three brothers who was associated with him in the firm.
Joe Louis has reached the stage in his ring career where he may have to undertake an exhibition tour to get the ring activity he needs.
BERLIN, Jan. 27.--Anticipating Chancellor Adolf Hitler's anxiously awaited speech before the Great German Reichstag Monday, Josef

SHANGHAI, Jan. 27 (AP).--Japanese reported today that Marshal Wu Pei-fu, most powerful of Chinese military leaders fifteen years ago, had accepted the Presidency of a new Japanese-sponsored entity intended to unite the regimes established by Japan in conquered Chinese territory.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27.-- Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer entertained today with a luncheon at Capricho in honor of Mrs. R. Jay Flick.

Sweeping in from the West like a fresh blast that collided violently with the gales swirling over Flatbush, Larry MacPhail, Brooklyn's fiery baseball czar, lost little time yesterday cracking the whip and letting folks know the Dodgers are getting ready for another campaign.

Returns to date indicate that the railroads in the United States, as a group, had gross revenues of $315,000,000 in December, the largest for that month in recent years with the exception of 1930 and 1936. The result compared with $300,320,821 in December, 1937, and $372,134,405 in December, 1936.
ALBANY, Jan. 27.--The first Democratic housing measure of the session made its appearance in the Legislature today, under the sponsorship of Assemblyman Robert F. Wagner Jr., and Senator Carl Pack.

TRYON, N.C., Jan. 27.--Stanford Tappan Crapo, retired railroad and bank director of Detroit, died at his home here last night following a brief illness. He was 73 years old. Services will be conducted Sunday in New Bedford, Mass., where he was born.
MONTREAL, Jan. 27.--Cecil Hart was given "leave of absence" as manager of the Canadiens today and replaced temporarily by Jules Dugal, secretary of the last place National Hockey League club.
Joseph H. De Bragga, Republican leader of Queens for a quarter of a century, died last evening in Bushwick Hospital of complications after an, operation. He was 72 years old.

ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., Jan. 27.--Miss Emmy-Lou Ruprecht, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Ruprecht of Englewood, celebrated their twentyfourth wedding anniversary today, was married here this afternoon to Bernard J. Salembier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Salembier, also of Englewood.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27.--An all-union Congress of the Soviet Russian Comunist party has been called for March 10 in a decision published today over the signature of Joseph Stalin as Secretary of the Central Committee.

Breaking by one degree the low temperature record of the Winter established Thursday, New York City yesterday had an official mercury reading of 6 degrees above zero. It was the coldest day the city has experienced in three years.

GRANTHAM, N.C., Jan. 27.--We were off to an early start this morning, but the wind had a headstart, so it was hardly what could be termed a favorable day for quail shooting. The wind not only blew hard but it was cold, and for about three hours it was difficult to convince us that we were really in the Sunny South.

ALBANY, Jan. 27.--Merchants would be compelled to see to it that marks of origin are displayed conspicuously on all merchandise sold over their counters under a bill introduced today in the Legislature by Assemblyman Denton D. Lake, Republican, of Fulton-Hamilton. Violation of the proposed law would be a misdemeanor.
Interviewed in the Hotel Astor's barber shop yesterday afternoon, the obliging Sam H. Harris touched upon various items:

BOSTON, Jan. 27.--Dr. Willard B. Segur of Ware, Mass., author of Dartmouth College's football song, "As the Backs Go Tearing By," and a Hampshire County public official, died today at the Deaconess Hospital after a two-month illness. His age was 73.

BETWEEN PERU AND PANAMA, Jan. 24.--The Peruvian Government has thrown a couple of monkey wrenches into the intricate machinery of Japanese penetration of Peru. The first jarred the commercial part of that machinery.

Essex Helmet, shown by the Essex Fox Hounds of Peapack, N.J., yesterday was awarded the American Foxhound Club Challenge Cup as the best American foxhound in the annual New York Hound Show held in the Squadron A Armory.

Changing times and "unprecedented" task of replanning and rebuilding entire neighborhoods have made it necessary for the real estate man and municipal officials to adopt a new approach to real estate uses and sound city development, in the opinion of E.L. Ostendort of Cleveland, Ohio, the new president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

LONDON, Jan. 27.--Arguing that it would be disastrous to increase Great Britain's already heavy burden of taxation, Reginald McKenna, chairman of the Midland Bank, declared at its stockholders' annual meeting yesterday that the government should meet additional expenditures on rearmament entirely by borrowing.
Trust funds established in 1911 with assets of $3,807,758 by the late William Rockefeller for the benefit of two daughters, Mrs. Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge and the late

Led by Tom McGorry and Jim Grubb, who made 10 points each, St. John's Prep continued its unbeaten pace in the Brooklyn Division C.H.S.A.A. basketball race by subduing Bishop Loughlin Memorial High, 37--22, at Loughlin last night. The victory was the eighth straight in the league for, the Redmen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--President Roosevelt announced today that he had approved the purchase in this country of an undesignated number of modern battle planes for France.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27.--Justice William I. Schaffer of the State Supreme Court interrupted argument in a labor case today to remark that "this will cease to be a land of liberty" ii the picketing of plants where employes were not on strike was permitted to continue.

Wholesale buying continued to be active during the week, but retailers appeared to be somewhat more cautious than in the past few weeks, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--Supply contracts valued at $8,645,808 were awarded during the week ended Jan, 21 by nine Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

CLIFFSIDE PARK, N.J., Jan. 27 (AP).--John L. Scullion died in Holy Name Hospital tonight two hours after he had been turned into a human torch by a man who, Police Chief Frank Borrell said, lured the 50-year-old plumber to his home, poured turpentine on him and set him afire.

A merger of the Charity Organization Society and the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, the two largest non-sectarian family welfare organizations of New York City, is under consideration by both organizations, it was announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Lesley E. Bogert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert of 2 East Eightieth Street and Newport, to Francis Taylor, also of Newport, took place and Twenty-ninth Street. The Rev. Willard E. Rice performed the ceremony.
Mr. Harold Nicolson is improving The Spectator notably by writing an article for it every week. An M.P. and a frequent speakes outside the House, he dislikes speeches.

LONDON, Jan. 27.--Britain and France will give financial assistance to Czecho-Slovakia to the extent of 16,000,000 as the result of an agreement reached today. The assistance is partly in return for the suffering endured by CzechoSlovakia during the September crisis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--The Federal Trade Commission announced today that two New York concerns and one in Passaic, N.J., have entered into stipulations to cease misleading representations in the sale of their products.

ST, LOUIS, Jan. 37 (AP).--Archbishop John J. Glennon stated today that he approved the position of St. Louis University and the Rev. Harry B. Crimmins, its president, in dismissing Dr. Moyer Springer Fleisher, head of the bacteriology department of the Medical School.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27.-- Closing with a rush by taking the last four holes, Max B. Kaesche of Ridgewood, N.J., retained his championship by winning from Rodney B. Stuart of Glen Ridge, N. J., in the final of the thirtysecond annual tournament of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests today at the Palm Beach Golf Club. Kaesche's margin was 3 and 2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--The British Government expressed its thanks for the assistance rendered by the United States in connection with the accident to the Imperial Airways flying boat Cavalier on the Bermuda run, through a letter to Secretary of State Hull from V.A. L. Mallet, its charge d'affaires here, which was made public today. The letter follows:

The appearance of two sizable issues lifted the total new bond financing this week to $14,200,000, compared with only $7,418,100 last week, and with $14,874,625 in new bonds during this period a year ago.

A new coffee futures contract replacing the present "A" contract will be submitted to a vote of the members of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on Feb. 28, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange. If approved, trading in the new contract will start on March 1, for delivery in May, 1939, and thereafter.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for two more units in the housing development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on the grounds of the old Catholic Protectory in the Bronx. The two structures will be eight and thirteen stories high and will cost $985,000 and $617,000, respectively.

One of the best-known lodging places on the lower East Side changed hands yesterday when the Mills estate sold the ten-story Mills Hotel, at the northwest corner of Rivington and Chrystie Streets, facing Roosevelt Park.

LONDON, Jan. 27.--Provisional arrangements have been made for a series of heavy shipments of gold to the United States which are hardly to be explained by the recent arbitrage purchases in London, and the inference is that they represent special consignments, possibly Dutch, or of previously earmarked gold.

Musical features of the annual President's Ball on Monday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis were discussed at an informal meeting yesterday afternoon in the Hotel St. Regis suite of Generals Hugh S. Johnson, chairman of the New York committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--A Senate coalition of Democrats and Republicans completed today the revolt of Congress against Administration advice in appropriation of relief funds by approving, 47 to 46, the sum of $725,000,000 voted by the House to finance WPA from Feb. 1 until June 30. President Roosevelt asked for $875,000,000.

On the eve of a nation-wide strike call the American Federation of Radio Artists agreed last night to meet with a newly formed committee empowered to speak for more than 70 per cent of the commercially sponsored network broadcasts and to continue to confer without recess "until a conclusion has been reached."

OTTAWA, Jan. 27.--Prime Minister Mackenzie King told Parliament today that German Nazi activities in Canada had been a subject of special investigation. He added that he would soon make an announcement concerning the results of the inquiry, including the behavior of some German consuls here.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP).-- The super nova, or exploding star, discovered in the Virgo cluster last week, more than trebled in brightness in a week.

Organizations and individuals in the printing trade made plans yesterday to raise a fund for the benefit of Frederic William Goudy, master type designer, whose workshop at Marlboro-on-Hudson was destroyed by fire yesterday with its treasure of original type drawings and equipment.

As the field in the thirteenth annual De Witt Clinton Eastern interscholastic indoor tennis tournament was reduced to the round of sixteen yesterday it became more and more apparent that among the survivors are two stand-outs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury announced tonight that the offering of about $100,000,000 of 1 3/8 per cent notes, Series B, of the United States Housing Authority, made on Thursday morning, had been subscribed nearly twenty-eight times, a new high record for any security offered publicly through the Treasury.

Metallography can hardly mean much to the man in the street. That it has something to do with metals is obvious enough. But what? To explain that the microscope is applied to determine the grain size of metals and relate this to chemical composition, rate of cooling, rolling and forging is only a little more illuminating.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP).-- Rear Admiral Arthur B. Cook, chief of naval aviation, told the House Naval Committee that the pending $65,000,000 naval air base program would give the fleet permanent bases in Alaska and the mid-Pacific for more than 400 longrange patrol planes.

WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 27.-- Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, returned to Berlin today after his short and uneventful visit here with the impression that the Poles, although they have much desire for good relations with Germany, are not prepared to sacrifice the independence of their foreign policy or their alliances with France and Rumania.

Increased Federal funds to extend the programs of local housing authorities to rehouse 1,000,000 families in the next five years was the first of nine planks in the platform adopted yesterday by the eighth annual meeting of the National Public Housing Conference at the Hotel Commodore.

General Franco's troops struck farther out along the coast north and east of Barcelona yesterday, finding no resistance. The inhabitants of the city continued to rejoice over the occupation. Food was scarce, however,

PARIS, Jan. 27.--Pierce C. Fournier, governor of the Bank of France, reviewed today the difficulties surmounted by the bank in the last year at the annual meeting of that institution. He concluded by enumerating many new factors that should permit the stockholders to face the future with confidence.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 27.--Influence of college football on the student mind was termed a disquieting factor in the realm of higher education by Robert M. Ogden, dean of Cornell University and president of the New York State Association of Colleges, at a meeting of the association today.

Undaunted by the turn of events which prevented it from holding an invitation ski jump at Randails Island tomorrow, the Telemark S.C. of Rosendale, N.Y., yesterday announced that the sanctioned event will go on as scheduled. The scene of action, however, will be the towering slide at Bear Mountain Park instead of the Triborough Stadium.

Milton Early Loomis, dean of Washington Square College and Professor of Government at New York University since 1934, was appointed Associate State Commissioner of Education by the State Board of Regents at its monthly meeting yesterday in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.
The 113th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York, oldest veterans organization in the country, was held at the Commodore last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--Department-store sales for the week ended Jan. 21 were unchanged, compared with the corresponding week last year, while sales in the four-week period ended Jan. 21 were 5 per cent below the similar period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

After five days of declining prices, the stock market suddenly reversed its course yesterday and, with little foreign selling to contend with, shares pushed into higher ground. Closing gains, which were sprinkled throughout the list, averaged from 1 to about 3 points.

With less foreign selling pressure than at any previous time this week, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and better support in new crop months left the list with gains of 1 to 11 points.

The singular story of a former cook of the Russian Imperial court who rose to affluence in the United States, later was forced to earn his living by posing as an art school model and ultimately was convicted of soliciting alms and died before sentence could be imposed upon him was unfolded yesterday in Traffic Court before Magistrate Anthony F. Burke.

Two of aviation's highest awards for development and research work were conferred on A.V. de Forest, Professor of Aeronautics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Russell C. Newhouse, engineer, of the Western Electric Company, last night as the Institute of the Aeronatuical Sciences ended its three-day convention with the annual honors night dinner at the Hotel Biltmore.

Anheuser-Busch, Inc., of St. Louis is not a subsidiary of Standard Brands, Inc., as erroneously reported here yesterday, nor is it in any way affiliated or connected with Standards Brands, Inc., by stock ownership or otherwise, according to a statement by Standard Brands, which was concurred in yesterday by representatives of Anheuser-Busch.

TRENTON, Jan. 27.--By a vote of 4 to 1, the Joint Appropriations Committee of the Legislature struck today from Governor Moore's budget an item of $221,906 for the Newark State Teachers College. It was indicated that a similar fate might be in store for the Paterson College.

The Neutrality Act is too rigid in its present form and should be revised along more flexible lines so as "to permit American foreign policy to be shaped by American rather than by foreign authorities," a committee of experts on international law repor ted yesterday to the Committee for Concerted Peace Efforts.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 27.--Representative Bruce Barton, New York City Republican, declared here tonight that, barring a foreign war, the New Deal was waging "a losing tight against an inevitable verdict."

ALBANY, Jan. 27.--A letter from Mayor La Guardia charging "discrimination" against New York State telephone users in the matter. of intrastate rates was disclosed today at a hearing of the Public Service Commission.

Leaders in the furniture and department store fields attended a funeral service yesterday afternoon for Martin Wortmann, president of Ludwig Baumann, who died on Thursday after he accidentally fell eleven stories through an elevator shaft in the department store at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street. He was 59 years old.

Youth Sunday will be observed tomorrow in the Protestant churches. There will be commemorated through the week the fifty-eighth anniversary of the Christian Endeavor movement. In several churches services will be conducted entirely by the young people.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27.--Frederick H. Prince, chairman of the board of Armour , Co., told stockholders today at the annual meeting that 1939 promised to be a better year for the company than was 1938. Operations in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 resulted in a loss of approximately $1,500,000.

Gallup vice president of Young Rubicam, Inc., and director of the Institute of Public Opinion, yesterday told a luncheon meeting of the Export Advertising Association at the Hotel Astor.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Jan. 27.-- This North Shore community fell heir today to several thousand pounds of fresh fish, all efficiently salted and iced. At least 400 residents promptly set out to collect the windfall, bringing into service trucks, automobiles, wheelbarrows, crates, baby carriages and paper bags.
With the visit to the Squadron A Armory tonight of Pennsylvania Military College, metropolitan indoor polo will have its first glimpse of intercollegiate action this season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--Arguments for and against a rehearing of the Black Tom and Kingsland sabotage cases ended today before the Mixed Claims Commission, which now has under advisement the petition of the American claimants that it set aside, with a view to reversal, the decision handed down at Hamburg in 1930 holding the charge of German responsibility "not proven."

BERLIN, Jan. 27.--The negotiations between George Rublee, American chairman of the Intergovernmental Committee on Refugees, and Dr. Helmuth Wohlthat of Germany regarding the evacuation of Jews from this country are progressing satisfactorily, it was announced today.

While the credit reservoir of the country is all set to handle a tremendous business expansion, the indications are that the rise in the average level of industrial production will not exceed 8 to 10 per cent this year, which would be below the 1937 level, Dr. Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, said yesterday.

Observing that "many guilty defendants escape," Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division voted yesterday to dismiss a false imprisonment suit on which James Morgan had been awarded a $3,500 verdict by a jury before Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--Trading by members in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 7 was 23.28 per cent of the total volume, compared with 19.17 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Total volume was 6,375,110 shares sold, compared with 8,459,430 shares in the earlier week.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27.-- Charles S. Howard announced tonight that Seabiscuit would pass up the $10,000 added San Felipe handicap at Santa Anita Park tomorrow, leaving nineteen other contenders to battle it out over the six furlong route in the day's feature attraction.

LONDON, Jan. 27.--A better position of British finances compared with that of 1914 was stressed at the annual meeting of stockholders of Lloyds Bank, one of the "big five" British joint stock banks, in a report by Lord Wardington, its chairman.
Herbert Hartley Ramsay, former president of the United States Golf Association, died yesterday afternoon at Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 52.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27.--Manhattan College's basketball team, paced by rugged Jim Sarullo, defeated St. Joseph's at Convention Hall tonight, 42--37, before a crowd of 5,000 fans.

Christian leaders from five foreign countries will address the World Christian Fellowship Dinner which will be held in the Hotel Astor on Feb. 14. The dinner will close World Christianity Days, the first of which will be observed here on Feb. 12.
ALBANY, Jan. 27.--Governor Lehman moved today to minimize the effectiveness of the proposed legislative investigation of the administration of the Unemployment Insurance Law.

After deducting $524,928 of preferred dividends, the result was equivalent to $1.95 each on 1,316,710 shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--The Lea bill for coordinated regulation of all forms of domestic transportation by the Interstate Commerce Commission raises the question of what to do about labor displaced by railroad consolidations but does not attempt to answer that question, Walter M.W. Splawn, a member of the I.C.C., told the House Interstate Commerce Committee today in his fourth and last day before it.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27.--Drawing a line between large and small employers, Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry ruled here today that a business employing only three men should be free "to choose employes from the open labor market, union or non-union."

PERPIGNAN, France, Jan. 27.-- The Spanish war is going on; the Catalan army is establishing new lines, the rear is being organized and the government already is functioning at Figueras. Premier Juan Negrin told me this today with all the emphasis he could command. Barcelona is lost; the new capital of Loyalist Spain is Figueras.

A group including Lehman Brothers, B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc.; Paine, Webber Co., and Morse Bros. Co., Inc., purchased yesterday $823,000 of Harrison, N.J., general refunding bonds, as 2 s on a bid of 100.88, the highest of seven bids.

Showing a mastery of the game that his opponent could not match, Joe Chamaco yesterday swept through both his matches with Allen Hall at the Fourteenth Street Billiard Academy in the threecushion championship tourney that is being conducted in various cities.

DOORN, The Netherlands, Jan. 27 (AP).--Former Kaiser Wilhelm II, Germany's one-time "all highest," wearing a dazzling white uniform with gold braid, celebrated his eightieth birthday with a gala dinner tonight.

Long Island University continued unbeaten and St. John's stumbled to its first defeat of the season in the basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

LONDON, Jan. 27.--Admiral of the Fleet Lord Chatfield, who built up the British Navy to its present peak of efficiency and power, is expected to be appointed tomorrow to the Cabinet post of Minister for the Coordination of Defense.

UNION CITY, N.J., Jan. 27.-- Joseph Saluto, a barber, who was described by police as a "mental case," slashed the throat and critically injured his crippled 20-yearold son, Leo, and then killed himself with a razor in their home at 407 Bergenline Avenue here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28.--Old-age pensions, according to Mrs. Sheridan Downey, wife of the new Senator from California, should not be emphasized to such an extent that efforts to help other classes of needy (including children), raise wages, and create employment are minimized.

OCONOMOWOC, Wis., Jan. 28 (AP).--Two national speed skating records were bettered today as a brilliant field, led by Miss Madeline (Maddy) Horn of Beaver Dam, competed in the first day's events of the Great Lakes open tournament on the Fowler Lake ice. Two meet records also were broken.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 28.--Dutch selling of international securities has not assumed dimensions so large as has been intimated in some foreign quarters.

MIAMI, Jan. 29.--The "psychological" atmosphere surrounding the prospects for peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organization has changed for the bet ter, according to William Green, president of the A.F. of L., who arrived here today for the opening of the Winter sessions of the executive council tomorrow.

Declaring that the city faces a $30,000,000 deficit in the 1939-40 budget now in preparation and that the "plain solution is retrenchment," Peter Grimm, acting chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, called on Mayor La Guardia and the administration yesterday to "get out the steam shovels and dig up economies."

After twelve years' absence from the repertoire, Massenet's "Thais" will be revived during the twelfth week of the Metropolitan Opera season, beginning next Monday. That week also will see the first performance this season of Wagner's "Das Rheingold," the debut of Douglas Beattie, American bass, and the return of Jan Kiepura and Armand Tokatyan, tenors.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29.--Dr. Francis Vincent Corcoran, rector of the Los Angeles Junior Seminary since 1936 and former president of De Paul University in Chicago, died of a heart attack last night in St. Vincent's Hospital. His age was 59.

Two string quartets by Haydn and as many of the Bach sonatas for viola da gamba and harpsichord formed the program offered by the New Friends of Music at the thirteenth concert of its current series, given late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

Bill Allum, star defense man, filled the hero's role at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. He notched a goal with 30 seconds left to play, enabling the New York Rovers to defeat the Port Colborne Sailors of the Ontario Hockey Association, 4--3, in the feature clash of an amaxeur double-header.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 29 (AP)--Tommy Smith of Utica today captured the men's New York State speed skating championship, defeating Joe Bree of New York City, the defending titleholder, by 40 points.

ROME, Jan. 29.--Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech of last night has been very warmly received in Rome, where it is hailed as a powerful contribution to the campaign started here two months ago for the satisfaction of Italy's "natural aspirations."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--Despite the armaments race exports of iron and steel from this country in 1938 fell by more than a third both in quantity, and value, as compared ...
DETROIT, Jan. 29 (AP).--The Detroit Red Wings came from behind twice tonight to gain a 2-to-2 deadlock with the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29.--Salo Flohr of Czecho-Slovakia strengthened his hold on first place in the international chess masters tournament today, defeating P. Romanovski in their adjourned game from the seventh round. Flohr's score was increased to 11--4, well ahead of the field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--Charles R. Hook, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers, assailed the National Labor Relations Act at the American Forum of the Air here tonight as biased in favor of organized labor and urged a five-point amendment program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--An opinion that Jewish efforts on behalf of Palestine must be redoubled, whatever other projects might be considered for Jewish colonization growing out of Nazi persecution, was voiced today by Henry Monsky, president of B'nai B'rith, in a report delivered to the annual meeting of the society's executive committee here.

Against the growing insistence that the part of the relief program now being conducted by the Federal Government should be turned over to local control, those who wish to preserve the present system have recently advanced the contention that local administration of relief is impracticable.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29.-- Peggy Shannon has been signed by RKO to replace Lucille Ball in the feminine lead opposite Lee Tracy in "What's a Fixer For," which Lew Landers will direct.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 29.-- Professor Will S. Monroe, educator and author, died today in a hospital here at the age of 75. He was stricken five days ago with a cerebral hemorrhage at his Couching Lion Farm, near Camels Hump Mountain, which had been his home since his retirement in 1925.

At the age of 36, Martin Thomas Manton was appointed a judge of the United States District Court in the Southern District of New York by President Wilson in 1916. At that time he was the youngest Federal judge in the United States and already had behind him a distinguished career at the criminal bar and in the practice of admiralty law in the Federal courts.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 29 (AP).--Aubrey (Bucky) Wells, daredevil driver of Keene Valley, N.Y., today suffered his first defeat in major bobsled competition in two years as Francis Tyler piloted his Sno Birds to a one-second victory in the four-man race for the Governor Lehman Trophy.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29.--The new labor truancy law, ordering the summary dismissal of any employe twenty minutes or more late and the criminal prosecution of any executive who fails to discharge such a truant, is meeting with some overt resistance.

Five regional architectural competitions designed to aid families of small incomes in solving their housing problems were announced yesterday by the Productive Home Architural Competition, a non-commercial organization with offices in 381 Fourth Avenue. The contest will cover the entire country and awards will total $10,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 29.--Declaring that drastic measures must be taken to stop the spread of rabies, Dr. Charles V. Craster, Newark Health Officer, proposed today that all dogs in the city, estimated at 25,000, be "gotten rid of."

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, L.F. Sanman took the high-overall scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The handicap winner in Class A was E. Hughes, who had 100 full targets.

DEL MAR., Calif., Jan. 29.--Ringing down the curtain on California's Winter golf season, E.J. (Dutch) Harrison of Chicago captured his first major tournament today--the $3,000 pro-amateur event staged by Bing Crosby.

PERPIGNAN, France, Jan. 29-- The French Government rushed additional troops to the Pyrenees border today to enforce its order to turn back all Spanish Government soldiers among the flood of refugees streaming into France.

Soviet Russia's greetings to the American people and to the World's Fair were voiced by Mikhail Kalinin, chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, in an address broadcast yesterday afternoon from Moscow.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 29-- Three young scientists have produced a totally new type of radio which may speed television development, give aviation a formidable "lifesaver" and revolutionize the whole field of ultra-short-wave transmission.
Support of the Catholic press as "the voice of truth" was urged yesterday by the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

PARIS, Jan. 29.--On the eve of Chancellor Hitler's speech and after the definition of the French position by Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet last Thursday and of that of Britain by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain yesterday, the Temps this evening sums up the situation and outlook as follows:
PARIS, Jan. 29.--A project for an outright military alliance between Japan, Germany and Italy was reported today to have been shelved "temporarily" by a conference of six Japanese diplomats in Paris.
ROME, Jan. 29.--If a fair plebiscite were held in Italy on the government's policy toward Jews the popular vote would be about 89 per cent against it.

It is beginning to appear that Nelson Benedict's "busman's holiday" is going to last as long as the fishing continues to be exciting in the immediate vicinity of Stuart, Fla. We had a letter from him yesterday, and he reports that the difficulty there is keeping from taking more fish than you can handle.
Banks are endeavoring to adapt themselves to the changed conditions under which banking must operate now because of altered business habits and a changed political ...

Using fire boats and land equipment in a four-hour battle during which six were injured, firemen subdued a blaze in a brick building at 322-326 East 103d Street, between First and Second Avenues, yesterday morning.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, admonished members of his parish yesterday to abstain from alcohol and tobacco and to forego entertainments "not calculated to foster high virtue" during the coming season of Lent, which begins this year on Washington's Birthday, Feb. 22.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--A letter to President Roosevelt urging him to place lawyers working for the Federal Government under the Civil Service was made public today by the National Lawyers Guild, of which Justice Ferdinand Pecora of the New York Supreme Court is president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--Accompanied by Mrs. Roosevelt, President Roosevelt motored to the National Theatre tonight and attended a special showing of Sutton Vane's "Outward Bound," which marked the opening of another annual drive for funds to fight infantile paralysis.

DETROIT, Jan. 29.--Two rival "presidents" of the United Automobile Workers, a C.I.O. affiliate, appeared on the same speaking platform today and matched accusations and claims in an effort to win rank and file support for their respective factions.

DETROIT, Jan. 29 (AP).--The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin said today that "sane Americans will not subscribe to a proposition of hurtling this nation into war for the internal, religious or racial difficulties extant in another nation."

IN a small town in France, about 1930 Pierre van Paassen saw a big black dog. He saw it once, twice, three times, four times--perhaps six or eight times altogether. Each time it pattered along the floor audibly. It would stop at a whistle and turn around, wagging its tail. Then it would begin to fade, grow fainter and fainter, and finally vanish like the cat in Lewis Carroll.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 28.--The Bourse here last week experienced an almost continuous fall in prices except on Thursday, when a slight recovery movement developed.

The charge that Vice President Garner is an "Aaron Burr" to President Roosevelt was made by Representative Vito Marcantonio before a cheering audience of 3,000 at an anti-Nazi meeting at the Hippodrome yesterday.

Urging a more complete understanding and firmer relationship between the Christian ministry and medicine, the Rev. Worcester Perkins described them yesterday morning as "the two great professions consecrated to the fulfillment of the highest ideals of mankind without thought of reward."
CHICAGO, Jan. 29.--Prices of corn futures on the Board of Trade here held close last week to the lowest levels in about two months.

ADAMS, Mass., Jan. 29 (AP)-- Speeding down the breakneck Thunderbolt run on Mount Greylock in a heavy snowstorm, Ted Hunter, former Dartmouth College Ski captain, today captured the Massachusetts downhill ski championship.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Jan. 29.--A bill to be introduced by Representative Sleeper of Rockland to outlaw the mixing of clams and tomatoes is heightening interest in Maine clam chowder, according to Arthur R. Greenleaf, Sea and Shore Fisheries Commissioner.

Hitler is to speak today in the German Reichstag, and the forecasts of his address which have come from sources apparently primed by official inspiration indicate that he will back Mussolini's claims for "fulfillment of Italian rights" in the Mediterranean. But even if these forecasts are correct, it remains to be seen how far he will go and how specific he will be.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--The Treasury Department today began the publication of a new monthly statistical Bulletin containing much data hitherto kept private and cutting in two the time lag in reporting capital movements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--Expansion of children's welfare work in the last year was reported to Miss Perkins today by Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 29.--Continued tremors in Chile's earthquake zone caused the government to give out a reassuring statement today. In response to many requests for information, the Meteorological Bureau stated that rumors of a possible repetition of last Tuesday's quake were without foundation.
HAVANA, Jan. 29 (AP).--Florian II, a consistent performer here this year, galloped to a two-length victory in the Matanzas Handicap, feature race of the program at Oriental Park today.
The Boston player, H. Sherman Howes Jr. of the Union Boat Club, triumphed in the final of the third annual invitation squash racquets tournament of the Union Club yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP).--Edward W. Smithers, chief of communications at the White House, died today of a heart attack. His age was 69.

A benefit theatre party will be given at Friday night's performance of Oscar Wilde's comedy, "The Importance of Being Earnest," starring Clifton Webb, Hope Williams and Estelle Winwood, at the Vanderbilt Theatre. Proceeds will aid the activities of the Bryn Mawr Summer School for Women Workers in Industry.

Experimental installation of television equipment in one of the nine operating rooms at Israel Zion Hospital, 4,810 Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn, to enable medical students in the galleries to observe surgical technique more closely was announced yesterday by Boris Fingerhood, superintendent of the hospital.
With her rosary beads in her hand, Delia Kelly, 60 years old, cook for J. Augustus Barnard of 129 East Seventy-first Street, was ...
PARIS, Jan. 29.--The price movement on the Bourse here continued downward last week, Friday's prices being the week's lowest, although there were never any signs ...
Satisfactory buying activity was reported last week in the various divisions of the New York wholesale market.

New York won the intercity Class B squash racquets trophy yesterday at the University Club by defeating Philadelphia, 4 to 3. On Saturday, the New York players turned back Boston, last year's victor, also by 4 to 3.
Fourteen veterans of the Grand Army of the Republic were entertained yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania by members of five allied organizations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 29.--Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha sailed for the United States tonight on the liner Nieuw Amsterdam for Washington conferences in response to President Roosevelt's invitation.

The religious life of America "needs a baptism of deep mysticism," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, the paster, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fiftyseventh Street.
The Boston Bruins cemented their hold on first place in the National Hockey League by defeating the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night.

President Roosevelt was announced last night as the recipient of the second annual award of the National Council of Young Israel at the twenty-seventh annual Youth Foundation dinner at the Hotel Commodore.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 29.-- Florida's $1,400,000 racing experiment, brand new Gulfstream Park, will set machinery in motion tomorrow for a forty-day meeting by accepting entries for Wednesday's Inaugural Handicap.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 30.-- Efforts to purge the economic faculty of the Tokyo Imperial University of liberal and nationalist elements has ended in complete disruption of the faculty by the resignation of Professor Fumio Yamada, the dismissal of Professor Eijiro Kawai, a liberal, and Professor Seibi Hijikata, a nationalist, and the resignation of nine others with nationalist sympathies.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 29.--Torger Tokle, the 19-year-old sensation who arrived from Norway eight days ago and lost no time in displaying his talents the next afternoon, returned to this skiing paradise today and thrilled a gathering of 10,000 enthusiasts with a record-breaking performance.
Elmer A. Rogers, attorney, represented the buyer in the purchase of the Mills Hotel in Rivington Street.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 29.-- Robert Carr Lanphier Sr., president and founder of the Sangamo Electrict Company, died at his home last night after a long illness. He was 61 years old last Wednesday.
Prices of cotton moved irregularly last week. At the close on Saturday active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 1 to 12 points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)--The Administration intends to ask Congress for authority to give to growers more than 4,000,000 bales of the cotton now sealed in warehouses under government loans, it was learned today.

Long Island University remained the only unbeaten team in metropolitan intercollegiate basketball circles as St. John's nine-game string of victories came to an end Friday. The ten-game streak of St. Francis, which was beaten in its opening game, was stopped on Saturday.

The Raritan Valley Country Club and the Montclair Athletic Club registered shut-out victories to provide the features of yesterday's New Jersey Division Metropolitan Squash Racquets League Class B team play. Raritan Valley triumphed at home over the Plainfield Country Club, while Montclair blanked the Racquets Club at Short Hills, 5 to 0.

Fresh from the unusual success of his production of "Hamlet" in its entirety, Maurice Evans presents tonight another Shakespeare work, "Henry IV," Part 1, in which he will portray Falstaff as a gentleman and not, he says, as "a bloated old drunk."
BOSTON, Jan. 29.--If any miler is going to stop Glenn Cunningham this year he will have to use as elephant gun. No one is going to check the Kansan's winning streak any other way.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 29-- Glenn S. (Pop) Warner said tonight that he had sent a special delivery letter to Temple University yesterday tendering his resignation as head football coach.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 29. --Units of the United States Fleet during the past week have taken up stations in a wide area commending the South Atlantic and the Caribbean, completing the first movement of the extensive Winter manoeuvres to test the navy's defenses of the long eastern coastline.
SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Jan. 29 (AP).--James J. Warren, Canadian banker and industrialist, died last night at his Winter home here at the age of 68. Death followed a heart attack of short duration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.--The Chamber of Commerce of the United States charged in a statement tonight that the 65,000,000 insurees in this country paid $103,281,169 in "hidden" taxes in 1937 in the form of special State levies on insurance companies. This figure, it said, excludes taxes that they pay in common with other businesses.

Agitations over social and economic changes should not occupy too much of the attention of church members, the Rev. Rowland H. Kimberlin of the Fort Hamilton Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, warned in the first of a sermon series yesterday morning.

In an effort to answer the old question of why race horses in this country do not endure like those in England, Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope of the New York State Racing Commission compiled some statistics, released yesterday, to show the difference in the racing of horses here and abroad.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Jan. 30.-- Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr., of Apa warnis, four times metropolitan champion, led a field of twenty-one contestants into the quarter-finals of the eighth annual women's New York State squash racquets ...

Wall Street felt that Chancellor Hitler's speech before the Reichstag yesterday was much milder than had been expected. His assurance that Germany had no designs on The Netherlands certainly was a main factor in helping the Dutch guilder to regain some of the heavy losses it suffered last...

Commissioner of Markets William Fellowes Morgan Jr. last night pledged his aid in building a public market on the lower West Side to replace the condemned Paddy's Market if he is convinced that future business will amortize the project within a reasonable time.

Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Lewis yesterday approved an offer of the Sanford Hotel Corporation, headed by Craig La Vin of New Haven, Conn., to purchase from the Brooklyn Trust Company, trustee for owners of certificates in Bond and Mortgage Guaranty Company issue 180,231, the six-story Hotel Sanford, in Flushing, Queens.

Directors of the Emsco Derrick and Equipment Company voted yesterday to pass the quarterly dividend of 15 cents on the common stock due at this time. The last payment was 15 cents on Nov. 25, 1938. The directors explained that in view of present business conditions dividend action at this time was not considered advisable.
OTTAWA, Jan. 30.--Prime Minister Mackenzie King intimated in Parliament today that Canada would not throw her doors wide open to political refugees, but would deal with special cases on their merits.
MONTREAL, Jan. 30 (Canadian Press).--Tommy Anderson, one of the "old men of Manhattan" who help make up Red Dutton's New York Americans, has climbed to the top of the National Hockey League scorers.
Banks and trust companies figured in several of the Manhattan realty deals announced yesterday, when a number of tenement properties passed into the hands of new owners.

The stock market was strong from the outset yesterday and closed with net gains of 1 to 5 points in quiet trading. Sentiment at the start was helped by the strength displayed by the principal European stock markets and by the fact that foreign selling...

The entry of Archie San Romani was received yesterday by Director Fred Schmertz for the Millrose A. A. track carnival at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, and Ambling Archie was promptly placed in the field for the Wanamaker Mile. That brought an end to San Romani's charges of "freeze...

Scoring their second victory in as many days, the New York Rovers remained far in front in the race for the Eastern Hockey League title by downing the Baltimore Orioles, 4 to 2, in the star contest of an amateur double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

DUBLIN, Jan. 30.--The death of Ireland's greatest modern poet, William Butler Yeats, was deeply mourned in every part of Ireland today, and strenuous efforts were being made to have his body brought here from Roguebrunet, near Mentone, France, for a great national funeral.
Apparel dealers and firms in allied lines were prominent in the leasing activity reported yesterday by brokers. Full-floor rentals accounted for a number of the transactions.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 30.--Testimony that the city of Newark was offered a tract of land in the Port Newark for $16,000 early in 1935 for which it moved to pay $190,000 more than a year later was introduced today at the meadow-land conspiracy trial.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today purchased "They Call It Glamour" by John Larkin and Jerry Horwin as a vehicle for Robert Taylor and Hedy Lamarr. The picture, dealing with the lives of professional advertising models, will go before the cameras late this Spring after Miss Lamarr completes "I Take This Woman," currently idle.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (AP).-- A pioneer step that may lead to changes in golf courses throughout the country will be taken at the national open championship in June.
