Although legislation enacted in Albany last year gives the city the power to demolish vacant and outmoded buildings, the Department of Housing and Buildings is reported to have been hampered in carrying out the provisions of this law in some cases, by "red tape"...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The news of the resignation of United States Circuit Court Judge Martin T. Manton in New York was received here this afternoon by Representative Hatton W. Sumners, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, who said no investigation...

While he was being buried in a Queens cemetery yesterday George Weinberg continued a living man to the jurors hearing the second trial of James J. Hines on charges of being a part of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer's policy racket.
The Yankees' rush to sign contracts for 1939 continued yesterday at a pace that was highly pleasing to the club's new president, Edward Grant Barrow.

CHUNGKING, China, Tuesday, Jan. 31.--A long manifesto issued yesterday marked the conclusion of the fifth plenary session of the Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang [Government party], which had been meeting here for the last week. Strict censorship of news reports regarding the session was lifted today.

The city of San Francisco, Calif., will be in the market on Feb. 6 with a new issue of $650,000 airport bonds, for which bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent. The bonds are to be dated Jan. 1, 1939, and are to mature serially on Jan. 1, 1940 to 1949.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company has filed a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission contending that its modified plan is the only one that has been devised during the six years of the proceedings upon which there has been any kind of general agreement among the parties concerned.
BERLIN, Jan. 30 (AP).--The of ficial translation of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's address tonight was in part as follows:

Operations last year of the Atlas Powder Company resulted in a net income of $1,013,056, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $2.69 each on 249,163 shares of no-par common stock, according to the annual report for 1938, issued for publication today.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Dater gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Jean Joers and Newell Childs, whose marriage will take place Friday in St. Thomas Church. Among the other guests were the Misses Suzanne Robbins, Nancy Miller and Eleanor Mullally, C. Alan Hudson Jr., William Colburn, William Tupper, Douglas Owens and Equen B. Meader.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey has enhanced his political prestige by his investigation of Judge Martin T. Manton and the subsequent resignation of the jurist, Republican leaders said today.

DELHI, India, Jan. 30.--The reelection of Subhas Chandra Bose yesterday as president of the Congress party reveals the growing strength of Left-wing elements within the party and emphasizes the deepening discontent against the higher hierarchy of the organization, which under the aegis of Mohandas K. Gandhi has controlled Congress affairs in recent years.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30.--The name of Fred Swan, former Stanford football star and for the last six years, assistant to Glenn S. (Pop) Warner, was mentioned most prominently today in speculation on the successor to the "Old Fox" as head football coach at Temple University.

ALBANY, Jan. 30.--Governor Lehman's budget, as submitted tonight to the Legislature, has left open for probable heated discussion in the next few weeks the question of relief financing. His program is regarded in informed quarters as the opening of the battle rather than the final gun.

THE hockey situation has become so complicated that this puzzled observer determined to see a lawyer about it. Just by luck Professor Moe Berg was encountered in conversation with a literary gent, Mr. Percy Waxman, who used to commit a great quantity of light verse, but is now leading a better life and sticking to prose.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--One of the largest throngs that ever visited the chamber of the Supreme Court heard Felix Frankfurter take the oath of office today as an associate justice, and swear in firm, clear words to "administer justice without respect to person."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The same Democratic-Republican coalition which administered to President Roosevelt his first defeat of the session on the matter of the supplemental WPA appropriation was rising in the offing today to threaten the Administration leadership on other questions soon to come before Congress.

HAVANA, Jan. 30.--The American yacht Chuckle III, sailed by Harold Halsted of Moriches Bay, today won the first race in the thirteenth international Star Class series for the Cup of Cuba, covering the ten-mile course in 1:26:53. Carl Pflug crewed on the winning craft.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in its annual report sent to Congress today gave a detailed summary of the nation's banking system as it is today and, without making definite recommendations, presented its ...

With persons close to the inner councils of both major political parties in agreement that the political fortunes of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey would profit by the resignation of Federal Judge Martin T. Manton, speculation was rife yesterday over Judge Manton's probable successor.

PARIS, Jan. 30.--Creed opened his Summer Fashion showing with a flattering mode, both feminine and tailored. He is featuring an extremely youthful silhouette with skirts 17 inches off the floor, some shortened even more by being cut up at the front and back hem.

"INSIDE GERMANY" is hardly what could be called a disinterested and nonpartisan re port on German affairs, but it carries considerable weight nevertheless, for the author is Albert Grzesinski, former Prussian Minister of the Interior and Police President of Berlin. It is an account of personal experiences in the days of the Republic and an analysis, from an exile's point of view, of conditions since the accession of Hitler.

The President's Birthday Ball, in aid of the New York Infantile Paralysis Fund, was held in the flag-decked grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The celebration, based on the theme of Americanism, was featured by a spectacular military pageant and a diversified program of entertainment.

The zone defense is a violation of the fundamental principles of basketball, it was charged yesterday by Dr. James Naismith, venerable inventor of the sport, in a denunciation of some modern trends of the game before the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln.
